site_title: Olam's executive director A Shekhar steps down from post to focus on Olam Food Ingredients
summary: Olam International's executive director A Shekhar is stepping down to focus on his role as CEO of Olam Food Ingredients (OFI), the company's food ingredients arm. Olam is seeking shareholders' approval to carve out and list OFI through a scheme arrangement, with plans for an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange by the first half of 2022.

site_title: Apple and Google are big; they are not conglomerates
summary: The article argues that the "end" of conglomerates, as predicted by business commentators in 2021, is not the case. Instead, large corporations have always diversified into various fields, but with a subtle relationship between the different pieces. In the post-war era, conglomerates arose as a response to government scrutiny, with companies acquiring unrelated businesses to avoid antitrust laws. The article cites examples of iconic conglomerates like Textron and ITT, which relied on financial legerdemain and endless acquisition to grow. Today's tech giants, such as Apple and Google, also exhibit a similar logic in their acquisitions, with each piece working together to form a cohesive whole.

site_title: China's December factory activity edges up despite virus outbreaks
summary: China's factory activity unexpectedly accelerated in December, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 50.3 from 50.1 in November. The economy has lost momentum since the summer amid disruptions from Covid-19 outbreaks and a slowing manufacturing sector. New export orders shrank further, and production remained in positive territory. Analysts expect a further slowdown in fourth-quarter GDP growth, and policymakers may roll out targeted stimulus packages to support the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong says Omicron variant has spread despite Covid restrictions
summary: Hong Kong authorities have reported cases of Omicron coronavirus variant infection in the community, marking the first local cases in nearly three months. The cases were linked to a breach of home quarantine rules by an air crew member who visited a restaurant, infecting his father and a client. This marks a significant shift from Hong Kong's previous record of no community-transmitted cases since October. The discovery highlights the challenges in controlling the spread of the Omicron variant despite strict Covid restrictions in place.

site_title: Koh Brothers unit, Oiltek, lodges prospectus for Catalist IPO
summary: Oiltek International, a subsidiary of Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, has lodged a preliminary offer document for an initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist-board of the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company aims to raise funds to expand into new and existing markets, particularly in South Asia, Africa, and Latin America, and increase its focus on the renewable energy sector. Revenue rose 13.2% to RM47.2 million in the half-year ended June 30, 2021, but net profit fell 11.2% to RM4.4 million. The company plans to distribute dividends not less than 40% of its net profits in FY2022 and FY2023.

site_title: Huawei says 2021 revenues down almost 30%, sees challenges ahead
summary: Huawei reported 2021 revenues of 634 billion yuan (S$134.4 billion), a 28.9% decline from 2020, due to US sanctions and weaker domestic consumption. The company expects continued challenges in 2022, citing an unpredictable business environment and growing deglobalisation. Despite this, rotating chairman Guo Ping expressed satisfaction with Huawei's 2021 business performance. The company will focus on information and communications technology infrastructure and smart devices, sticking to its strategy despite external pressures.

site_title: Gemini's former APAC execs to start new Singapore-based crypto venture
summary: Gemini's former Asia Pacific executives, Jeremy Ng and Eugene Ng, are launching a new Singapore-based cryptocurrency venture. The duo, who left Gemini in 2021 and 2022, respectively, will share more details on the project by the end of Q1 2022. Eugene Ng stated that "many parties" are involved in the venture, hinting at potential partnerships or investments. The exact nature and scope of the new venture remain unclear, but it is expected to be a significant development in the Singaporean cryptocurrency market.

images.alt_text: Gemini's ex-Asia Pacific head Jeremy Ng (pictured) and former head of business development for the region Eugene Ng have left the US cryptocurrency bourse and will launch their own crypto venture. ST PHOTO: JASON QUAH

site_title: Japan to help build Bill Gates' high-tech nuclear reactor in Wyoming: Yomiuri
summary: Japan's Japan Atomic Energy Agency (JAEA) and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries are set to collaborate with Bill Gates' TerraPower to build a high-tech nuclear reactor in Wyoming. The US government will provide $2 billion in funding, with the project expected to be completed by 2028. The reactor, known as Natrium, will utilize Japan's advanced reactor technology and data. This move aims to counter China and Russia's advancements in nuclear energy, following Japan's own past struggles with nuclear decommissioning.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while in Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, and London's Heathrow considered increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Digital priorities in the new normal
summary: Businesses in the Asia-Pacific region are poised to grow their digital transformation efforts in 2022, with a majority of enterprises increasing their IT budgets and prioritizing cloud computing, security, and digital workspaces. A recent study by ComputerWeekly found that nearly two-thirds of respondents plan to boost their IT investments, while only 6% plan to spend less. The region's cloud spending is expected to reach $200 billion by 2024, driven by a shift towards cloudification across all layers of the technology stack.

images.alt_text: Germany's SAP said on Sunday it was buying Qualtrics International Inc for US$8 billion in cash, pre-empting a planned stock market listing by the US-based company that specialises in surveying consumers online.

site_title: Hong Kong is increasingly shut off as inbound flights drop
summary: Hong Kong is experiencing a decline in inbound flights due to its strict Covid-19 policies, with Cathay Pacific Airways reducing flights by almost half. The airline has scheduled 150 inbound services in January, the lowest monthly total since May. Authorities have imposed tough quarantine restrictions, requiring overseas visitors to quarantine for up to three weeks. This has led to a significant decrease in flights to Hong Kong, with British Airways scrapping flights until March. In contrast, Singapore has struck agreements for quarantine-free air travel with over 20 countries, with airlines scheduled to operate 4,370 services in January.

site_title: The MIT professor defining what it means to live
summary: A living wage, defined as enough to secure a normal standard of living, including education, recreation, and savings for old age, has been a long-standing moral and economic claim. Theodore Roosevelt introduced the concept in 1912, and Amy Glasmeier's living wage calculator, widely cited, estimates the wage based on household size, housing costs, and other expenses. However, the calculator omits certain expenses, and critics argue that a living wage should include more than just basic necessities. The US has seen stagnant real wages, with the average top CEO making 351 times more than a typical worker in 2020.

site_title: Arkhouse Partners nominates directors to Preferred Apartment Communities board: sources
summary: Arkhouse Partners has nominated 5 directors to Preferred Apartment Communities' board, aiming to oust the majority of the 8-member board. The nominations were made privately, and the size and timing of Arkhouse's investment in Preferred Apartment Communities are unknown. This move is part of Arkhouse's effort to gain control of the real estate investment company's board.

site_title: 'We ran the Polar Circle half-marathon on a whim'
summary: Wong Su-Yen and Fermin Diez, a Singaporean couple, completed the Polar Circle Marathon, considered the "coolest marathon on Earth," in Greenland. They started running 3 times a week in 2019 to prepare for a trek to Everest Base Camp and eventually completed a half-marathon. Inspired by the challenge, they signed up for the Polar Circle Marathon at the last minute. Despite icy conditions and their inexperience, they persevered and finished the 42km course in 4 hours, earning medals and a lifetime experience.

site_title: In 2022, let's be more positive and less negative
summary: A columnist reflects on the natural tendency to focus on negativity, citing the cognitive bias known as negativity bias, which favors bad stimuli over good. This bias is rooted in evolution, as ancestors who focused on potential threats had a better chance of survival. However, this bias can lead to lost harmony, happiness, and health in personal and public discourse. The columnist proposes awareness, mindfulness, and intentional dwelling on positive stimuli to adjust the bias, and invites readers to join him in managing his own negativity bias in 2022.

site_title: Gold marks yearly dip as central banks seek to wean economy off stimulus
summary: Gold prices marked their biggest yearly decline since 2015, falling 4% in 2021, amid a resurgent dollar and investors' shift towards riskier assets. Central banks' plans to tighten monetary policy, driven by the threat of Omicron and transitory inflation, also contributed to the decline. Despite potential catalysts for gains, including a Fed policy mistake or geopolitical tensions, gold may face a "downhill battle" due to higher interest rates and yields.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, ComfortDelGro, The Hour Glass, Asia Vets, Alset
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies made significant announcements on Dec 31, affecting trading of their securities. ComfortDelGro and The Hour Glass will redesignate independent directors as non-independent directors starting Jan 1, 2022. Keppel will also redesignate its independent chairman. Asia Vets entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire fintech company Aldigi, resulting in a potential reverse takeover. Asia Vets shares resumed trading on Friday after a trading halt. The changes come after Singapore Exchange Listing Rules introduced a hard term limit of 9 years for independent directors.

site_title: Hanwell Holdings acquires 80 per cent stake in CKH Food Trading and 123 Mart for S$3.3m
summary: Hanwell Holdings acquired an 80% stake in CKH Food Trading and 123 Mart for S$3.3 million, with the deal set to take effect on January 1, 2022. CKH Food Trading supplies food products to 1,500 establishments in Singapore, while 123 Mart is a grocery minimart. The acquisition will allow Hanwell to tap into CKH's network and cross-sell its products, with CEO Henry Chu stating that it will enable the company to achieve greater economies of scale and accelerate growth in the segments.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust, Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust propose merger
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) have proposed a merger to become Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT), one of Asia's 10 largest real estate investment trusts (Reits). The merged entity will have a theoretical market capitalization of approximately S$10.5 billion and a combined portfolio of 18 commercial assets across Singapore, China, Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea. The merger, expected to be completed in mid-June 2022, will dilute MCT's concentration in Singapore to just over half of the enlarged portfolio, with Hong Kong accounting for 26%.

site_title: Creativity is the X-factor that sets you apart as an investor
summary: A study by David Gill and Victoria L Prowse found that cognitive skills, such as analytical and logical thinking, are key traits for investors. However, another trait, creativity, also sets successful investors apart. Creative individuals are more likely to excel in technical and managerial positions and have higher lifetime earnings. Unlike diligence, which can be outsourced, creativity is essential for differentiating oneself and outperforming others in the investment world. According to Howard Marks, true creativity involves seeing data and markets differently and forming novel insights, rather than just tinkering with existing approaches.

site_title: Sovereign wealth fund, public pension fund assets hit record US$31.9t
summary: Sovereign wealth and public pension funds reached a record US$31.9 trillion in assets in 2021, driven by rising US stock and oil prices and investments. Assets managed by sovereign wealth funds rose 6% to US$10.5 trillion, while those of public pension funds jumped 9% to US$21.4 trillion. State-owned investors deployed US$215.6 billion, with Singapore's GIC leading the way. Emerging markets received only 23% of the capital, and venture capital investments grew by 80% to US$18.2 billion, with a focus on healthcare, retail, and technology sectors.

site_title: World to ring in New Year under Covid cloud
summary: The world welcomed 2022 amidst the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with new restrictions, soaring case numbers, and a slight glimmer of hope for better times ahead. Over 5.4 million people have died since the virus was first reported in 2019. New variants, including Omicron, have pushed daily cases past one million, prompting cancellations and curtails of New Year's Eve celebrations worldwide. Despite this, some countries, like Brazil and South Africa, have lifted restrictions, and experts hope 2022 may mark a new, less deadly phase of the pandemic.

site_title: Sanction-hit Huawei says 2021 revenues down 29%
summary: Huawei's annual revenue fell 29% to 634 billion yuan in 2021, mainly due to US sanctions that hurt its smartphone sales. The company's telecom carrier segment remained stable, and it expects to round off the year with the same revenue. Despite challenges, Huawei's rotating chairman Guo Ping said the company is on a "bumpy but rewarding" road and is pivoting into new business lines. The US has barred Huawei from acquiring crucial components and forced it to create its own operating system.

site_title: Cathay cargo halt to hit Hong Kong prices, SCMP reports
summary: Hong Kong consumers will face higher prices for fresh produce, daily necessities, and electrical goods due to Cathay Pacific's long-haul cargo flight halt. Shipping costs are expected to surge 30% over the next 2-3 weeks, which will be passed on to consumers. This will lead to food and product shortages, particularly for seafood and vegetables.

site_title: Delivery Hero acquires majority stake in Spanish food delivery app Glovo
summary: Delivery Hero, a German food delivery group, has acquired a 39.4% stake in Spanish delivery app Glovo for 2.3 billion euros. The acquisition values Glovo at 2.3 billion euros, making it a majority stake. Delivery Hero already holds a 43.8% stake in Glovo, with the transaction expected to be completed in the coming months. The acquisition is part of Delivery Hero's expansion efforts in the European market.

site_title: PTTGC to spend up to US$1.3 billion by 2030 to improve efficiency through decarbonisation
summary: Thai chemical company PTT Global Chemical (PTTGC) plans to spend US$1 billion to US$1.3 billion by 2030 to improve efficiency and cut greenhouse gas emissions by 20% through decarbonisation efforts. The company aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 and has set aside US$22 billion for a 30-year portfolio adjustment strategy. PTTGC will focus on adopting cleaner fuels, digitalisation, and new technologies to reduce emissions, with plans to acquire new businesses and invest in sustainable processes.

site_title: A GST hike in 2022 would imply hope, more than fear
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong hinted at a Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike in 2022, suggesting the government's confidence in the country's economic recovery. Economists weigh the timing, with some seeing it as a move to build fiscal space, while others believe it's necessary to address the accumulated drain of COVID-19 support. A hike could help keep inflationary pressures in check, but may also affect the service industry and consumers. The government aims to phase out emergency support measures and lay the basis for sustainable finances.

site_title: New Year parties slashed as Covid wave hammers the world
summary: A global surge in Covid-19 cases driven by the Omicron variant has led to widespread New Year's celebrations being cancelled or curtailed. Over 1 million daily new cases worldwide have been reported, with record levels in the US, UK, France, and other European countries. Governments have reimposed restrictions, including mask mandates, curfews, and lockdowns, while some countries, like South Africa, have lifted restrictions to allow celebrations. The World Health Organization warns that the Omicron variant is putting immense pressure on health systems, with exhausted health workers and hospitals on the brink of collapse.

images.alt_text: Susan Chong.

site_title: Bitcoin faces uncertain 2022 after record year
summary: Bitcoin's record-breaking 2021 year is uncertain in 2022, with volatility and regulatory pressures expected to impact the sector. Despite a trebling in value to US$60,000 in 2020-2021, Bitcoin's price has dropped to under US$50,000, with some analysts predicting increased competition from ethereum. Sustained institutional adoption and integration into traditional financial systems are seen as key drivers of growth in 2022, according to experts. Regulatory uncertainty, particularly from China and the US, remains a significant concern.

site_title: JPMorgan, Citi employees to start 2022 with remote work as Covid cases rise
summary: JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup are allowing employees to work from home in the first two weeks of 2022 due to the rising number of Covid-19 cases in the New York region. The banks are encouraging staff to work remotely to minimize in-person interactions and reduce the risk of transmission. Employees are expected to return to in-office schedules by February 1. Other major US banks, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, have also revised their staffing strategies to prioritize remote work and vaccination requirements amid the surge in infections.

images.alt_text: IMF managing director Christine Lagarde with MAS managing director Ravi Menon at Singapore FinTech Festival 2017.

site_title: Advertising in the pandemic: how companies used Covid as a marketing tool
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, companies used advertising to tell three main types of story: emphasizing the supply chain impact, focusing on financial support, and highlighting emotional comfort. However, these tactics sometimes came across as insensitive or exploitative, such as fashion ads downplaying childcare burdens or e-cigarette ads promoting vaping as a health solution. The research also found that corporate partnerships with governments were often used to justify advertising campaigns, and that such marketing can create the illusion of corporate social responsibility while distracting from more radical change.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge down on Friday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,123.68 points on the final trading day of 2021, with 488.8 million shares worth S$313.2 million changing hands. The STI's decline was attributed to the impending policy tightening and surging inflation. Despite this, Keppel DC Reit was the best performer, rising 0.8%, while Hongkong Land fell 1.5%. The local banks DBS and OCBC had mixed performances, while UOB fell 0.4%.

site_title: The Lexus NX is now a contemporary crossover
summary: The Lexus NX has undergone a full redesign, embracing traditional luxury while incorporating new digital tech and battery power. The new model is longer and wider, with a more muscular appearance and a sleek LED strip at the back. It features a hybrid drivetrain, including a plug-in hybrid option, and offers a spacious interior with advanced infotainment system. However, the NX faces stiff competition in the market, particularly from BMW's X3 and Mercedes' GLC, and its price may not justify its features and dependability.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that the country's GDP is expected to grow 3-5% in 2022, citing the need for a vibrant economy to fund social programs. Meanwhile, Mapletree Commercial Trust and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust proposed a merger to become one of Asia's 10 largest real estate investment trusts. Other news included Hanwell Holdings' acquisition of CKH Food Trading and 123 Mart for S$3.3m, and P5 Capital's S$12.5m acquisition of GashubUnited Utility. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed down 0.1% on Friday.

site_title: Hundreds of homes feared lost in Colorado wildfires
summary: Wildfires in Colorado have destroyed hundreds of homes, with at least 370 homes lost in the Sagamore subdivision and potentially 210 in Old Town Superior. The fast-moving blaze has also engulfed hotels and shopping centers in the town of Superior, with warnings of potential deaths and injuries. Strong winds and a historic drought have fueled the fire, which has burned over 1,600 acres in Boulder County. Colorado Governor Jared Polis declared a state of emergency, citing the devastating impact on suburban communities.

site_title: Indonesia bans coal exports in January on domestic supply worries
summary: Indonesia bans coal exports in January due to concerns over low domestic supplies, citing a letter from the energy ministry. The country, the world's largest exporter of thermal coal, aims to ensure 25% of annual production is supplied to state utility PLN at a maximum price of $70 per tonne. The ban affects major customers China, India, Japan, and South Korea, and will be evaluated based on coal stock realisation for power plants and independent power producers.

site_title: Nearly 470 people lose at least S$8.5m in phishing scams involving OCBC
summary: At least 469 people in Singapore have lost S$8.5 million in phishing scams involving OCBC bank since December 1, with most losses occurring over the past two weeks. The scams involved unsolicited SMSes claiming issues with bank accounts, leading victims to click on links and enter login details. The police urge the public to follow crime prevention measures, including verifying information through official websites and not disclosing personal or banking details.

site_title: Global M&A volumes hit record high in 2021, breach US$5t for first time
summary: Global merger and acquisition (M&A) volumes reached a record high of $5 trillion in 2021, surpassing the previous record of $4.55 trillion set in 2007. The year saw 62,193 deals, a 24% increase from the previous year, driven by easy financing and booming stock markets. Despite looming interest rate hikes, dealmakers expect a continued flurry of large mergers in 2022, with the US leading the way, accounting for nearly half of global volumes. Buyouts backed by private-equity firms more than doubled this year, crossing the $1 trillion mark for the first time ever.

site_title: China Dec new home prices fall at slower pace: private survey
summary: China's new home prices in 100 cities fell 0.02% in December, a slower decline than the 0.04% drop in November, according to a private survey. This marks a tentative sign of stabilizing demand after authorities eased property financing measures to prevent a hard landing for the sector. The government has maintained its real estate policies, focusing on reducing leverage and discouraging speculation, while providing subsidies and deed tax cuts to boost home sales. This easing of curbs suggests a possible slowdown in the sector's decline.

site_title: Exxon in danger of being next Blockbuster, Kodak, CalSTRS CIO says
summary: CalSTRS CIO Christopher Ailman warns ExxonMobil is at risk of becoming the next Blockbuster or Kodak if it fails to adapt to the energy transition and climate change. The pension fund supported Engine No. 1's successful campaign to replace one-fourth of Exxon's board, citing the company's lack of holistic change. Exxon has increased investments in lower emissions projects, but Ailman says the company must fundamentally shift its approach to survive. If not, Exxon risks becoming a relic of the past, like Kodak and Blockbuster.

site_title: China's small businesses feel even more pain during Covid crisis
summary: China's small businesses face severe difficulties due to the Covid crisis, with high prices, intermittent outbreaks, and a slowing economy. According to government surveys, the current situation is the worst since February 2020, with the purchasing managers' index below 50, indicating a contraction. Smaller firms struggle with rising labor costs, the trade war, and economic turmoil, while medium and large firms see stronger expansions. The government has expanded financial support and encouraged banks to lend to these businesses at a lower cost, but recovery remains optimistic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish the year on a high
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with a 1.24% gain on the last trading day of 2021, driven by surging Chinese tech stocks. The Hang Seng Index rose 285.66 points to 23,397.67. This followed a weak lead from Wall Street, with global markets shrugging off concerns over US-EU trade tensions and new tariff threats. Despite the uncertainty, Hong Kong's market ended the year on a positive note, buoyed by the resilience of Chinese tech stocks.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index was up 1.24 per cent or 285.66 points to 23,397.67 at the close in a holiday-shortened trading session.

site_title: The love-hate relationship with Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's population has declined for the first time since 1961, with the local population decreasing the most, according to government records. The decline is attributed to a decrease in overcrowding in public places, a reduction in noise pollution, and a more peaceful environment. However, this decline is seen as a negative by some, as it has led to less excitement and a lack of budding experiences, such as trying new restaurants. The city's reputation as a bustling and exciting place to live has faded, leaving it with a "love-hate" relationship.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at the opening of trading on Friday, December 31, driven by gains from local banks and property developers. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 3.68 points to 3,130.32. US stocks closed lower on Thursday due to thin holiday trading, while European stocks rose on hopes of no new pandemic restrictions.

site_title: What's going to drive Singapore's investment management sector in 2022
summary: Singapore's investment management sector is poised for growth in 2022, driven by three key trends: the rise of digital assets, the "onshorisation" of funds, and the return to the workplace transition. As the sector navigates pandemic uncertainty, digital assets are gaining attention, with Singapore's favorable regulatory environment and skilled talent making it an attractive location for digital asset fund managers. Meanwhile, the trend towards "onshorisation" is driving funds to onshore their structures in Singapore, where the Variable Capital Company (VCC) scheme is proving successful. Finally, the return to the workplace transition is prompting firms to reassess their talent strategies, with a focus on ESG dimensions and personalized upskilling.

site_title: Gold set for worst performance in 6 years, inches up in thin trade
summary: Gold prices are set for their worst performance in 6 years, with a 4% decline this year, due to recovering economies and reduced demand for the safe-haven metal. Despite this, gold rose 0.2% to $1,818.43 per ounce in thin trade on New Year's Eve, as US Treasury yields dipped. The decline in jobless claims and a surge in Omicron cases failed to impact gold prices, which are also influenced by a stronger dollar. Silver and platinum also saw price movements, with silver on track for its worst year since 2014.

site_title: Tesla cedes sliver of its trillion-dollar value to end year
summary: Tesla ended 2021 with its first monthly decline since May, as investors digested CEO Elon Musk's massive share sale and a recall affecting hundreds of thousands of electric vehicles. The stock fell 7.7% in December, but still achieved a 50% annual gain, making it one of the few companies with a market value above $1 trillion. Musk's share sales and lingering chip shortage have led some investors to cut their exposure, with analysts divided on the stock's future.

site_title: US: Stocks end banner year on downbeat note
summary: US stocks ended the year on a downbeat note, despite a strong 2021, with major indices posting record gains. The S&P 500 fell 0.3% to 4,766.18, while the Dow lost 0.2% to 36,338.3, and the Nasdaq dropped 0.6% to 15,644.97. The year saw huge gains, with the S&P 500 up 27.1% and the Dow up 18.7%, as high-flying tech stocks pushed the Nasdaq up 21.4%. Investors traded cautiously ahead of the Omicron variant, which has caused widespread absences and cancellations.

images.alt_text: Asked if there was any chance May's plan could pass parliament, Justine Greening, who supported staying in the European Union, said "no".

site_title: Tesla raises China prices again on surging demand, SCMP says
summary: Tesla has raised prices of its Shanghai-made models for the second time in a month amid soaring Chinese demand. The Model 3's entry-level price increased by 3.9% to 265,652 yuan (S$56,368) after subsidies, while the Model Y's basic edition saw a 7.5% jump to 301,840 yuan. The price hikes come after a previous increase in November, but Tesla did not provide a reason for the new price adjustments.

site_title: China makes Reits push to speed up infrastructure investment
summary: China's state planner is pushing to boost the country's real estate investment trusts (Reits) market to speed up infrastructure investment. The National Development & Reform Commission (NDRC) has urged local bureaus to improve services and reduce red tape, allowing more infrastructure projects to be listed as Reits. China launched the public Reits market in June, but only nine Reits were listed at launch, with only three added since then. Analysts cite challenges, including a shortage of quality projects and legal issues, but regulators see Reits as a way to reduce debt and improve efficiency in infrastructure projects.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares flat at Friday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on December 31, 2021, down 1.21 points or 0.1% to 1,542.40. Trading volume was 40 million lots worth RM12 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 97 to 54.

site_title: 3G Capital buys control of Luxaflex maker in US$7b deal
summary: 3G Capital has agreed to acquire a 75% stake in Hunter Douglas, maker of Luxaflex blinds, in a $7.1 billion deal. The offer values the company at $198 per share, a 73% premium to its closing price. Hunter Douglas shares rose 70% in early trading. Minority shareholders will be able to exit at the same price. After the deal, the Sonnenberg family will hold a 25% stake in the company, which employs 23,000 people worldwide.

site_title: Oil posts biggest annual gain since at least 2016
summary: Oil prices ended the year with their biggest annual gains since at least 2016, rising 50.5% for Brent crude and 55.5% for US West Texas Intermediate. The global economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic slump and producer restraint drove the gains. Despite record-high Covid-19 cases worldwide, oil prices were set to post their biggest annual gains since 2016, with forecasts predicting further price increases in 2022.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 23.92 points to 1,567.53. The market saw 479 gainers compared to 413 losers, with a total volume of 2.523 billion lots worth RM1.861 billion.

site_title: North Korea's Kim talks food not nukes for 2022
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un marked his 10th year in power with a speech focused on economic development and improving people's lives, rather than nuclear weapons or diplomacy with the US. The speech, delivered on December 31, highlighted domestic issues such as rural development, school uniforms, and food security, which face a "great life-and-death struggle" due to international sanctions and the COVID-19 pandemic. Kim emphasized the need to implement a 5-year plan to boost the economy and improve living standards, but did not mention the US or specific denuclearization talks.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop on final trading day of the year
summary: European shares declined 1% on the final trading day of 2021 due to surging Covid-19 infections and concerns over global economic recovery. Travel stocks led losses, but the pan-European STOXX 600 still rose 22.5% for the year. Despite this, New Year celebrations were canceled globally due to the pandemic surge. The benchmark index is set to end the year in positive territory.

site_title: Are Apple AirTags being used to track people and steal cars?
summary: A growing concern is emerging over Apple's AirTags, which can track people and potentially steal cars. Women have reported finding AirTags on their cars and belongings, sparking fears of stalking and theft. Authorities are taking notice, with the West Seneca Police Department in New York investigating an AirTag found on a car bumper. Researchers warn that AirTags' Bluetooth technology and proximity to Apple's mobile operating system make them a uniquely harmful threat for stalking. Apple claims to have safeguards in place, but users are calling for more effective measures to prevent misuse.

site_title: Australia: Shares recover from pandemic-battered 2020 to gain this year
summary: Australian shares finished the year with a 13% gain, recovering from pandemic-driven losses in 2020, driven by record dealmaking activity, initial public offerings, and accelerating inflation. The S&P/ASX 200 index slipped 1% on its last trading session, despite a six-day Christmas rally. Australian banks logged their best year since 2013, with top banks adding 10-28% this year, while heavyweight miners extended gains for a sixth straight year, up 5%.

site_title: China to extend preferential tax policies for foreigners until end-2023
summary: China has announced the extension of preferential income tax policies for foreigners until December 31, 2023, as part of measures to ease the burden on taxpayers. The previous exemptions for benefits and allowances, such as housing rental and education for children, will cease on January 1, 2022. The government has also pledged to cut taxes and fees in 2022 to support struggling businesses, particularly middle and low-income groups.

site_title: China accuses Walmart of 'stupidity' over missing Xinjiang goods

Executive director Chan Tung Moe sees the virtual reality industry's potential as "limitless" and plans to take "measured steps" as the industry evolves.

site_title: Not quite over the moon at Eclipse
summary: Eclipse, a modern Asian contemporary restaurant in Singapore, aims high but falls short in its execution. Despite a well-meaning concept and personable staff, the restaurant's fine dining approach with Asian twists feels loosely executed, with an awkward storyline and inconsistent dishes. Standouts include the roast lamb rack and angel hair kombu pasta, but the set menu's creativity is often hindered by overthinking and a lack of seasoning. With a price tag of S$198 for a 5-course dinner, Eclipse needs to dial down its rhetoric and focus on substance over style to win over diners. Rating: 6/10.

site_title: Dollar ticks up against rivals in thin holiday trading
summary: The US dollar rose 0.11% to 95.924 against major currencies, driven by cautious optimism about the economic consequences of the Omicron variant. Despite record-high global Covid-19 infections, many governments have resisted lockdowns. The dollar index recovered lost ground from Wednesday, with the euro and sterling also moving higher. The Turkish lira continued to slide, and German government bond yields retreated from a 2-month high. Investors await the upcoming withdrawal of central banks' pandemic-time stimulus, expecting the European Central Bank to be less hawkish than the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: SenseTime jumps on debut after IPO delayed by US sanctions
summary: Chinese artificial intelligence giant SenseTime Group jumped 7.3% on its first day of trading in Hong Kong after a delayed IPO due to US sanctions. The company raised HK$5.78 billion selling 1.5 billion shares at HK$3.85 apiece, defying US Treasury Department sanctions over alleged human rights abuses in Xinjiang. Despite this, SenseTime secured $512 million from 9 cornerstone investors and attributed its strong debut to reasonable valuation and buying by short-term speculators, but warned that the trend won't continue due to ongoing bad news.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry launched the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme for H1 2022 with 3 confirmed sites and 4 on reserve, covering a total site area of 4.48 hectares. Singapore's GDP growth is expected to moderate in Q4 due to Omicron-related uncertainty. Tikehau Capital has received an eligibility-to-list letter from the Singapore Exchange for its SPAC listing. Electricity and gas tariffs are set to increase in Q1 2022. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver the Singapore Budget on Feb 18, 2022.

site_title: Policy rate can start increasing in early 2023, says ECB Governing Council member
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may raise interest rates early in 2023, according to Governing Council member Klaas Knot. The ECB will end its bond purchases by the end of 2022, and Knot believes the policy rate can increase after that, but the timing will depend on the economy's development. This comes as other major central banks, such as the Federal Reserve and Bank of England, have already started tightening monetary policy. Knot also noted that the Omicron variant may have a limited impact on prices next year.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall during Christmas week
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell to 198,000 for the week ended Dec 25, a seasonally adjusted drop from 206,000 a week earlier. This marks the lowest level since 1969, with claims declining from a record high of 6.149 million in early April 2020. Economists had forecast 208,000 applications, but the actual number fell short. The decline in claims indicates no significant impact from the surge in US coronavirus infections on employment.

site_title: Top 10 news events that made headlines in Singapore in 2021
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

In 2021, Singapore experienced significant news events, including the succession plan for Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, which led to a Cabinet reshuffle. The country's Covid-19 response was marked by new variants and a see-saw process of tightening and loosening measures. Parliament saw heated debates on foreign talent policy and the Foreign Interference (Countermeasures) Act. The property market faced cooling measures, including stricter ownership criteria for HDB flats. Media company Singapore Press Holdings underwent a restructuring, leading to a bidding war. The government also promoted electric vehicles, with Tesla becoming the top-selling sedan.

site_title: China central bank issues first loans for emission-cuts financing
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has issued 85.5 billion yuan (S$18.2 billion) in low-cost loans to promote green projects and corporate efforts to cut carbon emissions. This marks the first batch of loans under the carbon emission reduction facility (CERF), a new initiative aimed at encouraging financial institutions to provide loans for emission-cutting projects. The loans are available to financial institutions that have already lent to companies reducing their carbon footprint. This move is part of China's efforts to reduce its carbon emissions and promote sustainable development.

site_title: Singapore CBD Grade A office rents may grow twice as quickly in 2022: JLL
summary: Singapore's Grade A office rents in the Central Business District (CBD) are expected to grow at least double the 4.2% increase in 2021, according to JLL Singapore. The firm attributes this to strong demand from corporates expanding their presence in the city-state, coupled with limited supply. JLL forecasts a 7% or lower vacancy rate by the end of 2022, driving rental growth and intensifying investors' interest in Singapore's office assets. Cushman & Wakefield also projects a 4.6% increase in rents, with co-working space expected to grow substantially in 2022.

site_title: Didi reveals US$4.7b loss ahead of 2022 Hong Kong debut
summary: Didi Global disclosed a US$4.7 billion loss in its September quarter, citing regulatory actions that will force the ride-sharing leader to shift its listing from New York to Hong Kong next year. The company reported US$6.6 billion of sales, down 13% from the June quarter. Didi's shares slid 8% in New York and 13% in Hong Kong after the announcement. The company is planning to work with Goldman Sachs and others to facilitate the listing by introduction, a process that allows US investors to swap their shares for new stock in Hong Kong.

site_title: Boards expect transformation from their cloud investments
summary: Organisations worldwide are expected to spend $1.78 trillion on cloud and digital transformation initiatives in 2022, with half of companies generating more than 40% of their revenues from digital products and services by 2023. To truly transform, companies must reinvent themselves, moving beyond "digital sameness" and embracing the cloud as a liberator, freeing technical staff to develop unique digital products and services. Cloud computing, including autonomous technologies, is critical for this transformation, enabling speed, scalability, and resilience.

site_title: Singapore businesses in Xi'an take lockdown in their stride
summary: Singapore companies with exposure to Xi'an, China, are largely unaffected by the city's COVID-19 lockdown, which began on Dec 22. Companies like CapitaLand China Trust and EtonHouse International Education Group have implemented measures to minimize the impact, such as working from home and increased cleaning protocols. The lockdown is not expected to significantly affect their operations in China, with some companies like EtonHouse having more than 40 campuses across the country.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish marginally up
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed marginally up on December 30, 2021, in cautious holiday trade. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.11% to 23,112.01, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The gains followed a mixed close on Wall Street.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end the year 3.6% higher
summary: South Korea's stocks ended the year 3.6% higher in thin trading, despite a decline in the benchmark Kospi index. The index fell 15.64 points, or 0.52%, to 2,977.65. Technology shares led gains, with SK Hynix rising 3.15%, while Samsung Electronics fell 0.63%. The Korean won weakened, and foreigners were net sellers of 222.4 billion won worth of shares. The won has lost 8.6% against the dollar this year.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte signs 5t pesos budget for 2022
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte signed a 5.024 trillion peso (S$133.1 billion) budget for 2022, the country's largest ever. The 11.5% increase aims to sustain economic recovery and manage Covid-19 outbreaks. Duterte's last budget before his term ends in June will focus on building resilience and infrastructure development.

site_title: Ex-Bear Stearns CEO James Cayne dies aged 87
summary: James Cayne, former CEO of Bear Stearns, has died at 87 after suffering a stroke. Cayne, known for his success on Wall Street and his love of bridge, led the firm to record profits before its collapse in 2008. He was criticized by his predecessor and mentor, Alan "Ace" Greenberg, who blamed him for the firm's downfall. Cayne's net worth plummeted from $1.3 billion in 2007 to $61 million by 2008. He died days after suffering a stroke at a hospital in New Jersey.

site_title: Singapore's electricity, gas tariffs to rise in Q1 2022
summary: Singapore's electricity and gas tariffs are set to increase by an average of 5.6% or S$0.0133 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) from January 1 to March 31, 2022, due to higher fuel costs. The increase is attributed to imported natural gas prices indexed to oil prices, which account for 95% of Singapore's electricity generation. This rise will be applied to electricity tariffs before the 7% goods and services tax (GST).

site_title: Scientist behind the world's first smart bandage among winners of prestigious Fortune Times awards
summary: A scientist behind the world's first smart bandage has won a prestigious award from Fortune Times, a Chinese-language business magazine. The 7th annual awards recognize individuals and companies for innovative and sustainable products and solutions. The scientist's achievement is part of the recognition, which also includes winners in healthcare and impact investing. The Fortune Times awards honor outstanding contributions to business and sustainability, celebrating innovative solutions that drive positive impact.

site_title: Singapore stocks close lower on Thursday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% on Thursday, closing at 3,126.64 points, as Asian markets declined. Japan's Nikkei and South Korea's Kospi also dropped, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index edged up. Analysts attribute the decline to pre-New Year's Eve book squaring and a shift towards value over growth. The top performer was Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while Genting Singapore was the biggest loser, down 1.3%.

site_title: UK house prices cap strong year with another jump: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices rose 1.0% in December, capping the biggest full-year rise since 2006, according to Nationwide. This brings average house prices to a record high of £254,822. Economists expected a 0.5% monthly rise. The housing market rebounded after the 2020 lockdown, driven by demand for bigger properties as people work from home. However, the outlook remains uncertain, with the stamp duty holiday expected to slow the market next year, and the Omicron variant potentially supporting continued price growth.

site_title: China rebukes top investment bank over Lenovo's botched listing
summary: China's securities regulator has rebuked top investment bank China International Capital Corp (CICC) for failing to conduct thorough due diligence on Lenovo Group's US$1.6 billion Shanghai stock listing. The CSRC found that CICC relied heavily on Lenovo's explanatory documents, leading to a summons of 5 bankers involved in the listing for regulatory review. This move comes as China tightens listing requirements for first-time share sales to weed out sub-par firms. Lenovo had withdrawn its listing plan in October, citing potential lapses in prospectus information.

site_title: ST Engineering unit awarded second US Coast Guard Polar Security Cutter contract
summary: ST Engineering's unit, Halter Marine, has been awarded a second contract by the US Department of the Navy for the construction of a Polar Security Cutter (PSC) at a fixed price. The contract is valued at US$745.9 million and is part of a US$1.9 billion initiative announced in 2019 to recapitalize the US Coast Guard's PSC fleet. The new PSC is expected to meet current and future mission needs in polar regions, supporting economic vitality, scientific inquiry, and national interests.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares barely changed at Thursday's open
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.22 point or 0.01% to 1,544.82. Trading volume was 28.5 million lots worth RM10.3 million. The market saw a slight imbalance between losers and gainers, with 74 losers outnumbering 73 gainers.

site_title: Hong Kong axes quarantine exemptions for aircrew: sources
summary: Hong Kong's government has ended quarantine exemptions for aircrew working on non-China passenger flights, effective December 29, according to sources. Airlines, including Cathay Pacific, must now operate "closed-loop" flights with crew members spending up to 2 weeks in quarantine for each landing. The move aims to tighten border control measures amid the Omicron variant's spread globally. Cathay Pacific is consolidating passenger flight schedules and offering full ticket refunds to affected customers, citing the quarantine restrictions as a major constraint to operations.

site_title: Data centre, logistics boom could further whet investor appetite
summary: Investors are expected to further seek out logistics assets and data centers in the Asia-Pacific region in 2022, driven by increasing capital flows and optimism. Investments in the region's industrial real estate rose 50% in January to November 2021, reaching US$44.59 billion. Rising inflation concerns and the acceleration of e-commerce are driving demand for high-quality, core assets. The pandemic has accelerated the need for logistics space, with every US$1 billion increase in online sales requiring an additional 1 million square feet of warehouse space.

site_title: Ezion to wind up as protracted attempt to restructure, recapitalise fails
summary: Ezion Holdings, a liftboat operator, will proceed with winding up as it failed to secure sufficient support from major creditors. The company attempted to restructure and recapitalize since an investment plan lapsed in September 2020, but ultimately decided liquidation is the best course of action to ensure an orderly wind down of its affairs. Trading of its shares has been suspended since 2019, and the company will not submit a proposal for trading to resume. Liquidation will be overseen by a court-appointed liquidator.

site_title: China Evergrande shares fall after report of missed coupon payments
summary: China Evergrande Group shares fell 7.3% in opening trades after a report stated the company did not pay offshore coupons worth US$255 million due on Tuesday. The missed payment, combined with a previous missed coupon payment, puts Evergrande's US$19 billion in international bonds in cross-default. The company has over US$300 billion in liabilities and is scrambling to raise cash by selling assets and shares to repay suppliers and creditors. This decline wipes out gains made earlier in the week, following progress in resuming construction work.

site_title: Australia: Miners, banks help shares notch 3-1/2-month closing high
summary: Australian shares rose for a sixth consecutive session, closing at their highest in over 3.5 months, driven by gains in miners and banks. The S&P/ASX 200 index edged up 0.05% to 7,513.40, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto jumping 1% each. Gold stocks fell 1%, leading to a 12% decline in gold stocks this year, but experts say inflation may boost demand for safe-haven assets like gold.

site_title: Singapore GDP growth to moderate in Q4 on Omicron woes: poll
summary: Singapore's economic growth is expected to moderate in Q4 2021 due to uncertainty from the Omicron Covid-19 variant, with a median forecast of 5.4% GDP growth. This marks the 4th straight quarter of growth, with the economy growing 7.1% in Q3. Economists predict 6.8% growth for 2021 and 3-5% growth in 2022, depending on global pandemic progress. The central bank is expected to tighten monetary policy again in April 2022 due to inflationary pressures.

site_title: Only 18% of Japan's firms planning 3% pay hikes: survey
summary: Japan's biggest firms plan to raise pay by only 3% or more at upcoming labour negotiations, according to a Nikkei survey, falling short of Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's target. Only 18% of firms intend to boost pay, while 43% plan a 2-3% increase. Kishida has made wage hikes a key policy objective, but economists doubt he can budge firms enough to make a difference. The outcome may determine his ability to push forward his new capitalism vision and whether he can gain traction for his policy agenda.

site_title: Oil rises as fuel demand holds up despite surge in Omicron cases
summary: Oil prices rose 17 US cents or 0.2% to $79.40 a barrel, extending a four-day gain, despite a surge in Omicron cases. US fuel demand remained strong, with crude oil inventories falling 3.6 million barrels and petrol and distillate inventories decreasing. Governments worldwide eased testing rules and isolation measures to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Asean consumers show growing interest in sustainable investing: UOB
summary: Asean consumers are increasingly interested in sustainable investing, with 91% expressing a desire for financial institutions to provide more information on sustainable investment benefits. The Asean Consumer Sentiment Study 2021 found that younger generations, particularly Gen Z and millennials, are driving awareness of sustainability. In Singapore, 13% of respondents already buy sustainable investment products, and 61% are considering or interested in sustainable investments. The study also notes a significant increase in demand for sustainable products, with 51% of Gen Z respondents motivated to shape a better future for current and future generations.

site_title: Asia: Stocks subdued, oil caps stellar year
summary: Asian shares were flat on the last trading day of the year, as the Omicron variant clouded economic outlook. Oil prices rose, finishing the year with a 50% gain, while US crude inventories fell. China's blue chips added 1% despite a 5.5% annual loss, and Japan's Nikkei slipped 0.2% to a 4.6% annual gain. Taiwan's stocks rose 24% due to chip demand, and US bond yields rose 6 basis points, near a 1.55% peak.

site_title: CapitaLand Development in JV to develop 1.5b yuan business park in Suzhou New District
summary: CapitaLand Development has partnered Mitsubishi Estate to invest 1.5 billion yuan (S$318.2 million) in a business park in China's Suzhou New District. The 50/50 joint venture will start construction next year and complete in 2024, featuring multi-tenanted buildings with research and development spaces. The park will cater to high-tech new economy sectors and adopt a "Singapore-style garden city design concept" with green technologies.

site_title: Are shophouses an evergreen asset class?
summary: Singapore's shophouse market is experiencing a surge in prices and demand, driven by strong investor interest and limited supply. The escalating prices have tempted some buyers to flip these heritage properties for quick gains. High-net-worth investors, including family offices and funds, are increasingly attracted to shophouses due to their rarity and limited supply, making them a more attractive value proposition compared to traditional assets. This trend is expected to continue, with more institutional investors entering the market and driving up prices.

site_title: China to issue record treasury bonds in 2022, guide rates lower
summary: China plans to sell a record amount of treasury bonds in 2022, while keeping overall interest rates lower, to stabilize economic growth. The government aims to attract more long-term foreign investors and provide liquidity support for the issuance. To guide rates lower, China will moderately increase short-term treasury bonds and reform maturity date management. The goal is to make treasury bond yields a benchmark for other borrowings and encourage foreign investors to hold Chinese debt for longer.

site_title: Bukalapak appoints interim CEO after Rachmat Kaimuddin resigns
summary: PT Bukalapak.com, an Indonesian e-commerce operator, has appointed Willix Halim as interim CEO after Rachmat Kaimuddin's resignation. Halim, who is currently COO, will serve as acting CEO until a new president director is appointed at an extraordinary general meeting. Kaimuddin, who left Bukalapak after 2 years, will join the Indonesian government as a special advisor.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOB emerges as RHB's top pick among 'overweight' bank stocks
summary: RHB has upgraded UOB as its top pick among 'overweight' bank stocks in Singapore, citing its growing fee income base, healthy asset quality, and resumption of a 50% dividend payout ratio. The brokerage sets a target price of S$33.50, representing a 23.8% upside from its current share price. RHB expects UOB's net profit to rise 9% in FY2022, boosting its return on equity to 9.6%. The upgrade follows a similar call for DBS, with OCBC also receiving a target price.

images.alt_text: RHB gave UOB a target price of S$33.50, which represents an upside of 23.8 per cent from its share price of S$27.05 as at Wednesday's close.

site_title: British socialite Ghislaine Maxwell convicted of sex trafficking
summary: British socialite Ghislaine Maxwell was found guilty on 5 of 6 counts, including sex trafficking a minor, of recruiting and grooming young girls for abuse by late financier Jeffrey Epstein. Maxwell, 60, faces a potential 40-year sentence. The charges stem from 1994-2004, with alleged victims saying Maxwell began grooming them at 14 and arranging for them to give massages to Epstein. A sentencing date has not been set. Maxwell, the daughter of late British press baron Robert Maxwell, was convicted by a 12-person jury.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after mixed US close
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on December 30, 2021, following a mixed close on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.37% to 28,800.74, while the Topix index dropped 0.37% to 1,991.61. The declines were attributed to cautious trade.

site_title: Gold holds above US$1,800 as weak dollar checks yield pressure
summary: Gold prices remain above $1,800 per ounce as a weak US dollar supports bullion prices, despite firm Treasury yields eroding its appeal. Spot gold steadied at $1,803.03 per ounce, while benchmark 10-year US Treasury yields neared a 1-month peak. Investors favored riskier currencies as the Omicron variant's spread was downplayed, and Asian markets started listlessly. Gold is on track for its biggest annual decline since 2015, with analysts expecting thin and range-bound trading this week.

site_title: Industrial GLS for H1 2022 launched with 3 confirmed sites, 4 on reserve
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry launched its Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme for H1 2022, with 3 confirmed sites and 4 reserve sites totaling 4.48 hectares. The sites on the reserve list will be tendered if an acceptable offer is made and sufficient market interest is shown. This move aims to stimulate industrial development and provide opportunities for businesses to expand or establish new operations in Singapore.

images.alt_text: THE Ministry of Trade and Industry on Thursday (Dec 30) launched its Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme for the first half of 2022.

site_title: SK Hynix completes first phase of US$9b Intel NAND business buy
summary: SK Hynix has completed the first phase of its $9 billion acquisition of Intel's NAND flash memory chip business, receiving regulatory nods from 8 countries, including China. In exchange for $7 billion, SK Hynix will acquire Intel's NAND SSD business, with a second phase expected to close in or after March 2025 for the remaining $2 billion. The deal aims to boost SK Hynix's capacity to build NAND chips, entering the global top tier level and solidifying its position as the world's second-largest memory chip maker.

site_title: Paris again makes face masks compulsory outdoors
summary: Paris is reinstating face mask mandates outdoors for everyone over 11, starting Friday, to combat the spread of the Omicron coronavirus variant. The measure comes as France reports a record-high daily Covid-19 case total of 208,000. The government has also announced new restrictions, including extending the closure of nightclubs and encouraging remote work.

site_title: US calls on China and Hong Kong to release Stand News employees
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken called on Chinese and Hong Kong authorities to release Stand News employees arrested after a police raid. Blinken stated that silencing independent media undermines Hong Kong's credibility and viability. The Stand News raid raises concerns about press freedom in the former British colony, which returned to Chinese rule with a promise of protected freedoms. The US urges the PRC and Hong Kong authorities to immediately release the detained journalists and media executives.

site_title: Japan faces royal dilemma as ancient monarchy shrinks
summary: Japan's imperial family is facing a potential extinction due to a shortage of eligible emperors, with women barred from the throne under male-only succession rules. The current emperor, Naruhito, will be succeeded by his nephew Prince Hisahito, and if he does not have a son, the royal family will run out of male heirs. Despite public support for female succession, pressure from conservative lawmakers and voters makes it unlikely. Officials are brainstorming possible solutions, including allowing royal women to keep their title and public duties when they marry outside the family, and allowing men from abolished branches to "rejoin" the direct line through adoption.

site_title: SenseTime shares jump 23% in Hong Kong debut
summary: SenseTime Group, a Chinese artificial intelligence startup, made its Hong Kong debut with shares jumping 23% from their IPO price of HK$3.85, valuing the company at US$16.4 billion. The IPO raised US$740 million and saw the stock reach a high of HK$4.74, outperforming the Hang Seng Index. The strong debut was attributed to cornerstone investors buying 67% of the stock, despite the US Treasury's blacklisting of SenseTime due to its facial recognition program, which limited US investor participation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Koufu, Hatten Land, Yoma, Biolidics, Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust
summary: Several Singaporean companies made notable announcements on December 30, 2021, affecting their trading. Koufu Group proposed a voluntary conditional offer to privatize the company at S$0.77 per share. Hatten Land delayed crypto mining activities due to supply chain disruptions. Yoma Strategic secured a 20.2% stake in the company after restructuring a loan. Biolidics received approval for medical microbiology services, and Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust was granted a waiver on loan facilities.

site_title: Credit Suisse finds 2nd breach of Covid-19 rules by chairman: sources
summary: Credit Suisse chairman Antonio Horta-Osorio breached Covid-19 rules twice, once in Switzerland and once in Britain, where he attended Wimbledon during a required quarantine. The investigation, conducted by Credit Suisse's legal team, was prompted by reports of the Swiss breach and found that Horta-Osorio also broke Britain's rules. The bank's audit committee will now investigate and decide on further action. Horta-Osorio admitted to breaching Switzerland's rules and could face a fine of up to 5000 Swiss francs in the canton of St Gallen.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end down, but Nikkei up nearly 5% in 2021
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 0.4% on the last trading day of 2021, but the Nikkei index rose nearly 5% for the year, its highest annual close since 1989. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 28,791.71, while the Topix index fell 0.33%.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, December 30, 2021, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.3% or 8.29 points to 3,129.73. The market saw a cautious trading session after the US closed mixed and European equities fell. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, declined in early trade. The US Dow and S&P 500 closed at all-time highs on Wednesday, while European shares fell due to declines in technology, healthcare, and travel stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on December 30, 2021, due to ongoing concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant. The Hang Seng Index dropped 6.78 points to 23,079.76, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 4.12 points to 3,601.12. The Shenzhen Composite Index increased 3.39 points to 2,497.80.

site_title: Hot stock: Koufu rises 15% on privatisation news
summary: Koufu Group VL6 shares surged 15% on Thursday after its founding shareholders made a S$0.77 per share cash offer to privatize the company, valuing it at S$425.8 million. The offer, made by investment company Dominus Capital, is 15 times the operator's pre-pandemic earnings and 43 times its FY2020 earnings. Trading halted on Wednesday before resuming, with shares reaching a 1-year high of S$0.765.

site_title: Samsung Group in talks to buy US drugmaker Biogen: sources
summary: Samsung Group is in talks to acquire US biopharmaceutical company Biogen, valued at over $42 billion. This deal would be the largest overseas acquisition by a South Korean company. Biogen, which recently gained US regulatory approval for its Alzheimer's treatment Aduhelm, is looking to buffer declining sales from its main revenue drivers. The acquisition would be a significant move for Samsung Group, which has been investing heavily in the biopharmaceuticals sector.

site_title: UK pledges £105m to help vulnerable nations fight Omicron
summary: The UK has pledged £105 million in emergency aid to help vulnerable nations cope with the spread of the Omicron coronavirus variant, particularly in Africa. The aid will support measures to reduce transmission, increase testing, and boost oxygen supplies. This assistance aims to help tackle the spread of new variants worldwide and secure freedom from the pandemic.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P close at record highs as Omicron worries ease
summary: The US stock market closed at record highs on December 29, with the Dow and S&P 500 rising due to strong performances from retailers like Walgreens and Nike, despite concerns over the Omicron variant. Investors have largely shrugged off Omicron worries as early studies suggest it may be less likely to overwhelm hospitals. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.25%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.14%, marking the longest streak of gains since March. The main US stock indexes are on pace for their third straight year of strong annual returns.

site_title: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong to deliver Singapore Budget on Feb 18
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver the 2022 Singapore Budget on February 18, marking his first time doing so since becoming Finance Minister in May. The budget may include reviews of wealth taxes and a revised carbon tax rate for 2024. Analysts expect a discussion on a potential goods and services tax hike, with a possible rollout between 2022 and 2025. The public can share their views on the budget until January 17, and Parliament will debate the statement afterwards.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong will unveil the Singapore Budget on Feb 18, 2022.

site_title: Ocean cargo rates may drop as much as 40%, but could be still higher than pre-pandemic levels
summary: Ocean cargo rates may drop 40% in 2022, but are unlikely to return to pre-pandemic levels. Analysts expect rates to ease after the first quarter, but face downward pressure beyond 2022 as new vessels are delivered and capacity increases. Despite a decrease in spot rates during the Chinese Golden Week holiday, many expect prices to remain elevated due to logistical challenges. In 2023, new capacity is expected to help trade lanes achieve a better supply-demand balance, leading to lower spot rates, but not returning to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Didi revenue falls as China's regulatory crackdown hits business
summary: China's ride-hailing firm Didi Global reported a 1.7% decline in third-quarter revenue due to a regulatory crackdown. The company's domestic business was impacted after Chinese authorities demanded it remove its app from mobile stores and investigate its handling of customer data. Didi's CEO Daniel Zhang has resigned, and the company has delisted from the NYSE to pursue a Hong Kong listing. Revenue fell to 42.7 billion yuan, with international operations nearly doubling to 966 million yuan.

site_title: Philippine conglomerate Ayala to take 20.2% stake in Yoma Strategic
summary: Philippine conglomerate Ayala Corp will take a 20.2% stake in Yoma Strategic Holdings after the latter's second tranche of placement shares was restructured into a perpetual loan. Ayala's 5-year loan to Yoma Strategic was converted into a perpetual loan of US$49.1 million. This follows Ayala's initial 14.9% stake in Yoma Strategic in 2019. The companies plan to issue redemption shares at S$0.45 per share, which is the same issue price as the first tranche placement shares.

site_title: Food, glorious food
summary: The article discusses the food and beverage industry's outlook for 2022, despite uncertainties. It highlights new dining experiences, biophilic design, and sustainable practices in restaurants. The article also touches on design trends, including heritage buildings turned into contemporary eateries, and features reviews of new restaurants like Eclipse. Additionally, it mentions upcoming events and predictions for the arts scene, including art fairs and the continued interest in NFTs. Overall, the article emphasizes the potential for good food and dining experiences in 2022.

site_title: Tikehau Capital wins nod for SGX SPAC listing
summary: European asset manager Tikehau Capital has received an eligibility-to-list (ETL) letter from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for its special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) listing. The company, Pegasus Asia, plans to invest S$62 million in the SPAC, along with a sponsor's initial contribution of up to S$10 million. The listing is subject to conditions and market environment. Tikehau Capital is focused on technology-enabled new economy sectors in the Asia-Pacific region, and the SPAC aims to raise up to S$200 million. This is the second SPAC listing announced by the SGX this month, following Temasek-backed Vertex Venture Holdings.

site_title: J&J talc claimants say company is hindering case investigation
summary: Johnson & Johnson is facing a dispute with claimants in its talc lawsuit, with a lawyer claiming the company is hindering case investigation. The company has spun its talc liabilities into a separate unit, LTL Management LLC, which filed for bankruptcy, adding complexity to the case. Claimants' lawyers are seeking information from J&J, but the company has refused to provide it, prompting a motion to compel. A hearing to consider LTL's proposed legal representative is also being delayed, with claimants seeking to postpone consideration of future claims until the case dismissal decision is rendered.

images.alt_text: A lawyer for claimants suing Johnson & Johnson (J&J) over its baby powder wants a bankruptcy judge to force the pharma giant to produce requested information, saying it's hindering efforts to investigate the case.

site_title: China outlines vision for 4 mega data centre clusters
summary: China has approved plans to build 4 mega clusters of data centers in the north and west to support the data needs of Beijing and major coastal centers. The clusters will be built in Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, Gansu, and Guizhou provinces, utilizing local renewable energy resources to create green and low-carbon data centers. This move aims to address the energy consumption limitations faced by data centers in eastern China and support the country's goal of expanding its big data industry into a 3 trillion yuan sector by 2025.

site_title: US Covid-19 deaths and hospitalisations 'comparatively' low despite Omicron surge: health officials
summary: US Covid-19 deaths and hospitalizations remain low despite the Omicron variant surge, according to CDC Director Rochelle Walensky. The 7-day daily average of cases increased 60% to 240,400, hospitalizations rose 14% to 9,000, and deaths decreased 7% to 1,100. Walensky described these numbers as "comparatively" low, indicating a manageable spread of the Omicron variant in the US.

site_title: Staying grounded while competing digitally
summary: A recent survey by UOB Asean Consumer Sentiment Study 2021 found that 79% of respondents in 5 Asean countries preferred using their mobile apps for banking activities, with 7 in 10 anticipating increased online banking in the next 6 months. However, 37% of respondents preferred a combination of digital and physical services. UOB, which developed Asean's first digital bank TMRW, aims to serve 7 million customers digitally by 2026, while also leveraging digital wealth management solutions to build financial resilience. The bank has invested in both digital and physical transformation to create "simpler" and "smarter" banking experiences.

site_title: Europe: Tech, healthcare stocks lead shares lower as Omicron cases swell
summary: European shares slipped 0.1% on Wednesday as record coronavirus infections fueled investor concerns, with tech and healthcare stocks leading the decline. The Omicron variant's impact on economies was seen as a milder version, despite its ease of transmission. In contrast, Britain's FTSE 100 rose 0.6% on higher oil prices and optimism over the year-end. Analysts expect a global recovery to hit a minor bump in 2022, with inflation fears and Covid-19 risks persisting.

site_title: Board diversity for resilience and sustainability
summary: A growing focus on sustainability and resilience has led to a call for stronger board diversity policies, particularly in Singapore. Research has shown that diverse boards can offer cognitive diversity of perspectives, benefiting aspects of sustainability and resilience. However, barriers to board diversity include unconscious bias and the belief that diversity is secondary to skills. The Singapore Exchange's recent consultation paper requires issuers to maintain a board diversity policy addressing gender, skills, and experience, and disclosing related information in annual reports. Companies must consider how to effectively leverage diversity to strengthen business sustainability and resilience.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Biolidics, a medtech firm, announced that its subsidiary Biomedics Laboratory has been granted approval by the Ministry of Health to provide medical microbiology services, including Covid-19 PCR tests. The approval is expected to positively impact the company's revenue amid the pandemic. Biolidics shares rose 3.5% following the announcement.

site_title: Hatten Land delays crypto mining activities to January on supply chain disruptions
summary: Hatten Land, a Malaysian property developer, has delayed its crypto mining activities to January 2022 due to supply chain disruptions caused by border control measures and the Covid-19 pandemic. The company had previously announced plans to install 80 rigs in a pilot phase, but now expects to install over 2,500 rigs by the end of 2022. Hatten Land also plans to increase the number of rigs to 10,000 in the near future, with collaboration with other crypto mining partners.

site_title: Does the recent plunge in Sea's share price present a buying opportunity?
summary: Sea Ltd's share price has plummeted by over 40% following its third-quarter results, closing at US$216.89 on December 28. Despite strong revenue growth, the company remains loss-making, with net losses widening to US$450.1 million. The e-commerce arm, Shopee, reported revenue of US$1.45 billion, up 134.4% on-year, but its operating loss also increased. Analysts are divided on whether the recent dip presents a buying opportunity, citing concerns over growth and profitability. However, 31 out of 32 analysts covering the stock have a "buy" rating, with an average target price of US$405.

site_title: Bitcoin set for worst month since May crypto rout
summary: Bitcoin is on track for its worst monthly drop since May's crypto rout, with a 16% decline this month and a near 7% drop in the past day. Demand for speculative investments has waned due to the Federal Reserve's stimulus pullback, with some strategists predicting a "leveraged unwind" in Bitcoin longs. Despite this, some experts believe the token will recover, citing its year-to-date climb of 65% and potential hedge against inflation.

site_title: Entering third year of pandemic, still with hope and anticipation
summary: The Omicron variant of Covid-19 continues its spread globally, with record highs reported in the US and Europe. As the third year of the pandemic begins, experts express cautious optimism, acknowledging progress in vaccine development and distribution. However, continued vaccine inequality and new variants pose challenges. Experts advise against complacency, instead advocating for dedicated efforts to contain the virus while allowing life to continue. This approach allows for a more realistic acceptance of the pandemic's continuation, rather than resignation.

site_title: Putin declares Nord Stream 2 ready for gas exports
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin declared the Nord Stream 2 undersea gas pipeline ready for gas exports, citing its potential to lower European gas prices. The $11 billion pipeline, completed in September, faces resistance from the US and several European countries. Putin congratulated Gazprom and its partners on the project's completion, which is expected to be certified by the end of 2022. The pipeline has been built by Gazprom and funded by European energy companies, with half of the cost paid by them.

site_title: Vietnam's economy expands in Q4 as manufacturing revives
summary: Vietnam's economy expanded 5.22% in Q4, surpassing the median estimate of 3.7%, with full-year growth at 2.58%. The revival of manufacturing and extended exports recovery from the pandemic slump contributed to the growth. The country's trade surplus reached $4 billion and foreign direct investment increased 9.2% year-on-year, with consumer prices rising 1.81% in December. The economic growth is seen as a positive result given the pandemic's impact on the nation's economy.

site_title: US must not overstate its resolve in military engagements
summary: The US should not overstate its resolve in military engagements, as it often fails to follow through on its commitments, leading to a loss of credibility.
