The article cites examples of US military interventions in Vietnam, Afghanistan, Lebanon, and other countries, where the US withdrew its troops or failed to achieve its goals, resulting in heavy casualties and damage to its reputation. A credible threat from the US can serve as a powerful deterrent, but understating or overstating its commitment can undermine its credibility.

site_title: JD boosts share buyback as China clampdown weighs on tech
summary: JD.COM is increasing its share buyback plan by 50% to US$3 billion, extending it until March 2024. This move follows a series of tech firms repurchasing stock due to China's regulatory crackdown. The plan, originally set at US$2 billion, aims to boost investor confidence and counter the selloff caused by the crackdown. The move is part of JD.COM's efforts to maintain its market value amidst the economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The country's second largest online retailer will set aside US$3 billion for the buyback programme, which will be extended until March 2024, it says in a filing.

site_title: Chinese professor lands US$3.4b fortune with SenseTime IPO
summary: Chinese artificial intelligence company SenseTime has priced its initial public offering (IPO) at HK$3.85 per share, raising HK$5.55 billion and valuing the company at over US$16 billion. Founder Tang Xiao'ou, who holds a 21% stake, is now worth US$3.4 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. The IPO comes despite increased tensions with the US and Beijing's crackdown on tech giants, and SenseTime has faced criticism over its facial-recognition software used in the oppression of Uyghur Muslims in China.

images.alt_text: SenseTime is the first overseas offering by a high-profile Chinese tech unicorn since ride-sharing giant Didi Global's IPO. Its shares are scheduled to start trading on Dec 30 in Hong Kong, giving the company a market value of more than US$16 billion.

site_title: Rivian delays deliveries of pickup, SUV with big battery packs to 2023
summary: Rivian Automotive has delayed deliveries of its electric pickup truck and SUV with large battery packs to 2023, citing production challenges due to global supply-chain constraints and the Covid-19 pandemic. The company prioritizes building the Adventure Package with Large pack battery to serve the majority of its 71,000 preorders. Only 20% of preorders were for the larger battery pack, which offers 400 miles of range on a single charge. Rivian has delivered 386 vehicles so far and plans to introduce a delivery timing estimate feature for customers in early 2022.

site_title: Open banking is offering huge promises
summary: A revolution is underway in the financial services sector with the emergence of open banking, promising to eliminate petty irritations and bring about simplicity and convenience to consumers. This shift aims to liberate individuals from faceless anonymity and poor service, allowing for better accountability and financial protection. Open banking has already been implemented in the UK, with apps offering easy access to financial services, and is expected to bring about flexibility and reduced stress for consumers, allowing them to manage their finances in a more straightforward manner.

site_title: Oil prices climb again as US inventories fall
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday as US inventories fell, boosting demand sentiment. Brent crude rose 0.3% to $79.20 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.2% to $76.17 a barrel. The decline in US crude stocks and lower-than-expected petrol inventories contributed to the price increase. Oil prices have been supported by production cuts from three oil producers and are awaiting an Opec+ meeting on January 4 to determine whether to increase production.

site_title: Risk appetite sends Japanese yen to one-month low
summary: The Japanese yen fell to a one-month low due to increased risk appetite, despite rising cases of Omicron. The euro weakened 0.1% and the dollar index gained 0.1% as investors remained optimistic about economic momentum. The dollar rose versus the yen, reaching its strongest level since late November, while the Australian dollar increased. Sterling also gained 0.1% versus the euro. Analysts attributed the moves to continued optimism about Omicron and end-of-quarter investor flows, with some predicting the US dollar will continue to rise due to approaching rate hikes.

site_title: US pending home sales unexpectedly decline on low supply
summary: US pending home sales unexpectedly fell 2.2% in November to 122.4, according to the National Association of Realtors. This decline was attributed to high prices and low inventory, with buyers hesitant about home prices. The Midwest region saw the largest decline, 6.3%, and contract signings were down 2.7% compared to the same period last year. The pending home-sales data suggests the housing market is easing, but high prices and supply chain disruptions continue to weigh on activity.

site_title: Hong Kong's last major pro-democracy news outlet shuts
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy news outlet Stand News has ceased operations after a national security investigation led to a police raid, asset freeze, and arrests of 7 people, including acting editor-in-chief Patrick Lam and pop star Denise Ho. The move follows a series of devastating blows to the city's opposition, including the arrests of prominent activists and the election of a legislature vetted by Beijing. The closure is seen as a further blow to press freedom in Hong Kong, with the city ranking 80th in Reporters Without Borders' latest press freedom index.

site_title: Managing properties with innovation and adaptability
summary: Exceltec Property Management Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based property and facilities management company, has thrived despite facing numerous crises, including the 1997 Asian financial crisis, SARS outbreak, 2008 global financial crisis, and the Covid-19 pandemic. By leveraging its smaller size and agile operations, Exceltec has turned weaknesses into strengths, offering competitive prices and unique services. The company invests in research and innovation, adopting smart facilities management solutions and creating new products. Exceltec's adaptable approach has enabled it to emerge stronger from each challenge, establishing it as a prominent player in the industry.

site_title: Web3's messy vision of a tech future
summary: Web3, a decentralized online movement, aims to revolutionize the internet with blockchain technology, enabling spontaneous transactions and decentralized interactions. However, its practical applications remain unclear, with current uses limited to decentralized finance and digital collectibles. Critics warn that decentralization could lead to a lack of regulation and oversight, potentially exacerbating existing issues. The promise of Web3 to give individuals control over their data and online life may not materialize, and the technology's true potential remains to be seen as it navigates its messy and speculative early stages.

site_title: Log4Shell: The flaw that will cast a long shadow over the tech world
summary: A vulnerability in Apache Log4j versions 2.0 to 2.14.1, dubbed Log4Shell, has exposed a third of the world's web servers to remote code execution (RCE) attacks. The flaw allows threat actors to take control of Java-based servers and engage in RCE attacks, with widespread ransomware attacks reported in China and Iran. Despite efforts to patch systems, hackers have found ways to bypass security features, leaving organizations vulnerable. A temporary workaround, LogOut4Shell, has been developed to disable the JNDI mechanism and prevent exploits, but the cat-and-mouse game between attackers and defenders is expected to have long-term repercussions.

site_title: Indonesia poised for stronger GDP growth in 2022
summary: Indonesia is poised for stronger GDP growth in 2022, with Bank Indonesia projecting 4.7-5.5% growth, up from 3.2-4% in 2021. The country's vaccination efforts, digital economy, and commodity exports are expected to drive growth. However, fiscal stability poses a threat, with soaring debt levels of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) and a 6.24% state budget deficit in 2021. The government aims to return to a 3% fiscal deficit target by 2023, but market observers warn of potential risks. Indonesia's chairmanship of the G-20 in 2022 may provide opportunities to highlight growth sectors, but effective pandemic management remains crucial.

site_title: LMIR Trust obtains waiver of ratio of net property income to interest expense on its debts
summary: LMIR Trust, a retail property investment trust in Indonesia, has obtained waivers from three loan facilities due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on its properties. The waivers allow the trust to maintain a lower interest coverage ratio of 1.5 times, down from 2.5 times, to ensure it can meet its debt obligations. Despite a decline in mall capacity, the trust remains compliant with its debt covenants and has sufficient financial reserves. The waiver comes as the government may reinstate emergency public activity restrictions to combat the spread of the Omicron variant.

site_title: Maritime sector gets extended support amid prevailing travel restrictions, border control measures
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has extended support measures for the maritime sector until June next year, amid prevailing travel restrictions and border control measures. The MaritimeSG Together Package, originally set to expire in December, will now provide continued relief for regional ferry services and seafarers. The extension includes a S$3 million recovery grant for ferry operators, a 30% office rental rebate, and support for seafarers facing difficulties securing shipboard employment. The measures aim to support the sector as it navigates the ongoing challenges.

site_title: China to extend some favourable income tax policies
summary: China will extend some income tax policies to ease burdens on middle- and low-income groups, cutting taxes by $17.3 billion annually. Preferred tax policies on annual bonuses and equity-based incentives will be extended until the end of 2023 and 2026, respectively. The move aims to stabilize economic growth amid challenges such as a property downturn and strict Covid-19 curbs. China will also make infrastructure investments proactively next year to boost economic growth.

site_title: UK's Johnson warns of hospital risk for unvaccinated
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned that the majority of patients in intensive care due to Covid-19 have not received their booster vaccine, with up to 90% of those cases attributed to unvaccinated individuals. Johnson urged people to get their jabs as the UK reports record Covid infections driven by the Omicron variant. Despite increased hospitalizations, the number remains below the peak of 4,000 in January, with Johnson advising people to celebrate New Year's Eve cautiously and get a booster.

site_title: China warns of 'drastic measures' if Taiwan provokes on independence
summary: China has warned of "drastic measures" if Taiwan pursues independence, with Beijing official Ma Xiaoguang stating that any red line crossed will be met with force. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and has stepped up military and diplomatic pressure in recent years. The US, Taiwan's key international backer, has a law requiring it to provide Taiwan with defense means, while maintaining strategic ambiguity on intervention. Tensions are expected to escalate next year, with Ma warning of a more complex and severe Taiwan Strait situation.

site_title: US coronavirus cases hit record high
summary: US coronavirus cases reached a record high of 258,312 daily cases over the past 7 days, surpassing the previous peak of 250,141 on January 8. The Omicron variant accounts for 58.6% of circulating variants in the US. States with the highest daily infection numbers included New York, California, Texas, and Ohio.

site_title: Malaysia to spend US$335m for flood relief
summary: Malaysia has announced a US$334.93 million relief package to aid those affected by severe floods in 8 states, with direct cash aid for 30,000 households, death benefits, and utility bill relief. The floods, caused by unusually high rainfall, have displaced nearly 70,000 people and killed at least 48. The government's slow response has been criticized, and a national disaster management agency has warned of further flooding in the coming days. Relief measures also include funds for post-flood cleaning and reconstruction, particularly in the worst-hit states of Selangor and Pahang.

site_title: US goods trade deficit hits a record in November
summary: The US goods trade deficit reached a record $97.8 billion in November, a 17.5% increase from October, driven by a 4.7% rise in imports and a 2.1% decline in exports. This marks the fifth consecutive quarter that trade has negatively impacted GDP growth. Wholesale inventories rose 1.2% and retail inventories increased 2.0%, excluding autos. The economy grew at a 2.3% annualized rate in the third quarter, but trade deficits may continue to affect growth in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: The US trade deficit in goods mushroomed to a record in November as imports surged and exports slipped.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Wednesday, rising 5.15 points to 1545.04. The index saw 2.405 billion lots traded worth RM1.832 billion, with 462 gainers and 393 losers.

site_title: Biolidics receives MOH nod to conduct Covid-19 PCR tests
summary: Biolidics, a medtech firm, announced that its subsidiary, Biomedics Laboratory, has received approval from the Ministry of Health to provide Covid-19 PCR tests. The approval, subject to sales, is expected to contribute positively to the company's revenue amid the pandemic. Biolidics shares rose 3.5% after the announcement, following a previous expectation to start producing a Covid-19 rapid test kit commercially by the end of the year. The company's financial impact from the approval cannot be quantified due to uncertainty over sales uptake.

images.alt_text: An antigen rapid test kit manufactured by Biolidics.

site_title: Alibaba exploring options for Weibo stake with state firm
summary: Alibaba is exploring options for selling its 30% stake in Weibo, a Twitter-like social media service, amid Beijing's efforts to curb tech giants' influence in the media sphere. The state-owned conglomerate Shanghai Media Group (SMG) is reportedly in talks with Alibaba about a potential deal. This move comes as regulators seek to curtail the power of China's largest corporations, particularly those with significant media holdings. Weibo, which has over 248 million daily active users, has faced criticism for its content moderation practices, leading to a fine and reprimand from Chinese authorities.

site_title: Sri Lanka downplays default fears
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank downplayed fears of a debt default, citing a nearly doubling of foreign currency reserves to $3.1 billion, sufficient to cover a month's imports. The move comes after Fitch downgraded the country's debt rating, citing an increased probability of default. The central bank disputed the rating agency's decisions, saying they were "hasty and inexplicable." The government has imposed an import ban to shore up reserves, causing shortages of essential goods. The bank remains confident that its reserve position will remain "comfortable" throughout 2022.

site_title: GP Industries' shares rise 3.5% after rechargeable battery business restructuring announcement
summary: GP Industries' shares rose 3.5% to close at S$0.60 after announcing a demerger between its rechargeable batteries business and other business segments. The company plans to transfer its interest in the rechargeable batteries business to an unlisted investment holding company, GP Energy Tech, and offer investors a cash alternative or a share distribution. The proposed distribution is subject to shareholder approval and is expected to bring a clearer focus to the company's core business segments.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,138.02 points on Wednesday, driven by gains from Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) and Thai Beverage (ThaiBev). The top performer was FLCT, which increased 1.3%, while the bottom performer was Dairy Farm International Holdings, which fell 1.7%. Key Asian markets, including Japan, South Korea, and Hong Kong, ended lower, tracking Wall Street losses.

site_title: World hits record number of Covid cases in a week; more than 935,000 cases each day
summary: The world has hit a record number of Covid infections in a 7-day period, with over 935,000 cases detected daily on average between Dec 22-28, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). This is the highest since the virus emerged in 2019, with most cases occurring in Europe, where over 3.5 million cases were recorded in the last 7 days. Despite the increase in cases, deaths remain low, averaging around 6,450 per day, the lowest since October 2020.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open mixed as London returns
summary: Europe's stocks opened mixed on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.9% to 7,437.55 points, while eurozone equities declined. Frankfurt's DAX index fell 0.2% and the Paris CAC 40 eased 0.1%. The mixed performance followed solid gains on Tuesday.

site_title: China's top quant hedge fund High-Flyer apologises for losses
summary: China's top quant hedge fund, High-Flyer, apologized for a record slump in performance, citing mistimed trades and a complex market environment. The firm, which managed about $19.1 billion in assets, reported a significant decline in performance, with some clients experiencing losses. High-Flyer attributed the decline to its artificial intelligence failing to time trades well, and is adjusting its models, controlling its size, and lowering stock position concentration. The move highlights challenges facing China's quant hedge fund industry as regulatory scrutiny intensifies and popular trades become crowded.

site_title: Singapore, China ink 14 pacts to step up cooperation, including an ETF product link
summary: Singapore and China signed 14 memoranda of understanding (MOUs) and agreements to boost cooperation in areas such as the Belt and Road Initiative, trade, finance, and sustainability. The agreements include a link between Singapore's bond trading platform and China's, enabling greater investor access to China's bond market. Additionally, a link between exchange traded funds (ETF) products was established, allowing fund managers to offer products to investors in both countries. The collaborations aim to expand financial cooperation and promote economic growth.

images.alt_text: Fourteen Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) and agreements were announced at the 17th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation (JCBC). It was co-chaired by Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and China's Vice-Premier Han Zheng.

site_title: A million-pound artwork, once slated for demolition, finds a new home
summary: A 1-million-pound art installation, "Marabar" by Elyn Zimmerman, slated for demolition in Washington DC, has found a new home at American University. The National Geographic Society and the university reached a new agreement, allowing the installation to be relocated from its grounds to the university's campus. The agreement ends a nearly three-year debacle after the society initially decided to demolish the 1984 landmark. Advocates successfully campaigned to save the artwork, and excavation began this month with plans to install it at the university by summer 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Wednesday, tracking losses in mainland China and broader economic uncertainty. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.83% to 23,086.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. This follows economic uncertainty and losses in mainland China.

site_title: Deutsche Bank fined almost US$10m over Euribor controls
summary: Deutsche Bank has been fined nearly US$10 million by German financial regulator BaFin for inadequate controls related to the Euribor interest rate, a benchmark used in the financial industry. The fine, under a 2018 regulation aimed at preventing Euribor manipulation, marks a setback for the nation's largest lender as it seeks to restore its reputation. BaFin stated that Deutsche Bank lacked effective preventive systems, controls, and policies.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Koufu, a food court operator, received a S$425.8 million offer to be privatized, valuing the company at 15 times its pre-pandemic earnings. Halcyon Agri recorded a US$10.6 million gain from a land sale. Digilife Tech acquired a 71% stake in Stradbroke Investments for S$7.6 million. Chinese tech giants in Singapore are poaching local talent, with companies making better offers. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% higher at 3,138.02 points on Wednesday.

site_title: Air filters and outdoor spaces: Office costs rise
summary: Office costs are increasing as employees return to the workplace, driven by the need for more robust air filtration and newly installed outdoor spaces. Developers are investing in upgrades to improve ventilation, which could add 5-10% to monthly bills. Landlords are offering new amenities, such as rooftop and patio spaces, to lure tenants back. The cost of running the office today remains lower than pre-pandemic levels, but not as significantly as expected, due to various offsetting factors.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei retreats from 1-month high as chip stocks track US peers lower
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average declined 0.56% to 28,906.88 on Wednesday, retreating from a 1-month high, as chip-related stocks followed US peers lower. The broader Topix also fell 0.3%, with growth stocks down 0.63%. Chipmakers, such as Tokyo Electron and Trend Micro, were among the worst performers. The decline was attributed to a 0.48% loss on the tech-focused Nasdaq overnight.

site_title: Broadway's 'Music Man' is latest Covid victim as Jackman tests positive
summary: Broadway's revival of "The Music Man" has been canceled for five days after Hugh Jackman tested positive for COVID-19. Jackman reported mild symptoms and plans to return on stage after being cleared. The musical, which was set to open on February 10, is the latest New York City show to fall victim to the surge. Several other Broadway shows have also been forced to cancel performances due to COVID-19 cases, dealing a blow to the industry during its traditionally lean January and February season.

site_title: Koufu founders make S$0.77 per share cash offer to privatise company
summary: Koufu Group, a Singapore-based food court operator, has received a S$0.77 per share cash offer to privatise the company from its founding shareholders, valued at S$425.8 million. The offeror, Dominus Capital, represents a 15.8% premium over the last traded price. The deal, if successful, will give the offeror and the company greater control and allow shareholders to exit their investments. Analysts have mixed opinions on the offer, with some considering it a "decent" premium and others noting that investors may have paid more for the company's shares in the past.

site_title: Didi plans Hong Kong 'listing by introduction', picks banks: sources
summary: China's ride-hailing giant Didi Global plans to list shares in Hong Kong using a "listing by introduction" mechanism, allowing it to delist from the New York Stock Exchange. The move comes as Didi faces pressure from Beijing after running foul of Chinese authorities. Didi aims to file for the Hong Kong listing by end-April and list by June, with Goldman Sachs, China Merchants Bank International, and China Construction Bank International managing the process. The mechanism allows for a delisting without raising capital or issuing new shares.

site_title: Foxconn, Apple say worker dorms for India iPhone plant don't meet required standards
summary: Apple and Foxconn, the manufacturer of iPhones, have found that some worker dorms at a Foxconn plant in southern India do not meet required standards. The discovery came after a food poisoning outbreak in December, which prompted production to halt. Apple has dispatched independent auditors to assess conditions and is working with Foxconn to improve facilities. The facility has been placed "on probation" and Apple will ensure its strict standards are met before reopening. All employees will continue to be paid during the improvement process.

site_title: Chinese tech giants on talent poaching spree in Singapore
summary: Chinese tech giants are aggressively poaching talent in Singapore, offering higher salaries and perks to attract and retain top tech professionals. ByteDance, Ant Group, and other Chinese companies are hiring for various roles, including research and development functions, with some offering monthly salaries ranging from S$5,000 to S$22,000. This has led to a competitive job market, with even interns commanding high salaries. To stay competitive, tech companies are conducting formal compensation benchmark exercises, but pay is not the only factor, with in-demand talents valuing impact and autonomy over salary.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on ex-dividend date, Wall Street drop
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.89% on the ex-dividend date, with the Kospi index closing at 2,993.29, after investors sold shares and risk sentiment declined. On Wall Street, the S&P 500 closed slightly lower, snapping a 4-day rise, amid Omicron-driven travel disruptions. The won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners sold 121.8 billion won worth of shares, and the Kospi has risen 4.17% this year, but the won has lost 8.4% against the dollar.

site_title: Mercedes swept up in China Internet furore over model's eyes
summary: Mercedes-Benz removed a video advertisement from Chinese social media after it sparked a national debate over depictions of Asian-looking features by foreign companies. The video featured a woman with what some described as "slanted eyes," leading to public backlash and accusations of Western stereotypes about Asian people. The incident is the latest example of consumer nationalism in China, which has targeted brands like Dolce & Gabbana and Hennes & Mauritz in the past.

site_title: JD.com boosts share buyback as China clampdown weighs on tech
summary: JD.com boosts its share buyback plan by 50% to US$3 billion, extending the program until March 2024, amid China's regulatory crackdown on tech firms. The move follows similar announcements from rival e-commerce behemoth Alibaba and Tencent Holdings. JD.com's shares fell 2.1% on the news, as Chinese technology shares in Hong Kong declined 1.5% and tech stocks continue to slump due to increased oversight on antitrust and data security issues.

site_title: Hot stock: EC World Reit down as much as 6.9% after potential deal called off
summary: EC World Reit's units plummeted 6.9% after a potential deal to buy over 90% of its properties was called off due to fluctuations in exchange rates between renminbi and Singapore/US dollars. The consortium, finalizing the definitive terms, decided not to proceed citing current market conditions. As a result, 3.9 million units were traded at a low of S$0.745, with 4.7 million units changing hands by 11:58 am.

site_title: WHO warns of 'very high' Omicron risk as Covid surges worldwide
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned of a "very high" risk of Omicron-related illnesses as Covid-19 cases surge worldwide, with a 11% increase in global case numbers in the last week. The highly transmissible variant has overwhelmed healthcare systems in many countries, forcing governments to balance restrictions with economic needs. While some studies suggest Omicron causes milder Covid-19, the WHO urges caution, citing a growth advantage over the Delta variant and potential for hospitalizations, particularly among unvaccinated groups.

site_title: Thailand warns of spike in Covid-19 cases after 'super-spreader' event
summary: Thai health authorities have warned of a potential spike in Covid-19 cases after classifying the country's first cluster of the Omicron variant as a super-spreader incident. The cluster, linked to a couple who traveled from Belgium, infected hundreds and spread to 11 other provinces. Senior health official Opas Karnkawinpong urged residents to be cautious during the New Year, citing concerns over poor ventilation at crowded venues. Thailand has reported 740 cases of the Omicron variant, with daily case numbers expected to rise to 30,000 by March if measures are not tightened.

images.alt_text: The Omicron cluster identified in the northeastern province of Kalasin on Christmas eve has been linked to a couple who had travelled from Belgium and visited bars, concerts and markets.

site_title: Aspen terminates agreement to purchase land in Penang with Geo Valley
summary: Aspen, an indirect subsidiary of Malaysian developer Aspen (Group) Holdings, has terminated its conditional share and purchase agreement with Geo Valley to purchase land in Penang, Malaysia, due to non-fulfillment of conditions. Geo Valley will refund 24.4 million ringgit to Aspen and transfer its 25% equity in Aspen Park Hills to Aspen's subsidiary, Aspen Vision Homes. The termination is expected to have no material adverse impact on Aspen's financial performance.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Pansy Ho's Shun Tak walked away from a $556 million High Point deal in Singapore amid the latest property cooling measures. Businessman Ng Yu Zhi faces 6 new charges related to a $1.1 billion nickel trading scam, bringing the total to 75 charges. Loh Kean Yew, the new badminton world champion, received no prize money from his win. Gong Cha, the bubble tea business, is considering a sale or IPO, potentially worth $600 million. Singapore has frozen new bookings for VTL bus and flight entry before Jan 21, with VTL quotas and ticket sales to be reduced.

site_title: Tesla's Musk completes options-related sales plan-filing
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk completed stock sales related to his options set to expire next year, as announced in September. Musk exercised an option to buy 1.6 million shares and sold 934,090 shares for $1.02 billion to pay for taxes. This transaction completes his "preprogrammed" sales plan, with a total of 22.86 million stocks exercised, according to Reuters' calculation. Musk has sold approximately 10% of his Tesla stake, with a few tranches remaining.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares flat at Wednesday's open
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.40 point or 0.03% to 1,540.29. Volume was 26.8 million lots worth RM11.3 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 105 to 58.

site_title: Malaysian securities regulator charges Serba Dinamik, seeks arrest of CEO
summary: Malaysia's Securities Commission has charged Serba Dinamik Holdings' CEO Mohd Abdul Karim Abdullah with submitting a false statement to the stock exchange. The regulator is seeking his arrest and has issued a warrant. The false statement was related to a RM6 billion revenue figure published in Serba's quarterly report. An investigation was launched in May following concerns raised by external auditor KPMG about unverified contracts and transactions. Serba's shares have been suspended since Dec 15 after defaulting on a sukuk bond.

site_title: A cabinet of wonders opens wide
summary: The New York Public Library has unveiled its first permanent installation, "Treasures," showcasing over 250 items from its extensive research collections. The exhibition, supported by a $12 million gift, features medieval illuminated manuscripts, rare books, and artifacts from over 4,000 years of history. The display includes items such as Thomas Jefferson's handwritten copy of the Declaration of Independence, a Gutenberg Bible, and a 1971 cedar sculpture by Elizabeth Catlett. The exhibition aims to highlight the library's civic faith and the written word, with rotating cases dedicated to various themes.

site_title: Metaverse ETF appetite strong as ProShares files with SEC
summary: ProShares is planning to launch an exchange-traded fund (ETF) focused on the metaverse, tracking the Solactive Metaverse Theme Index. The index includes companies providing metaverse technologies, with top weightings from Apple, Meta Platforms, and Nvidia. This marks the latest firm to capitalize on the emerging metaverse trend, with global metaverse ETF assets reaching $2.2 billion. The ProShares Metaverse Theme ETF would join the successful Roundhill Ball Metaverse ETF, which has seen assets under management swell to $916 million since its launch in June.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 3,134.49 at Wednesday's open, driven by gains in FJ Benjamin and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while banking stocks were mixed. The US market closed lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones rising 0.3% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite slipping. European shares gained 0.6% and Tokyo shares opened flat.

site_title: Halcyon Agri to record US$10.6m gain from subsidiary's land sale
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation's indirectly-owned subsidiary, Tropical Rubber Cote d'Ivoire, sold 54.5 hectares of freehold land for US$19 million, resulting in a gain of approximately US$10.6 million. The sale is part of the group's deleveraging plan to strengthen its capital structure, and the proceeds will be invested in future growth of its core businesses. The transaction is expected to have a positive impact on earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Football: Son, Ji win South Korea's player of the year awards
summary: Son Heung-min and Ji So-yun have won South Korea's player of the year awards for a record 6th time each. Son, a Tottenham Hotspur player, topped a poll of KFA officials and journalists to win the male award for the third year in a row, while Ji, a Chelsea player, reclaimed the women's award. Both players achieved the record-breaking win in 2021, with Son scoring 22 times for Tottenham and Ji winning the domestic treble with Chelsea.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.59% at the open on Dec 29, 2021, weighed by Omicron variant fears. The Hang Seng Index dropped 138.48 points to 23,142.08. Similar declines were seen in the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices.

site_title: Chinese professor lands US$3.4b fortune with SenseTime IPO
summary: Chinese professor Tang Xiao'ou's AI company, SenseTime, priced its initial public offering at HK$3.85 per share, raising US$5.55 billion. Tang, 53, holds a 21% stake and is now worth US$3.4 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Despite US sanctions and a delayed listing, the company's shares are scheduled to start trading Dec 30 in Hong Kong, giving it a market value of over US$16 billion.

site_title: Carnival says most itineraries unchanged even as Omicron cases rise
summary: Carnival, the world's largest cruise operator, said most of its itineraries remain unchanged despite a surge in Omicron cases, which has raised concerns about a potential recovery in the cruise industry. Authorities in several Caribbean ports, Puerto Rico, and Mexico have disallowed passengers to disembark from ships with active Covid-19 cases, forcing Carnival to find alternative destinations. The US CDC has identified over 85 cruise ships with Covid-19 cases, prompting concerns of a possible temporary ban on cruising.

images.alt_text: Carnival said on Tuesday (Dec 28) a majority of its ships' itineraries were unchanged despite a surge in cases of the Omicron coronavirus variant, which has threatened to stall a recovery in the cruise industry.

site_title: Hong Kong November home prices drop for 2nd month, softening from peak
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 1.2% in November, the second consecutive month of decline, after reaching a record high in September. Despite this, analysts expect the property market to gain 10% in 2022 due to concerns that policy measures to cool the market may not be introduced. Consultancies Cushman & Wakefield and JLL forecast home prices to rise 6.5-10% and 5%, respectively, in 2022, driven by strong demand and low mortgage rates.

site_title: Delta, Alaska cancel hundreds of flights due to bad weather, Omicron cases
summary: Delta Air Lines and Alaska Air Group cancelled over 1,000 flights due to bad weather and rising Omicron cases, with 1,034 cancellations and 2,694 delays reported as of 2 pm ET on Tuesday. The US CDC said it's not considering a vaccine mandate for domestic flights, citing efforts to get people vaccinated instead. The average number of new Covid-19 cases in the US has risen 55% to over 205,000 per day. The CDC also shortened the recommended isolation time for asymptomatic infected Americans to 5 days.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat
summary: Tokyo shares opened flat on December 29, 2021, due to thin holiday trade. The Nikkei 225 index inched down 0.05% to 29,055.06, while the Topix index fell 0.10% to 2,002.95. This follows overnight gains on Wall Street.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest 6 from online media outlet
summary: Hong Kong's Police National Security Department arrested 6 current or former staff from pro-democracy news website Stand News, including Ronson Chan, for conspiracy to publish seditious publications. The arrests come after hundreds of police raided the premises of Apple Daily in June, leading to the newspaper's shutdown. Searches of the staff's homes are underway. The charges follow a trend of police crackdowns on pro-democracy media outlets in Hong Kong.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip as investors ready for end of 2021
summary: Asian stocks slipped 0.25% on Wednesday, December 29, as investors positioned portfolios for the new year and grappled with rising Omicron cases. Despite a volatile US trade session, Hong Kong and Chinese blue chips fell, while Japan's Nikkei slid 0.58%. Australia's ASX 200 rose 1% despite a surge in coronavirus cases. Investors are rethinking portfolio positions, focusing on companies that can pass on inflation and firms with dividend growth, as Omicron fatality rates remain low and lockdowns seem unlikely.

images.alt_text: Asian stocks slipped on Wednesday (Dec 29), following a mixed Wall Street session as the region's investors positioned their portfolios for the new year and continued to grapple with increasing global numbers of Omicron coronavirus cases.

site_title: Digilife Tech to acquire 71% stake in Stradbroke Investments for S$7.6m
summary: Digilife Tech has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a 71% stake in Stradbroke Investments for S$7.6 million, issuing 5.5 million shares at S$1.39 per share. The acquisition is expected to allow Digilife Tech to re-strategize its financial and capital resources, enter the digital application space, and access other businesses in Papua New Guinea. The deal is subject to shareholders' approval and is considered a major transaction under SGX listing rules.

site_title: Rivian delays deliveries of pickup, SUV with big battery packs to 2023
summary: Rivian Automotive has delayed deliveries of its electric pickup truck and SUV with large battery packs to 2023 due to production challenges. The company cited global supply-chain constraints, the Covid-19 pandemic, and labor market issues. Most of the 71,000 preorders in the US and Canada are for the smaller battery pack option, which provides 314 miles of range. Only 20% of preorders are for the larger battery pack option, which offers 400 miles of range. Rivian will prioritize building the larger battery pack version to meet the demand of most preorder holders.

site_title: Apple aims to prevent defections to Meta with rare US$180,000 bonuses: sources
summary: Apple has issued unusual stock bonuses to some engineers, worth up to $180,000, to retain talent and prevent defections to tech rivals like Meta Platforms. The bonuses, which vest over 4 years, are part of a larger effort to maintain engineering prowess in areas like augmented reality, artificial intelligence, and hardware engineering. The move comes as Apple faces competition from Meta, which has hired around 100 Apple engineers in recent months, and as the company navigates the shift to remote work.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends lower after 4-day rally to record high
summary: The S&P 500 closed slightly lower, ending a 4-day rally to a record high, as investors weighed Omicron-driven travel disruptions and store closures. The CDC shortened the recommended isolation time for asymptomatic Covid-19 cases to 5 days, helping to alleviate concerns. Despite this, the market was affected by thin trading and concerns over the Omicron variant and potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Egypt 'digitally unwraps' mummy of famed pharaoh
summary: Egypt has digitally unwrapped the mummy of Pharaoh Amenhotep I, revealing new mummification techniques used over 1,500 years ago. The research, led by Cairo University's Sahar Saleem and Egyptologist Zahi Hawass, used advanced 3D imagery to analyze the pharaoh's remains without disturbing his funerary mask. The study provides insight into the pharaoh's rule and mummification methods, shedding new light on ancient Egyptian practices.

site_title: Yen hits 1-month low as Omicron concerns ease
summary: The Japanese yen fell to a near 1-month low against the US dollar, weakening to 114.935 yen per dollar, before recovering to 114.80, amid easing concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant. The dollar index remained stable, while US equities reached a record high, despite expectations of a faster pace of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Markets are pricing in a 50% chance of a first quarter point rate hike by March, and the yen is expected to test its 2021 low in the near term.

site_title: Stocks to watch: EC World Reit, SGX, ComfortDelGro, CDL, Digilife Tech
summary: Key developments in the Singapore stock market include EC World Reit, where potential buyers have backed out of talks, causing its units to close at S$0.80. Singapore Exchange (SGX) announced a memorandum of understanding with the Shenzhen Stock Exchange to establish an exchange-traded fund link, resulting in a 0.9% increase in its shares to S$9.38.

site_title: From Qatar World Cup to Rio carnival: 6 key events in 2022
summary: Key events in 2022 include the Beijing Winter Olympics, where China will stage the games under strict rules, and the Rio Carnival, which is expected to return after the pandemic. The FIFA World Cup in Qatar is also set to take place, marking the first time the tournament will be held in the Middle East. China's President Xi Jinping is expected to secure an unprecedented third term in office, while US Republicans are bidding to retake both chambers of Congress in the midterm elections. Additionally, the Glastonbury music festival is set to return in June after being cancelled in 2020 due to the pandemic.

site_title: Moderna sheds US$98b in value as stock slumps 50% from peak
summary: Moderna's stock has slumped 50% from its record high in August, wiping US$98 billion from its market value. The decline comes amid the Omicron variant and recent FDA authorizations for Pfizer and Merck's coronavirus pills. Despite this, Moderna's shares are still up 131% for the year, making it one of the top performers in the S&P 500. Fellow Covid-19 vaccine maker Pfizer also declined, while BioNTech is on its longest losing streak since September 2020.

site_title: Oil settles higher despite Omicron concerns
summary: Oil prices settled higher on Tuesday, with Brent crude ending the session near US$80 a barrel, despite concerns over the rapid spread of the Omicron coronavirus variant. Supply outages and expectations of a drop in US crude inventories supported the price increase. Oil producers in Ecuador, Libya, and Nigeria declared forces majeures due to maintenance issues and oilfield shutdowns. US President Joe Biden pledged to ease a shortage of Covid-19 tests as the Omicron variant threatens to overwhelm hospitals.

site_title: 20 years on, dreams of euro rivalling US dollar persist
summary: Twenty years after its adoption, the euro still lags behind the US dollar in global value, with the US dollar holding about 60% of foreign-exchange reserves and the euro around 20%. Despite efforts to promote the euro as a tool of power, including by the European Commission, the dollar remains the dominant currency. Experts attribute the euro's limited international role to a lack of a safe asset, such as a euro equivalent to the US treasury bond, and instead emphasize the need for a productive European economy to strengthen the euro's value.

site_title: Europe: 'Santa Rally' pushes shares to 5-week highs
summary: European shares rose 0.6% to a 5-week high on Tuesday, driven by strong US market gains despite concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant. Analysts attribute the "Santa Rally" to risk appetite, with the Stoxx 600 aiming for its best month since March and a 22.4% gain in 2021. Most European markets, including Spain's IBEX and Germany's DAX, rose, while the French government announced tighter measures to combat the spread of Omicron.

site_title: Here's how the manufacturing sector will be impacted in 2022
summary: The manufacturing sector in 2022 will be impacted by key findings including a skills gap due to rapid technological changes and an ageing workforce. To overcome this, manufacturers must upskill employees and encourage students to enter the field through collaborations with educational institutions. Additionally, public and private collaborative smart factory research initiatives, sustainability transparency, and integration of manufacturing supply chain visibility will be crucial. Businesses must also prioritize digital solutions to analyze data and improve manufacturing productivity, inventory management, and reduce unplanned downtimes.

site_title: Singapore's updated insolvency kit may see more use next year as government support tapers off
summary: Singapore's updated insolvency kit, the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act (IRDA), may see increased use next year as government support tapers off. The IRDA, introduced in 2020, provides a kinder approach to firms trying to free themselves from debt. Rescue financing, debt workouts, and pre-pack schemes have been effective tools, with rescue financing ranking equally or above senior creditors and debt workouts slashing costs and keeping the distribution pie bigger for creditors. Experts predict a "significant uptick" in insolvency applications as aid packages end and the economy recovers.

site_title: Jan will see large amount of new condo supply launched in Greater Bangkok: consultancy
summary: The Bangkok condo market is expected to be more active in January 2022, with a large amount of new condo supply set to be launched in Greater Bangkok, according to Colliers International Thailand. The consultancy forecasts a 28.5% growth in new condo supply, with 24,000 units launching next year, mostly in outer Bangkok areas. Despite the COVID-19 Omicron variant, developers are better prepared and plan to launch projects after delaying in 2021. The low-rise housing segment is expected to remain robust, and developers are focusing on differentiating their properties with new selling points or services.

site_title: Swiss-EU relationship could fall apart if talks fail: EU
summary: The European Union's relationship with Switzerland could deteriorate or even collapse if negotiations over Switzerland's place in the EU internal market fail, according to European Commission vice-president Maros Sefcovic. The talks broke off in May over concerns about sovereignty, and Sefcovic stated that if negotiations fail, bilateral agreements would expire and make their relationship obsolete. The EU demands Switzerland agree to a dynamic alignment of laws, a level playing field, and regular contributions to EU funds. Sefcovic urged Switzerland to set out a clear timetable for resolving EU internal market issues by January.

site_title: Investing at market peaks
summary: Investor Dan invests at market peaks, only to see his portfolio value rise significantly over time. Despite experiencing significant market corrections, Dan's portfolio has delivered an average annual return of 6.1% from his initial $200,000 investment. This strategy challenges the conventional wisdom of buying at market bottoms and selling at peaks. Instead, Dan's disciplined approach focuses on capturing the long-term growth of equity markets, highlighting the importance of time and discipline in investing.

site_title: Data centres, 5G and technology are possible re-ratings catalysts for telcos
summary: Singapore's telecoms market is expected to continue competing in 2022, but analysts see opportunities for market players to diversify into new segments and reposition themselves for higher stock market valuations. The adoption of 5G is a key driver of these opportunities, with initial use cases mainly in the enterprise sector. Singtel, StarHub, and M1 are enhancing their enterprise offerings, aiming to reposition their business as a tech company and expand data centre capacity.

site_title: Ansell halts orders from Malaysian glovemaker Brightway after US ban
summary: ANSELL has halted orders from Malaysian glovemaker Brightway Group due to a US Customs ban following allegations of forced labor practices. The ban, imposed on Dec 20, led Ansell to suspend North America orders until Brightway resolves the labor issues. Ansell previously identified non-compliance at Brightway facilities through third-party audits and is working closely with the company on remediation plans. The company prefers to work with suppliers to ensure continued employment and improved conditions for workers rather than cancelling contracts in response to allegations.

images.alt_text: Ansell has halted its orders to North America from Malaysian glovemaker Brightway Group after US Customs banned the Malaysian group's products following allegations of forced labour practices, Ansell said.

site_title: For pop music, 2021 was the year of the deep dive
summary: In 2021, the pandemic led to a surge in music documentaries that delved deep into the creative process, artistic production, and personal struggles of musicians. Notable documentaries included "The Beatles: Get Back," "Velvet Underground," "Summer of Soul (...Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised)," and "The World's a Little Blurry" about Billie Eilish's early career. These films showcased the complexities of memory, artistic innovation, and the pressures of fame, offering a unique perspective on the music industry and its legends.

site_title: US says China visa applications in line with Olympic boycott
summary: The US maintains its diplomatic boycott of the Beijing Winter Olympics, despite China announcing visa applications from US officials. The boycott was announced earlier this month due to "crimes against humanity in Xinjiang and other human rights abuses." The US State Department confirmed that visa applications were for consular and security personnel, not athletes or officials. China denies allegations of genocide in Xinjiang and claims to provide job training and educational opportunities.

images.alt_text: Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian said at a regular press briefing on Monday that Beijing had received visa applications from US officials for the Olympics.

site_title: Return of China's prodigals
summary: China is encouraging its companies to return home by delisting from foreign exchanges and re-listing in either Hong Kong or the mainland. This process is expected to have predictable results and unpredictable consequences. To invest in China, it's recommended to focus on policy-supported sectors and themes, and limit exposure to strategic asset allocation. The recent monetary policy easing measures by China's central bank are insufficient to justify an overweight allocation to China equities. A more forceful policy shift is needed for a genuine recovery in Chinese risk assets.

site_title: Travellers urged not to buy Singapore-JB VTL tickets through third parties
summary: Singaporean bus operators Transtar Travel and Causeway Link have warned travellers not to buy VTL tickets through third parties, citing risks of inflated prices and compromised personal data. The operators advise purchasing tickets directly from their official channels, website, or Shopee, to avoid scams. The warning comes as some individuals are selling tickets on behalf of travellers at inflated prices, with some listings asking for up to eight times the normal price.

site_title: Integrating financial planning with gerontology
summary: Financial planning is evolving to incorporate insights from gerontology, a study of aging and human development, to address the growing needs of an aging population. Financial gerontology focuses on caregiving, family relationships, health, retirement, and economics to improve the quality of life of older people. As life expectancy increases, financial planners must provide complex advice on asset preservation, longevity, and aging. Integrating financial planning with gerontology can help clients navigate the aging process, anticipate potential impacts, and achieve financial well-being. This holistic approach is crucial for older adults to age successfully and live with dignity.

images.alt_text: Financial gerontology focuses on caregiving, family relationships, health, retirement and economics to improve quality of life.

site_title: Expect more turbulent years ahead for oil producers
summary: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) has faced a turbulent time since its formation in 2016 to counter the US shale boom. Despite initial production cuts, the group has shown remarkable cohesion and flexibility in adjusting supply to evolving demand. However, the future looks uncertain, with a looming supply shortfall expected by the end of the decade, and the group's ability to meet growing demand in a transition to fossil fuels. Opec+ producers will face pressure to cut output and balance the market, with Russia's spare capacity expected to be depleted within the next two years.

site_title: GCB deals volume set to ease, but prices expected to remain firm
summary: Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market is expected to see a slowdown in volume deals in 2022, but prices are anticipated to remain firm due to continued strong demand from ultra-high-net-worth individuals, entrepreneurs, and families. The supply of GCBs for sale has decreased following strong sales momentum in 2020 and 2021. Despite cooling measures, prices are expected to appreciate at a slower pace, with some areas, such as prime locations near the Singapore Botanic Gardens, continuing to draw suitors. Observers predict that GCB prices may increase by 5-7% in 2022, with some areas seeing a 20-30% increase in prices, and others, such as non-prime areas, seeing a 15-20% increase.

site_title: Saudi Arabia seeks to become a cultural hub as other Arab states falter
summary: Saudi Arabia is aggressively investing in its film industry, with a goal of becoming a major cultural hub in the Middle East. The kingdom has funded homegrown productions, sponsored filmmakers to study abroad, and established studios, with a target of 2,600 screens by 2030. Despite challenges, including decades of lagging behind in building a skilled creator class and social conservatism, Saudi Arabia's efforts may bolster the region's filmmakers, particularly Egyptian studios, which are already collaborating with Saudi producers. The push reflects broader shifts in the Arab world's creative industries, where conflicts, economic meltdowns, and state failures have damaged cultural legacies.

site_title: Tesla has 30% upside in 2022 on China demand: analyst
summary: Tesla is poised for a strong 2022 with 30% upside potential, according to Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives. China demand is expected to drive growth, with the country accounting for 40% of deliveries. New factories in the US and Germany will alleviate production bottlenecks. Ives estimates Tesla's annual production capacity will reach 2 million cars by the end of 2022, up from 1 million today, as demand outstrips supply. The analyst maintains an outperform rating and $1,400 price target for the company.

site_title: Lessons for digital transformation
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated digital adoption globally, with 60 million new digital consumers in South-east Asia since the pandemic began. Companies that underwent digital transformation were better prepared to meet the challenges and demands of the pandemic. A digital transformation requires a tech transformation, talent and culture adjustments, sponsor buy-in, innovation freedom, and incremental scaling. Digital tools will play a key role in accelerating the transition to a sustainable economy, enabling companies to measure, track, and manage sustainability goals, and increase workforce productivity. Despite challenges, companies are already using digital to solve sustainability issues, and successful digital transformations will lead to a more sustainable and equitable world.

site_title: Farewell to another strange year
summary: The shipping industry has shown resilience and resourcefulness in 2021, recovering well from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Freight rates skyrocketed, benefiting big container carriers. The Suez Canal blockade, which caused a 6-day jam, highlighted the industry's complexity, with many media outlets misunderstanding the situation. The cruise industry also faced challenges, but has seen a gradual recovery, with a focus on safety and fewer ports of call. In contrast, the tanker sector has struggled due to low demand, while bulk carriers have done relatively well, with analysts predicting a market downturn.

site_title: Malaysia's Minority Shareholders Watch Group to raise coverage to 450 listcos by mid-2022: CEO
summary: Malaysia's Minority Shareholders Watch Group (MSWG) plans to expand its coverage of listed companies on Bursa Malaysia to 450 by mid-2022, from 330 currently. The move aims to protect minority investors from unhealthy practices, such as related-party transactions and takeovers at unfair prices. MSWG's CEO, Devanesan Evanson, notes that the watchdog's role is crucial in deterring miscreants, but faces growing demands from market stakeholders and limitations in its ability to regulate the stock market.

site_title: Leading climate strategy from the board
summary: A global survey of 300 board directors found a significant gap between directors' statements and actions on climate change. While 75% believe climate change is crucial to their company's success, only 43% of companies have set greenhouse gas emission targets, and 50% are dissatisfied with current climate reporting. Directors need to prioritize climate knowledge, integrate climate change into executive performance metrics and investment decisions, and adopt more ESG-savvy directors to accelerate progress. Implementing these recommendations can help boards make real progress on addressing climate change.

site_title: ComfortDelGro unit divests Vietnamese taxi company
summary: ComfortDelGro, a transport operator, announced it will divest its 70% stake in Vietnamese taxi company VTCL to Helios Service and Investment Joint Stock Company for approximately S$3.3 million. The divestment has no material impact on ComfortDelGro's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2021 financial year. This move is not expected to affect the company's shares, which closed up 1.5% on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Developers, en-bloc hopefuls will need to meet in the middle in the wake of cooling measures
summary: Singapore's property sector is facing a cooling down after the government introduced new measures to curb exuberance. The measures include higher additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rates, ranging from 17% to 30%, and a tightening of the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) to 55%. This has led to developers pulling out of en-bloc acquisitions and potentially cutting prices. Smaller- to medium-sized sites are expected to be more attractive to developers, who may also form joint ventures to minimize risk. En-bloc hopefuls will need to temper their price expectations to meet developers on middle ground.

site_title: Singapore startups look to Russia amid tech labour crunch
summary: Singapore startups are turning to Russia to address a tech labor crunch in the city-state, participating in accelerator programs and tapping into tax incentives, free office space, and government grants. Despite reputational risks due to alleged government-linked cybersecurity hacks, many startups see opportunities in Russia's large pool of scientific and technological talent. Experts say Russian engineers are more affordable and skilled than those in Singapore, with some even surpassing those with 3-5 years of experience. Companies like Google and Yandex are also eyeing Russia's tech talent pool, with salaries ranging from S$7,000 to S$16,000 per month.

site_title: Bitcoin slides below US$50,000
summary: Bitcoin has slid below US$50,000, falling as much as 4.5% on Tuesday, with some analysts viewing this level as key for assessing the cryptocurrency's outlook. Investors are retreating from speculative markets due to concerns about central bank stimulus, but analysts say Bitcoin's disposition remains bullish if the US$48,000 to US$49,000 level holds. Technical studies suggest a potential tipping point for Bitcoin, with some analysts predicting a support level of US$44,200.

site_title: China simplifies bond issuance in Hong Kong for domestic institutions
summary: China's central bank simplified bond issuance procedures for domestic financial institutions in Hong Kong, aiming to improve foreign debt management. The current outdated rules have been scrapped, making it easier for institutions to issue yuan bonds in Hong Kong or other countries. This move reflects China's efforts to streamline its financial regulations and enhance cooperation with international financial institutions.

site_title: China slams US after space station's 'close encounters' with Musk's satellites
summary: China has accused the US of irresponsible and unsafe conduct in space after two "close encounters" between China's space station and satellites operated by Elon Musk's SpaceX. The incidents, which occurred in July and October, required the Chinese space station to perform evasive manoeuvres to avoid collisions. China's foreign ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian said the US ignores its obligations under international treaties, posing a threat to the lives and safety of astronauts. The US has not responded to the request for comment.

site_title: Miami's financial district to get another new luxury condo tower
summary: Miami-based developer Mast Capital plans to build a new 80-story luxury condo tower in the city's financial district, Brickell. The $103 million project will feature 400 condos, 850 rentals, and 1,650 parking spaces. The development aims for a $1 billion sellout, partnering a luxury lifestyle brand for "resort-style" amenities. This new project follows a pandemic-fueled boom in the area, with condo rents increasing over 30% since the first quarter. The development is part of a growing trend in Miami's financial district, targeting new arrivals to maintain demand in the red-hot market.

site_title: US, Russia set for Jan 10 security talks amid Ukraine tensions
summary: US and Russian officials will hold security talks on Jan 10 to discuss concerns about military activity and rising tensions over Ukraine. Russia seeks military guarantees, while the US has promised economic sanctions if Russia attacks Ukraine. The talks will be followed by a NATO meeting on Jan 12 and a broader meeting on Jan 13 involving Moscow, Washington, and other European countries. Russia has massed troops near Ukraine, raising fears of a potential new attack, but denies plans for an assault.

site_title: Singapore stocks ride on Santa Claus rally to close higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% on Tuesday, closing at 3,128.41 points, driven by a positive Santa Claus rally on Wall Street. The market saw 290 gainers and 175 losers, with Dairy Farm International Holdings being the top performer. Sentiment was also lifted across Asian markets, with key indices in Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, and Malaysia rising 0.2-1.4%.

site_title: China's Ant Group to close crowdfunded medical aid service
summary: Ant Group, a fintech affiliate of Alibaba, announced it will shut down its online crowdfunded medical aid service Xianghubao on Jan 28 due to significant changes in the industry and tightening financial technology regulations in China. Xianghubao, which had served over 100 million members since its launch in 2018, will cease operations as regulators crack down on unlicensed online financial activities. The move follows similar shutdowns of other leading players in the mutual aid industry, including Waterdrop and Meituan.

site_title: EU at crossroads: Why 2022 will be a big year for France and Europe
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is set for a busy 2022, with a re-election bid in April and a six-month presidency of the European Union starting next week. Macron aims to push for deeper European integration and growth, including a potential European Defence Union, amidst concerns over Russia's military build-up and the spread of the Omicron variant. However, not everyone shares his vision, with countries like Poland rejecting EU primacy over national legislation, potentially leading to a pro-integration agenda being pursued through coalitions of the willing. The EU's future remains uncertain, with Macron's re-election and the presidency likely to shape the bloc's economic and political character.

site_title: Germany buys Pfizer's Covid pill amid surging Omicron cases
summary: Germany is purchasing 1 million packs of Pfizer's Paxlovid, a COVID-19 treatment pill, amid the rapid spread of the Omicron variant. The pill is seen as promising for high-risk patients, and Germany expects its first deliveries in January. With a 43% increase in Omicron cases reported, Germany aims to fully inoculate 80% of its population by the end of January. The country has also implemented stricter COVID-19 rules, including limits on private gatherings.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Tuesday, up 5.98 points to 1539.89. The index saw 2.156 billion lots traded worth RM1.653 billion, with gainers outnumbering losers 592-303.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.24% to 23,280.56, driven by a see-saw session. Macau casino stocks fell sharply after reporting its first Omicron case. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, adding 0.39% and 0.83% respectively.

site_title: In euro waiting room, Bulgarians divided about joining
summary: Bulgaria is divided on joining the eurozone by 2024, with some citizens, like tennis instructor Krasimir Atanasov, eager to adopt the single currency, while others, like nationalist Valeria Petrova, fear it may lead to higher prices and debt. Finance Minister Assen Vassilev has promised a broad public debate, and economists believe there is a relative consensus across the political spectrum in support of eurozone entry. However, concerns about price rises, debt, and corruption may hinder Bulgaria's entry, with Brussels requiring strict measures to be taken before admitting the country.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Southeast Asia's startup ecosystem has seen a surge in secondary transactions as early investors look to exit their portfolio companies and private equity players enter the market. Singapore's highest rents in 6 years have fueled expat housing woes. Pavilion Energy, a unit of Temasek, has secured a deal to supply small-scale LNG to Zhejiang Hangjiaxin. Chia Seok Hoon has rejoined Citi as Singapore global subsidiaries group head. Singapore made a push for electric vehicle adoption in 2021, and the Straits Times Index rose 0.8% on Tuesday, driven by a Santa Claus rally on Wall Street.

site_title: SIA redesignates Hsieh Tsun-yan as non-independent director
summary: Singapore Airlines redesignates Hsieh Tsun-yan as a non-independent director, effective January 1, 2022. Hsieh, who has served on the board for over 9 years, will remain on several committees. He sold off shares in June, generating S$84, and continues to hold 39,250 ordinary shares. The redesignation comes amid SIA's bourse filing, with shares closing up 1% on the news.

site_title: China local Covid-19 cases up for 4th day as Xian outbreak expands
summary: China has reported a fourth consecutive day of local Covid-19 cases, with 175 symptomatic cases in Xian, a north-western city under lockdown. No Omicron infections have been reported. The city's 13 million residents are restricted from shopping and leaving without clearance. Nationwide, mainland China detected 182 local symptomatic cases, the highest daily count since March last year. Officials aim to contain the Xian outbreak by mid-January, but residents face uncertainty about when shopping restrictions will be lifted.

site_title: India 10-year bond yield at 20-month high; central bank support eyed
summary: India's benchmark 10-year bond yield rose to a 20-month high due to investor caution over heavy government debt, rising global oil prices, and a lack of central bank support. The yield reached 6.49%, its highest since April 2020, ahead of a debt auction on Friday. Traders expect the central bank to provide some form of support to ease market pressure, citing rising oil prices and high domestic inflation. The RBI sold 20.35 billion rupees in open market operations last week, further driving up yields.

site_title: Europe: Markets open higher after Wall Street surge
summary: Europe's major stock markets opened higher on Tuesday, following a strong showing on Wall Street. The Eurozone's Frankfurt DAX index and Paris CAC 40 rose 0.2% to 15,868.47 and 7,157.82 points, respectively. Investors appear confident that the Omicron variant won't derail the global economic recovery, despite US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Philippines ends open pit mining ban to reinvigorate industry
summary: The Philippines has lifted a 4-year-old ban on open-pit mining for copper, gold, silver, and complex ores, allowing stalled and new mining projects to attract investments and stimulate the economy. Environment Secretary Roy Cimatu signed an administrative order lifting the ban, which was imposed in 2017 to address environmental concerns. The move is expected to increase the country's annual export revenue from its mineral extraction industry by up to $2 billion over the next 5-6 years. Environmental activists have expressed dismay over the policy reversal, citing concerns about environmental damage.

site_title: Chinese VC firm Eastern Bell raises US$2b for latest yuan and dollar funds
summary: Chinese venture capital firm Eastern Bell Capital has raised over US$2.04 billion in its latest funding round, boosting its investment firepower. The firm's total assets under management reached 27 billion yuan. The yuan-denominated fund attracted government funds, banks, and insurers, while the dollar fund drew overseas sovereign wealth funds and pension funds. Eastern Bell Capital will continue to invest in industrial digitalisation and consumption upgrades, following a recovery in venture capital and private equity funding in China, which reached US$645.8 billion in the first 11 months of this year.

site_title: Malaysia shortens booster jab interval, lifts African nations travel ban
summary: Malaysia shortens its Covid-19 booster jab interval to 3 months for all adults, halving the previous interval, in an effort to slow the spread of the Omicron variant. The country also lifts its travel ban on 8 African nations, adding them to the list of high-risk countries. Malaysia has detected 306 possible Omicron cases among travelers and advises against non-essential travel to 18 high-risk countries.

site_title: Hong Kong to tighten air crew quarantine rules amid Omicron threat
summary: Hong Kong health authorities have tightened quarantine rules for air cargo crew amid the growing threat of the Omicron coronavirus variant. The new measures require returning air crew to spend 3 days in hotel quarantine before a period of home isolation. This follows several dozen Omicron infections detected among air crew who previously only had to quarantine at home. The move aims to prevent the spread of the variant into the community, with officials warning of a high risk of a fifth wave of infections. Vaccination rates in Hong Kong remain low, with less than 70% of the eligible population having received two doses.

site_title: Temasek's Pavilion Energy to supply small-scale LNG to Zhejiang Hangjiaxin
summary: TEMASEK-OWNED Pavilion Energy has signed a term deal with China's Zhejiang Hangjiaxin Clean Energy Co to supply up to 0.5 million tonnes per year of small-scale liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Singapore starting in 2023. The LNG will be delivered to a terminal in Zhejiang to be operated by Hangjiaxin, a joint venture between Jiaxing Gas and Hangzhou Gas. This agreement will provide Hangjiaxin with its own terminal, offering its end users more clean energy options.

site_title: Chia Seok Hoon rejoins Citi as Singapore global subsidiaries group head
summary: Chia Seok Hoon has rejoined Citi Singapore as the head of its global subsidiaries group, succeeding Gilbert Ng. In her new role, Chia reports to Ng and Munir Nanji, and will lead the group serving top-tier multinational clients globally. Chia brings experience from her previous stint at HSBC, where she led a team supporting locals and regional multinationals in Singapore. Her appointment comes as Citi supports clients in their environmental sustainability journey and leverages Singapore as a base for tapping Asia's growth.

site_title: China injects most cash in 2 months as demand for fund jumps
summary: China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) injected 200 billion yuan (S$42.5 billion) of cash into the financial system, the highest in 2 months, to alleviate liquidity pressure. The move came after a surge in demand for liquidity and a 15 basis point drop in the 7-day repo rate to 2.27%. The injection aims to support the nation's economic recovery from the pandemic and ease liquidity shortages in the interbank market, where costs on contracts soared to 5.2%. The PBOC pledged to use monetary policy tools more "proactively" to support growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rises to 1-month high driven by Wall Street strength
summary: Japan's Nikkei index rose to a 1-month high, closing at 29,069.16, driven by strong retail sales data and a surge in factory output, particularly in the auto sector. The S&P 500 index also ended at a record high, boosting risk sentiment. Technology stocks led gains, with Sony Group and precision makers experiencing significant increases. The market is expected to maintain momentum if the US market remains strong, but some investors may sell shares to gain profits if the market continues to rise.

site_title: Tencent's Riot Games settles gender discrimination suit for US$100m
summary: Riot Games, a subsidiary of Tencent Holdings, has settled a 2018 gender discrimination class-action suit for $100 million. The settlement will pay $80 million to current and former female employees and contractors who worked since 2014, and $20 million to attorneys' fees and expenses. The company agreed to oversee its pay processes for three years. This settlement comes as the video games industry faces reckoning over sexism in both content and workplace practices, following similar lawsuits against Activision Blizzard.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX cleared in Indonesia, scene of first fatal crash
summary: Indonesia has cleared Boeing's 737 MAX planes to operate in its skies after completing an investigation process and implementing improvements to the aircraft's system. The country joins neighbors Malaysia, Singapore, and India in lifting the ban on the aircraft, which was grounded following fatal crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia in 2018 and 2019. The US and Brazil had cleared the plane in late 2020, and other major markets, including Europe, have also lifted their bans. China, however, remains grounded, with a test flight conducted in August.

site_title: Indian capital closes cinemas, schools as Covid cases rise
summary: New Delhi has closed cinemas, schools, and gyms due to rising Omicron-related Covid infections, with a 0.5% case positivity rate over the last 2 days. The city has implemented restrictions, including a night curfew, 50% occupancy limits in bars and restaurants, and online-only schooling. Public transport and shops selling non-essential items will operate with reduced hours, and private offices will limit staff attendance to 50%. The move comes after the first tier of Covid-19 alerts was triggered, prompting the government to take measures to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: Japan maps out action plan for disposal of Fukushima water
summary: Japan has outlined a plan to release contaminated water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the sea, with treatment and dilution expected to start in spring 2023. The government aims to set compensation standards for affected industries and increase transparency to avoid reputational damage. The International Atomic Energy Agency will compile an interim safety assessment next year. The release is necessary to progress with the plant's decommissioning, with nearly 1.3 million tonnes of contaminated water stored in tanks at an annual cost of $1.2 billion.

site_title: CDL appoints new group COO, announces changes to board
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) has appointed Kwek Eik Sheng as its new group COO, effective Jan 1, 2022. Philip Yeo Liat Kok will step down from the board after serving over 9 years, with his role being redesignated to a non-independent director. CDL also announced the appointment of Wong Ai Ai as an independent director, who will bring expertise in climate change and landmark transactions. The company's shares rose 0.9% on the news.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: India allows emergency use of Merck's Covid-19 pill, 2 more vaccines
summary: India has given emergency use authorization to Merck's Covid-19 pill molnupiravir, Serum Institute of India's Covovax, and Biological E's Corbevax coronavirus vaccines.
