The health minister announced that 13 companies will manufacture molnupiravir in India for restricted use under emergency situations. This comes after the US FDA issued an EUA for molnupiravir earlier this week. India is also ramping up oxygen supplies and strengthening health infrastructure to contain a possible surge of Covid-19 cases due to the Omicron variant.

site_title: Indonesia sees palm oil output up by 2.6% in 2022
summary: Indonesia is expected to see a 2.6% increase in crude palm oil output to 51.01 million tonnes in 2022, driven by rising demand for exports and domestic consumption. The country is the world's largest producer and exporter of palm oil. Higher demand and lower competitor oil prices are expected to normalize prices, which have been disrupted by weather patterns and Covid-19 pandemic recovery. Domestic use of crude palm oil for biodiesel is also expected to increase to 10.15 million kilolitres.

site_title: Hong Kong to require vaccines in offices, schools, Cable TV says
summary: Hong Kong plans to expand its vaccine mandate to schools and workplaces, requiring inoculation for those entering offices and schools, with exemptions granted for those with medical conditions. The move aims to boost protection against the Omicron variant, following a zero-tolerance approach to COVID-19. The city has already required government employees to present vaccination records, with about 62% of the population fully vaccinated. The decision is part of Hong Kong's efforts to reopen its border with China, its top priority.

site_title: Singapore's electric vehicle journey in 2021
summary: Singapore has made significant efforts to encourage electric vehicle (EV) adoption in 2021. The government announced plans to set aside S$30 million over 5 years for EV-related initiatives, including improved charging provision. Additionally, the country aims to deploy 60,000 charging points at public and private premises by 2030, up from the previous target of 28,000. This push aims to support the country's EV journey and promote sustainable transportation options.

site_title: Indonesia detects first locally transmitted Omicron case
summary: Indonesia has detected its first locally transmitted Omicron case, a 37-year-old male from Medan who visited a restaurant in Jakarta's central business district earlier this month. The man is asymptomatic and in isolation at a Jakarta hospital. Health authorities have identified 47 confirmed Omicron cases in Indonesia, mostly imported, and are conducting contact tracing. The Omicron variant appears to be more contagious but less virulent than previous variants. This marks a shift in Indonesia's coronavirus outbreak, which has seen a significant decline in infections since peaking in July due to the Delta variant.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise after strong Wall Street rally
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.69% on Dec 28, driven by a strong Wall Street rally and buying before the ex-dividend date. The Kospi index closed at 3,020.29, with tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix advancing. Foreigners were net buyers of 439.1 billion won, while the won weakened 0.10% to 1,188.0 per dollar. The Kospi has risen 5.11% this year, but the won has lost 8.6% against the dollar.

site_title: 'Horrified' UN official condemns reported killings of civilians in Myanmar
summary: A UN official, Under-Secretary-General Martin Griffiths, condemned the reported killing of at least 35 civilians in Myanmar, saying he was "horrified" at the violence. The killings occurred near Mo So village in Kayah State on December 24, with reports of civilians being forced from vehicles, killed, and burned. Griffiths called for a thorough and transparent investigation into the incident, which he considered credible. The US Embassy also expressed outrage, stating it would continue to press for accountability for the perpetrators of violence against the people of Burma.

images.alt_text: UN Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief Coordinator Martin Griffiths said there were credible reports the civilians, including at least 1 child, were forced from vehicles, killed and burned.

site_title: Japan's industrial production jumps by record as car manufacturing rebounds
summary: Japan's industrial production surged by a record 7.2% in November, driven by a rebound in the auto industry, exceeding analysts' expectations. Despite supply chain disruptions, production remains below July's level, but the strong gains suggest a steady recovery path for Japan's economy. The data also signals potential strength for global trade and could boost consumer spending, with economists forecasting a shopping revival leading to Japan's return to growth this quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong Apple Daily founder and staff face new sedition charge
summary: Hong Kong prosecutors have filed a sedition charge against Jimmy Lai, the founder of Apple Daily, and six former staff members, accusing them of conspiracy to print and publish seditious publications between 2019 and 2021. Lai already faces two national security law charges, and the new charge carries a possible life imprisonment sentence. The case has drawn criticism from Western governments and human rights groups, who say the law has stifled freedoms in the Asian financial hub. The defendants will be remanded in custody until February 24.

site_title: Vietnam central bank says 2022 monetary policy to support recovery, eyes bad debt
summary: Vietnam's central bank plans to keep inflation under control while supporting the country's economic recovery in 2022. The bank aims to reduce its dependence on credit growth, with total bank lending rising 12.68% as of December 22. Deputy governor Dao Minh Tu warned of a risk of further bad debt, citing a 8.2% ratio of potentially classified bad debts. The government sets an economic growth target of 6.5% for 2022, but some analysts predict it could be lower due to the pandemic.

site_title: Football: Conte says regular tests helping Spurs deal with 'big mess' of Covid
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte supports the Premier League's daily antigen testing and twice-weekly PCR tests to combat Covid-19 disruptions. The measures were introduced after 15 games were postponed due to outbreaks. Conte believes the tests provide a good solution, knowing the results are available before games, and are better than relying on vaccine status. The measures have helped Spurs deal with the "big mess" caused by Covid-19, and the team is set to face Southampton on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas says Covid-19 variants to keep oil demand uncertain
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas expects oil demand recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic to remain fragile and uncertain in the next few years due to emerging new variants triggering lockdowns. Oil prices have largely recovered, with a 50% increase this year, but Petronas remains cautious about oil price volatility. The company forecasts a positive outlook for drill rig activity and fabrication of fixed structures and subsea facilities after 2024, while expecting volatile liquefied natural gas prices due to weather patterns and policy changes.

site_title: Huawei, Honor and Motorola push new foldable phones in China
summary: Chinese smartphone brands Huawei, Honor, and Motorola are introducing new foldable phones in the domestic market, aiming to win over the ultra-competitive Chinese market. Huawei's P50 Pocket, priced at 8,988 yuan, is already available, while Honor's Magic V and Motorola's third Razr clamshell are expected to launch soon. The smartphone market is expected to grow to 1.4 billion shipments in 2022, driven by novel form factors and capabilities like 5G wireless networking.

site_title: 20 years on, dreams of euro rivalling dollar persist
summary: The euro, introduced 20 years ago, has failed to rival the US dollar as a global currency, with the dollar holding about 60% of foreign-exchange reserves and the euro around 20%. The euro's value jumped during the COVID-19 pandemic, but it remains a respectable runner-up. The European Central Bank's focus on stability and inflation control has limited the euro's international role. A safe asset, such as a euro equivalent to the US treasury bond, is seen as essential for the euro to gain more global influence, but disagreements among European countries hinder progress.

site_title: Chinese Web users blast Musk over space station near-misses
summary: Chinese web users criticized billionaire Elon Musk after Beijing stated that China's space station took evasive action to avoid hitting two of his SpaceX satellites in July and October. The satellites moved into orbits that prompted the space station to change course, according to a document submitted to the UN's space agency. The incidents dealt a blow to Musk's reputation in China, where he is widely admired despite Tesla's recent struggles in the country due to crashes and scandals. Chinese social media users called for a boycott of Tesla, with one hashtag gaining 87 million views.

site_title: China Evergrande shares rise on vow to boost unit construction
summary: China Evergrande Group shares rose over 8% on Dec 28 after chairman Hui Ka Yan vowed to deliver 39,000 units of properties in December, a significant increase from previous months. The company aims to boost construction work amid over $300 billion in liabilities and a risk of default. Evergrande has missed a payment and had its bonds downgraded, but the shares have rebounded, trading up 7.4% at HK$1.59.

images.alt_text: Shares in China Evergrande Group jumped more than 8 per cent on Tuesday (Dec 28) morning after the embattled property developer said it had made initial progress in resuming construction work.

site_title: Australia's Covid-19 numbers surge as Omicron outbreak strains domestic politics
summary: Australia has reported a surge in COVID-19 infections, with over 10,000 new cases on December 27, as the Omicron variant spreads. The country is experiencing a resurgence of cases despite a high vaccination rate, leading to renewed containment measures such as mask-wearing and QR code check-ins. The Omicron variant has disrupted the country's reopening plan, with thousands of workers in the hospitality and airline sectors being forced into self-isolation. Friction between states over domestic border controls has also resurfaced, with New South Wales calling for Queensland to ease its testing rules.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.13% at the open on December 28, 2021, following strong gains on Wall Street as investors bet on the economy's ability to withstand the latest Covid-19 surge. The Hang Seng Index advanced 29.15 points to 23,252.91.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open Tuesday (Dec 28) following strong gains on Wall Street as investors bet the economy can weather the latest surge of Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise following strong Wall Street gains
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday following strong gains on Wall Street, driven by investors' optimism that the Omicron variant will not derail the economic recovery. Despite a surge in Covid-19 cases globally, markets saw gains in Tokyo, Singapore, Taipei, and Jakarta, while Shanghai and Hong Kong were flat or down. Oil futures rose, with benchmark WTI trading above US$75. The "Santa Claus rally" period, known for low trading volumes and light news flow, saw stocks drift higher, with the S&P 500 powering ahead 1.4% on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 6.25 points or 0.41% to 1,540.16. The index saw 176.87 million lots traded worth RM94.28 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 222 to 114.

site_title: Japan aims to put a person on the Moon by late 2020s
summary: Japan aims to send a person to the Moon by the late 2020s as part of the Artemis programme, a US-led initiative. The country also plans to launch a Mars probe in 2024 and explore ways to generate solar electricity in space. This move comes after Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa returned to Earth after spending 12 days on the International Space Station. Japan's space exploration targets are seen as part of a growing Asian space race, with China also aiming to become a major spacefaring power by 2030.

site_title: Chinese developer Shimao plans to use own funds to pay onshore bonds
summary: Chinese developer Shimao Group's flagship unit, Shanghai Shimao Co, plans to use its own funds to make onshore bond payments due in the next three months. The company also announced it will be difficult to meet its 38 billion yuan sales target due to a national credit tightening. Shimao Group sold its property management business to a sister company for 1.7 billion yuan, at a valuation higher than market average, and is in talks to sell commercial and hotel assets. The company's shares rose over 2% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Chinese developer Shimao Group's flagship unit said it plans to use its own capital to make onshore bond payments due in the next three months, and it is in talks to sell its commercial and hotel assets.

site_title: Sembmarine unit agrees to defer US$800m receivables from Borr Drilling for 2 years
summary: Sembmarine's wholly-owned subsidiary PPL Shipyard has agreed to defer US$800 million in receivables from Borr Drilling for 2 years from 2023 to 2025. The deferment is due to improving industry outlook for jackup drilling activities and Borr Drilling's continued operating performance improvement. The owed sum was from a 2017 sales agreement for 9 jackup drilling rigs. In exchange, Borr Drilling will pay an extension fee and make earlier interest payments, with the remaining interest to be repaid in quarterly instalments.

site_title: Japan's jobless rate rises to 2.8% in November
summary: Japan's jobless rate increased to 2.8% in November, surpassing the 2.7% rate in October and the median forecast of 2.7%. The jobs-to-applicants ratio remained unchanged at 1.15, matching the previous month's level. This marks the second consecutive month of steady job availability despite the rise in unemployment.

images.alt_text: Japan's jobless rate rose to 2.8 per cent in November, while the availability of jobs matched that of the previous month, government data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Marine, Asian Pay Television Trust
summary: Sembcorp Marine's PPL Shipyard has agreed to defer US$800 million in receivables from Borr Drilling from 2023 to 2025. Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) has extended the maturity date of its facilities by 3 years and plans to pare down NT$800 million using cash on its balance sheet. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust Management has called for a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Biden signs US$770b defence bill
summary: US President Joe Biden signed a nearly $770 billion defence bill, exceeding his requested amount. The bill includes funding to counter China's military expansion, bolstering the defense of Ukraine, and advanced aircraft and high-tech hardware procurement. A 2.7% pay increase for service members was also included. The measure contains significant criminal justice reforms, deemed "transformational" by Rep. Adam Smith, and was passed with wide bipartisan support despite liberal opposition. The bill also removes penalties against Russia and Saudi Arabia for human rights abuses.

site_title: Gold flat as US yields, dollar remain steady
summary: Gold prices remained steady at a near 1-week high on Tuesday, influenced by flat US yields and the dollar. Spot gold was mostly flat at $1,810.76 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.2%. Analysts expect thin trading and a range-bound market this week, as investors weigh economic growth and Omicron variant concerns.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Tuesday after US gains
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, driven by a risk-on sentiment after US gains during the Santa Claus rally. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.92% and the Topix index increased 0.85%. The benchmark gains followed US stocks reaching records despite tariff threats.

site_title: No 'panic' but Covid to 'overrun' some US hospitals: Biden
summary: US President Joe Biden warned that some hospitals may be "overrun" by Covid-19 cases due to the Omicron variant, but emphasized that the country is well-prepared and Americans should not panic. Biden acknowledged the need for more testing capacity and announced plans to send 500 million at-home test kits to Americans. He also stressed the importance of vaccination, noting that many unvaccinated individuals are driving hospitalizations, and called for a vaccine mandate for domestic air travel.

site_title: France to impose more work-from-home in Covid-19 fight
summary: France will order companies to impose at least 3 work-from-home days for employees to combat a fifth wave of Covid-19 infections, Prime Minister Jean Castex announced. The measure, effective for at least 3 weeks, comes after a record 100,000 daily cases reported on December 25. The government will also restrict access to public venues, prohibit standing in cafes and bars, and reimpose capacity limits for events. Meanwhile, the "health pass" will only be available to fully vaccinated individuals, and face masks may be required outdoors.

site_title: Highest Singapore rents in 6 years fuel expat housing woes
summary: Singapore's housing market faces challenges as rents reach a 6-year high, fueled by a shortage of migrant workers and increased demand. Analysts predict further increases in rents, with apartments costing $2,500-$4,000 per month facing the greatest pressure. The central bank warns that a decline in vacancies could trigger a sharper increase in rentals, as the city-state's rental prices jumped to 111.3 in the third quarter of 2021. Expat residents, particularly those with young families, are being hit hardest, with some opting to stay in serviced apartments or look for better deals elsewhere.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.2% on Tuesday, following overnight rallies on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 ended at a record. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 7.42 points to 3,111.66, driven by gains in major banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC. The S&P 500, Dow Jones, and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with European shares and Tokyo shares opening higher.

site_title: Apple closes New York City stores amid rising Covid-19 cases
summary: Apple has closed its New York City retail stores due to a spike in Covid-19 cases. The closed stores include flagship locations at Fifth Avenue, Grand Central, and SoHo. This decision comes after the company temporarily closed 3 US and Canadian stores earlier this month. Apple also mandated mask-wearing for customers and employees at its US retail stores.

site_title: North Korea's Kim convenes major party meeting ahead of New Year: KCNA
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un convened a major party meeting ahead of the New Year, a forum typically used to make significant policy announcements. The 4th Plenary Meeting of the 8th Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea was held on December 27, amid economic crises and international sanctions. The meeting aims to review policies, discuss strategic and tactical plans, and set practical steps for the country's development. North Korea has expressed openness to resuming talks with the US and South Korea, but only if hostile policies are lifted.

site_title: Delta cites new China Covid-19 rules after flight returns to US
summary: Delta Air Lines cited new Chinese Covid-19 cleaning requirements after a China-bound flight returned to the US on December 21. The flight was rerouted due to the new rules, which require extended ground time and are not operationally viable for Delta. Chinese authorities criticized the airline for leaving several Chinese citizens stranded with expired visas and Covid-19 tests. This incident is part of a larger issue as the Omicron variant affects airline workers and travel plans.

site_title: Goldman Sachs will require US employees to get booster shots
summary: Goldman Sachs will require US employees and visitors to receive booster shots of the Covid-19 vaccine starting in February. Anyone eligible for a booster shot must have obtained one to enter Goldman offices. Additionally, staff will be required to get tested twice weekly for Covid-19 starting in January. The new policies follow a surge in COVID-19 cases in the US, with average daily infections increasing 55% over the past week. This move is part of Goldman's efforts to maintain a safe work environment amid rising Omicron variant cases.

site_title: Oil prices rise to highest level in a month as Omicron concern eases
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Monday to the highest level since late November, driven by hopes that the Omicron coronavirus variant will have a limited impact on global demand in 2022. Global benchmark Brent crude rose to $78.60 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose to $75.57 a barrel. Despite rising Omicron cases causing flight cancellations, analysts believe the impact on oil demand will be short-term, and the global recovery story for 2022 remains on track.

site_title: Europe: Tech and healthcare help shares above one-month highs
summary: European shares rose 0.7% in thin trading, led by technology and healthcare stocks, with Roche gaining on regulatory approval for Covid-19-related products. The technology sub-index is on track to be the top performer in 2021, with a 33% gain. Despite easing concerns over the Omicron variant, rising cases worldwide threaten recovery. Markets globally also inched higher, with the S&P 500 hitting record highs.

site_title: US halves isolation guidelines for asymptomatic Covid-19
summary: US health authorities have halved the recommended isolation time for people with asymptomatic Covid-19 infections from 10 to 5 days. This decision comes as the Omicron variant spreads quickly and threatens social disruption. CDC Director Rochelle Walensky stated that the updates allow people to safely continue their daily lives. The change aims to minimize the impact on daily life while still mitigating the spread of the virus.

site_title: Daiwa House and Digital Core: A tale of 2 Reit IPOs
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) saw a surge in fundraising activity in the fourth quarter of 2021, with two large Reits, Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT) and Digital Core Reit (DC Reit), making their trading debuts on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). Both Reits have backing from big-name overseas sponsors with healthy pipelines of properties, offering right of first refusal (ROFR) to the newly listed Reits. However, DHLT's trading performance has been underwhelming, closing flat on its IPO price, while DC Reit jumped 14.8% higher than its IPO price, with a market cap of US$1.31 billion.

site_title: China talks up 'green' Olympics but prepares to fight smog
summary: China is hosting the Winter Olympics while promoting environmental efforts, but smog risks remain severe in Beijing, the capital city. Despite improved air quality, contingency plans are in place, and polluting industries are not expected to be shut down. China has made progress in reducing pollution, including planting trees and building renewable energy facilities, but concerns remain over water scarcity and the potential for hazardous smog to affect the Games. The country aims to make the Olympics "carbon neutral" for the first time, but environmental groups question the feasibility of this goal.

site_title: Japan's Nov retail sales rise but Omicron risks loom
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 1.9% in November, beating economists' forecast, due to decreasing Covid-19 cases and increased spending. The government approved a record $940 billion budget for fiscal 2022 and a $317 billion extra budget to support the economy. However, the Omicron coronavirus variant's spread in Japan's largest cities poses a risk to a consumption-led recovery, potentially suppressing consumption if new infections increase.

site_title: Spider-Man crosses US$1b mark to lead box office for 2021
summary: Spider-Man: No Way Home has become the top-grossing film of 2021 globally, surpassing the US$1 billion mark. The film, produced by Sony Group and Marvel Studios, earned an estimated US$81.5 million in North American ticket sales in its second weekend. Despite the pandemic, the movie's success can be attributed to its popularity among fans, with the film's social media buzz drawing audiences out of their homes and into cinemas. The film's all-star cast, including Tom Holland and Zendaya, contributed to its success.

site_title: Has the promise of the post-Cold War era faded?
summary: The post-Cold War era's promise of a universal liberal order has been replaced by a global landscape of growing geopolitical disorder, testing key gains of the post-World War II era. Rising authoritarianism, instability, and global volatility are concerns, with the US remaining the most powerful country but not an all-powerful hegemonic power. However, technological advancements, healthcare, and knowledge access may drive post-pandemic global progress, and the current environment contains opportunities for greater stability, including economic multilateralism and international institutions. The US-China relationship will be crucial in shaping global affairs, with the potential for either growing tension or cooperation.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats on Canada. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Didi shares slump as insiders blocked from selling stock
summary: Didi Global shares plummeted 5.4% to close at $5.30 per share on Monday, following a report that current and former employees have been banned from selling their stock indefinitely. This move blocks employees from unloading shares, just as early investors can sell stock after a 180-day lock-up period. The stock has dropped 62% in six months, erasing $42 billion in market capitalization. The ban comes amid regulatory crackdowns in China and the US, with Didi preparing to delist from US exchanges and list in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Didi Global tumbled on Monday (Dec 27) after the Financial Times reported that current and former employees of the firm have been banned from selling any of their stock indefinitely.

site_title: The 5 M's to empower 5G in Industry 4.0
summary: Industry 4.0 is transforming business operations, but manufacturers of all sizes need to know where to begin. With the advent of 5G, smart factories will comprise man, machine, and material working together seamlessly. To unlock full potential, manufacturers must consider the 5 M's: man (employee safety and productivity), machine (predictive maintenance), material (resource monitoring), method (new revenue models), and market (new systems or markets). A 5G-enabled smart factory requires a business-outcome focused digital transformation journey with the right technology, solution providers, and security measures.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at another record, extending Wall Street rally
summary: US stocks reached a record high for the second consecutive day, with the S&P 500 closing 1.4% at 4,791.19. Investors expect the Omicron surge to have a limited economic impact, despite record daily cases in Denmark, Greece, and Iceland. The Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the Nasdaq jumping 1.4% to 15,871.26. The "Santa Claus rally" period, which typically sees low trading volumes and light news, has contributed to the market's optimism.

site_title: The fight for your digital wallet
summary: Private digital currencies, such as Bitcoin and stablecoins, are gaining traction and threatening the dominance of traditional monetary systems. Central banks are exploring the possibility of issuing their own digital currencies, known as central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), to compete with private options. While CBDCs may be more suitable for retail payments, sovereign currencies struggle in cross-border transactions due to regulatory and coordination challenges. The rise of digital currencies may lead to monetary fragmentation and competition, with interoperability becoming crucial for their coexistence.

site_title: Lira slides almost 8% after intervention-driven surge
summary: The Turkish lira plummeted 8% against the US dollar on Dec 27, 2021, amid investor concerns over Turkey's monetary policy. The lira surged 50% last week after billions of dollars in state-backed market interventions and a government move to cover FX losses. Despite this, the lira remains 35% weaker than last year, and investor confidence remains uncertain. The central bank's state interventions cost over $8 billion last week, with individual depositors holding $163.7 billion in hard currencies.

site_title: Vietnam tech firm Society Pass takes wild ride after historic Nasdaq listing
summary: Vietnam-based e-commerce company Society Pass made a historic debut on the Nasdaq stock exchange in November, raising $28 million and briefly crossing the $1 billion market value mark. Despite its initial success, the company's shares have declined to $15.97, attributed to a market downturn caused by the Omicron variant. Society Pass faces pending legal action, including a lawsuit from an American venture capital firm, and controversy surrounding its CEO, Dennis Nguyen, who has a history of raising capital for now-defunct cafe and restaurant chains.

site_title: Organic growth, long-term approach to help fuel Pictet's Asia expansion
summary: Pictet Wealth Management is expanding its presence in Asia through organic growth, driven by strong investment offerings and a long-term approach to assets. Assets under management (AUM) in Asia have grown 40% over two years, with net new money more than doubling in the first half of 2021. The group expects Asia's economic growth to increasingly determine global trade flows, capital, and innovation, with its share of global wealth projected to rise to 30-40% by 2030. Pictet's focus on private market investing, including private equity and real estate, is also seen as a key trend.

site_title: What else to watch out for on Singapore's climate agenda
summary: Singapore is set to announce a revised carbon tax rate for 2024, aiming to decarbonize by mid-century. The nation aspires to become a carbon trading hub for Asia, with a projected US$5.6 billion in gross value-add by 2050. Singapore plans to import up to 4 gigawatts of low-carbon electricity by 2025 and phase out internal combustion engine vehicles by 2040. The government will also deploy 60,000 charging points by 2030, with all newly registered cars required to be cleaner energy models from 2030.

site_title: Is he back? Trump is doing everything to show that he is
summary: US President Joe Biden's plummeting popularity, coupled with economic discontent and a surge in the pandemic, has created an environment conducive to Donald Trump's potential return to the presidency in 2024. Despite being unpopular among many voters, Trump remains extremely popular among Republican voters, with 63% of Republicans and 37% of Republican-leaning independents saying he should be the leader of the Republican Party. A CNN poll found that nearly 6 in 10 Republican voters would select Trump as their presidential candidate in 2024, leading other potential candidates, including Mike Pence and Ron DeSantis.

site_title: China imposes new curbs on offshore IPOs from restricted sectors
summary: China has imposed new restrictions on offshore IPOs from restricted sectors, requiring firms in banned industries to seek a waiver before listing and capping foreign ownership at 30%. The move aims to tighten scrutiny on overseas listings, following the Didi Global IPO debacle. Companies using Variable Interest Entities (VIE) structures will face tougher scrutiny and higher costs, potentially affecting their decision to list overseas. The new rules, effective January 1, apply to new share listings and do not affect existing foreign-owned companies.

site_title: New UN Myanmar envoy says she is 'deeply concerned' by escalating violence
summary: The new UN special envoy to Myanmar, Noeleen Heyzer, expressed "deep concern" over escalating violence in the country, calling for a new year ceasefire between the military and its opponents. Nationwide protests since the February coup have resulted in over 1,300 deaths and 11,000 arrests. Diplomatic efforts have failed to resolve the crisis, with the generals refusing to engage with opponents. Heyzer also urged humanitarian assistance to be provided to those in need and for all sides to come to a ceasefire, amidst reports of attacks on civilians and ethnic rebels.

site_title: Will Singapore set a timeline for net zero?
summary: Singapore is reviewing its national emissions targets, which could include a "net zero" pledge, but some activists and academics urge the government to set stronger, more specific targets to achieve net zero emissions by 2050. The country's current targets project peak emissions at 65 metric tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent by 2030, with a goal of achieving a 36% reduction in emissions intensity from 2005 levels by 2030. Experts argue that Singapore's unique challenges, such as limited land and natural resources, make it difficult to set a net zero target, but others believe the country can achieve it with a clear plan and policies.

site_title: Italy's consumer-blind trust-busting
summary: Italy's antitrust regulator, the Autorità Garante della Concorrenza e del Mercato (AGCM), fined Amazon 1.13 billion euros (S$1.74 billion) for abusing its market dominance and forcing third-party sellers to use its in-house logistics service, Fulfillment by Amazon (FBA). The penalty is the largest ever imposed on a tech company. The AGCM decision disregarded consumer welfare, focusing instead on Amazon's control of logistics and its impact on competition. The ruling may open the door for similar antitrust actions elsewhere, but its implications for consumer choice and prices remain unclear.

site_title: How the supply chain crisis unfolded in 2021
summary: The 2021 supply chain crisis was triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, which led to a surge in demand for protective gear and a shift towards online shopping. As factories ramped up production, cargo vessels delivered goods globally, causing a shortage of containers in China. This led to delays in shipping, stockpiling of goods, and labor shortages, affecting industries such as manufacturing, retail, and logistics. The crisis highlighted vulnerabilities in the global supply chain, which has been reliant on lean production and faraway factories for years, and warned of potential shocks to the economy.

images.alt_text: As empty shipping containers piled up in many parts of the world in 2020, the result was a shortage of containers in the one country that needed them the most: China.

site_title: Thousands more cancellations as Omicron thins airline crews
summary: Airlines globally cancelled over 5,800 flights on Monday, including 700 US flights, due to Omicron's impact on flight crews. The Omicron variant led to over 2,300 US flight cancellations over the Christmas holiday weekend. Airlines acknowledge the variant's contribution, with some reporting high sick call rates, while others cite bad weather and maintenance issues. The CDC is under pressure to shorten recommended isolation periods for vaccinated employees.

site_title: Seoul ready to meet standards to join CPTPP trade deal
summary: South Korea plans to submit its application to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) by mid-April 2022, according to Trade Minister Yeo Han-koo. The country has prepared for the pact for 8 years and is "ready to meet the high standards" required to join. The CPTPP, which includes 11 Pacific Rim countries, would benefit both South Korea and Japan, with businesses and markets recognizing the importance of economic cooperation between the two countries. Japan's government has yet to confirm whether South Korea can fully meet the pact's standards.

site_title: Evergrande races to restart projects as debt repayments loom
summary: Evergrande Group has resumed construction at nearly 92% of its housing projects, a significant increase from 50% in September, as authorities push the debt-laden developer to pay migrant workers and deliver apartments. Chairman Hui Ka Yan aims to deliver 39,000 apartment units this month, a goal that is almost four times the firm's average monthly delivery since September. Evergrande faces over $300 billion in liabilities and has missed coupon payments, prompting a government campaign to deleverage developers and curb housing speculation.

site_title: US: S&P 500 hits record high on strong retail sales data
summary: The S&P 500 reached a record high on Monday, driven by strong retail sales data, despite Omicron-related flight cancellations. The index rose 22.82 points, or 0.48%, to 4,748.61, while the Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains. The strong retail sales underscored the economy's resilience, overshadowing concerns about trade tensions and tariffs.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) has signed an amendment agreement extending the maturity date of its 7-year facilities by 3 years to November 2028 on the same terms. As part of its financial close, APTT will pare down NTS$0.8 billion using cash on its balance sheet. Metro Holdings and Singapura Finance separately announced the passing of Phua Bah Lee, a senior adviser and independent non-executive director.

site_title: Green products emerging as China's new exports
summary: China is shifting its focus from polluting industrial exports to more sustainable products, driven by growing demand from environmentally conscious consumers. The country has curtailed exports of polluting products, such as steel, and is capitalizing on demand for green goods like e-bikes, digital printers, and artificial turf. China has become a leading global supplier of e-bike motors, digital printers, and solar panels, and its electric vehicles account for a significant share of global sales. As the country's exporters gain market share, China's overall exports are expected to take on a greener shade, with a growing domestic opportunity for green products.

images.alt_text: Solar panels are another area where China has emerged as the preeminent global export supplier. There will eventually be a huge domestic opportunity for green products, as a growing proportion of Chinese consumers start to consider the impact of their purchases in the move towards net zero.

site_title: China's industrial profit growth tumbles
summary: China's industrial profit growth slowed to 9% year-over-year in November, down from 24.6% in October, due to tumbling raw material prices, a faltering property market, and weaker consumer demand. Industrial firms' profits rose 38% year-over-year to 7.98 trillion yuan for the January-November period. Despite a slight cooling of factory-gate inflation, China's economy faces challenges, including a property downturn, supply bottlenecks, and strict Covid-19 curbs, which may impact growth in 2022.

site_title: China's Kintor says interim analysis of Covid treatment trial misses statistical criteria
summary: China's Kintor Pharmaceutical announced that interim analysis of its Phase III clinical trial for Covid-19 treatment proxalutamide missed statistical criteria due to low hospitalization rates among trial participants. The trial, enrolling 384 people, found no significant difference between the placebo group and the group taking proxalutamide. Kintor plans to seek consent from authorities, including the US FDA, to amend the clinical protocol and enroll patients at higher risk, such as those unvaccinated.

site_title: Absence of safety nets will continue to test high-flying markets in 2022
summary: The world's stock markets experienced a surge in 2021, driven by central banks and government spending, but are likely to face a tougher year in 2022 due to the removal of safety nets. The US Federal Reserve is dismantling its bond-buying program and interest rates are being raised, while the Biden administration's stimulus plan has been put on hold. Despite this, some analysts believe that the market will continue to recover, with Brent Schutte, chief investment strategist at Northwestern Mutual, predicting a return to "normalcy" in 2022. However, others warn of potential risks, including valuations, inflation, and supply-chain issues, which could impact the market's performance.

site_title: Evergrande races to restart projects as debt repayments loom
summary: China Evergrande Group has resumed construction at nearly 92% of its housing projects, with 89,000 workers involved, as authorities push the debt-laden developer to pay migrant workers and deliver apartments. The company aims to deliver 39,000 apartment units this month, a significant increase from its average monthly delivery of under 10,000 units. Evergrande is struggling with over $300 billion in liabilities and faces a maturity wall next year, prompting Beijing to ease financing for developers and homebuyers.

site_title: Don't wait till Jan 1 to start your resolution
summary: Millennials and Gen Zers are shifting away from traditional New Year's resolutions, opting instead to work on personal changes throughout the year. By making small, incremental changes, individuals can avoid procrastination and stay motivated. Those interviewed, including Alex Boughen, Noah Schnable, and Abbey Phaneuf, found that starting small and being consistent has helped them make lasting changes in their lives, such as improving their health and confidence. By focusing on gradual progress, rather than waiting for a specific date, people can create a more sustainable approach to self-improvement.

site_title: Billions in old cash still being hoarded 2 decades after introduction of euro
summary: Billions of euros, equivalent to $13.1 billion, in old cash remain unconverted 20 years after the introduction of the euro, with the majority located in Germany. The total amount that can be redeemed at central banks is unclear, with some speculating that it may be due to forgotten savings or mementos. Other European countries, such as France and Italy, have stopped exchanging old money, while Portugal will end the option to switch paper money in February.

site_title: EO Wilson, known as 'Father of Biodiversity,' dies at 92
summary: EO Wilson, known as the "Father of Biodiversity," has died at 92. A renowned Harvard University biologist and Pulitzer Prize winner, Wilson was a leading authority on ants and advocated for protecting the planet's biodiversity. He warned of the impending extinction of half of all animal and plant species by the end of the century due to human interference with the environment. Wilson's work on sociobiology and his book "On Human Nature" explored the link between biology and human behavior, while his research on ants led to a Pulitzer Prize in 1991.

site_title: Mother Teresa's charity barred from receiving foreign funds
summary: India's government has barred the Missionaries of Charity, a Catholic organization founded by Mother Teresa, from receiving foreign donations due to non-compliance with local laws. The charity, which works with the country's poorest people, had its licence to receive foreign funds renewed for the first time in 2021. The decision was made under the Foreign Contribution Regulation Act, with no details provided on the specific rules flouted. The charity has confirmed the decision and has asked its centres to stop operating foreign contribution accounts until the matter is resolved.

site_title: Chinese tech giant Baidu tests metaverse waters with new app
summary: Chinese tech giant Baidu launches a virtual reality app, XiRang, marking its entry into the metaverse industry. The platform allows users to create digital characters and interact in a 3D world, with plans to expand to 100,000 users. Baidu's move follows other digital giants like Nike, Ferrari, and Meta, which are experimenting with virtual goods in the metaverse. The platform is still in its infancy, with a potential full launch taking up to 6 years, according to Baidu officials.

site_title: India's Adani nears first coal shipment from shunned Australian mine
summary: India's Adani Group is set to ship the first coal cargo from Australia's Carmichael mine, a 7-year campaign by climate activists unable to stop the project. The mine, which will supply 10 million tonnes of coal annually, is expected to be the last new thermal coal mine in Australia. Adani has secured a market for the coal and plans to maximize cash flow returns on the railway line and port. The shipment is seen as a significant milestone for the project, despite criticism from climate activists who claim it will contribute to global warming.

site_title: Driven by e-commerce, Asean's digital economy growth to keep weighing on supply chains
summary: Asean's digital economy is expected to continue growing rapidly, driven by e-commerce, but this growth will put pressure on supply chains. Experts believe companies are better equipped to handle the challenges. Despite concerns, the region's economy is showing resilience. Recent developments include a US$2.2 billion sell-off of GoTo shares, which is tipped for a rebound, and foreign investors returning to Vietnam's stock market due to sweetened US trade terms. Meanwhile, Malaysia has taken steps to shield its economy from tariff threats, including a rate cut, and SMCCI and Maybank have signed a MOU to support Malay or Muslim-owned enterprises.

site_title: Leading Myanmar actor Paing Takhon jailed 3 years for pro-democracy protests
summary: A leading Myanmar actor, Paing Takhon, has been jailed for 3 years for supporting pro-democracy protests. He was arrested during a dawn raid at his mother's home in April and was on a junta celebrity wanted list. Takhon, 25, was active in mass protests following the February coup and used his massive social media following to rally support. He is the latest celebrity to be targeted by the junta, which has hunted over 100 celebrities for supporting the pro-democracy movement.

site_title: Malaysia government under fire over slow clean-up after deadly floods
summary: Malaysia's government is facing criticism for its slow response to the country's worst floods in years, which have left at least 48 people dead and 5 missing. Residents are frustrated with the lack of assistance and have taken matters into their own hands with a massive clean-up drive. Damaged homes and appliances are piled up on the streets, and concerns over disease outbreaks have been raised due to the mounds of rubbish left behind. Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob has admitted weaknesses in the flood response and pledged improvements in future, but many remain angry and in need of aid.

site_title: Singapore must expect new wave of Covid-19 cases in coming days due to Omicron: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore expects a new wave of Covid-19 cases in the coming days and weeks due to the Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong. The government has prepared for this next wave, and current vaccines and boosters are effective in protecting against severe illnesses. Omicron cases will be managed similarly to Delta cases, with those who recover at home and severe cases prioritized for healthcare resources. The government encourages the public to get vaccinated to avoid restrictions on movement and announced that unvaccinated workers will not be allowed to return to the workplace starting January 15.

site_title: China Huarong sells 70% stake in its consumer finance unit to Bank of Ningbo
summary: China Huarong Asset Management sold a 70% stake in its consumer finance unit to Bank of Ningbo for 1.1 billion yuan. The deal, subject to regulatory approval, marks Huarong's latest asset divestment as part of a business revamp. The move follows Huarong's struggles with debt and a missed earnings deadline, which led to a state-backed rescue plan and the sale of fresh capital. This sale is part of Huarong's efforts to focus on its main bad loan business and improve its credit profile.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 17.46 points to 1,533.91 on Monday, driven by gains. The index saw 2.207 billion lots worth RM1.359 billion traded, with 486 gainers outnumbering 334 losers.

site_title: Pandemic-wary workers to drive demand for Grade A space as they gradually return to offices
summary: Singapore's office property market may see a recovery driven by pandemic-wary workers returning to offices, with rent recovery supported by limited new supply and demand from growth sectors. Top-grade offices are expected to thrive, while poorer-grade buildings may struggle. The easing of work-from-home policies and increased demand from sectors like technology and healthcare are expected to drive growth, with office landlords optimistic about the outlook.

images.alt_text: CDL is redeveloping its former Fuji Xerox Towers, the proposed redevelopment will comprise a 45-storey integrated project with office, retail residential and serviced apartments components.

site_title: Jokowi builds hospital to recoup US$7b in medical tourism
summary: Indonesia is building a hospital in partnership with Mayo Clinic to attract medical tourists, aiming to recoup US$7 billion in annual losses due to outbound medical tourism. The Bali International Hospital, set to operate in mid-2023, is part of President Joko Widodo's bid to reduce imports of health services and equipment. The hospital will cater to wealthy Indonesians and foreign visitors, with around 2 million Indonesians traveling abroad for medical treatment each year due to the country's limited health system capacity.

site_title: Indonesian coffee chain Kopi Kenangan raises US$96m, becomes latest unicorn
summary: Indonesian coffee chain Kopi Kenangan has raised $96 million in its latest Series C round, valuing the company at over $1 billion, making it a unicorn. The funding, led by Tybourne Capital Management and Falcon Edge Capital, follows the company's top-line growth over the last 12 months, with sales more than doubling year on year. The fresh funds will be used to accelerate expansion across Indonesia and internationally, with plans to serve 5.5 million cups per month in Q1 2022.

site_title: Two decades after Euro, billions in old cash is being hoarded
summary: Two decades after the introduction of euros in 2002, billions of old cash remain unclaimed across Europe, totaling approximately US$9.6 billion. The majority of this amount is held in Germany, where the Bundesbank will continue to exchange deutschmarks indefinitely. Other countries, such as France, Spain, and Italy, have stopped exchanging old money, while Portugal will end its conversion option in February. The European Central Bank plans to redesign euro banknotes by 2024 and may launch a digital euro this decade.

site_title: China regulator to suspend some China Eastern, XiamenAir flights due to Covid-19
summary: China's aviation regulator will suspend 2 China Eastern flights from New York to Shanghai and 2 XiamenAir flights from Los Angeles to Xiamen starting January 3 due to Covid-19 cases. A total of 10 passengers tested positive for the virus upon arrival in China on December 14, prompting the regulator to halt subsequent flights. The suspensions are part of China's ongoing efforts to manage the spread of Covid-19 within its borders.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore welcomed 41,140 visitors in November, nearly doubling the previous month's 23,980, according to the Singapore Tourism Board. Indonesian coffee chain Kopi Kenangan raised $96 million in funding, becoming a unicorn. Keppel DC Reit acquired a London data centre for £57 million. US Bankruptcy Court confirmed EHT's Chapter 11 plan to liquidate entities. The Straits Times Index (STI) dipped 0.1% amid quiet trading due to the festive season.

site_title: Global bond winners for 2021 all came from emerging markets
summary: Emerging-market bonds outperformed global debt in 2021, with sovereign bonds from South Africa, China, Indonesia, India, and Croatia ranking among the top performers. Despite central banks withdrawing stimulus, these bonds posted high coupon returns, offsetting losses from price drops. Emerging-market bonds dropped 1.3% in 2021, outperforming the 3.8% decline in 2013. Analysts expect top performers like South Africa and Indonesia to continue gaining in 2022, driven by favorable interest-rate differentials and carry trades.

site_title: China imposes new curbs on offshore IPOs from restricted sectors
summary: China has introduced new restrictions on offshore initial public offerings (IPOs) by firms in sectors banned from foreign investment. Effective January 1, companies in restricted industries must obtain a waiver before listing abroad, with foreign investors limited to 30% ownership. Overseas investors will also be barred from participating in management. The move aims to curb the use of Variable Interest Entities (VIEs) to bypass foreign investment rules, following the Didi Global IPO controversy.

site_title: RBL Bank Tumbles after India appoints director to board
summary: RBL Bank shares plummeted 25% in Mumbai after India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), appointed a new director, Yogesh Dayal, to the bank's board. The move raised concerns about the bank's financial health, particularly after it reported a first-quarter loss due to a surge in soured loans. Despite the RBI stating the bank's financial position remains stable, shares are down 35% this year, trimming the lender's market value to $1.2 billion.

site_title: China starts to disinfect city of 13 million people after Delta outbreak
summary: China has begun widespread disinfection measures in the city of Xi'an, home to 13 million people, after a spike in Covid-19 infections, with daily cases reaching 150. The city has been locked down, and residents are advised to close windows and avoid touching surfaces. This surge in cases highlights the difficulty in eliminating the virus in China, which is trying to maintain its "Zero Covid" strategy ahead of the 2022 Winter Olympics. Authorities aim to control the outbreak by the end of January.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on year-end profit taking, virus scare
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.43% to 2,999.55 on Monday amid uncertainty over the Omicron Covid-19 variant and year-end profit-taking. Retail investors are selling shares to avoid capital gains taxes, while a surge in global Covid-19 cases is hurting investor sentiment.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end lower on Omicron fears, SoftBank falls
summary: Japanese shares ended lower on Monday, with SoftBank Group leading losses due to concerns over the Omicron Covid-19 variant. The Nikkei share average slipped 0.37% to 28,676.46, while the Topix lost 0.45%. SoftBank fell 2.96% after Credit Suisse sought information through US courts, potentially leading to legal action against the Japanese company.

site_title: Heavy snow causes travel chaos in Japan
summary: Heavy snow in central Japan on Dec 27 caused travel chaos, with traffic jams, flight cancellations, and train disruptions. Record drifts were recorded in some areas, leaving over 3,200 households without power. No injuries or deaths have been confirmed, according to officials. The weather forecast warned of more snow overnight, prompting warnings from authorities.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip in quiet start to week amid festive season; STI falls 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,104.24 points on Monday, amid quiet trading due to the festive season. Markets across Asia were mixed, with Japan and South Korea closing 0.4% lower, while Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI gained 1.2%. Dairy Farm International Holdings led the gainers, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage fell 0.7%. The most heavily traded counters were Singapore Telecommunications and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, with Singtel closing flat and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding rising 1.5%.

site_title: Malaysia seeks UN climate adaptation funds amid deadly floods
summary: Malaysia is seeking US$3 million from the UN Green Climate Fund to develop a national plan to adapt to climate change, amid deadly floods that displaced nearly 70,000 people. The funds are a small portion of the RM 9.8 billion allocated for flood mitigation efforts. Experts say the plan's implementation would likely cost much more. The plan focuses on areas like water, agriculture, and infrastructure, and is the first time the Malaysian government has sought money for climate adaptation.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop in thin trade as pandemic uncertainties rise
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Monday, driven by risk sentiment taking a hit from the Omicron variant of Covid-19. Banks and tech firms declined, while oil stocks tracked lower crude prices. Defensive sectors like healthcare and real estate led gains. The US FDA granted emergency use authorization for Roche's Covid-19 at-home rapid test, and airlines canceled over 4,500 flights due to Omicron uncertainty. Markets in Britain, Australia, and Hong Kong were closed for holidays, while Wall Street resumes trading later.

site_title: Tackling youth unemployment, widening talent pool crucial amid structural shifts: Hays
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has unlocked a new talent pool for global technology employers, providing a solution to significant skills shortages. Hays, a recruiting firm, notes that borderless jobs and "telemigration" could benefit businesses facing skills shortages. A report by Hays suggests that employers and skilled workers will need to adapt to long-term structural shifts, including increased remote work and hybrid models. To address youth unemployment, businesses should create jobs with built-in training and collaborate with educational institutions to provide career guidance.

site_title: Binance gets its first Gulf crypto regulatory nod in Bahrain
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, received in-principle approval from Bahrain's central bank to be a crypto-asset service provider. The approval marks the first regulatory nod for a Binance entity in the Middle East or North Africa. Binance CEO Changpeng "CZ" Zhao said the company will complete a full application process, pending establishment requirements. This approval comes as Binance expands its regional footprint, with plans to set up a potential headquarters in the Gulf. Bahrain has been an early adopter of digital assets, with Rain Financial and CoinMENA already licensed in the country.

site_title: Office, retail, industrial properties underpin Asia-Pacific investment bonanza
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate investment sales are expected to continue their growth momentum in 2022, with Singapore, South Korea, and Australia emerging as hotspots. The region saw a record $167.38 billion in acquisitions of income-producing properties from January to November 2021, a 24% year-over-year increase. The pipeline of pending deals exceeds $68 billion, with Cushman & Wakefield predicting investment volumes to match 2019 levels at around $180 billion. Low interest rates, real estate as an inflation hedge, and increasing demand for alternative assets are driving the growth.

site_title: US Bankruptcy Court confirms EHT's Chapter 11 plan to liquidate entities
summary: The US Bankruptcy Court has confirmed the Chapter 11 plan to liquidate entities of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT), following a confirmation hearing on Dec 20, 2021. The plan authorizes the liquidation of EHT's US units, with Bank of America and the Committee of Unsecured Creditors selecting the liquidation trustee. Stapled securityholders are not expected to receive distributions at this time, and the Reit trustee will dissolve EH-Reit and related entities. The effective date of the plan is on or before Dec 31, and the liquidation trustee will dissolve entities after that date.

site_title: China shares end lower as rising local Covid-19 cases drag consumer firms
summary: China shares ended slightly lower on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite index down 0.06% at 3,615.97, as rising local Covid-19 cases weighed on consumer sentiment ahead of the New Year holiday. The consumer staples sector slumped 1.3%, while the real-estate index rose 0.57% and the healthcare subindex gained 0.68%. Despite the losses, the blue-chip CSI300 index was down only 0.04%.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare to receive S$11.3m investment to boost Nature's Farm business
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Camsing Healthcare executed an investment and loan agreement worth S$11.3 million to boost its retail business Nature's Farm, which has been struggling since the Covid-19 pandemic. Qiren Holdings, a wholly-owned company of Lin Qiren, led the investment. The agreement involves the allotment and issue of 102.2 million shares and the exercise of 167.8 million options at S$0.042 apiece. The investment aims to support Nature's Farm's recovery and growth.

site_title: New Xinjiang chief vows to maintain focus on social stability
summary: Xinjiang's new leader, Ma Xingrui, has pledged to maintain focus on social stability in the region, following international criticism and boycotts over human rights practices. Ma, 62, who replaced Chen Quanguo as Communist Party secretary, aims to implement Chinese President Xi Jinping's blueprint for the region. He emphasized the government's commitment to "firmly promoting continuous and long-term social stability" in Xinjiang, with no reversal of progress made.

site_title: Gold edges up as weaker US yields counter stronger dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,811.31 per ounce, staying above the $1,800 level, as weaker US Treasury yields offset a stronger dollar. The dollar index fell to its weakest level in nearly a week, making gold less attractive for holders of non-US currencies. Analysts expect thin trading and a range-bound market for gold this week. Meanwhile, spot silver edged up 0.1%, while platinum and palladium also saw slight gains.

site_title: Hotel occupancy, RevPAR in November highest since pandemic hit
summary: Singapore's hotel sector recorded its highest occupancy rates and revenue per available room (RevPAR) since the Covid-19 pandemic, with 41,140 visitors in November, nearly double the previous month. Hotel occupancies hit 75.6% and RevPAR stood at S$133.23, the highest since January 2020. The growth was driven by the Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme and improved economic sentiment. Key markets included India, Indonesia, Bangladesh, China, and Malaysia, with visitors from the UK, US, Australia, and Germany also contributing to the increase. However, economists warn of the risk of stricter restrictions in 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Hang Seng closed for holiday on Monday
summary: The Hang Seng exchange in Hong Kong was closed on Monday for a public holiday. Trading resumed on Tuesday, Dec 28. This article does not contain relevant information about the Hang Seng exchange's closure.

site_title: China's industrial firms' profits slow on high commodity prices
summary: China's industrial companies experienced the slowest profit growth in over a year, with a 9% increase in November, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This marks a decline from the 38% profit growth in the first 11 months of the year, largely due to high commodity prices. Coal and crude oil suppliers saw profits rise over 200% in the same period, but this has negatively impacted other industries such as electricity and heating producers. Cost pressures remain significant, with profit declines narrowing at manufacturers of cars and general equipment.

site_title: Support for Japan PM up as voters welcome his Covid-19 measures
summary: Support for Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has increased to 65% of voters, up 4 percentage points from the previous survey, as the public welcomes his anti-Coronavirus measures, including a temporary border closure to new foreign entrants. This is the highest figure since February 2020, amid the emergence of the highly transmissible Omicron variant. Kishida's approval rating has risen due to his swift response to the pandemic, which has led to a sharp decline in daily new cases.

site_title: Myanmar court defers verdicts in Suu Kyi trial to Jan 10: source
summary: A court in Myanmar's military-ruled country postponed verdicts in the trial of ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi to January 10, according to a source. The trial, which began in February, involves two cases against Suu Kyi. The delay is the latest in a series of postponements in the trial, which has been criticized for its lack of transparency and fairness. The verdict is expected to be announced on January 10, but the outcome remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: [BENGALURU] A court in military-ruled Myanmar postponed on Monday verdicts it was expected to make in two cases in the trial of ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi to Jan 10, a source familiar with the proceedings said.

site_title: Jordan's Capital Bank plans to acquire Societe Generale Bank Jordan: chairman
summary: Jordan's Capital Bank has approved a mandatory offer to acquire Societe Generale Bank Jordan, aiming to expand its regional and domestic presence. The deal, subject to regulatory approval, is expected to be finalized in the next few months. The bank also plans to issue $100 million in perpetual bonds to drive growth. This move follows the bank's recent expansion in Iraq and its pursuit of growth in the region, with assets now around $6 billion.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust doubles student accommodation assets with US$213m acquisition
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) has acquired four US student accommodation assets for US$213 million, doubling its assets to 1,651 beds. The acquisition, 92% funded by debt, is expected to increase ART's pro forma FY2020 distribution per stapled security by 3.0% and EBITDA yield by 4.9%. ART's portfolio now comprises 8 assets with 4,400 beds, spread across 7 US states, reducing portfolio concentration risk. The acquisition is part of ART's strategy to grow its student accommodation assets, now accounting for 16% of its total portfolio value.

site_title: China oil demand to peak by 2030 on petrochemical use: CNPC research
summary: China's oil consumption is expected to peak at around 780 million tonnes per year by 2030, driven by robust petrochemical demand. This is a revision from previous forecasts of a peak in 2025, and marks a decade of growth in oil consumption. After 2030, overall oil demand is expected to decline due to transportation consumption declines amid electrification of vehicles.

site_title: ESG delivers new wave of financing opportunities for SMEs
summary: Global interest in environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investments has grown rapidly, with $35.7 trillion in sustainable investments in 2020. The trend is gaining momentum in the Asia Pacific, with nearly three in five investors planning to incorporate ESG into their analysis. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift, with 80% of Asian investors increasing their ESG investments. ESG financing for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) is emerging, with initiatives like the $60m Incomlend ESG Invoice Financing Programme, providing SMEs with quick turnaround invoice financing solutions and improving cash flow. This shift is critical for a sustainable future, empowering ESG-centric SMEs to grow and adopt responsible business practices.

images.alt_text: ESG financing solutions can improve SMEs' cash flow, giving them the fiscal agility to pursue new revenue opportunities or make bolder ESG-centric changes within their organisation and supply chain.

site_title: Australia records first Omicron death, authorities stick to reopening plan
summary: Australia reported its first confirmed death from the Omicron variant of Covid-19, a man in his 80s with underlying health conditions, as the country experiences a surge in daily infections. Despite the grim milestone, authorities have refrained from imposing new restrictions, citing low hospitalization rates. Omicron began spreading in Australia just as the country lifted most domestic border restrictions, leading to a surge in cases. Authorities have reinstated some restrictions, including mandatory mask-wearing and QR code checks, but have resisted a return to lockdown.

site_title: Figure skating: Hanyu seals Olympic berth with Japan championships win
summary: Olympic champion Yuzuru Hanyu successfully defended his singles crown at the Japanese national championships, securing his place at the Beijing Winter Games. Hanyu, who won gold at Sochi and Pyeongchang, scored 322.36 points, with 3 quadruple axel jumps in his program. He initially landed on 2 feet on a quadruple axel, but said he was relieved with his performance, aiming to master the jump for the Beijing Games.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open slightly lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.07% lower on Monday, influenced by concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell to 28,761.22, while the Topix index declined to 1,984.39. Thin holiday trade contributed to the slight decrease.

site_title: Asia: Shares dip as virus fears linger
summary: Asian shares opened lower on Monday due to lingering fears over the Omicron coronavirus variant, despite a recent surge in consumer spending during the holiday season. The Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo dipped 0.22%, while Shanghai marginally rose and Seoul was slightly down. Even in China, where a "zero-Covid" strategy has largely kept infections in check, officials recorded 206 new infections, the country's biggest figure in 21 months. The year-end holiday season has led to subdued trading, with many markets closed.

site_title: Hot stock: Hatten Land sees heavy trading on Huawei partnership
summary: Hatten Land's shares jumped 23.4% to a 1-month high of S$0.058 following the announcement of a partnership with Huawei International. The partnership will explore business opportunities in renewable energy, data centre, cloud computing, and more. Hatten Edge, a subsidiary, will spearhead the company's strategic pivots and digital initiatives. The move comes ahead of an extraordinary general meeting on Dec 30 to diversify the business into renewable energy, physical-digital malls, and cryptocurrency mining.

site_title: Digilife Tech in talks to potentially acquire shares from undisclosed company
summary: Digilife Tech, a Singaporean company, is in talks to acquire an undisclosed amount of shares from another company. The proposed acquisition, which may be a major transaction, is currently in discussions and has not yet resulted in a binding agreement. The company had requested a trading halt due to the discussions and will make further announcements once a deal is signed or if there are material developments.

site_title: Weather disasters cost US$20b more than last year: NGO
summary: A British aid group, Christian Aid, reported that the world's ten costliest weather disasters in 2021 caused US$170 billion in damage, a 13% increase from 2020. The disasters, including Hurricane Ida and flooding in Germany and Belgium, killed at least 1,075 people and displaced 1.3 million. The report attributed the upward trend to man-made climate change, with rich countries' infrastructure better insured and poor countries often unable to calculate the financial toll of disasters.

site_title: Bank of Japan policymakers debated rising inflationary pressure at Dec meeting: summary
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers discussed rising inflationary pressures at their December meeting, citing a potential shift in the country's inflation outlook. Wholesale prices rose at a record pace, reflecting higher commodity costs, while consumer inflation remains stuck around zero. Some board members suggested that rising global inflation could lead to an upgrade in the BOJ's price forecasts at their January meeting, where they will review their growth and inflation forecasts.

site_title: Hatten Land, Huawei in cloud computing, data centre, solar energy tie-up
summary: Hatten Land, a Malaysia property developer, has partnered with Huawei International to explore business opportunities in renewable energy, data centre, cloud computing, and fintech infrastructure. The collaboration aims to develop eco-friendly data centres and solar facilities in Malaysia, with Hatten's first 6,000-solar-panel project on Melaka mall set to be equipped with Huawei's smart inverters. The tie-up is part of Hatten's proposed diversification into renewable energy, physical-digital malls, cryptocurrency mining, and the metaverse.

site_title: Japan's Nov retail sales rise for second month
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 1.9% in November from a year earlier, exceeding economists' forecast of a 1.7% gain. The increase was driven by decreasing Covid-19 cases, which encouraged shoppers to spend on goods and services. This follows a 0.9% advance in October, the first rise in three months. The government approved a record $940 billion budget for fiscal 2022 to support the economy, which is expected to rebound by 6.1% in the current quarter.

site_title: New York sees increase in hospitalised children as Omicron hammers US
summary: New York health officials report a four-fold increase in Covid-19 hospital admissions for children under 18, with half of those being under 5, as Omicron cases rise nationwide. The US sees an average of nearly 190,000 new infections daily, and the White House promises to resolve the test shortage. Top advisor Anthony Fauci acknowledges a testing problem, vows to make more tests available, and emphasizes Omicron's high contagiousness, despite recent studies suggesting lower severity.

site_title: Oil prices mixed, US crude falls after Covid-19 flight cancellations
summary: Oil prices were mixed on Monday, with US crude futures falling 41 cents to $73.38 a barrel after airlines canceled thousands of flights in the US due to surging Covid-19 infections. In contrast, Brent crude rose 40 cents to $76.54 a barrel. The mixed market response was attributed to the holiday shutdown in the US, which affected trading on Friday. The article does not provide a conclusive statement, but highlights the contrasting price movements of US and Brent crude.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly lower on Monday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,106.27, after the Christmas weekend. Gainers outnumbered losers 70 to 36, with Hatten Land gaining 12.8% after signing an agreement with Huawei International to explore renewable energy and data centers. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell 0.2-0.4% each. European and Asian markets also closed lower, following a recent rally and concerns over the Omicron variant.

site_title: Crossbow-carrying intruder detained at Queen's castle in UK
summary: A 19-year-old man carrying a crossbow was detained at Windsor Castle in the UK after breaking into the grounds on Christmas Day. Security processes were triggered immediately, and the intruder was arrested and sectioned under the Mental Health Act for mental health treatment. The man used a rope ladder to scale a fence and was found by CCTV operators. The incident occurred as Queen Elizabeth II spent Christmas at Windsor Castle with her family, marking her first Christmas without her late husband Prince Philip.

site_title: UN 'horrified' by reports of massacre of civilians in Myanmar
summary: The United Nations is "horrified" by reports of a massacre in Myanmar, where at least 35 civilians, including children and women, were killed and their bodies burned. The incident occurred in eastern Kaya state, and a monitoring group and local media have blamed the attack on junta troops. The UN has called for a thorough and transparent investigation, and two workers for Save the Children remain missing after their vehicle was attacked. The violence is part of a broader crackdown by security forces in Myanmar, which has resulted in over 1,300 deaths since a February coup.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.05% to 1,517.26. A total of 79.31 million lots were traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 108 to 91. The market's performance was not affected by the latest Trump threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit to acquire second data centre in London for £57m
summary: Keppel DC Reit is acquiring its second data centre in London, "London Data Centre", for £57 million. The property, leased to a telco company until 2039, will increase the Reit's weighted average lease expiry to 8.1 years. The acquisition, expected to be completed in Q1 2022, will be funded by proceeds from the Reit's recent placement and external financing, increasing aggregate leverage to 38.2% from 36.4%. This is the Reit's third UK acquisition, with a total of 21 data centres in the Asia-Pacific and Europe.

site_title: Keppel FELS partners Sumitomo to explore ammonia fuel business in Singapore
summary: Keppel FELS, a global offshore group, has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Japanese trading house Sumitomo Corp to explore the feasibility and implementation of various ammonia fuel applications in Singapore. The companies aim to develop an ammonia bunkering vessel and expand the ammonia value chain, with plans to commence commercial operations in the mid-2020s. They also plan to utilize ammonia as an energy carrier for hydrogen production, leveraging Keppel's engineering expertise and bunkering experience to deepen decarbonization efforts.

site_title: US retail sales up 8.5% this holiday season
summary: US retail sales rose 8.5% this holiday season, the strongest in 17 years, according to a Mastercard study. Online sales increased 11% and in-store sales 8.1% from November 1 to Christmas Eve. Key growth areas included apparel (47.3% increase), jewelry (32% increase), and department stores (21.2% increase). Consumers made purchases earlier than usual, seeking "guaranteed by Christmas" delivery.

site_title: UAE plans to scrap import monopolies of some big merchant families: FT
summary: The UAE government plans to scrap import monopolies held by some of its biggest business families, according to a proposed legislation. The move aims to modernize the economy and give foreign firms the opportunity to distribute their own goods or change local agents.
