summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at the open on Friday, driven by optimism over the Omicron Covid-19 variant. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased 3.86 points to 3,100.67, with gains outnumbering losses 68 to 24. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose in early trade. The rally follows a strong holiday-shortened week on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 set a record and the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 68 to 24, after 25.4 million securities worth S$19 million changed hands.

site_title: Omicron hospitalisation rate up to 70% lower: UK government agency
summary: The UK's Health Security Agency reported that hospitalisation rates for Omicron are up to 70% lower compared to the Delta variant, with an estimated 31-45% lower likelihood of attending A&E and 50-70% lower likelihood of hospital admission. Preliminary research based on 132 confirmed Omicron hospitalisations found that 17 received a booster vaccine, 74 had received 2 doses, and 27 were not vaccinated. These findings support previous studies showing Omicron infections are less likely to result in hospitalization compared to Delta.

site_title: Japan to put off sending officials to Beijing Winter Olympics: NHK
summary: Japan is likely to cancel plans to send officials to the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics due to diplomatic pressure from the US and other Western countries. Despite not attending the Games, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has faced pressure within his party to take a tougher stance on China. Japan's delicate position as a close US ally and major trade partner with China has led to a softer stance on the issue. A decision is expected to be announced as early as Friday.

site_title: A Christmas to remember
summary: Industry leaders in Singapore share their reflections on 2021, a challenging year marked by the pandemic. Despite the difficulties, many companies remained positive, with Pan Pacific Hotels Group reporting a positive global business result. The hospitality industry continued to grow, with new hotel openings and awards for "Best Regional Hotel Chain" and "Asia's Leading Service Apartment." Notable figures, such as Nathan Yong and Ivan Heng, expressed their desire for the pandemic to end, allowing for a return to normal life. Meanwhile, fashion designer Max Tan sees opportunities for growth in the industry, as international brands shift their paradigms and Singaporean brands adapt to new consumer expectations.

site_title: Badminton champ has new game to master - managing sponsors
summary: Singapore's new badminton world champion, Loh Kean Yew, is poised to attract sponsors and companies as he chases Olympic glory in 2024. With a strong online presence and charisma, Loh is expected to multiply his followers and net worth as he becomes a marketable personality. Similar to Singapore swimmer Joseph Schooling, Loh's success in badminton could lead to lucrative sponsorship deals, with companies looking to associate themselves with his dynamic personality and rising star status.

site_title: Trump asks Supreme Court to block records release to Jan 6 probe
summary: Former US President Donald Trump asked the Supreme Court to block the release of documents related to the Jan 6 Capitol assault to a congressional committee. Trump's lawyers argued that a former president has the right to assert executive privilege, despite a federal appeals court ruling allowing President Joe Biden to waive it. The Supreme Court will review the case, which could impact the release of White House records and phone records potentially linked to the attack.

site_title: After another stunning US stock-market year, investors wonder how much gas is left
summary: The US stock market is poised for a potential decline in 2022 due to a more hawkish Federal Reserve, slowing earnings growth, and the ongoing pandemic. Despite a strong 2021, with the S&P 500 up 87% since 2018, the odds of continued positive momentum are considered low. Strategists project the S&P 500 to finish 2022 at 4,910, up 4.5% from the previous year. Rising bond yields and concerns over valuations may pressure stocks, while strong earnings and revenue growth could still drive the market higher.

site_title: mDR fires COO Richard Siau amid investigations into suspected misconduct
summary: mDR Limited has terminated the employment of group COO Richard Siau due to suspected misconduct amid investigations into unauthorized use of marketing incentive rebates at its subsidiaries. A total of S$2.08 million was misappropriated for unauthorized sales of handsets and accessories. Siau will no longer hold any position in the company, and Ong Ghim Choon will assume his roles and responsibilities. The company has made a police report and is cooperating with the Commercial Affairs Department and police.

site_title: Europe: London stocks climb as Omicron fears fade
summary: UK shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, extending a two-day rally, as concerns over the Omicron variant's effects faded. Financial stocks led the gain, with banks advancing 1.0%, driven by rising UK gilt yields. Analysts say investors are taking a "glass half full" approach, despite Omicron's lingering risks. The FTSE 100's gain pushed the market higher, despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: UK shares rose on Thursday as markets globally rallied following two research studies that suggested the effects of the Omicron coronavirus variant were less severe than the Delta variant.

site_title: US regulator authorises Merck's Covid pill
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) authorized Merck's Covid-19 pill for high-risk adults, expanding treatment options amid a winter surge of cases driven by Omicron. This comes a day after Pfizer's similar but more effective pill was authorized. Experts welcome the addition, citing the pills' ability to inhibit virus replication and withstand variants. The FDA's Patrizia Cavazzoni stated that the authorizations will help alleviate the burden on the nation's healthcare system, increasing the arsenal of treatment options available to the public.

site_title: Oil prices stable as positive Covid-19 news balances curbs
summary: Oil prices remained stable on Thursday, with Brent crude futures rising 0.4% to $75.56 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures increasing 0.3% to $72.97 a barrel. The stability was attributed to positive news about the Omicron variant being more containable, despite new Covid-19 restrictions amid surging infections. Analysts expect the rally to continue as long as Omicron remains contagious but less virulent.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were broadly stable on Thursday as signs that the worst effects of the Omicron variant might be more containable than previously feared were countered by new Covid-19 restrictions amid surging infections.

site_title: Tighter labour market due not just to recovery, but also constraints
summary: Singapore's labour market recovery is set to continue in 2022, driven by easing Covid-19 curbs and businesses seeking growth. However, the labour market still faces a manpower shortfall due to constraints, not just the recovery. A skills mismatch remains a concern. This tighter labour market is a departure from Singapore's traditional lagging labour market recovery.

site_title: Brexit trade trouble increasingly hits UK firms: BCC
summary: A survey by the British Chambers of Commerce found that 45% of UK companies reported difficulty trading with the European Union under the Brexit trade deal, up from 30% in January. For exporting companies, this figure was 60%. The survey also showed an increase in difficulty trading services with the EU, to 23% from 14%. The findings suggest structural issues with the Trade and Cooperation Agreement that could lead to long-term damage to the UK's import and export sectors.

site_title: Buzz!
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Christmas weekend dining options are still available, despite the holiday rush. Raffles Hotel Singapore is taking festive takeaway orders until Dec 25, while Les Amis offers luxurious takeaway items, including artisanal cheese and caviar. Amo & Gemma Steakhouse provide full Christmas dinner bundles with a 2-day lead time. For a change of pace, Mezame! offers tapas and signature fusion food. Christmas Wonderland at Gardens by the Bay features light displays, a Mistletoe Alley Market, and a Magical Carriage. Free concerts and jazz performances are also available, including Lyrebirds and Jacintha & Robert: The Christmas Songs Concert.

site_title: Pansy Ho's Shun Tak walks away from S$556m High Point deal amid latest property cooling measures
summary: Hong Kong-listed Shun Tak Holdings has called off its en-bloc deal for High Point condominium in Singapore, forfeiting its S$1 million tender deposit, amid the latest property cooling measures announced by the government. The deal, valued at S$556.7 million, would have been Shun Tak's fifth acquisition in downtown Singapore in five years. The cooling measures, which include higher buyer's stamp duty rates, are expected to cool the en-bloc market, analysts say.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at record, extending stocks rally
summary: US stocks closed at a record high on Thursday, with the S&P 500 rising 0.6% to 4,725.79, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbing 0.5% to 35,950.56. The Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 0.8% to 15,653.37. The rally was driven by optimism over the Omicron variant of Covid-19 and the approval of new virus treatment pills. The market also saw higher consumer spending and inflation, with the Commerce Department data showing a mostly decent picture of the US economy.

site_title: US durable goods orders increase more than forecast
summary: US durable goods orders increased 2.5% in November, exceeding forecasts and indicating steady demand for production growth in early 2022. Commercial aircraft orders rose 34.1%, while motor vehicle orders rose 1%. Core capital goods orders fell 0.1%, contrary to expectations of a 0.7% increase. Despite softer business equipment orders, the data suggests robust private investment to bolster productivity and production capacity.

images.alt_text: Orders placed with US factories for durable goods rose in November by the most in 6 months, exceeding forecasts and pointing to steady demand that will help drive production growth in early 2022.

site_title: Putin sees 'positive' US reaction to Russia security proposals
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin said the US reaction to Russia's security proposals is "positive," amid growing tensions over Nato's eastward expansion in Ukraine. Putin stated that Washington is willing to discuss the proposals, but disagrees with some points, and plans to meet in Geneva at the start of next year. The Kremlin has presented sweeping security demands, including barring Nato from admitting new members and restricting US bases in former Soviet countries.

site_title: Applied Materials and A*Star invest US$210m in research on heterogenous integration over 5 years
summary: Applied Materials and A*Star's research collaboration has secured a $210 million investment over 5 years to focus on heterogeneous integration and advanced packaging solutions for hybrid bonding and emerging 3D chip integration technologies. This brings the total investment to $460 million since the collaboration began 10 years ago. The partnership aims to accelerate materials, equipment, and process technology solutions to enable continued advances in power, performance, area, cost, and time-to-market. The new lab space and expanded research team will focus on creating "chiplets" and fine interconnects between them, increasing supply chain resilience and enabling companies to source from different suppliers.

site_title: Alibaba admits it was slow to report software bug after Beijing rebuke
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has admitted to being slow to report a major software bug in the Log4j open-source software, which was discovered by its researcher Chen Zhaojun in November. The bug, if left unfixed, could allow hackers to install backdoors in millions of computer systems. China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) has suspended cooperation with Alibaba on a cybersecurity information sharing platform for 6 months, citing the company's slow reporting of the flaw. Alibaba has pledged to strengthen its security flaw reporting systems and improve internet security.

site_title: The ghost of iX'mas future
summary: BMW's electric iX is its tech flagship, drawing inspiration from the hospitality industry, particularly boutique hotels. The car features a clean-sheet design, advanced features like air-conditioning and a companion app, and sustainable materials. The iX boasts a spacious interior, plush seats, and a large twin-screen display. Its electric propulsion provides nearly silent acceleration, and it handles with comfort rather than sportiness. However, the car's complex infotainment system and "Shy Tech" minimalism may require time to adjust to. The iX is priced at around $400,000 and is set to be joined by a more powerful xDrive50 version next year.

site_title: How 'Erdonomics' sank Turkey
summary: Turkey's economy is in crisis due to high inflation, stalling growth, and depleted foreign-exchange reserves. The crisis is largely self-inflicted, resulting from President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's government's suppression of democratic institutions, support for a religious state, and low-interest-rate policies. The Turkish inflation rate has reached 21% and is expected to rise further, affecting the well-being of Turkish households. The government's stimulus policies have accelerated inflation, triggering capital flight and a depreciation of the lira. Unless the government reverses course and implements reforms, the outlook for Turkey's economy will continue to deteriorate.

site_title: Singapore is at the forefront of the cell-based protein industry
summary: Singapore is at the forefront of the cell-based protein industry, with the government aiming to produce 30% of its nutritional needs locally by 2030. The country has already approved the sale of cultured chicken and is open to regulatory approval and financial support for other companies, including those producing cell-based seafood. The industry, which also includes plant-based alternatives, has huge potential with growth rates of 40% per year over the next two decades, and could provide a sustainable solution to the climate emergency, with conventional meat production contributing 14.5% of global greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Competizione offers furious final fling with fossil fuel
summary: The Ferrari 812 Competizione is a limited-edition, front-engined V12 sports car that marks a swansong for Ferrari's beloved engine type, which will be phased out due to emissions regulations. With 30 horsepower more than the 812 Superfast, the Competizione boasts a lighter, sharper, and more powerful engine, as well as a redesigned cooling system and aerodynamics. The car delivers unparalleled performance, handling, and character, making it a masterpiece of engineering. Only 999 units were produced, and they have already sold out, making the 812 Competizione a highly sought-after collector's item.

site_title: US new home sales race to 7-month high in November
summary: US new home sales reached a 7-month high in November, increasing 12.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 744,000 units, the highest level since April. This surge was largely driven by a shortage of previously owned homes on the market. However, soaring house prices remain a barrier for first-time buyers. The median new house price accelerated 18.8% in November to US$416,900, and it would take 6.5 months to clear the supply of houses on the market at the current sales pace.

site_title: Singapore's rempah king Damian D'Silva returns with new heritage restaurant hidden in PLQ
summary: Singapore's Damian D'Silva has opened a new heritage restaurant, Rempapa, located at Park Place Residences in Paya Lebar Quarter. The restaurant serves a constantly changing menu from morning to night, with dishes such as chickpea curry, pork chop curry rice, and nasi lemak. The standout dishes include the baca assam, a 'lost' Eurasian dish of melting soft braised beef cheek, and the kueh, including deep-fried kueh ku and glutinous rice balls. With a strong kitchen team and a commitment to delivering traditional recipes, Rempapa is a must-visit for food enthusiasts. Rating: 7.5.

site_title: Private equity is raising property funding faster than it can be spent
summary: Private equity firms have raised record US$289 billion for commercial-property deals, up 11% from last year and 57% from 2019. This surge in capital is fueling the real estate market, with US commercial-property prices increasing by 18% in the past year. Despite a lack of distressed deals, record-breaking sales are expected, with US$614 billion booked in the first 11 months of 2021. Private equity firms are also contributing to the record US$4 trillion of debt outstanding for real estate, with many lending as much as US$100 billion this year.

site_title: CICT acquires 3rd Sydney property for A$422m
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) has agreed to acquire a 50% stake in a Sydney, Australia integrated development for A$422 million (S$409.3 million). The property, named 101 Miller Street and Greenwood Plaza, features a premium grade office tower and retail space in North Sydney's central business district. The acquisition is part of CICT's efforts to expand its presence in Australia, with the total investment of A$1.1 billion in three Sydney properties expected to drive growth in the country.

site_title: China's yuan is propelling emerging currencies like never before
summary: China's yuan is experiencing a record-high correlation with emerging-market currencies, with its link to the MSCI Emerging-Markets Currency Index reaching 0.81 in September. This is driven by the yuan's strong links to the Brazilian real and India's rupee, and may play a crucial role in determining the performance of emerging markets in the coming year. Investors are drawn to yuan-denominated bonds as an alternative to US Treasuries, while some banks call for the yuan to join the dollar, euro, and yen as a global reserve currency.

images.alt_text: The Chinese yuan is having a greater impact on its emerging-market counterparts than ever before, and may play a crucial role in determining their performance in the coming year.

site_title: Japan's MUFG to launch new US$300m debt venture fund
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) will launch a new US$300 million debt fund for late-stage tech startups in the Asia-Pacific region, led by Singapore-based joint venture Mars Growth Capital. The fund, to be created early next year, will provide debt financing to startups, including unicorns, and support their initial public offerings if they choose to go public. The fund's financing decisions will be based on Liquidity Capital's artificial intelligence-driven credit scoring model, helping MUFG extend loans to startups in difficult financial situations.

site_title: 'Tis the season of giving - at a cost?
summary: A recent article questions the legitimacy of high profits by retailers during the Christmas season, amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. Two writers present differing views, with one defending the right to raise prices and the other seeing it as unsustainable and unsavory. The article raises questions about the ethics of corporate profiteering and the true meaning of Christmas, suggesting that the pursuit of high profits may come at the expense of the festive spirit.

site_title: Frasers Property scraps plans for JV involving investment, bridging loan
summary: Frasers Property has scrapped plans for a joint-venture investment involving a land deal. The company's subsidiary, Suzhou Sing He Ziang Management Consultancy, entered a framework agreement with an unnamed partner to acquire a 40% stake and provide a 1.6 billion yuan loan. However, the loan was repaid in full, and the joint-venture fell through, with no further details provided.

site_title: The lucrative Asian gaming industry is evolving
summary: The Asian gaming industry is experiencing significant growth, with revenues expected to exceed $140 billion by 2025, a 70% increase from current earnings. With 3 billion gamers worldwide, Asia-Pacific gamers make up over half of the global market. The industry is driven by emerging trends, including mobile, social, cloud, and eSports gaming, with South-east Asia accounting for 99% of the region's eSports revenue. To sustain growth, networks must prioritize gamers' needs, including reliable and consistent connectivity, low latency, and comfort. The industry is also evolving within the cloud ecosystem, with 5G, edge cloud, and cloud gaming emerging as key technologies.

site_title: A taste of Yamazaki 55
summary: The Yamazaki 55, a rare Japanese whisky, was recently paired at a dinner event at 3 Michelin-starred restaurant Odette. The 55, aged from 1960 and 1964 vintage, was described as having a buttery and creamy nose with a unique blend of flavors, including macadamia nuts and caramel. The finish was described as lingering with pleasant bitterness and sweetness. Compared to other single malts, the Yamazaki 55 is less smoky and has a lighter finish due to its aging in Mizunara white oak. The event showcased the whisky's complexity and finesse, with one bottle reportedly selling for S$1.2 million.

images.alt_text: One bottle was reportedly auctioned by Bonhams for close to S$1.2 million - 10 times its estimated price.

site_title: Winding up application filed against Kitchen Culture's subsidiary
summary: A creditor, Kim Hup Lee, has filed a winding-up application against Kitchen Culture Holdings' subsidiary, KHL Marketing Asia-Pacific, over outstanding rental arrears of S$1.8 million. The application will be heard in the High Court of Singapore on Jan 14. Kitchen Culture Holdings is seeking advice from its solicitors on the next steps, including resisting the application. The outcome of the case is uncertain and the company will make further announcements as required.

site_title: Italy business morale slips in December but consumers more upbeat
summary: Italy's business morale decreased in December to 113.1, down from November's 114.8, due to rising Covid-19 infections and concerns about economic recovery. However, consumer confidence unexpectedly increased to 117.7, beating forecasts, possibly due to government tax cuts announced in the 2022 budget. The eurozone's third-largest economy contracted 8.9% last year, with forecasts predicting a 6.0% rebound this year, despite recent positive data and reassurances from the government.

site_title: US inflation-adjusted spending stagnates as prices surge
summary: US consumer spending, adjusted for inflation, stagnated in November, with purchases little changed after a 0.7% gain in October. Unadjusted spending rose 0.6%, matching economists' estimates. Fastest price gains in nearly 4 decades eroded purchasing power, and inflation-adjusted disposable income fell 0.2% for the fourth straight month. The Federal Reserve's hawkish pivot has led to accelerated asset-selling and interest-rate projections favoring a 0.75% rate hike next year.

site_title: US dollar near one-week low as Omicron fears ease
summary: The US dollar index remains near a one-week low at 96.159, as fears of Omicron Covid variant's impact ease. Higher risk currencies like the Australian dollar and British pound gain, while the dollar rises against the Japanese yen. US consumer confidence improves, and a South African study suggests reduced hospitalization risks for Omicron patients. The Australian dollar rises 0.3%, and the Norwegian crown reaches one-month highs. Markets predict short-lived US dollar correction, with potential for rate hikes from the Fed.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose to 3.8% in November, exceeding economists' expectations. This is the highest inflation rate since February 2013. A new luxury mixed-use development, 30 Bideford Road, has been put on the market for S$600 million. The Housing & Development Board launched an executive condominium site at Bukit Batok West Avenue 8. Former Oriental Group executives have been charged with alleged misappropriation, securities fraud, and cheating. Singapore stocks gained 0.3% on Thursday, tracking regional gains amid thin trading.

site_title: China targets online platforms in quest to 'clean up' Internet
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) is launching a 2-month operation to scrutinize online platforms, targeting fake accounts and information. The operation aims to "clean up" the Internet by clamping down on deceptive behaviors, including boosting engagement figures and paying for fake fans and reviews. This follows a wide-ranging crackdown on several sectors, including technology and finance. Previous special operations have targeted celebrity fandom, minors' internet usage, and historical event discussions. The move is part of China's efforts to promote a "civilized" internet, with a focus on education about the ruling Communist Party.

site_title: Festive cocktails
summary: Award-winning bars share festive cocktail recipes for the holiday season. "Fancy Fizz" combines Monkey 47 Sloe Gin, persimmon syrup, lemon juice, egg white, and Brut Champagne, while "Christmas Martinez" features Farmer's Gin, Mancino Rosso, Luxardo Maraschino Cherry Liqueur, and Orange Bitters. The recipes, from Jigger & Pony and Manhattan Bar, require minimal ingredients and are easy to prepare at home. Perfect for holiday gatherings and entertaining, these cocktails showcase the creativity and expertise of award-winning bartenders.

site_title: Lew Syn Pau steps down as SUTL chairman, Richard Eu to be appointed ID
summary: SUTL Enterprise's non-executive chairman Lew Syn Pau steps down on Dec 31, allowing for a board refresh. Richard Eu, group chairman of Eu Yan Sang International, joins as an independent director on Dec 31. Eu, who stepped down as CEO of Eu Yan Sang in 2017, was recommended by SUTL's board through internal nomination and assessment. This change aims to bring in fresh perspectives and expertise to the board.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims hold steady below pre-pandemic level; consumer spending rises
summary: US jobless claims remain steady below pre-pandemic levels, while consumer spending rose 0.6% in November, contributing to the economy's strong finish to 2021. The unemployment rate hit a 21-month low of 4.2%. However, price pressures increased, with underlying inflation recording its largest annual increase since the 1980s. Economists forecast a 7.2% growth rate for the fourth quarter, with the overall 2021 growth expected to be 5.6%, the fastest since 1984.

site_title: US core capital goods orders fall unexpectedly in November
summary: US core capital goods orders unexpectedly fell 0.1% in November, contradicting economists' forecasts of a 0.6% rise. Shipments of core capital goods rose 0.3% after a 0.4% increase in October, but business spending on equipment contracted in the third quarter due to a shortage of motor vehicles and semiconductors. Durable goods orders accelerated 2.5% in November, driven by a 6.5% jump in transportation equipment orders, while civilian aircraft orders soared 34.1% after falling 4.1% in October.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust unit to divest Changi industrial building for S$13m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) agreed to sell an industrial building at 19 Changi South Street 1 to Esco Micro for S$13 million, a 4.8% premium over its purchase price in 2010. The building, valued at S$11.9 million, contributed 0.2% to MIT's portfolio gross revenue in 2021. The sale will fund committed investments and working capital requirements, or reduce existing debt. The transaction is expected to be completed by mid-2022 and is subject to JTC Corporation approval.

site_title: Budget retailer Miniso weighing Hong Kong listing next year
summary: Miniso Group Holding, a Chinese budget retailer, is considering a Hong Kong listing next year, according to people familiar with the matter. The firm is working with Bank of America and UBS Group on the proposed share sale, which could raise a few hundred million dollars. This move comes as some Chinese companies seek a foothold in Hong Kong amid Sino-US tensions, which may block their access to the US capital markets. Miniso has already listed on the New York Stock Exchange and operates over 4,200 stores in 80 countries.

site_title: Applied Materials and A*Star invest US$210m in research on heterogenous integration over 5 years
summary: Applied Materials and A*Star research institute have invested US$210 million in a 5-year research collaboration focused on heterogenous integration and advanced packaging solutions for the semiconductor industry. The investment will expand research facilities and hire 30 additional staff, aiming to accelerate the development of hybrid bonding and 3D chip integration technologies. This collaboration seeks to enable continued advances in power, performance, area, cost, and time-to-market, with the goal of manufacturing "chiplets" and increasing supply chain resilience.

site_title: Mixed-use newbuild on former Thong Sia Building site on the market for S$600m
summary: A newly completed 18-storey luxury mixed-use development, 30 Bideford Road, has been put on the market in Singapore for S$600 million. The freehold building, formerly known as Thong Sia Building, features 168 serviced residences, retail, office, and medical space. The development, designed by Nikken Sekkei, received its temporary occupation permit in 2020 and is located in the Orchard shopping belt. The sale is expected to attract investors looking for a brand-new freehold trophy asset in prime District 9, and the joint tender will close on February 15, 2022.

site_title: Spain revises GDP growth sharply higher after data doubts
summary: Spain's economy grew 3.4% in the third quarter, surpassing the initial estimate of 2.7%, according to official figures. The revision was attributed to stronger-than-expected household spending and exports. However, the improved data may be short-lived due to the resurgent pandemic, which has prompted lockdowns and travel bans in Europe. Analysts predict a slowdown in the economy during the winter, with the International Monetary Fund downgrading Spain's economic outlook for 2021 and 2022.

site_title: 53 of 65 Omicron cases detected in Singapore as at Monday arrived via VTL
summary: Singapore reported 53 of 65 Omicron cases as of Dec 20, with 41 detected through on-arrival PCR tests and 12 through the enhanced testing regime. Over 90% of cases were returning Singaporeans, permanent residents, and long-term residents. The Ministry of Health suspended the sale of new VTL flight tickets from Dec 23 to Jan 20 to slow the spread of the Omicron variant, while allowing eligible travellers to still travel via the quarantine-free scheme. The government aims to study and understand the variant, strengthen its defences, and minimize transmission.

site_title: Causeway Link VTL bus tickets from Jan 21 to 31 sold out as Malaysians return home for CNY
summary: Causeway Link's Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) bus tickets from Singapore to Johor Bahru sold out between Jan 21 and Jan 31 due to concerns over the Omicron variant and subsequent government restrictions. The government suspended ticket sales until Jan 20 and halved the quota for land VTL travel, resulting in 48 buses per day. Causeway Link had sold some pre-announced tickets, but ticket holders for days after the period now exceed the new capacity. The second bus operator, Transtar Travel, is taking a phased approach to ticket sales.

site_title: Singapore stocks gain on Thursday amid thin trading; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Thursday, driven by gains in regional exchanges, amid thin trading ahead of holidays. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,096.81, with 265 gainers outnumbering 169 losers. Key drivers included positive sentiment on the Omicron Covid-19 variant and gains in travel-related counters such as Singapore Airlines and SATS. Despite a decline in Keppel DC Reit, shares of Dairy Farm International and Genting Singapore closed higher, with analysts maintaining a buy call on Genting Singapore.

site_title: Asti's move to retrench CEO with S$1.4m entitlement questioned
summary: Asti Holdings, a semiconductor manufacturing services provider, has dismissed its CEO Michael Loh Soon Gnee with a S$1.4 million termination entitlement, sparking concerns over corporate governance. Professor Mak Yuen Teen questions the appropriateness of the move, citing a discrepancy between Asti's annual report and the company's bourse filing. Mak argues that the termination payment exceeds Loh's total remuneration for the previous year and that shareholder approval is required, but Asti claims no such approval was needed. The move has raised questions about the company's corporate governance and the lack of accountability for family-controlled companies.

site_title: London: Stocks climb as Omicron fears fade
summary: London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.2% on Dec 12, driven by a 2-day rally as research studies showed Omicron to be less severe than the Delta variant, lifting investor sentiment. Financial stocks led gains, with banks advancing 0.8%, while airline stocks Wizz Air and EasyJet also rose. However, the domestically focused mid-cap index was capped by a weakness in US dollar-earner companies, and British car manufacturers reported their slowest November in 37 years due to pandemic-related supply chain issues.

site_title: Tencent hands out US$16b of JD stock in crackdown-led shift
summary: Tencent Holdings plans to distribute over $16 billion of JD.com shares as a one-time dividend, a surprise move amid Beijing's crackdown on tech monopolies. The payout aims to buy goodwill with the government, which has pushed for dismantling barriers and sharing wealth among tech firms. Tencent President Martin Lau will exit JD's board, and the move may signal a shift in focus towards overseas growth and the metaverse. The payout has sparked speculation about Tencent's future holdings in other companies, but a person familiar with Tencent's management says there are no plans to pare down or exit investments.

images.alt_text: Tencent Holdings plans to distribute more than US$16 billion of JD.com shares as a one-time dividend, a surprise retreat from the Chinese e-commerce firm after Beijing moved to curtail the power of tech monopolies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up
summary: Tokyo stocks advanced on Thursday, December 23, 2021, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.83% to 28,798.37 and the Topix index increasing 0.91% to 1,989.43. The gains followed strong US consumer data, giving investors confidence. This was the second consecutive session of gains, as investors took heart from Wall Street's previous day's gains.

site_title: Thai GDP growth of 4% still possible next year despite Omicron: finance minister
summary: Thailand's finance minister, Arkhom Termpittayapaisith, stated that the country's economy is still expected to achieve a 4% growth rate next year despite the uncertainty surrounding the Omicron coronavirus variant. The tourism sector, which has recently reopened, is expected to recover, and an improved global economy will support Thailand's economy. The government's decision to reinstate mandatory quarantine for foreign visitors and scrap quarantine waivers for locals will likely have a minimal impact on growth.

site_title: China to fall short on promises to US as trade deal ends
summary: China is falling short on its promises to the US under the 2020 trade deal, failing to meet its target of buying 59% of the extra $200 billion in manufactured, agricultural, and energy goods by the end of 2021. Instead, China has secured only 45% of the promised goods, resulting in a record trade surplus of $358 billion with the US. Disruptions from the pandemic and punitive tariffs have hindered the deal's progress, with US officials calling for China to make changes to its trade policies.

site_title: Intel apologises in China over Xinjiang supplier statement
summary: Intel, a US chip maker, apologized in China for its recent letter to suppliers warning against sourcing products or labor from the Xinjiang region, amid criticism and calls for a boycott. The move follows restrictions imposed by "multiple governments" and US accusations of human rights abuses in the region. Intel claimed its commitment to avoid Xinjiang supply chains was an expression of compliance with US law, not a statement on the issue. The company's apology was met with skepticism in China, with some questioning its sincerity.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on December 23, extending a three-day rally, driven by optimistic US data and reduced concerns about Omicron hospitalizations. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.40% to 23,193.64, while the Shanghai Composite Index increased 0.60% to 3,643.34.

site_title: Europe: Stocks gain as concerns about Omicron's severity ease
summary: European stocks rose for a third day, with the Stoxx Europe 600 increasing 0.3% to a 2-week high, driven by optimism over Omicron's severity and the approval of Pfizer's Covid-19 pill. Studies suggest Omicron may not lead to hospitalizations, and AstraZeneca's booster shot increased antibody levels. The European Central Bank remains dovish, supporting growth prospects and sentiment for European stocks. Despite a relief rally, some analysts caution it's not sustainable, waiting for further news and studies on Omicron and the US-EU trade situation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at 1-week high as Omicron fears ease
summary: South Korean shares closed at a one-week high on December 23 as Omicron Covid-19 variant fears eased, boosting investor confidence. The Kospi index rose 0.46% to 2,998.17, with chip heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading gains. A South African study suggested Omicron was less likely to cause hospitalization than Delta, while the US authorized Pfizer's antiviral Covid-19 pill. Additionally, US consumer confidence improved and the White House resumed talks on a social spending and climate change bill, contributing to risk sentiment.

site_title: CICT acquires 3rd Sydney property for A$422m
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) has agreed to acquire a 50% interest in an integrated development in Sydney, Australia for A$422 million (S$409.3 million). This is the third Sydney property acquired by CICT, with the total investment reaching A$1.1 billion. The acquisition is expected to provide a new engine of growth for CICT in the developed market, with a potential to ride on Sydney's gradual recovery and rejuvenation. The purchase price is in line with an independent valuation and is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2022.

site_title: Apple shuts 8 US, Canada stores since Tuesday amid Covid surge
summary: Apple has temporarily shut down at least 8 retail stores in the US and Canada due to a surge in Covid-19 cases among employees and the public. The stores closed since Tuesday include locations in Miami, Atlanta, Houston, and Montreal. Apple typically closes a store when around 10% of staff test positive for Covid-19. The closures are part of the company's health measures, which include regular testing, daily health checks, employee and customer masking, and paid sick leave.

site_title: 2 dead, scores missing after Myanmar jade mine disaster
summary: At least two people have died and dozens remain missing after a landslide at a jade mine in northern Myanmar's Hpakant township. Rescuers fear scores more are unaccounted for as families are hesitant to admit their relatives were present due to a junta ban on digging until March 2022. The incident is the latest tragedy in the poorly regulated multi-billion-dollar jade industry, which has been linked to a decades-long civil war and rampant drug and arms trade.

site_title: Lotte Group weighs 10b yuan sale of China theme park
summary: Lotte Group is considering selling its stalled theme park project in northeastern China for at least 10 billion yuan (S$2.1 billion). The project, which was halted in 2016 due to safety and tax inspections, was initially planned to be completed by 2019. The decision to sell comes after Lotte Group retreated from China due to anti-Korean sentiment and subsequent slump in sales. Deliberations are ongoing, and there is no certainty a transaction will occur, with the company also considering keeping the complex.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on Thursday as Covid fears ease
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, following Wall Street's lead, as concerns over inflation and Covid eased. Preliminary studies from Britain indicated Omicron infections were less likely to result in hospitalization, and the FDA authorized Pfizer's anti-Covid pill. Despite new cases of the Omicron strain soaring, market watchers are becoming more confident the health effects will be milder. US data showed consumers remained upbeat about the economy, with the consumer confidence index jumping nearly four points, and GDP expanded at a faster annual rate of 2.3%.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts fined A$1m by regulator for flouting junket rules
summary: Australia's Crown Resorts has been fined A$1 million by the Victorian Commission for Gambling and Liquor Regulation for violating junket rules. The regulator found Crown Melbourne allowed an associate of an unsuitable junket operator to continue operations despite being directed to cease. This is the maximum fine currently in place, with a proposed increase to A$100 million. Crown Resorts had previously been penalized in April for similar breaches, leading to tightened regulations. The company has permanently ceased dealings with junket operators and plans to continue reforming.

site_title: Oriental Group's former CEO, execs hauled to court for alleged misappropriation, securities fraud, cheating
summary: Former Oriental Group executives, including CEO Tan Nai Lun, have been charged with misappropriation, securities fraud, and cheating. The group was wound up by the Singapore High Court in 2019 after failing to secure an investor deal. Tan Nai Lun is accused of misappropriating S$500,000, while others are charged with conspiring to manipulate the company's share price and forging documents. Seven individuals are also charged with placing unauthorized orders in the group's shares.

site_title: At least 10 major Singapore companies have new chiefs this year
summary: At least 10 major Singapore companies have changed their CEOs this year, with notable appointments including Dilhan Pillay Sandrasegara at Temasek Holdings, Yuen Kuan Moon at Singtel, Nikhil Eapen at StarHub, Helen Wong at OCBC, Vincent Phang at SingPost, Gary Ho at Nanofilm, Lee Ghai Keen at Venture Corp, Kerry Mok at Sats, Nicholas Chua at Ho Bee Land, and Anthea Lee at Keppel DC Reit. These changes reflect the companies' focus on digital growth, climate change, and transformation strategies.

site_title: Australian states reinstate Covid-19 curbs as Omicron cases jump
summary: Australia's two most populous states, New South Wales and Victoria, have re-introduced COVID-19 curbs, including mandatory mask-wearing indoors and limiting venue visitors, amid a surge in Omicron cases. The move comes as daily infections hit a record 8,200, with over 90% of the population double-vaccinated. Despite low hospitalizations and deaths, authorities aim to prevent healthcare workers from being furloughed due to testing positive. The changes, implemented two days before Christmas, are a cautious approach to managing the outbreak during the holiday period.

images.alt_text: Australia's two most populous states re-introduced Covid-19 curbs on Thursday as daily infections hit their highest amid an outbreak of the highly infectious Omicron variant and a rush on already-stretched testing clinics.

site_title: Japan rules out changes to Covid-19 curbs despite Omicron
summary: Japan's government has ruled out immediate changes to Covid-19 restrictions despite the discovery of the Omicron variant in the country. A family of three in Osaka was confirmed infected, but the origin of the virus remains unknown. The government is preparing to expand free testing for asymptomatic individuals to prevent Omicron's spread. No changes to current restrictions are being considered, with the focus on proactive measures to control the virus.

site_title: Indonesia sees commodities driving 2021 exports to record US$230b
summary: Indonesia's exports are expected to reach a record US$225-230 billion in 2021, driven by rising commodity prices, particularly coal, palm oil, tin, steel, and rubber. This would surpass the country's previous record of US$203.5 billion in 2011. The country's trade surplus is projected to be around US$34-35 billion, with some analysts expecting it could help anchor the rupiah currency amid global monetary tightening.

site_title: Singapore's surprise 3.8% headline inflation in Nov prompts higher full-year forecasts
summary: Singapore's inflation rate rose to 3.8% in November, exceeding economists' expectations of 3.4%. This is the highest since February 2013. Core inflation, excluding private transport, increased to 1.6%, above the 1.5% estimate. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) raised their full-year forecasts for 2021 to 2.3% for headline inflation, while maintaining their 2022 outlook. Economists expect the MAS to tighten policy settings in April, driven by higher core inflation, mainly due to services inflation and electricity costs.

images.alt_text: Christmas decor and car tail-lights illuminate Orchard Road. As the recovery in domestic demand continues, headline inflation surprised on the upside at 3.8 per cent in November, driven by higher private transport prices.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda says weak yen may push up cost of living, hurt households more than before
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that a weak yen may increase the cost of living and hurt households more than in the past, as Japan's reliance on expensive raw material imports grows. Despite acknowledging potential drawbacks, Kuroda believes the benefits of a weak yen, such as increased competitiveness and profits, outweigh the costs. A quantitative analysis by the Bank's staff found that the effects of the yen's depreciation on prices of durable goods have increased in recent years. Kuroda's comments highlight growing concerns among policymakers about the impact of a weak yen on Japan's fragile recovery.

site_title: Australia: Gold, banking stocks drive shares up as Omicron worries ease
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 7,387.6 points, driven by gains in gold and financial stocks, as concerns over the Omicron variant eased after studies suggested it was less lethal than the Delta variant. Despite a reported 8,200 new cases, investor sentiment improved, marking a third consecutive day of gains.

site_title: Co-working spaces in the CBD to continue expansion in 2022: Cushman & Wakefield
summary: Co-working spaces in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) are expected to expand 5.5% of Grade A office spaces in 2022, according to Cushman & Wakefield. This growth is driven by improving market conditions and occupiers' demand for flexibility, workplace analytics, and hospitality-style services. Major co-working operators WeWork, JustCo, and IWG will continue to dominate the market, with notable new openings including WeWork's 200,000 sq ft space at 21 Collyer Quay. Grade A office rents are forecasted to rise 4.6% year-on-year in 2022, with co-working operators expected to directly lease space and adopt hybrid arrangements.

images.alt_text: According to Cushman & Wakefield, Grade A office rents in the CBD are forecasted to rise by 4.6 per cent year-on-year in 2022.

site_title: Citigroup to sell Philippines consumer assets to Union Bank
summary: Citigroup has agreed to sell its consumer banking assets in the Philippines to Union Bank for a cash consideration plus a premium of $1.2 billion. The deal covers credit cards, unsecured lending, deposits, and investments, and is expected to conclude in the second half of 2022. Approximately 1,750 employees will transfer to Union Bank. The sale is part of Citigroup's strategy to reshape itself around more profitable units, with the wealth franchise focusing on hubs in Hong Kong, London, Singapore, and the UAE.

site_title: Biden says a Trump candidacy would motivate second term run
summary: US President Joe Biden says a potential rematch against 2020 rival Donald Trump in the 2024 presidential election could motivate him to run for a second term. Biden expressed confidence in his health and stated he would run again if he's in good health. Trump has hinted at another presidential campaign, but has yet to make an official announcement. Biden's comments come as his relationship with Vice President Kamala Harris has raised questions about her potential future in the White House.

site_title: Singapore's headline inflation surprises on upside at 3.8% in Nov, highest since Feb 2013
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose to 3.8% in November, exceeding economists' expectations and the highest since February 2013. Stronger private transport inflation of 17.9% drove the increase, while accommodation inflation rose to 2.7%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry revised their full-year estimates, but official forecasts for 2022 remained unchanged.

site_title: Japan professor creates 'tele-taste' TV screen
summary: A Japanese professor, Homei Miyashita, has developed a "tele-taste" TV screen called Taste the TV (TTTV), which can imitate food flavors. The device uses a carousel of 10 flavor canisters to create a taste experience on a flat TV screen. A commercial version of the TTTV would cost around 100,000 yen ($1,192). Potential applications include distance learning for sommeliers and cooks, and tasting games and quizzes. The technology aims to enhance the way people connect and interact with the outside world, especially during the COVID-19 era.

site_title: Bt Batok EC site launched; bids unlikely to top record for Tampines plot
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched an executive condominium (EC) site at Bukit Batok West Avenue 8 for sale by public tender, marking the second EC site launched in 2021. The 99-year leasehold site is expected to yield 375 residential units, with a site area of 12,449.30 square meters. Bids are anticipated to be moderate, with estimates ranging from S$580 to S$630 per square foot per plot ratio, potentially topping the record S$422 million bid for the Tampines Street 62 EC site in July 2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% or 13.56 points to 3,101.07 in early trade on Thursday, following a rally on Wall Street. The gains were driven by strong US consumer data, which boosted stocks in the US and Europe. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also saw significant gains, with DBS rising 0.5%, UOB 0.2%, and OCBC 0.9%.

site_title: British data indicates lower hospitalisation rate for Omicron
summary: British data indicates lower hospitalization rates for Omicron, with two studies showing the variant is less likely to result in hospitalization compared to the Delta variant. Experts welcome the trend, but note that Omicron's heightened infectiousness may still lead to more severe cases. These preliminary studies, published in Scotland and England, confirm a trend first identified in South Africa and are considered qualified good news, as they show a reduced risk of hospitalizations, but are subject to further analysis.

site_title: Japan raises FY2022 GDP growth estimate amid risks to outlook
summary: Japan has upgraded its fiscal year 2022 GDP growth estimate to 3.2% from 2.2% due to a record stimulus budget, despite risks from the Omicron variant and supply constraints. This marks the fastest growth since 2010, driven by the stimulus spending expected to push up GDP by 1.5% this fiscal year and 3.6% next fiscal year. However, the government has downgraded its current fiscal year estimate to 2.6% due to prolonged Covid-19 pandemic and supply constraints, delaying the economy's return to pre-pandemic levels until March next year.

site_title: Family-run listcos: A smart investment decision, or 'clusters of long-term insiders'?
summary: A Singapore-listed company, Asti 575, has retrenched its CEO, Michael Loh Soon Gnee, and will pay him S$1.4 million instead of S$2 million. This move is part of the company's efforts to ensure its survival. The company is on the Singapore Exchange's watch list and owns stakes in two other troubled companies. Family-run listcos are often criticized for their poor corporate governance structures, with decision-making concentrated in a cluster of long-term insiders, making it challenging for outsiders to bring alternative views. Experts warn that family-run companies may prioritize maintaining control over making sustainable investments.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 4.82 points or 0.32% to 1505.41. The index saw 234.14 million lots traded worth RM140.30 million, with 239 gains outnumbering 160 losses.

site_title: Xi'an locks down as China races to zero-Covid for Olympics
summary: Xi'an, a major Chinese city, has been placed under strict stay-at-home orders, affecting 13 million residents, as authorities attempt to contain a recent Covid-19 outbreak six weeks before the Winter Olympics. The lockdown includes mass testing, travel restrictions, and closure of non-essential businesses. Cases have spread to five other cities, including Beijing and Guangdong, fueling concerns about the virus's geographic spread. The strict zero-Covid strategy is part of China's efforts to host the Olympics safely.

site_title: Asti CEO retrenched amid 'difficult period' for company
summary: Asti Holdings CEO Michael Loh Soon Gnee has been retrenched amid a 'difficult period' for the company, which is undergoing a company-wide retrenchment exercise. The move comes as the group seeks to exit the SGX financial watch-list and remains afloat due to the pandemic and geopolitical tensions. Loh will remain chairman and Anthony Loh, CFO, will act as acting CEO until Dec 31. The company's shares closed up 3.6% on the news.

site_title: Tencent to give US$16.4b JD.com stake to shareholders as dividend
summary: Tencent, the Chinese gaming and social media giant, will distribute its majority stake in JD.com, worth HK$127.69 billion, to its shareholders as a dividend. The stake, which Tencent once held at 17%, will be reduced to 2.3%. JD.com, an e-commerce firm, has reached a stage where it can self-finance its growth, prompting the transfer. The move will see Walmart become JD.com's largest shareholder. The transaction will result in the transfer of 457.3 million shares, with eligible shareholders receiving 1 share of JD.com for every 21 shares held.

site_title: James Franco admits sleeping with students, says he had sex addiction
summary: Actor James Franco has admitted to sleeping with students at his acting school, saying he struggled with a sex addiction and has since worked to improve his behavior. In a podcast interview, Franco, 43, acknowledged that he "did sleep with students, and that was wrong" while teaching. He attributed his actions to a lack of clearheadedness and a sex addiction that developed after he became sober from an alcohol addiction. Franco has been in recovery since 2016 and agreed to pay $2.2 million to settle a 2019 civil lawsuit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH, Keppel, HPL, Chuan Hup, Intraco, Asti, QT Vascular
summary: Keppel Corporation, Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), and Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) are involved in a takeover battle for SPH. The Securities Industry Council has blocked a clause in Keppel's offer that restricts SPH from holding a rival meeting. Chuan Hup's subsidiary Ventrade Australia will enter a joint venture to develop a land site in Queensland. Intraco has entered an amended agreement to invest in digital asset platform MHC Singapore. Asti Holdings has dismissed its CEO amid a retrenchment exercise, and QT Vascular's shareholders have dropped an attempt to call for new directors.

site_title: Facts alone will not win over the unvaccinated, but incentives might
summary: Researchers found that providing additional information about the consequences of not getting vaccinated does not effectively motivate unvaccinated individuals, particularly those who believe the vaccine is unlikely to do them any good. In contrast, incentives such as employer vaccine mandates, which impose negative consequences for non-compliance, are more effective in increasing vaccination rates. Studies showed that such mandates can lead to nearly 100% vaccination rates among employee groups, highlighting the importance of alternative strategies beyond simply providing more information to change behavior.

site_title: Australia: Shares boosted by banks, gold miners
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 7,380.1, driven by gains in banks and gold miners, as a study eased concerns about the Omicron variant. The S&P/ASX 200 index was headed for a third straight gain. Heavyweight financials, including the "Big Four" banks, climbed 0.7%, while gold explorers rose 2.2% on a surge in bullion prices. Mining stocks pared gains, and Bega Cheese slumped 9.3% on a hit to its earnings forecast.

images.alt_text: Australian shares extended gains on Thursday, led by banks and gold miners, as a study helped ease concerns about the severity of the Omicron coronavirus variant, while Bega Cheese slumped on forecasting earnings outlook below analyst estimates.

site_title: North Korea's Kim praises 'fresh heyday' in China relations as long-time envoy departs
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un praised outgoing Chinese Ambassador Li Jinjun for improving relations between Pyongyang and Beijing, calling it a "fresh heyday." Kim's comments followed a meeting with Choe Ryong Hae, a top official, who conveyed Kim's appreciation for Li's efforts. The North Korea-China relationship has seen significant ups and downs since Li's appointment in 2015, but Kim is satisfied with the current state of relations, which have become more dependent on China due to international sanctions. Li departed office after 7 years, and Kim congratulated the North Korean people on "making progress in all fields of socialist construction."

site_title: Oil prices rally on inventory drawdown, casting Omicron caution to the wind
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures up 1.8% to $75.29 a barrel and US WTI crude futures up 2.3% to $72.76 a barrel. The increase was driven by a larger-than-expected drawdown in US inventories, despite concerns about the Omicron coronavirus variant's impact on fuel demand. The market is also buoyed by European utilities switching to heating oil due to record-high natural gas prices.

site_title: Novavax says Covid-19 vaccine triggers immune response to Omicron variant
summary: Novavax's Covid-19 vaccine has shown an immune response to the Omicron variant, with an additional booster dose further increasing protection. The company's 2-dose vaccine has been authorized for use in the EU and several countries. Novavax expects to begin manufacturing an Omicron-specific vaccine in January and will supply up to 200 million doses to the EU and over 1.1 billion doses to COVAX. Early data from other vaccine manufacturers, including Pfizer and Moderna, has also shown increased immune responses to Omicron.

site_title: South Korea's central bank to join Federal Reserve's Fima repo facility
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, has agreed to join the US Federal Reserve's Fima repo facility, a repurchase agreement facility for foreign and international monetary authorities. This move aims to boost the Bank of Korea's access to dollar liquidity when needed. The facility allows the Bank of Korea to exchange its US Treasury securities for US dollars at an offering rate of 0.25% and with a maximum operation size of $60 billion. The decision comes as the Bank of Korea prepares for a bilateral US$60 billion currency swap deal set to expire on December 31, 2021.

images.alt_text: South Korea's central bank said on Thursday (Dec 23) it would join the US Federal Reserve's repurchase agreement facility for foreign and international monetary authorities in a pre-emptive move aimed at boosting its access to dollar liquidity when needed.

site_title: US: Stocks rally again after good consumer data
summary: US stocks rallied for a second consecutive session, driven by strong consumer data, including a 4-point jump in the Conference Board's consumer confidence index to 115.8 in December. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.0% and 1.2%, respectively. Large tech companies, including Apple and Alphabet, also saw gains. Market optimism was bolstered by concerns about the health effects of the Omicron Covid-19 variant, with some analysts predicting milder outcomes compared to earlier strains.

site_title: Europe: Shares end at near one-week highs, boosted by tech stocks
summary: European shares ended near one-week highs, led by technology and industrial stocks, despite concerns over the Omicron variant's impact on global recovery. The Stoxx 600 rose 0.8%, with gains in tech, industrials, travel, and construction stocks. Investors remain cautious amid Omicron's spread, with some countries reimposing restrictions. The European Central Bank may raise rates by the end of next year, and the ECB may end its emergency bond purchases by March.

site_title: Singapore freezes new ticket sales for VTL entry before Jan 21
summary: Singapore has frozen new ticket sales for Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) entry from Dec 23 to Jan 20, aiming to reduce the country's exposure to imported Omicron cases. VTL flights and buses will be capped at half of their allocated quota, and Malaysia has also frozen ticket sales for its VTL. The move may disrupt firms' manpower plans, particularly in industries reliant on foreign workers, and could lead to a sharp decrease in new worker arrivals. Stricter enforcement measures, including on-arrival testing and daily antigen rapid tests, have also been implemented for VTL travellers.

images.alt_text: New ticket sales for Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) flights and buses entering Singapore from Thursday (Dec 23) to Jan 20 next year will be frozen, with quotas and sales to be temporarily reduced after that.

site_title: Incoming IMF CIO and late batik artist named Berita Harian Achiever of the Year 2021
summary: Shirin Abdul Hamid, the incoming International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief information officer, and late batik artist Sarkasi Said have been jointly named Berita Harian Achiever of the Year 2021. Shirin, a mother of two, was recognized for her outstanding achievements in IT and volunteer work, while Sarkasi was honored for his contributions to showcasing Singaporean batik worldwide. The awards, given out annually since 1998, celebrate Malay-Muslim individuals for their achievements in their chosen fields.

site_title: Hong Kong university confirms Tiananmen statue removal
summary: The University of Hong Kong confirmed the removal of its 24-year-old "Pillar of Shame" statue, commemorating those killed in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989, after it was deemed a liability. The 8-meter-high sculpture, created by Jens Galschiot, was dismantled and removed after being shielded by security barriers and guards. Galschiot claims the statue remains his private property and threatens to sue the university. The move is seen as part of Hong Kong's efforts to conform to China's authoritarian image, following the city's violent democracy protests and crackdown on opposition figures.

site_title: Christmas reflections from industry professionals
summary: Industry professionals reflect on 2021, sharing their experiences of navigating the pandemic's impact on their businesses. They see Christmas as an opportunity to recalibrate and prepare for the new year. Meanwhile, BTLifestyle highlights various new restaurants and businesses, such as Rempapa and The Social Kitchen. The professionals also discuss the importance of corporate purpose, financial literacy, and sustainability. With the year coming to a close, they look forward to tackling the challenges ahead, driven by a renewed sense of purpose and a desire to adapt to a changing landscape.

site_title: No country can boost its way out of pandemic: WHO chief
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, warned that no country can boost its way out of the pandemic, citing inequity in access to COVID-19 vaccines. The WHO emphasized the priority should be getting vaccines to vulnerable people, rather than additional doses to already vaccinated populations. The organization argues that blanket booster programs will prolong the pandemic by diverting supply to high-vaccination countries, allowing the virus to spread and mutate. Only half the world's countries have achieved the target of 40% vaccination coverage, with 67% in high-income countries and less than 10% in low-income countries.

site_title: Books, photo, coin found in time capsule from Confederate statue
summary: A time capsule buried 130 years ago in the base of a Confederate general's statue in Richmond, Virginia, was opened, revealing water-logged books and artifacts. The statue, which was taken down in September, was one of hundreds considered symbols of racism. The time capsule, hidden in 1887, contained relics from the Civil War, including a Bible and a photograph of Abraham Lincoln in his coffin. The opened capsule revealed 3 books, a photograph, and a coin, which suffered water damage. The discovery has sparked speculation about potential additional time capsules.

site_title: Companies must align digitalisation, sustainability plans
summary: Companies should integrate digitalisation and sustainability plans to maximize benefits. Separating these teams is a missed opportunity, as digital transformations can lead to operational efficiency and reduced energy usage. However, digitalisation itself consumes energy, and tracking its carbon footprint is crucial. Merging digitalisation and sustainability teams can help companies address climate change while driving innovation and efficiency. By aligning these efforts, organizations can create a more sustainable and efficient digital landscape.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.50% or 143.11 points at 28,705.32. This follows gains on Wall Street, driven by strong US consumer data. The Topix index also edged up 0.50% or 9.95 points to 1,981.46. The gains are seen as a positive sign for investors, who are taking heart from the recent US market performance.

site_title: UK approves Covid jab for under-12s as new daily cases top 100,000
summary: The UK has approved Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5-11, following a review by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency. The vaccine is considered "safe and effective" and the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation recommends a primary course for some in the age group. Amid rising Omicron cases, the government has cut the isolation period for positive cases and introduced new post-Christmas curbs, including restrictions in Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland.

images.alt_text: British regulators on Wednesday approved Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine for use in children aged five to 11, as the country reported more than 100,000 new daily cases for the first time as Omicron surged.

site_title: Wirecard funds supposedly held in trust by Citadelle with OCBC confirmed to be just a fraction of initial claims
summary: Wirecard's insolvency administrator has obtained bank records showing discrepancies between the company's claimed and actual funds in Singapore-based accounts held by Citadelle Corporate Services. Contrary to claims of up to €365 million, the records reveal only €3.25 million in one account and €2,000 in others. The findings cast doubt on Wirecard's financial dealings, with auditors citing local confidentiality laws as a reason for not uncovering the discrepancies earlier. The case has led to the suspension of a Wirecard director's registration as a Registered Qualified Individual.

site_title: Breaking down behavioural barriers key to SME digitalisation
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have successfully adopted digital technologies, with nearly 2/3 of SMEs in the country adopting digital solutions, according to a recent study. Despite facing common barriers such as relative judgement and choice paralysis, SMEs in Singapore are more receptive to technology, driven by government initiatives like SMEs Go Digital and the pandemic's acceleration of digital adoption. To overcome these barriers, technology providers and policymakers can simplify the process by providing clear guidance and highlighting the value of their solutions.

site_title: Data is power in the world of green bonds
summary: Green bonds have grown exponentially in size and importance over the last decade, with $70 billion issued in the third quarter of 2020 alone. To harness this power, financial firms must access reliable, auditable information to create a more equitable and energy-efficient business environment. A tokenisation platform streamlines green bond issuance, and firms must modernize their technology environments to support this growth and meet regulatory demands, such as the European Union's taxonomy for sustainable activities.

site_title: Watch retailers could continue to enjoy boom time
summary: Watch retailers Cortina Holdings and The Hour Glass posted substantial revenue and net profit growth in their latest financial results. Revenue rose 63% and 86.7% for The Hour Glass and Cortina Holdings, respectively, with higher gross margins contributing to the better performance. The industry's resilience was bolstered by demand for luxury watches amid pandemic-induced disruptions. The Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry reported a record-breaking export value of 2.2 billion Swiss francs in November, with precious metal watches showing "very high demand."

site_title: The Fish Farmer looks to reduce food waste, make aquaculture industry more sustainable
summary: Aquaculture company The Fish Farmer is working to reduce food waste and increase sustainability in the industry. The company, founded in 2007, has studied consumer preferences and partnered with retailers to utilize offcuts of fish that would otherwise go to waste. By using different farming techniques and partnering with companies to create value-added products, The Fish Farmer aims to minimize waste and provide high-quality fish to consumers. The company has seen a shift in customer tastes, with a focus on convenience and prepared dishes, and plans to continue innovating to meet changing trends.

images.alt_text: The Fish Farmer's farms have more than 100 caged long nets along sheltered waterways, which allow fish to swim with the tides and absorb natural nutrients.
Offcuts of garoupa have been turned into 3 dishes that come in "fuss-free restaurant quality" packages.
"We can't keep using and abusing all the resources... we cannot just keep catching fish." - Malcolm Ong, chief executive of The Fish Farmer on global warming, overfishing and pollution.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise in opening trade on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose in opening trade on Thursday, following Wall Street's lead, as concerns about inflation and Covid-19 eased. The Hang Seng Index advanced 25.87 points, or 0.11%, to 23,128.20. Other regional indexes also showed gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 3.21 points, or 0.09%, to 3,625.83, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rising 1.83 points, or 0.07%, to 2,522.12.

site_title: US health regulator authorises Pfizer's Covid pill as Omicron surges
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) authorised Pfizer's Covid-19 pill, Paxlovid, for high-risk individuals aged 12 and up, amid a surge of Omicron cases. The pill, which reduced hospitalisations and deaths by 88% in a clinical trial, is expected to help ramp up production quickly. President Joe Biden promised to invoke a law to facilitate this process. The approval comes as Americans struggle to find tests and Omicron threatens holiday plans.

site_title: The places where travel recovered fastest (and slowest) in 2021
summary: Travel recovery in 2021 varied significantly across destinations in the US and Europe. In the US, Florida's beaches and golf courses made it a top performer, with cities like Gatlinburg and Mobile ranking high due to their accessibility and Covid-safe attractions. In contrast, cities like San Francisco, San Jose, and Washington, DC struggled due to remote work and limited business tourism. In Europe, Turkey's reopening of its borders and its coastal regions made it a top performer, while cities like Amsterdam, Lisbon, and Brussels underperformed due to border closures and limited tourism.

site_title: Local farmers vs powerful global corporations
summary: PepsiCo India lost exclusive rights to use a special potato variety for its Lay's chips in India, a victory for small farmers and civil society. The company had registered the variety under India's Protection of Plant Varieties and Farmers Rights Authority Act in 2016, but a court ruled that farmers had been put to hardship and that the registration was granted despite discrepancies. The decision sets a precedent for other seed or food companies to respect farmers' rights to save and use their own seeds. The ruling highlights the need for a new blueprint that preserves the interests of all sides in the food industry.

site_title: SIC says Keppel's 8-week restriction on SPH shall be 'disregarded'
summary: The Securities Industry Council (SIC) has dismissed a clause in Keppel Corp's offer that restricts Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) from holding a shareholders' meeting for a rival offer within 8 weeks. This ruling could allow SPH to hold a meeting to vote on both Keppel and Cuscaden offers on the same day, paving the way for a potential vote on Cuscaden's revised offer, which SPH's independent directors recommend as superior.

site_title: How Singapore leapt back up in Covid Resilience Ranking
summary: Singapore jumped 19 spots to No. 18 in Bloomberg's Covid Resilience Ranking in December, marking a significant improvement after a Delta wave and easing of social and border restrictions. The city-state saw a decline in daily cases, hospitalizations, and intensive care cases, with 817 deaths reported as of December 21. With a high vaccination rate and conservative measures in place, Singapore aims to treat Covid-19 as a normal part of life without overwhelming its healthcare system.

site_title: South Korean businesses protest against return of strict Covid rules
summary: South Korean small business owners protested in Seoul against the return of strict social distancing rules, citing financial losses and urging the government to compensate them. The measures, effective until Jan 2, include a 9 pm dining curfew and gatherings restrictions, which have triggered a backlash from the business community. Despite a 92% vaccination rate, the government has not kept its promise of compensation for businesses, leading to concerns of economic disaster.

site_title: UK economy closer to pre-Covid levels despite Q3 downgrade
summary: The UK economy has recovered faster than previously thought, with GDP now 1.5% smaller than at the end of 2019, an improvement from its previous estimated shortfall of 2.1%. Despite a slower recovery in Q3, the economy is unlikely to return to its pre-pandemic size until well into 2022. Household savings remain high, and economists expect excess savings to support consumer spending as inflation and tax increases erode living standards. The current account deficit widened to £24.4 billion, largely due to a sharply wider trade deficit.

site_title: As lagging sectors close recovery gap in 2022, inflation could be new risk
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to slow down in 2022, with a predicted growth range of 3-5% after a year of recovery from the pandemic. The main sectors driving growth are manufacturing and services, with a broader recovery in the latter expected. However, inflation is emerging as a new risk, with economists predicting a 1.8-2.6% increase in core and headline inflation. China's hardline stance on Covid-19 and broader economic developments pose a significant risk to Singapore's growth, with a slowdown in China likely to impact investment demand and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Japan plans record annual budget for election year
summary: Japan plans to unveil a record annual budget of 107.6 trillion yen, a 0.9% increase from the initial spending plan, ahead of an election in summer 2022. The budget will fund stimulus packages and support households and firms, with tax income expected to reach a record 65.2 trillion yen. Despite efforts to reduce the economy's scarring from the pandemic, Japan will still need to borrow more than a third of the funds it needs, limiting new bond issuance to 36.9 trillion yen.

site_title: As inflation rears its head, central banks strike a precarious balance
summary: The US Labor Department reported a 6.8% increase in headline inflation in November, the highest rate since June 1982. This surge in inflation is attributed to a combination of factors, including the re-opening of economies following the pandemic, supply chain bottlenecks, and wage pressures. The Federal Reserve is expected to withdraw pandemic support and raise interest rates, aiming for a policy rate of 2.1% by 2024. This may lead to a rapid increase in inflation, with forecasters predicting an inflation rate of 2.6% next year and 2.3% in 2023.

site_title: Rio Tinto buys US$825m lithium mine in battery push
summary: Rio Tinto has agreed to buy a lithium mine in Argentina for $825 million, as the company accelerates its push into battery materials. The lithium brine project, located in the lithium triangle of South America, has the potential to produce battery-grade lithium carbonate. The deal follows recent acquisitions of Millennial Lithium and Neo Lithium, cementing Argentina's position as a long-term destination for lithium development. Rio's CEO says the acquisition is aligned with the company's strategy to prioritize growth capital in commodities supporting decarbonization.

site_title: Cementing a sustainable future with greener concrete
