summary: Singapore is pioneering the use of greener concrete, known as CO2 mineralised concrete, to reduce environmental impact in massive developments. The Tuas Megaport and JTC semiconSpace are being built with this sustainable material, which harnesses industrial carbon dioxide to create a solid mineral embedded in concrete. This process reduces emissions by 1.3 million tonnes, equivalent to removing 260,000 petrol cars from the roads. The use of CO2 mineralised concrete is seen as a key strategy to reduce embodied carbon in the built environment sector, which contributes 39% of global carbon emissions, and aligns with Singapore's sustainability targets.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Omicron worries persist
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Wednesday, as Omicron variant worries persisted, despite recent record highs. The Dow Jones fell 0.99 points, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 1.13 points. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 21.93 points. Investors remained cautious due to ongoing concerns about the Omicron variant's impact on the global economic recovery.

site_title: PropertyBT: Excluding singles from prime location public housing flats: An in-depth look (Ep 2)
summary: Singapore's new public housing (PLH) model excludes singles, sparking debate on its investment viability. Correspondent Leslie Yee argues that excluding singles is detrimental to the model's objectives, which aim to boost the birth rate through a pro-marriage policy. Experts weigh in, suggesting that the policy may inadvertently drive up prices of other HDB flats in central locations. The PLH model's investment case is also questioned, with some experts highlighting the plight of singles and the need for more affordable options.

site_title: En-bloc sale offers for Lakepoint Condo below reserve price
summary: Developers of Lakepoint Condominium in Singapore have closed the en-bloc sale tender below the reserve price of S$640 million due to new cooling measures, including higher additional buyer's stamp duty rates. The 99-year leasehold site, comprising 309 units, will proceed with a private treaty negotiation process. This move is attributed to developers becoming more cautious in light of the policy changes, which include a 35% additional buyer's stamp duty rate, up from 25% previously. The negotiation process will last 10 weeks.

site_title: Australian dollar and euro recover against US dollar
summary: The Australian dollar, euro, and sterling recovered against the US dollar on Wednesday, driven by improving risk sentiment and optimism about the economic outlook. The euro rose 0.1%, the Australian dollar gained slightly, and sterling increased 0.3% despite data showing a slower-than-expected British economy. The dollar index edged 0.1% lower, while Turkey's lira steadied after recent gains. Markets are cautiously optimistic about the economic impact of the Omicron variant, with trading volumes thinner ahead of the holiday season.

site_title: Raeesah Khan did not suffer from psychiatric disorder that would impair ability to speak truthfully: IMH expert
summary: A medical expert, Dr Christopher Cheok, testified that former Singapore MP Raeesah Khan did not suffer from a significant psychiatric disorder that would impair her ability to speak truthfully. Dr Cheok assessed Khan on Dec 17 and 20 and found her to be of "sound mind" and "mentally fit and present." Khan's statements in Parliament and before the committee were deemed reliable, with Dr Cheok attributing her emotional reactions to the topic of sexual assault to a normal response to trauma. The report concluded that Khan did not suffer from psychiatric disorders that would predispose her to telling untruths.

site_title: Raeesah Khan insists WP chief Pritam Singh had told her keep up her lie and 'take it to the grave'
summary: Former Workers' Party (WP) MP Raeesah Khan insists that WP chief Pritam Singh advised her to "take it to the grave" during a meeting on August 8, where she admitted to lying in Parliament about the police's handling of a sexual assault case. Khan's testimony contradicts earlier statements by Singh, WP chair Sylvia Lim, and vice-chair Faisal Manap, who disputed her account of the meeting. Khan claims she was advised to keep up the lie and not correct it, and that the WP leaders were sympathetic to her well-being after she revealed a traumatic experience as a victim of sexual assault.

site_title: Global shipping in crosshairs as environmental scrutiny deepens
summary: Global shipping costs are likely to remain high in 2022 as the shipping industry faces pressure to accelerate decarbonization, with the International Maritime Organization (IMO) aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2050. Environmentalists and regulators are pushing for a carbon levy, while companies grapple with green financing and limited capital availability. The IMO's goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050 requires a significant investment of $2.4 trillion, with many countries, including the US, urging the organization to adopt a zero-emissions target.

site_title: Incoming IMF CIO and late batik artist named Berita Harian Achiever of the Year 2021
summary: IMF Chief Information Officer Shirin Abdul Hamid and late batik artist Sarkasi Said have been named Berita Harian Achiever of the Year 2021. The award recognizes Shirin's outstanding achievements in IT and volunteer work at the international level, while Sarkasi's contributions to showcasing Singaporean batik to the world were also honored. The awards were presented on December 22, 2021, at a ceremony in Singapore, with Minister for Transport S Iswaran as the guest of honor.

site_title: Omicron has 80% lower risk of hospitalisation, new study shows
summary: A new study by the National Institute for Communicable Diseases in South Africa found that individuals contracting the Omicron variant of COVID-19 have an 80% lower risk of hospitalization compared to other strains. However, once hospitalized, the risk of severe disease does not differ from other variants. The study also showed that Omicron infections are associated with a 70% lower risk of severe disease compared to Delta infections.

site_title: SIC clears way for SPH shareholders to vote on Keppel, Cuscaden bids on same day
summary: The Securities Industry Council (SIC) has cleared the way for Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) shareholders to vote on Keppel Corp and Cuscaden Peak's competing bids for the company on the same day. A clause restricting SPH from holding a rival scheme meeting within 8 weeks from the Keppel meeting has been struck out, allowing shareholders to vote on both bids simultaneously. SPH's independent directors have recommended voting in favor of Cuscaden's revised offer of S$2.40 a share, which they consider superior to Keppel's offer of S$2.351 a share.

site_title: A US$180b green-debt boom grows faster than its impact
summary: The green debt market is growing at a faster pace than its actual impact, with the US$180 billion in green bonds issued this year far exceeding the real-world projects they support. Financial institutions are using financial engineering, such as reselling green loans, to inflate their contribution to climate change mitigation. This "double counting" can create an inaccurate picture of their role in the climate transition, making it challenging for policymakers to track their actual contribution. Proposed amendments to the European Union's green bond standard aim to prevent this greenwashing, but critics warn that the disconnect between green finance and actual green business may complicate efforts to address the climate crisis.

site_title: En-bloc hopeful Lakepoint Condominium now in private talks after offers fall short of reserve price
summary: Singapore's en-bloc hopeful Lakepoint Condominium has closed its tender and entered a private treaty negotiation process after offers fell short of its reserve price of S$640 million. The 99-year leasehold, comprising 309 residential units, was launched in October. The move comes amid new cooling measures, including a 35% additional buyer's stamp duty, which has made developers more cautious. PropNex Realty's head of investment and collective sales expressed cautious optimism about the tender, citing the site's attractive location and limited new private housing supply.

site_title: EU proposes law to implement OECD deal on tax
summary: The European Commission has proposed a law to implement a global minimum tax rate of 15% for large companies, as agreed upon by the G-20. The law, which applies to companies with revenues of €750 million, would ensure consistent application of the minimum tax rate across the EU. The Commission plans to propose a second law in 2022 to implement the agreement on taxing rights. The law includes provisions to reduce the impact on companies, allowing exclusions for 5-8% of tangible assets and payroll.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.73 points to 1,500.32 on Wednesday, driven by gains. Volume was 3.123 billion lots worth RM1.597 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 450 to 347.

site_title: Intraco to enter into revised agreement for investment into MHC Singapore
summary: Intraco has entered into a revised agreement to invest in MHC Singapore, a digital asset platform, with a new purchase consideration of S$10 million. Intraco will issue 42 million new shares and 58 million warrants to Australian entrepreneurs Mark Carnegie and Sergei Sergienko, who will hold equal shareholdings. The revised agreement reduces the cash payment and increases the share issuance. The deal is subject to several conditions, including shareholder approval and the successful restructuring of MHC Digital Group's businesses and assets.

site_title: QT Vascular says third EGM to appoint new directors will 'not proceed'
summary: QT Vascular has dropped its attempt to call a third extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to appoint new directors, following a requisition by shareholders Mission Well and Tansri Saridju Benui. The shareholders had submitted proxy forms for the third EGM by the deadline, and the circular was uploaded to the SGX. QT Vascular claims the resolutions proposed by the requisitioning shareholders are "flawed" and would breach the Companies Act. The company will discuss its next step with solicitors regarding potential court applications.

site_title: Chipmakers to start India production in 2-3 years
summary: India aims to establish a domestic semiconductor industry, with at least a dozen manufacturers expected to start local production in the next 2-3 years. The government has offered incentives, including a 760 billion rupee (S$13.7 billion) package over 6 years, to boost local chip production. The country plans to develop a full ecosystem for chip manufacturing, including silicon and display fabs, and will start taking applications for the incentive scheme from January 1. The goal is to reduce reliance on expensive imports and support the growth of the electronics industry.

site_title: As ESG awareness grows, experts weigh in on where to put your cash
summary: Investors are shifting focus from just environmental, social, and governance (ESG) aspects to also consider companies' social characteristics, such as equity and inclusion practices. Experts warn that green financing alone won't suffice to deliver on climate pledges, and that a broader view of ESG is needed. Key areas to consider include enabling technologies, storage, grid technology, and energy efficiency, rather than just renewable energy and decarbonization. The market underappreciates social characteristics, and equity and inclusion practices are expected to attract more attention. However, challenges persist, including inconsistent definitions, incomplete ESG data, and the risk of greenwashing.

site_title: Thai Central Group to close £4b deal for Selfridges in days
summary: Thai Central Group is set to close a £4 billion acquisition of Selfridges stores in the UK within days, according to sources. The acquisition, agreed with the Weston family in November, would see Central Retail Corp take a partial stake in Selfridges. Central Group, owned by billionaire Chirathivat family, has a presence in Europe since 2011 and owns several department stores globally. An official announcement could be made as early as Thursday.

site_title: COE premiums for smaller cars increase further to new six-year high
summary: COE premiums for smaller cars in Singapore reached a new six-year high, closing at S$58,801 on Dec 22, a 3.1% increase from the previous high set two weeks ago. Motorcycle COE prices also rose, with a 2.1% increase to S$9,601. Larger cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp saw a S$588 increase to S$80,989. Conversely, COE prices for goods vehicles and buses fell by 2.2%, and the open COE category decreased by 1.3%.

site_title: Singapore shares inch higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,087.51 points. The moderate gains followed Asian markets' cautious approach despite a strong US overnight rally. Trading volumes were muted, with gainers outnumbering losers 207 to 205. Shares of Thai Beverage and Hongkong Land led the STI performance, while travel and aviation-related counters declined due to tightened border safeguards and suspended ticket sales.

site_title: Myanmar seeks closer China ties with renminbi trade project
summary: Myanmar plans to start accepting the Chinese Renminbi as an official settlement currency for trade with China in 2022, aiming to restart joint projects and strengthen economic ties with Beijing. The move is seen as a response to the country's shortage of US dollars and foreign currencies, and analysts believe it may push Myanmar closer to China amid international isolation. The junta, which seized power in February, has identified infrastructure projects with China as a major priority for economic revival, including railways and ports.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has frozen new bookings for Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) flights and buses from Dec 23 to Jan 20 to reduce exposure to imported Omicron cases. Investment banking fees in Singapore surged 34.4% to US$1 billion in 2021, driven by a 91.1% growth in advisory fees for completed M&A deals. The country also invested over US$950 million in manufacturing projects in Iskandar Malaysia since 2019. The Straits Times Index rose 0.1% on Wednesday, closing at 3,087.51.

images.alt_text: The freeze on new VTL ticket sales, for both buses and flights, will be in effect from 11.59pm on Dec 22 to 11.59pm on Jan 20.

site_title: Asti CEO retrenched amid 'difficult period' for company
summary: ASTI Holdings CEO Michael Loh Soon Gnee has been retrenched amid a company-wide retrenchment exercise, following more than 8 years as CEO. The move comes as the group seeks to exit the SGX financial watch-list and remain afloat during a difficult period. Loh will receive S$1.4 million instead of his contractual S$2 million severance. Anthony Loh, CFO, will act as interim CEO until December 31. The company attributes its struggles to the pandemic and ongoing geo-political tensions.

site_title: Postponed WEF to remain in Davos, says chief
summary: The World Economic Forum 2022, postponed from January to early summer due to the Omicron variant, will remain in its traditional home of Davos, Switzerland, according to its chief Klaus Schwab. The event was initially scheduled to take place in Singapore due to the pandemic in Switzerland.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Crypto billionaire Zhu Su is in the early stages of buying a $49 million property in Singapore as trustee for his 3-year-old child. Binance has pulled out of Singapore, shutting down trading in January. The Singapore power sector is expected to undergo adjustments in 2022, with the Energy Market Authority considering tweaks to market rules to address price normalcy. The government has also introduced new cooling measures for the property market, including higher buyer's stamp duty rates and tighter debt servicing ratio thresholds. A third Covid-19 vaccine dose is now required to maintain vaccination status.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open on mixed note
summary: European stocks opened mixed on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.1% to 7,287.19 points due to a sharper-than-expected economic slowdown in the third quarter. In contrast, the Paris CAC 40 index rose 0.3% and Frankfurt's DAX increased 0.2%. Global markets rose, extending a rally after their latest sell-off as investors assess the impact of the Omicron variant.

site_title: Hynix wins China's approval to take over Intel's memory arm
summary: SK Hynix has secured China's approval to acquire Intel's Nand storage unit for $9 billion, clearing the way for a merger that will cement its position as the largest producer of Nand memory. The deal, valued at $7 billion in the first phase, will boost Hynix's market share of flash memory components to over 20%. China's watchdog has stipulated conditions, including ensuring pricing and supplies, to help a third-party company enter the market. The acquisition is part of Hynix's plan to triple its flash-memory revenue over five years.

site_title: Wirecard funds supposedly held in trust by Citadelle with OCBC confirmed to be just fraction of initial claims
summary: Wirecard's insolvency administrator has obtained bank records in Singapore that show discrepancies between the company's claims of funds held in trust and the actual amounts. Citadelle Corporate Services claimed to hold 30 million euros, but bank statements revealed only 2,000 euros. Similar discrepancies were found in other accounts, including one with over 21,000 dollars. Wirecard's auditor EY cited local confidentiality laws as a reason for not uncovering these irregularities earlier. The records are being presented as evidence to declare Wirecard's financial accounts as void, potentially supporting claims that the company's TPA business never existed.

images.alt_text: In November, detailed bank records surfaced after Wirecard's insolvency administrator Michael Jaffe managed to obtain leave from the Singapore High Court to use these records in his insolvency case.

site_title: Thai central bank holds key rate, cuts growth forecast for 2022
summary: Thailand's central bank held its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record-low 0.5% for the 13th consecutive meeting, citing the risk posed by the Omicron variant to the fragile economic recovery. The Bank of Thailand lowered its forecast for 2022 GDP growth to 3.4% and boosted its 2021 forecast to 0.9%. The central bank also cut its visitor forecast for 2022 to 5.6 million, down from 6 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.57% to 23,102.33 on Wednesday, driven by bargain buying and gains in Asia. The Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.64%. Covid concerns continue to impact sentiment, but the Hang Seng Index extended its previous day's gains.

site_title: Chuan Hup in JV with Siera associate to buy and develop Queensland site
summary: Chuan Hup Holdings announced a joint venture with Siera Group's associate to acquire a 964 sqm land site in Queensland, Australia, for A$7.6 million. The site will be developed into a 20-level, 60-apartment mixed-residential tower. Ventrade Australia, Chuan Hup's subsidiary, will take a 50% stake in the JV company, while Siera's associate, BHHP15, will provide development management services. The JV is expected to have a minimal impact on Chuan Hup's financials.

site_title: Smash hits from the court: 6 business leaders serve up lessons from badminton
summary: Six Singapore business leaders share how badminton has influenced their approach to business, citing key takeaways such as the importance of stamina, grit, and strategy. They attribute these qualities to the sport, drawing parallels between the fast-paced nature of badminton and the competitive business landscape. The business leaders, who are avid badminton players, credit the sport for teaching them resilience, teamwork, and adaptability, which they apply to their respective industries.

site_title: AM alpha buys Robinson 112 for S$269.7m
summary: AM alpha, a Munich-based real estate family office, has acquired Robinson 112, a 14-storey freehold office building in Singapore's central business district, for S$269.7 million. The building has a net lettable area of 92,205 sq ft and is currently occupied by high-rental paying tenants. AM alpha plans to refurbish the building to attract higher-rental tenants and hold the asset for the long term. The sale is a significant investment in Singapore's office market, which has seen increased activity in recent months.

site_title: Malaysia to suspend ticket sales for vaccinated travel lane to Singapore
summary: Malaysia will suspend ticket sales for its vaccinated travel lane to Singapore from Dec 23 to Jan 20, following Singapore's halt on ticket sales for 24 nations. The move comes after Malaysia detects 13 imported Omicron cases and verifies another possible 13 cases. The Health Minister will assess the Covid situation in both countries before resuming ticket sales on Jan 21.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on chip gains, investors look past Omicron
summary: South Korean shares ended higher on Wednesday, driven by gains in chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The Kospi index rose 0.32% to 2,984.48, despite rising Omicron cases worldwide. Foreign investors purchased net 303.7 billion won worth of shares. US President Joe Biden announced more vaccination and testing sites, but reassured that those inoculated can gather for the holidays. The won rose 0.08% to 1,192.0 per dollar, while US treasury bond yields rose 4.0 and 5.3 basis points.

site_title: Hot stock: SIA down 1.6% on halt in VTL ticket sales
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) shares fell 1.6% to a low of S$4.81 after the government froze ticket sales for Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) flights and buses from Dec 23 to Jan 20 to reduce Omicron exposure. Existing ticket sales for VTL flights can still be made. The freeze affects new ticket sales for travel into Singapore from Jan 21, with VTL quotas and ticket sales capped at half of allocated quota after that date.

site_title: NetLink Trust to recover cost of repairs from contractors that caused Toa Payoh service outage
summary: NetLink Trust will recover the cost of repairs from the contractors that damaged its fibre cables in Toa Payoh, resulting in a service outage for around 900 households. The incident occurred on Dec 21 and was resolved on Dec 22. The damage is estimated to cost hundreds of thousands of dollars, and NetLink will take action against the errant contractor. This incident highlights the importance of following procedures and exercising due diligence in earthworks for telecommunication network operators and contractors, according to the Infocomm Media Development Authority.

site_title: Apollo to lend US$4b to SoftBank in private credit deal
summary: Apollo Global Management is lending SoftBank Group Corp about $4 billion in a private credit deal, marking the largest ever such loan in the private credit market. The financing will be backed by SoftBank Vision Fund 2, which has invested over $27 billion in technology startups. The loan's interest rate is expected to be in the mid-single-digit percent range, and additional investors, including mutual funds and financial institutions, will also be part of the transaction.

site_title: South Korea's 'unicorn' numbers soar, ignite hopes of more blockbuster IPOs
summary: South Korea's startup scene is experiencing a surge in funding, with private investors pouring in record amounts. The number of "unicorns" in the country has doubled over the past three years, with many startups valuing over $1 billion. Companies like Coupang and Market Kurly are leading the charge, with investors flocking to platform businesses and "new economy"-related ventures. This trend is expected to continue, with venture capital investments reaching a record high in 2021 and expected to continue in 2022, prompting investment banks to target firms as potential IPO candidates.

site_title: Maersk agrees to US$3.6b deal to buy LF Logistics
summary: Maersk has agreed to buy Hong Kong-based LF Logistics for $3.6 billion in an all-cash deal, expanding its capabilities as an integrated container logistics company. The acquisition, expected to close in 2022, will more than double LF Logistics' revenue and operating profit by 2026. With a network of 223 warehouses and 10,000 employees in 14 Asian countries, LF Logistics provides land-based logistic services to over 250 global customers. The deal follows a series of acquisitions by Maersk to expand its capabilities in e-commerce and air freight.

site_title: China will be able to keep economic growth stable: state planner
summary: China's state planner, Ning Jizhe, expressed confidence in maintaining stable economic growth in 2022 despite challenges such as a property downturn and strict COVID-19 curbs. To achieve this, China will prepare for next year's economic work in advance, increase government spending, and strengthen support for manufacturers and small companies. The country will also focus on stabilizing industry supply chains, solving chip shortage issues, and ensuring price stability. China will implement proactive fiscal policies and build an integral domestic market to aid economic growth.

site_title: Some BOJ board members see positive impact on Japan's economy from weak yen
summary: Some members of the Bank of Japan's policy board believe the weakening of the yen has a positive impact on the Japanese economy, despite weaker effects on boosting exports. The currency's impact on business profits overseas and stock prices is seen as a positive factor, with some members noting that the effects are uneven depending on sectors and business size. This contradicts previous concerns about the yen's impact on exports.

site_title: US life expectancy saw huge drop in 2020 largely due to Covid-19
summary: US life expectancy dropped by 1.8 years in 2020, the largest decline in over 75 years, primarily due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The CDC reported life expectancy at birth was 77.0 years, down from 78.8 years in 2019. Men's life expectancy decreased to 74.2 years, while women's life expectancy fell to 79.9 years.

site_title: Tesla's Musk says he sold 'enough stock'; slams California for 'overtaxation'
summary: Elon Musk, Tesla's CEO, sold 13.5 million shares, approximately 80% of his planned 10% stake, after a Twitter poll. He attributed the sale to exercising stock options expiring next year and to pay taxes. Musk slammed California for "overtaxation," stating it's "increasingly difficult to get things done" due to overregulation and overlitigation. He moved Tesla's headquarters from California to Texas. Musk's sales of shares reduced the company's value by about a quarter, despite shares having hovered near record-highs.

site_title: Binance signs Dubai deal to work on international crypto framework
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, has signed a deal with the Dubai World Trade Centre Authority to collaborate on a new international framework for global virtual assets. The agreement aims to build a regulatory and legislative framework for cryptoexchanges, blockchain businesses, and digital currencies. Binance will share its experience with global regulators, while Dubai aims to license businesses in the city. The deal follows Binance's strengthening ties with the UAE, with its CEO Changpeng "CZ" Zhao recently buying a home in Dubai and meeting with officials.

site_title: GuocoLand group CFO resigns; new executive appointments announced
summary: GuocoLand's CFO Gregory Sim Chee Wah has resigned, effective December 31, 2021, to pursue personal interests. Sim's departure follows slightly over a year in the role, during which the company navigated the global pandemic. GuocoLand's CEO, Cheng Hsing Yao, thanked Sim for his steady leadership.

site_title: Investment banking fees in Singapore surge 34.4% to hit US$1b in 2021 to date
summary: Singapore's investment banking fees surged 34.4% to US$1 billion in 2021, driven by record M&A activity and debt capital market underwriting fees. M&A deals totaled US$175.1 billion, up 70.4% from 2020, with Morgan Stanley leading the market share. Debt capital market underwriting fees also increased 87.6% to US$182.6 million, with DBS capturing 16.4% market share. The growth in fees was largely attributed to a 91.1% growth in advisory fees for completed M&A.

site_title: NHL to skip Beijing Olympics as Covid-19 disrupts season, ESPN says
summary: The National Hockey League (NHL) and the NHL Players' Association have agreed to withdraw from the 2022 Beijing Olympics due to COVID-19 concerns. A recent virus outbreak has led to numerous player health and safety protocols, causing the league to postpone games and pause the regular season. The Olympics' dates, set for February 4, could be used for rescheduled NHL games, potentially forcing other Olympic teams to look elsewhere for players. This decision comes after a 2014 absence due to a dispute with the International Olympic Committee.

images.alt_text: The National Hockey League (NHL) and the NHL Players' Association have agreed that athletes won't participate in the 2022 Olympics in Beijing due to concerns about Covid-19, according to ESPN.

site_title: Gold holds tight range as higher yields counter Omicron fears
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,789.12 per ounce as investors weighed the Omicron coronavirus variant against higher US Treasury yields. The tighter range was fueled by improved risk appetite and rebounding global shares. The US FDA is set to authorize COVID-19 treatment pills on Wednesday, and countries across Europe considered new curbs on movement. Higher yields increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion, which pays no interest. Global shares rose despite the surging number of Omicron cases.

site_title: Warburg Pincus closes US$2.8b inaugural Asia real estate fund
summary: Warburg Pincus has closed its inaugural Asia-focused real estate fund at US$2.8 billion, surpassing its initial target. The fund, which focuses on asset-level, technology-enabled real estate opportunities, was oversubscribed by leading Asian institutional investors. This is the second-largest real estate fund dedicated to the sector in Asia, following Blackstone Group's US$7.1 billion fund in 2018. The fund will invest in areas such as logistics, data centers, and multifamily real estate, and will also reposition underperforming assets. This move is part of a growing trend of global private equity managers diversifying in Asia.

site_title: Australia's QE call shapes up as a cliffhanger with economists split
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) meeting in February is expected to be a cliffhanger as economists are split over the fate of its bond-buying program. 8 out of 14 economists predict the RBA will scrap quantitative easing, while 6 expect it to scale back from the current A$4 billion weekly pace and end purchases in May. The decision will be influenced by December labour force data, fourth-quarter CPI print, and the impact of the Omicron variant.

site_title: Singapore invested over US$950m in manufacturing projects in Iskandar since 2019: joint ministerial committee
summary: Singapore has invested over US$950 million in manufacturing projects in Iskandar Malaysia since 2019, according to a joint ministerial committee. In 2019, 104 projects totaling US$847 million were approved, and in 2020, another 104 projects totaling US$847 million were approved. Additionally, 20 manufacturing projects from Singapore with a total value of US$112 million were approved in the first half of 2021. These investments are in key sectors such as electrical and electronics, fabricated metal products, and machinery and equipment.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat as miners offset gains in tech, health stocks
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Wednesday, with technology and healthcare stocks offsetting losses in mining, led by BHP Group and Rio Tinto. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.1% to 7,364.8 points, despite a surge in coronavirus cases globally and concerns over economic fallout from the Omicron variant. The country reported over 5,000 daily Covid-19 infections and conducted an emergency national cabinet meeting to announce more vaccination funding.

site_title: US SEC denies Apple's bid to dismiss shareholder proposal on concealment clauses
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has denied Apple's bid to dismiss a shareholder proposal requiring the company to inform investors about its use of non-disclosure agreements and concealment clauses. The proposal, filed by investor Nia Impact Capital, aims to assess the potential risks of these clauses in cases of harassment, discrimination, and other unlawful acts. Apple had argued its policy was not to use concealment clauses, but the SEC denied the request, stating the company had not substantially implemented the proposal. The proposal will now be put to a vote at Apple's annual shareholder meeting next year.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank KE recommends investors to accept Dtac-True merger offer
summary: Maybank KE is recommending investors to accept the tender offer for the merger of Dtac and True Corporation, resulting in Thailand's largest telco by market share. The benefits of the US$8.6 billion merger deal are expected to take at least 2 years to emerge, with potential growth and a more stable profitability profile for the merged entity. Maybank KE has downgraded Dtac to "buy" and maintained "hold" on True, with target prices of 45.10 baht and 5.09 baht, respectively.

images.alt_text: Fitch Ratings analysts Nitin Soni and Duncan Innes-Ker said that higher capex requirements to roll out 5G networks, coupled with intense competition have made consolidation more attractive for telcos like Dtac and True Corp.

site_title: Credit unions seek regulator approval to hold crypto assets
summary: Credit unions are seeking regulator approval to hold and manage digital assets like Bitcoin. The National Credit Union Administration (NCUA) clarified that credit unions with federally insured deposits can partner with third-party crypto service providers to allow members to buy, sell, and hold digital assets. This move is seen as a step towards traditional financial services industry embracing digital assets. Credit unions aim to offer cryptocurrency custody services directly, but some may choose to partner with specialized crypto providers due to the complexity of custody. The NCUA has provided a clear path for partnerships, giving credit unions more confidence to move forward.

site_title: AstraZeneca, Oxford aim to produce Omicron-targeted vaccine
summary: AstraZeneca is working with Oxford University to develop a vaccine targeting the Omicron coronavirus variant. The move follows other vaccine-makers, including Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna, which are also working on Omicron-specific vaccines. AstraZeneca's antibody cocktail Evusheld retained neutralizing activity against the Omicron variant in a lab study, and Moderna plans to start clinical trials early next year. The partnership aims to produce a vaccine in case it is needed, and will be informed by emerging data.

site_title: Beyonce, Jay-Z and Ariana Grande in Oscars race as shortlists unveiled
summary: Beyoncé, Jay-Z, and Ariana Grande are among the contenders for the Best Original Song Oscar, with Beyoncé's "Be Alive" from "King Richard" and Jay-Z's "Guns Go Bang" from "The Harder They Fall" making the list. Billie Eilish's "No Time To Die" and Lin-Manuel Miranda's "Dos Oruguitas" from "Encanto" also made the cut. The shortlists for the International Feature Film and Best Documentary categories have also been unveiled, with several frontrunners and surprise entries. The final lists of nominees will be announced on February 8, with the Oscars ceremony taking place on March 27.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares build on rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks continued their rally, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.09% to 23,221.13, driven by a bounce in technology firms. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained, adding 0.21% and 0.26% respectively. This marks the second consecutive day of gains for Hong Kong stocks, as they extend their previous day's rally.

site_title: Database vendor MongoDB poaches top Amazon executives to compete with AWS
summary: MongoDB, a database vendor, has hired 8 top Amazon Web Services (AWS) executives in the past 2 years to compete with AWS. The hires include former AWS general manager Mark Porter as MongoDB's chief technology officer and former AWS head of developer marketing Matt Asay as global head of partner marketing. MongoDB CEO Dev Ittycheria believes the hires will help the company compete more aggressively by leveraging the expertise of former AWS executives in open source and cloud technologies. The moves are part of MongoDB's strategy to increase its annual revenue to $1 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge up at close
summary: Tokyo stocks closed slightly higher on December 22, 2021, after Japan detected its first known community transmission of the Omicron coronavirus variant. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.16% to 28,562.21, while the Topix index gained 0.09% to 1,971.51. The detection of Omicron is a concern, but investors seem to be brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FJ Benjamin, GuocoLand, Procurri
summary: FJ Benjamin plans to raise S$3 million for expansion and explore collaborations with Far East Organization. GuocoLand's CFO has resigned, replaced by Andrew Chew, while Procurri's CFO Choo Joo Kwang has also stepped down, with Sin Yi Tian taking over. These developments may impact trading of the companies' securities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.82 points or 0.3% to 1496.41 on Wednesday, December 22, 2021. The index saw 157 gains and 66 losses. The country's stock market opened higher despite global market fluctuations, with no specific reasons mentioned for the gain.

site_title: Biden says he is considering lifting US Omicron travel ban
summary: US President Joe Biden considers lifting the travel ban on people arriving from southern African countries where the Omicron variant was first identified, as it now accounts for over 70% of new US Covid-19 cases. The ban, imposed in November, has not prevented the mutation from becoming the dominant strain. Biden's health advisers have suggested reconsidering the ban, and airlines have expressed support for updating the restrictions as more data becomes available.

site_title: Keppel Data Centres in tie-up to explore Australia liquid hydrogen supply chain
summary: Keppel Data Centres has formed a partnership with four energy players to explore the development of a liquid hydrogen supply chain between Western Australia and Singapore, potentially extending to Japan. The 5 parties, including Woodside Energy, City Energy, Osaka Gas Singapore, and City-OG Gas Energy Services, will study the technical and commercial aspects of the supply chain until mid-2022. The collaboration aims to use LH2 from Australia to power Keppel Data Centres' data centers in Singapore, with potential applications for other Keppel business units.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Singapore freezes new bookings for VTL bus and flight entry before Jan 21
summary: Singapore has frozen new bookings for Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) bus and flight entries from December 23 to January 20 to reduce the country's exposure to imported Omicron cases. Existing ticket holders will still be allowed to travel under the VTL. The country will also temporarily reduce VTL capacity, halving it for land travel from Malaysia and capping flight ticket sales at half of the allocated quota. Strict enforcement measures, including on-arrival testing and daily self-administered antigen rapid tests, will be implemented for VTL travellers.

site_title: Fintech startup Finatext slumps 26% in Tokyo trading debut
summary: Finatext Holdings, a Japanese fintech startup, made its Tokyo trading debut with shares dropping 26% below the IPO price of 1,290 yen a share, resulting in a nearly 20 billion yen offering. The listing, led by Daiwa Securities and Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities, saw shares tumble in early trading. The IPO was priced at the top of its advertised range, with the company aiming to raise capital for its stock trading apps and brokerage infrastructure.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher extending US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on December 22, 2021, tracking US market gains. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.54% to 28,670.86, while the Topix index advanced 0.49% to 1,979.44. The gains followed a global market recovery from an Omicron-fueled sell-off.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday (Dec 22), tracking rallies on Wall Street as global markets recovered from an Omicron-fuelled sell-off.

site_title: Broadway grosses drop 26% as many shows cancel performances
summary: Broadway's ticket sales dropped 26% to $22.5 million last week, a significant decline from the previous week's $30.5 million. The decrease is attributed to multiple show cancellations due to positive coronavirus tests forcing cast or crew members to quarantine, with insufficient understudies or replacement workers to continue performances. This drop comes as the industry attempts to rebound from its lengthy shutdown, with total grosses in the week before Christmas in 2019 being $40.1 million.

site_title: Super-luxury home sales surge across America, rising 35% in 2021
summary: US luxury home sales surged 35% in 2021, with at least 40 residential properties selling for over $50 million. According to Miller Samuel, the country's 8 most expensive homes, valued at $100 million or more, were sold in various locations, including Los Angeles, New York, Palm Beach, and Montana. The top sales included a $200 million ranch in Montana and a $157.5 million duplex in New York. The surge in luxury home sales is attributed to low interest rates, a booming stock market, and a pandemic-era emphasis on home life.

images.alt_text: Beachfront homes are seen in the view from the penthouse of the Regalia luxury condominium in Miami Beach, Florida, U.S., on Tuesday, Feb. 11, 2014.

site_title: China developers flag risks after sharp share price rebound
summary: China property developers, including Tahoe Group and Sichuan Languang Development, have warned investors about investment risks due to poor fundamentals, following a sharp rebound in property stocks. The CSI 300 Real Estate Index reached a 2-month high, with some developers' shares surging over 60% in the past month. Tahoe Group and Sichuan Languang have defaulted on billions of yuan in debts and are seeking debt restructuring. The developers caution that their share prices have deviated from fundamentals and business conditions continue to worsen.

site_title: Biden urges Americans to get vaccinated, promises no return to 'darkest days' of pandemic
summary: President Joe Biden urged Americans to get vaccinated against COVID-19, promising no return to the darkest days of the pandemic. In a Christmas address, he unveiled measures to combat the Omicron variant, including increasing vaccination and testing sites, providing 500 million rapid tests, and deploying military medical personnel to support hospitals. Biden acknowledged the variant's high contagiousness but emphasized the effectiveness of vaccines, particularly with a booster shot. He also left the door open for further negotiation on a $2 trillion stimulus bill, despite Senator Joe Manchin's threat to torpedo it.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as banks negate gains in mining, tech stocks
summary: Australian shares ended flat at 7,355.2, despite gains in miners and technology stocks, as losses in banks and gold explorers countered the positive momentum. The S&P/ASX 200 index had its best session in two weeks on Tuesday. The Australian central bank remains optimistic about the country's economic recovery despite the Omicron variant's impact on global markets.

site_title: Oil prices settle higher, but market wary of Omicron
summary: Oil prices rose 3% on Tuesday, rebounding from a sharp fall, but investors remain cautious due to the Omicron variant cutting holiday travel plans and dimming near-term fuel demand. Brent crude settled at $73.98 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $71.12 a barrel. Despite a potential booster dose of the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine offering protection against Omicron, analysts predict limited upside and renewed selling if further restrictions are implemented.

site_title: Centres of Innovation provide tech solutions and R&D support for firms
summary: Singapore's Centres of Innovation (COIs) provide tech solutions and R&D support to firms, helping small and medium enterprises (SMEs) adopt technology and innovate. COIs, based in polytechnics and research institutes, offer a range of services including no-code app development, consultancy, training, and access to specialty equipment and laboratory facilities. By leveraging these resources, SMEs can streamline processes, reduce costs, and improve efficiency, with some companies seeing significant reductions in time needed for order processing and improved customer visibility.

site_title: Musk tweet fund adminstrator not filing statements, judge says
summary: A US$40 million fund established by the SEC to compensate investors harmed by Elon Musk's false tweets has not received required accounting statements from its administrator, Rust Consulting. US District Judge Alison Nathan directed Rust Consulting to submit a status report by January 7. The SEC reached a settlement with Musk and Tesla in 2018, setting up the Fair Fund to repay investors. Musk's tweets in 2018 sparked a lawsuit, which was settled without Musk admitting wrongdoing. The lack of transparency from Rust Consulting raises concerns about the distribution of funds to affected investors.

site_title: The benefits of inflation in the era ahead
summary: The article discusses the potential benefits of inflation in the era ahead, particularly in transforming the global economy towards a delevered, renewable-powered future. Rising debt levels have built up in the global economy, and inflation can serve as a policy anchor to address this issue. In the post-World War II era, high inflation led to elevated nominal GDP growth, which helped erode government debt. Similarly, the global energy transformation required to combat climate change will likely drive inflation, but also create opportunities for sustainable growth. As the world transitions to renewable energy, higher energy prices during the investment phase will catalyze the transition and spur innovation, ultimately leading to a delevered, renewable-powered future.

site_title: NatWest pleads guilty to US fraud charges, to pay US$35m
summary: NatWest Group's investment bank unit has pleaded guilty to US$35 million in wire and securities fraud charges related to a decade-long scheme to manipulate US Treasury debt markets. The firm agreed to pay the fine, serve 3 years of probation, and provide restitution. This comes after NatWest was fined £265 million by a British court for failing to prevent money laundering. The US Department of Justice's penalty is seen as too light by some, with critics arguing that the bank's behavior was unacceptable and warrants harsher punishment.

site_title: UPS orders 19 Boeing 767 cargo jets
summary: Boeing announced an order for 19 freighter planes to UPS, valued at $4.2 billion based on list prices. The deal comes as air cargo demand surges due to e-commerce growth and recent port backlogs. Boeing projects a 4% annual increase in air cargo demand over the next 20 years. UPS plans to take delivery of the aircraft between 2023 and 2025, with shares of both companies rising after the announcement. The order is part of a "record" cargo performance for Boeing in 2021.

site_title: Delta CEO asks CDC to cut quarantine time for breakthrough Covid cases
summary: Delta Air Lines CEO Ed Bastian asked CDC Director Rochelle Walensky to reduce the 10-day quarantine period for fully vaccinated individuals with breakthrough Covid-19 infections to 5 days. The request was made due to the impact on the carrier's workforce, with over 90% of employees fully vaccinated. The CDC declined to comment, but White House medical adviser Anthony Fauci mentioned considering a reduction in the quarantine period as the Omicron variant spreads. Delta proposed partnering with CDC to collect data on the new policy.

site_title: Indonesian developer Peak Tower Corp taps Marriott to run hotel at former Selegie Centre site
summary: Peak Tower Corp has partnered with Marriott to operate an 8-storey, 132-room hotel at the former Selegie Centre site in Singapore. The hotel, set to launch in 2024, will have a total gross floor area of 4,724.52 sq m. The development, valued at S$200 million, includes a rooftop garden and sky terraces. The project comes after Peak Tower received approval from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) to develop a hotel on the site, following a 25-year contract.

site_title: Amid Covid surge, Hamilton and other Broadway shows cancel performances
summary: Several Broadway shows, including Hamilton, Hadestown, and Aladdin, have cancelled performances until after Christmas due to a surge in COVID-19 cases. The cancellations coincide with the holiday season, typically the most lucrative time for theater productions. Jagged Little Pill, a rock musical, has closed permanently. Off-Broadway and touring shows have also been affected, with multiple productions cancelling performances. The Omicron variant is driving the surge in cases, prompting concerns about the future of performances.

site_title: Sultan Plaza up for collective sale with S$360m reserve price
summary: Sultan Plaza, a 44-year-old commercial building in Singapore, has been put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$360 million. The site, which spans 52,471.3 square feet, is zoned for commercial use and has a plot ratio of 5.0, allowing for potential redevelopment up to 30-35 storeys. The reserve price has been lowered from S$380 million in the previous attempt in 2019, amid the introduction of new cooling measures that may dampen demand for collective-sale sites. The tender is set to close on February 10, 2022.

site_title: Amazon among key tech firms to drop CES plans over Covid-19 concerns
summary: Amazon, Facebook parent Meta Platforms, Twitter, and Pinterest will not attend the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas due to concerns over the Omicron variant of coronavirus. The firms cited "quickly shifting situation and uncertainty" as reasons for their decision. In contrast, other tech companies such as Qualcomm, Sony Electronics, and Google are sticking with their plans to attend and show off new hardware or host meetings. The Consumer Technology Association, which runs CES, has implemented health precautions including vaccination requirements and mask-wearing.

site_title: MDI Ventures pools over 60 angel investors to fund Indonesia's early-stage tech startups
summary: MDI Ventures, the venture capital arm of Indonesian giant Telkom, has launched a network called eMerge to attract high-net-worth individuals to fund local early-stage tech startups. The network has over 60 angel investor members, including startup founders and conglomerate owners. This move aims to provide financing opportunities for Indonesia's growing tech ecosystem, supporting the country's digital transformation and economic growth.

site_title: US: Wall Street posts robust gains with boost from Nike, Micron
summary: US stocks rose sharply on Tuesday, driven by gains in travel and tech shares, as well as strong earnings from Nike and Micron Technology. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.6% to 35,492.7, while the S&P 500 gained 1.78% to 4,649.23. Nike shares jumped 6.1% after beating quarterly estimates, and Micron Technology shares rose 10.5% after forecasting strong second-quarter sales and profits. Despite volatility caused by the Omicron variant, investors are optimistic about the market's resilience.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's main indices closed sharply higher on Tuesday (Dec 22), with strength in travel and tech shares as well as in Nike and Micron Technology following their earnings, as stocks rebounded from a coronavirus-fueled rout the session before.

site_title: China shines regulatory spotlight on livestream retail boom as crackdown claims biggest star
summary: China has fined a prominent livestreamer, Viya, over 1.3 billion yuan (S$27.8 million) for tax evasion, marking a crackdown on the country's massive livestream e-commerce business. The sector, which is expected to be worth US$423 billion next year, has been criticized for tax dodging and has led to an "awkward tango" for global brands relying on internet stars to sell their products. The fine comes after a series of warnings and punishments aimed at tightening up practices in the industry, which has seen a sharp jump in new personalities last year.

site_title: MAS should match its proposed due diligence requirements with aggressive enforcement
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed that corporate finance advisers exercise reasonable judgement in their due diligence work, assess information veracity, and evaluate IPO suitability. This comes after concerns about financial institutions and licensed holders potentially failing to meet existing due diligence requirements. The MAS aims to ensure that all capital markets services are conducted fairly and in the best interest of investors.

site_title: Digital assets: From fringe to future
summary: The financial ecosystem is undergoing a fundamental transformation from geographic to digital. Digital assets, such as cryptocurrencies and tokenization, are gaining popularity, with the global market capitalization of cryptocurrencies exceeding $2 trillion. Regulators are working to establish a consistent framework for digital assets, and institutions are demanding a global infrastructure for stability and safety. To meet these demands, collaboration among stakeholders, fintech providers, and service providers is crucial, enabling the creation of integrated solutions and unlocking significant growth opportunities.

site_title: Remember the seafarers, make them 'key workers'
summary: Governments worldwide are imposing restrictions on social gatherings and international travel due to the highly transmissible Omicron variant of Covid-19. The crew change crisis, which began in 2020, continues despite efforts by maritime organizations and international agencies. Singapore has implemented policies to facilitate seafarer travel, including recognizing seafarers as "key workers" and providing vaccination efforts. A new initiative, CrewEQUIP, aims to establish a network of trusted quarantine facilities to ensure seafarers can safely join ships despite unpredictable government border policies. Industry groups call for long-term solutions to prioritize seafarers for vaccinations and boosters.

site_title: Bank pullback from commodity trade finance presents opportunity for specialist funds
summary: A banking pullback from commodity trade finance presents an opportunity for specialist funds to fill the widening gap. Industry blow-ups and regulatory changes have led to banks cutting their role in financing global trade in natural resources, leaving unmet demand for trade finance at 15% higher than in 2018. Specialist funds are extending their offerings beyond high-rate, high-risk deals, seeking partnerships with larger financial institutions for greater security, and may eventually play a similar role to banks in filling the financing gap for small and mid-size traders.

site_title: Openspace appoints Jessica Huang Pouleur as third general partner
summary: Venture capital firm Openspace has appointed Jessica Huang Pouleur as its third general partner. Pouleur joins co-founders Shane Chesson and Hian Goh, who have led the firm since 2014. She brings experience from her time at The Walt Disney Company and Providence Equity Partners, where she led investments in the telecommunications, media, and technology sectors. Pouleur will lead investments for Openspace's mid-stage growth fund, OSV+, and sits on the boards of several companies, including GoPlay and JIWA Group. Pouleur's appointment aims to help Openspace address the vibrant South-east Asian opportunity.

site_title: What to do at a market high
summary: Global stock markets continue to reach for multi-year highs, driven by strong demand and low interest rates. Central banks, governments, and pharmaceutical companies have injected liquidity into the economy, supporting economic growth. Investors should consider investing regularly, regardless of market fluctuations, as history shows that it can lead to greater rewards. A stock market correction, if it happens, could be an opportunity to buy more shares at lower prices, rather than a threat. Investors should have a strong stomach and be prepared to invest for at least five years, and never invest more than they can afford to lose.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound from Monday sell-off as energy stocks, miners jump
summary: European shares rebounded 1.4% on Tuesday, recovering from Monday's losses, as commodity-linked and travel stocks surged amid higher copper and crude prices. Miners and oil stocks were among the biggest winners. Investors were cautious due to concerns over the Omicron variant, but buying the dip helped offset worries.

images.alt_text: European shares ended higher on Tuesday (Dec 21), recovering Monday's (Dec 20) losses, with a jump in commodity-linked and travel stocks offsetting concerns about the spread of the Omicron coronavirus variant.

site_title: Don't make climate promises you can't keep
summary: CFA Singapore has warned that companies and governments making "net-zero by 2050" promises may not be able to keep them, as few have provided details on their path to achieving this goal. The finance industry has struggled to incentivize climate action, prioritizing promises over actual change. To tackle climate change, finance must focus on efficiently allocating capital, but should not promise more than it can deliver. Investors need timely, consistent climate-related data, and governments must set incentives to drive behavior change, such as a global price on carbon.

site_title: Tanoto Foundation donates S$1 million to Business China
summary: Tanoto Foundation donates S$1 million to Business China, a Singapore-based organization supporting local businesses operating in China. The partnership aims to develop business leadership, strengthen the talent pipeline, and foster Singapore-China relations. The donation will support five programs, including a dialogue series and a scholarship for students. This partnership is seen as timely, given the impact of Covid-19 on Singapore businesses and leaders, who are looking to rebuild and expand their operations in China.

site_title: Boost for Singapore sport via global ecosystem in tech industry
summary: Singapore's sports industry has received a significant boost with the opening of the Global Sports Innovation Centre (GSIC) Asia-Pacific headquarters at the Singapore Sports Hub. The centre, a partnership with Sport Singapore, offers a global ecosystem for sport tech innovation, valued at US$116.5 billion and expected to grow 10% annually. The GSIC aims to help Singapore's sports industry navigate the digitalisation climate through digitalisation, and has already connected startups with potential customers and provided guidance on product adjustments.

site_title: Blinken's visit sends strong signal US is back, but it still needs a long-term strategy on SE Asia
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's recent visit to South-east Asia sent a strong signal that the US is back in the region, with a focus on enhanced security and economic ties. Blinken signed agreements with Indonesia and expressed concerns over China's aggressive actions, including its grey-zone tactics in the South China Sea and its impact on the Mekong River. He hinted at a potential comprehensive regional economic framework and a funding proposal for undersea cables to boost internet access in Pacific countries. However, the US still lacks a long-term strategy to counter China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: Vietnam expected to lead Asean growth in 2022
summary: Vietnam's economy is forecasted to lead Southeast Asian growth in 2022 with a 6.5% growth rate, according to the Asian Development Bank. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact, the country's tourism and hospitality sector is expected to recover gradually, with international flights set to restart in January 2022. The seafood industry is also expected to face challenges due to a European Commission review, which could lead to a potential "red card" and significant losses. Meanwhile, Vietnam's manufacturing sector is expected to grow, driven by the expansion of the digital economy and a rapidly expanding middle class.

site_title: Businesses to take flight in 2022, but turbulence expected
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to continue recovering in 2022, with businesses optimistic about growth despite ongoing challenges. The country's full-year growth forecast for 2021 was narrowed to around 7%, close to 2019 GDP levels. Businesses are focusing on three key areas - digitalisation, sustainability, and talent - to seize opportunities for recovery and growth. The gradual re-opening of borders and restart of large-scale events are also expected to boost business travel and internationalisation efforts. However, new variants such as Omicron may threaten the re-opening of borders, and businesses will need to be prepared for emerging hurdles.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Nike, Micron lead gains
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Tuesday, following a sharp selloff in the previous session, as strong quarterly earnings from Nike and a positive forecast from chipmaker Micron lifted sentiment. The Dow Jones rose 137.34 points, the S&P 500 gained 26.94 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 159.49 points.

site_title: Sunak unveils £1b for companies hit by Omicron fallout
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced a £1 billion support package for hospitality businesses struggling with Omicron-induced demand slumps, providing up to £6,000 in cash grants per business. The move aims to ease pressure from firms demanding more support amid a "lockdown by stealth" amid record Covid-19 infections. Sunak declined to rule out further curbs but hinted at stepping in with more assistance if needed, while also preparing for the possibility of new restrictions.

site_title: Don't count oil out in 2022
summary: Oil prices have seen significant volatility, with a 15% decline from their peak in October, primarily due to Omicron fears. Despite this, the US Energy Information Administration forecasts a global crude shortage of 1.18 million barrels per day in December, which is expected to narrow to 0.35 million barrels per day next year. Cold weather is supporting short-term demand, suggesting that oil prices may recover in the coming months.

site_title: Dollar recovers some overnight losses; euro extends gains
summary: The US dollar partially recovered overnight losses on Tuesday, December 21, as risk sentiment improved following a sell-off in global markets. The euro gained for a second day, while the Australian dollar bounced back from a 2-day decline. The dollar index remained above Monday's low, near 96.42, and investors remain bullish on the greenback's outlook. The Omicron variant's resurgence raised concerns over the near-term economic outlook, but the dollar is still within striking distance of a 16-month high.

site_title: WHO approves Novavax as 10th authorised Covid jab
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) approved the Novavax Covid-19 vaccine, making it the 10th authorized jab. The European Medicines Agency had previously given it the green light, citing its conventional technology as a potential motivator for hesitant vaccine recipients. The vaccine is 90% effective in reducing symptomatic Covid-19 cases and can be stored at refrigerated temperatures, giving it a logistical advantage. The WHO's approval paves the way for countries to quickly approve and distribute the vaccine, potentially increasing equitable access to doses worldwide.

site_title: AT&T to sell Xandr ad unit to Microsoft
summary: AT&T is selling its advertising unit, Xandr, to Microsoft for $43 billion, partly due to high costs and struggling debt. Xandr was created in 2018 to use data from phone, internet, and TV services to target consumers. The deal will help Microsoft accelerate its digital advertising and retail media solutions, focusing on consumer privacy and advertiser goals. The sale does not include DirecTV's advertising sales business, which is subject to regulatory reviews.

site_title: UPS to buy US$1.5b of Boeing freighters as air cargo booms
summary: United Parcel Service (UPS) agreed to purchase 19 Boeing freighter jets worth $1.5 billion, bolstering its fleet as air-cargo demand surges due to e-commerce growth and shipping delays. The planes will be delivered between 2023 and 2025, amid a record-breaking year for Boeing's freighter sales. This purchase follows a trend of companies turning to air transport as ocean-cargo routes struggle with delays, driven by time-sensitive online shopping expected to persist even after the pandemic subsides.

site_title: Malaysia's YTL Power acquires Singapore data centre, with plans to further scale up capacity in region
summary: Kuala Lumpur-based YTL Power International has acquired Singapore start-up Dodid, marking its entry into the data centre industry outside Malaysia. The acquisition includes a 12.5 megawatt, Tier 3 data centre in Tagore Lane. YTL Power acquired Dodid through its digital infrastructure subsidiary YTL Data Center Holdings, but did not disclose the deal's value. This move aims to further scale up capacity in the region and expand YTL Power's presence in the data centre market.

site_title: Stamp duty traps to watch out for
summary: The Singapore government introduced new property cooling measures, including increased Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates, to curb the residential property market. ABSD rates increased by 5-15% for most buyers, with the highest rate of 44% for buyers purchasing equity interests in property-holding entities. The measures may help cool the market by putting pressure on developers to sell their remaining units, especially if they are unable to sell within 5 years. Taxpayers should be aware of potential "traps" in dealing with residential properties, including indirect purchases, joint purchases, and estate planning, to avoid unexpected tax bills.

images.alt_text: While it is often the desire of parents - when bequeathing property - to be "fair" and treat their children "equally", the arrangement of making each child a beneficiary can result in adverse tax consequences.

site_title: Extended Covid-19 support suggests govt caution in face of uneven recovery
summary: The Singapore government has extended support measures for foreign workers and Covid-19 affected employees until December 31, 2022, to address uneven recovery. Foreign workers will continue to be waived of levies, and the Covid-19 Recovery Grant will remain available for lower- to middle-income employees. The government also plans to review the S$250 levy rebate for construction, marine shipyard, and process workers, and may extend the Jobs Growth Incentive scheme in 2022, which subsidizes new local hires. The extended support aims to keep workers engaged in job search and training, and reduce the permanent scarring in the labor market.

site_title: Continued strength ahead in HDB, private housing rental markets
summary: Singapore's property market continues to show strength in the HDB and private housing rental markets, with en-bloc sales, construction delays, and foreign students and expats returning to the country contributing to the growth. Rents have risen, with some three-room flats in heartland locations and Districts 9 and 10 reaching S$3,000 and S$4,000 per month respectively. Analysts predict a further increase in demand and rents in 2022, driven by the resumption of international travel and improved hiring prospects.

images.alt_text: Among condo unit types, District 9 was the most popular for renting two-bedroom residences. Some 2,366 rental contracts were inked in Jan-Oct 2021, and the average monthly rent was S$4,321.

site_title: EU to limit vaccine validity in Covid pass to 9 months
summary: The European Union has adopted a binding acceptance period of nine months for vaccination certificates to encourage boosters. The measure, set to take effect from February 1, aims to harmonize recognition of EU Covid certificates across the bloc. This comes as the EU races to distribute booster jabs amid the Omicron variant, following unilateral measures by several member states requiring pre-departure tests or quarantine. The EU executive says the move will protect health and ensure safe traveling.

site_title: What America loses if it doesn't 'Build Back Better'
summary: The Build Back Better framework, a crucial spending plan proposed by President Joe Biden, is at risk of being blocked by Senator Joe Manchin's objections. If the plan is not enacted, millions of American children will be condemned to poor health, low earnings, and inadequate medical care. The plan aims to mitigate climate change, which will yield major health benefits from cleaner air. Manchin's claims about the bill's cost and national debt are disputed, with the Congressional Budget Office estimating the bill to be roughly deficit-neutral. The proposal's failure would condemn the US to falling behind other nations in meeting basic human needs, with growing gaps between US states and a weak social safety net.

site_title: US current account deficit widens to biggest in 15 years in Q3
summary: The US current account deficit widened to a 15-year high in the third quarter, reaching US$214.8 billion, or 3.7% of GDP. This represents a 8.3% increase from the previous quarter. The deficit was fueled by a record increase in imports, as businesses replenished depleted inventories. Despite the widening deficit, it remains below the peak of 6.3% of GDP in 2005, as the US is now a net exporter of crude oil and fuel.

site_title: European gas prices hit record as Russian flows via Yamal reverse
summary: European gas prices reached a record high on Tuesday as a Russian pipeline switched to flow east, contrary to speculation of a possible political motivation. The Yamal-Europe pipeline, a major route for Russian gas to Europe, reversed direction after falling in the previous days. Gas traders attribute the increase to strong power station demand, with French nuclear plants closed due to colder weather. European benchmark prices rose over 16% to a record high, with some experts warning that Europe's storage buffer is low, making it dependent on imports.

site_title: UK households face £18b increase in energy bills
summary: The UK is facing an £18 billion increase in energy bills next year, with households expected to pay an average of £2,000 per year, a 56% increase. This surge in gas prices could add 1.8 percentage points to headline inflation and 1.3% to consumer spending. The energy price cap is set to increase, and the government has opened a consultation to address the country's beleaguered energy market, where 24 suppliers have gone bust since August. The Bank of England may need to increase interest rates to combat the potential inflation increase.

site_title: US tornadoes push insurers 2021 bill over US$105b as climate change impact grows
summary: US tornadoes in December have pushed the insurance industry's 2021 bill for weather-related claims to over $105 billion, exceeding initial predictions. The $5 billion in insured losses from the tornadoes in the Midwest and South is part of a year of over $100 billion in catastrophe events, driven by climate change and "secondary perils" such as wildfires and winter storms. Experts warn that premiums will rise as insurers struggle to assess the risks of these unpredictable events, with some clients willing to bear higher retentions to keep premiums low.

site_title: Thailand approves more stimulus measures to boost economy
summary: Thailand has approved new economic stimulus measures to boost its economy, which is expected to expand 4% next year after a predicted 1% growth this year. The measures include tax breaks for shoppers, a co-payment scheme, and extended property transfer fees. The government aims to stimulate domestic consumption, exports, and government spending, with estimates suggesting the measures will lift economic growth by 0.7 percentage points in the first quarter. The measures are expected to help revive the economy, which has been struggling due to the pandemic-induced collapse of its tourism sector.

site_title: Electricity prices surge to record highs as Europe struggles to keep lights on
summary: Electricity prices in Europe have surged to record highs as France struggles to keep its lights on due to a power shortage. France is boosting imports from neighboring countries and burning fuel oil to meet demand, while Germany is closing nearly half of its nuclear capacity. The crisis has led to a 30% reduction in France's nuclear capacity by January, making the energy market vulnerable to weather conditions. Gas prices also jumped after shipments from Russia reversed direction, further exacerbating the crisis.

site_title: Sunak unveils £1b for companies hit by Omicron fallout
summary: Britain's Finance Minister Rishi Sunak announced a £1 billion support package for UK hospitality businesses affected by the Omicron variant, offering up to £6,000 in cash grants to pubs, restaurants, and other eligible businesses. The move aims to alleviate the growing clamour for more support amid a "lockdown by stealth" as Britons avoided social gatherings to avoid the virus. Sunak also provided extra funding for cultural institutions and compensation for sick pay.

site_title: Malaysia warns of more floods as PM acknowledges lapses in rescue efforts
summary: Malaysia warns of more floods as Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob acknowledges weaknesses in the government's response to flooding that has caused over a dozen deaths and displaced over 60,000 people. Torrential rain began last Friday, causing floods in eight states, and authorities have been criticized for their slow response. The Meteorological Department predicts more floods in the coming days, and the death toll has climbed to 17 in Selangor. The government vows to improve its response in the future, but nearly 63,000 people remain displaced.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 1.31 points lower at 1,492.59 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 2.452 billion lots worth RM1.666 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 449 to 355.

site_title: Toyota to start car hardware, software update service in Japan
summary: Toyota Motor Corp will launch a car hardware and software update service in Japan, called Kinto Factory, starting in late January. The service offers customization, new safety features, and software upgrades to car computer systems. The goal is to transform Toyota into a more service-based "mobility company" and encourage customers to keep their vehicles for longer, promoting sustainability. Kinto subscriptions have seen significant growth, with 28,000 subscribers as of November, and the company may consider expanding the service abroad.

site_title: Qatar targets US$10b of investments in US ports
summary: Qatar plans to invest at least $10 billion in US ports, primarily on the East Coast, with a focus on aging ports near major highways and rail lines. The investment is part of Qatar's infrastructure spree, reflecting its deepening ties with the US. The plan is at a preliminary stage and would be backed by debt linked to the port assets. This investment comes as the US government has approved a $1.2 trillion infrastructure package, but estimates suggest tens of billions of dollars are needed for investment in creaking infrastructure.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Several en bloc sites in Singapore are proceeding with the sale process despite cooling measures, with some already tendering and others in private treaty talks. Despite the measures, hopefuls continue to push forward, indicating a strong demand for en bloc sales in the market.

site_title: Dubai ruler must provide £554m to settle UK custody case
summary: Dubai's ruler, Sheikh Mohammed Rashid al-Maktoum, has been ordered to pay a record-breaking £554 million to settle a custody battle with his ex-wife, Princess Haya bint al-Hussein, over their two children. The majority of the award will ensure their lifetime security, addressing the "grave risk" posed by the sheikh. The settlement includes £251.5 million for Princess Haya's British mansions, £3 million for the children's education, and £11.2 million per year for their maintenance and security. The payments will be guaranteed via a £290 million security held by HSBC bank.

site_title: Funds shunning India turns rupee into Asia's worst currency in emerging market
summary: India's rupee is set to end the year as Asia's worst-performing emerging market currency, with foreign funds pulling $4.2 billion from the country's stock market. The currency declined 1.9% this quarter, partly due to record-high trade deficit and monetary policy divergence with the Federal Reserve. Experts predict the rupee could fall to 78 per dollar by end-March, with a possible decline to 74-75 range by the end of the fiscal year. This is the fourth straight year of losses for the rupee, with bonds also seeing significant outflows.

site_title: Airline passengers can claim if flight brought forward: EU court
summary: The European Union's top court ruled that passengers are entitled to compensation if their flights are brought forward by more than an hour, in addition to delays and cancellations. The compensation, ranging from $282.38 to $677.70, depends on flight distance and can be reduced by 50% if the airline offers re-routing in advance. Passengers can claim damages for inconvenience caused by a forward-scheduled flight, regardless of whether the airline offers re-routing or not. This ruling applies to flights operated by airlines such as Azurair, Corendon Airlines, and Lufthansa subsidiaries.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
