summary: European stocks rebounded 1.0% on Tuesday, reversing the previous day's sharp decline due to concerns over Omicron's economic impact. London's FTSE 100 index rose to 7,268.87 points, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX indexes also increased. The rebound follows a global selloff on Monday, as investors sought to recover from investor panic over worldwide measures to contain the fast-spreading Omicron variant.

site_title: Singapore stocks rebound on Tuesday tracking regional gains; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rebounded 0.4% on Tuesday, closing at 3,085.08, following regional gains. The Straits Time Index (STI) partially recovered Monday's losses. Shares of Dairy Farm International rose 3.8% and AEM Holdings climbed 2.4%, while Thai Beverage fell 0.8%. Trading activity was muted due to the holiday season. The local tech manufacturers' performance was a notable exception. Regional markets, including Australia, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Japan, also rose between 0.9% and 2.1%.

site_title: Thailand reinstates mandatory Covid-19 quarantine over Omicron concerns
summary: Thailand reinstates mandatory Covid-19 quarantine for foreign visitors, effective Dec 21, due to Omicron variant concerns. The "Test and Go" waiver will be suspended, and visitors will be required to undergo hotel quarantine for 7-10 days. The decision comes after the first local transmission of the Omicron variant was reported. Approximately 200,000 visitors previously registered for the quarantine waiver and sandbox programme will still be eligible. The decision will be reviewed on Jan 4.

site_title: FJ Benjamin to raise S$3m in placement deal with Far East Organization unit
summary: RETAIL group FJ Benjamin Holdings (FJB) will raise S$3 million from a Far East Organization unit for expansion. Western Properties, a Far East Organization member, will subscribe to 120 million new shares at S$0.025 each. The placement will raise Western Properties' interest to 16.7% and make it FJB's second-largest shareholder. FJB expects to see increased mall traffic post-Covid-19 disruptions and plans to collaborate with Far East Organization on new businesses and existing brands.

site_title: RBNZ out of step with Ardern as huge gender pay gap revealed
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank (RBNZ) has revealed a significant gender pay gap, with an average 21% gap as of June 30, more than twice the national public service shortfall. The bank attributed its inability to provide historical data, citing only starting calculations this year. The gap, excluding Governor Adrian Orr's salary, was 19.4%. The RBNZ's move comes as New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has pushed for greater equality, with Ardern reportedly out of step with the RBNZ's stance on the issue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with a 1.00% gain, jumping 226.47 points to 22,971.33, following a rally across Asian markets amid bargain buying. The fast-spreading Omicron virus variant continues to pose a concern. In other markets, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.88% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 1.05%. The gains were attributed to bargain buying after a recent sell-off.

site_title: Former Malaysian PM Mahathir to be discharged from hospital within days
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 96, is set to be discharged from the hospital within the next few days after completing medical investigations. He was admitted for a full checkup and observation last Thursday due to a history of heart troubles. Mahathir, who served as Malaysia's longest-serving prime minister from 1981 to 2003, will make him the world's oldest head of government after a second term in 2018. The hospital has confirmed the team of doctors treating him is satisfied with the results.

site_title: Applications for Covid-19 Recovery Grant extended to Dec 31, 2022; third tranche for workers who need more help
summary: The Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) in Singapore has extended the application period for the Covid-19 Recovery Grant to December 31, 2022, to support workers affected by the pandemic. Eligible workers can receive up to 3 tranches of assistance, with changes to eligibility criteria taking effect on January 1, 2022. The grant provides financial assistance to low- to middle-income workers and self-employed individuals who lost their jobs or experienced significant income loss due to the pandemic.

site_title: Chinese developer stocks jump most in a month
summary: Chinese developer stocks surged 4.5% on Tuesday, the largest gain in a month, as traders struggled to identify a catalyst. Poly Developments & Holdings Group and Sunac China Holdings saw significant jumps, with the former reaching its highest level since March. The divergence between mainland and Hong Kong developer stocks continues, with larger firms often listed in Shanghai and Shenzhen outperforming. Authorities' encouragement of lenders to fund acquisitions may benefit larger firms, including state-owned companies.

site_title: US to return US$154m stolen by Sony employee and converted to Bitcoin
summary: The US Department of Justice has taken action to return over $154 million allegedly stolen by a Sony employee, Rei Ishii, who converted the funds into Bitcoin. Ishii diverted the funds in May while attempting to transfer between Sony accounts, and then converted them into 3,879 Bitcoins, valued at over $180 million. The funds were seized by the FBI in December and have been fully recovered. Ishii has been criminally charged in Japan, and the US intends to return the stolen money to the victim.

site_title: En bloc hopefuls push on with tenders despite cooling measures
summary: Collective-sale hopefuls in Singapore continue to push forward with en bloc tenders despite recent cooling measures. Sites like Sultan Plaza, Tanglin Shopping Centre, and Baode Building have begun or plan to launch tenders, with reserve prices ranging from S$478 million to S$828 million. Developers are expected to become more cautious, with higher additional buyer's stamp duty rates and increased risk of not selling units within 5 years. Analysts predict that smaller, "realistically priced" en bloc sites will attract more buyers, while mega developments may face challenges.

site_title: UBS appeals 1.8b-euro tax penalty at French Supreme Court
summary: UBS Group has appealed a French Supreme Court ruling that ordered the bank to pay 1.8 billion euros in penalties for allegedly laundering funds for wealthy French clients. The bank is challenging the verdict, citing the potential impact on its business in other jurisdictions. The decision comes after a 2019 finding that UBS had illegally laundered funds, with the bank initially facing penalties of 4.5 billion euros.

site_title: Omicron's global spread prompts renewed lockdowns, delayed reopenings
summary: Many nations are imposing renewed lockdowns and delaying reopenings due to the rapid spread of the Omicron variant. Omicron infections have multiplied rapidly across Europe, the US, and Asia, with cases reported in at least 89 countries. Countries such as New Zealand, India, and Singapore are delaying border reopenings, while others like Israel and Kuwait are imposing restrictions. The variant's severity remains unclear, but it's spreading faster than the Delta variant and causing infections in vaccinated or recovered individuals. The rapid spread has ignited fears of economically disruptive restrictions, impacting financial markets.

site_title: Moderna could be ready to develop Omicron booster in weeks
summary: Moderna, the Covid-19 vaccine maker, expects to develop a booster shot to protect against the Omicron variant in a few weeks, according to CEO Stephane Bancel. The company hopes to start clinical trials early next year and aims to produce 500 million doses after regulatory approval, with current production capacities already higher than last year. Approval may require additional studies, potentially adding three months, but Moderna is confident in its development process and has already increased production, producing 700-800 million doses this year.

site_title: Richard Li's FWD withdraws US IPO plan with pivot to Hong Kong
summary: FWD Group, a Hong Kong-based insurer backed by billionaire Richard Li, has withdrawn its US initial public offering (IPO) plan due to China's tightening grip on overseas listings. The company, which raised $1.4 billion in a private placement this month, is now considering an IPO in Hong Kong early next year instead. The decision comes amid increased market volatility and high-profile failures of Chinese companies, such as Didi Global, which is planning to delist from the US.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound from 2-week low on chip optimism, upbeat exports data
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded 0.41% from a 2-week low on Tuesday, driven by chip heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix after Micron Technology's stronger-than-expected quarterly results. Upbeat exports data also suggested the economic recovery is on track. The Kospi index ended at 2,975.03, while the Korean won and benchmark bond yield fell. Chip shortages are expected to ease in 2022.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain on banks, energy stocks boost
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 7,308.5, driven by gains in financial and energy stocks. Heavyweight banks rose 0.4% and energy stocks gained 1.2%, despite Omicron's spread in Europe forcing lockdowns. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.2% on Monday. Energy stocks rebounded from a sharp drop on Monday, while technology stocks dropped 1.1%.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose slightly on Tuesday, helped by gains in financial and energy stocks, even as surging Omicron coronavirus cases triggered tighter restrictions in Europe and clouded the outlook for global economic growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets, oil rise after sell-off but virus casts shadow
summary: Asia's markets and oil prices rose on Tuesday after a sell-off, with investors seeking bargains amid concerns over the fast-spreading Omicron variant. The US social spending bill and central bank rate hikes also provided some support. However, uncertainty over the economic impact of the virus and related restrictions remains a major concern, with markets expecting volatility in the short term. Asia's main indexes ended the day with gains, while oil prices rose by at least one percent.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Dec 21, with the Nikkei 225 index jumping 2.08% to 28,517.59 and the Topix index gaining 1.47% to 1,969.79, driven by gains in Asian shares. Investors sought bargains after a sharp fall in the previous session, supported by gains in Asian shares.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank says new payment system to slash money transfer costs
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, launched a new retail payment system, "BI-Fast," aimed at reducing money transfer costs and supporting the country's booming digital economy. The system allows real-time, secure transfers of up to 250 million rupiah at a maximum cost of 2,500 rupiah per transaction. This is a significant reduction from the current cost of 6,500 rupiah per transaction. The move is expected to accelerate digitalization, promote financial inclusion, and support the country's economic recovery.

site_title: Australia: Healthcare, mining stocks help shares notch best day in 2 weeks
summary: Australian shares rose by 0.86% to their best session in two weeks, driven by healthcare stocks led by CSL's 4.9% gain, and mining stocks, which advanced on iron ore price rally. Healthcare stocks rallied 3.9% in their best session since August 2020, while mining stocks gained 1.1%. Energy stocks also firmed 1.6%, with analysts expecting rising Covid-19 cases to boost pathology revenues.

site_title: Financing a climate revolution
summary: The world is facing a critical climate crisis, with the 1.5-degree Celsius warming limit expected to be reached or exceeded in the early 2030s. To mitigate this, the private sector, particularly finance firms, plays a crucial role in aligning their financing activities to achieve net zero emissions by 2050. The Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (GFANZ) has pledged to manage $130 trillion in finance, while Citi has committed to a $500 billion environmental finance goal. Public-private sector collaboration is essential, with regulators and governments working together to create an enabling environment for investors to accelerate the deployment of capital at the required pace and scale.

site_title: Sanofi to buy US biotech firm Amunix for US$1b
summary: Sanofi has agreed to acquire US-based biotech firm Amunix for approximately $1 billion, with an additional $225 million contingent on development milestones. Amunix develops cancer treatments that utilize the immune system, focusing on cytokines and T-cells. The deal aims to expand Sanofi's immuno-oncology capabilities.

site_title: Japan government weighs raising FY2022 growth forecast to 3.0% or more: Yomiuri
summary: Japan's government is considering raising its fiscal 2022 growth forecast to 3.0% or more, following a record $317 billion extra budget. The projection would be an upgrade from a previous forecast of 2.2% real GDP growth. The update comes after parliament approved the budget, and the cabinet is set to approve the new forecast on Thursday. The move is seen as a response to the country's ongoing economic recovery, despite the risks posed by the Omicron variant and potential Covid-19 outbreaks.

site_title: Sky no longer the limit for Germany's 'Mainhattan' skyscraper boom
summary: Germany's "Mainhattan" financial hub is experiencing a skyscraper boom, with 18 high-rise buildings sprouting up across Frankfurt. The demand for property has led to record-high prices, with house prices rising 50% since mid-2016 and a 10% jump in the second quarter of 2021. Despite concerns of a bubble, developers remain optimistic, and the city's planning department agrees that the sky is no longer the limit for property prices, citing sufficient luxury apartments to meet demand.

site_title: Malaysian companies see Q4 earnings taking a hit due to severe flooding: CGS-CIMB
summary: Malaysian companies are expected to see their Q4 earnings take a hit due to severe flooding, with manufacturing facilities and estates sustaining damage and workers facing difficulties getting to work. Port operations were affected, leading to logistical challenges and shortages of materials. Analysts have cut net profit forecasts by 4% to reflect lower container volume, with some companies potentially incurring one-off costs for flood damage. The tourism and plantation industries are also expected to be impacted, with some estates disrupted by the floods.

site_title: Macau's casinos pin hopes on everyday gamblers after junket shutdowns
summary: Macau's casinos face a bleak short-term outlook due to the shutdown of their lucrative VIP gaming rooms, which cater to wealthy gamblers. The Chinese government's crackdown on the junket business has dried up a third of Macau's overall gaming revenues. To replace this revenue, casinos must draw mass-market gamers, but this depends on controlling Covid-19 travel restrictions and having mass players return to Macau at normal levels. Shares of affected companies have plummeted, with Wynn Macau, Sands China, and MGM China experiencing significant declines.

site_title: Japan upgrades economic view for first time in 17 months in Dec report
summary: Japan raised its overall economic assessment for the first time in 17 months in December, citing improved consumer and business optimism due to easing COVID-19 restrictions. The government upgraded its view on private consumption, business conditions, and employment, but downgraded its view on capital expenditure and housing construction. The country's economy is expected to rebound in the final quarter of 2021 after pandemic curbs were lifted. Authorities will closely monitor risks from new coronavirus variants, including Omicron. A record $317 billion extra budget was approved to support the recovery.

site_title: Citigroup hires for team to capture Australian unicorns
summary: Citigroup is expanding its commercial banking team in Australia to target smaller clients with revenue of A$75 million or more, aiming to increase its contribution to 10% of the bank's overall revenue in the country by 2024. The US lender is also seeking to capture "unicorns" like Afterpay, and has advised on several major deals, including the A$744.6 million acquisition of AutoPacific Group. Citigroup plans to hire 13 new staff to reach a team of 35 by the end of 2024, as part of its strategy to grow its commercial banking business in Asia.

site_title: SDAX Financial raises S$24m in Series B round led by Straits Trading and PSA
summary: SDAX Financial, a digital securities exchange, has raised S$24 million in its Series B round led by Straits Trading and PSA International. The funding will be used to roll out new product offerings and develop the technology platform. Straits Trading's investment ties in with its shareholder club initiative, allowing for fractional ownership of real estate and property. PSA's investment supports its commitment to ESG solutions and decarbonizing supply chains.

site_title: Amazon rival Snapdeal reveals sales dive ahead of mega India IPO
summary: Snapdeal, an Indian e-commerce startup, has filed preliminary documents for an initial public offering (IPO) to raise $225.6 million, following a record year for India market debuts. The company's revenue from operations dropped 44% to $4.7 billion in the year ended March 2021, while its loss narrowed by more than half. Snapdeal has refocused on value-driven e-commerce, selling items under $5, and has seen sales volumes grow 254% in the fashion category during the recent festival season. The IPO, targeted for early next year, comes after successful offerings from other tech companies.

site_title: New Zealand delays border reopening plans over Omicron concerns
summary: New Zealand has postponed its phased border reopening plans until the end of February due to concerns over the rapid spread of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus. The country had initially planned to ease restrictions from January, with non-quarantine travel set to resume for New Zealanders in Australia in January. The government cited uncertainty over Omicron's impact on health systems and the need for caution. Other measures, such as increased quarantine lengths and reduced pre-departure testing, will also be implemented.

site_title: China Mobile to raise up to 56b yuan in Shanghai listing
summary: China Mobile, the world's largest mobile network operator, plans to raise up to 56 billion yuan (S$12 billion) in a Shanghai public offering. The company aims to sell up to 845 million shares at 57.58 yuan apiece, following a similar path as its smaller state-owned rivals, China Telecom and China Unicom, which are already listed in China. The move comes amid rising Sino-US tensions, with the US blacklisting Chinese companies over allegations of human rights violations and finalizing rules to delist non-compliant firms from American exchanges in three years.

site_title: MDI Ventures pools over 60 angel investors to fund Indonesia's early-stage tech startups
summary: MDI Ventures, a venture capital arm of Indonesian giant Telkom, has launched the eMerge network to attract angel investors to fund local early-stage tech startups. The network has over 60 angel investors and has closed its first investment in GOX, an Indonesian livestream video platform. Members of eMerge invest via a syndicate and pool money through a special purpose vehicle company. MDI Ventures, which manages around $900 million in assets, has a track record of exits and has invested in over 50 startups in 12 countries.

site_title: Travellers to Hong Kong from Britain required to quarantine in government camp
summary: Travellers arriving in Hong Kong from Britain must initially quarantine in a government camp for the first four days, followed by 17 days of hotel quarantine and frequent testing. This new rule, effective from Tuesday, joins 12 African nations and the US in the city's strictest entry tier due to high Omicron infection rates. The tightened measures aim to control the spread of the virus, but have isolated Hong Kong and created challenges for airlines ahead of the Christmas travel period.

site_title: MOM extends foreign worker levy rebate, waiver of foreign worker levy during SHN
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore is extending the S$250 foreign worker levy rebate for 15,000 firms in the construction, marine shipyard, and process sectors until March 2022. The waiver of foreign worker levies during the entry stay-home notice (SHN) and residential onboarding program at migrant worker centers will also be extended until December 2022, providing safeguards against COVID-19 importation. This move aims to support affected sectors and help employers retain existing workers and reduce manpower reliance.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars on defensive on Omicron fears
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell due to concerns over the fast-spreading Omicron variant, which may lead to economically disruptive restrictions. The Aussie dropped 0.1% to US$0.71027, while the kiwi fell 0.2% to US$0.6706. Despite this, the Reserve Bank of Australia is optimistic that the variant won't derail its economic recovery. New Zealand will delay its border reopening to the end of February due to Omicron concerns.

site_title: Gold steady as traders assess Omicron, rate hike impact
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Tuesday, holding at US$1,790.57 per ounce, as traders assessed the impact of the Omicron coronavirus variant and interest rate hikes on inflation. The dollar hovered below recent highs, and US stocks closed 1% lower due to Omicron cases and a possible blow to a domestic spending bill. The Federal Reserve's hawkish turn has not changed the bond market's view that short-term interest rates may top out below the estimated peak.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.45% or 404.69 points to 28,342.50, and the Topix index increasing 1.25% or 24.20 points to 1,965.53. Investors sought bargains after a sharp fall in the previous session, despite a rout on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday with investors seeking bargains after a sharp fall in the previous session, shrugging off a rout on Wall Street.

site_title: Qatar Airways sues Airbus in A350 jet damage dispute
summary: Qatar Airways has initiated a UK court case against Airbus over damage to its A350 passenger jets, citing blistered paint and corrosion as safety concerns. The dispute, which has locked the two companies in a row for months, has led to the grounding of 21 A350 jets by Qatar's domestic regulator. Airbus claims the jets are safe despite surface degradation, while Qatar Airways argues that safety has been compromised. The case is considered unprecedented in aviation history, with several industry executives describing it as a rare legal showdown between two leading players.

site_title: Vietnam mobile wallet MoMo says valuation tops US$2b after latest funding
summary: Vietnam's e-wallet company MoMo has raised $200 million from investors, pushing its valuation above $2 billion. The funding round, led by Mizuho Bank, will support the growth of MoMo as a "super app" offering multiple services, similar to those in China and Indonesia. The company aims to double its 30 million users to 50 million in the next two years, driven by Vietnam's growing financial technology sector during the Covid-19 pandemic. MoMo plans to go public by 2025.

site_title: SoftBank, GIC back Colombia fintech's US$200m funding round
summary: Colombia-based fintech startup Addi has raised US$200 million in debt and equity funding, valuing the company at over US$700 million. The round included US$80 million in equity from GIC and Softbank Group's Latin America Fund, alongside US$125 million in debt financing from Goldman Sachs. The company aims for 5-fold growth next year and plans to expand into new markets, including Mexico and Brazil, with its buy-now-pay-later technology and 1-click shopping feature.

site_title: Parent company's exit offer for Pan Ocean turns unconditional
summary: Harim Holdings' exit offer for Pan Ocean, a bulk shipping company, has turned unconditional after Pan Ocean's shareholders approved its voluntary delisting from the Singapore Exchange. The offer, which is not a privatization exercise, aims to transfer ownership to the South Korean parent company. As of Dec 20, 54.71% of shares had been accepted, with 94.6% of shareholders voting in favor of the delisting. The offer remains open until Jan 3, 2022, and Singapore registered shareholders can elect to transfer their shares to the South Korea register.

site_title: Suspected Omicron cluster found at Anytime Fitness in Bukit Timah Shopping Centre
summary: A suspected Omicron cluster has been detected at the Anytime Fitness gym in Bukit Timah Shopping Centre in Singapore. Three fully vaccinated individuals, aged 18, 21, and 24, have tested preliminary positive for the Omicron variant, with mild symptoms. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is conducting contact tracing and has advised gym staff and visitors who may have been in close contact with the cases to quarantine or undergo testing. This brings Singapore's total Omicron cases to 71, with 65 imported cases and 6 local cases.

site_title: Boeing, Airbus executives urge delay in US 5G wireless deployment
summary: Boeing and Airbus executives, Dave Calhoun and Jeffrey Knittel, respectively, have urged the Biden administration to delay the US 5G wireless deployment on January 5, citing potential harm to aviation safety. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has issued airworthiness directives warning of 5G interference with aircraft electronics, and industry groups estimate that 345,000 passenger flights and 5,400 cargo flights could face delays, diversions, or cancellations. The aviation industry has pushed for more stringent measures to limit interference, while the wireless industry group CTIA has defended 5G as safe and accused the aviation industry of fearmongering.

images.alt_text: Boeing chief executive Dave Calhoun and Airbus Americas CEO Jeffrey Knittel on Monday (Dec 20) urged the Biden administration to delay planned deployment of new 5G wireless services, saying it could harm aviation safety.

site_title: China expected to extend regulatory crackdowns into 2022
summary: China is expected to extend its regulatory crackdowns into 2022, with a focus on data protection and national security risks. The country has already implemented stricter regulations on antitrust violations, private tuition groups, and property developers' debt. Analysts predict tighter scrutiny on private enterprise and deals that pose risks to national security. This could bring some certainty to investors, but the regulatory environment remains uncertain. The actions are part of Beijing's efforts to step up control and address concerns about the country's economic growth, which is expected to slow in 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher, gaining 0.22% or 50.71 points to 22,795.57, following two days of losses. Traders were cautious due to the spread of the Omicron virus variant. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.06 points to 1,494.96. Volume reached 240.61 million lots worth RM159.78 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 186 to 129.

site_title: Malaysian companies fear heavy losses from floods
summary: Malaysian companies fear heavy losses from the recent floods, particularly in the Shah Alam and Klang districts of Selangor state. The floods, which led to mass evacuations, have caused damage to property, assets, and products, as well as production disruptions. Manufacturers' association president Soh Thian Lai estimated losses could be in the millions of ringgit, while a Dutch chipmaking equipment supplier lowered its fourth-quarter revenue outlook due to the floods affecting its main production facility. Recovery work is underway, with shipping operations expected to resume soon.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% at the opening of Tuesday's session, recouping losses from Monday. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,088.16 points, with 83 gainers outnumbering 43 losers. 41.6 million securities worth S$43.8 million changed hands. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5 per cent or 15.19 points to 3,088.16 as at 9.01am.

site_title: Employers to receive over S$400m in JSS payouts from Dec 31
summary: Employers in Singapore's sectors facing safe management restrictions will receive over S$400 million in Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) payouts from Dec 31, 2021. This brings the total JSS support to S$28 billion since its introduction in 2020. The payouts will support over 380,000 local employees and include enhanced JSS payouts for Phase 2 and Stabilisation Phase periods. Eligible employers can expect payouts from Dec 31, while those who have not registered for PayNow Corporate or have existing Giro arrangements will receive cheques from Jan 14, 2022.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Pan Ocean, Nanofilm, Darco
summary: Stocks to watch on Tuesday, Dec 21, 2021: Pan Ocean's shares rose 0.1% to S$8.27 after Harim Holdings' shareholders approved its voluntary delisting from the Singapore Exchange. Nanofilm Technologies International's shares fell 4.1% to S$3.72 due to plant and equipment qualification costs. Darco Water Technologies' shares remained flat at S$0.126 after minority shareholders reached an amicable resolution with controlling shareholder Wang Zhi.

images.alt_text: Harim Holding's exit offer for Pan Ocean has turned unconditional after the latter's shareholders approved its voluntary delisting from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: WHO chief says 2022 must be year 'we end the pandemic'
summary: WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus calls for the world to end the Covid-19 pandemic by 2022, citing the rapid spread of the Omicron variant. Cases are surging globally, with Omicron identified in dozens of countries and higher transmissibility and vaccine resistance concerns. To end the pandemic, Tedros emphasizes the need to use all available tools, including vaccines, mask-wearing, and physical distancing, and to address the glaring inequity in access to vaccines.

site_title: Germany names a career banker to head the Bundesbank
summary: Germany's new government has appointed Joachim Nagel, a 55-year-old career central banker, as the head of the Bundesbank, the eurozone's largest central bank. Nagel, who spent 17 years at the Bundesbank, is expected to maintain Germany's traditionally tough stance on inflation and emphasis on market discipline. His appointment comes at a time of growing concern over inflation, with the European Central Bank leaving interest rates untouched last week. Nagel will succeed Jens Weidmann, a former conservative voice on the ECB board, and join Isabel Schnabel as one of two Germans on the governing council.

site_title: Analysis: Malaysia's labour abuse allegations a risk to export growth model
summary: Malaysia's reliance on migrant labour to fuel its export-reliant growth model is under threat due to mounting allegations of workplace abuse. Experts warn that the government and companies must address these allegations to avoid risks to the economy. Migrant workers, mainly from Indonesia, Bangladesh, and Nepal, have complained of abusive working and living conditions. The country's economy, which relies heavily on manufacturing and agriculture, could be impacted if the allegations are not addressed, potentially threatening its growth model.

site_title: World Economic Forum defers Davos meeting amid pandemic
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has postponed its annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, initially scheduled for January, due to ongoing uncertainty over the Omicron pandemic. The event will now take place in mid-2022, with organizers citing the transmissibility of Omicron and its impact on travel and mobility as the reason for the deferral. The cancellation affects world leaders and corporations planning to attend, and the WEF will instead organize online "State of the World" sessions.

site_title: Biden raises car petrol mileage standards to fight climate change
summary: President Joe Biden has raised car petrol mileage standards to limit emissions, reversing Trump-era regulations. The new standards, set by the Environmental Protection Agency, will require a 23.4 km per litre average fleetwide fuel consumption by 2026, saving Americans $210-$420 billion on fuel costs by 2050. Industry groups have expressed concerns that meeting the new standards will be challenging without government support. The move comes as Biden's Build Back Better social spending plan appears to be in jeopardy due to Democratic Senator Joe Manchin's decision not to support it.

site_title: Oil prices plunge as Omicron's rapid spread dims fuel demand outlook
summary: Oil prices plummeted 2.7% to $71.52 a barrel for Brent crude and 3.7% to $68.23 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate as the rapid spread of the Omicron coronavirus variant raised concerns about potential lockdowns and reduced fuel demand. Despite a Moderna vaccine booster dose showing protective effects against Omicron, the market reacted to investor worries. Oil rig counts in the US rose for a second week, but Opec+ compliance with production cuts fell short of targets.

site_title: Omicron now dominant Covid-19 strain in US: health authorities
summary: The Omicron variant has become the dominant Covid-19 strain in the US, accounting for 73.2% of new cases over the past week, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Omicron already constitutes over 90% of new cases in the Pacific Northwest and parts of the US South and Midwest. Top advisor Anthony Fauci warns of a bleak winter ahead, while US President Joe Biden is set to discuss the issue in a speech. Early data suggests Omicron may be more infectious and resistant to vaccines, but it is not more severe than the Delta variant.

site_title: US banks tighten Covid-19 precautions as Omicron variant spreads
summary: US banks are tightening COVID-19 precautions amid the rapid spread of the Omicron variant. Major banks, including Bank of America, are adjusting plans to encourage employees back to the office, with some choosing not to host holiday parties and others recommending booster shots. The Omicron variant's spread has raised concerns, prompting banks to reevaluate their pandemic-related rules and protocols.

site_title: Rise of Omicron dashes New York's Christmas cheer as Covid-19 surges
summary: Covid-19 cases surged in New York City and the US, driven by the Omicron variant, which is doubling in cases every 1.5 to 3 days with community transmission. This has dashed hopes for a normal holiday season, prompting public health officials to fear an explosion of infections after Christmas and New Year's gatherings. The World Health Organization warned of the rapid spread, highlighting the strain on testing infrastructure ahead of holiday travel and gatherings.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower after ugly session
summary: US stocks ended lower on Monday, closing above session lows but still in the red, amid rising worries over the latest Covid-19 strain and President Biden's spending plans facing opposition. Major indices were down the entire day, with investors reacting unfavorably to unfavorable news. The market's performance was described as "ugly" by Oanda's Edward Moya, with stocks finishing the day decisively in the red.

site_title: Explainer: Why Trump's US$1b capital raise was so popular
summary: Former US President Donald Trump's new venture has secured the second-largest private placement with convertible stock for a merger with a blank-cheque acquisition firm, worth US$1 billion. The deal's favourable terms, including the ability to sell shares immediately after the merger and a 40% discount to the average traded price, have made it popular among investors, including hedge funds and family offices. However, some investors have expressed concerns about publicly associating with Trump due to his social media ban. The merger's outcome is uncertain, with some investors potentially triggering a "death spiral" by selling shares and buying more.

site_title: Boris Johnson beleaguered after worst week of premiership
summary: Boris Johnson's premiership is facing its worst week after a by-election loss in North Shropshire and Brexit minister David Frost's resignation, citing concerns over lockdown measures and the UK's economic direction. Johnson's chaotic handling of the pandemic and his "big picture" approach to governance have weakened his ability to govern, with predictions of a leadership challenge in 2022. The UK's rising COVID-19 cases and hospital admissions threaten further restrictions, which could damage Johnson's authority. The Conservative Party is increasingly divided, and Labour has temporarily overtaken the Tories in polls, raising concerns about Johnson's long-term prospects.

site_title: Nadal tests positive for Covid-19 in latest blow for tennis legend
summary: Spanish tennis star Rafael Nadal tested positive for Covid-19, casting doubt on his Australian Open participation. The 35-year-old had been set to make his comeback after months of injury but will now have to assess his options. Nadal had been in Abu Dhabi for an exhibition tournament, where he lost to Andy Murray and Denis Shapovalov. He had been practising hard in Mallorca and had a new coaching staff member, but his Covid-19 diagnosis may impact his plans for the Australian Open, which begins on January 17.

images.alt_text: Spanish tennis star Rafael Nadal said on Monday he had tested positive for Covid-19, putting in doubt his participation in the Australian Open next month where was expected to make his comeback to major competition after months of injury.

site_title: Nike earnings rise despite lower sales in China
summary: Nike reported a 7% increase in net income to $1.3 billion despite lower sales in China due to supply chain woes and Covid-19 restrictions. Higher sales in North America and Europe, boosted by stronger pricing and inventory already in transit, offset the decline. Revenue rose 1% to $11.3 billion. Shares rose 3.5% in after-hours trading.

images.alt_text: Nike reported increased quarterly profits on higher sales in North America on Monday even as supply chain woes in Asia dented results in China and other markets.

site_title: Rising cases, Omicron highlight holes in Biden's strategy: experts
summary: US President Joe Biden is facing criticism from health experts for his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly with the recent surge in cases and deaths ahead of the Christmas and New Year holidays. Experts say Biden's strategy lacks urgency, testing, and global vaccine sharing, and that he needs to push mask-wearing, increase testing availability, and secure more funding. Despite a 65.2% vaccination rate, only 30% of the population has an additional booster shot, and the administration's efforts to combat the pandemic have been hindered by Republican opposition and misinformation.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop as Omicron worries intensify
summary: European stocks dropped 1.4% on Monday, their worst session in three weeks, amid concerns over tighter pandemic curbs and the spread of the Omicron coronavirus strain. Oil companies, miners, and auto stocks led declines, while travel stocks fell 1% but recovered from intra-day lows. The FTSE 100 index dropped 1% due to weakness in commodity-linked shares and reduced liquidity in the last weeks of December. Analysts warn that the Omicron variant's spread and potential new restrictions could lead to prolonged market pressure.

site_title: UK says Covid-19 surge 'extremely difficult' as Omicron grips Europe
summary: The UK is considering tightening coronavirus curbs to slow the spread of the Omicron variant, with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson saying the situation is "extremely difficult" and hospitalizations are rising steeply in London. Other European nations, including the Netherlands and Germany, are also considering new measures, including lockdowns and restrictions on gatherings. The Omicron variant is multiplying rapidly across Europe and the US, causing concern about its impact on the global economy, with financial markets and stock indexes falling. The World Health Organization has warned that Omicron may be spreading faster than the Delta variant and could still overwhelm healthcare systems.

site_title: The legal gift that keeps on grifting
summary: Corporations are doling out millions in year-end gifts, with Royal Dutch Shell's move to London granting its shareholders a boost. However, the extra money comes from a new legal and regulatory environment, not improved corporate governance. Stronger shareholder protections in the UK may be the main factor, but tax laws also play a significant role. This "legal arbitrage" allows corporations to circumvent laws, prioritizing shareholder interests over environmental and social concerns. The practice undermines the integrity of the law and creates an uneven playing field, favoring polluters and wealthy shareholders.

site_title: Grab's asset-light model acquiring more of a physical flavour
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing and food delivery company, is expanding its asset-light model by acquiring Malaysian grocery chain Jaya Grocer Holdings, marking a shift towards owning physical assets. The acquisition aims to support Grab's growing GrabMart offering, which includes a delivery-only supermarket and grocery services. While Grab's current model has been successful, owning physical assets may offer advantages in managing inventory and logistics for perishable groceries. This move could be a necessary step for Grab as it grows into a publicly listed multinational company.

site_title: 2022 will be a high-wire act for Asian businesses
summary: Asian businesses face significant challenges in 2022 due to the confluence of climate concerns, geopolitical tensions, and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The COP26 summit has sparked a growing sense of urgency among governments and businesses to address climate change, with investors increasingly leaving polluting assets in Asia. The US-China rivalry is expected to escalate, posing reputational risks for companies operating in the region. Governments in Asia are also becoming more directly involved in the management of their economies, leading to a more complex operating environment. Companies must develop long-term ESG strategies to stay ahead of these challenges.

site_title: Airlines amp up warnings on 5G service, see risk of late flights
summary: Airlines and aviation officials are warning of widespread flight delays and cancellations due to the rollout of 5G wireless service in early January, which may interfere with equipment on planes tracking altitude. The aviation industry claims the new signals pose a safety risk, especially during low-visibility landings, while mobile providers dispute this, saying the signals are safe and separated from altimeter frequencies. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is expected to impose restrictions, potentially costing the industry up to $2.1 billion in disruptions, with some estimates suggesting 70% of airliners may be affected.

site_title: Thai conglomerate Central Group snapping up more trophy assets on European shopping spree
summary: Thai conglomerate Central Group is reportedly in advanced talks to buy British retailer Selfridges for up to £4 billion (S$7.22 billion). This deal, if finalized, would mark the group's expansion into the European market, following previous acquisitions of iconic department stores in Denmark, Switzerland, and Germany. The purchase is seen as part of the group's strategy to become a global retail operator, driven by the saturated retail space in Thailand and the need for growth opportunities.

site_title: The big market questions for 2022
summary: Investors are facing several key market questions in 2022, including the outlook for inflation, stocks, and interest rates. Central banks have injected trillions into markets, but inflation has risen, prompting concerns about the Fed's asset purchases ending and interest rate hikes. Some predict inflation will peak in early 2022, while others expect it to persist. Goldman Sachs expects positive returns from global equity markets, while Pimco predicts European equities will be more challenged. Emerging markets are also expected to face challenges, particularly in China, where a zero-Covid policy may be tough to maintain.

site_title: Australia's hot housing market puts renters off having kids
summary: Australia's hot housing market is discouraging renters from having children, while encouraging mortgage holders to have kids, according to a study by the University of Sydney. The research found that a $100,000 increase in housing wealth boosts the probability of homeowners having a new child by 18%. Married couples who are mortgage holders are among the most likely to have kids, whereas renters face the opposite effect. This could have significant fiscal implications for policymakers, who are already grappling with an aging population and a fertility rate below the replacement rate.

site_title: Singtel down 1.3% on A$304m Australian tax case exposure
summary: Singtel's shares fell 1.3% on Monday after the telco flagged A$304 million in exposure, interest, and penalties from its recent Australian tax case loss. The dispute relates to the acquisition financing of Singtel Optus, with the Australian Taxation Office estimating a primary tax payable of A$268 million. Singtel will consider the details of the judgment and explore available options. Experts say the ruling suggests closer regulatory scrutiny for intra-company pricing of financing, while Citi lowered its target price on Singtel to S$3.56.

site_title: Forget making money in IPOs: They're Europe's biggest losers
summary: Europe's IPO market has been Europe's biggest losers this year, with half of the year's 10 biggest decliners in the Stoxx Europe 600 Index going public in the past 15 months. Companies such as THG, Auto1 Group, Allegro.eu, Deliveroo, and InPost have all slumped 39% or more, despite the benchmark index surging 19%. Investors have been drawn to high valuations and governance issues, leading to "extremely negative returns" if not selective. Despite this, fund managers will have opportunities to make up losses in 2022, with a strong appetite for high-quality listings.

site_title: Spider-Man rakes in stunning US$253m in largest opening of 2021
summary: Spider-Man: No Way Home earned the third-largest opening in US history, taking in an estimated $253 million over the weekend, the largest opening for any movie in 2021. This marks a potential billion-dollar-grossing film in the pandemic era, according to analysts.

site_title: Singapore households get 920,000 bottles of mouth gargle
summary: Singapore households received over 920,000 bottles of StayWell mouth gargle as part of a nationwide distribution by Temasek Foundation. The distribution took place from Nov 22 to mid-December, with 600 volunteers from institutions like Singapore Pools and the Ministry of Finance handing out the gargles to residents. The initiative aimed to slow down or prevent the spread of the virus in the new normal. Volunteers also helped seniors register digitally for collection slots, bridging the digital gap.

site_title: Pandemic renews focus on digitalisation in supply chain
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted global supply chains, leading to a severe shortage of containers and lengthy port delays. Companies are turning to digitalisation to ease supply stress, with industry experts emphasizing the need for innovation and technology to optimize supply chain efficiency. In Indonesia, garment manufacturers are leveraging digital tools to streamline processes, such as virtual rooms for buyers to view materials, and driverless trucks are being considered for the future. Strengthening global interdependency and investing in innovation are key to improving supply chain resilience.

site_title: Top US Senate Democrat vows vote on Biden's US$1.75t Bill
summary: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer announced plans for a vote on President Biden's $1.75 trillion policy bill and voting rights early in the new year. The bill faces opposition from Senator Joe Manchin, who stated he won't vote for the "Build Back Better" Bill, potentially blocking it. Schumer vowed to allow all Senate members to voice their positions on the bill. The votes will take place despite the roadblock, with Schumer seeking to give all members a chance to express their opinions on the Senate floor.

site_title: Oracle to buy Cerner for US$28.3b in bold move on health
summary: Oracle has agreed to acquire Cerner, a medical-records systems provider, for approximately $28.3 billion in an all-cash transaction. The deal, Oracle's largest-ever, is expected to be immediately accretive to earnings and contribute to earnings growth in the following years. Cerner's healthcare industry focus will bolster Oracle's cloud-computing and database businesses, which have struggled to gain ground in recent years. The acquisition is expected to close next year, with Oracle paying $95 per share, a 20% premium over Cerner's market value.

site_title: US home sales to rise 7.1% in 2021, fall next two years
summary: US home sales are expected to rise 7.1% in 2021, but decline 1.4% in 2022 and 3.8% in 2023 due to limited supply, higher mortgage rates, and prices. Fannie Mae attributes the decline to the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening and ongoing supply issues. A strong year-end surge in home buying is expected to drive the 2021 growth, with mortgage rates averaging 3.2% in 2022.

site_title: Finding balance between liberal internationalism and realpolitik
summary: US President Joe Biden's Democracy Summit, which excluded China and Russia, has raised questions about the US's "democracy standards" and its role in promoting democracy abroad. Critics argue that the summit's focus on ideological confrontation may be counterproductive, potentially demonizing geo-strategic rivals and forming an alliance against them. A balanced approach between liberal internationalism and realpolitik may be more effective in advancing US interests and promoting democratic principles. The US should consider strengthening its foundations at home and serving as a model to the rest of the world, rather than trying to lead a crusade for democracy.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In market news, European stocks declined with banks and healthcare sectors dragging, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow airport considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Regional markets tumble amid global rout, Omicron fears
summary: Regional markets plummeted on Monday, December 20, as Omicron fears and border tightening weighed on investors. Nearly all Asian indices fell, except for New Zealand, with major US indices also declining more than 1%. In Singapore, the STI dropped 1.3% to 1.2% lower, while banking stocks and Jardine-related counters were particularly affected. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.8% to 34,725.36, while Japan's Nikkei ended 2.1% lower. The Omicron variant's local transmission in Thailand is also sparking concerns about travel restrictions.

site_title: One click to debt: 'buy now, pay later' is fintech's flavour of the year
summary: BNPL, or "buy now, pay later," has become the flavour of the year in emerging markets, with companies like Grab and Traveloka offering interest-free instalments for online purchases. This trend is seeing increased scrutiny from regulators in South-east Asia. The convenience of BNPL has led to its widespread adoption, with many online retail platforms now incorporating the service. As the embedded finance industry continues to grow, BNPL is expected to play a significant role in its path to profitability. Regulators will closely monitor the industry's development to ensure consumer protection and fairness.

site_title: Should more Singapore property groups venture to the US?
summary: Singapore property groups may consider venturing into the US market as the country's residential development slows down due to property cooling measures. While some local groups, such as Mapletree Investments and CapitaLand Investment, are active in the US, they generally focus on logistics and commercial properties. The US market offers compelling yields, particularly in student housing and logistics sectors, but requires significant scale and resources to succeed. Smaller groups may prefer to focus on other overseas markets, while larger groups like Mapletree and CLI are expected to continue actively foraging in the US market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower on Omicron crackdown
summary: European stocks declined on Monday, mirroring global losses due to the Omicron variant. The FTSE 100 sank 1.9%, the CAC 40 lost 2.1%, and the DAX fell 2.4%. Economies are impacted as governments reimpose containment measures and consumers stay at home. Investors are cautious, withdrawing from risky investments, until the macroeconomic landscape stabilizes. Asian stocks and oil prices also dropped due to fears of a global surge in coronavirus infections and uncertainty over US President Biden's social spending bill.

site_title: European energy prices soar as a deep freeze arrives
summary: European energy prices surge as a deep freeze approaches, straining electricity grids amid low wind speeds and severe nuclear outages. Russia limits natural gas flows through a major transit route to Germany, boosting demand and sending prices to record highs. Energy prices have increased by 600% this year, with European gas surging 8.8% and German year-ahead power reaching a new record. The region's storage sites are at record-low levels, and traders expect liquefied natural gas to provide some relief, but it will take time.

site_title: Compulsory disclosure on board diversity allows champions to shine
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has mandated the disclosure of board diversity policies for Singapore-listed issuers, starting in 2022. This move aims to improve corporate governance and address gender imbalance on boards. The requirement, part of the listing rules, represents a significant step forward in mainstreaming board diversity. Companies must now comply with the mandatory policy disclosure, which includes gender diversity as a key factor. This change is expected to raise the profile of Singapore-listed issuers and promote better outcomes for companies. The move is seen as a positive development in corporate governance.

site_title: Aussie, pound struggle on Omicron, lockdown fears
summary: Global investors favored safe-haven currencies over risk-sensitive ones on Monday, December 20, amid concerns over Omicron variant lockdowns in Europe and the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance. The Australian dollar fell 0.5% to US$0.7091, while the British pound dropped 0.2% to US$1.3205. The US dollar index rose, and speculators increased their net long bets on the US dollar. The euro recovered 0.2% after tumbling 0.8% on Friday, while the Chinese yuan hit a 10-day low following a rate cut.

site_title: Ng Yu Zhi allegedly splashed over S$100m on supercars, watches, property; faces 6 more charges
summary: Singaporean businessman Ng Yu Zhi, 34, faces 75 charges related to a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam. He allegedly spent over S$100 million on luxury cars, jewelry, art, and property using funds from investors. New charges include transferring S$68.8 million to personal bank accounts and paying US$11 million for shares in Vickers Financial Group. High-profile investors, including Finian Tan and Thio Shen Yi, were among his victims. Ng remains on bail.

site_title: Japan Parliament approves record extra budget to secure post-pandemic growth
summary: Japan's Parliament approved a record US$317 billion extra budget to secure post-pandemic growth, with 36 trillion yen (S$434.1 billion) earmarked for Covid-19 measures, family support, and tourism promotion. The budget is the largest supplementary budget ever implemented, financed partly by additional government bonds. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida aims to restore the economy, boost growth, and fix public finances. The budget is part of a record 79 trillion yen economic package, which aims to boost GDP by 5.6% but private-sector economists say is too optimistic.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Omicron's spread stokes fears of tighter curbs
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones falling 143.32 points or 0.41% to 35,222.12, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropping. Concerns about tighter Covid-19 curbs and their impact on the global economy, as well as potential setbacks to President Biden's investment Bill, drove the decline. The declines follow a week of record highs in the US stock market.

site_title: 'Spider-Man' US$253m debut smashes pandemic-era record
summary: Spider-Man: No Way Home shattered pandemic-era records with a US$253 million opening weekend in the US and Canada, becoming the third-highest domestic opening weekend of all time. The film, starring Tom Holland, generated an additional US$334.2 million internationally and became the top-grossing film released domestically this year. Its success highlights the unmatched cultural impact of exclusive theatrical films, but the industry's recovery remains uneven, with the Omicron variant posing a new threat to cinemas.

site_title: Thailand extends investment incentives, eyeing US$15b in 2022
summary: Thailand has extended an investment incentive scheme for a year to bolster its economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, aiming for over $15 billion in investment pledges in 2022. The scheme includes tax exemptions for large-scale projects and was approved for a one-year extension by the Board of Investment. The move aims to support investment in high-tech industries, particularly in a special economic zone in the east of the country. This follows a significant increase in domestic and foreign investment applications this year, totaling around $24.4 billion.

site_title: Europe weighs Christmas curbs as Omicron sweeps continent
summary: European countries are considering curbs on Christmas gatherings amid the rapid spread of the Omicron coronavirus variant. The UK refused to rule out restrictions, while the Netherlands imposed a fourth lockdown. Other countries, including Germany, Ireland, and Italy, are also considering measures to control the spread of the virus. Omicron has been reported in at least 89 countries and has taken a toll on financial markets, with the US seeing a 50% increase in Covid cases since the start of the month.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down more than 2% over Omicron fears
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 2% on December 20, 2021, due to fears of the Omicron coronavirus variant's spread in Europe and the US. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 2.13% to 27,937.81, while the Topix index fell 2.17% to 1,941.33. Market concerns centered on the potential economic impact of the variant, with traders weighing the risks against the benefits of Omicron's relatively mild symptoms.

site_title: STI tumbles 1.2% with regional stocks on Monday amid Omicron fears
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% to 3,072.97 on Monday, tracking weak global markets amid Omicron fears. Regional markets also declined, with Japan, South Korea, and Hong Kong falling 1.8-2.1%. US Democrat Senator Joe Manchin's rejection of President Biden's spending plan contributed to the decline. Locally-listed glove and medical equipment makers were among the few bright spots, with Top Glove, Medtecs International, and UG Healthcare rising 1.4-6.3%.

site_title: Moderna says booster dose of its Covid-19 vaccine appears protective against Omicron
summary: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine appears protective against the Omicron variant, with a booster dose generating 37-fold increased neutralising antibodies against the variant. The current 100 microgram two-shot course is considered the "first line of defence" against Omicron, but the company plans to develop a vaccine targeting the variant. While a higher 100 microgram booster dose showed even higher antibody levels, the company does not plan to pursue approval for this dose. The data, not yet peer-reviewed, suggests the lower dose is "comfortably above" the risk threshold for breakthrough infections.

site_title: Taiwan Semiconductor gets approval for its new chip plant in Japan
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC) has received approval from Taiwan's investment commission to set up a US$7 billion chip plant in Japan, partnering with Sony Group. The technology used in the Japanese plant lags behind that used in Taiwan, sparking concerns of high-end technology outflow.

site_title: Global goods trade hits Covid bumps as risks tilt to downside
summary: Global merchandise trade declined 0.8% in the third quarter due to supply chain disruptions and rising Covid-19 cases, ending a 12-month expansion run. North American and European imports were weaker than expected, with exports from both regions declining. The Omicron variant has tipped the balance of risks towards the downside, with Europe's case count the highest. Despite this, trade volume is still up 11.9% year to date, and the WTO expects a 10.8% increase in 2021 if fourth-quarter data show a pickup in volume growth.

site_title: Carlos Marín, a member of Il Divo, dies at 53
summary: Carlos Marín, a 53-year-old Spanish singer and member of the multinational quartet Il Divo, has died in Manchester, England. Marín was admitted to the intensive care unit on December 8 and later intubated and placed in an induced coma. The cause of death was not specified by Il Divo. Marín was a key member of Il Divo, known for their pop opera sound and sold millions of albums. He released his first album at 8 years old and studied piano and singing in Madrid. Il Divo expressed their sadness and gratitude for Marín's contributions to music.

site_title: World Economic Forum defers Davos meeting amid pandemic
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has postponed its annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, initially scheduled for January 2022, due to the ongoing Omicron outbreak and travel restrictions. The meeting will now take place in "early summer" and will be held online, with "State of the World" sessions instead of the in-person meeting. The decision is the latest in a series of postponements and cancellations of high-profile events due to the pandemic.

site_title: Severe weather wrecks South-east Asia as 200 dead, ports shut
summary: Severe weather has caused widespread destruction in South-east Asia, particularly in Malaysia and the Philippines, resulting in 200 deaths and over 440,000 displaced people. Typhoon Rai, a super typhoon, brought torrential rainfall, flooding, and power outages, affecting major cities and ports. Operations at Port Klang, Southeast Asia's second-largest port, have been severely disrupted, with cargo delivery and vessel berthing delayed. The economic loss is estimated at US$86.5 billion annually due to disasters in the region, and international aid has been pledged to affected areas.

site_title: AXA Singapore CEO Jean Drouffe dies at age 47 of rare cancer
summary: AXA Singapore CEO Jean Drouffe, 47, died of a rare and aggressive form of cancer on December 17, after battling the disease for over a year. Drouffe, who joined AXA Group in 2000, held various senior management roles before becoming CEO in 2017. AXA Singapore's interim CEO, Mauricio Coarasa, will oversee the company's operations. Drouffe was remembered as a leader known for his kindness, positivity, and inspiring leadership, leaving a mark on the industry.

site_title: Wonking out: What would a hard landing look like?
summary: The Federal Reserve announced a shift in monetary policy to combat inflation, citing supply and demand imbalances related to the pandemic. However, this move is seen as a potential overcorrection, as inflation may not reach the same level as the 1980s. Historically, high inflation in the 1970s required a severe recession to bring it down, but recent inflation rates may be more manageable. The Fed's 2% inflation target may be too low, and a mild recession could be necessary to achieve it, raising questions about the cost of achieving low inflation.

site_title: Nanofilm appoints new chief commercial and strategy officer; says confident of growth outlook
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International has appointed Gian Yi Hsen as its new chief commercial and strategy officer, effective January 1, 2022. The company is confident of its growth outlook and is investing in plant and equipment qualification costs to meet increasing demand for its advanced materials and nanofabrication solutions. Production for its micro lens array project is progressing, and the company expects to contribute positively to its Nanofabrication Business Unit. Nanofilm also plans to accelerate its efforts to develop core technologies and new product offerings, with a focus on investing in cutting-edge technology ventures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.11 points to 1,493.90. Volume was 2.474 billion lots worth RM1.726 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 682 to 244.

site_title: BNP Paribas to sell Bank of the West to Canada's BMO for US$16b
summary: BNP Paribas is selling its US unit, Bank of the West, to Canada's BMO Financial Group for $16.3 billion. The sale will strengthen BMO's presence in the US and allow BNP Paribas to focus on Europe, where it is growing its investment banking business. The deal will give BNP Paribas more firepower for deals and buybacks, and the bank plans to use proceeds to fund these activities. Analysts welcome the sale, citing its value and strategic benefits for both parties.

site_title: Hong Kong eyes new security law after electing loyalist council
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam has announced plans to revive a controversial security law, which was shelved in 2003, after a pro-establishment council elected in a low turnout election. The new legislature, filled with Beijing loyalists, is expected to present new proposals by June on how to enact the security legislation. The move is seen as a significant shift, as the previous national security law, introduced in 2020, lacked language on treason, sedition, and theft of state secrets. Lam has stated that the constitutional responsibility of the SAR government is to pass the legislation, despite concerns from opposition members that it will further restrict democracy and civil society.

site_title: US economy to live with coronavirus without fed, fiscal props
summary: The US economy is expected to learn to live with the coronavirus without significant federal support in 2022, following the Federal Reserve's pivot towards tighter credit and the potential derailment of President Biden's $1.75 trillion spending plan. A policy-induced slowdown in the economy may help curb inflation, but leaves it vulnerable to shocks such as the Omicron variant. Economists warn that a failure to pass the spending plan could lead to a sharp slowdown in growth, potentially below 1.5% in the fourth quarter of 2022.

site_title: Chinese city takes back two plots of land from Evergrande
summary: China's city of Chengdu has taken back two plots of land from Evergrande, a cash-strapped property developer, totaling over 300,000 square meters. The move follows a similar action by the Haikou city authority in Hainan province. The Chinese government is scrutinizing Evergrande's assets, including those of its chairman Hui Ka Yan, amid the developer's struggles with over $300 billion in liabilities. Evergrande's shares fell 9.9% after missing a debt payment deadline, and the company has returned undeveloped lands worth $203.87 million to the government.

site_title: Oil prices slide as rapid Omicron spread dims fuel demand outlook
summary: Oil prices dropped over 3% on Monday due to concerns about new mobility restrictions to combat the spread of the Omicron coronavirus variant. Brent crude futures fell $2.42 to $71.10 a barrel and US WTI crude futures fell $2.79 to $68.07. The Netherlands went into lockdown, and US health officials urged Americans to get booster shots and wear masks ahead of the Christmas and New Year holidays. Despite this, US energy firms added oil and natural gas rigs for a second week in a row.

site_title: Elon Musk says he'll pay over US$11b in taxes this year
summary: Elon Musk announced he will pay over $11 billion in taxes this year, surpassing any American's record tax payment. Musk exercised 15 million options and sold shares to cover taxes, following a Twitter poll last month. He previously stated he expects a higher tax rate of 53% on stock options next year, after a report by ProPublica found he paid little income tax relative to his wealth. Musk's tax bill for 2021 could be over $10 billion if he exercises all options due to expire next year.

site_title: Global M&A activity smashes all-time records to top US$5t in 2021
summary: Global merger and acquisition (M&A) activity reached a record high of US$5 trillion in 2021, surpassing the previous record of US$4.42 trillion set in 2007. The US saw nearly double the deal volumes to US$2.61 trillion, while Europe and Asia Pacific also saw significant growth. Technology and healthcare led the way, driven by pent-up demand and strong corporate earnings. Private equity deals more than doubled to a record US$985.2 billion, and bankers expect a bumper bonus round in early 2022. Despite potential headwinds such as inflationary pressures and regulatory challenges, dealmaking activity is expected to remain robust.

site_title: How SAP uses 'social sabbaticals' to retain employees
summary: SAP's "social sabbatical" program, inspired by IBM, sends employees on immersive four-week challenges to solve real problems with nonprofit organizations in 51 countries, partnering with 500 organizations and impacting 6 million lives. Since its 2012 pilot, over 1,300 employees have participated, with significant impact on employee engagement and retention. The program is designed to provide a unique learning experience, injecting purpose and energy into work, and SAP advises other companies to set up similar programs, starting small and testing the waters.

site_title: UOB beefs up HNW team with new hire for South-east Asia
summary: UOB has hired Khoo Lin Wein as managing director and regional market head for South-east Asia, bolstering its private banking arm. He will expand the bank's high-net-worth client base and develop products to meet their needs. Khoo has 25 years of private banking experience, previously leading private banking for banks in Malaysia and Vietnam. This move is part of UOB's growth plans, aiming to double its wealth management fee income in 5 years, with current assets under management at S$137 billion.

site_title: India's used-car platform Cars24 valued at US$3.3b in new funding round
summary: India's used-car platform Cars24 has raised US$400 million in a funding round, valuing it at US$3.3 billion. Alpha Wave Global participated in the US$300 million equity infusion, while US$100 million in debt came from investors in India, Australia, and the UAE. The funds will be used to expand the company's presence in the Middle East, Australia, and South-east Asia. This follows rival Spinny's US$283 million funding round earlier this month and Droom Technology's initial public offering filing in November.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index shedding 1.93% due to concerns over the Omicron Covid variant and US President Joe Biden's economic agenda. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 1.07% and 1.77% respectively. The declines were attributed to Democratic senator Joe Manchin's refusal to support Biden's social spending bill, which has dealt a severe blow to the president's economic agenda.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post worst day in 3 weeks as Omicron fears trigger foreign sell-off
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 1.81% to their lowest close in three weeks, with tech heavyweights like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix falling 1.15% and 1.23% respectively. Foreign investors sold a record 552.3 billion won worth of shares, amid worries about the Omicron variant and tightening European curbs. The move follows the Federal Reserve's hint of interest rate hikes in March, and investors shifted towards safe havens. The won also fell 0.83% against the US dollar.

site_title: Toyota to halt production at 5 factories in January due to supply chain issues
summary: Toyota plans to halt production at five domestic factories in January due to supply chain issues, chip shortages, and the Covid-19 pandemic. This stoppage will affect approximately 20,000 vehicles, but it won't impact Toyota's annual target to manufacture nine million vehicles. The move follows a similar production reduction in North America, where Toyota expects to produce around 50,000 units in January.

site_title: StanChart fined £46.6m for misreporting liquidity position
summary: Standard Chartered has been fined £46.6 million by the Bank of England for misreporting its liquidity position between March 2018 and May 2019. The Prudential Regulation Authority found the bank made 5 errors reporting its dollar liquidity metric, which hindered the regulator's ability to monitor its position. The fine is the highest ever imposed by the PRA in a case where it was the sole enforcer. The bank's systems and controls fell below expected standards, according to the regulator.

images.alt_text: [LONDON] The Bank of England (BOE) said on Monday (Dec 20) it was fining Standard Chartered £46.6 million (S$84.2 million) for misreporting its liquidity position to the regulator and for failings in its controls.

site_title: Importance of credit reputation for SME business owners
summary: Singaporean business owners of Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) can benefit from having a good credit reputation when applying for loans. A credit report, maintained by Credit Bureau Singapore (CBS), assesses an individual's credit history, providing lenders with valuable information to evaluate creditworthiness. A good credit score can help lenders make informed decisions, while a poor credit score may lead to lower loan approval chances. To maintain a good credit score, borrowers should pay their bills on time, avoid multiple credit applications, and use credit monitoring services. Lenders review non-scored public records, account status history, and bureau scores to assess credit risk.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singtel faces A$304m Australian tax exposure, while OUE is set to acquire a 17.2% stake in an Indonesian tech investment company. Businessman Ng Yu Zhi faces 6 new charges related to a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam, totaling 75 charges. UOB expands its HNW team in South-east Asia, and Bosch's AquaEasy receives a S$1m convertible loan for aquaculture tie-ups. The STI fell 1.2% on Monday amid Omicron fears, closing at 3,072.97.

images.alt_text: The dispute relates to the acquisition financing of Singtel Optus, then known as Cable and Wireless Optus, in 2001.

site_title: After being crowned badminton's newest world champion, Loh Kean Yew can dream of Olympic glory next
summary: Singapore's Loh Kean Yew, 24, won the World Badminton Federation Championships, becoming the sport's newest world champion. The unseeded player trailed 9-3 in the first game but made a comeback to win in straight sets. Loh's victory drew parallels with the heroics of late Singapore shuttler Wong Peng Soon, who also executed the "clear" shot to win a crucial point. Loh's achievement marks a promising start to his Olympic ambitions, following his championship win.

site_title: Bosch's AquaEasy obtains S$1m convertible loan from Qian Hu in aquaculture tie-up
summary: Qian Hu, a MAINBOARD-listed fish service provider, has entered into a S$1 million unsecured convertible loan agreement with AquaEasy, a unit of the Bosch Group, in a strategic aquaculture tie-up. The 5-year agreement aims to enhance AquaEasy's AI and IoT solutions, increasing productivity and profitability. Qian Hu and AquaEasy have collaborated since 2020 on sustainable shrimp farming systems, and the CEO expects more strategic collaborations in new market areas such as research and development.

site_title: China cuts interest rates for first time in 20 months
summary: China's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate for the first time in nearly two years, lowering the loan prime rate to 3.8% from 3.85% in November. The move aims to boost economic growth amid a real estate crisis and coronavirus flare-ups. The reduction is expected to release 1.2 trillion yuan into the economy, with cheaper loans for new fixed-rate borrowers and a possible cut to the five-year LPR before long. Despite inflation concerns, the move is seen as a bid to support housing demand and kickstart growth in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Australia: Omicron, Magellan Financial drag shares lower
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.16% to 7,292.2, closing lower for the fourth session in five, due to concerns over oil demand and surging Omicron Covid-19 cases. Energy stocks dropped 3.4% and Magellan Financial Group plummeted 32.9% after losing a major client. The financial index also fell 0.8%, while miners rose 0.1%. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index finished 0.38% higher.

site_title: SenseTime reopens IPO, gets US$512m from cornerstone investors
summary: Chinese AI firm SenseTime Group reopened its IPO, securing US$512 million from 9 cornerstone investors, including state-backed funds and major Chinese companies.
