The IPO was delayed due to US sanctions over alleged human rights abuses. SenseTime will offer 1.5 billion shares at HK$3.85 to HK$3.99 apiece, aiming to raise up to US$767 million. Trading is expected to start on December 30, following a revised filing that excludes US investors.

site_title: Easing mortgage rules, new launches to boost Thai property sector: Maybank KE
summary: Thailand's property sector is expected to see significant growth in 2022, driven by favourable fiscal measures and new supply. The Bank of Thailand's easing of loan-to-value ratio (LTV) to 100% until December 2022 is expected to boost consumer and developer confidence. Analysts predict double-digit presales and earnings growth, with Land & Houses and Quality Houses emerging as top picks. New property projects planned for 2022 are expected to support the sector, despite concerns about oversupply.

site_title: Death of Chinese tycoon Xie Zhikun triggers selling in firms he controlled
summary: Chinese tycoon Xie Zhikun, founder of Zhongzhi Enterprise Group, died after suffering a heart attack in Beijing on December 18, triggering a sell-off in his firms. Shares of 9 listed companies plummeted, with Zhongjin Technology Services Group dropping 60% and Success Electronics Co losing 10%. Investors fear internal power struggles and management chaos, leading to a dumping of stocks. Xie's business empire, which includes mining, asset management, and financial services, faces challenges, with his net worth shrinking to $1.5 billion in 2019.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop on Omicron spike, Biden spending bill blow
summary: Asian stocks fell on Monday due to concerns over a fresh surge in coronavirus infections and the uncertain future of US President Joe Biden's social spending bill, which lost a crucial vote from a moderate Democrat. The Omicron variant forces governments to reimpose containment measures, while central banks start paring their financial support, leading to a decline in markets. The US Federal Reserve's announcement to speed up the taper of its bond-buying program and indicate interest rate hikes also contributed to the volatility.

site_title: Chinaoil Singapore appoints new head of crude trading after Zhang resigns: sources
summary: Chinaoil Singapore has appointed Li Henan as the new head of crude trading after Zhang Yufeng's resignation. Li will oversee the team that buys crude for PetroChina's Singapore refinery and trades Middle East, Russian, and Asia-Pacific crude grades. The move comes after Zhang's departure, which has made waves in Asia's crude markets, including a notable 2015 purchase. Chinaoil also plans to transfer senior trader Yue Zan from Beijing to its Singapore office. The reasons behind Zhang's resignation remain unclear.

site_title: Thailand reports first local Omicron case, eyes reinstating quarantine
summary: Thailand reported its first local case of Omicron, a Thai woman who contracted the virus from her fully vaccinated Colombian husband, and tested positive in late November. The health ministry is considering reinstating mandatory quarantine for foreign visitors due to concerns over the spread of Omicron. The proposal includes scrapping a quarantine waiver for vaccinated visitors and reverting to hotel quarantine and a "sandbox" program. This move aims to curb the spread of the variant, which has infected 63 people in Thailand so far.

site_title: Carro bags another US$15.6m in ongoing Series C round
summary: Carro, a US-based used car marketplace, has raised US$15.6 million in its ongoing Series C funding round, bringing the total funding to US$428.5 million. Celestial Sage International, Aldama Investments, and Simon James Moran invested in the round. This funding round follows a US$100 million investment by Temasek's Anderson Investments and other investors last month. Carro plans to go public on the Nasdaq stock exchange, pending growth rate. The Singapore-based unicorn operates in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand, and was founded in 2015.

site_title: Gold holds near 3-week high on Omicron jitters
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to near a 3-week high at $1,800.42 per ounce, driven by concerns over the rapidly spreading Omicron coronavirus variant. The metal's safe-haven appeal increased as European countries imposed tighter restrictions. US health officials urged Americans to get booster shots and be cautious over the winter holidays. The US Federal Reserve hinted at rate hikes and balance sheet reduction in 2022, supporting gold's price. Physical gold demand in India improved, while silver, platinum, and palladium also saw slight gains.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Monday's open; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% to 3,090.45 at Monday's open, following a downbeat Wall Street close on Friday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average tumbled 1.5%, while European stocks also declined due to Omicron variant concerns. Local banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS fell, while digital security company DiSa rose 25% after heavy trading. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over the Omicron variant and the Federal Reserve's stimulus withdrawal.

site_title: OUE to acquire 17.2% stake in Indonesian tech investment company for 1t rupiah
summary: PROPERTY developer OUE's wholly-owned subsidiary has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a 17.2% stake in Indonesian technology investment company Multipolar (MPC) for 1 trillion rupiah (S$95.6 million). OUE expects to fund the transaction from its available cash resources and completion is expected within 1 business day. The acquisition is expected to expand OUE's consumer division in Indonesia and provide opportunities for participation in the country's rapidly growing digital economy.

site_title: China's Kaisa says it has not repaid US$400m bond
summary: China's Kaisa Group, a property developer, claims it has not repaid a US$400 million bond, amid a liquidity crunch in China's property sector. The company faces financial difficulties, and this development is the latest in a series of challenges for the sector. Kaisa's non-payment of the bond is a significant concern, and its future is uncertain. This move may impact global financial markets and highlight the struggles of China's property industry.

site_title: Dutch prosecutors to demand sentences for MH17 suspects
summary: Dutch prosecutors will demand life imprisonment for four suspects, including Russian nationals Igor Girkin, Sergei Dubinsky, Oleg Pulatov, and Ukrainian citizen Leonid Kharchenko, for their alleged roles in the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in 2014. The trial, which began in March 2020, will formally present the indictment during three days of hearings starting this week. The suspects, who are in absentia, have refused to attend the trial. A verdict is expected in late 2022, with prosecutors vowing to ensure the sentence is enforced.

site_title: Record low 30% turnout in Hong Kong poll: official
summary: Hong Kong registered a record low 30% voter turnout in the first legislature poll under new China-imposed rules, with only 1,350,680 of 4,472,863 registered voters casting ballots. This is the lowest turnout in three decades.

site_title: Sydney shrugs off Covid-19 spike, resists calls to restore tough curbs
summary: Sydney has resisted calls to restore tough COVID-19 curbs, despite a spike in new infections. New South Wales reported 2,501 cases, with hospitalization rates lower than the peak of the Delta wave. Premier Dominic Perrottet urged a "move away from fear" and towards hope and confidence, citing high vaccination rates over 90% among those 16 and older. Australia's vaccination levels and lower hospitalization rates compared to other nations are expected to limit the spread of the Omicron variant.

images.alt_text: Australian authorities urged a "move away from fear" of the coronavirus on Monday, resisting calls to make masks mandatory indoors and limit the numbers of patrons at Sydney venues, even as new Covid-19 infections lingered near records.

site_title: Apple seeks dismissal of India apps market antitrust case, cites tiny market share
summary: Apple has asked India's antitrust watchdog to dismiss a case alleging abuse of market power in the apps market, citing its tiny market share in the country. Apple claims its market share in India is "insignificant" at 0-5%, while Google dominates with 90-100%. Apple denies forcing app developers to use its proprietary system and says its in-app commissions are "not unfair or excessive". The Competition Commission of India will review Apple's response and may order a wider investigation or dismiss the case.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam to visit Beijing on Dec 20-23
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam will visit Beijing from December 20-23 to brief Chinese leaders on Hong Kong's economic, social, and political situation. The visit comes after pro-Beijing candidates won a record-low turnout in the "patriots"-only legislative election. The election was held amid a Beijing crackdown on dissent in the global financial hub.

site_title: British finance minister resists new Covid-19 restrictions before Christmas
summary: British Finance Minister Rishi Sunak is resisting new Covid-19 restrictions before Christmas, citing uncertainty over the Omicron variant's impact. Despite the UK government's chief scientific adviser advising on immediate action to prevent NHS overloads, about one-third of cabinet members question the accuracy of the study. Sunak wants to wait for clearer information and believes people are self-policing and getting booster shots, prompting concerns about the spread of the variant.

site_title: 5 Questions with Philips: The trends shaping the future of healthcare
summary: Philips, a global health technology company, shares its views on the latest trends in the healthcare industry, shaped by the COVID-19 pandemic. Key trends include a shift from hospital to home and community care, increased adoption of telehealth, and the use of artificial intelligence to improve efficiency. The company predicts a focus on 'health care' rather than 'sick care,' with a focus on preventive care and healthy lifestyles. Philips envisions 'smart hospitals' that utilize technology to bridge gaps between care settings and homes, with telehealth, predictive analytics, and virtual wellness checks. Sustainability is also a priority, with 49% of APAC healthcare leaders expecting to prioritize sustainability practices.

site_title: Japanese space tourists return to Earth after 12 days on ISS
summary: Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa and his assistant Yozo Hirano returned to Earth after a 12-day stay on the International Space Station, parachuting into Kazakhstan's steppe. This marked Russia's return to space tourism after a decade-long pause. Maezawa's journey, which included mundane tasks like brushing teeth and using the bathroom, was a test of space tourism capabilities. The successful mission paves the way for Russia's re-entry into the space tourism market, following the rise of US-based competitors.

site_title: Hot stock: Singtel down 1.7% on A$304m Australian tax case exposure
summary: Singtel shares fell 1.7% to a 3.5-month low after the telco revealed A$304 million exposure to Australian tax penalties from a recent tax case loss. The exposure includes interest and penalties, affecting Singtel's financial performance. This marks the sixth most traded stock by volume, with 9.9 million shares changing hands by 10:17 am.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.68% or 194.08 points at 28,351.60, and the Topix index down 0.79% or 15.64 points at 1,968.83. The declines follow falls on Wall Street amid concerns over virus fears and the Fed's withdrawal of pandemic stimulus. Investors remain cautious, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Iris Capital launches Malaysia's first venture debt fund
summary: Iris Capital Partners has launched Malaysia's first venture debt fund, Iris Fund, with RM160 million (S$51.53 million) to finance high-impact startups in Malaysia and South-east Asia. The fund will be co-managed by Hanwha Asset Management and backed by Penjana Kapital, institutional investors, and high net worth investors. Its first investment is Growthwell Group, an alternative meat and seafood provider. The fund aims to provide non-dilutive financing to propel Malaysian startups and aid the country's economic growth.

site_title: Regional markets tumble amid global rout, Omicron fears
summary: Regional markets fell on Monday, Dec 20, amid Omicron fears and border tightening, with nearly all Asia indices losing ground except New Zealand. US futures declined 1.6% as US Senator Joe Manchin expressed opposition to President Biden's $1.75 trillion domestic investment bill. The S&P 500, Nasdaq, and Dow Jones futures each fell 1.6% by Dec 20.

images.alt_text: The STI dropped to a low of 3,078.07 as at 10.48 am, down 1.1 per cent or 33.56 points.

site_title: Fauci warns of bleak winter with Omicron 'raging through the world'
summary: US pandemic advisor Anthony Fauci warns of a bleak winter ahead due to the rapidly spreading Omicron variant, which is identified in dozens of countries and shows resistance to vaccines and higher transmissibility. Despite not being more severe than the Delta variant, Omicron poses a significant threat to hospital capacity, particularly in areas with low vaccination rates. Fauci urges unvaccinated Americans to get a shot and vaccinated individuals to get boosters to re-up protection. With over 50 million eligible people remaining unprotected, the administration is campaigning hard for vaccination.

site_title: Singtel flags A$304m of exposure, interest and penalties from Australian tax case loss
summary: Singtel has estimated a net tax exposure of A$304m (S$295.9m) following the Federal Court of Australia's dismissal of its appeal against a tax assessment by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). The dispute involves the acquisition financing of Singtel Optus in 2001, with the ATO estimating a primary tax payable of A$268m. The company has disclosed the exposures as contingent liabilities in its audited financial statements and will consider next steps, including provisions in the accounts.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, OUE, Keppel DC Reit, SPH Reit, Frasers Hospitality Trust
summary: Several Singaporean companies have announced new developments that may impact trading on Monday, Dec 20. Singtel expects to book a net tax exposure of A$304 million (S$295.9 million) after losing its appeal of a tax assessment related to an acquisition financing in 2001. OUE LJ3 has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a 17.2% stake in an Indonesian technology investment company for S$95.6 million. Keppel DC Reit issued 613,155 units to its manager for development management fees. Meanwhile, SPH Reit is taking out a S$50 million incremental facility loan to refinance existing loans, while Frasers Hospitality Trust has entered into a facility agreement with OCBC for a S$70 million revolving credit facility.

site_title: Australia: Banking, energy stocks drag shares lower
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.4% on Monday, led by losses in financial and energy stocks due to concerns over the Omicron variant. Energy stocks fell as oil prices dropped, while financials declined 1% due to losses in the "Big Four" banks. Magellan Financial Group plummeted 30% after losing a major investment mandate. Technology and healthcare stocks were the only bright spots, gaining 0.8% and 1.4%, respectively.

site_title: Big-ticket items go unsold in auction of Maradona assets
summary: A virtual auction of Diego Maradona's assets failed to attract big bidders, with over $1.4 million in assets remaining unbid. The sale, which drew over 1,500 potential bidders, totaled $26,000, with the highest-priced item selling for $2,150. The auction, ordered by a judge to pay Maradona's debts, included items such as a seaside apartment, BMWs, and a house in Buenos Aires, but none sold for significant amounts. The court will now decide what to do with the unsold items.

site_title: Richard Rogers, shaper of city skylines, dies aged 88
summary: British architect Richard Rogers, known for designing iconic buildings such as London's "Cheesegrater" and the Pompidou arts center in Paris, has died at 88. A leading figure in the "High Tech" school of architecture, Rogers pioneered a modern style that showcased machines and technology. He won the prestigious Pritzker prize in 2007 and completed over 400 commissions worldwide, including the European Court of Human Rights and the Millennium Dome. Rogers' emphasis on functional elements and the space around buildings defined his approach to architecture.

site_title: Google's YouTube TV reaches deal to restore access to Disney channels
summary: YouTube has reached a deal with Walt Disney to distribute Disney-owned channels on its platform, two days after talks broke down, resulting in a blackout. The agreement was reached after YouTube warned that an extension would require "equitable terms" and offered to lower its YouTube TV price by $15. Details of the agreement were not disclosed, but access to channels like ESPN and FX has already been restored.

site_title: Biden electric vehicle push hits setback in US Senate
summary: US President Joe Biden's push to boost electric vehicle tax credits hit a roadblock as West Virginia's Joe Manchin expressed opposition to a $1.75 trillion domestic investment bill. The bill aimed to increase the EV tax credit to up to $12,500 for union-made US vehicles and create a credit of up to $4,000 for used vehicles. Manchin's opposition appears to deal a fatal blow to President Biden's Build Back Better bill, which also targets climate change and expanding the social safety net.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi awaits verdict on illegally importing walkie-talkies
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi awaits a verdict in her trial for allegedly importing walkie-talkies without a license. If found guilty, she could face up to three years in prison. Suu Kyi has been detained since the 2021 coup, with over 1,300 people killed and 10,000 arrested in nationwide protests. Her trial is the latest in a series of judgments in a junta court that has also charged her with corruption and violating the official secrets act, punishable by up to 15 years in jail.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi is expected to hear the verdict in her trial for on Monday, the latest in a catalogue of judgements in a junta court that could see her jailed for decades.

site_title: Thailand, minus tourist hordes, gets by on exports, stimuli
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow at a rate of 2.8-3.7% in 2022, largely due to exports and government stimulus packages, as the country struggles to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. Tourism, a key sector, is expected to take longer to recover, with forecasts suggesting it will return to pre-pandemic levels in 2024. The government has allocated 1.5 trillion baht in stimulus packages since the start of the pandemic, and officials expect the country's sound fiscal standing to help manage financing and credit risks.

site_title: Laos opens new rail link with China built on a mountain of Chinese debt
summary: Laos has opened a $6 billion rail link with China, but analysts warn of a potential debt crisis due to unsustainable Chinese loans. The rail line connects Vientiane to Kunming, with plans for a high-speed network to Singapore via Thailand and Malaysia. Laos faces a debt burden of $13.3 billion, with 47% of its borrowings coming from China, and experts fear default could bind the country further to Beijing. The joint venture's debt and hidden debt risks pose significant challenges for Laos' economic development.

site_title: Wall Street's narrowing market breadth may be worrying signal for stocks
summary: The US stock market's narrowing market breadth is raising concerns among investors, with only 31% of Nasdaq stocks trading above their 200-day moving average. This is the lowest level in a year, despite the index's 18% year-to-date gain. The S&P 500, however, is still performing well, with 68% of its constituents above the moving average. Narrowing breadth can signal a period of rocky trading and weaker returns, but some analysts believe strong corporate earnings and market pricing in of a more hawkish Fed may limit declines.

site_title: Manchin delivers potential fatal blow to Biden's US$1.75t spending bill
summary: US Senator Joe Manchin, a moderate Democrat, has dealt a fatal blow to President Joe Biden's $1.75 trillion domestic investment bill, citing concerns about inflation. Manchin stated he cannot support the legislation, which aims to expand the social safety net and tackle climate change. The White House responded angrily, accusing Manchin of breaking his promise to find common ground. The bill's passage is crucial for Democrats' chances of maintaining control of Congress in next year's elections, and many Democrats feel it's essential to their party's future.

images.alt_text: US Senator Joe Manchin, a moderate Democrat who is key to President Joe Biden's hopes of passing a US$1.75 trillion domestic investment bill, said on Sunday (Dec 19) he would not support the package, drawing a sharp rebuke from the White House.

site_title: 2 mDR senior executives misappropriate S$2.08m
summary: Two senior executives at mDR Limited, a Singapore-based after-market service provider for consumer mobile products, have misappropriated approximately S$2.08 million in marketing incentive rebates, used for unauthorized sales of handsets and phone accessories. The executives, one of whom is an executive officer, were immediately suspended and are persons of interest. Preliminary internal investigations showed no direct impact on the company's net asset value or unaudited consolidated financial statements for the year ending Dec 31, 2021. The company has commissioned an internal audit to strengthen internal controls and procedures.

site_title: German government advisory panel urges fresh measures to fight Omicron
summary: Germany's government advisory panel urges immediate measures to combat the surge in the Omicron variant, warning of a risk to critical infrastructure such as hospitals and utilities. The panel advises "strong reductions in contacts" within the population to slow the spread, with cases projected to double within two to four days. Despite Health Minister Karl Lauterbach ruling out a lockdown before Christmas, the experts call for complete preparation to protect critical infrastructure and ensure adequate testing capacity and supply chains.

images.alt_text: Fresh measures are urgently needed in Germany to fight the surge in the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, a government advisory group said on Sunday.

site_title: US Treasury: New law only way to fully contain stablecoin risks
summary: The US Treasury's undersecretary for domestic finance, Nellie Liang, emphasized the need for Congress to pass legislation to regulate stablecoins, citing risks to investors and the financial system. Regulators will try to use existing authority, but Liang believes congressional action is necessary. A group of federal agencies has prepared to take steps on their own if legislation is not passed, but Liang considers this a "Plan B" and prefers congressional action. Stablecoins, pegged to assets like the US dollar, pose operational risks and could destabilize the system if not regulated.

site_title: Ringgit may continue to weaken through 2022, even as economy recovers: analysts
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is forecast to continue weakening against the US dollar in 2022, despite the economy's recovery, due to a hawkish US Federal Reserve. Analysts expect the ringgit to trade at an average of 4.20 per dollar, down from 4.15 this year. The Malaysian economy is expected to rebound in 2022, with a growth forecast of 5.5-6.5%, but the ringgit's depreciation will be mitigated by interest rate hikes from Bank Negara Malaysia.

site_title: Endowus makes donating easy this Christmas with Giving Machines
summary: Endowus, a Singapore-based digital wealth platform, has launched the Endowus Gives Back initiative, allowing individuals to donate S$5, S$10, or S$20 to 15 charities through physical or virtual "Giving Machines" around Singapore. The initiative aims to raise S$50,000, and to date, it has raised S$22,000. The machines dispense cards showing examples of tangible items that the donated amount will support, such as food, stationery, and rehabilitation sessions.

site_title: Climate funds a mixed bag, but asset managers step up pro-climate proxy voting in 2021
summary: A study by InfluenceMap found that most climate-themed and ESG funds are misaligned with the Paris Agreement goals, with 71% of broad ESG funds and 55% of climate-themed funds failing to meet the criteria. However, a separate study by Ceres reported a "dramatic increase" in proxy voting in favor of climate proposals by the world's largest asset managers, with the two largest asset managers, BlackRock and Vanguard, boosting their support for climate proposals by 31% and 37% respectively. Despite this, the majority of funds still fail to meet the Paris Agreement goals, and regulation is needed to enforce standards and penalize greenwashing.

site_title: Canada keeps mortgage stress test benchmark unchanged despite hot housing market
summary: Canada's Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions (OSFI) left the benchmark for uninsured mortgage stress tests unchanged at 5.25% despite a hot housing market, with house prices up 20% from last year. The benchmark applies to borrowers making a 20% down payment. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland acknowledged rising housing prices as a concern, but OSFI officials said residential mortgage credit risk has risen only modestly. The minimum qualifying rate for insured mortgages remains unchanged, and experts say it may remain stable unless inflation significantly increases interest rates.

site_title: In world of sports, the rules are there for a reason
summary: F1's 2021 season finale was marred by controversy when race director Michael Masi introduced a last-minute rule change, allowing Max Verstappen to overtake Lewis Hamilton and secure the championship. The decision, made in the final lap, was widely criticized for its potential to influence the outcome and disregard for established sporting protocol. The incident has raised questions about the role of the race director and the importance of adhering to established rules in sports.

images.alt_text: Max Verstappen (centre) came in first place with Lewis Hamilton (left) in second, after F1 race director Michael Masi introduced a concocted ruling in the middle of the race.

site_title: The "right" ESG strategy to innovate and grow
summary: In Singapore, many enterprises are prioritizing sustainable development and ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) strategies to stay competitive. However, a KPMG survey found that 52% of CEOs are only willing to invest up to 5% of revenue in sustainability-related programs, and many struggle to tell a compelling ESG story. Companies that wait and see for ESG may arrive late in the game, as the pace of renewable energy adoption and green innovations is slow. To succeed, business leaders should focus on creating long-term ESG strategies, engaging employees, and tracking progress with key metrics.

site_title: China's love for new mutual funds cools after tough year
summary: China's demand for new mutual funds is cooling after a tumultuous year, with fundraising expected to be the slowest in two years. Despite matching 2020's record of 2 trillion yuan (S$429 billion) in equity fund-raising, interest has waned due to China's economic recovery losing steam and a crackdown on private enterprise. Savers are also deterred by muted returns, with many holding just 2% of their assets in stocks and equity funds. Fundraising is expected to slow further in 2022 as investors become more cautious.

site_title: TDCX expands client range in gaming, crypto; eyes acquisitions
summary: Singapore-based TDCX, a New York-listed company, is expanding its client base in gaming, crypto, and other sectors. The company has added 16 new brands as clients in the first three quarters of 2021, bringing its total number of clients to 48. TDCX provides mission-critical services such as multi-lingual customer support, content moderation, and AI tools to its clients, including two major crypto exchanges. The company aims to diversify its business and acquire more clients, with a focus on global expansion and talent acquisition.

site_title: Embracing change to achieve success
summary: Singapore-based precision manufacturer Team-Metal has successfully adapted to changing market demands over its 33-year history. Initially starting as a middleman, the company transitioned to high-volume manufacturing of tape drives and office equipment before diversifying into high-mix, low-volume production for life sciences and medical industries. This shift required significant changes in methods and mindsets, but has paid off, with the company experiencing stable demand and revenue growth. Team-Metal continues to evolve, investing in digital marketing, Internet of Things implementation, and exploring new regions for expansion.

site_title: US dollar jumps as Omicron spreads amid rate-hike talk
summary: The US dollar rose 0.7% on Friday amid concerns over Omicron's spread and potential interest rate hikes by central bankers. The euro and British pound fell 0.8% and 0.6%, respectively, while commodity-linked currencies declined due to falling crude oil prices. A new study showed the Omicron variant has a risk of reinfection over 5 times higher than the Delta variant. Federal Reserve governor Chris Waller stated an interest rate increase may be warranted "shortly after" the Fed ends its bond purchases in March.

site_title: Turkish finance minister briefs banking sector on new economic model
summary: Turkish Finance Minister Nureddin Nebati briefed the country's banking association on the government's new low-rates economic model, amid the lira currency's record lows. The goal is to promote "healthy, consistent growth" while meeting financial needs of households and the real economy. Despite criticism from economists and opposition lawmakers, the government aims to boost credit, exports, and growth ahead of 2023 elections. The move comes as the lira has lost 55% of its value against the US dollar this year, prompting calls for a return to "rules of economic science".

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Women better at investing than men but fewer do (Ep 109)
summary: Women investors outperform their male counterparts, but fewer women invest, according to a conversation between correspondent Howie Lim and Tanya Rolfe, co-founder of Sophia. Women fear investing due to a lack of financial education, with 70% of women saying they would invest if they felt more financially literate. To close the gap, female founders and investors suggest providing women-centric education and increasing financial literacy. Despite better investment performance, women remain underrepresented in the market, with only 12% of investors identifying as female.

site_title: Mlion's international growth fuelled by steely determination
summary: Mlion Corporation, a steel solutions supplier, has achieved a record-breaking year with revenue surpassing $100 million for the first time, a 56% increase from 2020. The company's international growth is fueled by its ability to provide customized solutions for clients in second-tier cities, which offer more fertile ground for expansion. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, Mlion prioritized customer satisfaction, allowing customers to cancel or delay orders, and instead focused on digitization and innovation, including the launch of new platforms and technologies, such as "GoListid" and "GoTagID". The company aims to grow revenue by 3 times in 5 years, reaching $200 million.

site_title: China's property distress sours steel sector in warning sign for economy
summary: China's property distress has negatively impacted the steel sector, with steel prices decreasing from record highs due to reduced demand from construction activities. This shift has significant repercussions for China's economy, affecting industries such as cement, glass, and household appliances. The spreading balance-sheet crisis at real estate firms serves as a warning for policymakers, highlighting the need for economic stability and support.

site_title: Adaptation and innovation key to staying ahead for Oilfield
summary: Oilfield Services & Supplies Pte Ltd, a 22-year-old manufacturer of drilling tools and components, won the Enterprise Transformation award for adapting to digitalization and staying resilient to disruptions. The company invested in software to enhance efficiency, automated manual processes, and implemented autonomous solutions. This helped address a manpower shortage and enabled the company to manage uncertainty and volatility in the oil and gas market. With a strong overseas market presence, Oilfield Services plans to expand using asset-light models and consolidate businesses, aiming to establish more manufacturing hubs in Singapore and become a true multinational corporation.

site_title: Longer stays to drive longer-term growth for Pan Pacific's regional strategy
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group, a regional hotelier, plans to focus on longer-term growth in Southeast Asia, particularly in Singapore, as travel and tourism recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. CEO Choe Peng Sum expects serviced suites and managed properties to drive the regional strategy, with upcoming projects in cities like Jakarta, Phnom Penh, and Siem Reap. The company aims to capitalize on the growth of business travelers in industries such as energy and commodities, and sees opportunities in emerging markets with flexible policies on longer-stay guests.

site_title: Utracon makes effort to reduce carbon emissions
summary: Utracon Overseas, a construction company, has received a Sustainability Special Mention for its efforts to reduce carbon emissions. The company's director, Khoo Jyh Hao, aims to create more awareness and inspire others to adopt greener practices. Utracon Overseas uses prestressed tendons to reduce the quantity of concrete needed in its projects, resulting in a 35% reduction in carbon embodied in its materials. Despite facing financial crises and the COVID-19 pandemic, the company has successfully expanded its reach internationally and grown its employee base.

images.alt_text: Outside of work, Khoo Jyh Hao actively engages his children in recycling work, such as sorting plastics and papers and consumes a vegetarian diet in order to minimise carbon emission on a personal level.

site_title: Rising interest rates and their impact on mortgages in an open economy like Singapore
summary: Interest rates in Singapore are expected to rise due to the US Federal Reserve's decision to double its bond purchase scaling, with 3 interest rate hikes forecasted by the end of next year. This will impact mortgages, with fixed rates potentially rising by 30 basis points and floating-rate packages pegged to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) expected to increase more significantly. Experts advise locking down fixed rates before the gap widens, with some exceptions for those selling properties or expecting additional liquidity.

site_title: China's big tech money seen in US$2b worth of South-east Asian deals
summary: China's tech giants Alibaba, Ant Group, and Tencent invested over $2 billion in South-east Asian startups this year, participating in over 10 regional fundraises. Tencent made at least six investments across various sectors, including fintech, e-commerce, and analytics. This influx of Chinese capital highlights the region's growing importance in the tech industry, despite the companies facing pressure at home. The investments also underscore the intensifying AI race in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong 'patriots only' polls see muted turnout
summary: Hong Kong's "patriots only" polls saw a muted turnout of about 29% of the electorate, with 1.3 million people casting their votes out of 4.5 million eligible voters. The new rules drastically reduce the number of directly elected seats, with 20 of 90 legislature seats being directly elected, while the remaining seats are picked by pro-Beijing committees. Critics argue that the system strips Hong Kongers of their right to vote, with many opposition figures boycotting the election, while the government touted the system as an improvement.

site_title: German DAX gets support at 14,000
summary: The German DAX index has seen significant support at 14,000, following a strong bull run since its sell-off in February 2021. The index rebounded from the 8,726 region in just two weeks and performed relatively well in the first half of 2021. However, it was affected by rising infection rates, GDP growth, and inflationary pressure. The negative interest rate in the eurozone and Brexit also impacted the market. Despite these challenges, the DAX remains stable, with investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: Ensuring well-being of staff crucial to continuous success
summary: Reachfield Security & Safety Management, this year's Enterprise 50 winner, has built a strong reputation as a good employer. Founded by Alvin Lee in 2002, the company aimed to fill the gap in the security industry after the 9/11 attacks. Lee's experience as a property manager helped him understand the need for well-trained security staff, and he prioritized treating them well. Today, Reachfield provides security services to over 200 buildings in Singapore, employing 1,200 staff. The company prioritizes staff well-being, offering competitive pay, training, and a supportive work environment.

site_title: Transforming to adapt to an uncertain business environment
summary: Three companies, Elmich, Ademco Security Group, and Omni-Plus Systems, have successfully transformed to adapt to an uncertain business environment. Elmich, a landscape and urban greenery products manufacturer, expanded globally and implemented an enterprise resource planning system, increasing efficiency and reducing paperwork. Ademco Security Group shifted to a managed service model, optimizing manpower, saving costs, and decreasing carbon footprint. Omni-Plus Systems expanded operations, established a knowledge hub, and trained employees to upskill, enabling the company to grow faster despite a manpower shortage. The companies attribute their success to constant improvement, clear leadership, and government assistance, highlighting the importance of enterprise transformation in uncertain times.

site_title: Providing security and stability
summary: APRO-Asian Protection, a family-owned security agency, prioritizes providing security and stability to its clients and employees. Founded in 1985, the company has evolved into a progressive employer with a 20-30% premium over the minimum prescribed wages. APRO attributes its success to its business ethic, which focuses on employee satisfaction and retention, resulting in an average tenure of four to five years for security officers and 15 years for middle management team members. The company has grown rapidly, with an annual revenue of approximately S$80 million, and targets a 5-8% operating profit margin.

site_title: Falling US corporate bond sales are one of debt's few positives
summary: US corporate bond sales are expected to decline by 5-10% in 2022, a positive trend for the high-grade market. Strong demand and reduced supply will help sustain valuations, keeping risk premiums low. Despite potential risks such as rising interest rates and the pandemic, strategists expect consistent inflows and supply down to hold spreads in a range-bound manner, with some predicting tighter spreads and others expecting a widening. Companies' strong balance sheets and low leverage will help them weather potential economic slowdowns.

site_title: An eye for opportunities
summary: AllAlloy Dynaweld has established a new subsidiary, AllAlloy Safety, focusing on safety tool and equipment manufacturing. The company aims to improve working conditions for welding industry workers, who face risks from breathing in hazardous gases and physical safety concerns. The new business segment, which began a year ago, is already supplementing the company's revenue, which took a hit due to Covid-19. Despite the challenges, AllAlloy Dynaweld is expanding into Thailand and Vietnam, targeting the next three years for growth, with inoculation rates and border reopenings crucial to its success.

site_title: Yoma Strategic announces changes to board
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings announced changes to its board, with lead independent director Adrian Chan Pengee stepping down on Dec 31 and Wong Su Yen taking his place from Jan 1. Chan will also cease to serve on the nominating and governance committee and remuneration committee. Cyrus Pun Chi Yam was redesignated as an alternative director to executive chairman Serge Pun from Jan 1. Shares closed down 0.8% to S$0.132 on Dec 17.

site_title: Intangible assets on the ascent: Frameworks, valuation methods need to keep up
summary: Singapore's intangible assets, including brands, software codes, and patents, are gaining traction as investors evaluate companies. However, the lack of standard frameworks and valuation methods hinders the assessment of these assets. Traditional financial metrics, such as price-to-book and trailing price-to-earnings ratios, do not account for intangible assets. The importance of intangible assets is clear, with 85% of the S&P 500's intangible assets relative to enterprise value in 2020. Singapore's intangible assets have declined from 57% in 2010 to 28% in 2020, and investors are calling for increased awareness and recognition of these assets to better evaluate companies.

site_title: Now is the time to innovate for a sustainable future
summary: The Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards recognized top SMEs in Singapore, including Reachfield Security & Safety Management, AllAlloy Dynaweld, and Utracon Overseas, for their resilience during the pandemic. The awards highlighted the need for businesses to adopt sustainable practices, with climate change expected to be a long-term challenge. Utracon Overseas, ranked third, has received a Sustainability Special Mention for its efforts in reducing carbon emissions and innovating towards a greener future. Governments and enterprises must work together to shape policies and practices that balance sustainability and profitability.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for December 17, 2021, reveals a sharp decline in tanker and dry bulk market prices. The Capesize market fell by 2,100 points and $17,422, with the C10 transpacific run and C5 west Australia to Qingdao run contributing to the decline. Panamax markets also experienced corrections, with the Atlantic failing to find momentum. The Supramax/Ultramax market saw limited fresh enquiries, while Handysize activity dropped due to holiday season. The VLCC market rebounded slightly, with minor increases in Middle East Gulf to US Gulf and West Africa to China rates. Aframax rates came under pressure, particularly in the Mediterranean. Clean freight markets showed balance, with incremental improvements on all sizes.

site_title: Pfizer says pandemic could extend to 2024, vaccine data for younger children delayed
summary: Pfizer forecasts the Covid-19 pandemic could last until 2024, with some regions experiencing pandemic levels of cases for the next year or two. The company also reported a weaker immune response to its lower-dose vaccine for 2- to 4-year-olds, potentially delaying authorization. Globally, the disease is expected to transition to an endemic state by 2024, with low, manageable caseloads.

site_title: KinderWorld forges ahead with grit and perseverance
summary: KinderWorld International Group (KIG) has overcome numerous setbacks to become the largest owner/operator of foreign-owned international schools in Vietnam. Founded by husband-and-wife team Ricky and Carol Tan in 1986, the company initially faced financial challenges in Singapore but successfully expanded into China and Vietnam. After ceasing operations in China, KIG focused on Vietnam, where it has grown significantly, with 16 campuses and over 3,800 students. The company now plans to expand into new markets, including Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia, Indonesia, and Kazakhstan, and is considering an initial public offering to reward staff and continue expansion.

images.alt_text: While some questioned why KIG gave up the China market in favour of Vietnam in the past, it was a decision that Ricky firmly believes has paid off: "There is no right or wrong, but that was the decision for me as an entrepreneur at that time."

site_title: The risk of avoiding emerging markets
summary: Emerging markets face risks from the Omicron outbreak, inflation, and monetary tightening. Despite these challenges, long-term investors may be better off not shunning emerging markets, as they offer potential for greater growth and diversification. Studies show that emerging markets and developed countries have low correlation, reducing portfolio volatility and enhancing returns. However, experts recommend caution due to vulnerabilities in countries like Turkey, Brazil, and Indonesia, which are experiencing sizzling inflation, economic strife, and currency devaluations. Investors may consider indirect exposure through ESG funds or diversifying their portfolios.

site_title: S-Reits generate 6% total returns in 2021 to date
summary: S-Reits in Singapore have generated 6% total returns in 2021, outperforming the benchmark Straits Times Index's 13% gain. The top-performing sub-industries are healthcare, office, and retail Reits. Retail investors have driven fund flow activities, accumulating S$1.1 billion in net retail inflows, while institutional investors have seen net outflows of S$860 million. The sector has also seen significant asset acquisitions, with total purchase considerations exceeding S$11 billion.

site_title: Hunting for 'multi-baggers' in the Singapore market
summary: Investors in the Singapore market are struggling to find multi-bagger stocks, with the Straits Times Index's dull returns and lack of big tech-oriented stocks making it challenging to achieve significant growth. However, smaller companies with average market capitalizations of over $2.6 billion have delivered impressive returns, including 22 stocks that gained 500% or more in the past decade. Experts like Peter Lynch, who once achieved a 29.2% annual return, would likely focus on consistent long-term outperformers, including DBS, Venture Corp, and Micro-Mechanics, and watch for potential post-pandemic upside in companies like Thai Beverage and Straits Trading.

site_title: Badminton: Singapore's Loh Kean Yew is world champion
summary: Singapore's Loh Kean Yew becomes the first Singaporean to win the World Badminton Championships, defeating India's Srikanth Kidambi 21-15, 22-20 in the final. The unseeded national shuttler achieved the historic win in 42 hectic minutes. Loh's victory marked a milestone for Singaporean badminton, sending shockwaves throughout the badminton world.

site_title: British hospitality businesses reel from Omicron surge
summary: British hospitality businesses face a significant hit from the Omicron surge, with soaring cases and government restrictions leading to lost income and cancellations during the Christmas period. The UK government's "plan B" measures, including mask mandates and work-from-home advice, have resulted in a 10% drop in income for one pub and a 35% decline in expected revenue. Trade body UKHospitality reports £2 billion in lost trade, with many businesses struggling to stay afloat due to reduced customer numbers and increased rent payments.

images.alt_text: Britain's pandemic-weary hospitality businesses have taken a fresh hit from soaring coronavirus cases fueled by the Omicron variant, as anxious customers curtail socialising and cancel bookings over the Christmas period.

site_title: Turnout down as Hong Kong votes in 'patriots'-only election
summary: Hong Kong's "patriots"-only legislative election saw a turnout of 21.02% after 8 hours, significantly lower than the 31.16% recorded at the same point in 2016. The election, criticized by activists, foreign governments, and rights groups, has been marred by the absence of pro-democracy candidates, with around a third of seats to be selected by Beijing loyalists. Turnout is seen as a barometer of legitimacy, with observers questioning the government's intentions behind the low turnout, which may be intended to secure a high turnout and delegitimize the election.

site_title: Australia's new Covid-19 cases hit record high
summary: Australia reported a record high of 5,017 new Covid-19 cases on Saturday, with outbreaks growing in New South Wales and Victoria. The country's previous high was 3,820 cases. Despite the rise, Prime Minister Scott Morrison downplayed the risks, focusing on hospitalizations and cases in intensive care. New South Wales reported 2,482 new cases, Victoria reported 1,504, and Queensland reported 31. Morrison reiterated that the country is learning to live with the virus and easing pandemic curbs, including removing isolation requirements for fully vaccinated international travelers.

site_title: Netherlands locks down as Omicron spreads 'at lightning speed' in Europe
summary: The Netherlands has become the first European country to implement a full lockdown due to the rapid spread of the omicron variant, with nonessential shops, bars, and schools closing until mid-January. The country's Prime Minister Mark Rutte acknowledged the measure is necessary to prevent a worst-case scenario, citing a fifth wave of the virus as inevitable. Other European countries, including Austria, Germany, and Denmark, have also taken action, with tightened travel restrictions and closed public venues. The omicron variant is expected to dominate in France by the start of next year.

site_title: 2 mDR senior executives misappropriate S$2.08 million in company funds
summary: Two senior executives at mDR have been suspended and are persons of interest in a suspected misappropriation of S$2.08 million from the company's marketing incentive rebates at its subsidiaries. The unauthorized use occurred at 3 Mobile Telecom, A-Mobile, and Handphoneshop. Preliminary internal investigations have found the aggregate amount misappropriated, and both executives are not directors of the company. The incident occurred on December 10 and December 13, and the company has announced the cases.

site_title: US offices shut and holiday parties dim as a familiar feeling sinks in
summary: The US is experiencing a surge in COVID-19 cases, with over 120,000 new cases reported daily, prompting employers to scale back their in-person plans. Many companies, including Morgan Stanley, Jefferies, and Goldman Sachs, have canceled or postponed holiday parties due to the rising cases. Some firms, like Apple, have also delayed their office returns indefinitely. Employers are weighing vaccine guidelines and adjusting their office returns, with some requiring booster shots and others considering virtual celebrations. The World Economic Forum has also planned its annual meeting in Davos despite the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Yoma Strategic announces changes to board
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings announced changes to its board, with lead independent director Adrian Chan stepping down on December 31 to facilitate board renewal. Wong Su Yen will take his place as lead independent director from January 1. Cyrus Pun Chi Yam will be redesignated as an alternative director to executive chairman Serge Pun from January 1. These changes aim to refresh the board and reflect the company's growth and diversification into various sectors, including real estate, food and beverage, and financial services.

site_title: Omicron could put US Covid-19 surge into overdrive
summary: The US is facing a potential surge in COVID-19 cases due to the highly transmissible Omicron variant, with hospitalizations increasing 45% over the last month and cases rising 40% to a 7-day average of 123,000 new infections per day. Public health officials warn that Omicron could become the dominant variant in the country, straining hospitals and potentially leading to increased deaths. The variant's infectiousness has already led to disruptions in daily life, including cancellations of events and travel plans.

site_title: A different sort of festive
summary: A leader is needed to show they work for their team, not just themselves. During the pandemic, freedom has been lost, leaving employees feeling lost, uncertain, and fearful. To make a difference, leaders must show care and time for their employees, not just financial gifts. This includes listening, helping emotionally, and physically, as well as sharing their own experiences. Leaders must lead from the front, take responsibility, and involve their team in strategic thinking. By doing so, they can help their team cope with the challenges of the post-pandemic world and find happiness in their work.

site_title: Premier League 'paranoia' over Covid-19 lottery
summary: Premier League teams are experiencing "paranoia" over Covid-19 cases, with five matches postponed on Saturday and Sunday, taking the total to nine over the past week. Aston Villa manager Steven Gerrard expressed his concern over the constant changes in his team's medical status, while Liverpool's Jurgen Klopp warned that the schedule could become unsustainable. The Premier League is set to discuss the crisis on Monday, with some managers advocating for a temporary halt to the season.

site_title: Patient says cannot forgive suspected arsonist in fatal Japan clinic blaze
summary: A patient at a Japanese psychiatry clinic that was the site of a fatal arson attack says he cannot forgive the suspected perpetrator, who is a patient of the clinic and is in critical condition in hospital. The fire killed 24 people and occurred after a man set a bag of liquid on fire near a heater. This incident follows a 2019 arson attack in Kyoto that killed 36 people and a 2001 fire in Tokyo's Kabukicho district that killed 44 people. The suspect's condition and the investigation continue.

site_title: Thai prison set on fire during riot over coronavirus cluster
summary: A riot broke out at a Thai prison in Krabi, southern Thailand, over the handling of a coronavirus cluster, with hundreds of prisoners setting fire to the facility. The two-day riot resulted in minor injuries, with 14 inmates wounded with rubber bullets. Authorities have restored order, and prison officials will inspect the damage. The prison, which houses over 2,100 inmates, has a high rate of coronavirus infections, with 300 testing positive. Authorities have arrested 31 people, and almost 93% of Thailand's 281,535 inmates have been fully vaccinated.

site_title: French PM says Omicron to be 'dominant' in France from start of 2022
summary: French Prime Minister Jean Castex has stated that Omicron will be the dominant strain in France from the start of 2022, likening its spread to "lightning". The government plans to announce new measures to tackle non-vaccination and boost vaccination rates. France has seen nearly 3,000 people in intensive care with Covid-19. The country will introduce new travel restrictions, requiring travelers to show a compelling reason for travel between Britain and France, starting from Saturday. Castex also called for the cancellation of New Year's Eve celebrations to limit the spread of coronavirus.

site_title: Europe: Omicron worries pull stocks lower
summary: European stocks declined 0.6% on Friday, led by banks and luxury stocks, amid hawkish signals from central banks and rising Omicron concerns. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.3% for the week, with inflation surging to a record high in November. Despite travel stocks surging, auto stocks dropped 2.7% after a global semiconductor shortage. The European Central Bank reined in stimulus slightly but promised to support the economy, while the Bank of England unexpectedly hiked rates.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Sri Lanka as default fears mount
summary: International ratings agency Fitch downgraded Sri Lanka's credit rating to "CC" due to mounting fears of a sovereign default on its US$26 billion foreign debt. The downgrade comes as Sri Lanka's foreign reserves slumped to US$1.58 billion at the end of November, making it difficult for the government to meet its external debt obligations in 2022 and 2023. Sri Lanka's foreign-currency debt service payments total US$6.9 billion, equivalent to nearly 430% of its official gross international reserves.

site_title: Riverstone chairman and incoming Heeton chair boost their stakes
summary: Riverstone Holdings chairman Wong Teek Son and Heeton Holdings deputy chairman Toh Giap Eng increased their stakes in their respective companies after acquiring shares between Dec 10 and 16. Riverstone Holdings' stake rose to 51.26% following Wong's acquisition of 1.5 million shares at 64.9 cents per share, while Heeton Holdings' stake increased to 40.90% after Toh's acquisition of 1,375,000 shares at 31.1 cents per share. These moves come amid a decline in the Straits Times Index, with institutions net selling S$63 million of shares during the period.

site_title: Alibaba pledges carbon neutrality by 2030
summary: Alibaba Group has pledged to achieve carbon neutrality by 2030, aiming to reduce its own emissions by 50% and cut overall CO2 emissions by 1.5 gigatons by 2035. The company plans to deploy new energy-saving technologies, increase use of renewables, and explore carbon removal initiatives. This move follows China's president Xi Jinping's announcement of the country's goal to become carbon neutral by 2060, putting pressure on giant corporations to set their own roadmaps. Alibaba's efforts are part of a broader push by Chinese tech firms to cut emissions.

site_title: Death toll from Philippines typhoon passes 20
summary: At least 23 people have died in the Philippines due to Typhoon Rai, the strongest typhoon to hit the country this year. The storm ravaged the southern and central regions, knocking out communications and electricity, and causing widespread destruction on islands such as Siargao and Dinagat. Over 300,000 people were displaced, and reports of severe damage, including leveled communities and destroyed homes, are alarming. The typhoon's powerful winds and torrential rain have left residents struggling to access basic necessities like food, water, and electricity.

site_title: Omicron more likely to reinfect than Delta and is not milder: study
summary: A study by Imperial College London found that the Omicron coronavirus variant is more likely to reinfect individuals than the Delta variant, with a 5.4-fold higher risk of reinfection. The study also showed no evidence of Omicron being milder than Delta, contradicting earlier claims. The protection afforded by past infection against reinfection with Omicron may be as low as 19%. The study's findings have significant implications for public health, with experts warning of a major threat to health due to Omicron's ability to evade prior immunity.

site_title: Political row in Brazil over dystopian film 'Executive Order'
summary: Brazil is embroiled in a controversy over the dystopian film 'Executive Order,' which depicts a future where the government sends blacks back to Africa as a solution to slavery. The film, directed by Lazaro Ramos, has won praise internationally but faces allegations of censorship by the far-right government of President Jair Bolsonaro. The National Cinema Agency (Ancine) is under pressure to clear the film for release, amid claims of bureaucratic and censorship barriers. The delay has sparked accusations of censorship and criticism from the film's director, who says art is powerful and cannot be silenced.

site_title: Federal Reserve official sees first US rate hike in spring 2022
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller expects the first US interest rate hike in spring 2022, following the end of its bond-buying program in March. This decision comes after inflation reached its biggest jump in nearly four decades, with price increases affecting US consumers and businesses. The rate hike is expected to be "warranted shortly after our asset purchases end" to combat high inflation. The Fed's decision gives policymakers the ability to respond quickly to the economic situation.

site_title: Taiwan opposition hopes for boost in contentious referendums
summary: Taiwanese opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), is hoping for a boost in referendums that could affect ties with the US and energy security. The vote comes amid heightened tensions with China, which has pressured Taiwan to accept Beijing's sovereignty claims. The KMT's poor performance in last year's elections has fueled accusations of ties with China, and the referendums may serve as a show of no confidence in the government. The outcome will be closely watched, with implications for Taiwan's relationships with the US and China.

site_title: Mbappe to be new face of Dior
summary: Kylian Mbappe has announced a two-year partnership with Dior as the new face for the brand's men's fashion and perfumes. Mbappe, a French football star, will lend his image to Dior's creations by Kim Jones, Artistic Director for Dior men's collections. This partnership follows a similar model with other footballers such as Zinedine Zidane, David Beckham, and Lionel Messi, who have supported luxury brands. Mbappe's collaboration with Dior is expected to be announced in the coming months.

site_title: US recommends approving Google, Meta undersea data cable to Asia
summary: The US government recommended approving Google and Meta to use the Pacific Light Cable Network, a 12,870km undersea fiber-optic cable system connecting the US, Taiwan, the Philippines, and Hong Kong, to handle growing internet traffic with Asia.

site_title: US appeals court reinstates Covid-19 vaccine-or-test rule for US workplaces
summary: A US appeals court reinstated a nationwide vaccine-or-testing Covid-19 mandate for large businesses, covering 80 million American workers, after lifting a November injunction. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) rule applies to businesses with at least 100 workers. The ruling reverses a block imposed by a lower court, allowing the Biden administration's rule to take effect.

site_title: IMF board forms group to review data integrity after World Bank scandal
summary: The International Monetary Fund's (IMF) executive board formed a steering group to review data integrity and governance following a World Bank scandal. The group aims to present its findings by April 2022, with the goal of strengthening internal governance and accountability. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva was cleared of wrongdoing in the scandal, which involved allegations of pressure on World Bank staff to alter data in the "Doing Business" report to boost China's ranking. The IMF board expressed confidence in Georgieva and IMF staff, but acknowledged the need for additional steps to ensure data integrity.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund's executive board on Friday said it has formed a steering group to lead a review to improve institutional safeguards on data and governance after clearing IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva of wrongdoing in a World Bank data-rigging scandal.

site_title: Rod Stewart admits battery over Florida hotel fight
summary: Rod Stewart, 76, and his son Sean pleaded guilty to battery over a 2019 altercation with a Florida hotel security guard outside a children's party at The Breakers in Palm Beach. The incident occurred when the family was refused access to the party, and Stewart punched the guard. He was charged with simple battery but pleaded guilty to avoid a lengthy and costly trial. The judge withheld adjudication, meaning neither faces jail time or fines, and the victim, Jessie Dixon, had no objection to the resolution.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SPH Reit Management has taken out a 5-year, S$50 million incremental facility loan to refinance existing loans. This is part of an amended and restated facility agreement with a term loan facility of S$975 million secured by DBS Trustee in 2013.

site_title: Paris city council tightens rules on tourist rentals
summary: The Paris city council has voted to tighten rules on tourist rentals, aiming to curb the influence of home-sharing sites like Airbnb. The new rules will not authorize transforming commercial space into short-term accommodation if it disrupts local employment, housing, and commerce. In the past 6 years, Paris lost 59,000 square meters of commercial space and 900 businesses to short-term rentals. Airbnb disputes the rules, stating the "overwhelming majority" of hosts in Paris are locals, and claims the new rules will not have a noticeable impact on its activity.

site_title: Can Barcelona create a new kind of tourist economy?
summary: Barcelona is exploring a new kind of tourist economy, dubbed "pace tourism," which involves longer stays and greater integration with the local community. The COVID-19 pandemic has created an opportunity for the city to rethink its approach to tourism, which has led to strain on public goods and displacement of residents. By attracting "pace tourists" who stay for weeks or months, Barcelona could reduce its reliance on short-term visitors and create more local job opportunities. The city could leverage online platforms and innovative policies to make this model a success, potentially solving the urban conundrum of engaging with global tourism without succumbing to it.

site_title: Reflections and learnings of a continuing pandemic survivor
summary: A pandemic survivor reflects on the importance of mutual support and community during the COVID-19 pandemic. The author learned to listen better to others and themselves, gaining insight into the struggles of loved ones and friends. They realized that everyone is in the same pandemic storm, but each person's boat is different, with unique challenges such as job loss, education, and family isolation. The author emphasizes the value of having a community that can offer a listening ear and support, and recommends that people prioritize listening and supporting each other as a way to counter the pandemic.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as tech stocks slide
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Friday as technology stocks tumbled due to the Federal Reserve's decision to end pandemic-era stimulus faster. The Dow Jones fell 97.53 points, the S&P 500 dropped 16.17 points, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 143.66 points. Investors shifted towards cyclical markets amid concerns over the impact of the Fed's decision on the economy.

site_title: Oil prices post weekly loss on Omicron uncertainty
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, closing down 2% at $73.52 a barrel for Brent crude and 2.1% at $70.86 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. The decline was attributed to concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant and potential new restrictions on fuel demand. Oil prices were also down for the week, with Brent crude falling 2.6% and WTI crude falling 1.3%.

site_title: US: Dow drops as Wall Street ends tumultuous week on sour note
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, ending a tumultuous week on a sour note. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.5% to 35,365.44, while the S&P 500 fell 1.0% to 4,620.64. Concerns over the Omicron variant and the Federal Reserve's plan to withdraw pandemic stimulus measures weighed on markets. Electric car maker Rivian fell 10.3% after announcing a quarterly loss, and JPMorgan Chase closed 2.3% lower after being fined $200 million for recordkeeping violations. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.1% to 15,169.68.

site_title: Looming clash between man-made and natural risks
summary: Cities in the Anthropocene Era are facing increasing risks from both man-made and natural hazards, posing a significant threat to global economic stability. A study by Lloyd's and the Cambridge Centre for Risk Studies found that US$4.6 trillion of global GDP is at risk, with man-made risks becoming increasingly significant. Rising sea levels are expected to impact 9 of the 10 top cities at risk, primarily in Asia, and will exacerbate the already high exposure of coastal financial centers to catastrophic events. The world's cities and nations must take proactive measures to manage these risks and invest in resilience.

site_title: UOB makes board changes, appoints Teo Lay Lim as independent director
summary: UOB announced 3 board changes, including the appointment of Teo Lay Lim as an independent director and member of its executive committee, effective January 1, 2022. Teo, with over 30 years of experience in Accenture, will bring her leadership skills to the bank. The changes are part of UOB's ongoing board renewal.

site_title: Running to reach physical and spiritual breakthroughs
summary: Eugene Lim, 38, credits ultra-running for his spiritual breakthroughs and staying positive, despite the challenges of the pandemic. He began running at 19 as part of his National Service, and later took up ultra-trail running after completing an Ironman event. Lim finds that running alone allows him to focus on his thoughts and conceptualize ideas, leading to breakthroughs. He believes that pushing himself through physical discomfort helps him maintain a positive mindset and tackle other challenges in life.

site_title: A healthy start to 2022
summary: The 2020 American Dietary Guidelines emphasize the importance of nutrient-dense foods and beverages for supporting healthy weight gain throughout life stages. To achieve this, individuals should consume foods with little added sugars, saturated fat, and sodium, such as vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and lean meats. The guidelines also recommend limiting saturated fat intake to less than 10% of daily calories, choosing unsaturated fats, and avoiding foods high in saturated fat. Additionally, adequate calcium and vitamin D consumption, particularly in young children and post-menopausal women, is crucial for maintaining bone health.

site_title: Triple whammy of cooling measures, rising supply and higher rates can end up cycle in home prices
summary: Singapore's new property cooling measures, including higher additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rates and tightened loan-to-value limits, aim to temper the private home and HDB resale markets. The measures, which took effect on December 16, 2021, target non-citizens and first-time homebuyers, with rates ranging from 12% to 30% ABSD. Experts warn that these measures, combined with rising supply and higher interest rates, may end the ongoing price run-up in the market, potentially leading to a cycle in home prices.

site_title: Japanese companies are waking up to activist investors
summary: Japanese companies are witnessing growing activism from foreign investors pushing for better corporate governance and ESG practices. This trend is driven by global governance standards, particularly the presence and role of independent directors on boards. Despite a 39% share of independent directors in major Japanese companies, this lags behind global best practices. Japan's traditional corporate culture, including its 2-tier board structure, hinders progress. Activists are focusing on issues like board independence, separation of CEO and board chair roles, and gender diversity. Japan's financial regulators have recognized the need for global governance standards, and investors are expected to play a key role in driving change.

site_title: Vaccinated Singaporeans can fly to Sydney, Melbourne without quarantine from Dec 21
summary: Fully vaccinated Singaporeans can fly to Sydney and Melbourne in Australia without quarantine starting Dec 21, restoring two-way travel between Singapore and parts of Australia. New South Wales and Victoria states agreed to lift the self-isolation requirement, allowing eligible travelers to get a PCR test within 24 hours of arrival and isolate until negative results are received. This development is part of Australia's travel pilot for Singapore, which aims to test border measures before opening up to non-citizens.

site_title: Claws and effect - the Jaguar F-Pace SVR
summary: The Jaguar F-Pace SVR is a high-performance SUV that boasts a 5.0-liter V8 supercharged engine, producing 550 horsepower and 700 Nm of torque. It accelerates from 0-100km/h in 4 seconds and has a top speed of 286 km/h. The car is well-rounded, comfortable, practical, and handles corners with surprising haste, thanks to its firm suspension and responsive steering. With a price tag of S$459,999, the F-Pace SVR competes with other high-performance SUVs like the BMW M and Mercedes-AMG, but its unique blend of power and practicality makes it a compelling choice.

images.alt_text: The Jaguar F-Pace SVR just leaps up the road like a cat with its tail on fire while you hang on for the ride.
The cabin is usefully roomy in the back, and the front seats come with built-in fans.

site_title: Online brokers next in China regulatory crackdown
summary: Chinese officials are planning to ban online brokerages like Futu Holdings and UP Fintech Holding from offering offshore trading services to mainland clients, amid concerns over data security and capital outflows. The ban would block millions of retail investors from trading securities in markets like the US and Hong Kong. The move comes as part of a broader regulatory crackdown that has affected various sectors, including technology and education. The firms affected are likely to be notified of the ban in the coming months, with Futu and UP Fintech already experiencing declining shares.

site_title: Great Dane Peter Schmeichel still giving back to football
summary: Legendary Danish goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel, known as the "Great Dane," still actively engages with the sport he dominated for 22 years, including his iconic 9-year stint at Manchester United. Schmeichel, now 58, emphasizes the importance of grassroots football, criticizing the commercialization of the sport and the pressure on young players to reach elite levels. He praises the evolution of goalkeeping, citing Gianluigi Donnarumma's Player of the Tournament award at Euro 2020, and believes goalkeepers receive the recognition they deserve.

images.alt_text: Retired former Manchester United goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel with young players at the JSSL Singapore FA Cup 2021 tournament held at Our Tampines Hub on Dec 10-12.

site_title: JPMorgan Securities to pay US$125m to settle SEC charges on record-keeping lapses
summary: JPMorgan Securities has agreed to pay the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) $125 million to settle charges of violating record-keeping laws by failing to preserve staff communications on personal devices. The firm admitted to widespread lapses and agreed to implement compliance improvements. The fine, under SEC Chair Gary Gensler, is the first major enforcement action related to this issue. The SEC is now probing similar lapses at other financial institutions and has opened investigations into their records-keeping practices.

site_title: Dutch town approves licence for Meta data centre, the Netherlands' biggest
summary: The town of Zeewolde in the Netherlands has approved a licence for Meta to build its largest data centre, covering 166 hectares of farmland and using 1.38GWh of electricity. The facility is expected to create 400 permanent jobs and run on green energy, despite criticism from politicians and environmental campaigners. The decision marks a shift in Dutch policy, as the country's new government is questioning the national government's role in determining the placement of data centres. Initial construction costs are estimated at 700 million euros.

images.alt_text: The town of Zeewolde, 50km east of Amsterdam, on Thursday (Dec 16) approved plans by Meta to build the largest data centre in the Netherlands from which Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp can serve users all over Europe.

site_title: Chinese developer Shimao's unit to sell stake in special purpose vehicles
summary: Chinese developer Shimao Group Holdings' unit Fortune Spring Ventures is selling a 22.5% stake in three special purpose vehicles for US$267.89 million. The vehicles manage a property development project in South West Kowloon, Hong Kong. This deal comes as Chinese developers face liquidity crunches amid tightened regulations. The sale aims to alleviate the companies' financial pressures and is part of efforts to address the sector's liquidity issues.

site_title: Biogen Alzheimer's drug gets negative EU Regulator opinion
summary: The European Union's key panel of the drugs regulator issued a negative opinion on Biogen's Alzheimer's treatment Aduhelm, citing insufficient evidence of its effectiveness and safety. The panel found that the link between amyloid beta reduction and clinical improvement wasn't proven, and studies showed abnormal brain scans in patients. Biogen and its partner Eisai will ask the panel to reexamine the opinion, which could impact the drug's potential revenue. The decision follows a similar negative trend vote last month and a slow uptake in the US market due to concerns over side effects and clinical benefits.

site_title: Citi veteran Money K named as global head of global client service business
summary: Citi has appointed Money K as the global head of its Global Client Service (GCS) business, a key private banking arm. K, with over 20 years of experience at Citi, succeeds Tim Sullivan and will focus on growth for GCS, which has seen double-digit growth since its inception in 2012. K will work closely with regional leadership teams and product partners to drive the next phase of growth for the business. His appointment is seen as a strategic move to take GCS to the next level, with the business fuelled by clients' increased global presence.

site_title: New IDX ruling on multiple voting rights, more young investors spell good news for Indonesian tech IPO aspirants
summary: Indonesia's Financial Services Authority has introduced new rules allowing multiple shareholding rights for certain shareholders, a move seen as beneficial for tech companies such as GoTo, OVO, and Traveloka, which are planning to list on the Indonesian Stock Exchange (IDX). The new rules, which came into effect on December 1, include tax incentives and the ability for unprofitable firms to list. This is aimed at attracting Indonesia's unicorns and decacorns, with GoTo Group expected to list in the first quarter of 2022 with an estimated valuation of $25-30 billion. However, market players note that tech companies will face challenges, including Indonesia's relatively low capital base, and investor wariness of non-profitable companies.

site_title: Binance among firms stymied by Singapore's money-launder rules
