summary: Binance Asia Services, a cryptocurrency exchange affiliate, withdrew its application to operate in Singapore due to not meeting the Monetary Authority of Singapore's criteria for safeguarding against money laundering and terrorism financing. The decision was made "for strategic and commercial objectives only," according to Binance. Singapore's strict criteria, including "very high standards" for issuing crypto licenses, may be a deterrent to other firms, with around 70 companies still waiting for regulatory approval.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit to sell property at 69 Ubi Crescent for S$28m
summary: Chip Eng Seng's wholly owned subsidiary, CES Capital Holdings, has agreed to sell its 6-storey light industrial building at 69 Ubi Crescent for S$28 million to Merlions Two (BVI). The property, which has been generating stable rental income, does not significantly contribute to the group's revenue and profitability. The net proceeds from the transaction will be used for working capital purposes and pursuing better opportunities. The sale is part of Chip Eng Seng's asset management strategy to divest non-strategic assets.

site_title: Evergrande shareholder Chinese Estates shelves plans to go private
summary: Chinese Estates Holdings, a major stakeholder in China Evergrande, has rejected a proposal to take the embattled developer private after a shareholder vote. The proposal, valued at $245.30 million, was made by a British Virgin Islands-based company. Chinese Estates, which owns about 4.7% of Evergrande's equity capital, plans to resume trading on the Hong Kong stock exchange from December 20. The company also intends to sell its remaining Evergrande stake, either on the market or through block trades, after failing to take the company private.

site_title: Sinopharm, J&J, Sputnik vaccines produce little or no antibodies against Omicron: Study
summary: A study found that Sinopharm, J&J, and Sputnik vaccines produce little or no antibodies against the Omicron variant, with only 3 out of 13 people showing neutralizing antibodies after two doses of Sinopharm and 1 out of 12 for J&J. The study also found that Pfizer's mRNA shots and combination of prior infection and Pfizer shots generated the lowest reduction in protective antibodies, with a 5-fold drop compared to 44-fold for those without prior infection.

site_title: Zico Holdings to dispose of 49% stake in Zico Trust for RM9.6m
summary: Zico Holdings announced the disposal of its 49% stake in Zico Trust for RM9.6 million (S$3.1 million) to Riau Capital, a Singapore-based investment company. The move is aimed at focusing on the growing wealth management industry in Asia. Completion of the deal is subject to certain conditions, including approval from the Labuan Financial Services Authority. Following the disposal, Zico Holdings will retain a 51% equity interest in Zico Trust, while Riau Capital will hold 49%.

site_title: More than 2,500 flee to Thailand as rebels clash with Myanmar army
summary: At least 2,500 people, including hundreds of children, have fled to Thailand after clashes between the Myanmar army and ethnic minority rebels, the Karen National Union. The displaced people took refuge in the Thai town of Mae Sot. The clashes are part of ongoing turmoil in Myanmar, which was triggered by the military's ousting of a civilian government led by Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi in February. The situation remains volatile, with sporadic clashes reported in the countryside.

site_title: Singtel's Australian unit receives unfavourable judgment in court dispute with Australian Taxation Office
summary: Singtel's Australian subsidiary, Singapore Telecom Australia Investments (STAI), has received an unfavorable judgment from the Federal Court of Australia in a dispute with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) over the acquisition financing of Singtel Optus in 2001. STAI was ordered to pay A$268 million in primary tax, A$58 million in interest, and A$67 million in penalties, with Singtel Australia Investment eligible for a corresponding refund of A$89 million. The group will consider the details of the judgment and determine next steps, with Singtel committed to complying with tax obligations in markets where it operates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 17.37 points to 1,502.01 on Friday, with a total volume of 2.811 billion lots worth RM2.738 billion. Losers narrowly outnumbered gainers 434 to 425.

site_title: Oil declines as Omicron and monetary tightening darken outlook
summary: Oil futures fell for the first time in three days, dropping toward $71 a barrel, due to concerns about the impact of the omicron variant on demand and tighter monetary policy. The Bank of England raised interest rates, and daily Covid-19 cases surged in the UK and US hospitalizations increased. Softening oil demand in Asia and a global surplus in the market, as Omicron impedes travel, are also contributing to the decline. The market's structure has shifted to a bearish contango, with traders taking a risk-off attitude amid conflicting signals on demand and supply.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Reit takes out S$70m in loan facilities
summary: Frasers Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust (FH Reit) has entered into a S$70 million revolving credit facility with OCBC, in addition to an existing S$50 million revolving credit facility. The loan is secured by the Reit manager, Frasers Hospitality Asset Management, and is subject to certain conditions, including notification to the bank if the manager is no longer the Reit manager or majority-owned subsidiary of Frasers Property. Units of FHT closed flat at S$0.465 following the announcement, with aggregate facilities totaling around S$930.7 million potentially affected.

site_title: European gas plunges after Russia books pipeline at last minute
summary: European natural gas prices plummeted 16% after Russia unexpectedly booked pipeline space to deliver gas to Germany through Poland, easing supply concerns. The move comes as a cold snap forecast for next week is expected to be shorter than initially thought. Despite this, storage levels remain at their lowest for this time of year, setting the stage for a volatile winter. Traders remain uncertain about Russia's supply strategy amid increasing tensions with the West over Ukraine.

site_title: TikTok is getting into the restaurant business
summary: TikTok has partnered with Virtual Dining Concepts to launch TikTok Kitchen, a delivery-only restaurant chain with locations planned across the US, Canada, and the UK. The menu will feature viral food trends, including baked feta pasta, pasta chips, and a smash burger. Prices will be comparable to other Virtual Dining Concept brands. The company plans to devote profits to creators of the menu dishes and support culinary talents on the platform. Over 300 TikTok restaurants are planned, with more than 1,000 expected by the end of 2022, according to co-founder Robert Earl.

site_title: Singapore government raises alert on critical Log4j software bug, holds 2 emergency meetings
summary: The Singapore government has raised its alert on the critical Log4j software bug, which has been declared code red by experts and governments globally. The bug, which allows hackers to take full control of computer systems, has been exploited by amateur cybercriminals. The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) has held emergency meetings with government agencies to issue directions on patching systems and minimizing abuse. Businesses are urged to take immediate action to safeguard themselves, with the government advising against exploiting the bug.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit issues units to manager for payment of fees
summary: Keppel DC Reit issued 613,155 units at S$2.53 to its manager to pay for development management, divestment, and acquisition fees. The units were issued for the Intellicentre 3 East Data Centre, the divestment of iseek Data Centre, and the acquisition of Eindhoven Campus. As of Dec 17, the manager holds about 7 million units, representing 0.4% of the total units issued. Shares of Keppel DC Reit ended flat at S$2.46.

site_title: Mahathir admitted to hospital for check-up
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 96, was admitted to the National Heart Institute in Kuala Lumpur for a full medical check-up and further observation. He is expected to remain there for several days. Mahathir is undergoing "several investigations" which are expected to be completed in the coming days.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower weighed by falls across Asia
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, down 1.79% or 520.64 points, following profit-taking after previous day's rallies. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 28,545.68, while the Topix index slipped 1.42% to 1,984.47. The decline was attributed to falls in other Asian bourses.

site_title: Hong Kong's tweaked SPAC regime to launch on Jan 1
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange operator announced that blank-cheque companies, also known as SPACs, will be allowed to list on the exchange starting January 1, 2022. The new rules, which were tweaked in response to market feedback, include lowering the minimum number of institutional investors required to 20 from 30. The changes aim to make the regime more commercial and practical, and investors expect a decent interest in listing SPACs in the city. The move is seen as a positive step to tap into the global demand for SPACs, which offer strong valuations and shorter listing time frames.

site_title: AGV Group unit receives RM1.6m letter of demand from RHB Bank
summary: AGV Group's indirect subsidiary, AGV Galvanizing, has received a letter of demand from RHB Bank for RM1.6 million (S$517,900) due to a breach of contract and failure to pay hire purchase facilities. The bank has demanded the sum, interest, and legal fees be paid within 21 days. AGV Galvanizing must also return equipment, including a galvanising furnace system and rectangular mild steel water tanks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports grew 24.2% year-on-year, the fastest pace since February 2012. Crypto billionaire Zhu Su is in the early stages of buying a bungalow for S$48.8 million. CDL acquired a UK site for £6.5m to develop a build-to-rent residential skyscraper. ARA Asset Management's Korea unit acquired Marble Arch Place for £280m, paving the way for more outbound investments. The STI fell 0.6% to finish the week at 3,111.63, ending a dreary week in the red.

site_title: Singapore shares finish dreary week in the red; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.6% to 3,111.63, ending a dreary week in the red. Despite robust macroeconomic data, including a 12th consecutive month of rising exports, the market declined. Top advancers included DBS and pandemic-related counters, while Shangri-La Asia and Jardine group companies were among the biggest losers. Asia markets finished mixed, with the Nikkei 225 falling 1.8% and the Hang Seng Index losing 1.2%.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare to receive S$800,000 from Crest entities in settlement agreement
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare reached a "full and final" settlement agreement with Crest Capital Asia, where the entities will pay S$800,000 in instalments. The settlement follows a 2020 Singapore High Court judgement, which held Crest entities jointly and severally liable for S$12.6 million. Upon full payment, there will be no outstanding claims between the company and the Crest entities. The payment schedule includes S$300,000 within 3 working days, S$250,000 by Feb 28, 2022, and the final S$250,000 by Apr 29, 2022.

site_title: Europe: Stocks waver at open after rate calls
summary: Europe's stock markets wavered at the open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.3% and the Paris CAC 40 adding 0.1%, despite a mixed outlook due to monetary policy announcements. The previous day's interest rate hike by the Bank of England and inflation-fighting plans from the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank had sparked a rally. However, concerns over US-EU trade tensions and the impact of tariffs on markets weighed on investor sentiment.

site_title: GIC eyes Chinese property assets, confident Beijing won't let things spiral
summary: Singapore's US$744 billion sovereign wealth fund, GIC, sees opportunities in China's battered real estate sector despite defaults at China Evergrande Group and other developers. GIC's CEO Lim Chow-Kiat is confident the Chinese government can contain the fallout, citing its central bank balance sheet and levers to prevent a market spiral. The fund is exploring deals and buying debt in the sector, including potential investments in Chinese property bonds and sovereign debt, which have seen significant gains this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 1.20% to 23,192.63, following a retreat on Wall Street and heightened tensions between China and the US. The US imposed fresh sanctions and trade measures on Beijing over its treatment of the Uyghur minority, contributing to the market decline. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell 1.16% to 3,632.36, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 1.41% to 2,523.15.

site_title: Gong Cha owner mulling sale or IPO; the bubble tea business could be worth US$600m
summary: US private equity firm TA Associates is considering a sale or initial public offering (IPO) for its bubble tea chain Gong Cha, valued at at least US$600 million. Gong Cha's owner could opt for a sale or stake sale to a strategic partner to expand to mainland China. Deliberations are at an early stage, with potential options including a sale or IPO as soon as next year.

site_title: Australia: Commodity-linked stocks buoy shares as BNPL firms tumble
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% on Friday, snapping a three-day losing streak, as miners and energy stocks gained on firmer commodity prices. Gold stocks led gains, with Alkane Resources advancing 23.1%. Mining giants BHP and Fortescue Metals also rose. In contrast, tech stocks plummeted 3.9% due to a US review of buy-now, pay-later companies, including Afterpay and Zip, which tumbled 9.2% and 9% respectively. The S&P/ASX 200 index settled at 7,304 points.

site_title: Singapore exports to cap the year strongly; growth will carry into early 2022: analysts
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) are expected to finish the year strong, with a 24.2% year-on-year growth in November, the fastest pace since 2012. Analysts predict continued growth momentum into early 2022, driven by high vaccination rates, border reopenings, and robust global demand for electronics. ESG forecasts 9.5-10% NODX growth for 2021, with 0-2% growth expected in 2022. Electronics NODX rose 29.2% in November, driven by strong global semiconductor demand.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: EDBI joins extended Series A round of corporate services startup Sleek
summary: EDBI, the investment arm of Singapore's Economic Development Board, has joined an extended Series A round of Singapore-based corporate services platform Sleek, investing $25 million. Sleek plans to use the funds to enhance tech and product development, hire new talent, and expand globally. The startup, which has over 5,000 clients, aims to simplify corporate secretarial, accounting, and finance functions for entrepreneurs and business owners. This investment is seen as addressing the growing need for digitalization in SMEs.

site_title: Tech giant GoTo said to hire banks for US$1b Indonesian IPO
summary: GoTo Group, a tech giant formed from Indonesia's two most valuable internet startups, has hired banks to raise around US$1 billion from an initial public offering (IPO) in Indonesia, potentially listing as PT GoTo Gojek Tokopedia. The company has already raised over US$1.3 billion in a pre-IPO round, seeking a valuation of US$25-30 billion. Indonesia's revamped share listing rules aim to attract tech giants like GoTo, which could help the market set another all-time high in 2026.

site_title: Goldman says US$100 oil possible as record demand outpaces supply
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts US$100 oil by 2023 due to slow supply additions and record demand. The bank's base forecast is for US$85, but higher cost inflation or supply shortages could push prices to triple digits. Goldman remains bullish on oil despite recent price rallies, expecting investors to buy the dip after asset managers reallocate funds next year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on strong foreign inflows, post third weekly gains
summary: South Korean stocks closed higher on Friday, extending gains for a third week, driven by strong foreign buying. The benchmark Kospi rose 0.38% to 3,017.73, despite concerns over the Omicron variant and more hawkish central bank moves. The Bank of England surprised markets with a rate hike, while the European Central Bank trimmed its bond buying program. The won rose 0.25% to 1,180.9 per dollar, and the government announced a 4.3 trillion won stimulus package to support small businesses.

site_title: Australian Open organisers confirm medical exemption process
summary: Australian Open organisers have confirmed a medical exemption process for players who want to participate without being vaccinated against Covid-19. An independent 3-person panel of doctors will review applications, with decisions made by medical experts and submissions kept confidential. The process, agreed with the Victoria Department of Health, aims to ensure a safe and enjoyable event for players and fans. The tournament, starting on January 17, may set a precedent for other big events.

site_title: Supermax invests US$350m to build first US glove manufacturing facility
summary: Malaysian glove maker Supermax Corporation is investing US$350 million to build its first US glove manufacturing facility in Brazoria County, Texas. The facility, expected to begin construction in Q1 2022, will produce 400 million gloves per month and cater to at least 10-15% of US medical glove imports over the next 2-4 years. The project is part of Supermax's US$550 million total capital expenditure and will include capabilities such as automation and robotic engineering.

images.alt_text: Phase 1 of 4 of the facility, located in Brazoria County, Texas, will begin construction in the first quarter of 2022 and will be in production by the fourth quarter of 2022.

site_title: SPH Reit takes S$50m loan to refinance existing loans
summary: SPH Reit has taken out a S$50 million 5-year loan to refinance existing loans, amending its 2013 facility agreement. The new agreement includes provisions on change of control, requiring the sponsor to own at least 30% of the Reit's units and 100% of the manager. As of Dec 17, there has been no breach of conditions, and the sponsor has not entered into a share pledge arrangement. The Reit's units ended the day at S$0.975, up 0.5%.

site_title: Shimao downgraded by Fitch, Moodys
summary: Two major credit rating agencies, Fitch and Moody's, downgraded Shimao Group Holdings, a Chinese property developer, due to weak sales and unfavorable financing conditions. Fitch lowered Shimao's investment-grade status for the first time since 2012, while Moody's cut its rating deeper into junk due to increased refinancing risks. This move highlights the growing stress at the embattled company.

site_title: OCBC, Cromwell E-Reit execute sustainability-linked cross-currency swap
summary: OCBC Bank and Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) have executed a 5-year sustainability-linked cross-currency swap to hedge currency risks on Cromwell E-Reit's S$100 million fixed-rate perps. The swap allows Cromwell E-Reit to convert Singapore dollars to euros at a cheaper rate if it meets two green targets: achieving a certain rating under the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark and obtaining green building certifications for its portfolio properties. The deal is Singapore's first sustainability-linked cross-currency swap, offering cost savings and diversifying Cromwell E-Reit's capital sources.

site_title: Alpha JWC Ventures, AC Ventures co-lead US$10m fund in automotive services startup
summary: Indonesia-based automotive services startup Otoklix has raised US$10 million in a Series A round co-led by Alpha JWC Ventures and AC Ventures. The funds will be used to establish Otoklix's flagship workshop throughout Indonesia and improve technological capabilities. Founded in 2019, the platform connects users with independent workshops, providing a warranty and customer relationship management solutions. The number of partner workshops has grown from 100 to over 1,900, serving more than 100,000 customers annually.

site_title: China allows Tencent to publish app updates again after suspension
summary: Chinese regulators have given Tencent Holdings approval to publish updates to 9 of its mobile apps, including QQ Music and WeCom, after a suspension last month. The decision follows a crackdown on the country's tech companies for monopolistic behavior and user rights infringement. The 9 apps have been reviewed and cleared to resume regular updates in app stores. This move comes as part of a step-up in checks on mobile apps by Chinese regulators.

site_title: ARA Asset Management's Korea unit acquires Marble Arch Place for £280 million
summary: ARA Asset Management's Korea unit has acquired Marble Arch Place in London for £280 million (S$509 million). The mixed-use commercial asset features 141,000 square feet of office, residential, and retail space and is currently 90% occupied. The acquisition is expected to pave the way for more outbound investments across Europe, North America, and Pan Asia, according to ARA Korea's CEO Anthony Kang. The deal was facilitated by ARA Dunedin and underwrote by NH Investment & Securities, with ARA's co-investment in previous transactions.

site_title: Britain's Conservatives lose 'safe' seat, dealing blow to Boris Johnson
summary: Britain's Conservative Party suffered a significant defeat in a North Shropshire parliamentary seat, losing a "safe" seat it had held for over a century. The Liberal Democrats won the contest, overturning a majority of nearly 23,000 held by former Conservative lawmaker Owen Paterson. This is the second blow to Prime Minister Boris Johnson's leadership in a week, following Paterson's resignation over lobbying rules. The result is seen as a major upset, highlighting the party's struggles and Johnson's leadership challenges.

site_title: Grand Venture proposes to acquire China, Malaysia companies for S$20m
summary: Grand Venture Technology (GVT) plans to spend S$20 million to acquire two companies in China and Malaysia, enhancing its capabilities and capacity in aerospace and medical diagnostics, as well as semiconductor and life sciences businesses. The precision manufacturing solutions provider will issue new shares at S$1.1619 apiece to the sellers. The acquisition aims to augment GVT's presence in these regions and accelerate growth.

site_title: Thai energy giant Banpu lines up US$200m for US renewable push
summary: Banpu Power Pcl, a Thai energy giant, plans to invest at least $200 million in renewable energy projects in the US, primarily in Texas, by 2025. The projects aim to add 400 megawatts of solar and wind capacity, with Texas expected to account for 50% of Banpu's global renewable portfolio. The US market is seen as attractive due to its growing demand for clean energy and suitable environment for solar and wind farms. This move follows similar efforts by other Thai companies, citing the nation's limited opportunities for renewable growth.

site_title: Crypto billionaire Zhu Su in early stage of buying S$49m GCB as trustee for 3-year-old
summary: Crypto billionaire Zhu Su is in the early stages of buying a S$48.8 million bungalow in Singapore's Yarwood Avenue, a 31,862 sq ft site on a 999-year leasehold. Zhu and his wife, Tao Yaqiong Evelyn, were granted an option to buy the property as trustee for a 3-year-old child, and all three are Singapore citizens. The property, an old 2-storey bungalow with 6 bedrooms, is ripe for redevelopment and is considered a "fair price" given the redevelopment land cost in the area is around S$1,400-1,600 psf.

site_title: CDL acquires UK site for £6.5m; to develop build-to-rent residential skyscraper
summary: CDL acquires a 250-year leasehold site in Birmingham, UK for £6.5m to develop an 8-storey, 370-unit build-to-rent residential skyscraper called Octagon. The estimated total development cost is £110m, part of CDL's £110m UK private rented sector pipeline.

site_title: Alibaba sets ambitious US$100b GMV goal for Lazada
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has set ambitious goals for its South-east Asian arm Lazada, aiming to quintuple its gross merchandise value (GMV) to US$100 billion and reach over 300 million users. The target comes as the company seeks to offset Chinese economic and regulatory headwinds. Lazada's GMV has grown to about US$21 billion over the past year, with the company now the third-largest online retailer in emerging markets. The growth of South-east Asian online commerce is expected to double to US$363 billion by 2025, driven by the pandemic and increasing internet penetration.

site_title: World coal power demand to hit new high after China, India, US surge: IEA
summary: Global coal-fired power demand is expected to reach a new high this year, driven by rapid economic recovery in China, India, and the US. The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts a 9% increase in global power generation from coal, reaching 10,350 terawatt hours in 2021. Overall coal demand is expected to grow 6% this year, with China responsible for over half of global coal-fired power generation and India's generation forecast to grow 12%. This could undermine efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions, with IEA executive director Fatih Birol calling it a "worrying sign" for the world's progress towards net zero.

site_title: Goldman triples Asia ESG investments as bets start paying off
summary: Goldman Sachs has tripled its environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investments in Asia, with nearly 15 investments completed in the past two years, up from four during the previous period. The bank is expanding its push into other types of environmental and socially responsible projects, including clean energy and disability housing. Goldman's efforts come as the global pandemic has underscored the need for greater social investing, and the growing climate crisis is accelerating the focus on ESG. The bank has committed to reducing the carbon footprint of its fossil-fuel clients by a fifth and slashing emissions in other key customer groups.

site_title: Indonesia may see tighter monetary policy in 2022: Fitch Solutions
summary: Indonesia is likely to see a tighter monetary policy in 2022 to support its slow economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite Bank Indonesia's decision to keep the benchmark 7-day repurchase rate unchanged at 3.5% for the 10th consecutive month, Fitch Solutions expects the central bank to raise the rate by 50 basis points in 2022. This is due to rising price pressures, expected annual average inflation of 3.5% in 2022, and the country's large dependence on external financing.

site_title: Brokers' take: OCBC, UOBKH, RHB retain 'buy' on certain property players despite fresh cooling measures
summary: Brokerages OCBC and UOBKH have retained "buy" ratings on certain property players despite fresh cooling measures, citing cheap valuations and limited downsides. OCBC analysts believe share prices will stabilize in the near term, while UOBKH analyst Adrian Loh notes valuations are "not stretched" and the market will adjust to the new normal. RHB, however, downgraded its rating on the sector, citing expected sharp impact on near-term sale volumes and price momentum. Analysts have set target prices for specific stocks, including CDL, CapitaLand Investment, UOL Group, and PropNex.

site_title: Slumping glove stocks drag down entire Malaysian equity market
summary: Malaysia's equity market has declined 8.6% this year, with nearly two-thirds attributed to rubber glove exporters, which were a pandemic hotspot last year. Top Glove and Hartalega Holdings are the biggest contributors to the decline. Investors are shifting focus to reopening plays and vaccinations, and the sector's weight in the benchmark index has shrunk to 4% from over 10% last year. The outlook for 2022 remains tepid due to corporate earnings risks and political uncertainty.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip as global inflation, Omicron fears sap confidence
summary: Asian stocks slipped on Friday as investors lost confidence due to growing global inflation concerns and Omicron fears. The US dollar index fell, and yields on Treasury notes decreased, while the pound rose after the Bank of England raised interest rates. Asian markets, including Japan's Nikkei and the Hong Kong benchmark, also declined. The decline was partly attributed to renewed investor attention on tense Sino-US relations, with the US government imposing investment and export restrictions on Chinese companies.

site_title: Japan PM to seek maiden US visit as early as January 2022: sources
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida aims to visit the US as early as January 2022, despite initially planning for this year due to tight US schedules. The US administration's focus on a social bill delayed the visit, with a new target date set between January and January 17, potentially pushed to February or later. Kishida previously met with US President Joe Biden at the COP26 climate conference last month, indicating the trip's impact on bilateral relations will be minimal.

site_title: Pubs, parties push Australia's Covid-19 cases to record levels
summary: Australia has reported a record 3,820 Covid-19 cases, with cases in New South Wales and Victoria exceeding 3,400 a day, as the Omicron variant spreads in pubs and nightclubs. Authorities have identified at least 97 cases, including potential Omicron cases, among Taylor Swift album party attendees. Despite the surge, Prime Minister Scott Morrison ruled out lockdowns, citing the need to focus on hospitalization and intensive care. Booster vaccine shots are being accelerated to combat the Omicron strain, with daily cases in New South Wales potentially reaching 25,000 by the end of January.

site_title: Commodity trader Noble reaches agreement with creditors on US$1 billion of debt
summary: Noble Group Holdings, a Hong Kong-based commodities trading company, has reached an agreement with creditors to reduce US$1 billion of debt as part of a restructuring plan. The plan involves exchanging bonds for new notes and shares, with the goal of bolstering operations. The agreement is expected to complete by March 2022 and includes increased trade finance funding. The move is seen as a step towards a sustainable capital structure for the company, which has been undergoing significant restructuring efforts since its market value was severely impacted in 2015.

site_title: Stock to watch: SingHaiyi Group
summary: SingHaiyi Group, a property developer, lost its free float after securing 95.8% valid acceptances for a voluntary unconditional cash offer. The offer remains open until Jan 10, 2022, after which its offerors intend to delist the company. Shares ended 0.9% higher at S$0.117 on Thursday.

images.alt_text: SingHaiyi on Friday morning said it has lost its free float, after a voluntary unconditional cash offer for the group secured 95.8 per cent valid acceptances as at 6 pm on Dec 16.

site_title: Shimao bonds jump on report the Chinese developer plans to repay debts
summary: Shimao Group Holdings, a Chinese property developer, plans to repay publicly-issued debts due this month, according to a financial intelligence provider. This move led to a surge in bonds sold by Shimao's subsidiaries, with one bond jumping over 7% in value. The developer also plans to pay migrant workers salaries before the Chinese New Year. This news comes as Chinese regulators have been cracking down on the heavily indebted property sector, with rules capping new debt issuance. Shimao's shares and debt have been under strain earlier this month due to concerns over an asset sale and cancelled apartment deals.

site_title: Tee International to wind up Trans Equatorial Engineering on cash flow issues
summary: Tee International is winding up its subsidiary Trans Equatorial Engineering due to cash flow issues. The subsidiary, which installs industrial machinery and provides engineering services, has 136 claims totaling S$128.9 million against it. Tee International also faces 3 claims amounting to S$13.7 million. The group has appointed provisional liquidators and declared that none of its directors or substantial shareholders have an interest in the subsidiary's voluntary liquidation. This comes after a public reprimand of Tee International and two former C-suite executives for breaching mainboard listing rules.

site_title: Former McDonald's CEO repays company US$105m
summary: Former McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook has repaid the company $105 million in cash and stock, settling a contentious lawsuit over his dismissal in 2019 for an inappropriate relationship with an employee. Easterbrook had been accused of lying to investigators and exploiting his position as CEO. As part of the deal, McDonald's dropped its lawsuit against Easterbrook. The repayment comes after a year-long battle between the two parties, with Easterbrook apologizing for his mistakes and acknowledging that he failed to uphold McDonald's values.

site_title: Gold prices set for best week in 5 after Fed decision
summary: Gold prices are on track for their best week in 5 years, rising 0.8% after the US Federal Reserve decided to withdraw pandemic-era stimulus, making bullion cheaper for holders of other currencies. Spot gold was flat at US$1,797.47 per ounce, while US gold futures edged up 0.1% to US$1,799.80. This marks the first weekly gain in 5 weeks, as the dollar weakened following the Fed's decision.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on December 17, 2021, due to profit-taking after a strong rally in the previous session. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.71% or 205.44 points to 28,860.88, while the Topix index slipped 0.38% or 7.75 points to 2,005.33. Investors awaited the Bank of Japan's policy decision later in the day.

site_title: SingHaiyi loses free float, to delist after offer secures 95.8% valid acceptances
summary: SingHaiyi, a property developer, has secured 95.8% valid acceptances of a voluntary cash offer from its controlling shareholders, Gordon and Celine Tang. The offer, at S$0.117 per share, represents a 21.8% discount to the group's net asset value. As a result, SingHaiyi will lose its free float and be delisted, with less than 10% of shares now held by the public. Trading of the company's shares will be suspended on Jan 10, 2022, when the offer's close.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start day slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.05% lower on Friday, following US sanctions and trade curbs on China. The Hang Seng Index fell 11.72 points to 23,463.78, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The losses come amid US-EU trade talks and concerns over China's treatment of the Uyghur minority.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% at the opening of trade on Friday, December 17, following the negative lead from Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,125.71, with 29.7 million securities worth S$47.2 million changing hands. Non-oil domestic exports growth surged 24.2% year-over-year, beating the median forecast of 15.3%. Local banks were mixed, with DBS edging down 0.3%, UOB rising 0.1%, and OCBC rising 0.3%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1% on Wall Street, while European shares had their best day in over a week.

site_title: Evergrande boss leads US$46b in lost wealth for China's property tycoons
summary: Chinese property tycoons have lost a combined US$46 billion in wealth this year, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Evergrande founder Hui Ka Yan's wealth has plummeted by US$17.2 billion, and the company's bonds and shares are trading near record lows after failing to honor obligations. The government's crackdown on debt binge and aim to redistribute wealth has led to a slowdown in the real estate sector, with some tycoons losing their billionaire status. China is expected to add fiscal stimulus to stabilize its economy, but restructurings are likely to be challenging.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, December 17, 2021, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.3 points or 0.02% to 1,484.30. Losers outnumbered gainers 144 to 110, with a trading volume of 86.7 million lots worth approximately RM50 million.

site_title: UK, Australia sign deal forecast to create £10b in extra trade
summary: The UK and Australia have signed a free trade deal, forecast to boost bilateral trade by over £10 billion. The deal eliminates tariffs on Australian wine, beef, and other goods, while allowing for freer movement of service-sector professionals. It also includes provisions to protect British farmers and encourages British businesses to invest in Australia. The agreement is seen as a key step towards the UK's membership in a trans-Pacific trade bloc, and its impact is expected to boost the UK economy by £2.3 billion per year and unlock £10.4 billion of imports and exports by 2035.

site_title: Golf: Woods in final group at PNC Championship on highly anticipated return
summary: Tiger Woods will tee off in the final group at the PNC Championship, a 2-day 36-hole tournament in Orlando, Florida, alongside Justin Thomas and his son Mike. Woods, who has not competed since the 2020 PNC Championship, returns to golf after a car crash in February that left him with serious leg injuries. He will play with his 12-year-old son Charlie, and Thomas expressed excitement and low expectations for Woods' performance.

site_title: Binance in talks with Dubai, Abu Dhabi on headquarters plan: sources
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, is in talks with Dubai and Abu Dhabi to establish its global headquarters. The company, founded in China in 2017, has been exploring options to set up a headquarters in a regulated financial institution. Binance's CEO, Changpeng "CZ" Zhao, has expressed a preference for the UAE, citing its "pro-crypto" stance. The company has held discussions with officials from Abu Dhabi Global Market, Dubai International Financial Centre, and Dubai Multi Commodities Centre, and plans to make a major announcement on its headquarters plans next year.

site_title: US Senate backs Biden nominee Burns to be ambassador to China
summary: The US Senate has confirmed President Joe Biden's nomination of Nicholas Burns as ambassador to China, with a vote of 69-18. Burns, a former US ambassador to NATO and under secretary of state, is seen as a seasoned diplomat for the increasingly tense US-China relations. The White House announced a boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing due to China's human rights "atrocities." It's unclear when Burns will take up the post, but his confirmation marks a shift towards experienced diplomats in the role.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sets 2030 carbon emissions reduction targets
summary: Goldman Sachs has set ambitious carbon emissions reduction targets, aiming to cut emissions in oil and gas, power, and auto manufacturing by 17-22%, 48-65%, and 49-54% respectively by 2030. The bank will consider using carbon credits to achieve these goals, and its CEO, David Solomon, emphasized the bank's role in driving decarbonization in the real economy. However, critics argue that the targets are not enough, and campaigners are calling for an immediate halt to support for fossil fuel expansion.

site_title: Facebook exposes mercenary spy firms that targeted 50,000 people
summary: Facebook has exposed six private surveillance companies for hacking or abusing their services, targeting approximately 50,000 people across its platforms. The companies, which include firms from Israel, were accused of deploying digital espionage services, similar to the blacklisted NSO Group. Meta is suing NSO in a US court and is taking action against the other companies, amid a broader effort to combat digital espionage services. This move comes as American tech companies, lawmakers, and the Biden administration work to crack down on purveyors of digital espionage services.

site_title: Blockchain startup Nansen raises US$75m from investors including GIC
summary: Blockchain analytics firm Nansen has raised US$75 million in a Series B funding round led by Accel, with participation from Andreessen Horowitz, Tiger Global, GIC, and SCB 10X. The company plans to expand its blockchain analytics platform, which helps protect crypto assets. The funding will support the development of new features and enhance user protection. Nansen aims to utilize the funds to further strengthen its position in the blockchain analytics market.

site_title: BandLab raises US$53m in Series B round led by Vulcan Capital
summary: BandLab, a Singapore-based social music platform, has raised US$53 million in a Series B round led by Vulcan Capital, valuing the company at US$303 million. The funding will be used to expand the team and refine product offerings, including an artificial intelligence-powered idea generator and recently acquired ReverbNation. BandLab aims to prioritize artist compensation and rights protection, addressing a major barrier to artist growth. The company was founded by Kuok Meng Ru, son of billionaire Kuok Khoon Hong, and will use the funding to further develop its creator tools and services.

site_title: Elizabeth Holmes' intent takes centre stage as Theranos fraud trial draws to close
summary: US prosecutor says Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes lied to investors to obtain funding, while her lawyer argues she never meant to deceive. Holmes, 37, faces 9 counts of fraud and 2 counts of conspiracy for her role in the failed blood-testing startup. Prosecutors presented testimony from over two dozen witnesses, including investors and patients who received inaccurate results. Holmes' lawyer claims she relied on positive internal feedback when discussing the company publicly. The jury is now deciding whether Holmes' intent was to deceive investors.

site_title: FedEx reinstates 2022 profit target, shares soar
summary: FedEx has reinstated its original fiscal 2022 profit target, despite labour woes affecting profits ahead of the peak holiday season. The company reported flat year-over-year adjusted profit for the fiscal second quarter and shares rose 5% to $250.50 in after-hours trading. FedEx now expects full-year earnings of $20.50 to $21.50 per share, unchanged from its original forecast. The company attributes easing labour pressures to being "staffed up for peak" and believes it can retain required labour for the remainder of its fiscal year.

images.alt_text: US delivery firm FedEx reinstated its original fiscal 2022 forecast on Thursday (Dec 16), even as persistent labour woes chipped away profits ahead of the peak holiday season when the number of packages it handles often doubles.

site_title: Powell's hawkish tune gets equities going as bonds take a back seat
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's hawkish tone on inflation sparked a risk-on pivot, with stocks rising and bonds retreating. The Fed accelerated its asset-purchase program drawdown and outlined a road map for 8 interest-rate increases through 2024, raising the possibility of liquidity reduction. Despite initial concerns, equity strategists see a median 3.5% gain for the S&P 500 Index over the ensuing year, and currency strategists expect the US dollar's weakness to be short-lived.

site_title: Singapore exports surge in November as electronics boom continues; NODX up 24.2%
summary: Singapore's exports surged 24.2% year-over-year in November, driven by non-electronics products and electronics, with electronics exports rising 29.2%. This marks the 12th consecutive month of growth, exceeding forecasts. Strong demand from mainland China, Taiwan, and South Korea contributed to the growth, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) reaching a seasonally-adjusted peak in the first quarter of 2021. The strong momentum is expected to boost Singapore's growth outlook for the fourth quarter of 2021.

site_title: Pfizer files for full FDA approval of Covid-19 vaccine in adolescents
summary: Pfizer has filed for full FDA approval of its Covid-19 vaccine for adolescents aged 12-15, following its existing emergency use authorization for 5-15 year olds. The vaccine showed 100% effectiveness against Covid-19 in a late-stage study of adolescents. This marks the first time a Covid-19 vaccine has been approved for this age group in the US. Pfizer expects to file for approval with the European Medicines Agency and other regulatory authorities in the coming weeks.

site_title: Oil rises around 2% on strong US demand, upbeat Fed outlook
summary: Oil prices rose around 2% on Thursday, driven by strong US demand, falling crude stockpiles, and an upbeat economic outlook from the Federal Reserve. Brent crude oil rose 1.5% to $75.02 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 2.1% to $72.38 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration reported record US implied demand and a 4.6 million-barrel drop in US crude stocks. However, concerns about the Omicron variant and potential supply surplus next year limited gains.

site_title: Vast study confirms rare heart risk from Moderna jab
summary: A study in Denmark found that the Moderna Covid-19 jab carries a slight risk of heart problems, specifically myocarditis and pericarditis, mainly among individuals aged 12-39 years. The study, published in the BMJ, noted that vaccination with Pfizer was associated with an increased risk among women, while vaccination with Moderna was associated with a significantly increased rate of heart inflammation. Despite the risks, the study concluded that they are low and outweighed by the benefits of vaccination against Covid-19.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally as ECB promises support
summary: European shares rose 1.2% and 0.9% in the pan-European Stoxx 600 and euro zone index, respectively, driven by gains in banks and miners after the European Central Bank (ECB) promised continued support to the economy. The ECB will wind down its stimulus by March and double bond buys to 40 billion euros in the second quarter. Despite higher inflation projections, the ECB remains dovish compared to peers, and the decision comes after the Bank of England raised borrowing costs.

site_title: Airbus executive says latest order wins strengthen case for jet output hike
summary: Airbus has strengthened its case for increasing production of its A320-family narrowbody jets beyond its target of 65 a month, according to the company's chief commercial officer Christian Scherer. Recent orders from Qantas and Air France-KLM have reinforced Airbus' ambitions, despite reservations from suppliers and leasing firms. The company plans to increase output to 65 a month and is considering rates as high as 75. The latest orders also generated a breakthrough for US engine maker Pratt & Whitney at Qantas, with sales of new A350 freighters to two airlines in just a few days.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends sharply lower as investors dump growth stocks
summary: The US Nasdaq ended sharply lower on Dec 16, with tech giants like Nvidia, Apple, and Microsoft tumbling between 2.6% and 6.8% due to the Federal Reserve's announcement of faster end to pandemic-era stimulus. The Fed signaled 3-quarter-percentage-point interest rate hikes by the end of 2022, prompting investors to shift to more economically sensitive sectors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined marginally, while the S&P 500 lost 0.87%, with the Nasdaq Composite dropping 2.47%.

site_title: Fretting about data security, China's government expands its use of 'golden shares'
summary: China's government has expanded its use of "golden shares" to private companies with large amounts of key data, following a tougher stance on data protection. Authorities have taken minority stakes in firms such as Full Truck Alliance Co and Didi Global, gaining a board seat and/or veto rights for key business decisions. The move aims to ensure data security and control over national assets at risk of attack and misuse. This expansion is in line with China's new data security law, which went into effect in September.

site_title: Euro and sterling rise ahead of banks' policy meetings
summary: The euro and sterling rose ahead of Bank of England and European Central Bank monetary policy meetings, driven by investors' anticipation of potential interest rate hikes. The euro rose 0.2% versus the US dollar, while sterling rose 0.2% against the greenback, following the US Federal Reserve's decision to end pandemic-era bond buying and pave the way for 3 interest rate hikes in 2022. The BoE meeting and ECB meeting are expected to have minimal impact on the markets.

site_title: EV startup Rivian to build US$5b plant in Georgia, posts quarterly loss
summary: Rivian, an Amazon-backed electric vehicle startup, plans to build a $5 billion plant in Georgia, its second US assembly plant, to expand production. The company posted a third-quarter net loss of $1.2 billion, citing global supply-chain constraints, the pandemic, and labor market issues. Despite this, Rivian aims to ship its first vans to Amazon this month and plans to increase production of its vehicles. The new plant, set to open in 2024, will employ over 7,500 people and build 400,000 vehicles per year.

site_title: Wall Street firms retreat from office, holiday parties as virus spreads
summary: Wall Street banks and investment firms are adjusting their plans to return to office work due to the spread of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus. Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, Carlyle Group, Blackstone, and MetLife have all retreated from their push to get staff back to the office, with some allowing staff to work from home or postponing plans for in-person returns. The institutions are citing growing concerns over the fast-spreading Omicron and a spike in Covid-19 cases in financial hubs.

site_title: Taiwan central bank raises GDP forecast
summary: Taiwan's central bank raised its 2021 GDP forecast to 6.03% from 5.75% due to strong exports bolstering its technology-reliant economy. The bank maintained the benchmark discount rate at a record low of 1.125% and indicated a possibility of a rate hike next year. This decision comes as the US Federal Reserve prepares to end pandemic-era bond purchases and pave the way for interest rate hikes. The bank's governor stated that the economy is not overheating and inflation is in a controllable range.

site_title: A digital assistant to enable local businesses to expand in China
summary: Tencent Cloud is supporting local businesses to expand in China through its innovative cloud solutions. The company has reported strong revenue growth over the past two years, driven by the global demand for cloud-based solutions. According to Poshu Yeung, Senior Vice-President, Tencent Cloud International, businesses are recognizing the importance of the cloud in driving digital transformation and demand for cloud-based solutions has grown in tandem with companies shifting to a digital-first presence. This expansion aims to unlock the potential of emerging technologies such as AI and the Internet of Things in China.

images.alt_text: The fiancée of Jamal Khashoggi on Monday criticised President Donald Trump's response to his killing, urging him to set aside US trade interests in the push for truth, and demanded Riyadh disclose more details to bring those who ordered it to justice.

'We do not believe in the cookie-cutter approach; we customise and develop solutions that are tailored to the unique demands of each customer. This continues to be our commitment to our clients as we collaborate with them to expand into China and other parts of the world,' says Poshu Yeung, Senior Vice President, Tencent Cloud International

site_title: 10 things to entertain you this X'mas
summary: This X'mas season, entertainment options range from music albums like Norah Jones' retro-style "I Dream Of Christmas" and Michael Buble's "Christmas (The Deluxe Edition)", to Christmas movies such as "A Boy Called Christmas" on Netflix and "A Castle For Christmas" starring Brooke Shields. Book recommendations include "The Christmas Bookshop" by Jenny Colgan and "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens, while a new children's book "The Christmas Pig" by JK Rowling has sparked controversy. Additionally, a new card game "The Singaporean Dream: The New Normal" offers a humorous take on life during the pandemic.

site_title: Grooming the next generation of project managers
summary: Singapore's construction industry faces growing demand for transformational infrastructure projects, driven by the world's growing urban population and accelerated climate change. The government plans to issue $90 billion worth of new bonds to support infrastructure development, including new MRT lines and tidal walls to cope with rising sea levels. To meet this demand, the Project Management Institute (PMI) has introduced a new certification, Construction Professional in Built Environment Projects (CPBEP), which includes seven online learning courses to equip professionals with the skills needed to manage complex projects on time and within budget, leveraging digital and productivity-enhancing solutions.

site_title: China tycoon's daughter bought Asia's priciest apartment: SCMP
summary: LAU Chauin, daughter of Heungkong Group chairman Lau Chi-keung, purchased Asia's most expensive apartment, flats 16C and 16D in the Mount Nicholson development on The Peak in Hong Kong, for a combined HK$1.2 billion (S$210 million). The transaction marks a significant sale in the city's luxury real estate market.

site_title: Manpower Minister urges financial practitioners to build deep domain knowledge, among other advices
summary: Singapore's Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng urged financial practitioners to develop deep domain knowledge and acquire horizontal skills to seize opportunities. He noted the demand for private equity and venture capital as companies seek strategic investors to scale up and access business connections, technology, and expertise.

site_title: What does workplace sexual harassment do to a victim's career?
summary: A senior manager at a multinational corporation was harassed by the CEO, including daily texting with inappropriate comments and eventually physical harassment at her cubicle. Despite declining the CEO's advances, she was let go without a clear reason, suspecting her harassment experience was the cause. This case highlights the impact of workplace sexual harassment on a victim's career, potentially leading to job loss and career setbacks.

images.alt_text: The experience of workplace sexual harassment can have knock-on effects on victims' career-related decision-making processes.

site_title: In pursuit of under S$100 Japanese dining
summary: Yamato Japanese Restaurant and Hanare by Takayama offer affordable Japanese dining options under S$100. Yamato's omakase starts at S$68 and can go up to S$198, with a S$98 set that is simple yet fresh and priced well. The S$138 set offers additional ingredients and better quality. In contrast, Hanare by Takayama's kamameshi, a claypot rice dish, is underwhelming and lacks variety, with a price that doesn't justify the experience. Yamato has the edge over its competitors, offering no surprises and genuine quality at a reasonable price.

images.alt_text: Above: Hanare by Takayama's unagi kamameshi served with miso soup and pickles.
Above: Yamato's trio of appetisers comprises a disc of ankimo, chrysanthemum jelly with ikura, and sliced roast beef with mustard.
Left: Hanare's box of appetisers includes sashimi, vinegared dish and miso cod; (right) Yamato's pork belly hot pot features an earthy miso broth.

site_title: Inflation starting to chip away at world's debt burdens
summary: Inflation is reducing debt burdens globally, with household and business debt as a share of economic output experiencing record drops in the second quarter of 2021. This decline is due to inflation eroding debt liabilities, not a decrease in borrowing, as consumers and companies continue to borrow more. Almost every type of debt remains larger than it was at the start of 2020, with the US corporate borrowing spree raising red flags. Rising interest rates will make debt servicing harder, and central banks are pivoting from aiming for higher inflation to managing it.

site_title: Sweden turning into Europe hub for impact investors
summary: Sweden is emerging as Europe's largest hub for impact investors, attracting a record $4.5 billion in funding for sustainable startups this year. The country's venture capital firms, such as Norrsken VC, are investing in ventures addressing climate change, social impact, and governance issues. Sweden's thriving tech ecosystem, encouraged by a supportive public policy framework, is driving this growth, with billionaire founders reinvesting in the system to support impact-driven investments. This trend is expected to continue, with ESG assets projected to exceed $50 trillion by 2025.

site_title: UBS in talks with China Life for asset management JV: sources
summary: UBS Group AG is in talks with China Life Insurance Group to launch an asset management joint venture in China, as part of the Swiss bank's plan to bolster its presence in the country. UBS will hold a majority stake in the business unit, which would be China's first foreign majority-owned asset management joint venture with an insurer since 2019. The joint venture aims to expand UBS' asset management capabilities in China, a key market for the bank's growth strategy.

site_title: Singapore home prices buoyant as demographics support demand
summary: Singapore's home prices remain buoyant due to demographic support, despite low interest rates and supply concerns. The NUS Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies (IREUS) attributes this to the baby-boomer generation driving demand since the 1980s. However, as this generation exits the market, and live births decline, demographically driven demand may slow. Countries with rapidly ageing populations, like Japan, have seen their residential sectors slow down, suggesting a similar trend in Singapore may occur. This could impact the housing market, particularly for prime projects above S$3,000 psf.

site_title: The holidays are for Martinelli's
summary: Martinelli's sparkling cider is a holiday staple, particularly for dads, with 70-75% of its 25.4-ounce bottles sold between Halloween and New Year's Eve. The non-alcoholic beverage, dating back to Prohibition, was initially marketed as a "delightfully nonalcoholic" alternative to champagne. Its popularity soared after a viral TikTok challenge, resulting in 40 million additional bottles sold in the single-serve category. The brand, now led by a non-family member, aims to maintain its "premium fruit forward product" vision while embracing marketing changes, including leveraging social media platforms like TikTok.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) announced a 39% increase in private housing supply in the confirmed list of the Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme for first-half 2022, with 2,785 units to be released. The Singapore government also introduced cooling measures, including higher buyer's stamp duty rates, a tightened debt servicing ratio threshold, and a lower loan-to-value limit for HDB loans. Meanwhile, the sale of Eagle Hospitality Trust's New Jersey hotel for US$23.5m fell short of covering the entire mortgage loan, and Italy banned tourists from Singapore until January 31 next year.

site_title: India's ShareChat raises US$266m from investors including Temasek
summary: Indian content-sharing platform ShareChat has raised US$266 million in fresh funding from investors including Temasek, valuing the company at US$3.7 billion. The funding, led by Alkeon Capital and Moore Strategic Ventures, is part of ShareChat's third funding round this year. The platform, which has 180 million active users, will use the funds to develop artificial intelligence capabilities and strengthen its market position. ShareChat's short-video app Moj has 160 million users and competes with Meta Platforms' Instagram Reels. The funding comes as Indian consumers increasingly consume digital video content through apps and streaming platforms.

site_title: Qatar's record bet on London homes sees close to £700m of sales
summary: Qatari Diar Real Estate Investment's Chelsea Barracks in London has seen significant progress 14 years after the project's inception, with properties worth about £200 million sold this year, bringing the total to about £683 million. The deal, which was once marred by controversy, costly redesigns, and a split with co-developer, has now paid off. The project's sales demonstrate a rebound in UK homebuyer demand, with the index showing a six-month high in July.

site_title: MND ups confirmed-list private housing supply, but developers may still be hungry
summary: Singapore's Ministry of National Development (MND) has announced a 39% increase in private housing supply for the first half of 2022, with 4 new sites released on the confirmed list, yielding 2,785 residential units. The increase aims to address the dwindling inventory of unsold homes, but analysts note that the 5 available sites may not be enough to satisfy developers' hunger. The new supply, including 2,290 private homes, is the highest since 2018, but experts predict that developers will increasingly look towards the reserve list for smaller plots.

site_title: Eurozone business growth slipped in December as Omicron rose
summary: Eurozone business growth slowed in December due to renewed coronavirus restrictions and Omicron variant. The services industry, a key driver of growth, declined to an 8-month low, with demand for services dropping to its lowest since April. However, price pressures eased, and forward-looking indicators showed optimism about the year ahead. The Eurozone's Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 53.4, below expectations, and the manufacturing PMI also dipped to a 10-month low.

site_title: When time travel is good for us all: What history can teach us about the future
summary: A new perspective on time travel can help us create a better future by examining our past and understanding how we got to the current crises. Historian and futurist suggest that looking back at past lessons, both good and bad, is crucial to learning and making informed decisions. By understanding the past and its impact on the present, we can break free from flawed systems and create a more sustainable future. The article highlights the importance of storytelling, agency, and the need to reclaim our past to shape a better future.

site_title: Pandemic sparks digital brokerage boom; incumbents unfazed
summary: A pandemic-induced retail trading frenzy has sparked a digital brokerage boom in Singapore, with over 15 online trading platforms catering to younger investors. New entrants, such as Syfe Trade and Revolut, offer commission-free trades, cash credits, and fractional trading, targeting the younger demographic. Existing players remain unfazed, focusing on simplifying their interfaces and reducing costs. The competition is expected to benefit investors with lower fees, but it's not just about pricing; innovative value-added services will be key differentiators. The brokerage space is seen as a springboard for fintech companies to offer comprehensive services.

site_title: The artist who predicted the Internet age
summary: Nam June Paik, a Korean-American artist, is hailed as the "father of video art" and envisioned the Internet age, including Zoom, social media, and digital images, in the 1970s. His 1988 TV show "Wrap Around The World" linked people across the globe, while his 1974 work "TV Buddha" anticipated the selfie obsession. Paik's artworks, now on display at the National Gallery Singapore, chronicle his globe-spanning career and infuse Eastern philosophy into his practice. The exhibition highlights Paik's visionary contributions to video art, technology, and other fields, including music and performance.

site_title: All set for parties
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article highlights festive home decor ideas for Christmas parties in Singapore. It suggests adding a wreath on the door, using fabric decals to create a Christmas tree pattern, and dressing up the dining table with handmade tableware and velvet cushions. Other ideas include bringing home a winter wonderland, using a hinoki bottle chiller, and incorporating luxurious elements such as satin-print ottomans and marble tableware. The article also features local designers and brands, including Wonderland Botanicals, Ong Shunmugam, and Scene Shang, offering unique and stylish solutions for a festive holiday season.

site_title: Chanel reopens fashion boutique
summary: Chanel has reopened its fashion boutique in Singapore's Takashimaya, featuring a 865 sqm space inspired by Gabrielle "Coco" Chanel's Parisian apartment. The store boasts contrasting materials, iconic tweed furnishings, and a selection of accessories, shoes, and fine jewelry. The second floor showcases Chanel's ready-to-wear creations, accompanied by art pieces and photographs. The boutique offers the Cruise 2021/22 ready-to-wear collection, which combines playfulness and elegance, as a response to challenging global travel conditions.

site_title: Life after death
summary: A Singapore-based taxidermy studio, Black Crow Taxidermy & Art, caters to clients seeking to preserve and display deceased pets as keepsakes. The studio's unique service has gained popularity among pet owners struggling to cope with their loss. For those willing to invest in luxury items, the article also explores the features and value of a high-end Jaguar F-Pace SVR.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after Fed gears up for inflation fight
summary: US stocks opened higher on December 16, 2021, after the Federal Reserve announced a faster wind-down of pandemic-era stimulus, calming concerns about surging price pressures. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 108.85 points, the S&P 500 gained 9.28 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 63.49 points. The news helped to ease nerves around inflation, leading to a positive start to the trading day.

site_title: BOE surprises with first hike in crisis to curb inflation
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) surprised markets by raising interest rates for the first time since the pandemic, hiking borrowing costs by 15 basis points to 0.25%, in an effort to curb surging inflation. The decision, led by Governor Andrew Bailey, comes as inflation reached 5.1% in November, double the central bank's target. The move is seen as a response to the threat posed by record coronavirus cases and is the first from the BOE since 2018.

site_title: Eurozone bonds shaken by central bank moves
summary: Eurozone government bond yields rose after the Bank of England raised interest rates and the European Central Bank cut stimulus, with the ECB pledging to continue monetary support in 2022. The ECB also extended its bond purchases, and bond yields in Germany and Italy rose as ECB President Christine Lagarde spoke. Analysts saw the move as dovish, and European shares and the euro rose after the announcement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.83 points to 1484.64, closing higher on Thursday. The market saw 2.829 billion lots worth RM2.352 billion traded, with 504 gainers and 361 losers.

site_title: Sterling hits December highs after BOE raises interest rates
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) raised its main interest rate to 0.25% on December 16, becoming the first major central bank to do so since the pandemic. This move boosted sterling, which rose 0.7% against the US dollar and euro, reaching its highest levels since November. Analysts expect the European Central Bank to be more dovish, which may influence sterling's future performance. The interest rate hike aims to combat inflation pressures in Britain, despite recent robust economic data.

site_title: ECB dials back pandemic support, holds rates at record lows
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced it will end its 1.85 trillion euro pandemic-era bond purchasing programme (PEPP) in March 2022, but will ramp up a pre-crisis asset buying scheme to ease the eurozone economy. The ECB will maintain interest rates at record lows, with a boost in asset purchases from 20 billion euros to 40 billion euros in the second quarter. This move aims to support the economy as it transitions out of pandemic-era support.

site_title: US housing starts rise more than forecast to 8-month high
summary: US housing starts rose 11.8% in November to a 1.68 million annualized rate, the fastest pace in 8 months, beating economists' expectations. This suggests builders are making progress on backlogs despite supply and labor constraints. Applications to build increased to 1.71 million units, indicating future construction growth.

site_title: SET looks towards attracting SMEs and foreign listings
summary: The Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) aims to attract small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and foreign listings, following its success in raising $4.9 billion in initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2021. SET president Pakorn Peetathawatchai notes that liquidity and economic growth have contributed to the exchange's success, and expects continued fundraising in the near future. The exchange plans to introduce a new board, LiVE Exchange, targeting early-stage companies and will consider special purpose acquisition companies. SET aims to broaden its appeal, promoting Thai companies, lifestyle and well-being sectors, and environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) compliance.

site_title: Get into the Christmas party mood
summary: Freelance stylist Crystal Yap shares her tips on hosting an intimate yet memorable Christmas party. She emphasizes the importance of starting with a theme, which elevates the fun and party factor for all guests. Guests can choose from various themes, such as a 1980s fashion theme or a color theme, to create a cohesive and Instagram-worthy atmosphere. Experts also suggest considering dietary restrictions, using seasonal ingredients, and setting the table with flowers or tropical decorations. To end the party, hosts can subtly signal it's time to leave by stopping drinks, turning down the music, or giving guests a small gift, such as personalized plates or spices.

site_title: Taiwan central bank raises GDP forecast, stands pat on rates
summary: Taiwan's central bank raised its 2021 GDP forecast to 6.03% due to strong exports driven by global demand for technology and a shortage of microchips. The bank maintained its benchmark interest rate at 1.125% for 2022, predicting 4.03% GDP growth. This growth is attributed to continued recovery in major economies and demand for new technologies. The central bank has kept its policy rate unchanged since March 2020, with exports bolstering Taiwan's trade-reliant economy.

site_title: Bank of England hikes interest rate to 0.25% to combat inflation
summary: The Bank of England increased its key interest rate from 0.10% to 0.25% to combat UK inflation, which rose to 5.1% in November, more than double the bank's 2% target. The decision was made despite concerns over the Omicron variant and supply chain disruptions. Policymakers deemed the hike "necessary" to return inflation to target levels, but maintained quantitative easing stimulus. The BoE forecasts inflation to hold around 5% for the winter period and peak at 6% in April 2022.

site_title: No Signboard insists litigation over beer deliveries not material financially
summary: No Signboard Holdings 1G6, a Catalist-listed restaurant operator, has assured the Singapore Exchange (SGX) that litigation over beer deliveries will not significantly impact its financial position or ability to operate. The company is involved in a dispute with wholesale distributors Sprawl Transport & Logistic, which claims S$1.55 million for alleged beer shortages. No Signboard has filed counter-claims, which the company requests be taken into account. The litigation is expected to have minimal financial implications.

site_title: Airbus wins Air France-KLM jet order in dramatic treble
summary: Airbus secured a deal to supply all or most of Air France-KLM's requirement for dozens of narrowbody jets, beating rival Boeing. The order is for A321 single-aisle jets, with Airbus also favored to win the remaining two Transavia budget units. This win follows Airbus's recent deal with Qantas in Australia, and shares in Air France-KLM extended gains after the announcement. The deal could involve a firm purchase of 80 aircraft with options for another 60-80, marking the airline's biggest single fleet transaction.

site_title: Affordability at risk as global property prices keep rising
summary: Global property prices are expected to continue rising, with nearly three-quarters of experts predicting increased prices and decreased affordability in major markets over the next two to three years. Housing prices are forecast to ease but not stop, with interest rates also expected to move higher. This outlook is based on a Reuters survey of 103 experts covering eight major world markets, highlighting concerns about the impact on affordability and potential market shifts.

site_title: BT Explains: Why might MAS buy gold?
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) bought 26.3 tonnes of gold in May and June, its first significant increase in gold reserves since at least 2000. Analysts believe this move may be a hedge against a falling US dollar, as gold prices tend to rise when the USD declines. The US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing and ongoing inflation concerns are also seen as factors driving interest in gold. Despite the significant purchase, MAS's total gold reserves still represent a relatively small portion of its overall reserves.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise moderately as labour market tightens
summary: The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose moderately, increasing by 18,000 to 206,000 for the week ended Dec 11. This remains consistent with tightening labor market conditions. Claims have declined from a record high of 6.149 million in early April 2020. Economists had forecast 200,000 applications, and the drop in prior week's claims was 18,000.

site_title: Hike in BTO supply may ease HDB resale price surge, but construction delays still a concern
summary: Singapore's HDB resale prices may ease slightly due to a 35% increase in build-to-order (BTO) flat supply over the next two years. Analysts expect the increased options to bring down prices, with PropNex projecting a 6-8% rise in resale prices for 2022. However, construction delays remain a concern, and experts warn that if new BTO flats are not completed on time, demand may shift to resale flats, potentially driving up prices. The government has also introduced measures to cool the property market, including a tightening of debt servicing ratio and reduced loan-to-value limit.

site_title: Evergrande creditors sue for claims topping 84 billion yuan
summary: Chinese creditors have sued China Evergrande Group for over $13 billion in allegedly overdue payments, totaling 84 billion yuan. A Chinese court accepted 367 cases, following financial regulators' instructions to resolve debt problems. Meanwhile, Shimao Group Holdings' shares jumped 11% after it sought loan extensions and new loans from banks to prevent a cash crunch. China's financial regulator is coordinating negotiations to stabilize the embattled developer.

site_title: China property firm says 'has lost touch' with company it gave US$300 million
summary: A Chinese property firm, China Fortune Land Development, reported it has lost contact with a money management firm, China Create Capital, to which it gave over $300 million in 2018. The company has filed a report with the Shanghai Stock Exchange, stating there's no way to judge the impact on its earnings. This is part of China's debt-crippled real estate sector's woes, following Evergrande's default on $1.2 billion of bond debt and Fortune Land's own default on a $530 million bond in March. The matter has been reported to Chinese police.

site_title: Bukit Timah condo project Perfect Ten dangles 5% discount amid cooling measures
summary: Singapore luxury condo Perfect Ten, set to launch on Dec 19, is offering a one-time 5% discount amid the latest cooling measures. The 230-unit freehold development, located along Bukit Timah Road, features unique attributes and values that appeal to buyers. The developer, CK Asset Holdings, aims to facilitate buyer decision-making with the discount, applicable to all buyers but only for one time. The project's selling prices range from S$2.5 million to S$4.4 million, despite the measures expected to clip investment demand for high-end homes.

site_title: Youth and women bearing brunt of job losses in South-east Asia
summary: Youth and women in South-east Asia, particularly in Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam, are bearing the brunt of job losses due to the Covid-19 pandemic. According to the Asian Development Bank, those aged 15-24 accounted for 45% of job losses, despite making up less than 15% of the workforce. Women, in particular, were more likely to leave the labor force to care for their families, with 60% of job losses in Thailand attributed to women. The pandemic has exacerbated existing inequalities and exposed social protection gaps, highlighting the need for countries to address these issues and invest in inclusive growth.

site_title: Singapore property developers will face 'immense' pressure from higher ABSD: Redas
summary: Singapore property developers will face significant pressure from the latest cooling measures, including a 35% land Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rate, according to Redas. The increased rates will require developers to compress their development and project completion periods to meet ABSD remission requirements. This will impose immense pressure on land acquisition and development, forcing developers to prioritize projects and sales to meet stringent ABSD requirements. The measures were seen as "rather unexpected" given the property market's recent recovery from the Covid-19 situation.

site_title: Investors, foreigners, en bloc hopefuls to bear brunt of new property cooling measures
