summary: Singapore's new property cooling measures, which kicked in on Dec 16, aim to temper the exuberance in the private residential and HDB resale markets. Higher ABSD rates (5-15%) and tightened debt servicing ratio and loan-to-value limits will significantly reduce investor appetite, especially for high-end homes. Foreign buyers, en bloc candidates, and developers will feel the pain, while first-time Singaporean and PR homebuyers are the least affected. The measures are expected to reduce investor interest and curb market exuberance.

site_title: China tells Evergrande to prioritise paying workers, suppliers
summary: China Evergrande Group is prioritizing payments to migrant workers and suppliers, particularly before the Chinese New Year holidays, to prevent social unrest. Authorities are focusing on ensuring payrolls are met before the holidays, when thousands of migrant construction workers reunite with their families. The government is also working to dissolve risks related to Evergrande, protect homebuyers, and ensure social stability. Officials are discussing options to make salary payments, including using unsold apartments or returning land-sale proceeds, and have authorized local governments to take charge of Evergrande's incomplete sites.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Thursday, following a rally across Asia and on Wall Street, as traders welcomed clarity from the Federal Reserve on its monetary policy plans. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.23%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased.

site_title: Eurozone business growth slips in Dec as Omicron rises
summary: Eurozone business growth slowed in December due to renewed restrictions to curb the Omicron variant, affecting the dominant services industry. The IHS Markit Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index dropped to 53.4, its lowest since March, and the services PMI sank to an 8-month low of 53.3. Despite a dip in demand for services, factories suffered somewhat, and manufacturing PMI fell to a 10-month low. Price pressures eased, but remained high, and the ECB may consider halving asset purchases in April.

site_title: Hot stocks: Property plays in the red on new housing cooling measures
summary: Singapore's property stocks fell on Thursday after the government announced new measures to cool the housing market. Developer stocks such as City Developments Limited (CDL) and UOL dropped 2.7% and 0.9% respectively. Real estate agencies PropNex and APAC Realty also fell. The government raised additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rates and tightened the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) threshold, impacting property developers and investors.

site_title: Indonesia, Philippines hold key rates steady as recoveries gain speed
summary: Indonesia and the Philippines' central banks maintained their key interest rates steady, as economic recoveries gain momentum. Indonesia's Bank Indonesia kept the benchmark rate at 3.5% and the Philippines' Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas left it at 2%, despite concerns about emerging-market fallout from the Federal Reserve's decision. The decisions were in line with market expectations and followed the announcement that inflation in both countries is manageable, allowing for a patient approach to monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas left the benchmark rate at 2 per cent on Thursday (Dec 16), as predicted by all 20 economists in a Bloomberg survey.

site_title: Australia: CSL, energy stocks drag shares lower; tech rally limits losses
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.4% to close at 7,295.7, driven by a 8.8% drop in CSL, a healthcare firm announcing a discounted US$5 billion placement. Energy stocks fell 1.2%, with Beach Energy losing 2%, while tech stocks rallied 2.1% in tandem with US peers. Despite a blow-out monthly jobs report and rate hike expectations, the benchmark index extended losses into a third straight session.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher on Thursday, STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 3,128.80 on Thursday, driven by US Federal Reserve officials' announcement of doubling the pace of tapering and forecasting interest rate hikes in 2022 and 2023. Local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC were top advancers, while Isetan and property players City Developments, Hongkong Land, and Bukit Sembawang fell due to the latest property cooling measures. The market saw 941 million stocks worth S$979.1 million change hands, with HGH Holdings being the most actively traded counter.

site_title: China: Blue chips end higher as industrials, financials gain
summary: China's blue-chip stock index rose 0.75% to 3,675.02 points, driven by gains in industrial and financial sectors. The CSI300 index rose 0.58%, despite a 0.92% drop in consumer staples firms. Energy shares surged 1.23% due to strong oil and coal prices. A-shares of companies on the verge of being added to US blacklists also rose, while China's H-share index fell 22.7% this year.

site_title: China issues 1.46 trillion yuan in 2022 advance local bond quota
summary: China has issued 1.46 trillion yuan in 2022 advance local bond quota to spur investment and support the economy. The move aims to focus on key investment projects in the first quarter of 2022. China also plans to launch pilot schemes in Shanghai and Guangdong to eliminate hidden local debt.

site_title: SenseTime plans Hong Kong IPO re-launch Monday: sources
summary: Chinese AI startup SenseTime Group plans to re-launch its withdrawn Hong Kong IPO on Monday, Dec 20, at a deal size of US$767 million, according to sources. The company had withdrawn its IPO on Dec 13 after being added to a US investment blacklist due to concerns over its facial recognition program. SenseTime had initially planned to sell 1.5 billion shares at a price range of HK$3.85 to HK$3.99 each. The re-launch is pending approval from the Hong Kong exchange on amended risk disclosures.

site_title: Proposed due diligence requirements for CF advisers timely: industry experts
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed due diligence requirements for corporate finance advisers, aiming to improve the quality of disclosures from entities seeking to raise funds from the public. The proposed requirements, set to be introduced via a new notice, will mandate CF advisers to act with "due care, skill and diligence" when performing due diligence and establish a governance framework for their representatives and staff. Industry experts say the introduction of the notice is timely, as it will enhance existing general conduct requirements and provide legal "teeth" to the existing standards, ultimately leading to more informed investor decisions.

images.alt_text: MAS and CAD jointly launched the probe on Samtrade FX for potential offences under local securities laws.

site_title: Woman arrested, S$4.4m seized in Singapore-HK joint op against suspected cross-border pump-and-dump syndicate
summary: A Singapore-based woman was arrested in a joint operation between Singapore and Hong Kong authorities, with S$4.4 million in cash seized. The operation targeted a suspected cross-border pump-and-dump syndicate, where the woman allegedly artificially inflated stock prices and sold them to victims. This is the first joint operation to tackle such scams. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department coordinated with the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission and police to launch the investigation, using Singapore's Securities and Futures Act to prosecute the offence.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index up more than 2% after Fed decision
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose over 2% on Thursday, following the US Federal Reserve's more muscular stance on inflation, which extended rallies on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 jumped 2.13% to 29,066.32, while the Topix index gained 1.46% to 2,013.08.

site_title: India's ShareChat raises US$266m from investors including Temasek
summary: Indian content-sharing platform ShareChat raised $266 million in fresh funding from investors including Temasek, pushing its valuation to $3.7 billion. The funding round, led by Alkeon Capital, follows previous investments from Temasek and Moore Strategic Ventures. ShareChat, which has 180 million active users, aims to strengthen its position with the funds to develop artificial intelligence capabilities and deliver immersive social experiences. The company's short-video sharing app, Moj, has 160 million users and counts Meta's Instagram Reels as a rival.

site_title: South Korea central bank warns against inflation, leaves door open for Jan hike
summary: South Korea's central bank Governor Lee Ju-yeol warned of increasing inflation threats, citing a 3.7% consumer inflation rate in November and a 1.9% core CPI. The bank left the door open for an interest rate hike as early as January, with Lee stating the benchmark rate could be raised at the next review meeting on January 14. The bank's inflation outlook remains at 2% for next year, but upside risks seem bigger, prompting a cautious approach to monetary policy normalization.

site_title: Temasek-backed ride-hailing firm Ola raises US$500m loan
summary: Ola, a Temasek-backed ride-hailing firm, has raised US$500 million in a loan from international investors, exceeding initial expectations of US$1.5 billion. The company, which dominates India's ride-hailing market, plans to go public in the first half of 2022 and list its electric vehicle business separately. Ola's CEO, Bhavish Aggarwal, aims to build out the electric segment, starting with electric scooters, which began deliveries on December 15. The loan issuance is part of Ola's efforts to raise up to US$1 billion through an initial public offering.

site_title: Malaysia imposes stricter rules, booster requirements over Omicron threat
summary: Malaysia imposes stricter Covid-19 rules due to Omicron threat, banning mass gatherings and requiring booster doses for high-risk groups. The country reported its second Omicron case, an 8-year-old returning from Nigeria, and is verifying 18 suspected cases. Health Minister Khairy Jamaluddin announced the measures amid concerns about the variant's high transmissibility.

site_title: Reddit says it filed confidentially for US IPO
summary: Reddit has confidentially filed for an initial public offering (IPO), with the company stating it has not yet determined the number of shares or proposed price range. The IPO is expected to occur after the US Securities and Exchange Commission completes its review process, subject to market conditions. Reddit's IPO listing will report its operations and finances in a public filing if the IPO is pursued. The company has seen significant growth, including a 300% increase in advertising revenue to $100 million in the second quarter.

site_title: Gold rises on softer dollar; investors focus on ECB, BOE meetings
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,780.63 per ounce due to a softer dollar, while investors shifted focus from the US Federal Reserve to European Central Bank and Bank of England meetings. The Fed announced it would end pandemic-era bond purchases in March and pave the way for interest rate hikes. Gold prices are expected to be influenced by the ECB's decision on its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, extending US rallies after Fed meet
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending US rallies after the Federal Reserve signaled a more muscular stance on inflation. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.41% or 400.67 points to 28,860.39, while the Topix index increased 1.11% or 22.10 points to 2,006.20. This follows US stocks' gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending rallies on Wall Street after the Federal Reserve signalled a more muscular stance on inflation.

site_title: 5 more bodies recovered after boat capsizes off Malaysia
summary: Malaysian authorities have recovered the bodies of five more people who went missing after their boat capsized off the country's south, bringing the death toll to 16. The recovered individuals include 10 men and six women. Fourteen people were found safe, while 20 remain missing. Search and rescue operations continue for a second day.

site_title: Nomura hires Kwan as joint head of Asia investment bank ex-Japan
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc has hired Patrick Kwan, a veteran banker with 15 years of experience in Asia, as joint head of investment banking for Asia ex-Japan. Kwan, who joins Nomura on January 7, was previously Credit Suisse's vice-chairman, investment banking and capital markets, Asia Pacific. He will work alongside Kenji Teshima and be based in Hong Kong. The move aims to strengthen Nomura's presence in the region, following Kwan's extensive experience in the banking and capital markets sector.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher as Fed decision calms nerves
summary: South Korean stocks rose on Thursday, December 16, as the US Federal Reserve signaled it has met its inflation target and will end pandemic-era bond purchases. The Kospi index gained 0.57% to close at 3,006.41, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the gains. The benchmark bond yield fell, and the Korean won strengthened. The Fed also announced plans to raise interest rates up to 3 times next year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slip at Thursday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks slipped 0.57% at Thursday's open, with the Hang Seng Index falling 132.83 points to 23,287.93. The decline came amid concerns the US may impose fresh sanctions on Chinese firms and add them to a blacklist.

site_title: Asia tech conference calls off 2022 RISE event citing virus fears
summary: A major tech conference, the RISE Conference, scheduled for March 2022 in Hong Kong, has been cancelled due to concerns over the pandemic. Organisers cited "uncertainties brought about by the pandemic" for the decision, and stated the event will return in 2023. The conference, which brings together CEOs, startups, and investors, has been held in Hong Kong since 2015. The cancellation is a blow to Hong Kong's business hub, which has implemented China's "zero-Covid" strategy.

site_title: Japan's economy seen rebounding in Q4, analysts wary about rising material costs: poll
summary: Japan's economy is expected to grow sharply in the current quarter and the first three months of next year, with consumer and corporate activity rebounding from pandemic-induced tolls. Analysts forecast a 6.1% annualized GDP growth this quarter, with 4.9% growth in the first quarter of 2022. However, rising global material and energy costs pose uncertainty, with nearly all economists warning of a damaging impact. Despite this, the government's $490 billion spending package is seen as a potential boost to private consumption, particularly its tourism campaign.

site_title: Government to increase BTO, GLS programme supply together with cooling measures
summary: The Singapore government will increase the supply of private and public housing units, with the number of units available under the GLS Programme rising 40% in the first half of 2022. To temper demand, the government will raise Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates across the board, except for first-time buyers, and tighten the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) threshold to 55%. The Loan-To-Value (LTV) limit for HDB housing loans will also be reduced to 85%. The measures aim to support a stable property market and keep housing affordable for Singaporeans, amid rising prices and interest rates.

images.alt_text: Along with the latest cooling measures announced late Wednesday night, the government will boost supply in both the private and public housing markets.

site_title: UK records highest ever daily number of coronavirus cases
summary: The UK has recorded its highest daily number of coronavirus cases with 78,610 laboratory-confirmed cases, surpassing the previous peak of 68,053 in January. The surge in cases is attributed to the Omicron variant.

site_title: Santa Claus isn't coming to town: Covid sparks St Nick shortage
summary: A shortage of Santa Clauses has struck the US due to the pandemic, with a booking company and Santa training school reporting a high demand but limited supply. Festivities and parties have resumed this year, but the supply of bearded men in red is not meeting the demand, making it challenging for children to meet Santa. The shortage is attributed to the reduced festivities and events last year, leading to a lack of experienced Santas.

site_title: 'Forgotten' animals rescued after Indonesia volcano eruption
summary: Indonesia's Mount Semeru volcano eruption has killed 48 people, destroyed villages, and killed 767 cows, 648 sheep, and thousands of chickens. Volunteers from the Centre for Orangutan Protection (COP) have rescued and treated over 100 animals, including cows, goats, sheep, chickens, dogs, and cats, many of whom suffered burns, dehydration, and stress. The rescue efforts aim to not only save human lives but also alleviate survivors' trauma by saving the lives of their pets, according to COP's veterinarian.

site_title: EHT's New Jersey hotel sold for US$23.5m, insufficient to cover entire mortgage loan
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust's (EHT) New Jersey hotel, Delta Woodbridge, was sold for US$23.5 million, but the sale was insufficient to cover the entire mortgage loan balance of US$37.6 million. The net proceeds were used to offset the outstanding principal balance. The remaining amount will be payable by EHT's Chapter 11 entity EHT US1. The sale comes after 3 months of marketing efforts and a foreclosure judgment entered by the Superior Court of New Jersey in July 2021.

site_title: Thousands flee homes as typhoon lashes Philippines
summary: Thousands of people in the Philippines have fled their homes and beachfront resorts as Typhoon Rai, also known as "Odette", brings destructive winds and torrential rain. The typhoon is packing maximum sustained winds of 165 kmh and is expected to intensify to 195 kmh before landfall near Siargao island. Over 45,000 people are in emergency shelters, and scores of flights have been cancelled while ports are temporarily closed due to storm surges. The Philippines is hit by an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, causing significant damage to infrastructure and homes.

site_title: China's yuan holds steady, investors cautious after PBOC moves
summary: China's yuan held steady against the dollar on Thursday amid concerns the PBOC is becoming less tolerant of the currency's recent gains. The PBOC set the midpoint rate at a one-week high of 6.3637 per dollar, 0.12% firmer than the previous fix. Authorities' measures, including foreign exchange purchases and increased quotas for outbound investments, suggest a slowing yuan. Investors remain cautious due to the central bank's growing discomfort with the currency's strength.

site_title: Hot stock: Isetan down 13.6% after plans to sell Wisma Atria space did not take off
summary: Isetan Singapore shares fell 13.6% to S$3.56 after the department store operator failed to gather interest from investors to purchase its space at Wisma Atria shopping mall. The company had started gathering expressions of interest in July but concluded the process without a positive outcome. Meanwhile, the manager of Starhill Global Reit remains open to working with Isetan to improve the space and explore acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at Thursday's open, driven by a cooling of the housing market amid rising concerns over the property boom. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 4.91 points to 3,119.79. Meanwhile, US stocks rallied after the Federal Reserve outlined a more aggressive plan to address inflation, with the S&P 500 up 1.6% and the Nasdaq Composite up 2.2%. European shares also rose, despite weakness in the retail and energy sectors.

site_title: Europe: Technology shares support stocks with Federal Reserve meeting in focus
summary: European stocks rose 0.3% on Wednesday, ending a five-session losing streak, driven by gains in technology and healthcare sectors. Technology stocks added 1.3% and healthcare stocks climbed 1.1%, while retail and energy sectors were capped by a disappointing earnings update from Inditex. Crude oil prices dropped due to rising demand risks from the Omicron variant. Investors are cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision, with expectations of slowing bond purchases.

site_title: Indonesia reports first case of Omicron variant
summary: Indonesia has reported its first case of the Omicron coronavirus variant, detected in an employee at the Wisma Atlet hospital in Jakarta with no history of overseas travel. Five more suspected cases have been identified, including two Indonesians who recently returned from the US and Britain, and three Chinese nationals in quarantine in Manado. Currently, there is no community transmission, but the health minister has raised concerns.

site_title: ECB plots stimulus exit as inflation looms
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to confirm the planned end of its massive pandemic-era stimulus plan in March, amid soaring inflation and a new coronavirus variant threatening the recovery. The bank aims to wind down its 70 billion euro monthly asset purchases, a move that could be smooth or disrupt markets. The ECB may boost its pre-pandemic asset purchase programme or create a new envelope for financial support to avoid a "cliff-effect." Inflation has risen 4.9% year-on-year in the eurozone, exceeding expectations, and the ECB is expected to publish its 2024 economic forecasts, which may influence its future monetary policy decisions.

site_title: MOH grants Covid-19 testing services to Acumen, up to 100 sites islandwide
summary: Acumen Diagnostics, a joint venture between Q&M Dental Group and Acumen Research Laboratories, has been granted a licence by the Ministry of Health to provide Covid-19 testing services. The company, which operates 2 laboratories, will ramp up its testing services to meet the increased demand, with plans to roll out to 100 clinics islandwide by the end of the year. This move aims to provide highly accurate and accessible PCR tests to make Covid-19 testing hassle-free and convenient for Singapore residents.

images.alt_text: The home-grown medical technology company currently operates 2 laboratories that can process 7,000 diagnostic tests on a daily basis.

site_title: Increased supply from MND's confirmed-list private housing may not sate developers' appetite
summary: Singapore's Ministry of National Development (MND) has confirmed 4 private housing plots and an executive condo site for the first half of 2022, yielding 2,785 residential units. This represents a 39% increase from the previous half-year program and a 40% boost in supply from confirmed-list private housing sites. However, developers face dwindling inventory and high additional buyer's stamp duty, which may limit land-buying opportunities. The total supply from both confirmed and reserve lists is expected to decrease by 5% to 6,500 units.

site_title: Japan's Nov exports rise 20.5% yoy
summary: Japan's exports rose 20.5% in November from a year ago, exceeding economists' expectations of a 21.2% gain. This followed a 9.4% increase in the previous month. Imports rose 43.8%, higher than the median estimate of 40.0%. The trade balance came to a deficit of 954.8 billion yen, exceeding the median estimate of a 675.0 billion yen deficit.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 1.01 points to 1,483.82. The market saw 311.66 million lots traded worth RM207.05 million, with 254 gainers outnumbering 133 losers. The market's performance was largely unaffected by global economic news, including US-EU trade talks and stock market records in the US and Europe.

site_title: Signum Capital partners UOB in US$50m blockchain venture fund
summary: Signum Capital has partnered with UOB in a US$50m blockchain venture fund, the UVM Signum Blockchain Fund, with US$40 million committed to date. Both Signum and UOB Venture Management have each invested US$5 million. The fund is co-managed by Signum and UOB, with no specific investment targets or timelines mentioned. This partnership aims to invest in blockchain technology and its applications.

site_title: Italy bans tourists from Singapore till Jan 31 next year
summary: Italy has banned tourists from Singapore until January 31, 2022, due to a higher risk of Covid-19 infections. Only Singapore residents allowed for work, health, or study purposes, or those with specific exemptions, can enter Italy. Travelers from Singapore can still transit through Italy's airports to other destinations. The restrictions, in place until January 31, 2022, were implemented without specifying the reasons for the change.

site_title: Intel to invest RM30b in new plant in Malaysia, creating 9,000 jobs
summary: Intel to invest RM30 billion in a new chip-packaging and testing factory in Malaysia, creating over 9,000 jobs. The investment, valued at over US$7 billion, is expected to begin production in 2024, addressing the global semiconductor chip shortage. Intel's CEO Pat Gelsinger expects the shortage to persist into 2023, but notes that the industry will grow more than it has in decades. The move aims to bolster Malaysia's chip assembly industry, which accounts for over 10% of global trade.

site_title: Quick takes: How might fresh cooling measures affect Singapore's property market?
summary: The Singapore government has introduced a package of measures to cool the property market, taking effect from Thursday, Dec 16. The measures include raising additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rates by 5 to 15 percentage points, tightening the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) threshold to 55 per cent, and lowering the loan-to-value (LTV) limit for HDB loans to 85 per cent. Analysts predict a slowdown in property demand, with prices stabilizing and rising at a slower pace next year. Sales are expected to ease to around 400-600 units in December, and project launches may be held back. The measures are expected to impact investors, foreigners, and en bloc hopefuls, but will have a limited impact on demand for homes dominated by locals and first-timers.

site_title: Climate change imperils world's oil and gas reserves: research
summary: Climate change poses a significant threat to the world's oil and gas reserves, with 40% of recoverable reserves at risk due to rising tides, storms, floods, and extreme temperatures. Verisk Maplecroft's research notes that extreme weather events will become more frequent and extreme, affecting major producers like Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Nigeria. The consultancy identified nearly a third of the world's commercially recoverable reserves as high risk, with extreme heat and water shortages posing particular threats to Saudi Arabia and droughts and flooding in Nigeria.

site_title: GIC, SoftBank backs food startup ezCater in US$100m funding round
summary: EzCater, a US-based corporate food startup, has raised US$100 million in a funding round led by SoftBank's Vision Fund 2 and GIC, valuing the company at US$1.6 billion. This brings total funds raised to US$425 million. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic causing a 85% revenue plunge, ezCater has expanded its services and exceeded pre-pandemic revenue run rates through acquisitions. The company connects businesses with restaurants and caterers through an online platform and counts prominent customers like JLL and the San Francisco 49ers.

site_title: Time to redefine the concept of the Centre of Excellence
summary: Organisations are facing a growing "analytic divide" between those that can leverage data-driven insights and automate processes, and those that cannot. To bridge this gap, redefining the in-house Centre of Excellence (COE) is crucial. A people-centric approach, empowering every employee to be a "citizen data scientist," can help organisations upskill their workforce and deploy a self-service analytics platform. This can lead to increased data literacy, improved decision-making, and enhanced innovation, ultimately driving analytics breakthroughs and bridging the analytic divide.

site_title: Airbus unseats Boeing to replace ageing fleet of Qantas 737s
summary: Qantas has signed a multi-billion deal with Airbus to replace its aging fleet of 75 Boeing 737s with the A320neo and A220 aircraft, worth at least $4.6 billion. The order is the largest in Australian aviation history and will see Qantas flying mostly Airbus planes for decades. The decision is a blow to Boeing, which will now focus on its Dreamliner on Qantas routes. The move is seen as a sign of confidence in the future, with Qantas expecting an uptick in demand for next-generation aircraft.

site_title: Brands from Ferrari to Nike rush towards metaverse future
summary: Brands like Ferrari, Nike, and Uniqlo are rushing into the metaverse, a virtual reality version of the internet, to experiment and build an audience. Virtual worlds like Fortnite and Minecraft are already open for business, and companies are investing in digital clothing, NFTs, and virtual experiences. The metaverse offers valuable insights into product perception and direct sales opportunities, making it a priority for companies to innovate and stay competitive. However, the lack of a unified platform remains a challenge, and brands must adapt to each platform's codes to succeed.

site_title: South Korea to reinstate distancing curbs amid spike in Covid-19 cases
summary: South Korea will reinstate social distancing rules from December 18 to January 2 due to a surge in COVID-19 cases, with limited gatherings, restaurant closures, and restricted hours for entertainment facilities. Unvaccinated individuals will be restricted to solo dining or takeout services. The move aims to prevent the medical system from being overwhelmed, following a month-and-a-half of lifting curbs under a 'living with Covid-19' policy.

site_title: Driver charged with manslaughter after fatal Paris Tesla crash: source
summary: A driver of a Tesla taxi in Paris has been charged with manslaughter and causing unintentional injuries after a fatal accident last weekend. The driver lost control while traveling with his family, killing one person and injuring 19 others. Prosecutors are investigating the cause of the accident, which Tesla attributes to a blocked brake pedal. The incident has raised questions about Tesla's safety record, particularly its Autopilot driver assistance program. The driver's lawyer claims the car was in good condition and the driver took all necessary precautions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Property developers, Isetan, Starhill Global Reit, Q&M
summary: The Singapore government raised additional buyer's stamp duty rates and tightened debt servicing ratio thresholds as part of housing market cooling measures, affecting property developers CapitaLand Investment, City Developments Limited, and UOL, with their shares closing lower. Isetan, a department store operator, announced it had not gathered enough interest for the purchase of space at Wisma Atria shopping mall, while Starhill Global Reit remains open to acquiring the space. Q&M Dental Group received a licence for offsite swabbing and Covid-19 PCR tests services, and Del Monte Pacific posted higher earnings.

site_title: UK pay settlements rise to 2.2% as wage pressure starts to show: XpertHR
summary: The UK saw a 2.2% rise in annual pay settlements for British employers in the three months to November, according to XpertHR data. This marks the highest median basic pay award since June 2020 and a slight increase from the previous quarter. Despite the rise, pay settlements remain below the pace of inflation, with the top quarter of pay awards reaching 3% or higher. Experts attribute the increase to pay pressure due to high inflation and labor shortages, with the Bank of England closely monitoring the trend ahead of its interest rate decision.

site_title: US regulators unveil proposal to avert another Archegos
summary: US regulators proposed new rules to address regulatory defects exposed by the collapse of hedge fund Archegos in 2021. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) aims to increase transparency by requiring large investors who own security-based swaps to submit filings with the SEC. The rule would prohibit "fraudulent, deceptive, or manipulative conduct" connected to these transactions and make filings publicly available. The proposed rule is open for a 45-day public comment period.

site_title: Australia: CSL drags shares lower, tech stocks rise
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 7,313.4, marking the third straight session of decline, as healthcare stocks dropped 5.1% following a discounted equity raising by CSL. Tech stocks rose 2%, tracking the Nasdaq's strong finish, with Wisetech Global leading gains. Qantas flagged a first-half loss due to lockdowns, and New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% amid a 3.7% GDP shrinkage in the third quarter.

site_title: Brokerages offering free shares and commission-free trades in tussle for younger investors
summary: Singapore-based wealth management platform Syfe is launching Syfe Trade, a fractional trading product for US stocks, targeting younger investors. The platform allows users to buy dollar value fractions of any US stock or ETF, starting from $1. Syfe aims to onboard over 100,000 users in Singapore within the first six months. The company is competing with other brokerages offering free shares or commission-free trades, including Revolut and moomoo. Syfe will charge $0.99 per trade initially and $1.49 thereafter, with 2 free trades in perpetuity.

site_title: Work from office capacity may never hit 100% again
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce has decided that half of those who can work from home (WFH) will be allowed in the office from January 1, 2022. Despite easing Covid-19 restrictions, business owners and experts expect flexible work arrangements to remain, with many preferring the flexibility of WFH. Employers are now being empowered to decide on return-to-office schedules that suit their organizations effectively. Experts note that 100% office capacity may never be reached, with some firms adopting hybrid models and prioritizing employee autonomy.

site_title: Australia central bank sees no hike in 2022, QE tapering depends on data
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe said interest rates are unlikely to rise in 2022 unless inflation reaches the 2-3% target band. The central bank is open to ending its bond buying program, potentially in February, depending on economic data. Lowe cited a massive build-up in household savings and a strong consumer spending outlook as positives. The decision on tapering will depend on data on employment and inflation, as well as the economic impact of the Omicron variant.

site_title: Tips from X'mas party planners
summary: Christmas party planners share Covid-compliant tips, including dressing the home, planning food and entertainment, and hosting a festive gathering for a small group. Meanwhile, the National Gallery features a collection of Korean-American artist Nam June Paik's work, and two Japanese chef-run restaurants are reviewed for meals under $100.

site_title: EU to set up scheme to encourage CO2 removal from atmosphere
summary: EU policymakers plan to create a system to certify carbon removals by 2022, aiming to scale up removals to offset emissions from sectors like agriculture and heavy industry. The system will measure CO2 removals from technologies and land holdings, allowing farmers and landowners to earn EU-recognised credits for removing CO2. The goal is to capture 5 million tonnes of CO2 from the atmosphere annually by 2030, paving the way for an EU-regulated market to trade certified carbon removal credits. This move aims to create a financial incentive for storing CO2 and promote sustainable land management.

site_title: Renomination 'had nothing to do' with Federal Reserve policy shift: Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell denied any connection between the central bank's policy shift to counter inflation and his nomination for a second term. The Fed announced it will speed up the process of ending its bond-buying program, aiming to raise interest rates before the middle of next year. Powell cited data released in November as the reason for the policy shift, stating it was necessary to address rising consumer prices. The decision marks a more aggressive stance against inflation, which has been a pressing concern for the Biden administration.

site_title: World Bank unveils US$93b boost to fund for poorest nations
summary: The World Bank has announced a record-breaking $93 billion injection into its International Development Association (IDA) fund, primarily to support the world's poorest nations in recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic. The largest replenishment ever, it includes $23.5 billion from high- and middle-income countries and will be in place through June 2025, with 70% of the funding going to Africa. The funds will help countries better prepare for future crises and support their economic development.

site_title: Oil edges up on consumer demand, inventory declines
summary: Oil prices edged higher on Wednesday, rebounding from early losses after US inventory data showed strong consumer demand and the Federal Reserve announced it would end pandemic-era bond purchases in March to slow rising inflation. Brent crude futures rose 18 cents to $73.88 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude ended up 14 cents to $70.87 a barrel. US crude inventories declined by 4.6 million barrels, while distillate and petrol stocks also dropped. However, oil analysts expect the Omicron variant to curb demand in the coming months.

site_title: Federal Reserve signals 3 rate hikes in the cards in 2022 as inflation fight begins
summary: The Federal Reserve announced plans to end pandemic-era bond purchases in March and signal three quarter-percentage-point interest rate hikes by the end of 2022 to combat rising inflation. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated the economy is nearing full employment and inflation is uncomfortably high, warranting the interest rate increases. Policymakers forecast inflation to rise to 2.6% next year, then fall to 2.3% and 2.1% in 2023 and 2024, respectively. The Fed's benchmark interest rate is expected to rise from near zero to 0.90% by the end of 2022, with further hikes in 2023 and 2024.

site_title: US releases trove of secret files on Kennedy assassination
summary: The US released 1,491 secret files on John F. Kennedy's assassination, providing new insights into the investigation. The files, held by the CIA and FBI, show that investigators chased down leads on Soviet intelligence, African communist groups, and the Italian mafia. The documents, posted on the National Archives page, contradict conspiracy theories that Kennedy was killed by others, including Cuba or the Soviet Union. The release follows a 1992 law requiring all government records on the assassination to be disclosed, with 88% of the documents now available to the public.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as Federal Reserve maps out plan for battling inflation
summary: US stocks rallied after the Federal Reserve outlined a more aggressive plan to combat inflation, with the S&P 500 winning 1.6% and closing above pre-Fed announcement levels. The central bank announced it will phase out stimulus measures in March and raise lending rates as soon as May. Fed Chair Jerome Powell said the Fed will tighten policy in a gradual, yet accommodative, way due to robust economic activity driving inflation higher. Market reaction was positive, with investors relieved the Fed did not exceed expectations in terms of hawkishness.

site_title: How companies can digitalise their supply chains and operations
summary: Companies are reacting to post-Covid supply chain disruptions by investing in digitalization. A Citi and EIU report found 32.5% of global supply chain managers have increased investment in digital tools or processes since the pandemic. Asian managers were more likely to invest in digitalization, with 40% compared to 24.7% in Europe and 24.3% in North America. This shift towards digitalization is expected to help companies adapt to changing macroeconomic factors and technological transformation.

site_title: 1982 Ventures hits US$12.5m first close of inaugural seed fund
summary: Early-stage investor 1982 Ventures has raised US$12.5 million at the first close of its inaugural seed fund, targeting US$15 million. The fund is focused on young fintech startups in South-east Asia, with investments to date including Indonesian open banking player Brick and Vietnamese retail investment platform Infina. Backed by US fintech unicorn Carta, Genting Group, and Indonesian family office Trihill, the firm aims to back 30 startups in Indonesia, Vietnam, Singapore, and the Philippines, with a goal of being the best performing fund in the region.

images.alt_text: Scott Krivokopich and Herston Elton Powers of 1982 Ventures.

site_title: China central bank partially rolls over medium-term loans to boost liquidity
summary: China's central bank partially rolled over medium-term loans to boost liquidity, keeping the 1-year MLF rate steady at 2.95% for the 20th consecutive month. This move comes amid a slowdown in the economy, with recent indicators pointing to a slowing economy and dampened sentiment due to regulatory clampdowns. Analysts expect the PBOC to consider further easing measures, including a potential 5-basis-point reduction in the lending benchmark loan prime rate, to counter the economic slowdown.

site_title: Wikipedia creator's computer and NFT auctioned for almost US$1m
summary: Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales's computer and an NFT memorializing his first edit on Wikipedia 20 years ago sold for almost US$1 million at an auction. The NFT, which features the debut onscreen image of Wikipedia, sold for US$750,000, while the Strawberry iMac used for development sold for US$187,500. Proceeds will fund Wales's WT.Social project, a non-toxic social media network. This sale marks one of the highest prices paid for an NFT, following the sale of an NFT of the World Wide Web's source code for US$5.4 million in July.

site_title: Overpromised with 5G? Here's how Open RAN can help
summary: A new industrial revolution was promised with the rollout of 5G, but reality shows limited progress, with most populations having only low-band frequencies. Open Radio Access Network (RAN) technology, an open, cloud-based infrastructure, may help accelerate 5G adoption. Benefits of Open RAN include faster deployment, reduced costs, and increased innovation, but challenges include interoperability, performance, and security. Despite uneven progress, several countries, including Japan, Singapore, and Malaysia, are investing in Open RAN, which could add up to $285 billion to global GDP by 2030.

site_title: Getting Asia's banks on the path towards sustainability
summary: Asian banks are lagging behind in adopting environmental, social, and governance (ESG) principles, despite the growing importance of sustainable finance. Major European banks are leading the charge in green financing, but Asian banks, including established lenders, have been slow to act. However, there are hopeful signs, particularly in Singapore, where private banks are adopting more ESG factors in investment decision-making. The region's financial services ecosystem needs a concerted private-sector-led shift towards green banking to help Asia transition to a low-carbon economy and ESG-led future.

site_title: Australia reopens borders to non-citizens despite Omicron worries
summary: Australia reopened its borders to vaccinated skilled migrants and foreign students on December 15, 2021, after a nearly 2-year ban. The move aims to boost the economy, which has been impacted by COVID-19 lockdowns. The reopening comes despite concerns over the Omicron variant, which has led to a 2-week delay in international travel. Australia has nearly 90% vaccination rate and has lifted most restrictions for the unvaccinated, with the return of foreign students expected to ease labor shortages.

site_title: Omicron to be dominant in Europe by mid-January, EU warns
summary: The European Commission predicts that the Omicron variant will dominate Europe by mid-January, with case numbers doubling every 2-3 days. EU leaders are meeting to discuss ways to combat the new strain, focusing on booster shots and harmonizing travel rules. However, some EU countries, like Germany, are struggling with vaccine shortages, with Germany potentially lacking up to 60 million doses for the first quarter of next year. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control notes that undetected community transmission could be ongoing, with 70% of initial Omicron cases acquired locally.

site_title: Thomson Medical's digital arm in JV to launch telehealth app for women, children
summary: Thomson Medical's digital arm, Thomson X, has partnered with telehealth provider WhiteCoat to launch a mobile app offering seamless and personalized online-to-offline healthcare services for women and children. The app aims to address the underserved area of women's health and provide a broader set of offerings across women's and children's health. The joint venture is part of Thomson X's strategy to future-proof TMG's business model and extend its reach through partnerships. The app is expected to launch in 2022, and will support TMG's aim to cover the entire value chain of family planning, fertility, and early childhood healthcare.

site_title: HK's young 'neon nomads' keep dying trade flickering
summary: In Hong Kong, a new generation of young artists, known as "neon nomads," are working to keep the city's iconic neon-light trade alive. Despite the decline of traditional masters, many are turning to the internet and global communities to learn the skills. Artists like Karen Chan and Jive Lau are experimenting with new techniques and sharing knowledge on social media platforms. They aim to revitalize the neon culture, injecting new elements and perspectives to keep it relevant.

site_title: Isetan says no success in potential sale of Wisma Atria space
summary: Isetan, a Singapore department store operator, has failed to attract sufficient interest from investors to purchase its space at Wisma Atria shopping mall. The company had launched an expressions of interest exercise in July but reported no positive outcome. Isetan will continue to explore alternative opportunities to achieve a better yield for the property.

images.alt_text: Isetan had in July started an expressions of interest exercise to gather interest from target investors, but the exercise has since "run its course without yielding a positive outcome for the matter to proceed further at this juncture".

site_title: London nightclub owners pan UK's new Covid-19 rules for venues
summary: London nightclub owners criticized the UK's new Covid-19 rules, citing a lack of available rapid testing as a major challenge for enforcement. The rules, part of "Plan B," require Covid-19 vaccine passes for some venues and accept negative rapid tests. The measures aim to curb the spread of Omicron variants, with 4,500 cases registered in Britain. The new rules have already led to significant financial losses for the entertainment industry, with income falling by 27% in the past week.

site_title: Xi told Putin that China, Russia are better than allies, Kremlin says
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping told Russian President Vladimir Putin that their relations are more effective than an alliance, according to the Kremlin. Xi praised Putin's support for China's core interests and expressed willingness to roll out new cooperation plans. The statement comes amid rising tensions with the West, particularly over Ukraine. The two leaders also discussed US activities in the Asia-Pacific region, including the AUKUS partnership. Putin has proposed binding security guarantees against NATO expansion, but talks with the US have yet to yield results.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat ahead of Fed announcement
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened flat on Wednesday, awaiting the Federal Reserve's announcement on its pandemic-era monetary stimulus. The Dow Jones rose 0.01%, while the S&P 500 opened 0.05% higher. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.05%. The solid inflation readings have strengthened bets for a faster winddown of stimulus.

site_title: VTLs are here, but roaming revenue is still stuck in the slow lane
summary: Singapore's mobile network operators (MNOs) are seeing a potential recovery in roaming revenue as international travel normalizes. Despite the flatlining of mobile revenues over the past two years due to the COVID-19 pandemic, MNOs such as M1, StarHub, and Singtel are seeing early signs of recovery in roaming revenue. However, the actual timeline for this snapback is uncertain due to ongoing border reopening and testing requirements. Industry experts suggest that MNOs must approach roaming potential in innovative ways, such as forming international alliances or tapping data analytics, to capitalize on the recovery.

images.alt_text: M1 is seeing "some early signs of recovery in our roaming revenue", from Data Passport roaming subscriptions as people travel via vaccinated travel lanes, a spokesperson.

site_title: Europe tries again to allow everyone to invest in private equity
summary: European authorities plan to ease rules for individual investors to invest in private equity through the European Long-Term Investment Fund (ELTIF), a structure seen as a gateway for billions of dollars in fresh capital. The proposed changes aim to encourage investment in infrastructure and companies seeking long-term capital. The changes are expected to make it easier for individual investors to access private equity, which could provide fresh capital for buyout firms.

site_title: Zero-Covid policies and pollution curbs stunt China's oil demand
summary: China's oil demand is expected to remain subdued in 2022 due to its tough Zero-Covid policies, pollution curbs, and uncertainty over the Omicron variant. This has led to a decline in refinery operating rates and margins, and a decrease in the market for domestic fuels. The impact on prices will be a relief for inflation hawks at the central bank, potentially derailing Opec+ plans to raise production. As a result, China's status as the world's biggest buyer of crude oil is set to remain unchanged.

site_title: UK leadership faces questions as inflation surges, Tory MPs rebel over new Covid-19 regulation
summary: The UK's cost of living surged by 5.1% in the 12 months to November, exceeding economists' forecasts. The increase, driven by rising fuel and energy costs, has raised questions about Prime Minister Boris Johnson's leadership. Tory MPs rebelled over new Covid-19 regulations, with 100 voting against the government's rule requiring vaccination proof or negative tests at large events. The rebellion is seen as a significant blow to Johnson's authority, with Labour leader Keir Starmer leading in the polls and satisfaction with Johnson at an all-time low.

site_title: Japan admits overstating some govt economic data for years
summary: Japan's government has admitted to overstating construction orders data from builders for years, rewriting data from about 12,000 select companies since 2013. The practice, which included rewriting missing data and averaging late submissions, may have impacted GDP figures but experts expect minimal effects. The admission could dent credibility of official statistics, which are crucial for economists and investors. The government will examine steps to avoid such incidents in the future.

site_title: New cooling measures overturn sanguine outlook for new private home market for 2022
summary: Singapore's government has announced new property cooling measures, overturning the optimism for the private home market in 2022. Despite developers selling 12,467 new private homes in the first 11 months of 2021, exceeding expectations, the government has raised buyer's stamp duty and tightened debt servicing ratios to curb the market. The measures also limit HDB loan-to-value to 85% and increase public housing and private housing supply. Analysts expect the momentum in the private housing market to remain positive, but with a slower pace, due to diminishing unsold stock and limited mega launches.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific Q2 earnings up 63.8% to US$35.8m
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported Q2 earnings of US$35.8 million, a 63.8% year-over-year increase, driven by its US unit's more than doubled profits. Revenue rose 4.4% to US$651 million. The earnings surpass the company's previous guidance, indicating a strong performance in the second quarter.

site_title: America's new Indo-Pacific economic deal - awaiting the re-pivot to Asia
summary: The US is set to initiate talks on a new Indo-Pacific economic framework, aiming to surpass the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). However, concerns arise over the framework's inclusiveness and substance, as the US has historically struggled to balance geostrategic and economic interests in the region. The new deal's flexibility and targeted approach may lead to watered-down provisions, and its success is uncertain given the Biden administration's domestic challenges and low approval ratings.

site_title: Singapore announces new property cooling measures
summary: Singapore has announced new property cooling measures to promote a stable and sustainable housing market amid concerns of a potential property boom. From December 16, buyer's stamp duty rates will be raised by 5-15 percentage points, and the total debt servicing ratio threshold will be tightened from 60% to 55%. The loan-to-value limit for loans from HDB will also be reduced from 90% to 85%. The measures aim to dampen broad-based demand and prevent prices from running ahead of economic fundamentals.

site_title: Global economy set for sturdy if uneven growth in 2022
summary: The global economy is expected to experience sturdy but uneven growth in 2022, with a modest slowdown in the first quarter and a rebound by the spring. Global growth is estimated to ease to around 4.5% next year, with the US, euro area, Japan, and UK growing at 3.5%, 4.4%, 3.6%, and 4.6%, respectively. Higher inflation will lead to monetary policy divergence, with the UK and US expected to increase interest rates, while the Bank of Japan and European Central Bank are expected to maintain current lending rates. This divergence poses risks to financial markets and debt, particularly for emerging economies.

site_title: Inflation and Omicron killing Biden politically
summary: US President Joe Biden's first year in office has been marred by a sinking approval rating despite a strong economy, with indicators such as GDP growth and job creation. However, rising inflation, which reached its fastest rate since 1982 in November, has dampened consumer confidence. The Biden administration's handling of the pandemic, including the response to Omicron, has also been criticized. As a result, President Biden's party faces a slim majority in the House of Representatives and a high chance of losing control of the Senate in the 2022 midterm elections, making his ability to pass key legislation, including the Build Back Better Act, uncertain.

site_title: 3 more people tested preliminarily positive for Omicron variant
summary: Three more people in Singapore have tested preliminarily positive for the Omicron variant of COVID-19, bringing the total cases to 16, including 14 imported cases and two local cases. The new cases were identified through antigen rapid tests and polymerase chain reaction tests, and are linked to recent travel and dining activities. The Ministry of Health has issued Health Risk Warnings to affected restaurants and staff, and is conducting whole genome sequencing to confirm the variant.

site_title: Dollar steady, markets quiet as investors await Fed
summary: The US dollar remained steady on Wednesday, with markets quiet ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy statement and economic projections. Investors await the Fed's stance on rate hikes for 2022, with expectations of 1 or 2 hikes. However, a more dovish tone could lead to a dip in the dollar, according to Neil Jones, head of FX sales at Mizuho. The dollar held firm against the Japanese yen, while the euro and pound rose slightly, and the Australian dollar increased against the US dollar.

site_title: Blinken cuts short Asia trip due to Covid case in delegation
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken cut short a Southeast Asia trip due to a COVID-19 case in his delegation. A journalist testing positive for the virus in Malaysia led to the cancellation of his planned meetings with Thai officials. Blinken returned to Washington DC "out of the abundance of caution," after all other members tested negative. The decision aimed to mitigate COVID-19 spread and prioritize health and safety. Blinken's tour was part of efforts to challenge China's influence in Asia and re-establish US influence after the Trump era.

site_title: Lianhe Zaobao readers pick the word 'pan' to represent 2021
summary: Lianhe Zaobao readers have chosen the word "pan" (hope) to represent 2021 in the newspaper's annual poll. The word was chosen from a list of 10 nominees, including "bian" (change), "deng" (wait), and "shi" (food). The poll garnered over 12,000 votes, with "pan" receiving 3,300 votes, making it the winning word. This choice reflects the year's focus on resilience and perseverance in the face of challenges.

site_title: FLASH: Singapore announces new property cooling measures
summary: Singapore has announced new property cooling measures, effective December 16, 2021. The government will raise Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates and tighten the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) threshold. The LTV limit for HDB loans will also be reduced from 90% to 85%. To address demand, the government plans to increase public and private housing supply.

site_title: China's new home prices suffer biggest month-on-month decline in 6 years
summary: China's property market experienced a significant decline in November, with new home prices falling 0.3% month-on-month, the largest drop in 6 years. This was worse than the 0.2% drop in October, and was attributed to weak demand and a cash crunch among developers. The decline was seen across various sectors, including sales, investment, and construction.

site_title: Directors' roles and responsibilities in guiding companies through corporate actions
summary: Singapore's directors play a crucial role in guiding companies through corporate actions such as takeovers, mergers and acquisitions, and equity fund raisings. According to the Companies Act, directors must manage the company's business and make decisions in good faith, considering the company's interests. Robson Lee, a partner at Gibson Dunn, emphasizes the importance of directors' roles and responsibilities during such events, highlighting the need for directors to act in the best interests of the company. This is particularly relevant in the context of the Singapore market's recent sizeable deals.

site_title: Indonesia Parliament approves US$7.7b capital injection to state firms
summary: Indonesia's Parliament approved a $7.71 billion injection into 11 state-owned enterprises and investment agencies, including $657.7 million for state railway operator PT Kereta Api Indonesia to finance a China-backed high-speed rail project. The approvals also include funding for state electricity firm PT Perusahaan Listrik Negara, construction companies Waskita Karya and Adhi Karya, and other infrastructure projects. The capital injections aim to support the country's economic growth and expansion in 2022.

site_title: SGX rolls out mandatory climate reporting for financial, energy issuers from 2023
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has announced that climate reporting will be mandatory for financial, energy, and agriculture issuers starting from 2023, and for materials, buildings, and transportation industries from 2024. Mandatory climate reporting will be based on the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations. Issuers will also be required to set a board diversity policy and undergo training for directors. The new rules aim to promote transparency and better corporate governance, following a public consultation that received broad support from the market.

site_title: Thomson Medical's digital arm in JV to launch telehealth app for women, children
summary: Thomson Medical's digital arm, Thomson X, has partnered with telehealth provider WhiteCoat to launch a telehealth app for women and children. The joint venture aims to capture sustainable growth and provide better value for TMG's consumer base. Thomson X was established last year to future-proof TMG's business model and extend its reach through partnerships. The move is part of the company's efforts to extend its services and improve patient care.

site_title: 50% more bus tickets for quarantine-free travel between Singapore and JB from Dec 20
summary: Singaporeans can travel to Johor Baru (JB) with 50% more bus tickets available for quarantine-free travel starting December 20. The Causeway Link bus operator will increase its services from 16 to 26 per day, while Transtar will operate 24 services daily. Vaccinated Singapore citizens and residents can now enter Malaysia via the Causeway. Travellers will still need to adhere to test protocols and safe management measures, including a seven-day Covid-19 antigen rapid test regime after arrival in Singapore.

site_title: Omicron to be dominant in Europe by mid-January, EU warns
summary: European Union President Ursula von der Leyen warns that the Omicron variant will likely dominate Europe by mid-January, with case numbers doubling every 2-3 days. The EU is producing 300 million vaccine doses per month, but vaccination skepticism remains a concern. EU countries are implementing varying measures to combat the Omicron wave, including travel restrictions and vaccination requirements. However, some countries, such as Germany, are facing shortages of vaccine doses, with estimates suggesting a lack of 60 million doses for the first quarter of next year.

site_title: SingHealth Polyclinics names new CEO
summary: SingHealth Polyclinics has appointed David Ng as its new chief executive, succeeding Adrian Ee, who will step down on January 1, 2022. Ng, with over 20 years of public healthcare experience, oversaw the development of the largest polyclinic, SingHealth-Punggol. After Ee's departure, he will be succeeded by Ng, who will oversee the development of new and existing polyclinics.

site_title: China to lower import tariffs on 954 products in 2022
summary: China will lower import tariffs on 954 products in 2022, including medical equipment, Winter Olympics products, and auto parts that aid in reducing carbon emissions. Temporary import tariffs, lower than most-favoured-nation tariffs, will be implemented on these products. Import tariffs on cancer treatment drugs will remain at zero, while tariffs on Beijing Winter Olympics-related products will be lowered. Tariffs on auto parts aiding in carbon reduction will also be reduced. The moves aim to safeguard domestic industrial and supply chains and support the economy's stability.

site_title: WP leaders issued summons after failing to produce documents requested by privileges committee
summary: Singapore's Committee of Privileges has issued summons to Workers' Party (WP) leaders Pritam Singh, Sylvia Lim, and Faisal Manap to provide documents requested by the committee. The summons comes after the committee failed to receive the documents, which include internal correspondence between party senior leadership. The committee will consider the responses when it meets on December 20. Failure to comply with the summons could result in reprimand, fine, or jail time under the Parliament (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) Act.

site_title: US retail sales miss expectations in November
summary: US retail sales rose 0.3% in November, missing expectations, as Americans accelerated holiday shopping early to avoid shortages and higher prices. The increase follows a 1.8% surge in October and four consecutive months of sales growth. Consumer prices rose 0.8% in November, with a 6.8% year-over-year gain, the largest since June 1982. The modest sales gain suggests the economy is regaining steam after a slowdown in the third quarter. Federal Reserve officials are expected to speed up tapering of bond purchases and consider an early interest rate increase next year.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific Q2 earnings up 63.8% to US$35.8 million
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a 63.8% increase in Q2 earnings to US$35.8 million, driven by a 7% rise in US sales and a better sales mix. Revenue rose 4% to US$651 million, and gross profit margin improved by 180 basis points to 27.4%. The company's US unit contributed 73% of group turnover, with net profit jumping 151% to US$22.7 million. Del Monte Pacific also reduced its gearing and expects to generate higher net profit for FY2022, driven by operational efficiencies and higher-margin sales.

site_title: Omicron infects 70 times faster but is less severe, study says
summary: A University of Hong Kong study found that the Omicron variant of Covid-19 replicates around 70 times faster than Delta and the original strain, but with potentially lower infection severity. The study, led by Michael Chan, discovered that Omicron replicates less efficiently in human lung tissue than the original strain. This may signal lower disease severity, but Omicron's high transmissibility poses a significant threat, with the variant already detected in 77 nations and causing breakthrough and re-infection cases, particularly among young people with no significant risk factors.

site_title: India approves US$10b plan to lure semiconductor and display makers
summary: India has approved a US$10 billion incentive plan to attract semiconductor fabricators and display manufacturers, aiming to establish itself as a global electronics production hub. Israel's Tower Semiconductor, Apple's Foxconn, and a Singapore-based consortium have expressed interest in setting up units in India. The plan also includes a design-linked incentive to encourage 100 local companies in semiconductor design. The move comes as India seeks to capitalize on the global semiconductor shortage affecting automakers and tech companies.

site_title: Temasek-backed Sustenir appoints Jack Moy as CEO
summary: Sustenir, an urban farming startup backed by Temasek, has appointed Jack Moy as CEO following Benjamin Swan's departure. Moy, who joined Sustenir in 2017, previously held the role of chief operating officer. He played a key role in establishing the company's consumer brand and partnered with government agencies during the Covid-19 pandemic to boost local food production. Moy's appointment marks a significant change for the company, which aims to revolutionize urban agriculture.

site_title: QT Vascular shareholders vote to remove incumbent directors; third EGM being sought to appoint new directors
summary: QT Vascular shareholders voted to remove incumbent directors Mimon Brosh, Sho Kian Hin, and Ng Boon Eng, with 58.1% of votes cast in approval. The move comes after a previous attempt to install new directors was defeated. Requisitioning shareholders, Mission Well and Tansri Saridju Benui, plan to convene a third EGM to appoint new directors, citing a lack of confidence in the company's management. The company's directors have refused to attend the meeting, and a court application has been made to challenge the validity of the vote.

site_title: SIA swaps passenger plane orders for freighters
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has finalized a purchase agreement with Airbus for 7 A350F freighter aircraft, replacing its fleet of Boeing 747-400F freighters. Deliveries are scheduled for the fourth quarter of 2025, making SIA the first airline to operate this new generation widebody freighter aircraft. The A350F offers improved fuel efficiency and range, allowing SIA to manage capital expenditure and bolster its cargo business, which has been crucial in offsetting the financial impact of the pandemic on air travel.

site_title: As China's Internet stocks collapse, tech investors look to software
summary: China's internet stocks are collapsing due to Beijing's regulatory crackdown, prompting tech investors to shift to software companies, which are expected to triple their earnings next year and post the fastest profit growth in the MSCI China Index. Analysts see the sector growing at a pace triple that of its US peers, driven by the government's push for data security and technology self-sufficiency. Despite the selloff, some software companies are booming, with Longshine Technology surging 160% and Beijing SuperMap Software jumping 60%.

site_title: MAS proposes to introduce due diligence requirements for corporate finance advisers, including on IPOs
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes introducing due diligence requirements for corporate finance advisers, including those involved in initial public offerings (IPOs). The requirements would assess the suitability of listing applicants and conduct independent reviews of due diligence performed by advising teams. The goal is to raise standards of conduct and improve disclosures from entities raising funds from the public. MAS seeks public comments on the proposal until February 15, 2022. The regulator aims to strengthen investor confidence in Singapore's capital markets.

site_title: Scholz vows biggest transformation of German economy in a century
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz has vowed to transform the country's economy, focusing on climate protection and digitalization, with the goal of making it "fit for the future" in at least 100 years. He emphasized the need for modernization, equal opportunities, and stronger European Union ties. Scholz also prioritized tackling the pandemic and strengthening transatlantic alliances in the face of security threats, particularly the Russian military build-up in Ukraine. His government will work to expand qualified majority voting in the European Council and maintain a dialogue with Moscow.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell for a fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index declining 0.91% to 23,420.76. The decline follows investors' anticipation of the Federal Reserve's policy decision, which is expected to taper financial support measures sooner than initially stated. Other indices, including the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index, also saw losses, with declines of 0.38% and 0.58% respectively.

site_title: UK MPs fire warning shot at Johnson in Covid vote
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced intense pressure after nearly 100 MPs from his party broke ranks and voted against new coronavirus restrictions. The measures were passed, but the rebellion from all sections of Johnson's ruling Conservatives was seen as a "clear message" that colleagues are not happy with how the government is operating. The vote marked a significant blow to Johnson's popularity, which has taken a battering in recent weeks due to a series of scandals. A by-election in a safe Conservative seat on Thursday could further erode Johnson's support, with some predicting a leadership challenge in the new year.

site_title: Local stocks close lower on Wednesday, STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index fell 0.2% to close at 3,114.88, with traders taking a cautious stance ahead of the US Federal Reserve's FOMC meeting, which may impact market expectations on tapering pace and interest rate hikes. Asian markets also showed slight gains, with the exception of the Hang Seng Index, which fell 0.9%. Local stocks, including Great Eastern Holdings and Jardine Cycle and Carriage, were among the top gainers, while tech plays like AEM Holdings and Venture Corporation were among the biggest decliners.

site_title: One more Chinese developer seeks to extend debt due
summary: Guangzhou R&F Properties is seeking a six-month extension of a US$725 million debt note due January 13, amid China's ongoing real-estate market slump and credit crunch. The company may not be able to fully pay off the note if proposals aren't backed. This news comes as Shimao Group Holdings' dollar bonds hit all-time lows, highlighting the Chinese government's challenge in stabilizing the economy amid property woes. The situation may prompt the state to take action to rescue the sector.

site_title: Japan lower house passes record extra budget to prop Covid-hit economy
summary: Japan's lower house of Parliament passed a record US$316 billion extra budget to support the country's economy, still recovering from the Covid-19 pandemic. The budget, the largest in Japanese history, aims to revive growth and target wealth distribution to citizens. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's government prioritizes short-term recovery over long-term fiscal reform, focusing on a "new capitalism" to generate wage hikes and economic growth.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Philips is reportedly selling its Toa Payoh properties after launching an expression of interest (EOI) exercise. The affluent are setting up family offices in Singapore due to its strategic location and trusted legal system. En bloc developer Peace Centre sold its property for S$650m after a fifth attempt. ST Engineering aims to boost its R&D spending to 75% of its budget by 2026, while investors are being frozen out of crypto exchange CMBDEX for almost three years. Vietnam is surprised by the US tariff announcement and seeks a lower rate, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: H&M Q4 sales rise 8%, returning to pre-pandemic level
summary: H&M reports a 8% increase in Q4 sales, reaching pre-pandemic levels of 56.8 billion crowns (S$8.5 billion). Despite store closures due to restrictions, local currency sales returned to 2019 levels. The company's sales in local currencies increased 11% year-on-year, exceeding analyst expectations.

site_title: Hong Kong's young 'neon nomads' keep dying trade flickering
summary: A generation of young artists in Hong Kong, known as "neon nomads," are working to keep the city's iconic neon-light shop signs alive. Despite the trade being dominated by masters who refused to pass on their knowledge, many young artists, like Karen Chan, are turning to the internet and traveling abroad to learn from global communities of neon enthusiasts. With the help of online resources and social media, these artists are creating modern, locally-inspired neon art pieces, aiming to break the boundaries of the traditional trade and keep it alive.

site_title: Sanofi, GSK announce positive booster data for their Covid-19 vaccine candidate
summary: Sanofi and GlaxoSmithKline announced positive booster data for their Covid-19 vaccine candidate, showing a strong immune response with a single booster dose. The trial, which began in September, found neutralizing antibodies increased nine to 43-fold regardless of the primary vaccine used. The companies plan to continue the trial to accrue more data, with results expected in Q1 2022. This booster trial is considered the most comprehensive to date, and Sanofi hopes it can help the company catch up with rivals in the Covid-19 vaccine market.

site_title: Sports Hub contractor in dispute with subcontractor for breach of contract
summary: Dragages Singapore is suing 2 Hong Kong firms, Craft Projects (HK) Company and Craft Projects International Company, for S$14.8 million over alleged breach of contract for the roofing works of the Singapore Sports Hub. The sub-contractor, CFPL, failed to complete its sub-contract works and rectify defects, and also failed to perform the works with due diligence. The defendants deny the allegations, stating that Dragages commenced the proceedings outside the 6-year limitation period and that the final payment certificate was incorrect. A pre-trial conference is scheduled for Dec 17.

images.alt_text: Dragages Singapore, which is part of French company Bouygues Group, was the main contractor for the design and construction of the Sports Hub. It had entered into a sub-contract with Craft Facade (CFPL) to carry out the roofing works in 2011.

site_title: Europe: Markets open mixed
summary: Europe's stock markets opened mixed on Wednesday ahead of US interest rate decisions, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.1% due to UK inflation rising to 5.1% in November. The Paris CAC 40 index rose 0.6% and Frankfurt's DAX index increased 0.4%. Pressure mounts on central banks to tackle inflation, which has surged due to energy price hikes, supply chain issues, and demand. The Federal Reserve is expected to announce a faster withdrawal of financial support, while the European Central Bank and Bank of England make rate decisions on Thursday.

site_title: London nightclub owners pan UK's new Covid-19 rules for venues
summary: London nightclub owners criticized the UK's new Covid-19 rules, citing the lack of rapid tests as a significant challenge for enforcement. The new "Plan B" measures, announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, include Covid-19 vaccine passes for venues and the acceptance of negative rapid tests. The owners argue that the rapid test requirement will be difficult to enforce, raising concerns about the effectiveness of the new measures in halting the spread of the Omicron variant.

site_title: SBF calls for 3-month extension of Jobs Support Scheme in Budget 2022 wishlist
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has submitted a Budget 2022 wishlist, calling for a 3-month extension of the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) to support businesses facing uncertainty and cost pressures due to the endemic Covid-19. The SBF also requested a 1-year extension of the temporary bridging loan programme and increased support for sustainability and cyber resilience. Additionally, the federation proposed expanding the market readiness assistance scheme and increasing government incentives for adopting green solutions and electric vehicles.

site_title: Plant-based product review startup abillion taps into e-commerce with US$10m funds
summary: abillion, a plant-based product review startup, has secured a US$10 million funding round led by 1/0 Capital, bringing its total funding to US$17 million. The new funds will be used to build a peer-to-peer marketplace within the app and expand product development capabilities. Founded in Singapore, abillion has gained over 1 million downloads and 1 million reviews of plant-based food and products from 70,000 restaurants and 60,000 brands across 160 countries. The startup aims to use social media and e-commerce for sustainability and social impact.
