summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's recent acquisitions have offset its acquisition upsides, with Fitch Ratings projecting the trust's net debt to Ebitda ratio to hit 8.9 times by FY2022, exceeding the agency's threshold for a negative rating action. Analysts expect the trust's leverage to fluctuate based on equity issuance and acquisition completions. Despite this, the trust's strong pipeline of projects and increasing asset granularity provide growth prospects, maintaining its "BBB+/Stable" rating.

site_title: Starbucks launches probe in 5,400 China stores over expired food
summary: Starbucks China orders a full inspection of its 5,400 stores after undercover reporters discovered staff using expired ingredients in two outlets. The company apologized and vowed a zero-tolerance policy on food safety, citing a violation of operating regulations. The incident sparked anger among customers, with many calling for better quality at a higher price. The issue comes amid growing consumer nationalism in China, where foreign brands have faced criticism and boycotts.

site_title: Blinken urges China to stop 'aggressive actions' in Indo-Pacific
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken urged China to stop "aggressive actions" in the Indo-Pacific region, warning of concerns over Beijing's claims of the South China Sea, subsidies to state-run companies, and trade disruptions. Blinken said Washington would work with allies to defend the "rules-based order" and ensure freedom of navigation in the South China Sea, which affects $3 trillion in commerce annually. He emphasized the need for China to change its behavior, stating that countries in the region, including Indonesia, want this change.

site_title: Malaysia gives conditional approval for use of Ronapreve Covid-19 treatment
summary: Malaysia's health ministry has given conditional approval for the use of the single-dose antibody cocktail Ronapreve to treat Covid-19. Additionally, the ministry approved a clinical trial import license for Merck & Co's Covid-19 pill Molnupiravir to be used in studies in Malaysia. These approvals aim to provide more treatment options for Covid-19 patients in the country.

site_title: FOMO Pay joins DBS Digital Exchange, paving way for merchants to accept crypto payments
summary: FOMO Pay, a Singapore fintech company, has joined the DBS Digital Exchange (DDEx) as a member, allowing merchants to accept crypto payments. FOMO Pay, founded by Louis Liu in 2015, has obtained new licenses from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to facilitate transactions with digital payment tokens. The move aims to promote the adoption of crypto as a payment method in Singapore, aligning with the country's vision to become a global crypto hub.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as Woolworths slumps on bleak earnings view
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% to 7,349.10, driven by Woolworths Group's forecast of lower first-half operating income, leading to a 10.6% slump in its shares. Tech stocks also declined 0.5%, following the US Nasdaq's weaker finish. Investors are concerned about the potential impact of the Omicron variant and an increasingly hawkish Federal Reserve, which may signal a faster wind-down of asset purchases and interest rate hikes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.82 points or 0.19% to 1,492.04. Losers outnumbered gainers 233 to 117. This comes amidst global market trends, with European stocks also down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: World Bank keeps Thai growth outlook at 1% this year, sees better 2022
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 1% this year due to the ongoing impact of the coronavirus outbreak, but is projected to accelerate to 3.9% in 2022 as the service sector recovers and tourism activity increases. The World Bank attributes this growth to vaccination progress and a resumption of tourist arrivals. Economic activity is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels by the end of 2022, with foreign tourist numbers rising to 7 million in 2022 and 20 million in 2023. Monetary policy is expected to remain accommodative to support the recovery.

site_title: CapitaLand Development to acquire residential site in Binh Duong for S$1.1b
summary: CapitaLand Development has agreed to acquire a 18.9 ha site in Binh Duong New City, Vietnam for S$1.1 billion. The site will be developed into a large-scale residential project with over 3,700 freehold units for 13,000 residents, set to be completed by 2027. The project is CLD's largest in Vietnam and will boost its pipeline of residential units in the country, with the developer expecting to launch the project in phases starting in 2024.

site_title: QT Vascular says directors will skip Dec 15 EGM to oust incumbents, pending court application
summary: QT Vascular's directors will skip an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Dec 15, citing a pending court application to determine the validity of a requisitioning shareholders' call for a second vote. The directors will continue to hold office pending court guidance. A second EGM was called by shareholders Mission Well and Tansri Saridju Benui to appoint new directors, but the resolutions were previously rejected by a margin of 1.7 million shares at a Dec 6 EGM. QT Vascular's shares fell 14.3% after the announcement.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices continue to rise in Nov; volumes recover: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condominium resale prices in Singapore continued to rise in November, with a 0.8% month-on-month increase and 9.3% year-on-year growth. Volumes also recovered, rising 2.4% to 1,636 units resold, with the median capital gain standing at S$225,000. The highest median capital gain was recorded in District 10, while District 17 had the lowest. The en bloc market's easing restrictions and displaced owners contributing to the recovery of resale volumes, and robust demand and diminishing stock driving price increases.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, QT Vascular, Raffles Medical, CDL
summary: Keppel Corp is acquiring a 51% stake in Cleantech Renewable Assets for up to US$150 million. QT Vascular's directors will not attend an EGM, seeking a fresh bid for board seats. Raffles Medical Group partnered South Korea's Myongji hospital to create a "travel medicine pass" for travellers between Singapore and South Korea. City Developments Limited's shares hit a 3-week high after announcing plans to divest Millenium Hilton Seoul, reaching S$7.18.

site_title: Funding strains remain for Japan's small hotels and restaurants, complicating BOJ policy
summary: Japan's small hotels and restaurants continue to face financing strains due to the Covid-19 crisis, with a tankan survey showing an index of minus 33 in the three months to December. This is worse than the previous survey, highlighting the plight of service-sector firms still reeling from the pandemic's impact. The Bank of Japan is set to consider scaling back emergency funding, with the board leaning towards tapering corporate bond and commercial paper purchases while leaving intact a loan scheme targeting smaller firms.

site_title: Biotech startup Cargene raises US$19.2m in funding from Chinese investors
summary: Biotech startup Cargene Biopharma raised US$19.2 million in funding led by Chinese investors BioTrack Capital, Hyfinity Investments, and Legendstar Capital. The funding will be used to accelerate technology development and advance Cargene's lead asset to obtain US FDA marketing approval. The company is working on oligonulcleotide therapeutics for cardiovascular, fibrotic, and pulmonary diseases. This funding comes amid a surge in biotech activity, driven by the pandemic's success with Covid-19 vaccines.

site_title: Despite onerous restrictions, buying a PLH flat can pay off
summary: In Singapore's recent BTO exercise, buyers of Prime Location Public Housing (PLH) flats, such as those in River Peaks I and II in Rochor, can potentially earn significant capital gains. With a 10-year minimum occupation period and restrictions on resale, buyers may see a 126% net gain, exceeding the 98% rise in the HDB Resale Price Index between 2004 and 2021. However, financial flexibility is impacted by the long holding period, and renting restrictions apply. Despite this, PLH flats offer a more affordable and accessible option for Singaporeans, with subsidies and CPF housing grants available.

site_title: Gold muted as spotlight shifts to Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices remained largely unchanged on Tuesday, influenced by cautious investor sentiment ahead of key central bank meetings this week, including the US Federal Reserve's 2-day monetary policy meeting. Investors expect the Fed to accelerate its plans for rolling back pandemic-era economic support measures, potentially leading to interest rate hikes and higher government bond yields. The ECB is also set to confirm its pandemic emergency stimulus scheme will end next March, further weighing on gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold prices were little changed on Tuesday (Dec 14), as cautious investors focussed on key central bank meetings this week, with the US Federal Reserve likely to accelerate its plans for the roll-back of its pandemic-era economic support measures.

site_title: Singapore stocks flat at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.02%
summary: Singapore stocks remained flat at the open on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.02% to 3,120.44. The market weighed concerns over the Omicron variant, but gains outnumbered losses 58 to 56. Local banks were mixed, with DBS slipping 0.4%, UOB gaining 0.5%, and OCBC rising 0.4%. This comes as US stocks fell on Monday ahead of key Federal Reserve decisions, and European stocks ended lower due to rising Omicron variant risks.

images.alt_text: Bourse operator SGX announced that it has signed a MOU with its Chinese counterpart to establish an exchange-traded fund (ETF) link.

site_title: Joyful moment or risky move? Europe divided over kids' vaccines
summary: Europe is divided on vaccinating younger children against COVID-19, with countries taking different approaches. Some, like Italy, are making vaccination a "joyful moment" with entertainment and games, while others, like France and Germany, are targeting only the most vulnerable kids. The European Medicines Agency has approved the use of Pfizer-BioNTech's lower-dose vaccine for the 5-11 age group, but some governments are limiting the rollout due to concerns over data and safety. The rollout is expected to vary by country, with some starting as early as December 15.

site_title: Elon Musk named Time magazine person of the year
summary: Time magazine named Elon Musk as its person of the year 2021, citing his influence on technological shifts and troubling trends reshaping people's lives. Musk, the CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, became the world's wealthiest person this year, with a valuation of over $1 trillion for Tesla. He has courted controversy with his provocative Twitter feed and vision for colonizing Mars. Time editor-in-chief Edward Felsenthal noted Musk's impact on the decline of traditional institutions and the concentration of wealth and power in the hands of a few individuals.

site_title: Oil eases on worries Omicron could reduce demand
summary: Oil prices eased on Monday as concerns over the Omicron variant's impact on global demand weighed on the market. Brent futures fell 1.0% to $74.39 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.5% to $71.29 a barrel. Despite a forecasted increase in global oil demand, the World Health Organization warns of a "very high" global risk from the variant, which may evade vaccine protection. OPEC will meet on January 4 to discuss its output policy, with some predicting a potential cut in supply.

site_title: Vietnam conglomerate Masan eyes IPO for retail unit in 2023-2024
summary: Vietnamese conglomerate Masan plans to launch an international initial public offering (IPO) for its retail unit, The CrownX, in 2023-2024. The company has raised US$350 million from investors, including TPG and Temasek-owned SeaTown Master Fund. The CrownX, Vietnam's largest retail company, has a post-investment valuation of US$8.2 billion and plans to strengthen its consumer wallet services and digitize its platform ahead of the IPO. Masan will hold 81.4% of the consumer retail unit, with CEO Danny Le stating the company's focus will shift to scaling up its Point of Life platform nationwide.

site_title: Santa Claus rally? Much will depend on this week's FOMC meeting
summary: The US stock market is experiencing a year-end rally, dubbed a "Santa Claus" rally, due to rising hopes and optimism on Wall Street. However, investors should note that the impact of the Omicron variant on global confidence and growth is still uncertain. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) expects the variant to hurt growth, but the US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in 2022 due to growing inflation concerns. The outcome of the upcoming FOMC meeting on Wednesday will be crucial in determining the market's direction.

site_title: GameStop, AMC slump to multi-month lows
summary: Shares of GameStop and AMC Entertainment plummeted to multi-month lows, with GameStop down 11% at $141.74 and AMC slumping 14% to $23.64. The sell-offs come amid market declines and worries over a hawkish Federal Reserve and Covid-19 resurgence. The companies have faced recent unwelcome news, including GameStop's quarterly loss and AMC's top executives selling large stakes. Retail investors, who drove the initial gains, may be running out of funds as government stimulus checks are depleted.

site_title: NatWest fined nearly £265m in money laundering case
summary: NatWest Group has been fined nearly £265 million for breaching Britain's laws on money laundering. The bank pleaded guilty to three offences under the Money Laundering Regulations 2007, relating to a customer's £365 million deposit, some of which was in cash, between 2012 and 2016. Judge Sara Cockerill also ordered NatWest to pay $4.2 million in costs and made a £460,000 confiscation order, stating the bank's failings allowed the money laundering to occur.

site_title: Adobe targets upstart Canva in push for video, meme creators
summary: Adobe has launched Creative Cloud Express, a suite of products aimed at making it easier for users to create graphics, videos, and other digital content, in an effort to expand its reach beyond design professionals and compete with upstart Canva, which is valued at $40 billion. The move is a response to a growing market for design software outside the professional customer base, with Adobe estimating a potential market size of $41 billion in 2023. The new product suite will be free with pre-built templates, and Adobe plans to move free users to paid versions to increase revenue.

images.alt_text: Adobe is intensifying its effort to reach outside a core audience of design professionals in a bid to shield its long-standing industry dominance against burgeoning competition from upstarts.

site_title: Harley-Davidson says electric motorcyle unit will list on NYSE
summary: Harley-Davidson announced it will take its electric motorcycle division, LiveWire, public through a merger with AEA-Bridges Impact, valuing the combined entity at $1.8 billion. The move aims to raise $545 million to accelerate production and invest in new product development. LiveWire, established in 2019, has been available since then with a starting price of around $30,000. The transaction is expected to close in 2022, with Harley-Davidson holding 74% of the new company, and its CEO Jochen Zeitz planning to stay on as CEO for up to two years.

site_title: Brother fears Assange may not survive US prosecution
summary: Julian Assange's brother, Gabriel Shipton, expressed concerns that his brother may not survive US prosecution. Assange's fiancee, Stella Moris, recently revealed he suffered a mini-stroke in late October. The US government is seeking to prosecute Assange for WikiLeaks' 2010 publication of top-secret military documents. Assange's lawyers have raised health concerns, and demonstrators, including Roger Waters and Susan Sarandon, rallied outside the British consulate in New York to show support. The UK court's decision to overturn a ruling blocking Assange's removal has increased pressure on him, with Shipton fearing for his brother's life.

site_title: Row as foie gras comes off menu in some French cities
summary: French politicians in the Perigord region have denounced a decision by several cities to ban foie gras from official functions, calling it "political opportunism." The ban, which was welcomed by animal rights activists, is based on an outdated understanding of the production process, with most foie gras now made on small, ethical farms that comply with strict quality standards. Politicians argue that the force-feeding used to produce foie gras is now gentle and not as brutal as in the past, with some even defending the delicacy's gastronomic identity.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as market awaits key Federal Reserve decision
summary: US stocks fell on Monday as markets awaited the Federal Reserve's decision on scaling back stimulus, amid lingering worries over the Omicron variant. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.9%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.9% and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.4%. The Fed is expected to accelerate stimulus reduction, potentially leading to interest rate increases by mid-2022. Companies such as Arena Pharmaceuticals and Harley-Davidson saw gains, while Peloton Interactive jumped 7.4% after unveiling a new advertising spot.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a flurry of activity with various developments. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2. US stocks edged down from record highs amid tariff threats, and London's Heathrow eyed higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Chinese developers slump as Shimao bonds plunge
summary: Chinese real estate developers saw a slump in bonds and shares after Shimao Group Holdings' dollar notes plummeted 9 cents on the dollar, with other companies' bonds also falling. The decline snapped a buoyant mood in the sector, which had been boosted by Beijing's pro-growth policies. Shimao's 12% drop led a 2.8% decline in the Bloomberg Intelligence stock index of real estate firms, with other developers like Sunac China Holdings and Agile Group Holdings also retreating. The sell-off renewed concerns over the sector's health.

site_title: Horse racing idols app injects new life into Japan mobile gaming market
summary: The Japanese mobile gaming market has seen a surge in popularity with the release of Uma Musume Pretty Derby, a game that combines horse racing and idol culture. The game has generated hundreds of millions of dollars since its release in February 2021, becoming one of the world's top-grossing mobile games despite its Japan-only release. The game's success has bridged the gap between horse racing and gaming enthusiasts, with players spending millions of yen on in-game purchases and characters. This has provided a significant boost to Japan's mobile gaming market, which has been dominated by aging titles.

site_title: With troubles behind it, CDL can enter 2022 with a spring in its step
summary: CDL, a property giant, can enter 2022 with a positive outlook after the hotel operations posted a significant improvement in Q3 2021. Revenue per available room (RevPar) rose 117% to S$92, although still 42% below pre-pandemic levels. The company received a S$1.26 billion offer for its Millennium Hilton Seoul and adjoining land plot, resulting in an estimated gain of S$530 million. This sale will have a positive impact on CDL's net asset value and reminds investors that the company's share price is undervalued. The proposed deal also marks the group's fourth hotel divestment and its efforts to monetize assets and grow its fund management business.

site_title: Asian oil consumers yet to follow through on strategic releases
summary: The US has released 50 million barrels of crude oil from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, but Asian oil consumers have yet to follow through on their commitments, prompting skepticism in the market. The US has granted its first release to Exxon Mobil, but the other participating countries, including China, Japan, South Korea, India, and the UK, have been radio silent. The Asian nations' reluctance to release reserves may be due to concerns about jeopardizing their relationships with major producers and tapping into their reserves ahead of peak winter demand.

site_title: Apple closes in on US$3t market value
summary: Apple's market value hovered just shy of the $3 trillion mark on Monday, closing at $175.74 after a 2% decline. The company's shares rose 11% last week, extending a 30% year-to-date gain, driven by strong consumer demand for iPhones and services. Apple is on track to become the world's most valuable company, surpassing Microsoft's $2.6 trillion market value. The milestone marks a significant milestone for CEO Tim Cook, who has overseen the company's expansion into new products and markets, with Apple's stock returning 22% per year since the 1990s.

site_title: Spielberg's 'West Side Story' opens to tepid box office receipts
summary: Steven Spielberg's remake of West Side Story opened to an estimated $10.5 million in North American ticket sales, a disappointing result despite rave reviews. The film's global total stands at $14.9 million, falling short of Disney's pre-release goal of $25 million. Industry experts caution against making swift judgments, as musicals often experience slow starts. Spielberg remains committed to releasing his directorial projects theatrically, despite signing a deal with Netflix. The film's underwhelming box office performance raises concerns about the viability of non-visual effects-driven films in the current market.

site_title: Biden and Manchin will keep talking on US$1.75t spending bill: Manchin spokesperson
summary: US President Joe Biden and Senator Joe Manchin continued discussing a $1.75 trillion spending package, despite months of disagreement. The bill aims to bolster the social safety net and fight climate change, but faces opposition from Republicans and Manchin's concerns about inflation. Democrats have scaled back the bill's scope from $3.5 trillion, and a Congressional Budget Office analysis found it would add $3 trillion to the federal budget deficit over a decade. Despite this, top Senate Democrat Charles Schumer hopes to pass the bill by Christmas, with Manchin's vote crucial to its passage.

site_title: Malaysia, Chinese firm sign deal on second-generation biodiesel, biojet fuel
summary: Malaysia and China's Shanxi Construction Investment Group signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to produce second-generation biodiesel and biojet fuel. The HVO plant in Malaysia's Johor state is expected to bring RM3 billion in foreign investment and create nearly 800 jobs. The biodiesel and biojet fuel products will be used for the Chinese market and exported to Europe and the US. This collaboration aims to meet the increasing demand for HVO, particularly in Europe, and will utilize Malaysia's palm oil products.

site_title: The inflation suspense goes on
summary: The US inflation rate remained steady at 6.8% in December, aligning with expectations. Financial markets responded by reducing "breakeven rates" for inflation expectations over the next few years. However, underlying inflation appears to be high, around 4%, due to a constrained economy with spending back to pre-pandemic trends but production hindered by bottlenecks and labor force withdrawals. The Federal Reserve considers a sustained doubling of inflation a blow to its credibility, but the exact duration of elevated inflation remains uncertain.

site_title: Grab: a bellwether for Asean's digital growth?
summary: Grab's $40 billion IPO marks a significant milestone in Asean's digital growth story, but also highlights the region's challenges in politics, interoperability, talent, and sustainability. The ride-hailing giant's success demonstrates the potential for Asean tech players to join the global digital landscape, but also underscores the need for the region to address geopolitics, data interoperability, and sustainability. As Asean's digital economy is expected to reach $1 trillion by 2030, policymakers must prioritize openness, data management, and talent development to support the region's digital growth.

site_title: What 'transitory inflation' really means
summary: The US Federal Reserve's definition of "transitory inflation" is being reevaluated as data shows inflation rates are becoming more structural, despite initial claims that it was temporary. The Fed's chairman, Jerome Powell, previously defined "transitory" as a short-term phenomenon, but recent data suggests that inflation is persisting, with the Consumer Price Index (CPI) rising 6.8% year-over-year, its fastest pace since 1982. The Fed's stance on inflation is shifting, and experts warn that persistent higher inflation poses a significant risk to the economy, potentially leading to lost control of bond yields and impacting investors.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund misses domestic spending target
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has invested only half of its planned US$40 billion in domestic spending, with US$22 billion invested by the end of 2021. Crown Prince Mohammed Salman announced the plan in January, aiming to invest 150 billion riyals (S$54.6 billion) annually from 2021 to 2025. The fund's progress on domestic projects, such as Neom, has been slow, and its investments abroad have been more successful, with the sale of stakes in companies like Citigroup and Facebook.

site_title: What could possibly go wrong? These are the biggest economic risks for 2022
summary: Key economic risks for 2022 include the Omicron variant's impact on global growth, sticky inflation, US Federal Reserve rate hikes, and China's Evergrande real estate slump. Other risks include emerging markets' vulnerability to US rate hikes, a hard Brexit, and a fresh euro crisis. Potential positives include a global spending splurge fueled by pandemic savings and a potential boost to 5.1% global growth. However, a more contagious and deadly Omicron variant could drag on economies, while inflation and supply problems persist. The US Federal Reserve's rate hikes could lead to a recession in 2023, and a slowdown in China could have global implications.

site_title: Australia's Crown targets 2022 opening for troubled Sydney casino
summary: Crown Resorts, an Australian casino operator, aims to open its gaming floor in its Sydney resort early in 2022, nearly a year after its Sydney casino licence was suspended due to alleged dealings with organised crime groups. Following a leadership overhaul and board changes, the company is targeting a reopening. Business has seen a pick-up in recent weeks, and CEO Steve McCann believes the business has turned the corner, with annual corporate costs expected to be around A$130 million.

site_title: Trudeau proposes Canada, US harmonise electric vehicle rebates
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau proposed harmonizing electric vehicle rebates with the US to avoid a trade conflict. Trudeau's remarks came after the US threatened retaliatory tariffs on American goods and Ottawa suspended parts of the North American free trade agreement. The proposal aims to protect Canada's auto sector, which relies on integrated supply chains with the US. Trudeau emphasized the importance of cooperation between the two countries, highlighting their 50-year history of making cars together.

site_title: UAE de facto ruler, Israel's Bennett in historic meeting
summary: UAE de facto ruler Sheikh Mohammed Zayed al-Nahyan hosted Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett in a historic meeting, marking the first public encounter between the two leaders. The talks focused on shared concerns about Iranian activity, while the UAE also seeks to improve relations with Tehran. Bennett accepted an invitation to visit Israel, and the meeting aimed to advance cooperation and positive steps for the people of both nations and the region.

site_title: Tiong Seng hopes to set new rules for construction processes
summary: Construction group Tiong Seng is changing its procurement methods to save time and manpower. The company is working closely with subcontractors and experimenting with different building materials. Tiong Seng has stepped in to procure common materials, pursuing greater savings from economies of scale. This move aims to adapt to changes in the industry environment and improve efficiency.

site_title: UBS ordered to pay US$2b after French tax fraud appeal
summary: A French court of appeals ordered UBS to pay a reduced US$2 billion penalty for helping wealthy French clients hide undeclared funds in Swiss accounts. The penalty, down from 4.5 billion euros, includes 800 million euros in damages and a confiscation order of 1 billion euros. The ruling upheld a 2019 decision, but the bank can still appeal to France's top court, which may reduce the fine further.

site_title: November sales of new private homes double to 1,546 units
summary: Singapore's new private home sales rebounded in November with 1,546 units sold, a 70% increase from October and about double the number sold in the same month last year. The top-selling projects were CanningHill Piers, The Commodore, and Normanton Park, with the priciest non-landed home selling for S$48 million. Homes in the S$1 million to S$1.5 million range were the most popular, accounting for 29% of all sales, and nearly 60% of sales were in the Rest of Central Region.

site_title: Keppel Corp in consortium to acquire majority stake in solar platform for up to US$150m
summary: Keppel Corp, in a consortium with Keppel Asia Infrastructure Fund LP and Cloud Alpha, is acquiring a 51% stake in Cleantech Renewable Assets for up to US$150 million. Cleantech, a solar energy platform with over 600 megawatts of capacity across Asia, aims to reach a cumulative generation capacity of 3 gigawatts by 2026. The deal reflects Keppel's commitment to sustainability and its Vision 2030 plans for a 7-gigawatt renewable energy portfolio by 2030.

site_title: Blinken is in Asia, but his mind's on Ukraine
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is on a world trip to Southeast Asia, but his primary focus is on Ukraine and potential Russian invasion. Blinken is concerned about the strategic juncture and the threat of other nations, including China and Iran, taking advantage of the situation. He will meet with leaders in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand to discuss trade facilitation, digital economy, and worker standards, while also pushing back on China's assertiveness and securing support for pressure on Myanmar's military rulers. Meanwhile, the US is warning Russia against invading Ukraine, with President Biden threatening economic sanctions and US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan hinting at targeting the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline.

site_title: Indonesia expects drastic cut to budget deficit on tax windfall
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, has cut the country's budget deficit estimates to 4.1% of GDP in 2022, down from 4.85%, due to a tax windfall and tempered spending. The government aims to bring the deficit under the 3% limit by 2023. New tax hikes and measures to reduce financing needs are expected to bolster earnings. Indonesia joins other nations in tightening their belts ahead of 2022, as the country's growth recovery is set to take hold.

site_title: Keppel Corp in consortium to acquire majority stake in solar platform for up to US$150m
summary: Keppel Corp, through a consortium, has agreed to acquire a 51% stake in Cleantech Renewable Assets for up to $150 million. Cleantech, a solar energy platform, aims to reach 3 gigawatts of generation capacity by 2026. The deal reflects Keppel's commitment to sustainability and aligns with its Vision 2030 plan to grow its renewables business. Keppel's CEO, Loh Chin Hua, stated that the investment will accelerate the company's growth in the renewables space, targeting 7 gigawatts of renewable energy assets by 2030.

site_title: Miss India wins Miss Universe 2021 pageant held in Israel despite boycott calls
summary: Miss India, Harnaaaz Sandhu, was crowned Miss Universe 2021 at the 70th edition of the pageant held in Eilat, Israel, defying boycott calls from Palestinian groups. Despite the controversy, the event was attended by an estimated 600 million viewers worldwide. Singapore's Nandita Banna made it past the opening round for the first time in 34 years, while Paraguay's Nadia Ferreira and South Africa's Lalela Mswane took first and third place, respectively.

images.alt_text: Miss Universe 2021 winner Harnaaz Sandhu of India after winning the crown iin the Red Sea resort of Eilat, Israel, on Dec 13.
Host Steve Harvey speaking to Miss Singapore Nandita Banna, one of the Top 16 finalists, during the pageant.

site_title: At least 64 people confirmed dead in Kentucky after barrage of tornadoes
summary: At least 64 people confirmed dead in Kentucky after a barrage of tornadoes tore through six states, with the death toll expected to increase. The tornadoes destroyed a candle factory in Mayfield, killing eight people, and caused widespread damage across the state. Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear estimated the death toll from the disaster at 80 and possibly higher. President Joe Biden declared a major federal disaster in Kentucky, paving the way for additional federal aid.

site_title: From Singapore to Seoul: Supporting S Korea's digital drive
summary: A Singaporean technology conglomerate, ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC), is partnering with Hyosung Heavy Industries to build a carrier-neutral data centre in South Korea. The project aims to support the country's rapidly growing digital economy, which is driven by governmental policies such as the Digital New Deal. The data centre will be built with support from Standard Chartered, which acted as mandated lead arranger and original lender. The project is expected to generate USD45 billion in national GDP and create 50,000 jobs, highlighting the potential of South Korea's digital drive and the opportunities for international companies to expand into the market.

site_title: EMA to offer scheme for large businesses to secure fixed price electricity plan
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore is launching the Temporary Electricity Contracting Support Scheme (TRECS) to provide large businesses with 1-month fixed price electricity plans amid "unprecedented volatility" in the market. The scheme offers around 300 megawatts of power capacity and is available from December 15 to December 27. EMA works with generation companies and retailers to offer the fixed price plans, which are not mandatory for businesses. The move aims to address the impact of volatile prices on large businesses and ensure access to electricity supply for consumers.

site_title: Be wary before jumping on the blockchain bandwagon
summary: Starbucks' bean-to-cup tracking program, which uses blockchain technology, has raised concerns about its necessity. The company claims it can already track its coffee beans, but critics argue that blockchain is an expensive and slow database. Similar initiatives by companies like Kickstarter and property developer Hatten Land have also sparked criticism, with investors and users expressing skepticism about the practical use cases and environmental impact of blockchain technology. Experts predict that 90% of blockchain-based supply chain initiatives will suffer from "blockchain fatigue" by 2023 due to limited use cases and high participation requirements.

site_title: UK declares 'Omicron emergency', ramps up booster programme
summary: The UK has declared an "Omicron emergency" amid rising cases and deaths, prompting Prime Minister Boris Johnson to accelerate the rollout of Covid-19 booster shots to all adults aged 18 and older by December 31. The government has also raised the pandemic alert to Level 4, citing concerns about the variant's rapid spread and its impact on the economy, which is already slowing down. The UK economy is expected to contract in December, with economists predicting a 4.7% growth rate for next year, down from 5.2% previously.

site_title: Dollar stands tall in blockbuster week for central banks
summary: The US dollar strengthened ahead of central bank meetings this week, with investors watching for hints on the Fed's bond buying unwinding and potential interest rate hikes in 2022. The dollar index rose 0.3% to 96.38, while the euro fell 0.4% to US$1.1268. Analysts predict moderate hawkish risks at the Fed's FOMC meeting on Wednesday, but some believe the dollar's gains have already factored in short-term strength. Other currencies, including the Norwegian krone and Turkish lira, also declined against the US dollar.

site_title: New Silkroutes receives statutory demand for S$146,234 from landlord
summary: New Silkroutes Group received a statutory demand of around S$146,234.73 from landlord Fragrance Regal for unpaid rent at the Fragrance Empire Building in Alexandra Road. The demand was issued after the company failed to respond to a previous letter, which was only retrieved on Dec 13, due to work-from-home arrangements during the Covid-19 pandemic. The company is reviewing the demand with its legal and financial advisers and will take necessary action.

site_title: Apple's upcoming iPhone SE 5G could help attract billion-plus Android users, says JP Morgan
summary: Apple's upcoming iPhone SE 5G is expected to attract over 1.4 billion non-premium Android users, targeting the mid-range smartphone market dominated by Samsung and Huawei. The iPhone SE, priced between $269-$399, could lure both low- to mid-end Android users and older iPhone model users. This move is seen as a strategic move by Apple to expand its customer base and offset the impact of global chip shortages and supply chain disruptions. JP Morgan analysts have raised their estimates for iPhone SE unit sales to 30 million units and annual iPhone shipments to 250 million units.

site_title: Iron ore jumps over 7% on bets China will boost fiscal stimulus
summary: Iron ore prices surged over 7% in Singapore and Dalian, driven by expectations that China will boost fiscal stimulus in early 2022 to bolster its economy. The decision by China's Communist Party to prioritize "ensuring stability" and "front loading" policies has boosted demand optimism. Economists predict China will start adding fiscal stimulus after curbs on property are expected to remain. The four-week winning streak in iron ore futures has pushed prices to their highest close since late October, with prices reaching US$116.15 a tonne.

site_title: Hong Kong court sentences Lai to prison over Tiananmen vigil
summary: A Hong Kong court sentenced former media mogul Jimmy Lai and seven other pro-democracy activists to prison for commemorating China's June 4, 1989, Tiananmen Square crackdown. The sentences, ranging from 4 to 14 months, were the latest example of the city's crackdown on dissent and free speech. Lai received 13 months, while Lee Cheuk-Yan, a former lawmaker, received the heaviest sentence of 14 months. The convictions were seen as a warning to others who would defy the government's ban on commemorating the Tiananmen Square massacre.

site_title: Singapore businessman and Jardine veteran YC Boon dies at 87
summary: Singapore businessman and Jardine veteran YC Boon, 87, has passed away following a short illness. He served as chairman of the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce from 1988 to 1990 and was its longest-serving board member, contributing 35 years of service. Boon was also active in several organizations, including the Singapore National Employers Federation and the CPF Board. He will be remembered for his sterling service to the business community and his contributions to various organizations in Singapore.

site_title: Elon Musk named Time magazine person of the year
summary: Time magazine has named Elon Musk as its Person of the Year for 2021, citing his influence on life on Earth and potentially life off Earth. Musk, 50, overtook space race rival Jeff Bezos to become the world's richest person this year, with Tesla's electric car company valuation soaring above a trillion dollars. Musk's ambitions include colonizing Mars, orbital flights to the Moon, and making humanity a multi-planet species. He is known for his influence on markets and cryptocurrencies with a single tweet, and his groundbreaking electric vehicles.

site_title: China detects first case of Omicron coronavirus variant
summary: China has detected the first case of the Omicron coronavirus variant on the mainland, reported in Tianjin after a traveller from overseas tested positive on Dec 9. The asymptomatic patient is being treated in isolation in hospital. This discovery marks the first Omicron case in mainland China, raising concerns about the spread of the variant.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.98 points to 1494.86, closing higher on Tuesday with a trading volume of 2.629 billion lots worth RM1.85 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 491 to 386.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat; Fed meeting eyed
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened flat on Monday ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting later this week, despite Apple's shares climbing as it neared a $3 trillion market capitalization. The Dow Jones fell 0.03%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.04%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.06%. Market uncertainty due to potential US-EU tariffs remains a concern.

site_title: Pfizer to buy Arena Pharmaceuticals for US$6.7b
summary: Pfizer agreed to acquire Arena Pharmaceuticals for $6.7 billion in an all-cash deal. Arena's ulcerative colitis treatment candidate, etrasimod, is in a late-stage study. The acquisition aims to expand Pfizer's cancer and inflammatory disease treatment pipeline. Pfizer will finance the transaction using its cash reserves, representing a 100.2% premium to Arena's last closing price.

site_title: Malaysia says US chipmaker Intel to invest US$7b in new facility
summary: Intel Corporation is investing US$7.10 billion in a new facility in Malaysia, expanding its manufacturing capabilities for advanced semiconductor packaging technologies in the northern state of Penang. The investment will strengthen Intel's supporting activities and global service center, positioning Malaysia as a key hub for manufacturing and shared services. The facility's addition is expected to bolster Intel's operations in the region, with a press conference scheduled for Wednesday at the Kuala Lumpur International Airport.

site_title: Credit Suisse announces new members of executive board
summary: Credit Suisse announced a new executive board overhaul, appointing Francesco De Ferrari as CEO of its wealth-management division and interim CEO of Europe, Middle East and Africa. Christian Meissner became CEO of the Americas region, while Helman Sitohang and Andre Helfenstein were named CEOs of the Asia-Pacific and Switzerland regions, respectively. The bank also introduced a new board of directors model to enhance effectiveness and governance. This move comes after the bank suffered significant losses in 2021, including a quarter drop in its share price and multiple controversies, including bribery and client losses.

site_title: Tanglin Shopping Centre makes 4th collective sale attempt at S$828m
summary: Tanglin Shopping Centre is making its fourth attempt at a collective sale, with a guide price of S$828 million. The site, which is over 50 years old and comprises 313,435 sq ft, has a reserve price lower than its previous bids in 2011 and 2017. The commercial zoning allows for multiple development options, including hotel and residential uses, and offers no additional buyers' stamp duty. The site is located in the prime Orchard area, with nearby amenities and transportation links. The tender closes on February 22, 2022.

images.alt_text: Tanglin Shopping Centre is making a fourth try for a collective sale with a guide price of S$828 million.

site_title: Binance in tie-up with Dubai government as questions over headquarters linger: sources
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, is set to sign a memorandum of understanding with the government of Dubai, a potential location for its global headquarters. The move comes as Binance faces increasing scrutiny from various jurisdictions over regulatory compliance and money laundering concerns. Despite withdrawing its crypto licence application in Singapore, Binance is strengthening its ties with the UAE and exploring opportunities in the Middle East and Europe. The company's CEO, Changpeng "CZ" Zhao, has expressed his commitment to Dubai, citing its "very pro-crypto" government and business-friendly environment.

site_title: Intraco to invest in digital asset platform
summary: Intraco, a mainboard-listed trading company, has entered into a binding heads of agreement to invest S$10 million in digital asset platform MHC Digital Co (MHC Singapore) for a 51% stake. The investment includes S$10 million in cash and the issuance of 100 million new shares at S$0.50 per share. MHC Singapore will take over the businesses and assets of Australian digital asset platform MHC Digital Group. The deal is subject to shareholders' approval and various conditions, including regulatory approvals and financial performance. Intraco expects the investment to create new revenue streams and enhance shareholder value.

site_title: Vatican office apologises for hurting Catholic LGBTQ community
summary: The Vatican's Synod of Bishops has apologised for removing a link to a Catholic gay rights advocacy group's resource material, causing pain to the LGBTQ community. The link was restored after criticism on social media. The Synod is preparing for a 2023 meeting in Rome, and the apology is seen as an attempt to address concerns about the Church's stance on LGBTQ issues. The Vatican acknowledged the importance of inclusivity and promoting understanding within the Catholic community.

site_title: New China import rules bring headaches for food and beverage makers
summary: China's new food safety rules, effective January 1, require all food manufacturing facilities abroad to be registered for their goods to access the Chinese market. This has caused disruptions for food and beverage makers, including Irish whiskey, Belgian chocolate, and European coffee brands. Despite a delay allowing existing products to be exempt, many exporters fear their goods will not be able to enter the market. Experts say the rules aim to better oversee food imports and place responsibility for food safety with manufacturers.

site_title: At least one patient has died from Omicron variant in the UK
summary: At least one patient has died in the UK after contracting the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, according to Prime Minister Boris Johnson. The Omicron variant is spreading rapidly, accounting for 40% of London's infections, and Britain is advising double-jabbed individuals to receive an additional vaccine dose due to vulnerability. Johnson has imposed tougher restrictions to combat the spread, warning of a "tidal wave" of Omicron.

site_title: Raffles Hospital partners South Korea hospital to launch 'travel medicine pass'
summary: Raffles Hospital, a Singaporean hospital, has partnered with Myongji Hospital in South Korea to launch a "travel medicine pass" for travelers between the two countries. Pass holders will receive priority medical treatment, pre-departure and on-arrival Covid-19 tests, and seamless access to medical facilities in case of emergencies. The partnership aims to create a safe and seamless international travel experience, and sign-ups can be made through Raffles Medical Group's RafflesConnect app.

site_title: Opec upbeat on 2022 oil demand, says Omicron impact to be mild
summary: Opec raised its world oil demand forecast for the first quarter of 2022 to 99.13 million barrels per day, up 1.11 million bpd from the previous forecast. The organization expects oil demand to grow by 5.65 million bpd in 2021 and 4.15 million bpd in 2022, pushing consumption above 2019 levels. Opec believes the Omicron coronavirus variant will have a mild impact, allowing the world to manage Covid-19 challenges effectively. Output cuts are gradually being unwound, with Opec+ agreeing to boost monthly output by 400,000 bpd in January.

site_title: Significant resources expended to investigate ex-WP MP Raeesah Khan's allegations: Police
summary: Singapore's police force dedicated significant resources to investigating former Workers' Party MP Raeesah Khan's allegations of a sexual assault case in Parliament, despite her later confession to lying. The police checked records of over 1,400 cases and interviewed more than 1,400 officers, but found no match. The investigation's quantitative impact was significant, causing delays in handling other cases and affecting public trust in the police. The police emphasized the importance of public trust in their ability to prevent and detect crime, and warned that false accusations can erode this trust and affect officer morale.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Energy Market Authority is considering market rule adjustments to address high power sector prices. CDL is selling a 5-star hotel in Seoul for S$1.26b, its largest hotel divestment. Binance has shut down its Singapore operations, closing registrations and trading by February 13. JPMorgan and Nuveen acquired a 50% interest in One George Street for US$472m each. Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,119.95.

site_title: Omicron poses 'very high' global risk but data on severity limited: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has classified the Omicron coronavirus variant as posing a "very high" global risk, citing evidence of potential evasive immune escape and high transmission rates. While data on severity remains limited, preliminary findings suggest Omicron may be less severe than the Delta variant, with most cases in Europe being mild or asymptomatic. However, increased transmission is expected to lead to hospitalizations and potential health system burdens, regardless of severity. More data is needed to fully understand the severity profile of Omicron.

site_title: Thai central bank is focused on growth ahead of rate review
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, is focused on promoting economic growth ahead of its rate review next week. Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput stated that domestic considerations, such as inflation, growth, and financial stability, will dictate the central bank's rate trajectory. Despite US Federal Reserve actions, Thailand is less concerned due to its relatively stable economy and lower vulnerability to rapid tapering. The central bank projects a 0.7% growth this year and 3.9% in 2022, with forecasts to be reviewed at the Dec 22 rate meeting.

site_title: Omicron seen trumping inflation for Bank of England this week
summary: The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates at a record low due to concerns over the Omicron variant, pushing back its first rate increase since the pandemic into 2022. Economists and analysts, in a Bloomberg survey, predict a 6-3 decision in favor of keeping rates unchanged, with most seeing liftoff in February. This decision aligns with market expectations, which imply a less than 40% chance of an increase, down from nearly 100% last month. The move reflects the BOE's cautious approach to COVID-19 and inflation concerns.

site_title: Singapore stocks kick off week in the red, STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks started the week on a downward trend, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.5% to 3,119.95, led by caution over the new Omicron virus variant and Federal Reserve tapering decisions. Despite this, trading firm Intraco I06 rose 85.4% after announcing a 51% stake acquisition in MHC Digital Co. Local lenders Jardine Matheson Holdings, UOB, DBS, and OCBC were among the decliners, while digital security firm Disa Limited was the most heavily traded counter.

site_title: Chinese developers slump as Shimao bond plunge spooks investors
summary: Chinese developers' bonds and shares plummeted after Shimao Group Holdings' dollar notes dropped as much as 9 cents on the dollar, sparking concerns over the sector's health. The sudden selloff, which included declines in other companies' bonds, halted trading in six of Shimao's yuan bonds and led to a 2.8% drop in a Bloomberg Intelligence real estate index. Optimism over Beijing's pro-growth policies had driven yields down, but the inclusion of a phrase by President Xi Jinping clarifying "overly optimistic views" on property policies fueled the decline.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at close
summary: Hong Kong shares closed 0.17% down at 23,954.58 on Monday, despite a record lead from Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.40% to 3,681.08, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.60% to 2,561.91. The downbeat Hong Kong market followed a similar trend in Europe, where stocks fell due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Sultan Plaza, City Plaza join ranks of en bloc hopefuls
summary: Sultan Plaza and City Plaza in Singapore are expected to launch collective sale tenders, with potential reserve prices of S$360 million and S$850 million, respectively. The 99-year leasehold Sultan Plaza, housing 244 units, and the 18-storey freehold City Plaza, with 531 units, have obtained signatures from 80% of unit owners. Both properties have a history of en bloc attempts, with previous tenders in 2019 for Sultan Plaza and 2017 for City Plaza. The tenders are set to be launched in about 2 weeks.

site_title: Revolut names HSBC's Deepak Khanna as new head of wealth and trading
summary: Revolut has appointed Deepak Khanna, former head of wealth products at HSBC, as the new head of wealth and trading. Khanna, with over 2 decades of experience in wealth management, will lead teams launching Revolut's wealth and trading products and manage product performance. He starts his new role on December 14. This appointment comes after Revolut obtained a capital markets services licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore on December 6, with plans to implement its commission-free stock trading feature in the first half of 2022.

images.alt_text: The former HSBC head of wealth products and journeys will start his new role on Dec 14

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Parkway Life Reit, Golden Energy, No Signboard, Top Glove
summary: Several Singaporean companies have made notable announcements that may impact trading on Monday. City Developments Limited (CDL) plans to sell its Millennium Hilton Seoul and adjoining land plot for S$1.26 billion. Parkway Life Reit acquired a nursing home in Japan's Greater Tokyo Region for S$38.4 million. Golden Energy and Resources is consolidating its stake in an Australian subsidiary for US$30 million. No Signboard reiterated that litigation over beer deliveries won't affect its financial position. Top Glove Corporation posted a net profit of S$60.1 million for the first quarter of fiscal year 2022.

site_title: Investors push world's top chemicals companies over hazardous substances
summary: Investors managing $4.1 trillion in assets are urging the world's top chemicals companies to phase out production of hazardous substances linked to serious health problems. The 23 investors, including Aviva Investors and Storebrand, have called for increased transparency and a shift to safer chemicals. They also want companies to share data with the International Chemical Secretariat and set out plans to develop products for a "circular economy". The move comes as regulators toughen rules around hazardous chemicals and analysts warn of potential billions of dollars in clean-up and compensation costs.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened steady on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index flat at 7,292.85 points, Frankfurt's DAX index up 0.2% to 15,654.05, and Paris's CAC 40 almost unchanged at 6,992.14. The week is expected to be dominated by central bank decisions on interest rates amid surging inflation. The Bank of England will decide on Thursday to raise borrowing costs, while the European Central Bank and Federal Reserve also hold monetary policy meetings.

site_title: Binance pulls out of Singapore, shuts down trading in January
summary: Binance has withdrawn its application for a crypto permit in Singapore, effectively shutting down its operations in the city-state by February 13. Users will be able to buy and sell crypto until January 12. The move comes as Binance is set to announce its global home, potentially excluding Singapore. Binance has also announced plans to set up a blockchain innovation hub in Singapore, despite the closure.

images.alt_text: Binance Singapore unit has withdrawn its application for a crypto permit by MAS to operate in the city-state, and will shut down its operations in the financial hub by Feb 13, it said in a statement.

site_title: Malaysia, Chinese firm sign deal on second-generation biodiesel, biojet fuel
summary: Malaysia and China's state-owned Shanxi Construction Investment Group signed a memorandum of understanding to collaborate on the production of second-generation biodiesel and biojet fuel. Shanxi Construction plans to invest in a hydrogenated vegetable oil (HVO) plant in Malaysia's Johor state, which can produce sustainable aviation fuels. The move is driven by increasing demand for HVO, particularly from Europe. The project aims to support Malaysia's energy and commodities sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, Dec 13, 2021, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index advancing 0.71% to 28,640.49. Investors took heart from US rallies and digested the Bank of Japan's key business confidence survey. The broader Topix index also rose 0.13% to 1,978.13.

site_title: Brokers' take: Mixed commercial S-Reits to offer stronger growth in FY2022, DBS says
summary: DBS expects mixed commercial S-Reits to offer stronger growth in FY2022, driven by the economy's reopening and return-to-office recovery, with projected growth of 8-20%. The bank has "buy" calls on Suntec Reit, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, and Mapletree Commercial Trust, citing strong distribution per unit growth. DBS projects upside of 21.4% for CICT, 27.5% for Suntec, and 17.8% for MCT. The recovery in office rents is expected to continue, with "flight to quality" trend favoring prime office buildings.

site_title: Circles.Life offers to buy back US$5m in employee options
summary: Digital telco Circles.Life is offering to buy back US$5 million in employee stock options ahead of a planned initial public offering, as part of its employee stock ownership plan (ESOP) liquidity event. This move comes as more South-east Asian startups explore ways to allow staff to partially cash out share options earlier to retain talent. The company, which holds ESOP liquidity events every 18 months, has seen its employee stock options grow 13-fold in value since their initial award.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks ease off 7-week high on caution ahead of Fed meeting
summary: South Korean shares closed lower on Monday after touching a 7-week high due to investor caution ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. The benchmark KOSPI index fell 0.28% to 3,001.66, as foreigners sold net 136.9 billion won worth of shares. The won ended flat, and bond yields fell, while technology giant Samsung Electronics and biopharmaceutical firm Samsung Biologics dropped 0.13% and 3.22%, respectively. The country reported a 20.4% jump in exports for the first 10 days of December.

site_title: Why Singapore is attracting family offices globally
summary: Singapore is attracting family offices globally due to its business-friendly environment, low taxes, and high standard of living. Mr. Amit Lohia, vice-chairman of Indorama Corporation, chose to set up his family office in Singapore, citing the city-state's ability to manage complex family wealth and provide a secure environment for family assets. Singapore's government has actively courted family offices with incentives, such as tax breaks and streamlined regulations, to establish itself as a hub for ultra-high net worth individuals. As a result, Singapore is becoming a popular destination for family offices seeking a secure and efficient wealth management solution.

site_title: As floods slam more US firms, US$50b economic drag expected in 2022
summary: US businesses are expected to face a nearly $50 billion annual economic hit from flooding in 2022, with 3.1 million days of operations lost due to floods. Climate change is fueling extreme weather events, putting 730,000 commercial properties at risk of projected flood damage. Cities like Miami, New York, and Pittsburgh are among the high-risk areas, while inland cities like Nashville and Cincinnati are also at significant risk. The economic fallout is expected to worsen over the coming decades, with 4 million days of operations lost by 2052.

site_title: Britain says Omicron accounts for 40% of London infections
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the Omicron variant of coronavirus accounts for 40% of London infections, with the variant spreading at a "phenomenal rate". Unless action is taken, a million people could be infected by the end of the month, according to Britain. Double-jabbed individuals are vulnerable to the variant, prompting the call for an additional vaccine dose. Johnson imposed tougher restrictions earlier this month in response to the Omicron variant's detection on November 27.

site_title: Baode Building launched again for collective sale at S$27m indicative price
summary: The Baode Building in Singapore has been put up for collective sale with an indicative price of S$27 million, the same price as its previous attempt in July 2021. Located near Paya Lebar MRT Station, the 8-storey freehold building has 14 residential units and a site area of 11,102 sq ft. Developers are encouraged to tap into the growing demand for new residential units in the area, according to Colliers. The latest tender will close on January 18, 2022.

site_title: Shifting supply chains creating new opportunities in alternative port choices: CBRE
summary: Supply chain shifts are creating opportunities for alternative ports and industrial spaces in Asia and beyond. CBRE reports that ports in Xiamen, Qingdao, and Tanjung Pelepas in China, and those in Southeast Asia such as Piraeus and Valencia in Europe, are expected to attract more container volume as manufacturers diversify their suppliers. In the US, East and Gulf Coast ports like Charleston and Houston may benefit from shifts in manufacturing to Asia or Europe. Meanwhile, emerging economies like Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines are emerging as key distributors and manufacturers, with Vietnam's registered foreign direct investment reaching $22 billion in the first three quarters of 2021.

site_title: Business sentiment cautious in Japan as virus fears linger
summary: Japan's major manufacturers remain cautious about the economy, with business sentiment flat for the quarter due to lingering concerns about the pandemic. The Bank of Japan's Tankan survey showed a reading of plus 18, unchanged from the previous quarter. However, among large non-manufacturers, confidence improved to plus 9, the sixth consecutive improvement. The concerns over the Omicron variant have led to emergency measures, but the vaccination programme has picked up speed, with 78% of the population fully inoculated.

site_title: Libor limbers up for 'Y2K' walk into a US$265t sunset
summary: The London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) is set to be discontinued on December 31, marking the end of its role in pricing derivatives and loans worth over $265 trillion globally. The rate's demise is being compared to the "Y2K" computer coding issue in 2000, with banks spending around $10 billion preparing for the transition. Although many derivatives markets have already switched to new benchmarks, regulators warn of potential glitches in loan markets, particularly if borrowers miss warnings of the switch. The rate is being replaced by central bank-set rates, including the US Federal Reserve's Sofr rate.

site_title: Miss India wins Miss Universe; Singapore makes it to 2nd round for first time in 34 years
summary: Miss India Harnaaz Sandhu was crowned Miss Universe in Eilat, Israel, in the 70th edition of the pageant, which faced challenges due to the pandemic. Sandhu took the top prize, with Paraguay's Nadia Ferreira as first runner-up and Miss South Africa Lalela Mswane as second runner-up. Singapore made its first appearance in the second round in 34 years, with 21-year-old Nandita Banna reaching the top 16. The pageant, which was held in Israel despite Palestinian groups' calls for boycotts, received criticism for cultural insensitivity.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise after Wall St rally
summary: Asia stocks rose in early Monday trade, following a record-breaking rally on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong rose 1.03% and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 1.09%. The S&P 500 on Friday surged 0.9%, despite a 6.8% jump in consumer prices, which may signal a sooner tapering of US Federal Reserve's monetary policy. Analysts expect interest rate hikes in 2022, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell set to update markets this week.

site_title: The winds of change in board governance
summary: Changes in corporate governance are driven by external events, international best practices, and shifts in social attitudes. In response to scandals, regulators have strengthened governance rules, such as the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002. International governance standards, like the Singapore Code of Corporate Governance, have also led to increased board independence, with 54.5% of directors being independent in 2021. Societal standards, including gender diversity, are also evolving, with women making up 13.4% of board directors in 2021, but progress is slow, with only 17.2% of top 100 companies having female directors.

site_title: Taiwan set to keep benchmark rate unchanged with economy strong: poll
summary: Taiwan's central bank is expected to keep its benchmark discount rate unchanged at 1.125% on December 16, according to a Reuters poll of 25 economists. The decision is driven by a strong economy supported by robust tech demand, despite a slight slowdown in the third quarter due to Covid-19 cases. Policymakers anticipate the economy will expand over 6% for 2021, with inflation expected to remain under control, ending the year at around 2%. A rate hike would strengthen the Taiwan dollar, raising concerns about being labeled a currency manipulator by the US.

site_title: JPMorgan, Nuveen acquire 50% interests in One George Street for US$472m each
summary: JPMorgan Global Alternatives and Nuveen Real Estate have acquired a 50% interest each in One George Street in Raffles Place for US$472 million each, totaling US$944 million. The 23-floor Grade A office tower has over 50 multinational tenants and a 97% occupancy rate. The acquisition is seen as a cyclical upswing opportunity, with Singapore's attractiveness as an investment destination and increasing demand from the technology and financial services sectors. The joint venture aims to capitalize on stable income and premium office space.

site_title: Manufacturing success in an era of accelerated transformation
summary: Asean's manufacturing sector is emerging from a challenging two-year period, with the industry racing to accelerate transformation efforts and adopt Industry 4.0 technologies. Despite ongoing trade tensions and fluctuating consumer demand, research by the Boston Consulting Group projects that Asean could generate up to $600 billion in additional manufacturing output by 2030 if manufacturers capitalize on current opportunities. However, the question remains whether Asean's manufacturers are ready to move up the value chain and lead as a global hub for smart manufacturing innovation, with many needing to rapidly compress their transformation timelines and adopt a holistic approach to technological adoption.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at the open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.03% at the open on Monday, December 13, 2021, as investors took heart from US rallies. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,242.26, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. These gains followed US market records despite ongoing US-EU tariff concerns.

site_title: China's Sensetime to withdraw US$767m Hong Kong IPO after US ban: sources
summary: Chinese AI startup SenseTime Group will withdraw its $767 million Hong Kong IPO after being added to a US investment blacklist. The company was placed on the list by the Biden Administration due to concerns over its development of facial recognition programs for ethnic Uyghurs in China's Xinjiang region. SenseTime plans to update its prospectus and relaunch the IPO process, potentially in the future. The US Treasury's designation of SenseTime as a "Chinese military-industrial complex company" has sparked international controversy over human rights abuses in Xinjiang.

site_title: Gold extends gains on US inflation data, focus on central bank meetings
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,786.51 per ounce, driven by US inflation data showing the largest annual gain since 1982. Investors await central bank meetings, including the US Federal Reserve, which is expected to signal faster tapering of asset buying and earlier interest rate hikes. Reduced stimulus and rate hikes tend to increase government bond yields, raising the opportunity cost of holding bullion. The European Central Bank is set to halve its asset buying in April.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.51 points or 0.37% to 1,494.39. The market saw 223.67 million lots traded worth RM116.21 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 185 to 1.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as easing Omicron fears support commodities
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 7,388, driven by energy and mining stocks as commodity prices strengthened amid easing concerns about Omicron's impact on global economic growth. Energy stocks climbed 1.6%, led by Beach Energy and Woodside Petroleum, while mining stocks rose 1.4% with gains from Rio Tinto, BHP, and Fortescue. Property investor Charter Hall also advanced 4.7% after hiking its earnings guidance. The rebound follows a 0.4% drop on Friday.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts targets early 2022 opening for Sydney casino
summary: Crown Resorts, an Australian casino operator, aims to open its Sydney casino in early 2022, following talks with regulators to address governance concerns and alleged money laundering. The casino's license was suspended in 2020, but the company has made progress in addressing regulators' concerns. Business at Crown's sites has picked up, especially over weekends, as Australia relaxed Covid-19 curbs, but annual corporate costs are expected to be higher due to the suspension.

site_title: No spooky sights yet at 'haunted' residence, Japan PM says
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said he slept soundly in his new residence, which is reputedly haunted by ghosts, after becoming the first premier in nine years to inhabit the official Tokyo home. The residence was the site of a 1936 attempted coup, leading to reports of ghostly apparitions. Kishida, however, dismissed the rumors, stating he felt "fresh" after his first night in the residence.

site_title: Hot stock: CDL up as much as 2.7% on Millennium Hilton Seoul divestment
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) shares surged 2.7% to a 3-week high on Monday after announcing plans to divest the Millennium Hilton Seoul hotel in South Korea for S$1.26 billion. This marks CDL's fourth hotel divestment from the Millennium & Copthorne Hotels portfolio and is expected to result in a S$529.73 million gain. The sale, along with the adjoining land plot, is CDL's largest hotel divestment to date, with the company recognizing the gain post-deal.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.7% at the opening of trading on Monday, December 13, 2021, following a rally on Wall Street due to an inflation reading in line with expectations. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,156.71 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 26, with S$55.4 million worth of securities changing hands.

site_title: Private equity firms plan cuts in China to escape property woes
summary: Private equity firms are reducing their exposure to Chinese real estate, with a third planning to cut investments over the next 3 years, according to a survey by Coller Capital. This follows struggles at major developers like China Evergrande Group and Beijing's efforts to cool the nation's frothy property market. Additionally, China's private market fundraising has slumped 60% year-to-date, and investors are shifting their focus to Asia Pacific outside of China, with the biggest increases in buyout, infrastructure, and venture capital.

site_title: Alibaba fires employee who accused former co-worker of sexual assault
summary: Alibaba Group Holding fired an employee who accused a former co-worker of sexual assault, citing "strong social concern" and a "bad impact" on the company. The employee had publicly accused the co-worker and a client of assault during a business trip, prompting Alibaba to fire both the accused and 10 other employees who publicized the incident. The company dismissed the original accuser, stating she had "spread false information." Chinese prosecutors later dropped the case against the co-worker, but approved the arrest of the client.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars struggle to break resistance in bumper central bank week
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars struggled to break above recent resistance levels on Monday, dipping against the US dollar ahead of a week of central bank meetings. The Aussie fell 0.1% to US$0.7166, while the kiwi was 0.1% lower at US$0.6792. Investors await the Federal Reserve meeting and other central bank decisions on unwinding monetary stimulus and potential interest rate hikes. Traders will also monitor Australian labor data on Thursday, which could influence the RBA's decision to end quantitative easing.

site_title: Formula One: Verstappen earns first world title on last lap
summary: Max Verstappen won his first Formula One world title by overtaking Lewis Hamilton on the last lap of the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix, securing the championship by 8 points. The victory came after a late crash slowed the field, allowing Verstappen to catch Hamilton on fresher tires and pass him on the inside at Turn 5. Mercedes protested the result, but it was upheld, ending a 4-year championship streak for Hamilton. The win marked a historic season for Formula One, with a record 22 races, and raised concerns about the toll the schedule takes on teams and drivers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, extending US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, extending US rallies. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.09% or 309.51 points to 28,747.28, while the Topix index advanced 0.89% or 17.50 points to 1,992.98. The gains came as investors digested the Bank of Japan's business confidence survey and US rallies despite tariff threats.

site_title: After sky-high prices, Singapore's power sector is due for some adjustments in 2022
summary: Singapore's energy regulator, the Energy Market Authority (EMA), is proposing changes to market rules to address the volatility in the wholesale electricity market. The proposed changes aim to ensure that volumes of supply match demand, potentially reducing prices and stabilizing the market. The EMA is seeking feedback on a proposal requiring power generators to submit energy offers for standby gas at a price corresponding to the long run marginal cost. This could alleviate potential gas shortfalls and reduce price volatility, benefiting independent retailers and consumers.

site_title: South Korea to test AI-powered facial recognition to track Covid-19 cases
summary: South Korea plans to launch a pilot project in January using AI-powered facial recognition and thousands of CCTV cameras to track Covid-19 cases. The system, to be tested in Bucheon, will analyze footage from 10,820 cameras to track an infected person's movements and close contacts. The goal is to reduce the strain on contact tracing teams and make tracing faster. However, concerns have been raised about the invasion of privacy, with human rights advocates and lawmakers expressing concerns that the government may retain and harness data beyond the pandemic.

site_title: Saudi Arabia expects 2022 budget surplus after years of deficit
summary: Saudi Arabia expects to post its first budget surplus in nearly a decade in 2022, with a forecasted surplus of 90 billion riyals (S$32.7 billion) or 2.5% of GDP. The kingdom plans to reduce public spending by 6% and military spending by 10% despite a surge in oil prices, which helped to refill state coffers. The surplus will be used to increase government reserves and strengthen the kingdom's financial position.

site_title: Japan's Oct machinery orders rise for first time in 3 months
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 3.8% in October, the first increase in three months, indicating firms are spending and the economy is recovering. This follows a larger-than-expected contraction in July-September. The Bank of Japan is expected to debate extending pandemic relief programs beyond March 2022 and maintaining ultra-easy monetary policy. Despite supply bottlenecks easing, the outlook for production and spending remains sluggish, and the central bank is cautious due to uncertainties around the new Omicron variant.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala tells CNBC investing in crypto ecosystem
summary: Abu Dhabi's state fund Mubadala has invested in the crypto ecosystem, citing the rapid growth of cryptocurrencies and stablecoins. CEO Khaldoon al-Mubarak stated that the market value of cryptocurrencies has increased from $200 billion to $2.5 trillion, making it a business worth investing in. Mubadala has $243 billion in assets and plans to focus on the related infrastructure, including blockchain technology and energy usage. The move comes amid concerns about the potential risks of cryptocurrencies on the financial system.
