site_title: Severe weather 'new normal', US emergency chief warns after tornadoes
summary: US emergency management official Deanne Criswell warns that severe weather has become the "new normal" due to climate change, citing the recent massive tornado outbreak in six states that left over 90 dead and dozens missing. Criswell emphasizes the need to reduce the impacts of intense storms, including hurricanes, tornadoes, and wildfires, as the US faces a growing challenge in addressing severe weather events. Scientists agree that evidence is building, suggesting that warming temperatures may increase the occurrence of severe weather conditions.

site_title: Europe's big meat and dairy firms accused of climate 'greenwash'
summary: A new report by the Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy (IATP) has accused Europe's major meat and dairy firms of "greenwashing" and failing to address their significant greenhouse gas emissions. The 35 largest companies in the EU, UK, and Switzerland are responsible for 7% of EU emissions, with emissions from their supply chains, particularly livestock, exceeding those of the Netherlands. Only a few companies have climate plans, but many rely on "accounting tricks" to hide their true emissions, and off-load costs to farmers in their supply chains.

site_title: New Zealand home prices to continue moderate growth: Reinz
summary: New Zealand's median house prices rose 1.1% seasonally in November and 23.7% year-over-year, reaching NZ$925,000. Growth is expected to continue, albeit moderately, with a 25% increase forecast for the year. The property market has become one of the least affordable in the world, with prices doubling in seven years. Affordability is set to worsen, with price inflation easing next year and outright falls in 2023.

site_title: CDL unit to sell 5-star hotel Millennium Hilton Seoul, adjoining land for S$1.26b
summary: CDL unit City Developments Limited (CDL) plans to sell the 5-star Millennium Hilton Seoul and its adjoining land plot in South Korea for 1.1 trillion won (S$1.26 billion). The sale, expected to be completed by Feb 28, 2022, is part of CDL's capital recycling strategy and is valued at a premium of 835.17 billion won (S$960.4 million) over its net book value. The sale is expected to generate a gain of S$529.73 million for CDL.

site_title: Next year's more substantial reopening seen boosting recovery
summary: Singapore's business scene is expected to experience a more substantial reopening in 2022, driven by vaccination efforts, calibrated border restrictions, and policy support for growth sectors like green finance. Industry watchers predict broadened growth from exports to domestic demand, with inflation rising but not out of control. However, observers also highlight room for further reopening, particularly for international travel, and caution that Singapore must maintain consistency, transparency, and certainty in its Covid-19 strategy to avoid a deterioration in its business environment.

site_title: Canada to hold supply-chain summit after flooding disaster: source
summary: Canada will hold a supply-chain summit in early 2022 to discuss strengthening supply chains after the recent flooding disaster that cut off the country's main port. The event will bring together industry figures, shippers, and organizations to ensure the supply chains can recover and become more resilient. The summit comes after the Covid-19 pandemic and floods in British Columbia severely impacted Canadian transportation supply chains, affecting nearly one-third of the country's GDP. The event aims to explore options to reduce reliance on Vancouver and increase use of smaller ports like Prince Rupert.

images.alt_text: In the aftermath of disastrous floods last month that cut off Canada's main port, Ottawa will convene a summit of industry figures and shippers to discuss strengthening supply chains, a government source said on Sunday.

site_title: Superbonus! Italy's green growth gambit lines homes and pockets
summary: Italy's "superbonus" scheme, offering 110% government funding for building green initiatives, has seen massive take-up, boosting GDP by 0.7% and creating 153,000 jobs. However, the scheme has also been marred by corruption, with over $1 billion in suspected fraud uncovered. Critics argue the high cost to the state and subsidies covering new gas heating, which continues fossil fuel use, are major drawbacks. Despite flaws, the scheme stands out among Italy's efforts to meet its climate targets, with climate analysts welcoming the reduction in emissions and improvement in air quality.

site_title: Berlin warns no green light for Nord Stream 2 pipeline if any Ukraine 'escalation'
summary: Berlin has warned that the Nord Stream 2 pipeline will not operate if there is any escalation in Ukraine, according to an agreement between Berlin and Washington. German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock stated that this agreement was reached due to the tense security situation in Ukraine. The warning comes as fears of a Russian invasion grow. The pipeline, which would increase Russia's gas supply to Europe, has been a contentious issue due to its potential impact on Ukraine's energy security.

site_title: UK announces booster drive to fight 'tidal wave' of Omicron
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a booster drive to combat the "tidal wave" of Omicron, with over-18s to receive a booster jab by the end of December, one month earlier than planned. The country's medical advisers raised the Covid Alert Level due to a rapid increase in Omicron infections, which double every two to three days. Johnson described the spread of the mutation as an "emergency" and warned of a significant increase in infections.

site_title: UOB distributes more than 2,700 laptops to students
summary: UOB has distributed over 2,700 laptops to students in Singapore as part of its UOB My Digital Space programme. The bank donated 230 new laptops worth S$300,000 to underprivileged students, while refurbishing and distributing 2,500 used laptops through its partnership with non-profit organisation Engineering Good. The programme aims to provide digital learning tools and skills to disadvantaged children, with over 1,230 beneficiaries helped since its inception last year. The laptops will help students from lower-income families with home-based learning, particularly those who lack access to devices.

site_title: Raeesah Khan may have lied in WhatsApp message due to dissociation: Pritam Singh
summary: Singapore's Leader of the Opposition, Pritam Singh, suggests that Raeesah Khan may have lied in a WhatsApp message due to dissociation, a mental health condition where a person disconnects from their thoughts and feelings. Khan had claimed that party leaders told her to "take the information to the grave," but Singh says this is a lie. Singh also questions Khan's self-confessed dissociation as a possible factor, but notes that nothing of her general performance as an MP was out of the ordinary.

site_title: Abandoned projects shatter confidence in China's housing market
summary: Construction cranes stand idle in China's Yunnan Province, Heilongjiang, and Hainan Island due to halted building projects. Tens of millions of square feet of unfinished apartment buildings remain, a legacy of the 2021 real estate boom. Private homeownership, legalized only two decades ago, has led to a rapid decline in the housing market. The situation is particularly challenging for ordinary Chinese citizens who have invested in these projects. The halt in construction has dealt a significant blow to China's housing market, eroding confidence in the industry.

site_title: Young Arabs swipe to fintech as saving and investing take off
summary: Young Arabs are turning to fintech to track spending, budget, and invest, driven by a lack of savings and investment culture in the Middle East. Many, like Mayar Akrameh, are using online banking services and apps to manage their finances, seeking to save and invest for better living and future goals. The fintech sector is growing, with an estimated 465 companies expected to raise over $2 billion by 2022, and platforms like Lune are making it easier for users to manage their finances and invest.

site_title: Amid China's crackdown, India's funding booms as ecosystem matures
summary: India's startup ecosystem is experiencing a funding boom, with the number of deals increasing by 176% since Q1 2020, reaching 422 in Q3 2021. Private equity investors have also joined the fray, with investments breaching $15.4 billion in Q3 2021. The boom is attributed to India's mature ecosystem and outsized exits, such as the Walmart acquisition of Flipkart, rather than China's crackdown on tech companies. Investors are drawn to India's growing digitalization, consumer awareness, and improved founder quality, leading to increased competition and quicker deals.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Why investors should worry about Reit placements (Ep 14)
summary: Singapore-listed Reits have raised funds through placements this year, with many units priced at discounts. Investors should be wary of these discounts due to their dilutive impact on upside from acquisitions. The market appetite for potential placements is also a concern, as it may drive down prices further. Senior correspondent Ben Paul analyzes market trends and corporate issues in Singapore, advising investors to exercise caution when considering Reit placements.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for December 10, 2021, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk ships. The Capesize market peaked mid-week before declining due to sustained downward pressure from the Pacific and Ballaster routes. The Panamax market saw a brief rise but ultimately eased, with charterers taking a firm hold. The Supramax/Ultramax market experienced stronger demand, particularly in the US Gulf and Indonesian coal markets. The Handysize market showed some small rises, while the VLCC market continued to slide. The Suezmax market took a positive turn in West Africa, and the Aframax market tightened in the Mediterranean and Atlantic.

site_title: Central banks to meet as inflation forces divisions
summary: The world's top central banks are set to diverge in their monetary policy decisions, with some focusing on tackling surging inflation and others keeping demand afloat. The Omicron variant's impact on growth and inflation will be a crucial consideration, with officials worried about potential new restrictions and supply chain disruptions. The US Federal Reserve is expected to confirm a quicker withdrawal of stimulus, while the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan will maintain dovish stances. The Bank of England may also delay rate hikes, while Norway's central bank may hike again.

site_title: Three life hacks to reinvent your life in the New Year
summary: A writer offers three life hacks to reinvent one's life in the New Year, focusing on bite-sized goals, routines, and accountability structures to achieve lasting change. Studies show that 80% of New Year's resolutions fail, but by setting achievable daily goals, creating routines, and establishing accountability mechanisms, individuals can increase their chances of success. This approach allows for gradual progress and motivation through the release of dopamine, ultimately leading to sustained change.

site_title: Driving women entrepreneurship in Singapore
summary: In Singapore, women make up 44% of the workforce, but only a quarter of business owners are women, despite being highly educated. Reaching an equal number of women-owned businesses could add $95 billion to the economy, or 20% of Singapore's GDP. Societal expectations, such as the division of labor at home, and gender bias in the business world, may be holding women back. Initiatives like the Singapore Women Entrepreneurs Network aim to provide community support and mentorship to encourage more women to start and grow businesses. The network, launched by the Singapore Business Federation, connects female entrepreneurs with peers, business leaders, and trade associations to help them succeed.

site_title: Lee family of OCBC selling 6 semi-Ds at S$43.18m
summary: The Lee family of OCBC Bank is selling 6 semi-detached houses on a freehold site in Coronation Road West for S$43.18 million, or S$2,000 per square foot. The buyer, a Singaporean in his early 30s, is expected to hold onto the properties, as redevelopment may not be profitable given the high purchase price and land costs. The sites can be redeveloped into 6 semi-detached houses or 3 bungalows, subject to approval.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust's latest acquisitions, equity raising could sow doubt among investors
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) plans to acquire 17 modern logistics assets for S$1.47 billion, with the acquisition expected to be financed through a combination of equity and debt. However, the trust's latest acquisitions and equity raising may raise doubts among investors due to the low DPU accretion of 2.2% and a preferential offering priced lower than the initial S$1.92 unit price. The actual accretion in DPU may fall short of the pro forma DPU used to justify the acquisitions, leading to questions about the trust's ability to raise funds and make acquisitions on attractive terms.

site_title: Traveloka ramps up giving-back efforts
summary: Traveloka, a South-east Asian lifestyle app, collaborated with Blessings in a Bag and The Social Kitchen to bring cheer to the needy. During its 12.12 Super Lifestyle Sale, the company pledged a donation of S$2 for each transaction, raising funds for a charity campaign to provide 12 curated experiences for children from vulnerable areas and low-income families in Singapore. Traveloka also distributed meals and vouchers to 1,000 beneficiaries and initiated an Upscale Employment Programme to support employees with special needs.

site_title: Dollar loses ground after US inflation data
summary: The US dollar index lost ground on Friday after US consumer prices increased roughly in line with expectations, easing concerns of a much higher inflation reading. The consumer price index rose broadly amid supply constraints for the largest annual gain since 1982. Despite this, the dollar was down 0.12% at 96.09 against a basket of its rivals, with the euro and pound up 0.17% and 0.28% respectively. Investors had feared a higher inflation reading would lead to faster interest rate hikes, but the data showed no credible alternative to the dollar.

site_title: Philippine central bank probes hacking complaints at banks
summary: The Philippine central bank is investigating complaints of online fraud at BDO Unibank, where clients lost money to a scheme involving funds channeled to Union Bank of the Philippines accounts. The regulator, in close coordination with BDO and Union Bank, is taking remedial measures, including reimbursement of affected consumers. This comes after a surge in complaints posted on social media since the early part of the week.

site_title: WP chief Pritam Singh denies telling Raeesah Khan to lie, but says he took no steps to correct untruth from Aug to Oct
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh denied telling former MP Raeesah Khan to lie about a sexual assault case, but said he took no steps to correct her false statement from August to October. Singh claimed Khan had been told to take ownership of the untruth and clarify the truth if it came up, but she did not. The issue led to her resignation from the WP and Parliament. Singh also questioned the impact of her lie on the police, saying it was not a "broken-back" organization.

site_title: Faisal Manap let Raeesah Khan's lies go unaddressed as he trusted WP chief Pritam Singh to 'resolve the issue': Report
summary: Faisal Manap, Workers' Party (WP) vice-chair, allegedly allowed Raeesah Khan's lies to go unaddressed in Parliament, despite knowing it was a potential offence. Manap trusted WP chief Pritam Singh to 'resolve the issue', instead of taking action himself. The Committee of Privileges reported that Manap believed the matter was best handled by Singh and that allowing the lie to persist could affect him, Singh, and WP chairman Sylvia Lim personally.

site_title: We now know we can work from home, but are we ready to be fired from home too?
summary: CEO Vishal Garg fired 900 employees over Zoom in a 3-minute speech, with no warning or indication they were being let go. This act sparked outrage and trauma among the dismissed employees. Singapore's authorities have guidelines for same-day terminations, which include in-person terminations unless impractical due to Covid-19 transmission risks. The author suggests that remote terminations can be done in a graceful and sensitive manner, as long as proper communication and support are provided. However, mass remote terminations should be avoided, as they can be impersonal and unfair.

site_title: Singapore's hub appeal takes a hit from Covid
summary: Singapore's global business hub appeal has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with investors and watchers citing the need for a faster and fuller reopening to restore confidence. The city-state fell from 1st to 5th place in the Institute for Management Development's world competitiveness ranking and slid down Bloomberg's Covid-19 resilience index. Despite this, Singapore remains a small open economy with few rivals in the region, and policymakers are working to reopen domestically and internationally in a safe manner. The government has introduced various pilot schemes and reopened borders, including quarantine-free Vaccinated Travel Lanes, to boost economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Pan Pacific Hotels Group says there is some spillover of demand from upcoming events including the Singapore Airshow 2022 and the 2022 Singapore Grand Prix. Seen here is part of the crowd at 2019's race.
Prof Theseira says the pandemic ''completely disrupted'' Singapore's connectivity to regional operations or global headquarters, with no clarity on near-term relief.

site_title: Philippine central bank probes hacking complaints at banks
summary: The Philippine central bank is investigating complaints of an online fraud where funds were diverted from BDO Unibank to Union Bank of the Philippines. The incident allegedly affected some BDO clients, with one account using 5 million pesos of stolen funds to buy Bitcoin. BDO has implemented additional security controls and Union Bank has frozen several accounts. The regulator is working closely with both banks to ensure remedial measures are taken, including reimbursement of affected consumers.

site_title: Blinken heads to South-east Asia to deepen cooperation on China pushback
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is set to visit Southeast Asia, aiming to deepen economic and security cooperation with the region as a united front against China's growing influence. Blinken's trip follows President Biden's vision for an Indo-Pacific economic framework, focusing on trade facilitation, digital economy, and supply chain resiliency. Despite the administration's efforts, analysts say the lack of a formal structure for economic engagement and increased access to the US market may limit its influence, with China's economic lead seen as a significant challenge.

site_title: SenseTime to delay Hong Kong IPO after US blacklist report
summary: Chinese AI firm SenseTime is delaying its Hong Kong IPO due to US government tensions, specifically the Treasury Department's plan to add the company to a list of Chinese military-industrial complex companies. The delay comes as investors express concerns and regulators require adjustments to address regulatory issues. SenseTime denies US accusations, stating they are "unfounded" and has promised to protect its interests. The IPO's future remains uncertain, with some investors at risk of losing their shares if the offering is withdrawn by April, as agreed upon in a previous funding round.

site_title: Bitcoin posts fourth consecutive weekly drop from all-time high
summary: Bitcoin has posted its fourth consecutive weekly decline, falling about 10% from its all-time high of $69,000 on November 10. Despite being touted as an inflation hedge due to its fixed supply, the cryptocurrency has struggled to maintain its value. Proponents argue that its idiosyncratic nature makes it a hedge against swings in other financial markets, while others point to its speculative nature and lack of evidence supporting its inflation-hedge image. The decline comes after a brief bounce triggered by a report showing US inflation accelerated.

site_title: Russell 2000 Index is bellwether for US economy
summary: The Russell 2000 Index, a bellwether for the US economy, has lagged behind other major indices, including the Nasdaq, DJIA, and S&P 500, with a year-to-date performance of 12%. Smaller companies, which comprise the index, are more vulnerable to US government and state-level restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to a preference for mega-cap firms. The index faces headwinds ahead, including the potential for a new COVID-19 variant and the US Federal Reserve's efforts to rein in inflation. A potential support zone is 2,130-2,150, and a bullish scenario suggests the index may end the year on a positive note with a "Santa Claus rally."

site_title: Pritam Singh meant to tell Raeesah Khan to speak the truth, even if he didn't specifically say so: Committee report
summary: Singapore's Committee of Privileges released a report on former Workers' Party MP Raeesah Khan's fabrication of a sexual assault case during a parliamentary speech. According to the report, party chief Pritam Singh told Khan to take responsibility for the truth, even if he didn't specifically say so, but this was misinterpreted by Khan as an assurance to continue the untruth. Singh had an expectation, not understanding, that Khan would clarify the truth if the matter was raised. Khan's lie was only addressed after Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam questioned her about it, and she subsequently admitted to the lie in Parliament.

site_title: From the Great Resignation to the Great Realignment
summary: The "Great Resignation" is a global trend where millions of workers, including in the US, China, and Singapore, are leaving their jobs due to dissatisfaction with their work-life balance, material success, and sense of purpose. In Singapore, over 56% of workers are seeking new jobs, and organizations must realign their employment practices, engagement policies, and aspirations for employee-employer relationships to retain talent. The trend is driven by an emotional disconnect between individuals and organizations, rather than a gap in material needs, and requires organizations to focus on building meaningful careers, employee development, and wellness programs to foster a sense of purpose and fulfillment.

site_title: Buybacks and director acquisition momentum continues for second week
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.6% over the week, with 22 stocks conducting share buybacks totaling S$61 million. CapitaLand Investment led the buybacks, while DBS Group Holdings, UOB, and Singapore Exchange received the highest net institutional inflows. Meanwhile, director and substantial shareholder transactions saw 120 changes filed for nearly 50 primary-listed stocks, with notable acquisitions including Wee Investments' purchase of UOL Group shares and Tan Jeh Wuan's allotment of Digital Core Reit units. Institutions were net sellers, with S$41 million of net outflow, with some companies announcing increased share buyback targets.

site_title: Global insurance outlook bright, but concerns over cyber, climate risks: Swiss Re chairman
summary: Swiss Re chairman Sergio Ermotti says the global insurance outlook is bright due to strong economic growth and rising affluence, despite concerns over cyber and climate risks. Property and casualty premiums are expected to more than double to $4.3 trillion by 2040. The worst of Covid-19 claims appears to be over, with the global insurance industry poised for growth.

site_title: Senior Japanese officials to skip Beijing Olympics: sources
summary: Senior Japanese officials are likely to skip the Winter Olympics in Beijing due to diplomatic boycotts, joining the US and other countries citing China's human rights record. Japan's decision is expected to be made by the end of the month, with only Olympics-related personnel attending. China has called the boycotts "political posturing" and a smear campaign.

site_title: Stability most important word for China's economy
summary: China's economic policy in 2022 will prioritize "stability" as a key word, according to Han Wenxiu, an executive vice-minister of the Communist Party's central financial and economic affairs commission. The government aims to ensure economic growth in a "reasonable range" by stimulating activity and confidence, while also enforcing fair competition policies and strengthening anti-monopoly regulations. Despite consumption and investment facing multiple barriers, the government plans to boost demand for goods and accelerate e-commerce infrastructure development, particularly in rural areas.

site_title: Biden orders US to stop financing carbon-intense fossil fuel projects abroad
summary: The Biden administration has ordered US government agencies to stop financing carbon-intensive fossil fuel projects abroad, prioritizing clean energy technology and international collaborations. The policy, set in an executive order, aims to promote clean energy, boost US cleantech competitiveness, and support net-zero transitions. It defines "carbon-intensive" projects as those with a greenhouse gas intensity above 250 grams of carbon dioxide per kilowatt hour and bans US financing of overseas coal projects without emissions capture. The policy exempts projects for national security or geostrategic reasons or those critical for energy access to vulnerable areas.

site_title: Swiss trader at centre of insider ring gets no more jail time
summary: A former Swiss trader, Marc Demane Debih, has been sentenced to time served after cooperating with prosecutors on an insider trading ring. Debih, who made $70 million from tips stolen by bankers, admitted to using the money to pay off others in the ring. He cooperated with prosecutors, helping win 3 convictions, including that of a former Goldman Sachs banker. US District Judge Denise Cote agreed to leniency due to Debih's cooperation and 15 months in jail. Several others involved in the ring remain uncharged or fugitive.

site_title: What nominating committees should consider for disclosures on investigations
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) emphasizes the importance of nominating committees (NCs) in disclosing their independent assessment on the continued appointment of directors under investigation. NCs must rigorously assess whether allegations and conditions cast doubt on a director's suitability or affect shareholders' confidence. Two common myths - NCs are pre-judging by not allowing directors to serve while under investigation, and NCs must support directors in a crisis - should be replaced with a focus on what is in the best interest of the company and shareholders. NCs should consider appointing new directors, designating a lead director, and overseeing investigations to protect investors' confidence.

site_title: Ford expects to triple electric Mustang output by 2023
summary: Ford Motor expects to triple the production of its electric Mustang Mach-E SUV to over 200,000 units per year by 2023 for North America and Europe, according to CEO Jim Farley. This move aims to meet the high demand in the hot electrical vehicle market, pitting Ford against rivals General Motors, Stellantis, Volkswagen, and Tesla.

site_title: Return-to-office plans are turning 'shybrid' with ongoing delays
summary: US workers face uncertainty about returning to the office due to ongoing Covid-19 delays. Companies such as Lyft, Ford, Google, and Uber have pushed back return-to-office plans, with some shelving them indefinitely. Many firms are adopting hybrid models, with around half planning to reduce office space, while a quarter expect staff to fully return to in-office work. A survey found that only 11% of HR executives plan to go fully remote, and many workers are open to new jobs to maintain flexibility.

site_title: S-Reits with healthcare and China assets outshine in November
summary: Global Reit markets declined 3.8% in November, with iEdge S-Reit Index ending the month down 2.4%. S-Reits with healthcare assets (First Reit, ParkwayLife Reit) and China-based assets (Sasseur Reit, EC World Reit, BHG Retail Reit) outperformed, with First Reit and BHG Retail Reit leading the pack with 18.0% and 15.4% total returns, respectively. These Reits are diversifying into developed markets and capital-efficient growth strategies, with First Reit's acquisition of 12 nursing homes in Japan and Sasseur Reit's outlet sales growth of 21.8% in the 9-month period.

site_title: G-7 finance chiefs plan to discuss inflation as prices soar
summary: The Group of Seven (G-7) finance ministers will convene virtually on Dec 13 to discuss the recent surge in inflation, amid supply-chain snarls and rising energy prices. The meeting comes as the US and other large economies face a major political challenge in containing inflationary pressures. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen shared concerns with Germany's finance minister, Christian Lindner, about Russia's escalation of armed forces in Ukraine. The G-7 is uncertain about what measures can be taken to address inflation, with experts saying it's unclear what governments can do to impose a solution.

site_title: Top equity funds in Asia are all buying China's green stocks
summary: Top-performing US$1 billion-plus equity funds in Asia have invested heavily in China's renewable energy sector, with returns of at least 40% in 2021. Funds such as the US$3.7 billion China AMC Energy Innovation Equity Fund and the First State Cinda New Energy Industry Equity Fund have led the pack, driven by China's push for carbon neutrality by 2060 and the growth of the electric-vehicle supply chain. Stocks like Contemporary Amperex Technology Co and BYD Co have surged over 80% and 50% respectively, fueled by policy support and President Xi Jinping's "common prosperity" drive.

site_title: DHL doubles robots as humans alone can't handle holiday crunch
summary: DHL, a leading supply-chain firm, has doubled its use of robots in the US ahead of the holiday season to handle the increased demand. The company now has 1,500 picking robots at its warehouses, in addition to 15,000 seasonal workers. This move aims to mitigate supply-chain disruptions caused by the growth of e-commerce and higher labor costs. CEO Oscar de Bok attributes the disruptions to the shift in the supply chain, with fewer intermediaries between consumers and retailers.

site_title: A year after first US shots, pandemic hallmarks re-emerge
summary: The US is experiencing a resurgence of COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations, with over 50 million cases and nearly 800,000 deaths reported since vaccination efforts began. Mask mandates and vaccination sites are being reinstated in some areas, and hospitals are reaching record capacity levels, particularly in New Mexico and Michigan. The Delta and Omicron variants are driving the surge, and vaccine hesitancy and politicization have hindered efforts to control the pandemic. Experts attribute the resurgence to the waning of immunity and the ease of virus transmission during colder weather.

site_title: ConocoPhillips offloads Indonesia assets in Asia-Pacific revamp
summary: ConocoPhillips has sold its assets in Indonesia to Medco Energi Internasional for $1.36 billion, marking the US oil and gas producer's exit from the country. This move is part of ConocoPhillips' Asia-Pacific revamp, which also involves increasing its presence in Australia. The company will sell its 54% stake in an Indonesia oil field and 35% shareholding interest in a pipeline company. ConocoPhillips' CEO Ryan Lance said the deal enhances the company's diversification advantage and lowers its aggregate decline rate.

images.alt_text: US oil and gas producer ConocoPhillips will quit Indonesia, selling its assets there for US$1.36 billion to domestic energy company Medco Energi Internasional, and beef up in Australia as it continues to reshape.

site_title: China brands US democracy 'weapon of mass destruction'
summary: China has branded US democracy a "weapon of mass destruction" following the US-organised Summit for Democracy, which excluded China, Russia, and Hungary. The move comes after Beijing criticized US democracy as corrupt and a failure, while touting its own version of "whole-process people's democracy". The US has repeatedly denied a new Cold War with China, but tensions remain high over trade, technology, human rights, and Taiwan. The US has responded by calling on countries that value democratic institutions to "expand engagement" with Taiwan, now with only 14 diplomatic allies.

site_title: Airbnb, Lucid and Zscaler added to Nasdaq 100 tech benchmark
summary: The Nasdaq 100 tech benchmark has added six new stocks, including Airbnb and Lucid Group, effective December 17. The removed companies are CDW, Fox, Cerner, Check Point Software Technologies, Trip.com Group, and Incyte. The changes aim to reflect changes in market capitalization. Stocks entering the index can benefit from increased liquidity and a lower cost of capital, but may not always see immediate gains, with only 64% of new additions increasing in value on the first day.

site_title: US Fed says banks must keep better tabs on risks after Archegos
summary: The US Federal Reserve has told banks to maintain sufficient margin when dealing with investment funds and understand their positions after the collapse of Archegos Capital Management, which incurred massive losses. The regulator is reviewing specific firms' weaknesses and may take further action. The Fed emphasizes the need for firms to obtain critical information from investment funds, particularly regarding their strategies, concentrations, and relationships with other market participants. The review aims to ensure safe and sound banking practices.

site_title: History of ghosts and murder awaits Japan PM in 1929 mansion
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is set to move into a century-old mansion that has a dark history of ghost sightings and murder. The 1929 residence, which underwent a 2005 renovation to ward off evil spirits, was once the site of a military uprising and assassinations. The mansion, which was previously unoccupied, still costs taxpayers around $1.9 million annually for upkeep. Kishida's move aims to be closer to the prime minister's office, but the location's ominous history has raised concerns among lawmakers.

site_title: Malaysia charges Dyson supplier ATA with labour law violations
summary: Malaysia has charged Dyson supplier ATA IMS with 4 labour law violations related to worker accommodation, following complaints of forced labour and allegations of appalling working and living conditions. The charges come after Dyson severed relations with ATA and ended its contract. Authorities inspected the company in February, May, and July, finding excessive overtime hours and poor living conditions for migrant workers. Police are also investigating claims of a former worker being beaten by police after questioning about sharing information on working conditions with activists.

site_title: 3M hit with US$22.5m verdict in latest US military earplug trial
summary: A US federal jury awarded Theodore Finley, a US Army veteran, $22.5 million in a verdict against 3M Co over alleged hearing damage caused by the company's combat earplugs. Finley received $7.5 million in compensatory damages and $15 million in punitive damages. This is the largest verdict yet in the massive litigation over the product, which has resulted in over $28 million in combined awards to plaintiffs in four cases. The verdict surpassed a previous $13 million awarded to a US Army sergeant.

site_title: Can't shake this: Taylor Swift to face copyright lawsuit
summary: Taylor Swift must face a copyright lawsuit over her 2014 hit single "Shake It Off," which songwriters claim copied lyrics from R&B girl group 3LW's 2014 song "Playas Gon' Play." A California judge ruled there were "some noticeable differences" but "enough objective similarities" for the case to proceed to a jury trial. Songwriters Sean Hall and Nathan Butler are seeking unspecified damages and had previously had their case thrown out in 2018 before it was revived. Swift's representatives had previously dismissed the claim as "ridiculous" and "nothing more than a money grab."

site_title: Crypto is as crypto does: Risk profiles differ, invest accordingly
summary: Crypto market volatility is a reality, with recent flash crashes in Bitcoin and Ethereum, plunging prices by over 20% and 16%, respectively. Despite speculation about the causes, it's clear that crypto is not for the faint-hearted, with prices rising and falling rapidly due to fear and greed. However, a venture capital investor notes that crypto is approaching a major innovation cycle, with distinct categories of assets: mature and stable (Bitcoin), fast-evolving (Ethereum and others), and early experimental (DEFI, NFT, etc.). Investors should be aware of risk exposure, especially in categories 2 and 3, and consider allocating assets to crypto, but with caution.

images.alt_text: Crypto is not for the faint-hearted, but could be at the cusp of a major innovation cycle.

site_title: Nato chief rejects Russia demand to deny Ukraine entry
summary: Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg rejected Russia's demand to deny Ukraine entry into the alliance, stating that the decision will be made by the 30 Nato allies and Ukraine. Stoltenberg emphasized that Nato cannot accept a system where big powers control other members' actions, and that Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity must be respected. The Western allies have redeclared support for Ukraine and warned Russia of deep consequences if it invades, while Russia has increased troops near Ukraine's border and demanded guarantees that Ukraine will not become a Nato launchpad.

site_title: US imposes sweeping human rights sanctions on China, Myanmar and North Korea
summary: The US imposed sweeping human rights-related sanctions on China, Myanmar, North Korea, and Bangladesh, targeting dozens of individuals and entities. The sanctions include Chinese AI company SenseTime Group, which faces an investment ban, and Myanmar military entities, including those responsible for a brutal crackdown on opponents. The measures coincide with President Biden's Summit for Democracy, where he announced initiatives to bolster democracy and support pro-democracy legislation. The sanctions were condemned by China, while Canada and the UK joined the US in imposing sanctions on Myanmar.

site_title: The big questions on Omicron: What we know and what it means for us
summary: Singapore reported its first local Omicron case on Dec 9, a front-line worker at Changi Airport who received a booster shot. The new variant, B.1.1.529, emerged in Botswana on Nov 11 and was named Omicron by the WHO on Nov 24. Omicron has 32 mutations in its spike protein, potentially evading vaccines. Current Covid-19 vaccines are still effective, but a 3-shot course may be needed to neutralize the variant. Booster shots may be necessary every few months to combat new variants, but their effectiveness and duration are unclear.

site_title: Sony's gaming division to buy 'God of War' maker Valkyrie Entertainment
summary: Sony's gaming division has agreed to buy Valkyrie Entertainment, the developer of the popular "God of War" game, for an undisclosed amount. This marks Sony's fifth acquisition this year, aiming to bolster its PlayStation Studios. Valkyrie will continue to operate under its current management team, making "invaluable contributions" to the division's franchises, according to Hermen Hurst, head of PlayStation Studios.

site_title: Singapore approves Pfizer Covid-19 jab for children aged 5 to 11
summary: Singapore has approved the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5 to 11, allowing them to receive the jab from the end of the month. The vaccine will be administered in smaller doses, with a 21-day spacing, and those aged 18-29 who completed primary vaccination at least 5 months ago can receive booster shots from Dec 14. The decision was made after a thorough evaluation by the Health Sciences Authority, citing a 90.7% vaccine efficacy rate in a study of over 2,000 children, with no reported cases of severe side effects.

images.alt_text: The Pfizer vaccine is the first Covid-19 vaccine approved by Singapore for use for children aged 5 to 11.

site_title: Starbucks union vote a victory for US Gen Z workers
summary: Starbucks employees in the US, primarily in their 20s, have successfully formed the first union in a company-owned US cafe, despite management pressure. This victory is seen as a significant moment for Gen Z workers, who are eager to improve working conditions and have no hope of owning a home. The union movement is gaining momentum, with experts predicting that unions may become "cool again" for this generation. The success of Starbucks employees may serve as an example for young workers in the US who are unfamiliar with unionization.

site_title: Conquering the wealth curse
summary: Asia's wealthiest families are amassing unprecedented trillions in wealth, but the "wealth curse" remains a significant concern. A study of 3,200 families found that 7 in 10 lost their fortune by the second generation, with only 1 in 10 retaining their wealth by the third generation. To combat this, ultra-high-net-worth (UHNW) individuals are setting up family offices, trusts, and foundations to manage and preserve their wealth. Singapore, with its favorable regulatory and tax frameworks, is becoming a hub for family offices, with 221 set up in 2022, up from 22 in 2018.

site_title: JPMorgan set to pay US$200m fine over lax staff monitoring
summary: JPMorgan Chase is set to pay a US$200 million fine to resolve US regulatory investigations into lax employee monitoring during the Covid-19 pandemic. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) are involved in the settlement. The unusual fine serves as a warning to the financial industry about the importance of monitoring employee communications. JPMorgan was required to scrutinize years of messages on personal devices, and regulators have been investigating the bank's compliance leading up to and during the pandemic.

site_title: Global players eye Indonesia's fast-growing logistics sector
summary: International logistics companies, including US-based C H Robinson, are eyeing Indonesia's rapidly growing logistics sector, expected to reach $138 billion by 2026 with a 9.2% annual growth rate. Despite current market dominance by local players, international firms are seeking to tap the country's infrastructure expansion and growing economy. Companies like C H Robinson plan to focus on global shippers and improve their presence in strategic areas, while experts advocate for opening domestic sea freight to foreign players and expanding public-private partnerships to drive down logistics costs and improve efficiencies.

site_title: Early US Omicron cases caused mild illness in vaccinated
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported that the first Omicron cases in the US were mostly among vaccinated individuals, resulting in mild illnesses with no reported deaths. As of Dec 8, 43 cases were investigated, with 1 hospitalization. Symptoms included cough, tiredness, and congestion or runny nose.

site_title: World Bank approves US$600m funding for Philippine reforms
summary: The World Bank has approved a $600 million loan to support the Philippine government's reform program, aiming to position the country for a competitive and resilient economic recovery. The loan will fund measures to promote private investment, cut business costs, and expand broadband services, benefiting underserved populations and small and medium enterprises. The reforms are expected to level the playing field for domestic and foreign operators, attracting investment to the retail sector and boosting economic growth.

site_title: Amazon says massive cloud outage caused by 'unexpected behaviour'
summary: Amazon's cloud computing business, AWS, experienced a massive outage due to "unexpected behavior" from a large number of clients, causing delays in communication between networks. The outage, which lasted several hours, affected various services, including Disney parks, Netflix videos, and smart home gadgets. Amazon attributed the issue to a surge of connection activity that overwhelmed networking devices. The company acknowledged the problem and vowed to learn from it to improve availability. Experts debate the feasibility of duplicating services across multiple cloud providers to prevent similar outages.

site_title: Biden slams Kellogg's for replacing striking workers
summary: US President Joe Biden criticized Kellogg's management for replacing striking workers, calling it "deeply troubling" and vowing to "aggressively defend" collective bargaining. Biden, a union supporter, urged the company to negotiate a solution to the labor dispute. He stated that collective bargaining is essential for protecting workers' rights from employer threats and intimidation.

site_title: US: Wall Street gains, S&P hits record closing high as CPI meets expectations
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, with the S&P 500 hitting a record closing high, as the inflation rate met expectations and waning concerns over the Omicron variant fueled a broad rally. The S&P 500 surged 0.95% to 4,712.02, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.73%. The inflation rate rose 6.8% annually, the highest in nearly 4 decades, but market participants expect the Federal Reserve to tighten monetary policy sooner rather than later to combat inflation.

site_title: Daimler truck gains in debut after split from Mercedes
summary: Daimler Truck Holding made its debut as a separate company, rising 7% in its first trading day after splitting from Mercedes-Benz. The company valued at around 24 billion euros (S$36.9 billion) aims to move quickly towards an electrified and autonomous future. Daimler retains a 35% stake in the truck firm, which is expected to join Germany's DAX index in the first quarter of next year, potentially surpassing current members Deutsche Bank and RWE. The split is seen as a strategic step to accelerate Daimler's restructuring and increase transparency.

site_title: China Evergrande defaults on its debt. Now what?
summary: China Evergrande Group, a real estate giant, has defaulted on its debt with a major credit ratings firm, Fitch Ratings, declaring it in default. The company had failed to meet a payment of $82 million to bondholders, prompting the ratings firm's move. Evergrande's next step remains unknown, with possibilities including bankruptcy, a fire sale, or business as usual. The Chinese government is expected to play a role in the company's restructuring, but its willingness to intervene has been questioned, raising concerns about the impact on the country's financial system and homeowners who have invested in the company.

site_title: The US and China should go head-to-head on climate goals
summary: The US and China should engage in competition to drive down greenhouse gas emissions, rather than cooperation. The rapidly growing electric vehicle market is a prime example, with Chinese companies like BYD and Nio gaining ground on US companies like Tesla. The US and China's joint climate statement at COP26 is missing the mark, as the bulk of emissions reduction will come from private companies competing in the market. Consistent, long-term support for green technologies, like financial incentives for US businesses, is key to building up US industrial capacity and competing with Chinese rivals.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip on Omicron worries, but post best week since March
summary: European stocks fell 0.3% on Friday, marking a third straight session, due to concerns over the Omicron Covid-19 variant and US inflation data. Despite this, the Stoxx 600 index posted its best weekly gain since March, up 2.8%. US annual consumer prices rose 6.8%, the largest year-on-year increase since June 1982. The European Central Bank is considering a temporary bond purchase plan, seen as a dovish step, while US monetary policy remains uncertain.

site_title: Oil prices on track for biggest weekly gain since August
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, Dec 10, 2021, and are on track for their biggest weekly gain since late August. The Brent and US West Texas Intermediate crude benchmarks are expected to gain about 8% this week, driven by easing concerns over the Omicron variant's impact on global economic growth and fuel demand. Despite a brief bout of profit-taking, oil prices rose 0.6% to $74.85 a barrel, setting the stage for a strong weekly performance.

site_title: Is investing your new year's resolution? Take action now
summary: A survey commissioned by Syfe found 56% of people overspend during the holiday season, despite 94% having personal finance resolutions for 2022. To achieve financial goals, individuals should focus on making prudent financial decisions and growing extra funds through investing. Strategies include a value-driven approach to spending, resisting impulsive purchases, and turning festive savings into gains. Experts recommend starting small, diversifying investments, and reflecting on investment goals for the new year. By taking these steps, individuals can set themselves up for long-term financial success.

site_title: Surrounded by icons: Designer furniture classics fill this Bukit Timah home
summary: Ng Yoh Thai's 2-storey home in Bukit Timah is filled with nearly every inch of designer furniture and lights, showcasing his 25-year collection. The former technology banker, now a tech startup owner, has a love for designer furniture for their workmanship and timeless appeal. Classics include the Barcelona chair by Mies van der Rohe, Arco lamp by Achille & Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, and Eames Lounge Chair and Ottoman by Charles and Ray Eames. Ng's collection has been built with the help of famed interior designer Peter Tay and online purchases, with some pieces being rare and hard to obtain.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as inflation data meets estimates
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday as consumer price data met estimates, easing concerns about monetary policy tightening. The Dow Jones rose 0.21%, the S&P 500 gained 0.43%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.72%. The data showed prices rose largely in line with expectations, reducing pressure on investors. The market gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and concerns about tariffs.

site_title: Breathing - and diving - deep
summary: Koh Su Hock, 47, credits yoga and qigong with helping him overcome stress-related health issues, including heart palpitations and insomnia. After a health scare in his late 20s, he began practicing yoga, which led to improved physicality, mental well-being, and a new career path. He now teaches yoga and co-founded two startups, including a telemedicine clinic and a boutique yoga practice, to promote wellness. He also recently took up free-diving and restarted triathlon training, finding freedom in pushing his limits.

site_title: China to focus on stability in 2022, keep growth in reasonable range
summary: China will focus on stabilizing its economy in 2022, aiming to keep growth within a reasonable range. The country will implement a prudent monetary policy and proactive fiscal policy. The Central Economic Work Conference emphasized the need to prioritize stability and ensure macroeconomic stability across all regions and departments. China will also adjust policies to promote economic stability in the coming year.

site_title: Kallang Roar returns as Lions eye Suzuki Cup glory
summary: Singapore's national football team, the Lions, made a triumphant return to competitive football with a 2-1 win over Palestine in the Asean Football Federation Suzuki Cup. This victory, after over 2 years without a win, marks a significant comeback for the team. With a maximum 6 points in the bag, Singapore aims to secure a semi-final berth for the first time since 2012, facing tougher challenges ahead in the tournament.

site_title: 4 Covid-19 deaths, 454 infections; lowest daily figures since September
summary: Singapore reported 454 new Covid-19 infections and four deaths on Dec 10, marking the lowest daily cases since Sept 8. The ICU utilisation rate increased to 50.7% and there were 637 hospital cases, with 40 in critical condition. The weekly infection growth rate remained below 1, with the 28th consecutive day of low growth. Singapore's death toll now stands at 783, and the total number of cases is 272,433.

site_title: Lessons from a sinking to help us stay afloat
summary: 80 years ago, on Dec 11, 1941, British battleships Prince of Wales and Repulse were sunk by Japanese aircraft off the coast of Malaya, marking the first time battleships were lost to air power in open sea. The loss of 840 lives, including Admiral Tom Phillips, shocked the British Empire and signalled the "end of the era of the battleship" and the rise of air power. The incident highlights the dangers of a blinkered mentality, the importance of adapting to new trends, and the need for flexibility in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: US consumer prices climb at fastest annual rate since 1982
summary: US consumer prices rose 6.8% from November 2020, the fastest annual pace since 1982, exceeding forecasts and fueling inflation concerns. The increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) reflected broad advances in most categories, with core prices rising 0.5% and reaching a 30-year high of 4.9% from a year earlier. This reinforces expectations for the Federal Reserve to accelerate the wind-down of its bond-buying program and potentially raise interest rates by mid-2022 to combat inflation.

site_title: No Signboard says legal spat over beer will not affect finances, business operations
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Catalist-listed restaurant operator, has stated that a legal dispute over beer deliveries with wholesale distributors Sprawl Transport & Logistic will not significantly impact its finances or business operations. The company believes the claims are "unmeritorious" and "unlikely to succeed," with no provision made for liabilities. A trial is set for March 2022, and the company will closely monitor the proceedings.

site_title: Insurers to end Covid-19 relief on Dec 31, existing policyholders supported until policy renewal
summary: Singapore's general insurers will end Covid-19 relief measures on December 31, but existing policyholders will be supported until their next policy renewal. Policyholders on flexible premium instalment plans will continue to receive financial assistance. From January 1, insurers will discuss suitable alternatives and assistance with individuals and businesses facing financial difficulties due to the pandemic. Insurers will support policyholders bilaterally after the industry-wide relief measures conclude.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit to buy Japanese nursing home for 3.2b yen
summary: Parkway Life Reit is acquiring a 150-bed nursing home in Japan's Greater Tokyo Region for 3.2 billion yen (S$38.4 million), funded by yen-denominated debt, which is expected to be accretive for the Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) with a net property yield of 5.9%. The deal will increase the weighted average lease expiry by gross revenue for Parkway Life Reit's portfolio from 17.42 years to 17.47 years, and marks a 7% discount against an independent valuation of the property.

site_title: US consumer prices climb at fastest annual rate since 1982
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.8% from October, the fastest annual rate since 1982, exceeding forecasts and extending a trend of sizeable increases. The 6.8% annual gain from November 2020 reflects broad advances in most categories. The Federal Reserve is expected to accelerate its bond-buying program and consider interest rate hikes, with annual CPI increases anticipated to hover near 7% in 2022, a fresh 30-year high.

site_title: China's central bank urges backing for affordable housing in Shanghai
summary: China's central bank urges banks to innovate affordable housing products and services in Shanghai, while also cautioning developers to be prudent. The move aims to support the private housing market and meet the needs of homebuyers. Key banks signed strategic pacts with local government-backed companies to support affordable housing, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, China Construction Bank, and Bank of Shanghai. The goal is to increase affordable housing supply and materialize common prosperity in Shanghai.

site_title: Former Yinda Infocomm to exit telecom business by selling units for nominal sum
summary: Totm Technologies, a Catalist-listed company formerly known as Yinda Infocomm, plans to exit its telecom business by selling loss-making subsidiaries, Yinda Technology Singapore and Yinda Technology (Thailand), to an associate of its chairman for a nominal S$1,001. The sale is expected to yield a net gain of S$415,000 and boost the company's diversification into biometrics solutions. The deal requires approval from independent shareholders and will have a positive impact on Totm's pro forma loss per share and net tangible assets.

site_title: Philosophy for techies: Dataism is bad for mankind and worse for Big Tech
summary: Yuval Harari, author of Sapiens, has expressed concerns about "dataism," a philosophy that reduces human beings to sources of data flows within a technological apparatus. Harari believes dataism will lead to the eradication of mankind in 100-200 years, as humans are seen as replaceable algorithms. This perspective has been met with opposition from public intellectuals, including Lord Rabbi Jonathan Sacks, who characterizes Harari's claims as "exaggerated and misleading." Dataism ignores fundamental philosophical principles, such as freedom, self-consciousness, and morality, and has been criticized by tech firms for trampling on human rights and digital personhood.

site_title: US wins appeal against block on Assange extradition
summary: The US government has won an appeal against a London court ruling that blocked the extradition of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange. The US challenged a decision that deemed Assange a suicide risk if extradited, citing assurances from the US government that he would receive appropriate treatment and not face harsh conditions. The High Court in London has ordered the case to be returned to Westminster Magistrates Court for a final decision on extradition. Assange's partner, Stella Moris, has vowed to appeal the decision, calling it a "grave miscarriage of justice" and accusing Britain of acting on behalf of a foreign power.

site_title: First major IPO in India after Paytm's dismal debut ends flat
summary: Star Health and Allied Insurance's first major IPO in India ended flat after listing in Mumbai, failing to attract investor interest despite a blockbuster year for domestic listings. The stock initially fell 6% before reversing course to gain 4.4% and ended the day flat. The IPO fell short of its target, with investors questioning the top price of 900 rupees due to the company's loss in the year ended March 2021 and potential extension of losses due to the Omicron pandemic.

site_title: Changi Airport front-line staff to take ART daily after local Omicron case detected
summary: Front-line staff at Changi Airport in Singapore will take antigen rapid tests (ART) daily for seven days after a 24-year-old passenger service worker tested positive for the Omicron variant. The worker, who handled transfer passengers, has been placed under close monitoring. Staff serving passengers undergo routine testing and PCR tests every seven days, while those in close contact with passengers take ART daily. The move is in response to the emergence of the Omicron variant and follows the designation of the variant as a variant of concern by the World Health Organization.

site_title: Leading, learning in the metaverse
summary: The metaverse, a virtual-reality space, is the next phase of the internet, allowing users to interact with a computer-generated environment and other users. It will impact various sectors, including corporations, educational institutions, and governments. Users can engage in various activities, such as buying digital outfits, meeting friends, and attending events, all within the metaverse. As the metaverse becomes more prevalent, individuals and organizations will need to adapt and develop skills to navigate this rapidly shifting technological landscape.

site_title: HSBC, JPMorgan, Deutsche Bank tell London staff to stay home
summary: Major UK banks HSBC, JPMorgan, and Deutsche Bank have instructed staff to work from home due to the UK government's new pandemic guidance, which advises employees to work from home if possible. The move comes after a surge in Omicron cases, with some firms reducing office staff to pre-pandemic levels. The changes are expected to impact the City of London, which has seen foot traffic decline during earlier lockdowns, with businesses relying on office workers for sales and revenue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish the day lower
summary: Hong Kong shares closed down 1.07% on Friday, following a weak lead from Wall Street and ahead of a key US inflation report. The Hang Seng Index fell 259.14 points to 23,995.72, while the Shanghai Composite Index declined 0.18% to 3,666.35. The Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange gained slightly.

site_title: US eyes 'powerful' Asia economic deal in 2022
summary: The Biden administration plans to sign a "powerful" economic framework agreement with Asian nations in 2022, focusing on supply chains, export controls, and artificial intelligence standards. Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo aims to engage developed and emerging economies, with a flexible agreement that may not require Congressional approval. The goal is to address supply chain coordination, limit sensitive products in export controls, and harmonize technical standards for AI and cybersecurity. The framework aims to deepen US engagement with Asia, following a four-year absence under the Trump administration.

site_title: United Global gets S$0.45-a-share takeover bid from vehicle linked to board members
summary: United Global, a lubricant manufacturer listed on the Catalist, is facing a S$142.3 million takeover bid from DMW Investments, an investment vehicle linked to board members, offering S$0.45 per share. The offeror plans to de-list the company and exercise compulsory acquisition rights if it acquires 90% of shares. Shareholders have been told to exercise caution and seek professional advice. The offeror aims to give shareholders a market premium, but does not intend to make major changes to the business or management team.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 12.91 points lower at 1,488.88 on Friday. Volume reached 2.606 billion lots worth RM1.744 billion. Losers surpassed gainers 594 to 278. The market decline follows global economic concerns, including US-EU trade talks and bank and healthcare sector drag.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: IQIYI is reportedly laying off hundreds of employees amid losses and share price pressure, cutting wage expenses by a fifth. Singapore has purchased AstraZeneca's Evusheld drug cocktail, while Binance is in talks with Indonesia's richest family for a crypto venture. Pine Capital's plan for a reverse takeover has failed after a potential investor backed out. Singapore Post will change its chief financial officer in February, with Vincent Yik taking over to drive the company's Australia growth strategy. The STI fell 0.22% due to investors weighing the Federal Reserve's potential taper.

site_title: Evergrande's Hui forced to trim stake in company
summary: China Evergrande Group Chairman Hui Ka Yan was forced to sell 277.8 million shares, reducing his stake to 59.78% from 61.88%. The shares, worth US$64 million, were sold as part of a massive restructuring effort for the company, which was officially labelled a defaulter by Fitch Ratings. Hui has been pledging stock to raise funds for liabilities exceeding US$300 billion. The sale comes after the developer failed to make two coupon payments on time, and it marks a significant step in the company's restructuring process.

site_title: Singapore Post to change chief financial officer in Feb 2022; new CFO to help drive Australia growth strategy, says board
summary: Singapore Post is replacing its group chief financial officer (CFO) Richard Lai with Vincent Yik, effective February 11, 2022. Yik, 49, has extensive experience in the Asia market, particularly in Australia, where SingPost is expanding its business. His appointment aims to drive the company's Australia growth strategy. Lai is leaving to pursue other career opportunities, following the departure of former CEO Paul Coutts in September 2021.

site_title: World rushes to boost against Omicron, but questions remain
summary: The Omicron variant has triggered a global rush for booster shots, with scientists and governments seeking a third dose as the most expedient strategy against the new strain. The World Health Organization has expressed reservations, emphasizing the need to ensure vaccine access to those yet to receive their first doses before richer governments roll out boosters. Despite uncertainty, the gap between the unvaccinated and the boostered is widening, with countries like the US, UK, and South Korea slashing wait times for third doses.

site_title: Next year will be tough for credit markets; private equity managers major exception
summary: Private credit assets under management are expected to surge 70% to $1.5 trillion over four years, driven by interest rate hikes and volatility in traditional credit markets. Private equity managers, such as Apollo Global Management and Blackstone, are set to benefit from the growth. Private credit firms are less susceptible to market volatility due to their floating-rate structures and long-term investment horizon. Analysts expect a "sweet spot" for private credit in the event of a short-term public debt-market disruption, creating opportunities for direct lending funds.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open after Asian, US losses
summary: European stocks declined at the start of trading on Friday, following losses in Asia and overnight on Wall Street. The FTSE 100 index fell 0.3% to 7,301.77 points, while the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices lost 0.4% and 0.5%, respectively. The decline was attributed to a slowdown in Britain's economy before the Omicron variant, as well as anticipation of key US inflation data.

site_title: ECB's stimulus exit likely next year ahead of stronger inflation outlook
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is likely to exit its emergency bond-buying stimulus next year, with a possible interest-rate increase following in 2022, according to economists polled by Bloomberg. The ECB aims to cushion the exit from its 1.85 trillion-euro pandemic plan, which is set to stop net purchases in March 2022. Despite President Christine Lagarde's views on transitory inflation, economists expect the ECB to raise interest rates and gradually return to its regular bond-buying program in 2023.

site_title: SoftBank co-leads US$400m round in Temasek-backed cybersecurity firm
summary: SoftBank co-led a $400 million Series E round in cybersecurity firm Claroty, backed by Temasek's ISTARI, Bessemer Venture Partners, and Schneider Electric. Claroty will use the funds to acquire Medigate, a healthcare IoT security company, and expand into the healthcare sector. The company faces a 82% cyberattack rate in the last 18 months, citing risks to patient safety, public safety, and the environment. Claroty's CEO Yaniv Vardi will join SoftBank's investment activities board.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources buys remaining stake in Stanmore owner for US$30m
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) agreed to purchase the remaining stake in Stanmore Resources' owner, Ascend Global Investment Fund, for US$30 million. Gear will acquire 20.3% of the company, which owns 75.3% of Stanmore Resources, a coal producer. The deal is expected to be completed within 7 business days and will not significantly impact Gear's earnings per share. However, it may decrease consolidated net tangible assets by 6.4% for the year to Dec 31.

site_title: iQiyi said to lay off hundreds of employees amid losses, share price pressure
summary: Chinese video streaming platform iQiyi is laying off hundreds of employees amid deep losses and share price pressure. The company aims to cut 20% of its staff across departments, with cuts in the least profitable divisions as high as 40%. iQiyi has a headcount of over 7,700 people and is also reducing wage expenses by a fifth.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares drop ahead of US inflation data
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1% on Friday ahead of US inflation data, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 28,437.77 and the Topix index at 1,975.48. The decline comes as Wall Street snapped a three-day rally. Investors await the US inflation report, which could impact global markets. The US inflation data is expected to be released later in the day, and its impact on global markets will be closely watched.

site_title: Saudi sovereign fund PIF set to raise US$3.2b in Saudi Telecom stake sale
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is set to raise $3.2 billion by selling a 6% stake in Saudi Telecom (STC) in a secondary share offering, priced at 100 riyals ($36.42) per share. The deal, the largest equity capital market transaction in the Middle East this year, is part of PIF's efforts to diversify the Saudi economy through Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's Vision 2030 plan. PIF owned 70% of STC before the sale, and the deal is expected to help wean the economy off its dependence on oil.

site_title: Mouse with Covid sparks Taiwan lab alert after biting scientist
summary: A Taiwanese lab worker tested positive for Covid-19 after being bitten by a laboratory mouse infected with the virus. The worker, in her 20s, had received two vaccine doses and had not traveled abroad recently. Authorities believe she is infected with the Delta variant and are investigating whether the mouse bites transmitted the virus. The incident threatens to undo Taiwan's success in controlling Covid-19 outbreaks, but most contacts have tested negative, reducing the risk of a new widespread outbreak.

site_title: Binance in talks with Hartonos, Telkom Indonesia to set up crypto venture: sources
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, is in talks with Indonesia's richest family, the Hartonos, and state-owned telecom operator Telkom Indonesia to set up a cryptocurrency trading exchange. The partnership, if successful, would spur wider adoption of cryptocurrencies in Indonesia, where many adults have limited access to formal finance. Binance would gain a greater foothold in the rapidly developing economy, while the Hartonos would invest in digital currencies. Discussions are ongoing, with terms potentially changing, and the Indonesian government has been supportive of crypto assets, allowing them to be traded alongside commodity futures.

site_title: STI down as investors weigh faster Fed taper, China property woes
summary: Singapore shares ended the week in negative territory due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's potential faster taper of asset purchases and China's property debt crisis. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.22% to 3,135.61, with the exception of Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index. Analysts predict a massive debt restructuring exercise in China, which may prompt a dip in China growth next year. The decline was also attributed to hawkish changes in the Fed's stance and consumer price inflation data.

site_title: US considers banning key exports to Chinese chipmaker SMIC: WSJ
summary: US officials are considering banning key exports to Chinese chipmaker SMIC due to its alleged ties to China's military. The Defense Department has proposed closing regulatory loopholes to block SMIC's access to advanced US technology. Some Commerce Department officials are trying to block this proposal, while the US is also considering adding more Chinese technology companies to blacklists and banning US investment. This move comes after the US House of Representatives passed legislation to ban imports from China's Xinjiang region over forced labor concerns.

site_title: More than a quarter S-E Asia CFOs haven't transformed key finance functions: Deloitte
summary: More than a quarter of South-east Asia's CFOs haven't transformed key finance functions, despite recognizing their importance, according to Deloitte's survey of 105 CFOs and finance leaders. The areas of business finance, risk monitoring and compliance, data analytics and management, are under-transformed. CFOs are now focusing on long-term priorities to become more agile, and must pivot from operational finance to financial insights, developing new roles and skillsets. The survey also found that 73% of respondents will continue remote working to supplement finance teams amid a skills shortage.

site_title: China's stock of unsold new homes hits 5-year high amid weak demand
summary: China's unsold housing stock in its 100 biggest cities reached a 5-year high in November, rising 2.1% to 521.10 million square meters, according to a private sector survey. This marks the 36th consecutive month of on-year gains, amid weak demand and tighter regulations in the property market. New homes continue to face a supply-demand imbalance, with 44.95 million square meters of unsold stock and 34.37 million square meters of home transactions. Experts expect home purchase policies to ease in December and the first quarter of 2022, but predict a property downturn in the first half of 2022.

site_title: Vietnamese tourist city pledges to phase out dog and cat meat
summary: Hoi An, Vietnam, has pledged to phase out selling cat and dog meat, a first in the country where the practice is considered a delicacy. The city signed a deal with animal rights group Four Paws International to eradicate the trade and promote animal welfare. A national poll found only 6.3% of Vietnamese surveyed consume dog meat, with 88% supporting a ban. This move aims to improve the city's reputation and reduce health risks associated with rabies infections, with authorities hoping it will set an example for other places in Vietnam.

site_title: Australia's Fortescue CEO to step down as firm pivots to renewable energy
summary: Fortescue Metals Group CEO Elizabeth Gaines is stepping down as the company transitions to a diversified renewable energy and resources firm under the leadership of Chairman Andrew Forrest. Gaines will remain on the board as a non-executive director and assist in the search for her successor. The company aims to become the world's biggest green energy group, focusing on its green power arm, Fortescue Future Industries. A management consulting firm has been enlisted to help identify the next CEO, with the goal of achieving 15 million tonnes of green hydrogen production by 2030.

site_title: Top Glove's Q1 net profit tumbles 92.1% to RM185.7m; executives say industry a case of 'survival of the fittest'
summary: Top Glove Corporation reported a 92.1% drop in Q1 net profit to RM185.7 million, down from RM2.4 billion in the same period last year. Revenue fell 66.7% to RM1.6 billion, attributed to normalizing average selling prices and demand for gloves. The company's executive chairman, Lim Wee Chai, described the glove industry as a "case of survival of the fittest" due to intense competition. Top Glove is preparing to adapt to the new normal, with a focus on regaining market share in the US and improving production efficiency through innovation and research and development.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.25 points to 1,503.04. Losers outnumbered gainers 160 to 109, and volume reached 162.39 million lots worth RM73.58 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares end the day lower
summary: Australian shares ended the day 0.4% lower at 7,353.50, despite a 1.6% weekly gain, due to energy stocks falling 1.5% on weaker oil prices. Technology stocks also declined, while domestic healthcare stocks dropped 1.8% after a three-session rally. The focus now shifts to US inflation data and its potential impact on the Federal Reserve's meeting next week.

site_title: Gold poised for 4th weekly fall on jitters ahead of US inflation
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,778.13 per ounce, but are on track for a fourth consecutive weekly fall ahead of US inflation data that could prompt the Federal Reserve to scale back its bond purchases. Investors are cautious due to a hawkish Fed pivot and uncertainty around the Omicron variant, which could delay rate hikes. Spot silver fell 0.3% and platinum rose 0.9% as investors also took stock of US jobless claims at their lowest in over 52 years.

site_title: EU countries expected to agree 9-month duration of Covid travel pass: sources
summary: EU countries are expected to agree on a 9-month duration for Covid-19 travel passes, which would require a booster shot for EU citizens to travel freely within the bloc. The proposal also includes imposing PCR tests on all incoming travelers from outside the EU, a measure aimed at addressing concerns about the Omicron variant. The move aims to facilitate travel while minimizing risks, but some eastern European countries are concerned about the impact on the travel industry.

site_title: China's domestic air traffic recovery faltering due to zero-Covid policy
summary: China's domestic air traffic has faltered due to the zero-Covid policy, which has led to tighter travel rules and weaker consumer confidence. Domestic capacity fell from 115% of pre-Covid levels in April to 77% in October, contrasting with the US domestic recovery. Airlines have cut flights and reported losses, with Air China, China Eastern, and China Southern posting a combined loss of nearly 8 billion yuan. The fourth-quarter outlook is dimming, with domestic air passenger traffic at around 40% of pre-Covid levels in November.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end 7-day rally but mark best week in 2 months
summary: South Korean shares ended a 7-day rally on Friday, closing 0.64% lower, as investors shied away from riskier assets ahead of US inflation data. The KOSPI benchmark index gained 1.41% for the week, its best in 8 weeks.
