The BOE's decision to halt QE may have significant consequences for global monetary policy and public finances.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the Singapore stock market, NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. However, stocks in Europe and the US declined due to bank and healthcare concerns, as well as US-EU tariff threats. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls. Meanwhile, Heathrow Airport planned to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Separately, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Encanto leads another quiet weekend at North American box office
summary: Disney's animated musical film "Encanto" remains at the top of the North American box office charts for its second weekend, collecting $12.38 million from 3,980 venues. The film's 2-week total is $57.6 million domestically, a 54% drop from its debut. The box office is quiet, with only holdover titles like "House of Gucci" and "Ghostbusters: Afterlife" performing well, as big-budget films return to cinemas in December.

site_title: Singapore's leading pro golfers all set for a busy January with 3 big events
summary: Singapore's top golfers are set for a lucrative January with three major events, including the SMBC Singapore Open, which boasts a $1.25 million prize purse, a 25% increase from last year. The Asian Tour's The Singapore International will also take place from Jan 13 to 16, with a $1 million prize purse. Additionally, the Singapore Pro Series Invitational will run from Jan 5 to 6, offering a $10,000 bonus to the overall winner. The events promise a welcome boost to the golfers after a six-month wait without winnings.

site_title: The Segway that did not change the world: the dangers of confirmation bias in investing
summary: The Segway, once hailed as a revolutionary transportation device, failed to gain traction due to confirmation bias among its creators. The company's backers only sought affirmation from those who believed in the product, ignoring market research and user feedback. This bias led to the Segway being criticized for being heavy, uncool, and awkward to maneuver. Confirmation bias is a common pitfall for investors, causing them to overlook negative news and stick with declining stocks. To avoid this, investors should focus on goal-based investing, ignore noise, and create rules to stay disciplined.

site_title: UBS rolls out quarantine reimbursements to match US rivals
summary: UBS has introduced a quarantine reimbursement plan for Hong Kong employees, matching similar plans by US rivals such as Citadel, JPMorgan Chase, and Morgan Stanley. The Zurich-based lender will pay up to HK$2,000 per day for a mandatory quarantine stay, totaling HK$42,000 for a three-week stay. The plan aims to retain staff affected by Hong Kong's strict zero-Covid policy, with most of the world reopening.

site_title: CGS-CIMB raises target price of CICT to S$2.57 after Sydney acquisitions
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) has raised its target price to S$2.57 after acquiring 2 Sydney office buildings for A$330.7 million. Analysts CGS-CIMB and Maybank Kim Eng expect the move to boost portfolio diversification and enhance income resilience. The acquisitions are expected to provide an uplift to the Reit's distribution per unit and adjusted net asset value per unit. CICT's overall portfolio property value is expected to increase by 3% to S$22.4 billion post-acquisition.

site_title: Myanmar's ousted leader Suu Kyi sentenced to four years' jail
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi was sentenced to four years in prison on charges of incitement and breaching coronavirus restrictions. President Win Myint also received a four-year sentence. Critics describe the case as a farce, and human rights groups have condemned the sentencing as part of a widespread attack on the civilian population. The trial was closed to the media, and Suu Kyi's lawyers were barred from communication. The international community has demanded her release, and Western states have condemned the violence in Myanmar since the military coup in February.

site_title: Singapore is top investor in Vietnam for 2nd year running
summary: Singapore remains the top investor in Vietnam for the second consecutive year, with foreign direct investments (FDIs) totaling US$6.8 billion in the first 10 months of 2021. Vietnam's economic potential and large domestic market, with a growing middle-class population, continue to attract businesses. Singapore companies are diversifying into sectors such as manufacturing, real estate, and consumer services, with support from Enterprise Singapore (ESG). Vietnam's GDP growth is expected to reach 3-3.5% in 2022, making it one of the fastest-growing South-east Asian economies.

site_title: Suu Kyi's sentence halved to 2 years, Myanmar state TV reports
summary: Myanmar's deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi's sentence has been reduced from four years to two years after a partial pardon by the head of the military-appointed government. Suu Kyi, 76, and ousted President Win Myint were found guilty of incitement and breaching coronavirus restrictions. The US has condemned the sentence, urging the regime to release Suu Kyi and other detained officials, calling for the restoration of democracy and an end to violence. Suu Kyi and Win Myint will serve their sentences in an undisclosed location, avoiding prison.

site_title: QT Vascular shareholders vote to reject 5 would-be directors in ongoing board tussle
summary: QT Vascular shareholders rejected 5 would-be directors in an extraordinary general meeting, with shares representing 50.2% of valid votes cast voting against each resolution. The failed candidacies follow concerns over relationships among the proposed directors and come after the company's CEO and 3 other directors were ousted in a previous EGM. A second EGM on Dec 15 will decide the fates of 2 remaining directors.

site_title: Crypto players waiting on Singapore's playbook
summary: Singapore's regulatory framework for cryptocurrencies is seen as well-calibrated, but authorities are treading a fine line between maintaining regulations and stifling innovation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has granted just 4 licenses to digital payment token (DPT) service providers since January 2020, with over 70 applicants waiting in the pipeline. Regulators are under pressure to balance restrictions and incentives, with international standards for anti-money laundering and terrorist financing risks taking precedence. The city-state's reputation and credibility as a hub for cryptocurrency businesses remain a draw, with Huobi and Binance setting up separate Singapore units awaiting licenses.

site_title: Budget 2022: balancing growth priorities on the pandemic tightrope
summary: Singapore's 2022 Budget faces uncertainty due to the emergence of the Omicron variant, which may affect the effectiveness of existing vaccines. The government has allocated billions of dollars to combat the pandemic, but with Omicron's potential to cause fresh uncertainty, the budget may need to adjust to include funds for updated vaccines and booster jabs. This could impact economic growth projections, which were previously set at 3-5% for 2022, and could also lead to a re-closure of borders and global supply chain disruptions, exacerbating inflation concerns.

site_title: US and China: Healing a wounded relationship
summary: US and China have seen an improvement in their relationship after a virtual meeting between President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, with China cooperating in various areas despite previous demands from the US. China joined the US in releasing oil from its strategic reserve, resumed military-to-military exchanges, and is working with the US and European partners in talks with Iran. The improved relationship is attributed to Biden's perseverance, which led to a change in China's attitude after a September phone call. While areas of disagreement remain, the relationship has regained normalcy, with China characterizing the relationship as "mutual respect, peaceful co-existence and win-win cooperation".

site_title: Grab's share price slide a reminder of risks in any de-SPAC
summary: Grab, a Southeast Asia ride-hailing and delivery services provider, made its trading debut on the Nasdaq via a merger with Altimeter Growth Corp, the largest SPAC transaction to date. Despite initial exuberance, Grab's shares closed 20.5% lower on the first day of trading, down to $8.75 from $11.01. This decline is part of a trend of SPACs falling post-business combination, with over three-quarters of 2021's completed SPACs trading below their $10 IPO price. Investors should familiarize themselves with the nature of SPACs and consider the risks post-business combination.

site_title: Beijing biotech firm banks on GM corn in race to be China's Monsanto
summary: China is poised to open its $120 billion corn market to genetically modified (GM) seed, with Beijing-based biotech firm Dabeinong Biotechnology set to benefit from the move. Dabeinong, which has an insect-resistant and herbicide-tolerant corn already approved as safe by the agriculture ministry, expects to dominate the market for the first two years, generating around $214 million in royalties by the third year. The company hopes to emulate the success of US seed giant Monsanto and help farmers, while rival seed giants like Syngenta and Corteva are also entering the market.

site_title: Higher interest rates don't mean tougher times for tech
summary: Higher interest rates are not expected to negatively impact the tech sector, contrary to the traditional view that rising yields reduce tech's premium valuations. Historically, tech has outperformed the broad market when yields climb, with global tech stocks beating world stocks in over half of the 12-month periods since 1973 when 10-year US Treasury yields rose. The recent rate hikes have been minimal and have not significantly impacted lending and credit-sensitive value stocks. Tech companies are coping well with higher costs, with fat gross margins and strong demand for high-quality debt.

site_title: Scholz to take charge of Germany as Merkel era ends
summary: Germany's Parliament will officially elect Olaf Scholz as the country's next chancellor on December 8, marking the end of Angela Merkel's 16-year reign. Scholz's centre-left coalition, including the Greens and Free Democrats, aims to make Germany greener and fairer, with a focus on climate change and equality. The new government has vowed to secure Germany's path to carbon neutrality and implement a gender-balanced cabinet, with women in key security portfolios. Scholz has also promised to make vaccinations compulsory, despite initial opposition from the FDP.

site_title: Top China Covid expert hints at way to 'normality'
summary: China's top health expert, Zhong Nanshan, has identified two conditions for the country to return to "normality": fatalities from Covid-19 should fall to 0.1% and the virus's reproduction rate should remain within 1-1.5. To achieve these goals, China needs to fully vaccinate its population, normalize prevention and control measures, and develop therapeutic drugs. Authorities should adhere to the Covid Zero policy to combat the omicron variant.

site_title: Nobel literature winner Gurnah receives medal in UK
summary: British novelist Abdulrazak Gurnah received his Nobel Prize for Literature medal in a ceremony in London due to coronavirus restrictions. He won the award in October for his novels portraying colonialism and refugee plights, becoming the fifth African to win the prize. The 72-year-old author, born in Zanzibar, fled to Britain as a refugee in the 1960s and is known for his breakthrough novel "Paradise" and his advocacy for refugee rights.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on banks, energy boost
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.15% to 34,633.43, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.22% and 0.21% respectively. The gains were driven by a boost in bank and energy stocks, as investors favored economy-linked shares over technology-heavy ones amid Omicron concerns and taper fears.

site_title: All eyes on the Fed as it pursues 'dual mandate'
summary: The US Federal Reserve is pursuing its "dual mandate" of maintaining stable prices and maximum employment, a goal established in 1946 and reinforced in 1975. Under Chairman Jerome Powell's leadership, the Fed has implemented aggressive monetary policies, including buying over $4 trillion in assets during the pandemic, to support the economy and keep unemployment low. However, rising inflation has raised concerns, and the Fed is now poised to taper its stimulus programs and potentially raise interest rates to achieve price stability. The Fed's dual mandate has led to a more nuanced approach to monetary policy, balancing the need to support employment with the goal of controlling inflation.

site_title: Special report over Raeesah Khan saga was released to keep parliament informed
summary: The Committee of Privileges in Singapore's Parliament released a special report on the Raeesah Khan saga, following oral evidence heard on Dec 3-4. The report, released on Dec 6, details the committee's findings and progress in its investigation into Khan's complaint against former Workers' Party MP Raeesah Khan, who admitted to lying in Parliament and resigned. The report will be presented to Parliament in due course, keeping lawmakers informed of its findings.

site_title: Next pandemic could be more lethal than Covid, vaccine creator says
summary: AstraZeneca's vaccine creator, Sarah Gilbert, warns that future pandemics could be more lethal than COVID-19, citing the need for better global preparedness. The novel coronavirus has killed 5.26 million people and had a significant economic impact. Gilbert emphasizes the importance of retaining knowledge and advances made in the fight against COVID-19. A panel of health experts has called for permanent funding and greater ability to investigate pandemics through a new treaty, with proposals including $10 billion in annual funding for pandemic preparedness.

site_title: Pawnbroker Maxi-Cash plans S$5.18 million fund-raising exercise for working capital
summary: Maxi-Cash Financial Services Corp plans a S$5.18 million fund-raising exercise to raise up to 32 million ordinary shares, with an issue price of S$0.162 apiece. The estimated net proceeds of S$5.06 million will be used for working capital to expand its secured lending business and pawnshop network.

site_title: Investors brace for potential hit to earnings because of Omicron
summary: Investors are bracing for a potential hit to US corporate earnings due to the emergence of the Omicron Covid-19 variant, which is spreading across the US and affecting travel plans. Retailers, restaurants, and travel companies are particularly vulnerable, with supply-chain disruptions and inflation concerns also weighing on the economy. Despite this, analysts expect only a modest drag on service spending, and the variant's impact will depend on how long it lasts. The Omicron variant has already impacted airline shares, with the NYSE Arca airline index down 8.3% since November 26.

site_title: Russian bans for tech giants is last resort, Interfax reports
summary: Russia is willing to engage in dialogue with foreign tech companies over possible bans if they do not establish official representation in the country by the end of the year. The state communications regulator, Roskomnadzor, initially demanded that 13 foreign tech companies set up in Russia by January 1, but now considers this a last resort. Companies such as Twitter, Google, and Facebook face Russian court cases for violating the same legislation. Roskomnadzor's deputy head stated that slowdowns and blocking are not preferred, but will be considered if companies fail to comply.

site_title: Europe: Equities climb at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose on Monday, despite uncertainty over the Omicron coronavirus variant, with London's FTSE 100 gaining 0.6%, Frankfurt's DAX 0.8%, and Paris' CAC 40 0.7%. Asian indices fell due to Omicron concerns and US jobs data. Markets remain uncertain, with the head of markets stating that the Omicron variant threatens to derail the economic recovery.

site_title: IFS Capital, Tat Hong to explore crane leasing business tie-up in China
summary: IFS Capital, a Mainboard-listed financing firm, has inked a non-binding MOU with Hong Kong-listed crane provider Tat Hong Equipment Service to explore a crane leasing business tie-up in China. IFS Capital would own a 60% stake in the joint-venture company, which would provide financing solutions for tower cranes. The deal aims to expand IFS Capital's SME financing solutions and geographical footprint into China, with no other directors having any interests in the MOU.

site_title: Hong Kong developer to offer 300 homes at 50% discount to market price
summary: Hong Kong developer New World Development is launching a subsidized private housing project offering 300 homes at a 50% discount to market price. The project, aimed at addressing the city's chronic housing shortage, requires a 5% down payment and prioritizes first-time homebuyers aged 25-45. The estimated cost of each unit ranges from HK$2.7 million to HK$4.95 million. This initiative is part of New World's "New World Build for Good" research project, which aims to encourage other corporations to create affordable housing projects in the community.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida vows sweeping defence review, outlines other priorities
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has vowed to strengthen Japan's defense posture, including acquiring the capability to strike enemy bases, to counter an assertive China and unpredictable North Korea. He also aims to defeat deflation by increasing worker wages to 3% or more, and will lay groundwork for private-sector firms to hike wages through taxation and deductions. Additionally, Kishida plans to make booster shots available sooner, without waiting for the current 8-month period, to combat the spread of the Omicron variant.

site_title: Viking Offshore and Marine warrant holders get proposal amid ongoing cash offer
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine has proposed a S$0.01 offer for each warrant, allowing warrant holders to subscribe for one new share at S$0.50 apiece. The offer comes amid an ongoing mandatory unconditional cash offer for shares, with the joint offerors holding an 87% stake in the company. Warrant holders have 10 business days to exercise, accept, or let the proposal lapse, with independent financial adviser and directors' views to be released within 14 days.

site_title: South Africa urges vaccines 'without delay' as cases surge
summary: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa urged citizens to get vaccinated against Covid-19 as the country battles a surge in cases driven by the Omicron variant. Daily infections rose five-fold in a week, with about a quarter of tests showing positive results. Despite the rise, fatalities remain low, and 14.8 million people have been fully vaccinated. The government aims to vaccinate 70% of the population by year's end, and efforts are underway to overcome vaccine hesitancy with pop-up vaccination sites.

site_title: China tech index tumbles to lowest since launch as rout deepens
summary: China's tech index plummeted 3.3% to its lowest level since its inception in July 2020, as concerns over regulatory scrutiny and Beijing's tightening grip on the data-rich private sector intensified investor angst. The decline tracks a 9.1% plunge in the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index and follows Didi Global's delisting from the US stock market. The Hang Seng Tech Index has fallen nearly 48% from its February peak, wiping out about $1.5 trillion in combined market value, with Alibaba Group and JD.com Inc being the biggest losers.

site_title: Wall Street holds fast to fossil fuels as climate pressure grows
summary: Major global banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, continue to support fossil-fuel companies despite climate pressure, with $2.5 billion in bonds issued for these companies in 2021. The finance industry has pledged to fight climate change, but bankers argue that polluters need help to transition to new energy sources. Executives at several major banks face internal tensions over balancing revenue and climate goals, and critics argue that banks are putting profits over the planet's chances of avoiding catastrophic warming.

site_title: Former WP MP Yaw Shin Leong disputes Pritam Singh's account of his sacking
summary: Former Workers' Party MP Yaw Shin Leong disputed party chief Pritam Singh's account of his 2012 departure, saying Singh's account was "not true". Singh claimed Yaw failed to address the party and media after allegations were made, leading to his sacking. Yaw responded on Facebook, not confirming or denying the exact circumstances of his departure, but stating Singh's account was inaccurate. The dispute arises after Singh's remarks following former MP Raeesah Khan's resignation from the party.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.46% on Dec 6, amid uncertainty over the Omicron variant's impact on the global economy. New virus strains and above-target inflation are key risks to financial stability in 2022, according to MAS. Tech talent is in high demand, with two surveys by recruitment firms indicating a pick-up in hiring activity in 2022. Chinese developer Sunshine 100 China Holdings defaulted on US$178.9 million of debt and interest payments, and UOBKH added Sembcorp Marine and BRC Asia to its alpha picks, while Digital Core Reit debuted on the SGX mainboard, jumping 14%.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks close down
summary: Hong Kong shares closed down on Monday, with major tech firms contributing to the losses. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.76%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes declined 0.50% and 1.22%, respectively. This follows a global trend of declining stocks, with the US and EU in focus due to ongoing trade tensions. The decline in Hong Kong's stock market is attributed to losses by major tech firms, weighing on the overall market.

site_title: Evergrande moves toward restructuring as debt deadlines loom
summary: China Evergrande Group is moving toward restructuring as it acknowledges its US$300 billion of debt as unsustainable. The embattled developer plans to engage with offshore creditors on a restructuring plan, amid a barrage of statements from Chinese regulators aiming to contain the fallout on homeowners and the financial system. The move poses a test for Xi Jinping's government as it tries to rein in financial excesses without derailing economic growth. Evergrande's stock plummeted 20% after the announcement, while regulators emphasize containment over bailout.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS says hospitality recovery delayed, not derailed by Omicron
summary: DBS Group Research has downgraded its expectations for Singapore's hospitality recovery, citing the emergence of the Omicron variant. However, the research team believes the impact will be minimal due to domestic demand drivers and higher vaccination rates. DBS maintains "buy" calls on Ascott Residence Trust (ART) and Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT), citing their exposure to large domestic markets and stable rent. The research team forecasts robust distribution per unit growth for the hospitality trusts, with potential upside of 32.7% for ART and 33.3% for FEHT.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 18.29 points to 1,483.45 on Monday, with 790 losers outnumbering 242 gainers. Volume reached 3.66 billion lots worth RM 2.567 billion.

site_title: UBS gives Hong Kong staff cash to cover Covid quarantine costs: memo
summary: UBS Group has offered Hong Kong staff up to HK$2,000 (S$351) per day to cover mandatory hotel quarantine costs, amid the city's strict COVID-19 restrictions. Eligible employees, up to executive director level, can receive the payment between now and the end of November 2022. This move aims to support staff during the challenging period.

site_title: Australia: Shares close slightly higher
summary: Australian shares closed 0.05% higher at 7,245.1 on Monday, driven by upbeat comments from Treasurer Josh Frydenberg on 2022 economic growth and gains in the energy and gold sectors. The benchmark rose despite worries over the Omicron variant, with rising cases forcing some regions to tighten border controls. Investors await the Reserve Bank of Australia's meeting on Tuesday, where the cash rate is expected to remain at 0.10%.

site_title: G8 Subsea, KoolLogix and Nanosun win top accolades at Emerging Enterprise Awards, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Applications are now open for the Emerging Enterprise Awards 2025, with a deadline of June 30. The awards recognize and celebrate innovative and rapidly growing businesses in various industries. The program aims to promote entrepreneurship and support the development of emerging enterprises. Eligible businesses must be established within the last three years, have a minimum turnover of $1 million, and be based in a participating country. Winners will be announced in August 2025, with a ceremony to be held later in the year. The awards aim to provide a platform for emerging businesses to showcase their achievements.

site_title: CapitaLand sells entire Ho Chi Minh City luxury residential development Define
summary: CapitaLand's luxury residential development Define in Ho Chi Minh City has sold all 88 units within 2 hours of its exclusive preview. The residences, priced at an average 125 million dong (S$7,424.74) per square metre, feature private courtyards, lap pools, and a co-working lounge. About 80% of buyers were Vietnamese, with foreigners making up the remaining 20%. Foreigners will receive a 50-year lease, while locals will receive a freehold lease. The development is co-developed with Thien Duc Trading - Construction Company and is set for completion in 2024.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M reopens 4 shuttered Chinese dental centres after Covid-19 hits Liaoning
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group, a 16-dental centre operator in China, has reopened 4 shuttered dental centres in Liaoning province after a Covid-19 outbreak prompted local authorities to suspend non-emergency medical treatments. The centres reopened between Nov 17 and Dec 3, with the company continuing to monitor the situation and implement precautionary measures. The company's shares closed down 2.04% on Monday.

images.alt_text: People lining up for Covid-19 testing after Covid-19 cases were detected in Dalian in the Chinese province of Liaoning in early Nov 2021.

site_title: Audits of cooling systems help reduce energy usage and emissions, Sustainability Impact Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A recent study suggests that Japan's job seekers are more likely to break into the country through social media platforms, with Facebook being the preferred choice. The study found that 41.4% of foreign workers in Japan entered the country through Facebook, while 24.6% came through LinkedIn. The remaining 34% entered through other means. The study highlights the growing importance of social media in the job search process, particularly for foreign workers looking to enter Japan's highly competitive job market. This trend is expected to continue in the future, with Facebook remaining a key platform for job seekers.

site_title: 3DOM inks deal for provision of batteries, energy storage solutions to G8 Subsea
summary: 3DOM, a battery maker, has entered into an agreement with G8 Subsea to supply batteries and energy storage solutions for its renewable energy projects. 3DOM will invest up to US$10 million in G8, acquiring up to 5% stake, and provide technology systems for monitoring battery conditions. The two companies will jointly explore opportunities in renewable power generation, electric mobility, and energy storage. G8's founder, Gerald Tan, stated that the collaboration enables the company to offer world-leading clean energy storage solutions.

site_title: China central bank to cut reserve requirement ratio for second time this year
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced a 50 basis point cut in the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) for banks, effective December 15, releasing 1.2 trillion yuan (S$257.7 billion) in long-term liquidity to boost slowing economic growth amid ongoing COVID-19 cases. This is the second RRR cut this year, aimed at bolstering the economy.

site_title: Digital Core Reit jumps 15% to close at US$1.01 in SGX mainboard debut
summary: Digital Core Reit, a Singapore-based data centre real estate investment trust (Reit), made its trading debut on the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) with a 15% jump to close at US$1.01. The Reit's IPO price was US$0.88, and it raised nearly US$1 billion. The Reit's initial portfolio comprises 10 data centres in the US and Canada, with a total appraised valuation of US$1.4 billion and 100% occupancy.

site_title: Chinese Internet ADRs sell-off is 'overdone', Citigroup says
summary: Citigroup analysts say concerns about Chinese companies delisting from US exchanges are "overdone", with Didi Global's recent announcement of a Hong Kong listing being an "isolated case". The risk of other ADRs de-listing by 2025 is possible, but shares of big-cap companies with dual listings in Hong Kong may be a buying opportunity. The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index slumped 9.1% last week, amid investor unease over the Securities and Exchange Commission's plan to mandate foreign companies' bookkeeping in the US or risk being kicked off the NYSE and Nasdaq within 3 years.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain for fourth day, but Omicron weighs
summary: South Korean stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, driven by foreign buying of chip shares and offsetting concerns about the Omicron coronavirus variant. The KOSPI index closed 0.17% higher at 2,973.25, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix gaining 0.93% and 0.42%, respectively. Investors remained cautious ahead of US inflation data, leading to a decline in the won and benchmark bond yield.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower on Omicron
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday, Dec 6, 2021, due to investor caution over the Omicron coronavirus variant. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.4% to 27,927.37, and the Topix index dropped 0.5% to 1,947.54.

site_title: Revolut bags CMS licence from MAS; to roll out stock trading feature in H1 2022
summary: Revolut has secured a capital markets services (CMS) licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to roll out its stock trading feature in the first half of 2022. The feature allows customers to buy fractional shares in US-listed companies with no account minimum needed to invest. Revolut's stock trading feature will offer commission-free trades, rivaling online brokerages such as TD Ameritrade and Tiger Brokers. The move aims to expand Revolut's global product offerings, with plans to bring commodities and cryptocurrencies to customers in Singapore subject to relevant approvals.

site_title: GIC in joint venture to buy Australian office building for A$335m
summary: GIC and Australian-listed property group Charter Hall have established a joint venture to acquire the 50 Marcus Clarke office building in Canberra, Australia for A$335 million (S$322 million). The 40,000 square-meter Grade A office building has above-market sustainability credentials and is a major tenant hub for the Australian government. This acquisition further increases Charter Hall's exposure to Canberra's growing office market, with steady office demand expected due to healthy employment growth and government demand.

site_title: Longer trading for Philippine stocks, FX begin as Covid eases
summary: Philippine stocks and currency trading resumed their pre-pandemic schedules, with stocks trading 5 hours a day and currency trading 7 hours a day starting Dec 6, as the country eases COVID-19 restrictions. The extended trading hours aim to align with regional markets and boost economic recovery. Dealers are optimistic about the move, citing declining COVID-19 cases and the relaxation of travel rules. The new schedule is seen as a sign of business-as-usual in the Philippines, with market participants expecting an upward trend in economic activities.

site_title: China Everbright Water bags 143m yuan water treatment project in Jiangsu
summary: China Everbright Water secured a 143 million yuan (S$30.7 million) water treatment project in Jiangsu province. The 30-year concession period will provide wastewater treatment services to industrial enterprises, with a daily capacity of 5,000 cubic meters. The project, on a rehabilitate-operate-transfer model, includes a 24-kilometer water pipeline network. This marks the company's second project in Changzhou, following a 2020 concession agreement for a wastewater treatment project with an investment of 100 million yuan.

site_title: UOBKH adds Sembcorp Marine, BRC Asia to December alpha picks
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has added Sembcorp Marine (Sembmarine) and BRC Asia to its December alpha picks, citing improved outlooks for the offshore renewables and drilling sector. Sembmarine's share price was added with a target of S$0.11, representing a 32.5% increase from its closing price, while BRC Asia was added with a target of S$1.76, driven by its monopolistic market share and government infrastructure spending. UOBKH removed Sea and iFast from its portfolio due to lack of share-price catalysts.

site_title: Dalian exchange studying new contracts of North-east Asia crude to shipping futures: state media
summary: China's Dalian Commodity Exchange plans to develop trade, shipping, and logistics derivatives in North-east Asia, including a potential North-east Asia crude oil futures contract. The exchange aims to promote a new international market and list various products such as recycled steel, benzene, and ethanol. It will also research container capacity futures and explore structured futures and options products. The exchange, known for its benchmark iron ore futures, will accelerate the listing of options contracts and focus on cash settlement. Details on the timeline for listing products are not provided.

site_title: Pivoting to promising segments an increasingly vital growth driver for Reits
summary: Singapore-listed Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) are pivoting to promising segments as digitalization and the Covid-19 pandemic create demand in other areas. Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) successfully pivoted to data centers, with occupancy rates around 95% for its data centers, outperforming its overall portfolio. Hospitality-focused Reits, such as Ascott Residence Trust (ART) and CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT), are also diversifying into new asset types, including rental and student housing. Reit managers can earn acquisition and divestment fees from buying promising assets and selling those with limited growth potential, with ARA Asset Management achieving a 62% earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization margin on fee revenue in the first half of 2021.

site_title: Australia's Boral exits US with US$755m fly ash business sale
summary: Australia's Boral sells its US fly ash business for US$755 million to Eco Material Technologies, marking its exit from the US market as it focuses on domestic business. This sale is part of Boral's retreat from its global expansion strategy, which led to a significant writedown in 2020. The US business sale brings in over A$4 billion (S$3.84 billion) for Boral, allowing the company to concentrate on its domestic market.

site_title: STI gains 0.46% amid mixed regional showing, Omicron uncertainty
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.46% on Monday, Dec 6, amid uncertainty over the Omicron variant's impact on the global economy. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 3,116.32. The Monetary Authority of Singapore warned that the pandemic remains a source of considerable uncertainty, with mutated virus strains threatening progress.

site_title: China starts round 2 of massive desert renewable energy build
summary: China has begun the second round of its massive desert renewable energy build-out, with the National Energy Administration (NEA) requesting provinces to submit a list of projects by December 15. The projects, which must be at least 1 gigawatt in capacity, will start construction in 2022 and finish by 2023. This follows the announcement by President Xi Jinping in October that the first 100 gigawatts of projects were already under construction, with Morgan Stanley analysts predicting the second batch will be even larger. The projects aim to complement intermittent wind and solar power.

site_title: Malaysia's 2025 renewable target to be backed by strong solar power growth: Fitch Solutions
summary: Malaysia's renewable energy target has been revised to 31% by 2025, driven mainly by strong solar power growth, according to Fitch Solutions. The country aims to generate 31% of its power capacity from renewables, with solar power expected to be the main driver. Improved hydropower capacity, particularly from the upcoming Baleh Hydroelectric Project, will also contribute to the target. The government has implemented various schemes, including the Large Scale Solar programme and Net Energy Metering 3.0 scheme, to spur solar power growth and meet increasing power demand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 2.12 points or 0.14% to 1499.62. Trading volume was 145.3 million lots worth RM82.4 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 134 to 167.

site_title: Traders dump Asean stocks on fears over Omicron
summary: Emerging-market traders are dumping Asean stocks due to fears over Omicron, causing the MSCI AC Asean Index to fall over 4% since US Thanksgiving. This decline outperforms the 2% drop in Latin American shares and a tiny gain in eastern European equities. The gauge of South-east Asian stocks slumped nearly 7% in the 2 months after the Delta variant was officially named in May.

site_title: Tech talent most in demand as hiring activity picks up in 2022: recruitment firm surveys
summary: Tech talent is in high demand as hiring activity increases in 2022, according to recruitment firm surveys. Salaries in tech areas are expected to rise significantly due to a talent shortage, with professionals commanding 10-15% salary premiums when switching jobs. The Robert Walters Salary Survey 2022 found that 85% of firms in the tech and transformation industry are giving pay rises, the highest among 7 sectors surveyed.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down on open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.07% on Monday, tracking US rate hike fears and the impact of Beijing's crackdown on big tech firms. The Hang Seng Index dropped 254.87 points to 23,511.82. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.25%. The decline was attributed to concerns over a potential US rate hike and the ongoing impact of the tech crackdown.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall as Omicron spreads, US inflation data in focus
summary: South Korean stocks fell on Monday, with the KOSPI slipping 3.58 points, or 0.1%, to 2,964.75, amid concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant's spread and US inflation data. The Omicron variant has spread to about a third of US states and has been confirmed in 24 cases in South Korea. US jobs data suggested an earlier-than-expected tapering by the US Federal Reserve. Foreigners were net sellers of 18.1 billion won worth of shares, with the won falling 0.4% to 1,184.4 per dollar.

site_title: SoftBank slumps 9% Monday after week of bad portfolio news
summary: SoftBank shares plummeted 9% on Monday, extending a 6-day slump, as key companies in its portfolio delivered bad news. Didi Global's preparation to withdraw from US stock exchanges and the US FTC's lawsuit to block SoftBank's Arm Ltd sale to Nvidia Corp. weighed on the company's stock. SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son is relying on completing the Arm transaction to secure a windfall, but the stock is off 35% this year, its worst annual decline since 2006.

site_title: New virus strains, above-target inflation key risks to financial stability in 2022: MAS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) warns of key risks to financial stability in 2022, including new virus strains and above-target inflation, which could lead to a tightening in domestic financial conditions. The economy is expected to expand 3-5% next year, but growth could be uneven, with sectors like manufacturing gaining traction while pandemic-sensitive sectors face mobility restrictions. Households should be cautious with large new commitments, and banks are well-equipped to meet credit needs despite elevated leverage risks. Overall, MAS's stress test suggests that most firms and households are resilient to interest rate and earnings shocks.

images.alt_text: Corporates, households and banks in Singapore have remained stable over the year, buoyed by strong capital buffers, Covid-19 support measures and improving financial conditions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat with eyes on Fed, Omicron
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on December 6, 2021, amid US rate hike concerns and Omicron variant news. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.06% to 28,013.24, while the Topix index rose 0.09% to 1,959.67. Despite this, the US stock market had closed the previous day with record highs despite tariff threats.

site_title: Over 5,000 travelled via land VTL between Singapore and Malaysia in first 5 days
summary: Over 5,000 people traveled quarantine-free by land between Singapore and Malaysia via the vaccinated travel lane (VTL) in the first 5 days after border measures were eased. 2,771 people entered Singapore from Malaysia through air VTL during the same period. The total number of people who made the bus trips is lower than the maximum allowed, with most tickets sold out for the rest of the month. The relaxation of border measures has allowed families to reunite for the first time in nearly 20 months, with many hoping that the emergence of the Omicron variant will not derail quarantine-free travel.

site_title: Why young Singaporeans should venture abroad to be 'future-ready'
summary: Young Singaporeans should consider venturing abroad to gain valuable experience, learn from diverse communities, and develop leadership abilities. With the rise of urbanization in South-east Asian markets, Singaporean companies are expanding overseas, yet few young Singaporeans are taking advantage of this opportunity. Embracing the unknown and broadening perspectives can help individuals become "decathletes" - adaptable and resilient in a rapidly changing world, rather than just focusing on short-term competitive advantages.

site_title: Toshiba walked away from potential buyout talks and Brookfield offer: sources
summary: Toshiba Corp has walked away from potential private equity buyout offers, including a Brookfield Asset Management offer, and instead plans to split itself into three separate companies. Private equity firms have estimated a potential deal could be done at 6,000 yen a share, valuing Toshiba at around $31.51 billion. However, Toshiba's decision has widened the gulf with some hedge fund investors, who question the transparency of the company's ongoing strategic review and the fairness of the proposed split. The company's outside director, Paul Brough, has stated that splitting Toshiba is the "best alternative," despite some shareholders expressing concerns.

site_title: China Evergrande shares hit 11-year low after firm says no guarantee it can meet repayments
summary: China Evergrande shares plummeted 12% to an 11-year low after the firm stated there's no guarantee it can meet debt repayments. The 30-day grace period for a $82.5 million coupon payment ended, and Evergrande is grappling with over $300 billion in liabilities. Chinese authorities have summoned the firm's chairman amid a potential collapse that could send shockwaves through China's property sector and beyond.

site_title: HKEX to open New York office to bolster international presence
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) plans to establish a representative office in New York to bolster its international presence, amid doubts over its status as a financial hub. The office, expected to open next year, will be staffed by about 5 people and will require regulatory licenses. This move follows Beijing's tightening grip on Hong Kong and strict quarantine measures restricting travel. HKEX aims to capitalize on US regulators pushing to delist Chinese firms and expand its ties to the Chinese mainland.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% or 5.41 points to 3,107.34 at the Monday open, driven by gains in mobile satellite communications company Addvalue Technologies and marine engineering group Sembcorp Marine. Local banks were mixed, with DBS and UOB up, while OCBC lost 0.3%. The gains came despite uncertainty surrounding the Omicron variant, which is affecting global markets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA Engineering, Digital Core Reit, Hong Lai Huat
summary: SIA Engineering Company signed a 10-year agreement with Safran Aircraft Engines to provide engine test services for CFM LEAP-1A and -1B engines. Digital Core Reit will start trading on Monday with an initial portfolio of 10 data centers in the US and Canada. Hong Lai Huat Group is expected to commence trading on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange next week after receiving regulatory approval for a dual listing.

site_title: Saudis raise oil prices for Asia, US despite Omicron's spread
summary: Saudi Arabia raised oil prices for buyers in Asia and the US, signaling strong demand despite the Omicron variant. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC+) boosted crude output, and Saudi Aramco increased its key Arab Light grade for Asian and US customers by 60 US cents. Prices for Europe will be cut. The move comes as Brent crude falls 15% since late November, and OPEC+ predicts a supply surplus in early 2022. Saudi Arabia's CEO, Amin Nasser, expressed optimism about demand, contradicting market concerns over Omicron.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises target price of CICT to S$2.57 after Sydney acquisitions
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) has acquired 2 Sydney office buildings for A$330.7 million (S$317.6 million), boosting portfolio diversification and income resilience. Analysts CGS-CIMB and Maybank Kim Eng have raised their target prices on CICT, with CGS-CIMB setting a target price of S$2.57 and Maybank Kim Eng at S$2.55, representing upside of 25.4% and 24.4% respectively. The acquisition is expected to enhance CICT's distribution per unit (DPU) and adjusted net asset value per unit, with analysts citing a macro recovery and stable earnings profile.

site_title: Gold holds steady as investors weigh faster Fed taper prospects
summary: Gold prices held steady at $1,783.91 per ounce on Monday, as investors weighed the prospect of a faster end to the US Federal Reserve's pandemic-era asset purchases. The labour market data suggested a tightening labour market, which could lead to earlier interest rate hikes and reduced stimulus. The dollar index rose, increasing gold's cost for buyers holding other currencies. US employment growth slowed, but the unemployment rate dropped to a 21-month low of 4.2%. Gold prices may be affected by reduced stimulus and interest rate hikes, which tend to push government bond yields up.

images.alt_text: Gold prices held steady on Monday (Dec 6) as market participants weighed the prospect of a faster ending to pandemic-era asset purchases by the US Federal Reserve after data suggested the labour market was rapidly tightening.

site_title: Shock to crypto daredevils joins list of scary market omens
summary: A brutal selling wave has hit the cryptocurrency market, wiping billions of dollars from profitless growth companies, IPO stocks, and SPACs, and causing losses for retail traders. Bitcoin, the most affected, has dropped 21% since Friday's close and is trading at around $42,290, its lowest point since record highs earlier this year. The decline has raised concerns about risk tolerances and brokerage balances among small-time traders, and could signal a negative wealth effect, eroding confidence among larger bettors.

site_title: Some lessons learnt from day trading in cryptocurrencies
summary: A 25-year-old computing major, Ivan Xu, has spent 10 months day trading cryptocurrencies, taking advantage of the bull market phase. Xu believes that cryptocurrencies will rise in value as more people need them for digital transactions and that companies like Meta's metaverse will drive growth. He tracks 20-30 cryptocurrencies daily, focusing on those with real-world use cases, and aims to buy dips to maximize gains. Xu notes that day trading is not for the faint of heart and has lost half of his initial capital in the past. He plans to sell his holdings when the market falls back into bear territory and return to salaried work.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Scrutinising discounted placements by Reits
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust successfully raised US$100 million through a discounted placement of new units, with units sold at US$0.649 each. The placement was more than 2 times covered, and investors were attracted to the potential upside from acquiring 3 promising US properties for US$201.6 million. However, critics argue that the significantly discounted price may have motivated investors to take a chance, potentially diluting existing unitholders. Reit managers should disclose the extent to which potential upside is affected by discounted placement prices.

site_title: Bond market's faith in Fed set for biggest test since the 1980s
summary: The bond market is poised for its biggest test since the 1980s as the Federal Reserve prepares to discuss winding down its asset purchases to combat rising inflation. Fed Chair Jerome Powell has stated that inflation has become "more persistent" and will "linger well into next year," leading to a shift in market expectations. The US consumer price index is expected to surge 6.7% in November, its largest jump since the Fed's last tightening cycle in the early 1980s. Investors are betting on tighter monetary policy to cool growth and bring prices under control, with yields on short- and long-term Treasuries narrowing.

site_title: Funds pour into crypto, managers boost holdings
summary: Hedge fund and private equity managers in the UK plan to add cryptocurrencies to their portfolios in the next 1-2 years, according to a recent EY survey. 31% of hedge fund managers and 13% of private equity managers intend to boost their holdings substantially, despite the slump in Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies following their November highs.

site_title: Governments help arms firms avoid Covid slump: report
summary: The world's largest arms manufacturers, including US firms Lockheed-Martin and BAE Systems, experienced a 1.3% increase in profits to a record $531 billion in 2021, despite the global economy contracting by over 3%. Governments worldwide continued to buy arms during the pandemic and implemented measures to support their defense industries. China's arms sales expanded, but still lagged behind US and British firms, accounting for 13% of the top 100 arms sales. Only France and Russia saw their firms' sales decline last year.

site_title: Canada's real estate stocks slide in worst streak since January
summary: Canada's real estate stocks experienced their worst streak since January, with the S&P TSX Composite Real Estate Index falling 1% on Friday, marking the fourth week of losses. The decline is attributed to rising interest rate hike bets at the Bank of Canada and Federal Reserve, as well as the spread of the Omicron variant. This is despite the Bank of Canada's October statement that it could increase interest rates as early as spring to combat accelerating inflation. The sector's losses are expected to continue as consumer prices rise.

site_title: Bitcoin plunges over 20% in another sign of market nerves
summary: Bitcoin plummeted over 20% on Dec 4, reaching a low of $42,296, before rebounding to around $48,300. The token has now declined over 20% from its all-time high of $69,000. The overall crypto sector has lost around a fifth of its value, sliding to $2.2 trillion. Experts attribute the decline to risk aversion, spiking inflation, and concerns over the Omicron variant. Despite the downturn, Bitcoin is still up over 60% this year.

site_title: The finance research crisis is all too human
summary: Academic finance research faces a replication crisis, with half of market-beating strategies potentially being false, according to Professor Campbell Harvey. The crisis is attributed to the distorting power of incentives, which encourage researchers to tweak data and methodology to produce eye-catching findings. This practice, known as "p-hacking," can lead to statistically significant results that are not necessarily meaningful or reliable. Harvey's warnings are disputed, but his advice to be sceptical of asset management research is sound, as it promotes a more critical approach to understanding markets.

site_title: SenseTime launches Hong Kong IPO to raise up to US$767m: term sheet
summary: SenseTime Group, a Chinese AI startup, is launching a Hong Kong IPO to raise up to US$767 million. The deal involves selling 1.5 billion primary shares at a price range of HK$3.85 to HK$3.99 each. Eight cornerstone investors have subscribed for US$450 million, or 58.6% of the deal, ahead of its launch.

site_title: Alibaba overhauls e-commerce businesses, appoints new CFO
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has announced a restructuring of its e-commerce businesses, forming two new units: international digital commerce and China digital commerce. The international unit will include AliExpress, Lazada, and Alibaba.com, aiming to become more agile and accelerate growth. The company also announced the appointment of a new CFO, replacing the outgoing one amid increasing competition, a slowing economy, and regulatory challenges. This reorganization is part of efforts to adapt to the changing market landscape and drive growth.

site_title: New variant fears disrupt start of top US energy conference
summary: The World Petroleum Congress, a major US energy conference, began this week with a reduced attendance due to the spread of the Omicron Covid-19 variant. The 4-day event, which was rescheduled from 2020, brings together top energy executives and government ministers to discuss the oil market's future, new technologies, and low-carbon strategies. Originally expected to feature officials from Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, India, and the US, the conference now focuses on the industry's response to the pandemic and its impact on the energy sector.

site_title: What it takes to build 21st century cities
summary: The UN projects that 68% of the global population will live in cities by 2050, with Asia and Africa accounting for 90% of the increase. To build 21st-century cities, governments must prioritize sustainable progress, inclusivity, and modern technology. This includes engaging citizens in the planning process, using cutting-edge technology, and embedding transparency. Cities must also be designed to be accessible and inclusive, with a focus on physical security, public mobility, and healthcare. A human-centered approach to smart city innovation is crucial, and collaborative spaces are needed to bring together public, private, and government sectors to drive inclusive and sustainable urban development.

site_title: New ESG focus, expanded markets, wealth reporting among BT's new content offerings
summary: The Business Times (BT) is updating its content offerings to cater to readers' needs, particularly those investing abroad. The updates include expanded companies and markets coverage, double the wealth coverage, and new columns on topics such as climate crisis, work-life harmony, and cryptocurrency. A new environmental, social and governance (ESG) beat will be launched in January, focusing on critical issues. The changes reflect reader feedback and aim to strengthen BT's core reporting while providing a premium, curated product.

site_title: Family offices actively tapping direct private deals in Asia: Citi
summary: Citi is expanding its direct private deals in Asia, matching family office clients with Asian companies, amid rising demand for such investment opportunities. The bank's Asia head of family office advisory, Faye Ong, said Citi may serve around 500 family offices in the next 2-3 years, up from 300 currently. Family offices are allocating a significant portion of their portfolios to direct investments, with 62% in Asia, compared to 42% in Europe and 39% in North America. This growth is driven by the increasing diversification of family offices into private Asian companies, particularly in Singapore.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Bullish outlook for cryptocurrency in 2022 and beyond (Ep 108)
summary: BT Money Hacks discusses cryptocurrency's outlook for 2022 and beyond with Evie Zhang, co-founder and CEO of Coinomo. Experts Simon Guidecoq and Healy Consultants share a bullish outlook, citing potential growth and increased adoption. Key takeaways include the importance of understanding pros and cons, safeguarding digital assets, and considering non-fungible tokens in portfolios. The conversation concludes that cryptocurrencies and NFTs may offer opportunities for investors, but caution is advised, and independent advice should be sought.

site_title: Total solar eclipse plunges Antarctica into darkness
summary: A total solar eclipse plunged Antarctica into darkness on December 4, 2021, as a rare astronomical spectacle witnessed by a handful of scientists and thrill-seekers. The eclipse, visible only in Antarctica, lasted approximately 40 seconds, with the "ring of fire" phase occurring at 0746 GMT. This was the first total solar eclipse in Antarctica since 2003 and the next one won't occur until 2039. The eclipse was streamed live by NASA from the Union Glacier camp, where experts and adventure tourists paid around $40,000 to witness the rare event.

site_title: Sunshine 100 China Holdings defaults on SGX-listed bond payment
summary: Sunshine 100 China Holdings defaulted on a US$178.9 million debt and interest payment due Sunday, Dec 5, due to liquidity issues stemming from the macroeconomic environment and real estate industry. The company cited these factors as the reason for its inability to meet its debt obligations on the 10.5% senior notes due 2021, listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The default may trigger cross-default provisions under other debt instruments.

site_title: ST Engineering eyes S$11b topline in 2026 with cutting edge technologies
summary: ST Engineering aims to increase its top line to over S$11 billion in 2026 by spending more than 75% of its R&D budget on cutting-edge digital technologies. The company has identified 8 focus areas, including cybersecurity, smart traffic management, and neuromorphic computing, to develop enhanced solutions and new capabilities. ST Engineering will allocate 4-5% of revenue annually for R&D, with a focus on leveraging research to drive business outcomes and partnerships with universities and research agencies to expedite research and commercialization.

images.alt_text: Dr Lee says that ST Engineering earmarks 4-5 per cent of revenue each year for R&D. For the financial year 2020, the group generated a revenue of S$7.2 billion and some S$360 million was set aside for R&D.

site_title: My first chapter in venture capitalism
summary: A young associate at Vertex Ventures SEA reflects on their first year in venture capitalism, learning the importance of having an open mind and humility. Key takeaways include the crucial role of founders and their management teams in startup success, the value of a founder-first mentality, and the long-term nature of the VC industry. The associate notes that founders' abilities to navigate business uncertainties and assemble a strong team are critical to a startup's success, and that building relationships with founders takes time. The VC industry is also characterized by its long learning curve and iterative feedback loop, requiring investors to be adaptable and open to learning.

site_title: Aussie heads towards decline as AUD/USD dips below support level
summary: The Australian dollar (AUD) is expected to decline as the AUD/USD pair dips below a key support level of 0.7143. The completion of a head and shoulders pattern, a rising wedge formation, and bearish signals from technical indicators such as the Relative Strength Index (RSI) and Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) support the bearish outlook. The pair is expected to test the first support line at 0.7 and potentially retest the neckline support turned resistance, with a downside target of 0.6335 if the neckline is successfully retested.

site_title: Hotel investment outlook brightens in Asia-Pacific
summary: Hotel investment in the Asia-Pacific region is expected to see a resurgence in 2022, driven by growing consumer and investor confidence as countries transition from pandemic to endemic management. The sector is expected to see over $10 billion in sales, with key drivers including Australia, Japan, mainland China, and South Korea. Investors are seeking assets with strong domestic demand potential and opportunities for refurbishment or repositioning. However, bid-ask spreads remain a challenge, with some assets trading at wider premiums than others.

site_title: BT podcast: Make your SME more profitable with simpler low-cost digital solutions
summary: BT podcast episode discusses making SMEs more profitable with low-cost digital solutions, including website building, payment integration, analytics, and mentorship. Guest Wong Wenbin, Head of GrabPay, highlights the gap in digitalization adoption and challenges impeding digitalization. Key takeaways include the importance of access to credit for SMEs, the need for alliances and digital solutions to stand the test of time, and the potential for cashless transactions to drive growth. A case study also showcases an SME that tripled sales after digitalization.

site_title: China's power in Asia falls as US regains authority: study
summary: China's power in Asia decreased in 2021 due to its shift towards domestic production and consumption, while the US regained authority through better diplomacy and vaccination efforts. China's demographics and financial system pose structural weaknesses, and its isolationist stance lost ground on cultural and diplomatic influence. The US, ranked first, was bolstered by President Joe Biden's administration and a speedy recovery from the pandemic. China's power index fell due to concerns over its rapidly ageing population and heavy domestic debt load, making it unlikely to surpass the US in dominance in Asia.

site_title: Taiwan says it's an important partner, and will keep talking to US on currency
summary: Taiwan's central bank stated that the country's trade surplus with the US is primarily due to the China-US trade war and soaring tech demand during the Covid-19 pandemic, rather than exchange rate factors. Despite exceeding US Treasury thresholds for possible currency manipulation, Taiwan and the US maintain "smooth" communication channels and will continue to discuss currency issues. The US Treasury is working with Taiwan to develop a plan to address the underlying causes of the country's currency undervaluation and excessive external surpluses.

site_title: Metaverse hype fuels digital property market
summary: Investors are betting big on digital real estate, with record-breaking purchases of virtual land in platforms like The Sandbox and Decentraland. Republic Realm spent $4.3 million on digital land, while Tokens.com bought a prime patch in Decentraland's Fashion Street district for $2.4 million. The metaverse, a future Internet with virtual reality, is gaining traction, with interest soaring after Facebook's rebranding as Meta. Digital land is functioning as an asset, with investors predicting it will become a valuable commodity, and luxury brands are already venturing into the metaverse.

site_title: When crisis hits: dealing with mistakes
summary: Leaders must promptly address mistakes to prevent damage to their team and organization's credibility. When errors occur, especially in high-stakes environments, leaders should hold themselves accountable, apologize, and make amends. They should also investigate the cause of the mistake, take corrective action, and be transparent in their findings. Compassion and fairness should be exercised in dealing with team members who make mistakes, and disciplinary action should be proportionate and justified. Effective leadership requires quick thinking, integrity, and wisdom to navigate the complexities of dealing with mistakes.

site_title: Addvalue seeks to issue over 1 billion new shares at S$0.0127 each to raise S$13.2 million
summary: Addvalue Technologies, a mobile satellite communications company, has secured funding of up to S$13.2 million from investors, including Economic Development Innovations Singapore (EDIS), to raise S$12.6 million for working capital and business expansion. The company will issue up to 1 billion new shares at S$0.0127 each, representing a 3.8% discount to its weighted average share price. The funding will also result in a 46.4% increase in outstanding shares, with EDIS and another creditor becoming substantial shareholders.

site_title: SIAEC signs 10-year agreement to provide test services for Safran's CFM LEAP engines
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) has signed a 10-year agreement with Safran Aircraft Engines to provide test services for the CFM LEAP-1A and -1B engines. The agreement will be conducted at SIAEC's engine test facility, upgraded with the latest data acquisition and control system from Safran Test Cells. This expansion strengthens SIAEC's engine maintenance services, enhancing its value to OEM partners and airline customers. The transaction is not expected to impact SIAEC's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending March 31, 2022.

site_title: UK to require pre-arrival Covid tests for all travellers
summary: The UK will require all travellers to take a pre-flight Covid-19 test 48 hours prior to their flight, starting December 7. The measure is temporary and will be reviewed as the omicron outbreak develops. The test must be taken regardless of vaccine status. The move comes after over 150 people in the UK were identified with the new variant, and is expected to prompt an angry reaction from the airline industry. The measure will be reviewed and may be lifted if the situation improves.

site_title: US ship logjam stretching far into Pacific is longer than ever
summary: The number of container ships waiting to enter the US ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach has risen to 96 under a new counting method, exceeding 100 for the first time. The logjam, which has been ongoing since November, involves vessels waiting an average of 20.8 days to enter the ports, with those outside the official area taking longer to arrive. Despite efforts to alleviate the bottleneck, including longer trucking hours and incentives for timely pickup, relief is not expected until months, with American importers booking January orders in advance of the Lunar New Year holiday.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for December 3-9, 2021, reveals a gradual recovery in the tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize index and timecharter average (5TC) rose to 4,594 and $38,096, respectively. In the Atlantic, the transatlantic trade saw strong fixtures, while the Panamax market experienced significant gains. Ultramax and Supramax vessels also saw increased activity, with rates tightening due to tonnage scarcity. The market for Suezmax and Aframax vessels remained steady, with Aframax experiencing a slight decrease in the Mediterranean. The Handysize market saw a slow start but improved in the latter half of the week.

site_title: 552 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; 1 imported case 'preliminarily positive' for Omicron
summary: Singapore reported 552 new Covid-19 cases, with 523 in the community and 15 imported cases, including one preliminarily positive for Omicron. The ICU utilization rate decreased to 51.2%. Thirteen people aged 52-96 died of Covid-19 complications, bringing the total fatalities to 759. The weekly infection growth rate remains below 1, and 87% of the population has completed the full vaccination regimen or received two shots.

site_title: Investors frozen out of crypto exchange CMBDEX for almost 3 years
summary: More than 2,000 investors were left frozen out of the crypto exchange CMBDEX for nearly three years, with investors told they could not sell their tokens due to "technical difficulties." Sources claim this was a deliberate attempt to lock in their money. CMBDEX, which launched in 2018, was not regulated by the Payment Services Act, which came into force in January 2020. The exchange also terminated its partnership with Kopitiam in May 2020.

images.alt_text: A spokesperson for food court operator Kopitiam said the crypto tie-up with PLMP was stopped back in May 2020 based on business considerations.

site_title: Buybacks & director acquisitions rise amid STI pull back
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 4.0% from November 26 to December 2, with institutions net selling S$486 million worth of shares. However, 26 primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks totaling S$206.7 million, led by CapitaLand Investment. In director and substantial shareholder transactions, 29 acquisitions were reported, with notable transactions including Wee Investments' acquisition of UOL Group shares and Nikhil Eapen's acquisition of StarHub shares.

site_title: Up for auction: Wikipedia creator's computer and NFT of first edit
summary: Wikipedia founder Jimmy Wales' personal computer from 2001, used to program the online reference resource, and an NFT memorializing his first edit, are up for auction. The Strawberry iMac and NFT, featuring the debut onscreen image "Hello world", will be sold online through Dec 15, with Christie's hoping to fetch hundreds of thousands of dollars. The proceeds will fund Wales' WT.Social project, a non-toxic social media network. The sale is part of Christie's growing trend of auctioning NFTs, with previous sales reaching record-breaking prices.

site_title: Safe-haven yen, Swiss franc rise on Omicron fears, Fed policy uncertainty
summary: The yen and Swiss franc rose on Friday amid concerns over the spread of the Omicron variant and potential aggressive Federal Reserve action to curb inflation. The US dollar traded little changed after a weaker-than-expected jobs report, which still showed solid labor market details. The Fed's benchmark interest rate is expected to rise by a quarter-percentage-point by May 2022, with a 74% chance of such a move. Global equities and bond yields fell, and the euro rose 0.1% against the dollar.

site_title: Facebook's stock is on sale, but the retail crowd isn't buying
summary: Facebook's parent company, Meta Platforms Inc, saw its stock decline 7.9% over the past five sessions, outpacing its tech peers. However, retail investors failed to buy into the stock, with net purchases barely increasing to around $40 million. This is a stark contrast to previous selloffs, when retail investors had driven a rebound in the shares. Meta's stock is now trading at 22 times earnings, making it cheaper than about 40% of the stocks in the Russell 1000 Value Index, with the company's price to trailing profits at a record low.

site_title: QT Vascular nominating committee raises concerns over proposed new directors ahead of EGM
summary: QT Vascular's nominating committee has raised concerns about the proposed new directors, citing potential conflicts of interest due to their common directorships with other listed companies. The proposed new directors, including Tansri Saridju Benui, may not be in compliance with the company's code of corporate governance. The committee has noted that further matters need to be established before a conclusion can be reached on the proposed board's efficacy and compliance. If the proposed directors are voted in, they will face scrutiny from the current board, which has expressed its intention to resign if they are elected.

site_title: Allegations at Parliament committee hearing rock WP members, party leaders say they will respond
summary: A Parliament committee hearing in Singapore has sparked controversy within the Workers' Party (WP), with allegations of party leaders' involvement in a scandal involving former MP Raeesah Khan. The committee released a special report and video recordings of its sessions, which revealed that WP leaders knew about Khan's lie about accompanying a rape victim to make a police report. Former MP Daniel Goh expressed anguish and anger, while others questioned the credibility of Khan. The WP has remained silent, promising to respond to the allegations in due course, as the party's leaders have yet to testify.

site_title: Dormitory-bound work pass holders cannot enter Singapore via VTL: MOM
summary: The Manpower Ministry (MOM) of Singapore has banned employers of S Pass and work permit holders in the construction, marine shipyard, and process sector from making new applications for workers to enter Singapore via vaccinated travel lanes (VTLs). Workers must enter Singapore via ongoing industry initiatives or the Work Pass Holder General Lane, with on-arrival COVID-19 testing and isolation. Exceptions include Malaysian and female work pass holders. The move aims to reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission in dormitories and worksites, where workers reside.

site_title: Google hires former Amazon executive to work on machine learning
summary: Google has hired Alex Spinelli, a former Amazon executive who worked on the Alexa voice assistant, as a vice president. Spinelli joined Google from LivePerson, where he worked on chatbots and a partnership with Google Cloud. He is now working on machine learning initiatives, including TensorFlow, a software developed by Google for building artificial intelligence systems. This move is part of Google's efforts to advance its AI capabilities.

site_title: WP will respond at 'appropriate forum and juncture'; Pritam prepared to give evidence to Committee of Privileges
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has responded to the interim report released by the Parliament's Committee of Privileges, stating that it will address the allegations against its leaders at an "appropriate forum and juncture." Party chief Pritam Singh is prepared to give evidence to the committee, following a press conference on Dec 2. The WP expressed gratitude for public support and noted the committee's work remains in progress.

images.alt_text: (From left) Sengkang GRC MP He Ting Ru, Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh and party chairman Sylvia Lim at the WP's press conference on Dec 2, 2021.

site_title: A longevity road map for happier, more fulfilling lives
summary: A new book by Andrew Scott and Lynda Gratton proposes a "longevity roadmap" for a happier, more fulfilling life by challenging the traditional view of age as a fixed, biological process. The authors argue that the gap between chronological and biological age is widening, and society and workplaces fail to accommodate this shift. By embracing a more flexible understanding of age, individuals can stay healthy, engaged, and productive, leading to a more fulfilling life. The book aims to provide a framework for redefining what it means to be "old" and how to live a longer, happier life.

images.alt_text: "At every age, we have more time ahead of us. So we need to prepare differently and . . . do things differently... I think seizing those opportunities is the essence of a longevity society," says Scott (above).

"At every age, we have more time ahead of us. So we need to prepare differently and . . . do things differently... I think seizing those opportunities is the essence of a longevity society," says Scott.

site_title: John Soh, Quah Su Ling await verdict in penny stock crash trial
summary: A marathon trial over the 2013 penny stock crash in Singapore is nearing its conclusion. John Soh, 62, and his partner Quah Su Ling face charges of market manipulation, deception, and cheating. The prosecution alleges Soh was the mastermind behind the $8 billion crash, while Soh claims he was only promoting shares. The defense argues that the Singapore Exchange's intervention into trading led to the crash, and several key witnesses' credibility has been questioned. The verdict is expected soon, with Soh facing 188 charges and Quah 177.

site_title: Singapore suspends crypto exchange embroiled in dispute with BTS, FT reports
summary: Singapore's regulator has suspended Bitget, a cryptocurrency exchange, amid a dispute with BTS's agency Hybe over promoting Army Coin, a digital currency with no connection to the South Korean boy band. Bitget removed the Monetary Authority of Singapore's logo and blocked Singapore users after Hybe threatened to take legal action. The exchange has over 1.5 million users worldwide and had previously advertised Army Coin as a way to provide lifetime financial support to BTS members.

images.alt_text: The septet at this year's American Music Awards.

site_title: Bitcoin extends downtrend, falls 12.1% to US$47,176
summary: Bitcoin fell 12.1% to US$47,176.09, losing US$6,567.6 from its previous close, marking a 31.6% drop from its year-high of US$69,000. Ether also declined 10.1% to US$3,794.61. These losses follow a downtrend for the cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Google and other tech giants enlist mom-and-pop shops in antitrust campaign
summary: Google and other tech giants, including Amazon, Facebook, and Apple, are teaming up with small business owners to lobby against antitrust bills aimed at regulating their market dominance. The companies claim that stricter regulations would make it harder for small businesses to reach customers and promote their products online. In contrast, anti-monopoly groups are using small businesses to argue that Big Tech preys on them and makes it impossible for them to operate without relying on internet monopolies. The bills targeting the tech giants have bipartisan support, but the outcome is uncertain due to the possibility of Republican control in Congress.

site_title: Australia Omicron variant spreads, testing reopening plans
summary: Australia reported its first community transmission of the Omicron coronavirus variant at a school in Sydney, prompting concerns about reopening plans.
