The Omicron variant spread to 13 cases in Sydney and a suspected case in Queensland. Despite this, federal authorities remain committed to reopening the economy, citing hopes that the new variant is milder than previous strains. Some states and territories have tightened domestic border controls, while others, like South Australia, are testing arrivals from affected areas.

site_title: Biden says he is crafting a plan for Russia-Ukraine crisis
summary: US President Joe Biden announced the development of comprehensive initiatives to deter Russia's potential invasion of Ukraine, amid concerns of over 94,000 Russian troops massed near Ukraine's borders. Biden stated he would not accept Moscow's "red lines" and emphasized the US's willingness to use economic sanctions and other tools to address Russian actions. A video teleconference between Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin is expected within days, with the White House engaged in talks for the call.

site_title: Vietnam's EV maker VinFast plans US IPO in H2 2022
summary: Vietnam's EV maker VinFast plans a US initial public offering (IPO) in the second half of 2022, with the company expecting to raise up to $3 billion. The IPO would make VinFast one of the first Vietnamese companies to be traded in the US, with the company aiming for a post-IPO value of $25 billion to $60 billion. VinFast is planning to roll out electric SUVs in the US, Canada, and Europe by the end of 2024 and has already unveiled its two electric SUVs, the VF e35 and VF e36.

site_title: US bill puts Mexico electric car investments at risk: Minister
summary: Mexico's Economy Minister Tatiana Clouthier warns that a US bill offering tax credits for electric vehicles (EVs) built with domestic labor may put investments in Mexico at risk. At least two EV investments could close, and eight states may lose out on automaker expansions. Clouthier is discussing the issue with US senators, calling the US actions "contradictory" during improved supply-chain negotiations. This move may impact Mexico's efforts to boost its electric vehicle industry.

site_title: SpaceX wins more Nasa flights as Boeing Starliner stumbles
summary: NASA awards SpaceX three additional Crew Dragon flights to the International Space Station, keeping crew rotations intact while Boeing's Starliner vehicle faces glitches. SpaceX now has six flights, with the new missions expected as soon as 2023. NASA is working with Boeing to address Starliner certification issues, with the company planning to reschedule its test in the first half of 2022. The move aims to maintain a US presence on the station, with the next SpaceX "Crew-4" flight set for April 15.

site_title: After calling China's crackdown, this fund is going big on solar
summary: A Hong Kong-based investment firm, Strategic Vision Investment, is doubling down on its bets on China's solar companies, despite a crackdown on the education industry. The fund's flagship $350 million Value Multiplier Fund has returned over 200% in 2020 and is up 35% this year, outperforming the HFRX China Index. The firm's chief investment officer, Ken Xu, expects solar power to account for 60% of global electricity generation in the next 20 years, driving growth in solar glass and power inverter manufacturers.

site_title: Bitcoin tumbles 5.5% to US$53,436
summary: Bitcoin fell 5.5% to $53,435.9, a 22.6% drop from its year-high of $69,000 on November 10. Ether, linked to the ethereum blockchain network, dropped 6.8% to $4,208.68. These declines follow a broader market slump.

site_title: UN extends Somalia anti-piracy effort by 3 months
summary: The UN Security Council voted unanimously to extend a 3-month anti-piracy program off Somalia's coast, allowing international naval forces to continue fighting piracy. France warned the extension was too short, while Somalia stressed the absence of pirate attacks justifies ending the operation. The program, which has been in place since 2008, will be transitioned to a bilateral military cooperation framework after the extension. Somalia objects to a 1-year extension and calls for a rethink of the policy.

site_title: Mexican airline Interjet plans to restart in 2022 with 10 airplanes
summary: Mexican budget airline Interjet plans to resume flights in 2022 with 10 leased Airbus 320 planes, ending a year-long shutdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic's financial toll. Interjet aims to forgive 90-99% of its debt to creditors through a judicial process, which has been slowed by a strike by its 5,000-employee union. The airline's new CEO, Luis Bertrand, says Interjet is "alive and viable" and plans to restart operations while negotiating financial and labor agreements.

site_title: Nasdaq tumbles 2% as traders weigh jobs report
summary: The Nasdaq tumbled 1% on December 5, 2021, as traders weighed the mixed jobs report, which showed the smallest US payrolls gain this year in November and a lower-than-forecast unemployment rate of 4.2%. Despite this, several economists believe the report won't be a game-changer for monetary policy, and the Federal Reserve may still accelerate its tapering of asset purchases. Tech shares led declines, and Facebook parent Meta Platforms plummeted 20% from its September peak, entering a bear market.

site_title: Hundreds of companies promised to help save forests. Did they?
summary: Hundreds of companies, including major brands like Coca-Cola and Mars, pledged to end deforestation in their supply chains by 2020. However, a decade later, no company has achieved this goal, and many others did not even try. Companies face challenges in tracking the origin of commodities, making it difficult to ensure that products are grown without deforestation. Despite this, some companies, like those in Brazil and Indonesia, have made progress in reducing deforestation, and there is hope for collective action to address the issue through agreements like the 2030 pledge to end deforestation.

site_title: Twitter admits policy 'errors' after far-right abuse
summary: Twitter has admitted that its new picture permission policy, aimed at combating online abuse, was marred by "errors" and malicious reports, allowing far-right groups to use it to harass opponents and avoid scrutiny. The policy, which allows users to request the removal of images posted without their consent, was met with concerns from anti-racism advocates. Twitter acknowledged the issues and expressed regret for the mistakes made during the policy's rollout. The incident highlights the challenges of implementing policies to combat online abuse and the need for more effective moderation.

site_title: Oil steadies, paring gains as rising Covid cases spur demand worries
summary: Crude oil prices ended little changed on Friday, erasing earlier gains, amid growing worries over rising Covid cases and a new variant that could reduce global demand. Opec+ stuck to its plan to add 400,000 barrels per day in January, but left the door open to changing policy if demand suffers. The World Health Organization urged vaccination to combat the virus, as the US reported six confirmed cases of the Omicron variant in Nebraska.

site_title: Omicron in 10 US states; South Africa surges
summary: The omicron variant of COVID-19 has spread to at least 10 US states, including New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Missouri, Maryland, and Nebraska, with community spread confirmed by Anthony Fauci, President Joe Biden's top medical adviser. South Africa has also seen a surge in cases, with the daily number of confirmed cases almost quadrupling since Tuesday. The FDA has warned that the variant reduces the sensitivity of some molecular tests, and Fauci predicts more cases will arise as the variant spreads in the community, potentially competing with the delta strain for dominance.

site_title: Elon Musk's wealth drops US$15b as tech stocks plunge
summary: Elon Musk's net worth dropped by $15.2 billion, leaving him with $268.9 billion, as technology stocks tumbled amid inflation and economic tightening fears. The decline, the largest among tech billionaires, follows a 20% drop in Meta Platforms Inc. shares. Other tech billionaires, including Jeff Bezos, Larry Ellison, and Mark Zuckerberg, also saw significant losses, with combined wealth dropping $27.4 billion. The losses are attributed to market volatility and the Federal Reserve's potential to taper asset purchases.

images.alt_text: The richest US tech moguls dropped tens of billions in collective wealth as technology stocks tumbled amid fears of inflation and economic tightening. Elon Musk's net worth fell by US$15.2 billion on Friday - the most among tech billionaires - after Tesla shares extended losses.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida likely to cancel US visit due to Omicron: NHK
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is likely to cancel his planned US visit for talks with President Joe Biden due to the spread of the Omicron variant of Covid-19. The meeting was originally scheduled for this month, but Kishida is considering rescheduling it after the new year. This decision comes amid the rapid spread of the new coronavirus variant and the US political situation.

site_title: WHO tells Asia-Pacific to brace for Omicron as variant spreads
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned Asia-Pacific countries to prepare for a surge in COVID-19 cases as the Omicron variant spreads globally, despite travel curbs. Cases have been reported in India, Japan, Malaysia, Singapore, and South Korea. The WHO emphasizes that border controls can only delay the spread, and vaccination rates vary greatly across the region, with Indonesia fully vaccinating only 35% of its population. Global health authorities are also considering booster shots, but their effectiveness is uncertain.

site_title: China stock losses in US top US$1 trillion on delisting fear
summary: US-listed Chinese stocks have suffered a historic sell-off, erasing over $1 trillion in value since February. The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index plummeted 9.1% on Friday, its largest decline since 2008, following Didi Global's decision to delist from the NYSE. The decline is part of a broader market downturn, with technology shares bearing the brunt, and is fueled by regulatory pressure on Chinese firms. The sell-off has left investors with significant losses, with Alibaba Group Holding's market capitalization dropping by nearly 60% since its peak in February.

site_title: Gold rises 1% as virus jitters, lower yields lift demand
summary: Gold prices rose 1% on Friday due to uncertainty sparked by the Omicron coronavirus variant and lower US Treasury yields. Spot gold reached $1,785.29 per ounce, while US gold futures settled 1.2% higher. The metal's appeal increased as investors sought safe-haven assets amid concerns over the Federal Reserve's tapering and the Covid situation. Despite a weak financial market sentiment, gold was still on track for its third consecutive weekly loss due to hawkish Fed officials and rising interest rates.

site_title: SEC moves a step closer to delisting China firms in the US
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has finalized a plan to require foreign companies to comply with US disclosure requirements, potentially leading to the delisting of over 200 Chinese companies from US exchanges. The new law, which was mandated by Congress in 2020, requires foreign companies to allow US auditors to inspect their books, a requirement China and Hong Kong have refused to comply with. The SEC will identify non-compliant companies and give them three years to comply, after which they may be delisted.

site_title: IMF chief warns Omicron could slow global growth
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva warned that the Omicron variant of Covid-19 could slow global economic recovery, similar to the Delta strain. The IMF projected 5.9% global growth this year and 4.9% in 2022, but the US and other major economies experienced downward revisions. The new variant may dent confidence and lead to downgrades of growth projections. Policymakers are also dealing with inflation concerns, supply chain issues, and uneven vaccine distribution, which are slowing the rebound. The IMF expects the US Federal Reserve to increase interest rates in 2022.

site_title: Goldman Sachs launches green finance group with Beijing think tank
summary: Goldman Sachs has launched a green finance working group with the International Finance Forum (IFF) in Beijing, aiming to facilitate dialogue on climate action among corporations and researchers. The group will advise policymakers on enhancing green finance cooperation between the public and private sectors. The partnership could generate $16 trillion in infrastructure investment opportunities and 40 million new jobs in China by 2060, according to Goldman research. The group's co-chairs, John Waldron and Zhu Xian, aim to deploy climate technologies at scale and promote greener energy sources.

site_title: Indonesia poised for strong Q4 growth, but Omicron could throw spanner in the works
summary: Indonesia is poised for strong economic growth in Q4 2021, driven by improved investor confidence and resurgent consumer spending. However, the emergence of the Omicron variant of Covid-19 could impact growth if tighter restrictions or another lockdown are implemented. Indonesia's full-year GDP growth is expected to be between 3.7% and 4%, down from the government's earlier estimate of 4%. The country's vaccination rates and new daily infections will be closely monitored for any potential impact on growth.

site_title: Daily ARTs for all VTL arrivals to Singapore; 7 more countries added to high-risk category
summary: Singapore has added seven countries - Bulgaria, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Luxembourg, Norway, and Poland - to its high-risk category for travel due to the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, effective Dec 6. All long-term pass holders and short-term visitors with recent travel history to Ghana, Malawi, and Nigeria within the last 14 days will be restricted from entering, transferring, or transiting through Singapore. From Dec 6, all VTL arrivals will undergo daily antigen rapid tests (ARTs) for 7 days, with supervised tests on days 3 and 7.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge up as Wall Street rallies overnight
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% to close at 3,101.93 points, with 269 advancers beating 194 decliners. The overnight rally on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 climbed 1.4% and the Nasdaq rose 0.8%, influenced the regional market. Asia's markets took a wait-and-see approach, awaiting further market developments and economic indicators.

site_title: Can Hong Kong keep its SPAC envy at bay?
summary: Hong Kong's consideration of allowing special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) has sparked debate. Despite initial interest, the Asian financial center appears to be cautious, with proposed restrictions limiting participation to professional investors. This move may be driven by a desire to avoid losing exciting startups to Singapore, which has relaxed rules for local SPAC listings. Hong Kong's concerns about excessive speculation and regulatory arbitrage are valid, but the city's decision may ultimately hinder its ability to attract innovative companies, potentially harming its competitiveness in the region.

site_title: Europe: Shares end bumpy week with losses
summary: European shares ended a bumpy week with losses, falling 0.6% on Friday, amid worries over the Omicron coronavirus variant and the US Federal Reserve's hawkish turn. The Stoxx 600 erased morning gains, closing down for the week. Despite a rebound in London's FTSE 100, basic resources sector lost 2.5% and tech stocks declined. The European Central Bank may set a "transitory" inflation policy at its upcoming meeting.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends lower on Omicron worries, Fed taper angst
summary: US stocks closed lower on Friday due to concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant and the Federal Reserve's tapering of monetary support. Despite a strong jobs report, the Nasdaq led declines, and the S&P 500 lost 0.9%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.19%. Investor anxiety was fueled by uncertainty around the Fed's next move and the potential for earlier interest rate hikes. The tech sector, led by Apple and Microsoft, was a major loser, with defensive sectors consumer staples and utilities outperforming.

site_title: China-listed firms rush to divest property businesses amid sector crackdown
summary: China-listed firms are rapidly divesting property businesses amid industry-wide liquidity stress triggered by tightened lending curbs and financial woes at major developers. Industry-wide liquidity stress has led to increased regulatory scrutiny. This year has been marked by headlines of financial struggles at China Evergrande Group, with companies now seeking to sell off real estate assets to mitigate risks. The divestments are part of a broader sector crackdown and aim to address liquidity stress and ensure financial stability in the Chinese property market.

site_title: Sporting calendar comes alive as fans return in droves
summary: The AFF Suzuki Cup football tournament is set to kick off in Singapore this month, with thousands of fans expected to attend matches at the National Stadium and Bishan Stadium. The tournament, featuring regional powerhouses Thailand and the Philippines, will see capped attendance of 10,000 at the National Stadium and 1,000 at Bishan Stadium, a significant decrease from pre-pandemic levels. This marks a positive step towards normalcy, with the government and event organizers working together to bring back sports events while ensuring safety.

site_title: Investors snap up metaverse real estate in virtual land boom
summary: Investors are snapping up metaverse real estate as the global market is expected to reach $1 trillion in the near future. Tech companies and luxury brands are entering the metaverse via non-fungible tokens (NFTs), and investors are buying concert venues, shopping malls, and other properties. The metaverse is a 4-dimensional online world where avatars live, work, and play, and it's powered by blockchain technology. Companies like Tokens.com and Metaverse Group are breaking ground on virtual properties, and luxury brands like Louis Vuitton and Gucci have already entered the metaverse.

images.alt_text: Hrish Lotlikar (left), co-founder and the chief executive of SuperWorld, notes that one can buy virtual land that covers the earth at those locations; Michael Gord (right), co-founder of the Metaverse Group, argues that sceptics should look at the trends catalysed by the pandemic.

site_title: China Evergrande gets US$260m demand, warns of non-payment
summary: China Evergrande has received a US$260 million demand under a guarantee obligation, warning it may not be able to repay due to a liquidity crisis affecting China's property sector. The company has already failed to pay US$82.5 million in coupons and grapples with over US$300 billion in liabilities. Repayment dates under certain agreements may be accelerated if it fails to meet the obligation. Evergrande's financial struggles come as the company stumbles from debt deadline to deadline. The company's liquidity crisis has significant implications for its ability to meet its financial obligations.

site_title: Singapore public offer of Digital Core Reit IPO is 16.1 times subscribed
summary: Singapore's Digital Core Reit, a data centre real estate investment trust (Reit), has seen its public offer of 13.4 million units subscribed 16.1 times, exceeding the total available units. The international placement tranche was also subscribed 19.6 times. Successful applicants will receive units by Monday, and trading will begin at the same time. The Reit manager forecasts a distribution yield of 4.75% for 2022 and 5% for 2023.

site_title: IMF says US monetary policy should focus more on inflation risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that US monetary policy should focus more on inflation risks due to intensifying pressures, especially in the US, and uncertainties caused by the Omicron variant of Covid-19. The IMF suggests the Federal Reserve should accelerate tapering asset purchases and raise interest rates earlier than expected to address inflation. This would also help emerging and developing economies prepare for rising interest rates in advanced economies.

site_title: A journey through the history of futures and derivative markets regulation
summary: A new book, "Algo Bots and the Law," by Gregory Scopino, explores the intersection of regulation and execution technology in the futures and derivative markets. The book discusses the implications of rapid electronic execution, fueled by artificial intelligence, on market oversight. Scopino, a Georgetown University adjunct law professor, examines the regulatory environment and proposes solutions, including regulating algo bots as market participants and introducing market disruption funds to prevent flash crashes. While the book provides a detailed history of futures and derivative regulation, it may be too technical for finance professionals, missing opportunities to link law and economics to the future of execution and market integrity.

site_title: US payrolls growth slowed in November while jobless rate fell
summary: US job growth slowed to 210,000 in November, its smallest gain this year, while the unemployment rate fell to 4.2% as forecast. The labor force participation rate rose to 61.8%. Despite the mixed picture, the drop in unemployment and rise in labor force participation may prompt the Federal Reserve to accelerate the tapering of pandemic stimulus. The US job market remains below pre-pandemic levels, with payrolls still 3.9 million below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Can't find a Rolex or Patek Philippe? Blame the Reddit crowd
summary: Luxury watch demand has skyrocketed due to lockdown savings, revenge spending, and a broader interest in alternative assets, outpacing supply. Waiting lists have grown, and second-hand market prices are rising. The boom is attributed to a combination of factors, including a growing interest in luxury watches. As a result, Rolex and Patek Philippe are particularly hard to find, forcing buyers to seek alternative options. The luxury watch market continues to thrive, with brands like Vacheron Constantin, Franck Muller, and Bvlgari celebrating notable achievements and milestones.

site_title: Didi's US exit shows Xi is the ultimate arbiter for China's companies
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has asserted his control over the country's companies, with Didi Chuxing announcing it will list in Hong Kong after the US pulled its listing plans due to regulatory crackdowns. This move signals Xi's ability to dictate where Chinese companies go public, rather than US politicians or market forces. The decision comes as Xi tightens his grip on the private sector, following a national security law in Hong Kong and a crackdown on dissent. Didi's move is seen as a sign that Xi is the ultimate arbiter of China's corporate champions, following a path set by predecessors like Alibaba and Sina Weibo.

site_title: Who owns a recipe? A plagiarism claim has cookbook authors asking
summary: A plagiarism claim has sparked a debate among cookbook authors about recipe ownership. US copyright law does not protect recipes as creative works, making it difficult for authors to claim ownership. However, some argue that introductions, photography, and design can be copyrighted. A recent case involving cookbook author Elizabeth Haigh, who allegedly plagiarized recipes from Sharon Wee, has reignited the debate. Many cookbook authors feel vulnerable to recipe theft, particularly those documenting traditional recipes from minority cultures. The lack of a powerful lobby to push for individual recipe copyright has led some authors to consider hoarding knowledge to protect their work.

site_title: Making fitness a priority
summary: A Singaporean man, Jimmy Tiu, credits running as a key aspect of his fitness routine, which he started in 2013 to stay fit for his wife. He aims to cover 4-10 km per run, often pushing himself to surpass previous records. Despite the pandemic, Tiu continued to prioritize exercise, even working from home. He emphasizes the importance of making time for fitness and advocates for prevention over cure. Tiu's running has given him a sense of achievement and allows him to stay healthy for quality time with loved ones.

site_title: 766 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; ICU utilisation rate up slightly at 57.3%
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore reported 766 new Covid-19 cases on December 3, down from 1,101 the previous day. The ICU utilisation rate increased to 57.3%, with 9 deaths attributed to Covid-19 complications. The total number of fatalities in Singapore now stands at 744. The new cases include 738 in the community, 11 in migrant worker dormitories, and 17 imported cases, bringing the total to 267,916.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as weak jobs growth eases aggressive taper bets
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Friday, easing concerns about the Federal Reserve's quicker tightening of monetary policy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 52.99 points, or 0.15%, to 34,692.78. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 up 12.39 points, or 0.27%, and the Nasdaq up 47.39 points, or 0.31%. Weaker-than-expected US jobs growth eased fears of aggressive taper bets, allowing stocks to climb higher.

site_title: Evergrande's Hui summoned by Guangdong government
summary: China Evergrande Group Chairman Hui Ka Yan was summoned by the Guangdong government after the troubled property developer announced plans to work with creditors on a restructuring plan for its offshore debt. The company warned of a high risk of default, given its over $300 billion in liabilities. Authorities have begun laying the groundwork for a debt restructuring, assembling accounting and legal experts to examine the company's finances. The move comes amid concerns over the impact on China's economy, which is struggling to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: US payroll growth slowed in November while jobless rate fell
summary: US job growth slowed in November with a 210,000 increase in nonfarm payrolls, the smallest gain this year. The unemployment rate fell to 4.2%, lower than forecast. Job growth was slower across industries, including declines at automakers and retail outlets. The household survey showed robust job growth, while the labor force participation rate edged up to 61.8%. The jobs report offers a mixed picture of labor market progress, with potential restrictions due to the Omicron variant.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Moody's Investors Service upgraded Grab Holdings' corporate family rating to "B2" following its public listing, citing improved liquidity and financial flexibility. The rating upgrade also upgraded Grab's senior secured term loan to "B2" and changed the outlook to "stable". Grab's public listing added $4.4 billion to its cash liquidity. Meanwhile, Digilife Technologies proposed to divest its 90% stake in loss-making Singapore Electric Vehicles due to adverse business conditions caused by travel restrictions.

site_title: Shakespearean actor Antony Sher dies aged 72
summary: Award-winning theatre and film actor Antony Sher, 72, has died after a battle with cancer, according to the Royal Shakespeare Company. Sher, known for his portrayal of Shakespearean roles, won an Olivier Award in 1985 and was praised by Prince Charles as his favorite actor. He was in successful movies such as "Shakespeare In Love" and was part of a pioneering gay couple in Britain. The RSC described him as "beloved" and "a hugely celebrated career on stage and screen."

site_title: Moody's raises Grab's ratings to 'B2' on Nasdaq debut
summary: Moody's Investors Service upgraded Grab Holdings' corporate family rating from 'B3' to 'B2' following its Nasdaq debut, citing improved liquidity and financial flexibility. The rating upgrade also reflects the elimination of redemption risk from its convertible redeemable preference shares. Grab's public listing added US$4.4 billion to its cash liquidity, providing greater financial flexibility for growth. However, the company's rating remains constrained by investment, execution, and governance risks, with Moody's considering further upgrades if Grab turns profitable and maintains robust liquidity.

site_title: Brace yourself for the stormiest Huracan
summary: The Lamborghini Huracan STO is a high-performance racing car designed for the road, boasting a Super Trofeo Omologata (STO) badge. With a 5.2-litre V10 engine producing 600 horsepower, it accelerates from 0-100km/h in 3 seconds and features advanced aerodynamics. The car's design is aggressive, with a rear wing, slots, and louvres to optimize airflow. Its handling is sharp and responsive, making it a thrill to drive. Despite its racing heritage, the STO lacks refinement, prioritizing performance over comfort.

site_title: Hundreds of telecoms towers downed in Myanmar coup resistance
summary: More than 400 telecom towers in Myanmar have been destroyed by opponents of the military coup, severing connectivity for many customers. The attacks, claimed by militias allied with a shadow Myanmar government, aim to undermine the government's administrative machinery. The military has previously shut down the internet in many areas, and 88% of the destroyed towers are owned by Mytel, a partly army-controlled firm. The destruction of the towers is part of a broader crackdown by the military, which has killed over 1,300 people and arrested thousands since the coup in February.

site_title: About the new variant Omicron
summary: The Omicron variant, first detected in Botswana on Nov 11, has spread globally, prompting governments to implement new measures. The World Health Organisation has declared Omicron a Variant of Concern, citing over 30 mutations in the spike protein, which may impact transmissibility and severity. While some countries, like Japan and Israel, have imposed travel bans, others, such as Singapore, are taking a more cautious approach. Early data suggests Omicron may be displacing Delta in South Africa, but it's unclear if it will cause severe disease or trigger another wave of infection.

site_title: WHO has no reports yet of Omicron Covid deaths
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported no deaths related to the Omicron variant of Covid-19, despite a growing number of countries registering Omicron infections. The WHO is collecting evidence and expects to find more cases and potentially deaths as countries continue to test and monitor the variant. The dominant variant remains Delta, and restrictions in place are primarily aimed at controlling Delta cases, which account for 99.8% of uploaded sequences. The WHO expects several weeks to assess the transmissibility and disease severity of Omicron.

site_title: China looks to ease monetary policy to help smaller firms
summary: China plans to cut the reserve requirement ratio for banks to aid smaller firms, according to Premier Li Keqiang. This move aims to increase support for the real economy, particularly for small and medium-sized companies, to ensure stability and health. The exact timing of the reduction was not specified. China will continue to implement prudent monetary policy, keeping liquidity reasonably ample and making policies based on market needs.

site_title: Daily ART tests for all VTL travellers; seven more countries added to high-risk category
summary: Singapore has tightened its border measures in response to the new Omicron variant of the coronavirus. Starting December 6, seven countries will be added to the high-risk category, requiring daily testing for all Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTL) travellers. Long-term pass holders and short-term visitors from Ghana, Malawi, and Nigeria within the last 14 days will not be allowed to enter, transfer, or transit through Singapore. VTL travellers will undergo daily Antigen Rapid Tests (ART) for seven days, with supervised tests on the third and seventh days.

site_title: China Tech rout deepens to US$1.5t as Didi starts US delisting
summary: Chinese tech shares plummeted 1.5% in Hong Kong, reaching record lows, amid Didi Global's decision to delist from US exchanges. The move, prompted by US regulators' new law requiring foreign companies to open their books to American scrutiny, is expected to pressure Chinese firms' share prices. The combined market value of Chinese tech firms traded in Hong Kong has evaporated about $1.5 trillion since February. Analysts predict a potential reset in valuation expectations for Hong Kong-listed Chinese equities.

site_title: Sri Lanka suspends cooking gas cylinder sales over mystery explosions
summary: Sri Lanka has suspended the distribution of all gas cylinders amid a surge in unexplained cooking gas explosions and fires, with 60 reported incidents as of Thursday. The government, citing safety concerns, has ordered gas companies to add ethyl mercaptan to cylinders to detect leaks. State-run Litro gas and Laugfs Gas have been notified of the suspension, which will remain in place until the companies complete the process. The government will also conduct sample testing on future shipments and return any stocks not meeting local standards.

site_title: Astra sinks Advent's US$7.6b buyout of Biotech
summary: Private equity firms Advent International and GIC dropped their US$7.6 billion bid to buy Swedish Orphan Biovitrum due to insufficient shareholder acceptance, with only 87% tendering their shares. The bid was conditional on 90% acceptance, and the company faces price pressure and debt from recent acquisitions. AstraZeneca, which holds an 8.1% stake in Sobi, remained silent on the offer. The bid ultimately fell through, leaving Sobi's future uncertain.

site_title: UK study finds mRNA Covid-19 vaccines provide biggest booster impact
summary: A UK study found that mRNA Covid-19 vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna provide the biggest booster impact, with six of seven boosters enhancing immunity after initial vaccination with Pfizer-BioNTech's vaccine and all seven increasing immunity after two doses of AstraZeneca's vaccine. The study supports the decision to bring forward booster doses to 3 months after the second vaccination, and booster shots also helped generate a broad T-cell response against the Beta and Delta variants.

site_title: Oil rises as Opec+ poised to act if demand weakens
summary: Oil prices rose 2.7% on Friday after Opec+ said it could review its production hike policy if oil demand weakens due to rising lockdowns. Brent crude futures rose to $71.58 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $68.23 a barrel. Opec+ stuck to plans to add 400,000 barrels per day in January, but left room for change if demand is affected by the Omicron variant. Despite concerns, global mobility data shows demand is recovering, averaging 93% of 2019 levels.

site_title: DBS chief apologises for recent banking services outage, review being done
summary: DBS Group Holdings' chief Piyush Gupta apologized for the recent 2-day tech disruption that left customers unable to access digital banking services. The issue was caused by a problem with access control servers, not a cyberattack. The bank is reviewing its processes and cooperating with the Monetary Authority of Singapore, which described the disruption as "serious." The regulator will consider supervisory actions following a thorough investigation into the root causes of the issue. DBS services returned to normal on November 25, although some customers experienced problems.

site_title: Lagarde says 2022 hike unlikely but will act on prices if needed
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated that a 2022 interest rate hike is unlikely, but the ECB will act on prices if necessary. Lagarde expressed uncertainty about long-term commitments due to the economy's current state. The ECB plans to decide on stimulus measures on December 16, with its pandemic bond-buying program set to expire at the end of March.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with small loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed slightly lower on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.09% to 23,766.69, weighed down by tech firms. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.94%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 0.71%. Concerns about Omicron eased, allowing traders to pare an early sell-off.

site_title: Singapore public offer of Digital Core Reit IPO is 16.1 times subscribed
summary: Singapore public offer of Digital Core Reit IPO was 16.1 times subscribed, exceeding expectations. The offer saw 10,736 valid applications for 214.8 million units at US$0.88 per piece. The international placement tranche was about 19.6 times subscribed. This strong demand indicates a positive reception of the company's initial public offering (IPO).

site_title: Hong Lai Huat to dual-list on Frankfurt bourse
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group, a Singapore-based property developer, is set to list on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (FSE) after receiving regulatory approval for a dual listing. The move will allow the company to reach a broader audience and access international investors without issuing new shares. Hong Lai Huat's primary listing will remain on the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange. The dual listing is expected to commence the following week.

site_title: Digilife Tech to sell 90% stake in loss-making EV firm for S$2.5m
summary: Digilife Tech proposes to sell 90% stake in loss-making Singapore Electric Vehicles (SEV) to SEV Holding for S$2.5 million, aiming to "re-strategise" its financial and capital resources. The EV fleet business was adversely affected in 2020 due to travel restrictions, resulting in a net loss of S$324,595 as of end-June. The deal is seen as an opportunity to monetise underperforming assets, streamline existing businesses, and focus on core operations, with the net proceeds used for working capital and future business expansions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Entities linked to Chip Eng Seng and SingHaiyi submitted a S$650m bid for the Peace Centre, a Singaporean property. Retail sales in Singapore rose 7.5% in October, despite still being below pre-pandemic levels. CICT entered the Australian market with a A$330.7m acquisition. LMG Marin won a contract to design the world's first zero-emission fuel tanker. The SGX committee fined Tee International and its former executives for breaching rules, including failing to disclose information on transactions. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% higher on Friday.

site_title: China's Kaisa starts talks with bondholders as default threat looms
summary: China's Kaisa Group Holdings begins talks with offshore bondholders to extend the deadline for a $400 million debt repayment due December 7, amid a risk of default. The company has failed to secure 95% approval for an exchange offer of its 6.5% offshore bonds. A group of bondholders has offered extra time to negotiate repayment and provided $2 billion in fresh funding, but major progress has not been made. Shares of Kaisa slipped 8.82% on Friday, taking the stock's decline this year to around 75%.

site_title: En bloc die-hard Peace Centre finally nails it with S$650m deal
summary: Chip Eng Seng, a SingHaiyi joint venture, and Ultra Infinity have made a joint S$650 million bid for the combined development of Peace Centre and Peace Mansion through a private treaty, marking the largest collective sale this year. The joint offerors, led by Chip Eng Seng, have secured a 40% stake, while the remaining 2 parties hold 30% each. The deal is subject to various approvals, including a sale order, lease top-up approval, and planning criteria. This marks the fifth attempt by the Peace Centre's collective sale committee to find a buyer, with the owners initially expecting offers in excess of S$650 million.

site_title: Hong Kong court finds former bourse executive not guilty of graft
summary: A Hong Kong court has found former stock exchange executive Eugene Yeoh not guilty of receiving bribes to favorably review listing applications. IPO consultant Richard Lum was also found not guilty, despite being accused of paying bribes to Yeoh. The prosecution failed to prove Yeoh was aware of Lum's role in at least 12 IPOs between 2015 and 2019. The verdict marks a significant outcome in a high-profile graft case, with both Yeoh and Lum cleared of wrongdoing.

site_title: Vietnam's VinaCapital weighing Singapore SPAC IPO next year
summary: VinaCapital, a Vietnamese asset manager, is exploring setting up a blank-check company to list in Singapore next year, with potential earnings of up to S$250 million. The company, which manages $3.7 billion in assets, has held discussions with regulators on the proposed initial public offering. This move could benefit Singapore's equities market, which has seen just eight first-time share sales this year, raising $1 billion in total. Several other firms, including Novo Tellus Capital Partners and Quadria Capital, are also considering similar listings.

site_title: Berkshire's Munger says now 'even crazier' than dotcom bust
summary: Berkshire Hathaway's Charlie Munger stated that markets are "even crazier" than the dotcom bust, warning of wild valuations. He expressed disdain for cryptocurrencies, praising China's ban on their use. Munger also advocated for Australia to play a role in bridging the US-China divide. He remains bullish on renewable energy, citing its environmental benefits. Berkshire's cash pile reached $149.2 billion in the third quarter, and Munger expressed confidence in the company's position.

site_title: Sale of standard rail tickets at MRT stations to end by March 2022
summary: The Singapore Land Transport Authority (LTA) will phase out the sale of standard rail tickets at MRT stations between January and March 2022. The move follows low usage, with fewer than one in 1,000 trips paid using standard tickets since 1987. Standard tickets will be replaced by stored value cards or account-based ticketing options, offering commuters more savings and convenience. The LTA has also reduced the minimum top-up amount for stored value cards to $2, allowing commuters with limited cash to continue their journeys.

site_title: Singapore stocks cap off volatile week in the black; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks closed the week in the black, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.3% to 3,101.93 points. The STI edged up 9.82 points, driven by Sats, which gained 2.6%, and UOB, which rose 0.5%. The US markets had an overnight rally, with the S&P 500 climbing 1.4% and the Nasdaq rising 0.8%. Markets in Asia took a wait-and-see approach, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi also showing gains, while Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index fell 0.7%.

site_title: Indian doctors strike as Omicron sparks fears of third wave of Covid-19
summary: India reported 9,216 new Covid-19 infections on Friday, with the detection of the Omicron variant in one person raising concerns of a third wave. Resident doctors in groups across the country are striking non-critical work to demand new post-graduate students be enrolled to boost staffing. With India's healthcare sector already strained due to a record second surge in infections and deaths, the situation is described as "disastrous" by the Federation of Resident Doctors' Association of India. The country has seen new cases plateauing around 10,000 in recent weeks.

site_title: Europe: Equities move higher at open
summary: European stock markets rose on Friday, driven by easing Omicron concerns and gains in Asian markets. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.5%, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 rose 0.8%. The gains followed easing Omicron concerns ahead of key US data, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index recovered from early losses and closed higher, rising 1.00% or 276.20 points to 28,029.57, as investors bought back shares following recent declines. The broader Topix index gained 1.63% or 31.49 points to 1,957.86. This recovery comes as investors look to bargain-hunting opportunities in the market.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as Omicron shock eases; set for fourth weekly loss
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P ASX 200 index rose 0.33% to 7,249.1, as the Omicron variant's initial shock eased, leading to a fourth weekly loss. Heavyweight miners, such as BHP Group and Rio Tinto, surged 1.9-3.5%, while banks and oil stocks also gained. However, gold stocks declined 2.1% due to concerns over US interest rate hikes. The index is set to lose 0.6% for the week.

site_title: Brokers' Take: DBS raises TP for Far East Hospitality Trust to S$0.78 on Central Square divestment
summary: DBS Group Research raised its target price for Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) to S$0.78 from S$0.70 due to the potential divestment of Central Square for S$313.2 million. Analysts believe this sale will unlock value for unitholders, minimize income drag, and free up capital for further acquisitions. The divestment is expected to result in a lower gearing ratio and increased debt headroom, providing significant firepower for the Reit. The analysts maintain a "buy" rating, citing attractive earnings floor and distribution growth.

images.alt_text: The DBS analysts believe that the market has not priced in the sale of the Central Square - which accounts for 8 per cent of its assets - and expect the transacted price, at about 58 per cent premium to net asset value, to be a key catalyst for the stock.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post best weekly jump in 7; US data, Omicron in focus
summary: South Korean stocks posted their largest weekly jump in 7 years, closing up 0.78% at 2,968.33, driven by foreign and institutional buying. Gains were capped ahead of US payrolls data and concerns over the Omicron variant. The benchmark bond yield rose, while the won ended lower with its sharpest weekly gain since mid-February.

site_title: Washington wants to restrict exports of surveillance tech used in rights abuses
summary: The US is launching an Export Control and Human Rights Initiative to restrict exports of surveillance technologies used in human rights abuses. The initiative, to be discussed at President Biden's democracy summit, aims to work with allies to monitor and restrict the proliferation of such technologies. The US has already taken steps to prevent China and Myanmar from using American technologies for suppression, and has blacklisted Israeli companies for their role in human rights abuses. The initiative will develop a non-binding code of conduct to guide export licensing policy and practice, and involves many signatories to the Wassenaar Arrangement.

site_title: WHO tells Asia-Pacific to brace for Omicron as variant spreads
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned Asia-Pacific countries to prepare for a surge in Covid-19 cases due to the spread of the Omicron variant, despite travel curbs. The region, home to 650 million people, has seen cases reported in India, Japan, Malaysia, Singapore, and South Korea. Many governments have tightened travel rules, but the WHO stresses that border controls can only buy time. Vaccination rates vary, with Indonesia fully inoculating only 35% of its population, and some countries are considering booster shots, but their effectiveness is uncertain.

site_title: China easing rules for US business travellers, approvals in 10 days
summary: China has announced it will reduce approval time for US business travelers to 10 working days, a move aimed at addressing US concerns about resuming business travel. The decision, made by China's Ambassador to the US Qin Gang, also includes efforts to make COVID-19 testing more convenient and allow executives to work during quarantine. Beijing is working to upgrade "fast track" travel arrangements, following a meeting between President Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden. The move is seen as a positive step in strengthening cooperation between the two countries.

site_title: Didi's 44% slump makes it biggest China IPO loser in US
summary: Didi Chuxing, a Chinese ride-sharing company, has seen its US shares slump by 44% since its initial public offering in June, making it the biggest Chinese IPO loser in the US. The company is set to delist its US shares and will start work on a Hong Kong share sale, with plans to file for the listing around March. Approximately 36% of Didi's outstanding shares were sold short, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: Citigroup applies for China securities licence
summary: Citigroup has applied for a securities licence in China, aiming to expand its presence in the world's second-largest economy. The bank submitted its application to the China Securities and Regulatory Commission and plans to hire around 100 people in mainland China in the next two years. Citigroup is also seeking a futures licence in the coming months, following a recent report by the Wall Street Journal. The move is part of the bank's efforts to increase its onshore presence in China.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as Omicron, Federal Reserve taper keep traders on edge
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Friday as traders reacted to the spread of the Omicron virus and the Federal Reserve's plan to withdraw pandemic-era financial support. Hong Kong fell over 1% after US officials adopted a rule targeting Chinese tech firms, while Shanghai rose. Global markets have whipsawed since Omicron emerged, with experts warning it could take weeks to assess its economic impact. The Federal Reserve is preparing to tighten its belt, with Jerome Powell suggesting a faster taper of bond-buying and higher borrowing costs.

site_title: Musk sells Tesla shares worth US$1.01b: filings
summary: Elon Musk sold 934,091 Tesla shares worth US$1.01 billion, as well as exercised stock options to buy 2.1 million shares. This transaction brings Musk's total Tesla share sales to over US$5 billion since 2021. The filings were made public in US securities.

site_title: Rerserve Bank of Australia to start tightening in early 2023: economists
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to raise interest rates in early 2023, with 16 economists predicting at least one rate hike by the end of the first quarter of 2023. Economists forecast a cash rate of 0.50% by the end of 2023, with markets already pricing in a first rate hike as early as July 2022. The RBA's decision is driven by rising inflation, with core inflation expected to reach 2.5% and wage growth at 3% in 2023.

site_title: US sues to block chipmaker Nvidia's US$40b merger with UK's Arm
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is suing to block Nvidia's $40 billion merger with UK's Arm due to concerns it would undermine competition in the computer chip industry. The FTC claims the deal would give Nvidia control over critical infrastructure, leading to higher prices and stifling innovation. The move comes as the world faces a global semiconductor shortage, with President Joe Biden launching efforts to boost domestic chip production. Nvidia has offered a subdued initial reaction, stating it will continue to work to demonstrate the transaction will benefit the industry and promote competition.

site_title: China's Nov services activity expands at slower clip: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector expanded at a slower pace in November, with the Caixin/Markit services PMI falling to 52.1 from 53.8 in October. Rising inflationary pressures and small-scale Covid-19 outbreaks contributed to the slowdown. The sector's growth remains above the 50-point mark, but analysts warn of potential challenges ahead, including margin pressures and weak consumer purchasing power. Policymakers are urged to support small and midsize enterprises and address high cost pressures.

site_title: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi to de-list from NYSE
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing will de-list from the New York stock exchange following US regulators' adoption of a rule allowing foreign firms to be removed. The move comes after a Chinese regulatory crackdown and months after Didi's IPO, which was overshadowed by a cybersecurity investigation. The company has faced significant challenges, including its app being ordered off app stores and government inspections. Didi will start the process of de-listing from the NYSE and prepare for a potential listing in Hong Kong.

site_title: Singapore's retail sales up 7.5% in October on handset launches; still below pre-pandemic levels
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 7.5% year-over-year in October, driven by mobile phone sales, to S$3.6 billion. Online sales accounted for 15.2% of total sales, still below pre-Covid levels. This marks a slight improvement from the previous month's 6.8% growth and 0.7% month-on-month increase.

site_title: SGX committee raps Tee International and its former C-suite execs for breaching rules
summary: The Listings Disciplinary Committee (LDC) of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) has publicly reprimanded Tee International, its former executive director and group chief executive Phua Chian Kin, and former group chief financial officer Yeo Ai Mei for breaching mainboard listing rules. The breaches occurred due to unauthorised remittances and failure to disclose required information in the company's annual report. Phua used the remittances to settle personal debts, while Yeo failed to ensure compliance with mainboard rules. The reprimands were issued as both parties did not contest their liabilities.

site_title: Sembmarine unit LMG Marin wins contract to design world's first zero-emission fuel tanker
summary: Sembmarine's wholly-owned subsidiary LMG Marin has won a contract to design the world's first zero-emission fuel tanker, a green ammonia-fuelled vessel, for Grieg Edge. The tanker will transport green ammonia from a Norwegian facility to Svalbard from 2024, replacing coal-fired power. The contract comes after Sembmarine rebalanced its product solutions portfolio with a focus on renewables since 2015. The zero-emission vessel is part of the group's commitment to reduce shipping greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 and enhance Singapore's status as a major marine fuel bunkering hub.

site_title: Gold heads for weekly fall on hawkish Fed talk
summary: Gold prices are set for a third consecutive weekly drop, down 1.3% this week, amid signals from the Federal Reserve that it may end its pandemic-era asset purchases and raise interest rates faster to combat inflation. US Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic suggested ending bond-buying by March, while US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen emphasized the Fed's need to combat inflation without a "wage-price spiral". This could lead to higher interest rates, increasing the opportunity cost of non-interest bearing gold.

site_title: OECD urges Japan to keep fiscal, monetary support for economy
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has urged Japan to maintain its expansive fiscal and monetary support for the economy until its recovery from the pandemic is on track. The OECD suggests that if the Bank of Japan's monetary policy succeeds in bringing inflation to its 2% target, it may lead to higher interest rates and trigger fiscal consolidation. The OECD recommends continuing fiscal support in the near term, with fiscal consolidation efforts resuming only once the recovery is secure to ensure long-run sustainability.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.48% lower on Friday, December 3, 2021, after two days of gains, amid concerns over the spread of the Omicron variant globally. The Hang Seng Index fell 113.67 points to 23,675.26. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index increased marginally. The decline follows a global trend, with US stocks also falling despite reaching fresh records due to US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens lower with US jobs data in focus
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.14% lower, down 38.23 points, after a Wall Street rebound, with investors focusing on US jobs data due later. The Topix index edged up 0.14% in early trade. The US jobs data is expected to impact investor sentiment and could influence Asian markets.

site_title: Grab founder's stake sheds billion-dollar mark after shares sink 20.5% by debut close
summary: Grab co-founder Anthony Tan's stake lost its billion-dollar mark after the company's debut on the Nasdaq with a 20.5% share price drop to US$8.75. Tan's US$1.1 billion stake and co-founder Tan Hooi Ling's US$333.7 million stake were significantly reduced. The plunge wiped out US$17 billion of Grab's market value, leaving its market cap at US$34.5 billion. The drastic decline followed Grab's opening price of US$13.06.

site_title: US averts government shutdown 1 day ahead of deadline
summary: The US Congress approved a stopgap funding bill, averting a government shutdown with a vote of 69-28 in the Senate. The bill, which had already passed the House, will keep federal agencies running until February 18, 2022. This rare show of cross-party unity ensured a smooth transition into the new year, avoiding a costly shutdown. The agreement was made with the clock ticking down to the 11.59 pm Friday deadline.

images.alt_text: The US Congress approved a stopgap funding bill on Thursday in a rare show of cross-party unity to keep federal agencies running into 2022 and avert a costly holiday season government shutdown.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday's open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% at the open on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping to 3,085.97. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.8% on Wall Street, while European shares fell 1.2% due to Omicron-related restrictions. Local banks UOB and DBS saw gains, while OCBC declined. Tokyo stocks also opened lower, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.1%.

site_title: New US Covid-19 international travel testing rules take effect on Monday
summary: The US has implemented new international travel testing rules, requiring all air travelers to obtain a negative Covid-19 test within one day of travel, starting Monday. This is a tightening of existing rules, which previously allowed vaccinated travelers to present a test taken up to three days prior. The CDC has given airlines a three-day grace period for some travelers to adjust. Temporary exemptions for countries with limited access to same-day testing are being considered, but details are still being finalized.

site_title: Entrepreneur builds business out of teaching his kid Chinese, now Sequoia and Tiger Global are backing it
summary: Entrepreneur Hugh Yao, who relocated to Singapore with his family, noticed his 3-year-old son adopting English as his primary language while neglecting Chinese. Frustrated, Yao began teaching his son Chinese, which eventually led to the launch of his business, 'Chinese for Kids.' The company has gained traction, attracting backing from prominent investors such as Sequoia and Tiger Global. Yao's innovative approach to teaching Chinese to young children has shown promise, and his business is now poised for growth.

site_title: Lyft names Amazon Studios' Elaine Paul as CFO
summary: Lyft has named Elaine Paul, Amazon Studios' CFO and VP, as its new CFO, replacing Brian Roberts who is stepping down after seven years. Paul will take the position starting January 3. The move comes as Lyft and rival Uber attempt to cut costs amid a decline in ridership and drivers due to the pandemic. Roberts will remain as an adviser until June 2022 to assist with the transition. Paul previously worked at Hulu and Walt Disney in senior finance roles, and her appointment is seen as a strategic move for Lyft.

site_title: US clears first hurdle in bid to avert government shutdown
summary: The US House of Representatives voted to keep federal agencies running for 11 weeks, avoiding a government shutdown until February 18. The temporary legislation passed with a Democratic majority, but faces a challenging path in the Senate. The stop-gap measure aims to prevent a costly shutdown, which was set to occur at midnight on Friday.

site_title: Japan's service sector activity expands at fastest pace in 2 years
summary: Japan's services sector activity expanded at the fastest pace in over two years in November, driven by a jump in new business and stronger consumer confidence. The au Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 53.0, marking the fastest expansion since August 2019. Despite increased demand and capacity pressure, staffing levels decreased for the first time since July. Stronger spending on services, including dining out and overnight stays, could support Japan's economy amidst ongoing challenges such as a global chip shortage and rising raw material costs.

site_title: China gives long-awaited approval to Boeing 737 MAX after crashes
summary: China's Civil Aviation Administration (CAAC) approved the Boeing 737 MAX to resume service, clearing the way for the plane to return to airline schedules in China in 2022. The decision comes after months of negotiations between Boeing and Chinese authorities, and paves the way for the delivery of over 100 MAX aircraft to Chinese carriers. The CAAC's approval also confirms Boeing's place in China, a key growth market in aviation, despite ongoing trade and political tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Q&M unit's PCR tests can detect Omicron variant
summary: Q&M Dental Group announced that its PCR test kits, developed by Acumen Diagnostics, can detect Omicron, a new Covid-19 variant. The locally manufactured kits, Acu-Corona 2.0 and Acu-Corona Duplex, can also detect the Delta variant. This allows for quicker and more efficient deployment of the tests, highlighting Q&M's cost-effectiveness and self-sufficiency compared to imported peers.

site_title: CICT enters Australia market with acquisition of 2 office buildings for A$330.7m
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) has acquired two office buildings in Sydney, Australia for A$330.7 million (S$330.7 million), its first entry into the Australian market. The acquisition, expected to be completed in Q1 2022, will increase CICT's portfolio value by 3% to S$22.4 billion, with 93% of the enlarged portfolio based in Singapore. The move aims to diversify CICT's income stream and provide opportunities for growth in the Australian market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, City Developments Limited, FLCT, SPH, Keppel, HPL
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) and City Developments Limited (CDL) saw developments affecting their securities. CICT's subsidiary acquired 2 Grade A office buildings in Sydney for A$330.7 million (S$330.7m). CDL will acquire Central Square from Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) for S$315 million to redevelop into a mixed-use hub. FEHT's units fell 0.9% to S$0.575.

site_title: US appeals court will not block China Telecom revocation order
summary: A US federal appeals court rejected China Telecom Corp's emergency bid to halt a US FCC order revoking its authority to provide services in the US. The FCC had ordered China Telecom to discontinue US services by early January, citing concerns over exploitation and control by the Chinese government. The court will issue a schedule to consider the legal arguments, which is likely to take months. China Telecom warned it would cease significant operations if the FCC action is not temporarily halted. The decision affects China Telecom's 335 million subscribers worldwide and its services to Chinese government facilities in the US.

site_title: FLCT divests leasehold property in Melbourne, Australia for A$42.5m
summary: FLCT divests leasehold property in Melbourne, Australia for A$42.5m, exceeding its book value and initial purchase price. The property, consisting of 2 industrial buildings, will provide the Reit with greater financial strength and flexibility. Net proceeds of A$38.5m may be used to fund potential acquisitions, reduce debt, or for other corporate purposes. The divestment is expected to be completed by the first half of 2022, with units of FLCT closing at S$1.45 on Dec 2, down 2% from the previous day.

site_title: Kaisa bondholders reject Chinese developer's debt swap proposal
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings failed to secure approval from bondholders for a debt swap proposal aimed at avoiding default. The company sought to exchange US$400 million of dollar notes due December 7 for new ones due 18 months later, but the offer fell short of the required 95% approval rate. This failure puts Kaisa at risk of reneging on its obligations, which could lead to a contagion risk in the offshore property bond market. Kaisa has vowed to explore feasible solutions, including asset disposal and debt restructuring, to address its liquidity issue.

site_title: Jewellery magic
summary: Gucci's latest high jewellery collection, Hortus Deliciarum, is an extravagant ode to nature's beauty, featuring 130-plus one-of-a-kind pieces inspired by elements of Mother Nature. The collection, designed by Alessandro Michele, is divided into four chapters, each representing a different aspect of nature: landscapes, sunset skies, rose gardens, and the animal kingdom. The collection showcases bold, lavish jewellery with symbolic motifs, opals, diamonds, and other precious gems, offering a grand farewell to a lacklustre year and a welcome to a better one.

site_title: Facebook inks largest private sector US office lease of 2021
summary: Facebook, now known as Meta Platforms, has signed the largest private sector US office lease of 2021, occupying a 719,000 square foot site in Sunnyvale, California, and a nearby 280,000 square foot site in Burlingame. The leases bring the total new space to over 1 million square feet. The move aims to reduce employee commute times and support public transit, with employees expected to spend about half their time in offices starting next year.

site_title: Oil ends higher after a day of wild swings on Opec, Omicron
summary: Oil prices rose 1-2% on Thursday after Opec+ stuck to its plan to boost output slowly, surprising markets. Brent crude futures settled 1.2% higher at $69.67 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures rose 1.4% to $66.50. The decision comes after a wild swing in prices, with crude losing 24% in the last three weeks due to uncertainty over the Omicron variant and supply concerns. Opec+ aims to add 400,000 barrels per day to its target in January, sending a signal of confidence that prices have been overdone.

site_title: US adopts rule that could see Chinese firms leave Wall Street
summary: US market regulators have adopted a rule allowing them to delist foreign companies, primarily Chinese firms, from Wall Street exchanges if they fail to provide information to auditors. The rule requires companies to disclose if they're "owned or controlled" by a government. This comes after Congress passed a law targeting Chinese companies, requiring the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board to inspect audits of foreign firms listed on US markets. Beijing has refused to allow PCAOB inspections, affecting about 220 firms, and has asked Chinese companies to withdraw from US indices.

site_title: 'Game changer': Laos opens Chinese-built railway line
summary: Laos has officially opened a US$6 billion Chinese-built railway line, spanning 414 km, connecting the cities of Kunming and Vientiane. The project, part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, aims to boost Laos' economy, but analysts have raised concerns about the country's ability to pay its US$1.06 billion debt. The railway, which includes high-speed rail and state-of-the-art infrastructure, is expected to have a significant impact on Laos' economy, but its long-term viability remains uncertain.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall as Omicron worries rattle investors
summary: European stocks fell over 1% on Thursday, as Omicron coronavirus variant concerns led to increased restrictions and worries about economic recovery. The Stoxx 600 closed down 1.2%, with travel and leisure shares suffering the most. Tech stocks, including semiconductor companies, declined due to a report on slowing iPhone 13 demand. Despite this, mining and healthcare stocks were among the biggest gainers. The continent's equity benchmark remains 5% away from record highs, with investors awaiting clarity on the variant's impact.

site_title: Bankers' quest for more money and power
summary: Goldman Sachs' CEO David Solomon and senior leaders are seeking ways to boost their eight-digit pay packages in today's era of hyper-wealth creation. They've explored ideas such as investing in the bank's SPACs and proposing big raises and incentive packages for 2022. The push for higher pay comes as the bank's trainees are being rewarded with significant bonuses, putting pressure on senior leaders to keep up. The efforts aim to maintain their status and power in the competitive banking world.

site_title: South Korea's inflation hits decade high, boosting rate hike views
summary: South Korea's consumer inflation surged to a decade high in November, reaching 3.7% and exceeding the central bank's 2% target for an eighth consecutive month. This boost inflationary pressure is fueling expectations of another interest rate hike by the Bank of Korea in January. The Bank of Korea revised its inflation forecast to 2.0% for next year and now expects annual inflation to be above its 2.3% forecast, citing supply chain bottlenecks and strong demand. The central bank also warned that inflation could remain above its target for a considerable time.

site_title: A coco Christmas
summary: Chanel has released four Christmas collections inspired by its iconic founder Coco Chanel. The Coco Crush fine jewellery line features matelassé patterns, while the No 5 collection uses diamonds and white gold to represent Chanel's lucky number and perfume. Additionally, the luxury brand has rewritten the rules of watchmaking, and Louis Vuitton debuted its watch collection at LVMH Watch Week.

site_title: Kamala Harris' spokeswoman quits as VP hits bumpy patch
summary: Kamala Harris' chief spokeswoman, Jen Psaki, will leave her position at the end of the year, amid the vice-president's political turbulence. Psaki cited the grueling nature of the job as a reason for her departure. The move comes as Harris faces internal tensions and strained relations with President Joe Biden's team. Harris expressed her support for Psaki, saying she would always be part of the Biden-Harris family. The vice-president's future in the White House has been a subject of speculation, with some commentators questioning her place in the administration.

site_title: Reinfections three times more likely with Omicron: South African research
summary: A preliminary South African study suggests that the Omicron variant is three times more likely to cause reinfections compared to the Delta or Beta strains, providing the first epidemiological evidence of its ability to evade immunity from prior infection.

site_title: China advisers to recommend lower 2022 GDP target as headwinds grow: sources
summary: China's government advisers are set to recommend a lower 2022 GDP target, ranging from 5% to 5.5%, amid growing challenges to the economy, including a property downturn and strict Covid-19 curbs. This is a decrease from the "above 6%" target set for 2021. The recommendations come ahead of the annual Central Economic Work Conference, where policymakers are expected to boost monetary and fiscal support to help the slowing economy.

site_title: Business travel could rebound in 2022, despite Omicron factor
summary: Business travel may rebound in 2022 despite the Omicron variant, with corporate travel operators seeing a rise in bookings and enquiries. Singapore's quarantine-free Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) and the reopening of Western borders have sparked optimism. Analysts expect firms to have more conservative travel budgets, resulting in lower fare premiums compared to pre-pandemic levels. This suggests a potential return to business travel, driven by the need for in-person meetings and customer engagement.

site_title: US: Stocks end solidly higher after two negative sessions
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, ending a two-session decline, as markets recovered from concerns over a coronavirus variant and a potential US government shutdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.8% to 34,639.79. Despite two negative sessions, major indices spent most of the session in positive territory, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records. Market experts attribute the rally to a period of weakness over the last couple of weeks, with Terry Sandven stating that the market is "rallying today after a period of weakness."

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SP Group and Banpu Next have partnered to develop sustainable energy and smart-city solutions in Thailand and the Asia-Pacific region. They will explore district cooling systems, cross-border renewable energy certificates, and smart-city solutions to support sustainable and smart-energy cities. This collaboration aims to drive urban decarbonization efforts in the region, contributing to a more environmentally friendly and efficient urban landscape.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific to launch Mori at an estimated average price of S$1,900 psf
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings will launch its freehold condominium Mori on Dec 4 with an estimated average price of S$1,900 per square foot (psf). The 137-unit project, located in District 14, features 2 residential blocks and an outdoor onsen. Prices start from S$1,680 psf, with the aim of achieving an average psf price of S$1,900. Mori is expected to achieve its Temporary Occupation Permit in 2026.

site_title: Ion Mobility launches Singapore's first electric motorcycle
summary: Ion Mobility, a Singaporean startup, has launched the Mobius, the country's first electric motorcycle, set to be sold in Indonesia in the first half of 2022. The battery-powered bike will be produced in China, Indonesia, and Singapore, with plans to assemble 1,500 units per month by the end of 2022. CEO James Chan aims to expand the company's presence in Southeast Asia and beyond, targeting 200 million combustion motorcycles ripe for displacement by a zero-emissions model.

site_title: Britain approves new rules to boost London as global listing centre
summary: Britain's markets watchdog is introducing new rules to boost London's role as a global listing centre, catching up with New York and EU financial hubs. The revised listings rules allow a targeted form of dual class share structures, increasing investor protections. Minimum public float requirements decrease to 10% from 25%, and market capitalisation thresholds rise to £30 million from £700,000. The changes aim to attract more tech company listings and support economic growth, while maintaining investor protections.

site_title: Asean needs to come together on efforts to develop carbon pricing systems, offset markets: report
summary: Asean nations need to collaborate on developing carbon pricing systems and offset markets to meet their decarbonization goals, according to a report by the Singapore Institute of International Affairs (SIIA). The region's current reliance on fossil fuels and differing carbon pricing policies pose a risk of carbon leakage, which could lead to increased emissions in countries with less stringent measures. SIIA recommends that Asean countries work together to establish a regional carbon price and coordinate their efforts to advance a low-carbon economy, while also addressing operational and reputational issues in carbon markets.

site_title: Record volumes at LA ports to become 'new normal' after crisis
summary: The Port of Long Beach and its neighboring port of Los Angeles have set a record for cargo volume, with 20 million 20-foot equivalent units expected to move this year. This is likely to become the new normal due to high consumer demand for goods. Despite efforts to ease congestion, long delays persist, with 49 container vessels anchored off the southern California coast. However, a new queuing system and incentives, such as reduced shipping fees and penalties for delayed containers, are helping to improve the situation.

site_title: Delivery, ride-hailing firms fight EU plan for gig workers
summary: European companies that operate food delivery and ride-hailing apps, such as Uber and Deliveroo, are concerned about a proposed EU plan that could classify gig workers as employees rather than self-employed individuals. The draft proposal, seen by Bloomberg, would apply to companies controlling digital workers' performance and communication with customers. If implemented, it would likely impact companies' labor costs and business models, with Uber, Deliveroo, and Bolt being particularly affected. The EU plan aims to bolster labor rights for gig workers.

site_title: Uber to allow users to book rides via WhatsApp in India
summary: Uber to launch a feature allowing users in India to book rides via WhatsApp, expanding its services to the platform's 500 million user base. The new service will enable users to book rides without needing to download the Uber app, and will offer the same safety features and insurance protections as the existing app. The feature will initially be launched in Lucknow and expanded to other locations by next year, with support for Indian languages to be added in the near future.

site_title: Robotaxis roaming around Yokohama are winning over unlikely fans
summary: Nissan Motor Co. is conducting Japan's largest demonstration of autonomous vehicles in Yokohama, testing its self-driving taxi service in the area near its headquarters. The demonstration is a step toward a commercial robotaxi launch, despite regulatory hurdles and further technology improvements needed. Although a full-scale launch is still years away, Nissan's efforts aim to move forward with its robotaxi service.

site_title: Upskilling in the time of the pandemic
summary: During the pandemic, there has been a significant demand for training and courses aimed at upskilling, particularly in areas such as data science, software engineering, and user experience design. Education providers have responded with various programs, and reskilling and upskilling have become essential for workers and employers to adapt to digitalization. This trend is expected to continue as companies redirect to digitalization and employees rethink their capabilities and capacity.

site_title: US is world's biggest plastic polluter, report finds
summary: The US is the world's largest contributor to global plastic waste, producing around 42 million metric tons in 2016, exceeding China and the European Union combined. On average, every American generates 130kg of plastic waste per year, with a projected 53 million metric tons entering the ocean annually by 2030. The report calls for a national strategy to tackle the crisis, suggesting steps such as reducing virgin plastic production, improving waste management, and using biodegradable materials.

site_title: Cooling the cities of tomorrow in South-east Asia - A shift towards carbon neutrality
