summary: South-east Asia is expected to experience rapid urbanisation, with 70% of the population projected to live in cities by 2050. This will exacerbate the "urban heat island" effect, where buildings shed heat to cool themselves, leading to increased energy demand. The region is already facing significant cooling demands, with a projected 200 GW of additional generation capacity needed in 2040. Climate change is also expected to worsen, with 600-1 billion people in Asia at risk of lethal heat waves by 2050, according to a McKinsey study.

site_title: As global airlines prepare for Omicron volatility, agility will be key
summary: Global airlines are bracing for volatility due to the Omicron coronavirus variant, which may lead to schedule changes, destination adjustments, and a reliance on domestic markets. Fitch Ratings has lowered passenger traffic forecasts for 2021 and 2022, citing the emergence of new variants. Airlines are adapting to the new variant, with some adjusting schedules and others requiring negative Covid-19 tests for international travelers. The impact of Omicron will vary by country and region, with countries with strong domestic markets better shielded from international travel uncertainties.

images.alt_text: United Airlines has launched its Newark- Cape Town route, and Delta Air is expecting strong bookings over the Christmas period.

site_title: A perfect storm awaits businesses as compliance issues continue to mount up
summary: A perfect storm of compliance issues is looming for businesses, exacerbated by the pandemic and prioritizing business survival over internal controls. Many compliance professionals have left their posts, and those remaining face a challenging landscape of complex, interconnected risks, including supply chain disruptions, cyberattacks, and evolving government regulations. The COVID-19 pandemic has introduced new challenges, forcing compliance teams to assess new suppliers and navigate remote work, increasing IT security breaches and cyberattacks. To survive, compliance teams need support and investment, with technology offering hope in streamlining workflows and enabling quick risk flagging.

images.alt_text: The average day for a compliance team will see it stretched in multiple directions, always feeling as if they are playing catch-up and conforming to new rules and regulation. This not only includes compliance with national and international laws and regulations, but also adherence to the company's ethical and moral principles.

site_title: Currency markets calm in 'eye of the storm'
summary: Currency markets experienced a calm day on Thursday as investors awaited news on the Omicron variant and the US Federal Reserve's stimulus tapering. The US dollar edged lower against most rival currencies, while the euro rose 0.2% and sterling rebounded 0.4%. The dollar index fell 0.2% to 95.892, near a 16-month high. Traders await clarity on the Fed's tapering pace, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaling potential swifter action to address inflation concerns.

site_title: Visitors from Singapore to South Korea using VTL spared new 10-day quarantine
summary: South Korea has announced a 10-day quarantine for all arrivals starting Dec 3, but the quarantine-free Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) arrangement with Singapore remains unchanged. Travel agents in Singapore had expressed confusion and concern, but the South Korean embassy clarified that the VTL arrangement would proceed without change. Travel companies, including Chan Brothers Travel, have confirmed that they will proceed with tours to South Korea, citing a high demand for travel despite the new restrictions.

site_title: Reliable Italian cooking at Griglia
summary: Griglia Open Fire Italian Kitchen, a casual eatery on Craig Road in Singapore, offers reliable Italian cooking with a focus on charcoal-grilled dishes. The menu features Mediterranean-inspired options, including a signature set menu for two and à la carte dishes. Standout items include burrata, eggplant, and pappardelle, while the grilled Spanish turbot is a highlight. The restaurant's pleasant ambiance and staff make it a no-brainer to return to, earning a 6.5-star rating.

site_title: Apple tells suppliers iPhone demand has weakened
summary: Apple has informed its component suppliers that iPhone demand has weakened, contrary to the company's initial expectations. This change is attributed to a global supply crunch, which has led some consumers to abandon their attempts to acquire the iPhone 13 line-up. Despite this, Apple remains on track for a record holiday season. The company's revised outlook signals a shift from the originally envisioned blockbuster quarter, but its overall performance is expected to be strong.

site_title: Twitter is again losing Jack Dorsey, its multitasking, wizard-bearded visionary
summary: Twitter co-founder and CEO Jack Dorsey is stepping down, marking the end of an era for the company. Dorsey will remain on Twitter's board until next year. He cited a desire to choose the company over his own ego, but his departure is seen as a reflection of the company's need for a more hands-on leader. Former Twitter CTO Parag Agrawal will take over as CEO, who has worked at the company for 10 years and is regarded as a trusted leader. Twitter's leadership change is part of a trend in major tech companies, where founders are stepping down to make way for more experienced leaders.

site_title: Tel Aviv residents face soaring costs in world's priciest city
summary: Tel Aviv, Israel, has become the world's most expensive city, surpassing Paris, Singapore, Zurich, Hong Kong, and New York, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit's ranking. The city's soaring costs are largely due to the strong Israeli shekel against the US dollar, increased prices for transport and groceries, and a lack of affordable housing options. Residents, including musicians and seniors, struggle to make ends meet, with some opting to live in hostels or avoid luxuries like restaurants. The high cost of living has remained a persistent issue in Tel Aviv, despite past protests and economic measures.

images.alt_text: Tel Aviv is now more expensive than Paris, Singapore, Zurich, Hong Kong and New York, said the Economist Intelligence Unit.

site_title: WHO members agree to begin talks on global pandemic treaty
summary: The World Health Organization's (WHO) member states agreed to establish an intergovernmental negotiating body to negotiate a global pandemic treaty, aiming to strengthen global defenses against pandemics. The treaty is intended to ensure a more coherent and equitable response to future pandemics. However, the US and other countries are pushing for a weaker mechanism without legal obligations for member states. Talks are set to begin by March, with the goal of reaching an international agreement. The treaty's details and scope remain to be determined.

site_title: Alibaba shares are cheapest ever as crackdown wipes off US$526 billion
summary: Alibaba's US-listed shares have hit a record low, with American depositary receipts trading at a multiple of 18.7, the lowest since its 2014 debut. The shares have slumped 4% and 2.5% in Hong Kong, wiping off $526 billion in value over 13 months. Concerns over regulators' scrutiny of growth drivers, including fintech and online advertising, and uncertainty over the future of tech companies using variable interest entities, are contributing to the decline. Analysts are scrambling to adjust their price targets, with the average falling for 18 straight weeks.

site_title: Defiance launches NFT ETF as crypto workaround-funds proliferate
summary: Defiance ETFs launched the Defiance Digital Revolution ETF (NFTZ) to track blockchain-related companies and non-fungible token (NFT) index, as conventional cryptocurrency exchange-traded fund (ETF) approval remains elusive. The new ETF aims to capitalize on the growing trend of cryptocurrency and blockchain investments. With NFTZ, investors can gain exposure to the digital asset market through a traditional ETF, potentially offering more regulatory clarity and accessibility.

site_title: What makes a wine great? It's not one that's just old and complex
summary: A reevaluation of what makes a great wine is underway, moving beyond the traditional notion of complexity and nuance. Greatness in a wine is now defined by its ability to meet the needs of a particular occasion, rather than just being age-worthy. This shift acknowledges that not all great wines are expensive or rare, but rather those that are balanced, refreshing, and evoke a sense of place and culture. Personal experiences with various wines, regardless of their price or reputation, can also be considered great if they evoke memorable moments and convey the essence of the occasion.

site_title: Weibo to guide Hong Kong offering price at HK$272.80 a share
summary: Weibo Corp priced its Hong Kong shares at HK$272.80, a 2.8% discount from Wednesday's US$36 close, raising about HK$3 billion despite Beijing's market-dampening regulatory moves. The Chinese social media company sold 5.5 million new shares and 5.5 million existing shares, amid concerns over Chinese regulators' tightening oversight on local firms traded overseas. Weibo's American depositary receipts plummeted 9.6% on Wednesday, their biggest fall since late August.

site_title: Investors flee US corporate junk debt on inflation, Omicron concerns
summary: US corporate junk bond investors fled low-rated companies in November, marking the worst month since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic. High-yield bonds saw an average return of -1.03% and spreads widened the most since the pandemic's beginning. Concerns over inflation and the Omicron variant drove the moves, with investors seeking higher yields. The market may benefit from November's poor performance, as higher yields could attract investors in 2022, according to some analysts.

site_title: Cuscaden waives walk-away right from SPH bid; gains final regulatory approval
summary: Cuscaden Peak has waived its right to walk away from its bid for Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) due to a material adverse effect (MAE). The consortium, comprising Hotel Properties, CLA Real Estate Holdings, and Mapletree Investments, has received final regulatory approval from Australia, providing SPH shareholders with "greater transaction certainty." The waiver offers higher transaction certainty compared to Keppel Corporation's scheme, which still requires shareholder approval. Cuscaden is offering an all-cash offer of S$2.36 per share, with the success now in SPH shareholders' hands.

site_title: Opec+ agrees to proceed with January oil-production hike
summary: Opec+ agreed to proceed with a 400,000-barrel-per-day oil-production hike in January, adding to global markets. The decision, made amid uncertainty over the Omicron variant's impact on demand, leaves room for adjustments if market conditions change. Oil prices fell 2.5% to $63.96 per barrel after the announcement, as traders had expected a delay in the supply hike. The move may strain Saudi Arabia's relations with the US, which has urged the kingdom to maintain supplies to prevent inflationary price spikes.

site_title: Down jacket maker feels the heat over no-return policies
summary: Canada Goose Holdings Inc has faced criticism from China's top consumer protection organisation for its "bullying" customers with its no-return policies. A customer claimed to have been told that all products sold at retail stores in mainland China were non-refundable, despite the company denying this. The China Consumer Association has warned the brand to behave "arrogantly and in a superior way" or risk losing consumer trust. This comes after the company was fined 450,000 yuan in September for "misleading" consumers in its ads.

site_title: Kaisa abandons Hong Kong projects in race to avoid default
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, a Chinese property developer, is abandoning its Hong Kong projects to avoid default on its offshore dollar debt. The company has been reversing its expansion in the city through a series of asset sales amid a liquidity crunch during China's property deleveraging campaign. Kaisa needs to raise funds to repay its US$400 million of notes maturing on December 7, and its bondholders are considering a debt swap offer. The company's assets in Hong Kong, including 4 residential sites, are being sold, but net proceeds will be insufficient to cover its outstanding bond payments.

site_title: Singapore's first wave SPACs to move ahead with filing plan: sources
summary: Singapore's first wave of Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) are preparing to file preliminary prospectuses for listings on the Singapore Exchange. Vertex Holdings, Novo Tellus Capital Partners, and Tikehau Capital are set to lodge documents for their respective IPOs, which could lead to listings by the end of this year. The firms aim to raise S$200-300 million each, which would benefit Singapore's low listing volumes. The move is seen as a potential game-changer for the market, following Singapore's recent opening to SPAC listings.

site_title: CDL to acquire Central Square for S$315m as part of Central area facelift
summary: CDL to acquire Central Square in Singapore for S$315 million as part of its plans to redevelop the area into a mixed-use lifestyle hub. The 99-year leasehold commercial and residential development currently holds a remaining lease tenure of 72 years. The acquisition includes a serviced residence and commercial spaces, with an estimated potential gross floor area uplift of 67% to 735,500 sq ft. The deal includes an incentive payment of up to S$18 million, subject to conditions by Dec 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: The group now owns the 81,660 sq ft Central Mall site, comprising the freehold 7-storey Central Mall office tower and some conservation shop houses.

site_title: 1,101 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; weekly infection rate up slightly at 0.70
summary: Singapore reported 1,101 new Covid-19 cases, with a weekly infection growth rate of 0.70, down from 0.67 the previous day. The ICU utilisation rate decreased to 56.4%, and 9 people aged 56-99 died from complications linked to Covid-19. The total number of fatalities in Singapore is now 735. The new infections include 1,050 community cases, 41 in migrant worker dormitories, and 10 imported cases, bringing the total cases to 267,150.

site_title: US jobless claims remain low following prior week's plunge
summary: US jobless claims rose by 28,000 to 222,000 in the week ended Nov 27, slightly exceeding economists' expectations. This marks a return to a trend prior to the prior week's unusually low reading, which was attributed to seasonal adjustment issues. Continuing claims for state benefits fell to a pandemic low of 1.96 million, indicating a solid pace of hiring. However, the emerging Omicron variant poses a risk to this trend.

site_title: Boss of Singapore Lamborghini dealership arrested, out on bail
summary: The CEO of EuroSports Global, Goh Kim San, was arrested by the Commercial Affairs Department in Singapore on December 2, 2021, but released on a S$50,000 bail. He was suspended in August amid an investigation and had voluntarily stepped down from his duties. Despite not being charged, the nominating committee and board concluded that he should continue in his roles as executive chairman, CEO, and director. Goh's leadership is crucial to the company's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, and he will also oversee the production of a new electric motorcycle and groom the next generation of leaders.

site_title: What's next for China's US$60t property market in 2022?
summary: China's US$60 trillion property market is expected to be a significant risk factor for 2022, according to Goldman Sachs. Economists predict slower growth due to the prolonged property market deleveraging, strict Covid restrictions, and normalizing exports. While regulations may continue, local policy easing could maintain a stable property market. Some analysts, like DBS China, see a positive sign in local governments' easing policies, while others, like Moody's Analytics, warn of potential ramifications for the domestic financial system and household consumption. A modest recovery is expected, but the worst of the regulation intensity and corresponding shocks may be over.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Business travel may soon return in 2022, despite the Omicron variant affecting the general travel sector. Razer Inc's top executives proposed taking the gaming hardware maker private in a deal valued at HK$24.7 billion. Gloria Mansion condominium is back on the market with a reserve price of S$69 million. Singapore healthcare benefit costs are expected to rise by 9% in 2022, and the STI dipped 0.2% due to cautious trading amid Omicron concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.81 points to 1,501.74. The market saw 3.738 billion lots traded worth RM3.065 billion, with 716 losers outnumbering 272 gainers.

site_title: Didi, Pinduoduo and others could seek homecoming on US delisting threat
summary: China plans to restrict overseas listings through variable interest entities, potentially leading to Chinese companies like Didi Global and Pinduoduo seeking homecoming listings in Hong Kong. The move could result in these companies delisting from US markets and returning to domestic stock exchanges, including Hong Kong. This could create opportunities for companies like Li Auto and XPeng, which have already pivoted to Hong Kong listings. Analysts predict that Chinese internet companies with US listings may accelerate plans for secondary offerings in Hong Kong if regulators crack down on the VIE structure.

images.alt_text: Didi and other Chinese Internet companies with US listings may accelerate plans for secondary offerings in Hong Kong if regulators crack down on the use of the variable interest entity structure.

site_title: CDL to acquire Central Square for S$315m as part of Central area facelift
summary: CDL has agreed to acquire Central Square in Singapore for S$315 million, as part of a plan to redevelop its Central Mall properties and surrounding area into a mixed-use lifestyle hub. The acquisition includes a 99-year leasehold site with a remaining lease tenure of 70.7 years, and CDL plans to increase the site's potential gross floor area by 67% to 735,500 sq ft. The deal is expected to be completed in Q1 next year, with a potential incentive payment of up to S$18 million subject to certain conditions.

site_title: No change to STI constituents
summary: There are no changes to the Straits Times Index (STI) constituents following the December quarterly review. The reserve list, comprising Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Keppel Reit, NetLink NBN Trust, Olam International, and Suntec Reit, will replace ineligible constituents. The next review will take place in March next year, with changes taking effect on December 20. The STI is jointly calculated by FTSE Russell, Singapore Press Holdings, and the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Grab tumbles 33% on Nasdaq debut day, fails to sustain initial surge
summary: Grab's shares plummet 33% on their Nasdaq debut day, falling below the $10 mark after briefly surging 18% at market open. The company's high cash burn and uncertain prospects have raised concerns among market observers, with some analysts predicting a gloomy near-term outlook. Despite positive comments from S&P Global Ratings and analyst Brian Freitas, others, including Shifara Samsudeen and Aequitas Research, are cautious, citing the company's lack of track record in generating positive free cash flows and sustaining profitable operations.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall as Apple roils tech sector
summary: European stocks fell more than 1% on Dec 2 as technology shares plummeted following Apple's warning of slowing iPhone 13 demand. The Stoxx Europe 600 index dropped amid concerns about the Omicron coronavirus variant, which is affecting travel and travel-related shares. The economic rebound is being assessed for risks posed by the variant.

site_title: US: Tech weighs on equity trading as Apple tumbles
summary: US stocks were affected by technology companies, particularly after Apple's demand warning for its iPhone 13 lineup, which led to a decline in the Nasdaq 100. Despite this, the S&P 500 remained little changed. Boeing led gains in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The job market showed progress with a smaller-than-expected rise in US state unemployment benefits. Pfizer's Covid-19 shot is expected to hold up against the Omicron variant, according to an executive.

site_title: Omicron variant lands in Singapore; 2 cases recovering in isolation wards
summary: Two imported Covid-19 cases in Singapore have preliminarily tested positive for the Omicron variant, arriving from Johannesburg on a flight on Wednesday. Both cases, who are fully vaccinated, are recovering in isolation wards at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases, with mild symptoms. There is currently no evidence of community transmission, and they had not interacted with the community before testing positive.

site_title: Century-old Selfridges falls to Thai ownership
summary: The Weston family, owners of Selfridges & Co, has agreed to sell the British department store operator to Thai conglomerate Central Group. The deal, reportedly worth £4 billion, could be announced this month. Central Group, owned by the Chirathivat family, is one of Asia's wealthiest families. This sale comes as retail business on major shopping streets suffers, with trophy assets in the UK attracting interest despite declining retail property values.

site_title: Eurozone government bond yields fall on Omicron worries
summary: Eurozone government bond yields fell on Thursday as the new Omicron coronavirus variant dampened risk sentiment, outweighing expectations for faster US monetary policy tightening. European shares dropped after the US identified its first known case of the Omicron variant. US borrowing costs rose, with the 10-year Treasury yield up 0.5 basis points. German and Italian bond yields fell, while the spread between 10-year Italian and German yields tightened. The European Central Bank is considering delaying a decision on its bond buying programme, potentially extending uncertainty and volatility.

site_title: Faith in Singapore leaders hit by record covid wave: Institute of Policy Studies poll
summary: Singaporeans' trust in their government's Covid-19 management has fallen to 53% during the record wave, with older respondents more likely to be disgruntled. The trust has since improved to almost 60%. Around 70% believe Singapore can win the fight against Covid-19, and 80% are satisfied with the healthcare system. The government has paused social easing and border reopening due to the Omicron variant, with 80% favoring a slower reopening with fewer deaths.

site_title: UK: Shares slide as inflation, Omicron risks grow
summary: The UK's benchmark FTSE 100 index declined 0.5% on Thursday as fears of the Omicron coronavirus variant and inflationary pressure from supply chain difficulties and increased demand for consumer goods grew. Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey warned that the economic impact of Covid-19 still remains strong, while banks slipped amid uncertainty about interest rate hikes. Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged people to get vaccinated against Omicron, which has seen 32 cases of the variant reported.

site_title: Sentiment poll shows slowing growth in Singapore factories; Purchasing Managers' Index loses 0.2 point to 50.6 in November
summary: Singapore's factory sector experienced slowing growth in November, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) losing 0.2 points to 50.6, indicating a contraction. The slowdown follows earlier peaks in July and is attributed to production and logistics disruptions. The sector is now awaiting the impact of the new Omicron variant on activity. This decline is in line with similar trends in the region, and experts are monitoring the situation closely.

site_title: 'Returnship' programmes tie-ups among 12 recommendations by SBF to support women in the workforce
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) recommends 12 strategies to support women in the workforce, including "returnship" programmes that allow workers to test the waters of returning to a full-time role after a long hiatus. The programmes can be pilot-tested through collaborations between organisations, institutes of higher learning, and government agencies. SBF also suggests recalibrating hiring processes, investing in training, and promoting flexible career pathways to encourage women to remain in the workforce. Additionally, the government is urged to explore policy adjustments, such as increasing childcare leave provisions and subsidising family care leave.

site_title: VTL travellers from Singapore exempted from South Korea's new quarantine requirements
summary: South Korea has exempted vaccinated travellers from Singapore under its Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme, despite new quarantine requirements that will be implemented from December 3. The decision was made after the Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency announced plans to impose a 10-day quarantine on all inbound travellers. However, the Embassy of the Republic of Korea in Singapore confirmed that the VTL arrangement will proceed without change. Eligible travellers from South Korea can continue to enter Singapore under the VTL scheme, subject to Covid-19 tests.

site_title: China: Blue chips close higher as property, auto stocks gain
summary: China's blue chips rose 0.3% to 4,856.16, led by real estate developers that announced plans to issue domestic bonds, easing liquidity strains on the cash-strapped sector. Analysts expect the government to continue its deleveraging campaign, but any policy loosening will be measured to curb speculative demand. The property sector downturn is expected to continue into 2022, with home prices and sales falling due to tight credit policies and a looming property tax.

site_title: Japan drops ban on inbound flight bookings after confusion
summary: Japan has lifted its ban on new inbound flight bookings after confusion arose due to a government agency's instruction to airlines not to accept new reservations for December. The ban was initially implemented to prevent the spread of the Omicron variant of coronavirus, but it caused worries among travelers aiming to return for year-end holidays. The transport ministry has since cancelled the instruction and airlines can now accept new reservations, with arrivals limited to 3,500 per day, down from 5,000 previously.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip on Thursday amid cautious trading; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% or 6.14 points to close at 3,092.11, amid cautious trading due to concerns over the Omicron Covid-19 variant. The market saw a mixed day in Asia, with South Korea's Kospi rising 1.6%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 0.6%, and Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index rising 1.2%. The STI was led by SGX, climbing 0.7%, while Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust was the biggest decliner, falling 2%.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit unitholders vote in favour of investment in M1's network assets
summary: Keppel DC Reit unitholders have voted in favor of investing S$89.7 million in bonds and preference shares to acquire M1 Network's mobile, fixed, and fibre assets for S$580 million. The investment, which includes a 15-year network services agreement, is expected to provide Keppel DC Reit with stable and regular cash flows and enhance total unitholders' returns. The Reit manager believes the investment is opportunistic and distribution-per-unit accretive, with an effective yield of 9.17% per annum.

site_title: Razer execs seek to delist group at valuation of HK$24.7 billion
summary: A consortium led by Razer executives, including chairman Min-Liang Tan and non-executive director Kaling Lim, has proposed taking the gaming hardware maker private with a valuation of HK$24.7 billion (S$4.3 billion). The offer price is HK$2.82 per share, a premium of around 44% to Razer's closing price on Oct 28. The consortium includes private equity firm CVC Capital Partners and is advised by Credit Suisse. The proposal is final and aims to address Razer's low trading volumes and undervaluation in Hong Kong.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at 2-month low as Omicron worries persist
summary: Australian shares ended at a 2-month low on Thursday, closing 0.2% lower at 7,225.2, amid persistent worries about the Omicron variant of the coronavirus. The technology sector fell 3.2%, tracking the Nasdaq's drop, while utilities and industrials sectors helped prevent a steeper decline. Afterpay plummeted 6.3% to a 4-month low after postponing its US$29 billion deal with Jack Dorsey. The S&P/ASX 200 index is expected to remain volatile due to Omicron updates, supply chain issues, and inflation concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.55% to 23,788.93 on December 2, 2021, as traders took advantage of bargains after recent losses, despite a plunge on Wall Street. The Omicron virus strain's severity remains uncertain.

site_title: China property market to keep cooling into H1 2022 on tight curbs: poll
summary: China's property market is expected to continue cooling into the first half of 2022 due to tight credit policies and a looming property tax, according to a Reuters poll. Average home prices are forecast to fall 1.0% in the first half of 2022, with property sales by floor area expected to slump 16% and property investment dropping 3.0%. Policymakers are expected to maintain curbs, but may fine-tune regulations and ease restrictions in some areas.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on strong foreign buying, chip boost
summary: South Korean shares ended 1.57% higher on Thursday, driven by strong foreign buying and gains in chip heavyweights as semiconductor shortages are expected to ease. The KOSPI closed at 2,945.27, following a 2.14% gain on Wednesday. The won and benchmark bond yield also rose.

site_title: Alibaba shares are cheapest ever as crackdown wipes off US$526 billion
summary: Alibaba Group Holding's US-listed shares have hit a record low, trading at a multiple of 18.7, the lowest since its 2014 debut. The shares have slumped 4% and its Hong Kong shares have closed 2.5% lower, wiping off $526 billion in value in 13 months. The company's growth drivers, including fintech and online advertising, are under scrutiny from regulators in Beijing, and its future outlook is uncertain due to plans to ban foreign listings through variable interest entities. Wall Street analysts are scrambling to adjust their price targets as investors continue to bail on the stock.

site_title: Sembcorp furthers green pivot with latest acquisition in China; observers say risks present but surmountable
summary: Sembcorp Industries has acquired a 35% stake in Chinese renewable energy company State Development Investment Corporate Group (SDIC) New Energy for S$320 million. The acquisition is part of Sembcorp's goal to reach 10 GW in gross installed renewables capacity by 2025 and brings its renewable gross capacity in China to 3.3 GW. Market analysts view the move as positive, citing the potential for a valuation premium and increased focus on renewables. The acquisition is expected to be earnings accretive from the first year, with a boost of about 10% to Sembcorp's bottom line.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower on Omicron fears
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Dec 2, 2021, due to lingering concerns over the Omicron variant of Covid-19. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.7% and the Topix index fell 0.5%. These losses brought the benchmark indices to 27,753.37 and 1,926.37, respectively. The market decline was attributed to worries about the economic impact of the Omicron variant.

site_title: Australia's Omicron count edges higher, health authorities on edge
summary: Australia reported its seventh Omicron case, a person who arrived from Qatar, prompting state governments to bolster border controls. New South Wales Health Minister Brad Hazzard urged caution, while other states, including South Australia and Tasmania, introduced restrictions on interstate arrivals. Australia has also delayed reopening borders to skilled migrants and foreign students, and citizens returning from southern Africa must undergo hotel quarantine. The country aims to avoid high Covid-19 death numbers, having reported 212,000 cases and 2,000 deaths.

site_title: South Korea slaps 10-day quarantine on all inbound travellers as it hits record daily Covid cases
summary: South Korea has implemented a 10-day quarantine for all inbound travelers starting Friday, amid a record high of 5,266 daily Covid cases and concerns over the Omicron variant. The measure comes after the country confirmed its first five cases of the variant, including a fully vaccinated couple from Nigeria. The government has restricted arrivals from eight countries, including South Africa and Ethiopia, and will suspend direct flights from Ethiopia starting Saturday. The quarantine exemption for fully vaccinated travelers has been halted for two weeks.

site_title: Singapore healthcare benefit costs to rise by 9% in 2022: Willis Towers Watson
summary: Singapore healthcare benefit costs are expected to rise by 9% in 2022, following a 7.7% increase in 2020 and 8.6% in 2021. The growth is in line with the Asia-Pacific trend, which is projected to rise by 7.6% in 2022. The main drivers of medical costs are overuse of care and excess care by insured members. Cancer, cardiovascular, and musculoskeletal conditions remain the top three costliest for Asia-Pacific insurers, with musculoskeletal and mental health disorders expected to be among the fastest-growing conditions in the next 18 months.

images.alt_text: Singapore's projected growth in healthcare benefit costs in 2022 is in line with an overall growth trend in the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: SP Group, Banpu Next in clean energy solutions tie-up; eyes Asia-Pacific region
summary: SP Group and Banpu Next have formed a partnership to develop clean energy and smart city solutions in Thailand and the Asia-Pacific region. The companies will explore district cooling systems, renewable energy certificates, and smart city solutions to support sustainable growth. The partnership aims to offer cities and districts more low-carbon, high-efficiency solutions, with Banpu Next expecting lower energy costs and higher profits for its customers. The collaboration strengthens both companies' clean energy ambitions to meet future demands.

images.alt_text: This strategic partnership will strengthen both companies' clean energy ambitions to meet the clean energy demands of the future.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend losses as Omicron concerns mount; Afterpay tumbles
summary: Australian shares fell 0.54% to 7,197.1, amid concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant, with miners and tech stocks among the top losers. Afterpay dropped 5% after postponing its shareholder meeting, while Openpay rose 8.3% after signing a partnership with American Express. Woolworths and Wesfarmers gained 0.7% and 0.3% respectively after receiving a buyout proposal from Woolworths for Australian Pharmaceutical Industries.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank KE upgrades Frencken back to 'buy' on price correction
summary: Maybank KE has upgraded Frencken Group to 'buy' from 'hold' following the company's recent share price correction to S$2.12. Analyst Lai Gene Lih remains positive on the tech sector, citing solid demand dynamics, but is selectively choosing stocks amid supply-side bottlenecks. Frencken's target price remains unchanged at S$2.50, below its former target of S$2.63. The analyst believes Frencken's margins will trend upwards with new products, despite some inefficiencies.

site_title: Apple tells suppliers iPhone demand has slowed as holidays near
summary: Apple has informed its component suppliers that demand for the iPhone 13 lineup has weakened due to slowing sales, contrary to previous expectations. This follows a production goal cut of up to 10 million units earlier in the year due to a global supply crunch. The reduced demand may impact Apple's plans to make up for the shortfall in the next year, when supply is expected to improve.

site_title: Bank of Japan seeks ways to mitigate cost of monetary easing: board member
summary: The Bank of Japan is seeking ways to mitigate the cost of its monetary easing, warning that prolonged ultra-low interest rates could strain bank profits. Board member Hitoshi Suzuki said the bank will continue to improve its policy framework to balance the effect and cost of easing. Japan's banking sector remains stable, but any further delay in the economic recovery could increase credit costs for financial institutions. The BOJ has already fine-tuned its monetary policy framework to make it more sustainable, allowing bond yields to move more flexibly around its 0% target.

site_title: Severity of Omicron infection questioned around the world
summary: The Omicron variant of Covid-19 continues to spread globally, with new cases reported in the US, Norway, Ireland, and South Korea. Australia's chief medical officer says there's no indication that Omicron is deadlier than other strains, with all reported cases being mild or symptom-free. The World Health Organization's chief scientist says vaccines will likely protect against severe cases of the variant. Meanwhile, South Africa is in talks with Pfizer and Merck & Co to gain access to Covid-19 treatment pills, and Indonesia extends quarantine times for arrivals and bans government officials from overseas travel.

site_title: European business says technical standards 'new battleground' for China, rest of world
summary: A European business group has labeled technical standards a "new battleground" for Chinese companies and their overseas rivals, urging Beijing to provide fair treatment. Despite China's 1.8% share in international technical standards, the country is rapidly increasing its influence in standards-setting, particularly in 5G. However, the European Chamber of Commerce warns that China's state-led approach may prioritize its own interests, deviating from a market competition-centric model. The EU should cooperate with China while maintaining international rules and reciprocity to avoid fragmentation and reduce innovation.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust declares S$0.01461 DPU for advanced distribution
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has declared a distribution of S$0.01461 per unit for its advanced distribution period from Oct 1 to Dec 1. The trust acquired a portfolio of 17 Grade A logistics assets for S$1.4 billion, with 97.5% of the proceeds used to fund the acquisitions. The distribution consists of a taxable income component, tax-exempt income component, and capital component. Unitholders are entitled to the distribution, which will be paid out on or around Jan 12, 2022.

site_title: Business travel rebounds but not as fast as leisure travel
summary: Business travel is rebounding, with corporate travel operators seeing a 20% increase in demand since Singapore launched quarantine-free Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs). Executives are taking advantage of the feature to conduct home visits and attend business meetings. Analysts forecast a 30% increase in business travel next year, despite the emergence of the Omicron variant. However, leisure travel is expected to recover faster, driven by essential general travelers. Airlines are launching flights to Singapore, and the country's air hub is expected to regain its position, with travelers able to make stopovers and generate tourism revenues.

site_title: Top oil producers may freeze output amid Omicron concerns
summary: Major oil producers, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, are set to meet on Thursday to decide on output levels from January, potentially freezing them amid concerns over the Omicron variant. The emergence of the new variant has led to countries reinstating travel bans and mulling further restrictions, which could tighten demand and hurt oil prices. Analysts predict the alliance will stop increasing output by 400,000 barrels per day as planned, citing market volatility.

site_title: Hong Kong quarantine pushes Cathay pilots to 'breaking point'
summary: Cathay Pacific pilots in Hong Kong are quitting in droves due to the city's strict quarantine regime, which has taken a mental toll on crew and families. Over 120 pilots have resigned in recent weeks, with many applying for jobs at airlines in countries that have shifted to a strategy of living with the virus. The airline has secured a bailout but pilots are concerned about Hong Kong's future as a major transport hub. The city's leaders say normalizing travel with China must come first, but this approach has caused alarm among multinationals.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday, extending Omicron rout
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, extending a Wall Street rout, due to lingering concerns over the Omicron variant of Covid-19 and US Federal Reserve policy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.01% to 27,653.16, while the Topix index dropped 0.65% to 1,924.14.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.9% in early trade on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping 28.25 points to 3,070. The decline follows sharp losses on Wall Street, where US authorities announced the first confirmed case of the Covid-19 Omicron variant, leading to losses in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index.

site_title: US to delay UK trade deal over post-Brexit concern: FT
summary: The US will delay its deal to remove tariffs on UK steel and aluminum imports due to concerns about post-Brexit trade rules affecting Northern Ireland. The US Commerce Department cited British threats to trigger emergency clause Article 16, which could suspend parts of the Brexit agreement that introduced checks on goods movement from mainland Britain to Northern Ireland. The delay follows US expressions of grave concern that a disagreement between London and Brussels over the implementation of the 2020 Brexit treaty could undermine the Good Friday accord, which ended decades of violence in Northern Ireland.

site_title: CGS-CIMB upgrades SIA to 'add', positive on FY2022 recovery
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded its call on Singapore Airlines (SIA) to "add" from "hold" with a higher target price of S$5.86, citing a strong recovery in Q3 FY2022 despite Omicron variant uncertainties. Analyst Raymond Yap expects rapid expansion of quarantine-free travel via Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) schemes to boost SIA's recovery. However, potential downside risks include longer-than-expected travel bans and increased competition. Despite this, SIA's airfreight markets and robust year-end peak season are expected to drive growth.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed with traders sensitive to Omicron headlines
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday amid uncertainty over the Omicron variant, with traders concerned about potential economic disruptions and the impact on inflation. The US reported its first Omicron case, sparking a late plunge on Wall Street, and the Federal Reserve is expected to end its bond-buying program and raise interest rates next year. The OECD cut its growth outlook, warning the mutated strain threatens the global recovery. Markets are highly sensitive to negative headlines, with the VIX gauge of volatility at its highest level since February.

images.alt_text: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday and oil edged up with traders still trying to claw back their latest Omicron-induced losses but still full of uncertainty after Wall Street suffered a late plunge in response to the United States reporting its first case.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH, SPH Reit, Keppel, Sembcorp, Ntegrator
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) transferred its media-related business to a new company, SPH Media Trust, for a nominal consideration, eliminating the need to meet specific requirements under the Newspaper and Printing Presses Act. Keppel Corporation acquired up to 70% of Malaysia-based Glocomp Systems for S$36 million. Sembcorp Industries acquired a 35% interest in China's SDIC New Energy for S$320 million. Ntegrator International secured an S$8.6 million contract extension. Trading halted for Bread specialist QAF pending an announcement.

site_title: Most powerful global data broker winning war against US
summary: China has outmaneuvered the US and its allies in the crucial domain of data, positioning itself as the world's most powerful data broker. Beijing has enacted laws and regulations that grant the Chinese Communist Party control over private data, exerting extraterritorial power over global data flows. This has led to foreign companies, including Tesla and Apple, building dedicated Chinese data centers to access the large Chinese consumer market. The US has yet to develop a comprehensive approach to data governance, leaving the Biden administration's answer to the challenge of limiting strategic data flows to China as "maybe."

site_title: Asean market to enjoy strong cyclical upturns in 2022: Credit Suisse
summary: Asean markets are expected to experience strong cyclical upturns in 2022, according to Credit Suisse's report. The region's top picks include Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines, driven by factors such as cheap multiples, low foreign ownership, and bounce-back earnings. Analysts favor these markets over China and Taiwan, which have already become normalized. The banking sector is expected to gain from inflationary pressures, and vaccination rates in Asean are higher than in the US and Europe, leading to a higher resistance to Covid-19.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.32 points or 0.22% to 1,493.61. Losers outnumbered gainers 273 to 112, with a total trading volume of 244.40 million lots worth RM135.44 million.

site_title: South Korean inflation hits decade high, boosting rate hike views
summary: South Korea's consumer inflation reached a decade high in November, increasing 3.7% from the previous year, exceeding analysts' expectations of a 3.1% rise. This marks the eighth consecutive month the inflation rate remains above the central bank's 2% target, fueling expectations of another interest rate hike next month. The fast growth in inflation is a concern for policymakers, highlighting the need for further monetary policy adjustments to maintain price stability.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at Thursday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday on a downward trend, following losses across most of Asia. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.57% to 23,524.05, driven by the US reporting its first Omicron variant case. Asian markets also declined, with the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes dipping 0.10% and 0.15%, respectively. The decline was fueled by concerns over the new variant and US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Thai crypto unicorn plots expansion in bid to be Asia's Coinbase
summary: Thai crypto exchange Bitkub Online is planning expansion into countries such as Malaysia, the Philippines, and Laos to become Asia's Coinbase. The company, which commands a near-monopoly in Thailand, aims to achieve exponential growth in digital currency wallets to 1 billion globally in 5 years. Bitkub's CEO, Jirayut Srupsrisopa, plans to expand through new ventures or acquisitions, focusing on under-banked countries with high social media usage and potential for cryptocurrency use. The company's valuation has reached over $1 billion in less than 4 years.

site_title: South Korea's revised Q3 GDP up 0.3% qoq, matching advance estimate: central bank
summary: South Korea's economy expanded 0.3% in Q3, matching the advance estimate, according to the Bank of Korea. This was slower than the 0.8% growth in Q2, driven by a 0.2% decline in private consumption and a 2.4% drop in capital investment. The revised Q3 GDP data is consistent with the earlier estimates, providing a clearer picture of the country's economic performance.

site_title: US companies battle rising prices and labour shortages: Federal Reserve survey
summary: The US economy expanded modestly in October and the first half of November, with prices rising at a moderate to robust pace amid strong demand for raw materials, logistical challenges, and labor market tightness. The Federal Reserve considers speeding up the end of its bond-buying program to curb inflation, which has run above its 2% target, and is weighing a faster timeline for interest rate hikes. Businesses struggle to fill job openings, leading to wage growth and increased incentives, with the US unemployment rate currently at 4.6%.

site_title: Dorsey-led Square rebrands to Block in nod to blockchain
summary: Square Inc., led by Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, is rebranding to Block Inc. to expand beyond its payment business and into new technologies like blockchain. The name change aims to distinguish the corporate entity from its businesses, which will continue to maintain their respective brands. Shares rose 1% in extended trading. The move comes after Dorsey stepped down as Twitter CEO, following his investment in bitcoin and his interest in blockchain technology. The new name will become effective on or about December 10.

site_title: Gloria Mansion tries for en bloc sale again with lower S$69m reserve price
summary: Gloria Mansion, a 12-storey freehold condominium in Singapore, is back on the market with a reserve price of S$69 million, down from its initial asking price of S$79 million in 2018. The property, completed in 1995, features 31 apartments and sits on a 45,742 sq ft site. The current plot ratio is 1.4 and is zoned for residential use under the Master Plan 2019. This marks the second attempt at an en bloc sale for the property, which was previously launched in 2018 before property cooling measures were introduced.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again as Omicron case derails rally
summary: US stocks fell for a second consecutive session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 1.3% to 34,022.07, the S&P 500 shedding 1.2% to 4,513.01, and the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 1.8% to 15,254.05. The decline followed the announcement of the first confirmed case of the Covid-19 Omicron variant in the US, which is expected to derail the rally.

site_title: US government shutdown looms as lawmakers squabble
summary: The US government is at risk of a shutdown as lawmakers struggle to reach a budget agreement, with funding set to expire on Friday. A five-week shutdown in 2018-2019 caused disruptions, including affected airport security lines. Despite deep divisions, most lawmakers hope to avoid a repeat, but a small group of Republicans are refusing to agree to a budget that funds vaccine mandates. Economists warn that a shutdown could cost the US economy $6 billion, and several Democrats have expressed frustration at the partisan stalemate.

site_title: Sembcorp to pay 1.5b yuan for 35% stake in Chinese renewable energy company
summary: Sembcorp Industries is acquiring a 35% stake in SDIC New Energy, a Chinese renewable energy company, for 1.5 billion yuan (S$320 million). SDIC New Energy has a portfolio of 30 operational wind and solar PV assets with a total gross installed capacity of 1.9 gigawatts across 7 provincial regions in China. The acquisition will give Sembcorp Industries a significant presence in China's renewable energy sector.

site_title: Disney names Susan Arnold as its first woman chair
summary: Disney appoints Susan Arnold as its first woman chair, succeeding Bob Iger on December 31. Arnold, a 14-year board member, brings experience from The Carlyle Group, Procter and Gamble, and McDonald's Corp. The move follows a trend of untangling CEO and chairperson roles in big corporations. Several Disney executives, including Studios head Alan Horn and president Gary Marsh, have announced plans to leave by the end of 2021.

site_title: Qualcomm chip aims to create new category of handheld gaming devices
summary: Qualcomm has released a new chip designed for gaming-specific handheld devices, offering 5G connectivity and a potential new mobile platform for video gamers. The "G3x Gen 1" chip is partnered with Razer to create an initial test device for game makers, featuring a touch screen, physical controls, and longer battery life. This new device aims to create a new category of handheld gaming devices, potentially disrupting the gaming industry and offering more flexibility to play streaming games on the go.

site_title: Tinder owner to pay founders US$441m to settle valuation lawsuit
summary: Match Group, the parent company of Tinder, will pay US$441 million to the app's co-founders, Sean Rad, Justin Mateen, and Jonathan Badeen, to settle a lawsuit over the valuation of stock options. The lawsuit, filed in 2018, alleged Match and its parent firm InterActiveCorp schemed to undervalue stock options, with the founders claiming they were shortchanged by several billion dollars. The settlement ends all legal actions in exchange for the founders agreeing to end their claims. The deal marks a significant payout for the co-founders of the popular dating app.

site_title: EU unveils 300 billion euro answer to China's Belt and Road Initiative
summary: The European Union has unveiled a 300 billion euro plan, dubbed the Global Gateway, to invest globally in infrastructure, digital, and climate projects by 2027, as an alternative to China's Belt and Road Initiative. The EU aims to strengthen supply chains, boost trade, and fight climate change, focusing on digitalisation, health, and energy sectors. Unlike China, the EU's financing is expected to be more transparent and beneficial to local communities, with private sector involvement. The plan is seen as a true alternative to China's initiative, offering fair and favourable terms.

site_title: WTA suspends all tournaments in China over Peng concerns
summary: The Women's Tennis Association (WTA) has suspended all tournaments in China due to concerns about the safety of Chinese player Peng Shuai. WTA Tour chairman Steve Simon made the announcement, citing the need to prioritize Peng's well-being. The decision comes after the WTA had previously planned 11 events in China, but they were relocated or cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This suspension includes Hong Kong, and it marks a significant shift in the WTA's stance on China.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound from Omicron-spurred rout
summary: European shares rose 1.7% on Wednesday, their best session in almost six months, after fears of the Omicron strain of the coronavirus eased. The Stoxx 600 index recovered from a seven-week low and is 4% away from its record high. Industrial stocks, autos, and travel & leisure led the gains, while miners and oil stocks also rose. The European Union's drug regulator expects to greenlight Covid-19 vaccines tailored to Omicron in 3-4 months.

site_title: UK housing sees higher-than-expected increase in prices in November
summary: The UK housing market saw a higher-than-expected 0.9% increase in home prices in November, reaching £252,687, with the annual rate of growth climbing to 10%. Despite the end of a tax relief for homebuyers, factors such as housing shortages and pandemic-driven demand continue to support the market. However, Nationwide Building Society warns of a squeeze on living standards due to inflation and potential interest rate increases, posing uncertainty for the market's pace.

site_title: Dollar up, risk currencies recover from Omicron fears
summary: The US dollar steadied on Wednesday, with the dollar index at 95.940, after rising on Tuesday following hawkish comments from the Federal Reserve. Riskier currencies, including the euro, sterling, and Australian and New Zealand dollars, recovered from previous losses as investors bet that the Omicron variant won't derail the economic recovery. The euro was down 0.1% at US$1.1322, while sterling rose 0.2% to US$1.33175. The Chinese yuan reached a 6-month high at 6.3596 per dollar after better-than-expected manufacturing data.

site_title: China home sales slump deepens as policy easing shows little effect
summary: China's top 100 developers saw a 38% year-over-year decline in contract sales to 751 billion yuan in November, surpassing the 32% drop in the previous month. Despite policy easing, the industry slowdown persists due to a widening debt crisis and prohibitive borrowing costs. Moody's Investors Service predicts weak national sales growth for the next six to 12 months, with a Bloomberg Intelligence index of mainland developers down 31% this year.

site_title: Trump's social media venture seeks US$1b raise: sources
summary: Former US President Donald Trump's social media venture, Trump Media & Technology Group, is seeking a $1 billion investment from hedge funds and family offices, valuing the company at nearly $3 billion. The deal comes after Trump Media's blank-check acquisition firm, Digital World Acquisition Corp, saw its shares surge following the company's announcement. However, some investors have distanced themselves from the deal due to Trump's ban from top social media platforms and regulatory risk. Trump Media plans to roll out its social media app, TRUTH Social, in the first quarter of 2022, with a subscription service to follow.

site_title: Facebook hits anti-vaccine campaign harassing doctors
summary: Facebook-parent Meta has removed an anti-vaccine campaign that harassed medical workers, journalists, and officials, including those in France and Italy. The "V-V" conspiracy movement was linked to tens of thousands of comments on pro-vaccine posts, with supporters using hate speech and swastikas on multiple platforms. Meta took down accounts and suspended users who engaged in harassment, signaling the company's ongoing efforts to combat pandemic-tied misinformation.

site_title: Japan halts new incoming flight bookings over Omicron: ministry
summary: Japan has asked airlines to halt new incoming flight bookings for one month due to concerns over the Omicron virus variant. Following the detection of a second Omicron case, authorities have tightened border measures, including banning entry of non-citizens from 10 southern African nations and quarantining citizens and residents from several dozen countries. Japan has logged around 18,360 deaths during the pandemic and has a vaccination rate of 77%. Existing bookings will not be affected.

site_title: Empathy, purpose and hope: Giving strengthens society
summary: Companies like TDCX, Cordlife, and Elpis @ Hideout are participating in SG Cares Giving Week, a charity event from Dec 1-7. Inspired by a TDCX employee who volunteered at an animal shelter, the company launched a campaign to support SPCA Singapore and Purely Adoptions. An internal auction raised S$5,000, while a donation drive via Giving.sg will support the SPCA until Dec 20. This initiative aims to demonstrate the power of corporate giving, fostering empathy, purpose, and hope in society.

site_title: Oil prices sink again as traders use Omicron as an excuse to hit 'sell'
summary: Oil prices dropped 61 cents, or 0.9%, to $65.57 a barrel, amid worries the Omicron variant could cut oil demand. The decline followed a brief rally, with traders using the variant as an excuse to sell. Despite a US release of 50 million barrels of oil reserves, retail petrol prices remain unchanged. Analysts expect more bullish momentum to return when WTI crosses above $70 a barrel, but major brokerages say the selloff has come too far, too fast. Opec+ is meeting to decide whether to continue adding 400,000 bpd to supply.

site_title: OECD lowers world growth forecast, warns of Omicron threat
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) lowered its global growth forecast to 5.6% for 2021, citing the threat of the Omicron coronavirus variant. The variant is adding to existing uncertainty and risks, potentially threatening the economic recovery. The OECD also warned that low vaccination areas could create "breeding grounds" for deadlier virus mutations. Despite this, the report remains cautiously optimistic about the recovery, with forecasts for 2022 remaining unchanged at 4.5%.

site_title: Travel bans over new Covid strain 'unfair', 'ineffective': UN chief
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres criticized travel bans targeting countries over the new Covid-19 Omicron variant as "unfair" and "ineffective." He urged increased testing for travelers instead. The World Health Organization has deemed the Omicron risk "very high," but some African countries feel punished for sharing information about the variant. Officials in South Africa and Malawi accused Western countries of "Afrophobia," while the WHO's director for Africa opposed barring travelers from the continent, citing global solidarity. Guterres called for more effective measures to reduce transmission risk while allowing travel and economic engagement.

site_title: Australia home price boom ebbs in November as sellers rush in
summary: Australia's housing market experienced a slowdown in November, with home prices rising 1.3% after a 1.5% increase in the previous month. National home prices have increased 22.2% from last year, driven by a pandemic-driven shift to the country. Median home prices reached A$698,170, with regional prices climbing 25% amid the shift. Sellers are entering the market, with new listings up by two-thirds since early September, potentially moderating price growth.

site_title: Mediation can help preserve or even repair relationships
summary: Businesses are increasingly adopting mediation to resolve commercial disputes, with a significant increase in cases at the Singapore International Mediation Centre (SIMC) during the COVID-19 pandemic. The shift is driven by the recognition that mediation is a more sustainable and effective way to resolve disputes, with high-value cases reaching $55 million on average. The Singapore Convention on Mediation has increased business confidence in using mediation, and the global enforceability of mediated settlements has made it easier for businesses to hold each other to the terms of their settlement across the world.

site_title: UBS says Sarah Youngwood to succeed Gardner as group CFO
summary: UBS appoints Sarah Youngwood as its group chief financial officer, effective May, replacing Kirt Gardner. Youngwood has been JPMorgan Chase's financial chief for Consumer & Community Banking since 2016 and will join UBS's executive board in March.

site_title: Binance's Singapore crypto hub plans in regulatory limbo
summary: Binance's Singapore arm is facing regulatory limbo as its licence application remains under review by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The company's CEO, Changpeng "CZ" Zhao, has hinted that Binance may withdraw its application and shift its global base elsewhere, potentially moving operations closer to its global headquarters. If Binance leaves Singapore, it could impact the city-state's efforts to establish itself as a key player in the crypto arena, and users may no longer be able to buy and trade cryptocurrencies through Binance Singapore and Binance.com.

site_title: Price gains tempt some buyers to flip shophouses
summary: A seasoned Singaporean property investor has made at least 3 shophouse flips this year, realising 35% capital appreciation in one deal and 19% in another. The investor bought and resold properties in Stanley Street, Smith Street, and Keong Saik Road, with prices ranging from S$11.5 million to S$25 million. The transactions were brokered by Richard Tan, and the investor's gains are attributed to the strong demand and limited stock in the conservation shophouse market.

site_title: UAE marks golden jubilee of its founding
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) marked its golden jubilee on December 2, 2021, celebrating 50 years of its founding. The country has achieved significant economic and social development, with a thriving nation hosting people from over 200 nationalities, a 93% literacy rate, and welcoming 15 million tourists annually. The UAE's economy is the second-largest in the Arab world, driven by tourism, transport, and logistics, financial services, and renewable energy. The country aims to build a knowledge economy and has successfully diversified away from oil dependence. The UAE and Singapore have a strong diplomatic relationship, with Singapore being one of the top destinations for UAE investment in the region.

site_title: Advertising giants see surge in Q3 profits, predict rapid growth in coming years
summary: Advertising giants WPP and Publicis reported a surge in Q3 profits and are optimistic about rapid growth in the coming years, despite concerns over the Omicron Covid-19 variant and reduced advertising spending by clients. Procter & Gamble also stated plans to continue marketing spend, and GroupM predicts global advertising spending will reach $1 trillion by 2026, driven by digital ad growth.

site_title: US announces first Omicron case in traveller returning from South Africa
summary: The US has announced its first confirmed case of the Omicron variant, detected in a fully vaccinated traveler who recently returned from South Africa and was recovering from mild symptoms in California. According to the CDC, the individual's close contacts have tested negative. Top health official Anthony Fauci emphasized the importance of vaccination, boosters, and masking in indoor public settings to stay protected.

site_title: Lessons from troubles besetting listing of Eagle Hospitality Trust
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT), a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust, faced significant troubles after its listing in May 2019. The trust, which adopted a master lease arrangement, struggled with concentration risk and rental defaults by its master lessees. Despite assurances, the trust's stapled securities fell 14% after a notice of default from the City of Long Beach. EHT's financial resources depleted due to the impact of COVID-19 and delinquencies by the master lessees. The trust filed for insolvency protection and disposed of 15 of its 18 hotel properties. The case highlights the importance of the commitment and financial strength of master lessees in a master lease arrangement, and the need for adequate disclosure of risks before a Reit's listing.

site_title: When businesses do good, they become agents of social change
summary: Businesses can create social change by prioritizing giving back to their community while maintaining profitability. As consumers become more purpose-driven, companies must quantify their impact to meet growing demand for sustainable and equitable practices. Measuring social value can be achieved through social return on investment (SROI) and social impact statements, which provide a holistic approach to creating social value. By doing so, businesses can unlock new potential for long-term community progress and become agents of social change.

site_title: Thailand's historically high household debt puts dampener on recovery
summary: Thailand's household debt, a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, has reached an 18-year high of 14.13 trillion baht, or 90.6% of the country's GDP, according to the Bank of Thailand. Economists warn that this high debt will limit household consumption, which is projected to be 11.6% below pre-Covid levels in 2019. The lack of foreign tourists, mainly due to the Omicron variant, also contributes to the pessimism about consumption. Experts suggest that luring tourists back to Thailand might be easier than reducing household debt, and the country's high debt levels are expected to linger for several years.

site_title: Australia economy's Q3 slump not as bad as feared, recovery underway
summary: Australia's economy experienced a 1.9% decline in the third quarter, but the drop was less severe than forecast, with GDP growth slowing to 3.9% for the year. A speedy recovery is underway, driven by high vaccination rates, strong consumer spending, and resilient labor market. Household consumption dropped 4.8% in the quarter, but retail sales have been surging, and consumer savings have increased, supporting spending power. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates low, and economists predict GDP will surpass its pre-pandemic peak this quarter.

site_title: Singapore's unemployment rates could return to pre-Covid-19 levels by end-2022: economists
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate for residents is expected to return to pre-Covid-19 levels by end-2022, according to economists. The employment rate for residents rose to 67.2% in June, up from 64.5% a year ago, driven by economic recovery and government measures. However, the unemployment rate for PMETs remains high at 3.4%, reflecting skills mismatch and job churn. Economists believe that border restrictions and tighter visa policies may contribute to a persistent shortage of low-skilled workers, but a sustained recovery could see unemployment rates return to pre-pandemic levels by 2022.

site_title: Japan keen to speed up digital yen launch as China adds geopolitical twist
summary: Japan's new government is urging the Bank of Japan to speed up the launch of a digital yen, citing China's rapid progress in issuing a digital currency as a potential challenge to the global economic order. China has already run tests for a digital yuan, while Japan has only started its experiment in April. The government sees the digital yen as crucial for Japan's national security and economic dominance, particularly in relation to the US dollar. If other G-7 nations, such as Europe and the US, also issue digital currencies, it could put pressure on the BOJ to issue a digital yen sooner.

site_title: Suncity closes Macau VIP gaming rooms after CEO's arrest: sources
summary: Suncity Group Holdings, Macau's largest junket operator, has closed all its VIP gaming rooms in Macau after CEO Alvin Chau's arrest on allegations of cross-border gambling and money laundering. The move, expected to cut a third of its Macau workforce, follows a broad investigation into Chau's business. Authorities are cracking down on the promotion of gambling in mainland China, where it is illegal, and seeking to rein in Chinese gambling-related funds into Macau. The closure has exacerbated losses for Macau-listed casino stocks, with shares in Wynn Macau and Bloomberry Resorts Corp tumbling.

site_title: La Ville sold for S$152 million in third bid at collective sale
summary: La Ville, a 40-unit freehold development in District 15, Singapore, was sold via collective sale to Hong Kong-listed ZACD Group for S$152 million, exceeding its reserve price of S$148 million. The site, which is close to Katong Park MRT Station and various amenities, saw strong competition among bidders, resulting in a land rate of approximately S$1,477 psf ppr. Owners representing over 80% of the site's value have consented to the sale, with expected gross sales proceeds ranging from S$3 to S$5.9 million per unit.

site_title: Pick up ideas for a festive celebration
summary: The article "BTLUXE CHRISTMAS" highlights the importance of finding joy during the holiday season despite the pandemic's impact on travel plans. It features interviews with local business personalities, including Gregory Van and Rachel Lim, who reflect on how the pandemic has deepened family relationships. The article also provides a guide to festive celebrations, including wine and dine options, staycation ideas, and gift suggestions. Additionally, it offers inspiration for decorating homes, with a feature on resort designer Christopher Chua's festive shophouse home in Singapore.

site_title: Australia raises possibility of more legislation on Big Tech
summary: Australia is launching a parliamentary inquiry into the world's largest technology companies, including Alphabet and Facebook, to investigate their behavior and potential need for new legislation. Prime Minister Scott Morrison said the inquiry will focus on issues such as algorithm safety, identity verification, and enforcement of restrictions. This comes after Australia implemented laws requiring tech companies to pay local media for content and share user identities in anonymous accounts. The inquiry's findings will be reported by February 2022, amid tensions with tech companies, including Google and Facebook, which have previously threatened to shut down their Australian operations.

site_title: Fed signals inflation concerns, possible earlier end to supports
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled growing concerns about high and stubborn inflation, potentially speeding up the plan to withdraw financial support from the economy. Inflation has reached a 30-year high, and a new coronavirus variant, Omicron, threatens to derail the economic recovery. Powell suggested the Fed could end its bond-buying program sooner than expected, which could lead to higher interest rates and a slower economy. This decision may also impact the job market, with millions of workers still missing from the job market, and could be influenced by the Omicron variant's impact.

site_title: After bumper year for main bourse, Vietnam sets sights on top 4 ranking in S-E Asia
summary: Vietnam's stock exchange aims to rank among the top 4 in Southeast Asia by 2030, according to the Ministry of Finance. Currently, the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange ranks fifth in terms of market capitalization to GDP. The exchange has seen a significant boom from first-time retail investors and the rise of fintech. This growth is expected to contribute to Vietnam's goal of improving its ranking.

site_title: Global airlines prepare for Omicron-induced volatility
summary: Global airlines are preparing for Omicron-induced volatility, which may lead to schedule adjustments and reliance on domestic markets. Analysts predict a decline in bookings and further delays in business travel recovery. Fitch Ratings lowered global passenger traffic forecasts for 2021 and 2022 due to the emergence of new variants. Airlines with strong domestic markets, such as the US, China, and Russia, are better shielded from volatility. Major European airlines, however, are more dependent on international travel, placing them at risk of fallout from the Omicron variant.

site_title: Mourning and celebration mingle at the Fashion Awards in London
summary: The Fashion Awards in London featured a mix of mourning and celebration as attendees braved the cold weather. Model Jourdan Dunn and makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury were spotted on the red carpet for warmth. The event's attendees included Maria Sharapova, whose whereabouts were briefly queried by a producer. The evening's focus was on fashion, with the awards recognizing outstanding contributions to the industry.

site_title: 5G spectrum win a much-needed boost for TPG, but still an uphill battle for the telco
summary: TPG Telecom has been awarded 2.1 GHz spectrum for S$31 million, a provisional win that is a significant boost to the telco's 5G prospects. However, TPG still faces an uphill battle to catch up with market leaders Singtel and StarHub-M1, which have already rolled out standalone 5G services. The telco must deploy a new 5G network within 5 years, with standalone coverage of at least half the island by the end of 2022, and full nationwide coverage by 2025. Analysts predict TPG will need to spend more on network density, exacerbating earnings pressures, and question its viability in the Singapore market without a future-proof 5G licence.

site_title: M1 unit to acquire up to 70% stake in Malaysian ICT service provider
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, plans to acquire up to 70% stake in Malaysian ICT service provider Glocomp Systems and its affiliates for RM111 million (S$36 million). The deal will see Glocomp restructured as a subsidiary of M1's AsiaPac Technology. The acquisition marks M1's expansion into cloud services and is seen as a natural extension of its business. Glocomp's founders will retain 30% of the remaining stake.

site_title: US private firms hire 534,000 workers in November: ADP
summary: US private firms hired 534,000 workers in November, according to ADP, with the services sector adding 434,000 jobs. Goods-producing companies added 110,000 workers, including 50,000 in manufacturing. The labor market recovery has regained 15 million jobs since its start, but still lags five million jobs behind pre-pandemic levels. The hiring surge precedes expected official government data, but a new Covid-19 strain may impact job recovery in the coming months.

site_title: Livestock industry needs to do more on methane: investor group
summary: An investor group, FAIRR Initiative, warns that the livestock industry's weak efforts on methane emissions and deforestation may hinder global climate change mitigation efforts. Livestock accounts for 44% of man-made methane, and only a fifth of the world's largest livestock producers measure their emissions. The group assesses 60 animal protein producers, scoring some companies as "low risk" while others, like JBS and Tyson, are considered "medium risk" due to concerns over deforestation and animal welfare.

site_title: Shophouse market rounds off banner year - 217 transactions worth S$1.53b so far
summary: The Singapore shophouse market has had a record-breaking year with 217 transactions worth S$1.53 billion, surpassing the previous high of S$1.46 billion in 2018. The majority of buyers are from China, seeking capital appreciation, while rental yields have remained flat or declined due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Prices in prime areas such as Districts 1 and 2 have risen 15-20% this year, with some transactions reaching S$5,000 psf or higher. The market is expected to continue growing, with limited stock available for sale, but prices may face resistance due to interest rate hikes and concerns about loan support.

site_title: Renewable energy additions on track for record high in 2021: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a record high of 290 GW of renewable power capacity additions in 2021, with solar energy providing nearly half of the increase. By 2026, renewable electricity capacity is expected to reach 4,800 GW, accounting for nearly 95% of the global power capacity increase, surpassing fossil fuels and nuclear combined. The growth is driven by solar power, onshore wind, and hydroelectric power, with South-east Asia expected to see a 65% increase in renewable capacity over the next 5 years.

site_title: CPF top-ups hit new annual record of S$4b as at November 2021
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board reported a record S$4 billion in top-ups for 2021, with 127,000 first-time top-ups, doubling from last year. 1 in 2 of these first-timers is aged above 50. The full-year figure surpassed the previous record of S$3 billion in 2020.
